column1: Digital Fabrication: Student Art Exhibits
column5: Josh Ajima (Loudoun County Public Schools)
column6: What if a bunch of educators got together to share examples of digitally fabricated student art? What if those teachers collaborated to plan and execute student art exhibits that utilize technologies such as 3D printing, vinyl cutting, laser cutting, CNC, Scratch programs and physical computing devices? A combination of brainstorming session, art exhibit and collaborative art exhibitor planning meeting. Starter ideas include 3D printed Gumball Galleries, Interactive Art Synthesizers and vinyl graffiti art walls. Work together to create awesome opportunities for students to explore new media and technologies and express ideas involving art, history and culture.
column7: Digital fabrication empowers students to express themselves, their history and culture through art.
column8: Sharing of digital fabrication files empowers student collaboration on art exhibits for both local and global audiences.
column9: Student art featuring the medium of digital fabrication empowers students as connected members of technology rich communities.

column1: Empowering Student Literacy in the Digital Age
column5: Grant  Faulkner (rogers & cowan / booktrack), jason hovey (Booktrack)
column6: Today's students are constantly engaged with and distracted by technology. Trying to create meaningful learning experiences that compete with students' expectations and satisfaction with their own use of technology can be very difficult. At this panel, you will learn how to get students excited about reading and writing through fun and engaging projects that leverage music, writing communities, storytelling apps and peer feedback to create powerful student work. The focus will using available technology to ignite a passion for reading and writing, creating projects that further students' interest in the written word for authentic purposes and facilitating deeper discussions of student work.
column7: Discover beneficial technology platforms that will empower students through creativity and innovation.
column8: Explore what educational tools are available to students and how quantify quality solutions over distracting methods.
column9: Learn how to re-engage students in reading and writing through compelling exercises and mediums.

column1: Music in 2022
column5: Alan Cross (The Guild Agency)
column6: Alan Cross is an internationally known broadcaster, writer, blogger and speaker.In his 30 years in the music business, Alan has interviewed the biggest names in rock, from David Bowie and U2 to Pearl Jam and the Foo Fighters. Since 1993, he_s been the host of the radio documentary series The Ongoing History of New Music, which is heard across Canada and the US. He_s also written four reference books on alt-rock, recorded four audio books (all top-sellers on iTunes), written liner notes for dozens of CDs and contributed to magazines and other publications in Canada and the US.
column7: A look ahead to how we_ll enjoy our music ten years from now.
column8: To gain a greater perspective on the future of music.
column9: To gain a greater perspective on the history of music.

column1: Changing K-12 Spending: The 2% Solution
column5: Mary  Skipper (Somerville Public Schools), Greg Nadeau (Public Consulting Group)
column6: K-12 public schools in the U.S. spend $12,401 per student each year. What if we could transform public education for just 2% of that amount? Hear from Mary Skipper, Superintendent of a mid-sized urban school district in Boston, as she shares how she moved from traditional, industrial age processes of group instruction to new, vastly more effective teaching and learning models. We will engage you in an exploration of barriers in education and collaborate on ideas, strategies and solutions that we can implement in our schools tomorrow.
column7: Participants will learn about innovative ways to change the cost of educating students in the K-12 system
column8: Participants will collaborate on effective teaching and learning models that can be implemented in their own communities.
column9: Participants will receive best practices that will help make more efficient use of the limited financial resources provided to educate students.

column1: How Mastery-Based Learning Changes the Game
column5: Jeremy Kraushar (Mastery Collaborative, Office of Postsecondary Readiness, NYC Dept. of Education), Joy Nolan (Mastery Collaborative)
column6: NYC is home to a remarkable array of schools practicing competency-based (aka mastery-based) education (CBE). Members of the NYC-based Mastery Collaborative will discuss shortcomings inherent in traditional 0-100/A-F grading. We will offer details and resources from several distinct CBE models now in use with diverse students across the city, and will discuss how CBE levels the playing field via better alignment/continuity across grade levels, greater transparency, deepened shared understanding, increased student agency and metacognition.
column7: Participants will analyze the elements of traditional grading that negatively impact students (particularly struggling/under-served students).
column8: Participants will better understand how a community of mastery-based learning models in NYC provide meaningful and transparent feedback for students.
column9: Participants will consider how mastery-based/competency-based teaching and learning levels the playing field for diverse public-school students.

column1: How much is too much? Forum for Educator Feedback
column5: Kris Kaase (CCSSO), Scott Norton  (CCSSO)
column6: How do we achieve an appropriate balance of assessment in schools? How do we increase transparency of expectations for assessments? The Council of Chief State School Officers (CCSSO) is working with its members, state school chiefs, to address these questions. As state leaders of education, CCSSO wants to gather feedback from educators about the ways these efforts are working, having an impact, or can be improved. The goal is to engage educators and determine ways to bring their voice into this important issue.
column7: CCSSO will highlight key takeaways from its resource Ensuring Comprehensive Statewide Systems of High- Quality Assessments: A Framework for the Role
column8: Participants will provide feedback on effective ways to reduce testing and openly discuss the effect of efforts to reduce te
column9: CCSSO will use this _focus group_ feedback to provide information to school chiefs and leading district superintendents in order to support efforts

column1: Personalized Blended Learning
column5: Mariette  Fourmeaux du Sartel (Hewlett-Packard Company)
column6: Here_s a familiar story.  Textbooks become outdated and online materials offer convenient distraction portals. Educators are faced to decide which world is right for their students. This session equips the educator with tools to blend the best of the printed and digital worlds.  You will learn how to add interactive digital content to your education materials, without affecting appearance.  Bring your laptop because this is an immersive session and you are invited to create individualized learning materials that deliver: (1) Better learning outcomes by targeting students_ individual needs; and (2) Access to supplemental online materials from the printed page.
column7: Access better learning outcomes by targeting your students' individual needs.
column8: Provide real-time adaptive learning solutions to students right off of paper.
column9: Learn how to connect interactive digital content to your education materials while keeping the graphic freedom of your education materials.

column1: Save Teachers Time For What Matters: Instruction
column5: Aurora Martinez (Curriculum Associates), Woody Paik (Curriculum Associates)
column6: Assessments are an important tool in measuring concept mastery and student progress, but are they being used to drive instruction and ultimately benefiting the teacher and student? Are you over testing? Join this session to learn how you can assess less to know more about students, freeing up more time to teach and learn creatively. An experienced educator and thought leader will discuss assessments and how they can be used to achieve better instruction and greater student achievement.
column7: How teaching and learning can be informed by assessment data to customize learning pathways for every student
column8: Learn how to develop systems that minimize duplicate assessments, establish coherence and boost usefulness of data to inform teaching and learning
column9: Strategies for auditing current assessments and determining gaps in efficiency and data utilization

column1: Should our STEM notebooks go paperless?
column5: Melissa Wrenchey (Nikola Tesla STEM High School), Arny Leslie (Nikola Tesla STEM High School)
column6: In our STEM school, students are using journals as they take notes and then use these journals for review, test taking and information retention.  This year though we are trying something new:  What if students journaled electronically?  Using a cloud-based tool, students can journal in virtually the same way with some cool electronic tools like bookmarking and searching.
column7: Participants will compare electronic journals to paper journals.
column8: Participants will collaboratively evaluate student work from both electronic and hand-generated journals.
column9: Participants will evaluate the best tools for journaling and discuss some innovative applications with digital tools.

column1: Brain Training for Teens: Ratcheting Up Reasoning
column5: Lori Cook, Ph.D., CCC/SLP (Center for BrainHealth), Jacquelyn Gamino, Ph.D. (Center for BrainHealth)
column6: A scientifically validated program that teaches advanced reasoning strategies to middle school students is showing around 18% gains in fact recall and as much as 25% increases in the ability to convey meaning from text. The program, called Strategic Memory Advanced Reasoning Training (SMART), teaches students how to best learn, empowering critical thinking, reasoning, judgment, and decision-making. Learn how SMART, developed by cognitive neuroscientists and clinicians at the Center for BrainHealth, is improving academic performance and day-to-day life in the classroom and beyond for teens across the economic spectrum, at different levels of achievement, and even after brain injury.
column7: Learn why top-down teaching leverages the brain_s innate ability to change throughout life, especially during the critical teenage years.
column8: Understand how the training teachers model has helped to exponentially grow a scientifically validated brain training program across multiple states.
column9: Debunk the myths that a child_s education can only be saved before age 5 and that improving brain function more than a year post-injury is improbable.

column1: (Entrepreneurship) Mindset Matters
column5: Brandon Busteed (Gallup), Kim Smith (NFTE)
column6: Exploring the benefits of school age young people learning the entrepreneurial mindset. Recent research suggests that students who learn to think like entrepreneurs can do better in school and develop key employment skills for the jobs of the future.
column7: Entrepreneurship can teach important non-cognitive life skills such as creativity and determination.
column8: Entrepreneurship can help students do better in other academic subjects such as math and writing.
column9: Entrepreneurship can teach key workforce skills which will be in high demand in the coming job market.

column1: If They Ask It They Will Learn
column5: Chris Fancher (Meridian World School)
column6: A good teacher asks multiple questions throughout a class period as she formatively assesses her students knowledge. A great teacher will get a list of questions his students have about a topic and will create a plan - with the students - to get answers to these questions. And, this great teacher will encourage daily input of additional questions to be answered until everyone in the room feels that the topic has been appropriately addressed.Come experience this process as we generate questions to be answered by the attendees; we tackle the answers to these questions; and we create a plan to use this process in our classrooms.
column7: Understand the importance of pursuing student-generated questions about a topic as a way to go deeper with learning.
column8: Learn a process to help students create questions that become personal learning goals for that student.
column9: See how to take this questioning process and create a foundation for inquiry in your classroom.

column1: Specially Designed Instruction by Design
column5: Kathy Clayton (Ed21 Consulting Services), David Carrales (Ed21 Consulting Services)
column6: Specially designed instruction (SDI) is the linchpin of special education services. The implementation of SDI can be difficult to achieve especially in general education classrooms.  Participants will be introduced to the application of design thinking methodology and how it can effectively address the delivery of specially designed instruction to students with disabilities.  A case study will be presented to illustrate the use and value of this model in the K-12 educational environment.
column7: Understand Specially Designed Instruction
column8: Understand the basics and application of Design Thinking Methodology
column9: Understand the Value of the Use of Design Thinking in implementing services for students with disabilities

column1: Students as Global Entrepreneurs Thru 3 Big Pivots
column5: Yong Zhao (University of Oregon), Homa Tavangar (Growing Up Global)
column6: As follow-up to best-selling World Class Learners, a team of diverse educators collaborated to take this idea to implementation, exploring a radical approach: Students as global entrepreneurs. Instead of imposing a just-in-case, preparing-for-employment mindset, our research confirms we should cultivate creative, entrepreneurial thinkers: learners that are ALERT to possibilities. This calls for 3 key elements: student-driven learning that nurtures curiosity, strengths & passions; product-driven learning that solves real challenges for authentic audiences; and school as a global classroom where learning is expansive, responsive and collaborative. Join us to explore how to create these shifts.
column7: How can teaching pivot to allow entrepreneurial thinking to flourish by nurturing student-driven, self-directed learning?
column8: How to take project-based learning to the next step and spur product-oriented learning? How can product-oriented learning be applied to any topic?
column9: How can any classroom become a global classroom, and why does it matter?

column1: Thinking Like a Programmer: The Next Literacy
column5: Stacy Sniegowski (Mobile Makers Academy), Jessi Chartier (Mobile Makers Academy)
column6: Demand for software developers is skyrocketing, so new coding classes and bootcamps for teens and adults are answering the call. As more people learn valuable programming skills, can they improve success across disciplines and workplaces? Does learning to approach problems like a developer afford learners critical thinking skills, social and emotional competencies, and cutting-edge literacies? Join us in this core conversation as we use data and research to explore how things inherent to coding - iterative development, grit, resourcefulness, curiosity, problem solving, and adaptability - may improve motivation, academic progress, and life-long learning in both adolescents and adults.
column7: Review data and research findings to explore the usefulness of Agile project management in learning, regardless of area of study.
column8: Investigate how the problem-solving cycle of software development directly addresses the NCTE_s definition of 21st Century Literacies.
column9: Analyze how SEL skills fostered in software development - such as growth mindset and embracing failure -  can improve student success.

column1: Adult Literacy: The Untold Key to Economic Success
column5: Shlomy  Kattan (XPRIZE)
column6: 36 million adults in the U.S. lack basic literacy skills, as do millions more around the world. Adults who lack basic reading skills face reduced employment potential, hinder their children_s learning and slow our economy. Estimates show $225 billion in lost U.S. productivity and tax revenue, and $230 billion in added annual health care costs.Shlomy Kattan will highlight XPRIZE_s newest challenge to revolutionize adult learning, and help us imagine a future where low-literacy adults can download an app on their own mobile device, and in over the course of 12 months, see an increase in literacy skills across the board. Imagine: a paradigm shift in how we approach adult learning globally.
column7: 1.	Can we create mobile applications that will put learning tools in the hands of those who need them most, so learning can happen anytime, anywhere?
column8: 2.	What could the future look like with more than 30 million additional adults minds empowered to tackle the world_s grand challenges?
column9: 3.	How will the adult education industry change when we put learning tools directly in the hands of adult learners, allowing 24/7 access?

column1: Building a better corporate-academic partnership
column5: Karl McDonnell (Strayer Education, Inc.)
column6: Education and business must be linked in order to maintain America_s competitive edge. Karl McDonnell, CEO of Strayer Education, Inc., will discuss the why and how of effective corporate-academic partnerships and provide a peek into the inner workings of a national program that was recently reimagined to fit both employer and employee needs. In addition to workforce-integrated learning, he will discuss destigmatized vocational training, sub-degree tracks and other skills-based solutions. The goal is to spark a dialogue around education_s critical role in developing tomorrow_s talent.
column7: Describe how uniting higher education and business can help close the ever-widening skills gap in the United States.
column8: Identify accessible, relevant and tangible models for building better corporate-academic partnerships.
column9: Explain how free college degree programs are an example of work-integrated learning that benefits employees, employers, and the corporate ecosystem.

column1: How Online Ed Will Create a More Skilled Workforce
column5: Daphne Koller (Coursera)
column6: Access to education has come farther in the past four years than it has in the past 1,000 years. People around the world are now able to access the world_s best education, thanks to an internet connection and the efforts of many dedicated educators. Today, online education is reaching millions around the world, and is teaching much more than calculus; it_s giving rise to new data scientists and designers, entrepreneurs and business leaders for whom daily doses of on-demand online courses have opened new career possibilities. Hear from Coursera, the company that has pioneered this movement, about how open online education will create lifelong learners of us all.
column7: Learn how universities are using online platforms to help close skills gaps globally.
column8: Learn about the needs of online learners and how educators can evolve their offerings to satisfy new demands for education throughout a lifetime.
column9: Learn about the current research around the efficacy of online learning.

column1: Learning for the Job
column5: Kari Tarr (Airbnb), Zane Claes (Airbnb)
column6: Changing roles at a company often involves a self-directed learning process. At Airbnb, it_s common for people to teach themselves new things and move into different roles. We_ve even recently had our first-ever move into the engineering department (from Finance) by a self-taught programmer.The other speaker, Zane, has spent the last 10 years researching effective learning strategies and writing to help people make transitions just like these. Trying to self-manage a learning curriculum which will set you up for success in a new role can be a full-time task. This session will cover how to set up your own growth plan, find and evaluate learning resources, and ultimately land your new job.
column7: How to set up a personal learning plan
column8: How to find, evaluate and use the best learning resources
column9: How to use your new skills to change jobs, paths or careers

column1: Leveraging Digital Tools for Self-Directed PLCs/PD
column5: Jon Maxwell (Katy Independent School District)
column6: Join us for this empowering session to uncover a unique professional development structure to actively engage teachers and campus leadership for focused, individualized improvement via digital tools. Dynamic dialogues will be conducted to empower educators in overcoming the challenges of initiating change. Teacher driven PD combined with digital PLCs ensure that every school and teacher focus on their specific needs to provide unparalleled learning experiences. Through the use of online tools educators are able to share resources, information, and personal experiences to improve instruction and foster a community of sustainable professional development focused on student success.
column7: Educators will take away new practices and strategies, based on their data, to determine next steps & goals for immediate growth and sustained action.
column8: The digital opportunities will ignite participants to develop online professional learning communities, based on individual need and relevant data.
column9: The cyclical approach for PD will provide a road map for educators to follow, allowing them to synthesize data and develop a personalized action plan.

column1: Making Web Literacy the Fourth _R_ in Education
column5: Mark Surman (Mozilla Foundation)
column6: In today_s digital world, the ability to explore, create and connect online isn_t an inherent part of our education system. Web literacy is a critical skill that kids, and many adults, need to learn and sharpen _ they_re constantly online, using digital tools and devices to consume, but not to create. By 2025, almost 5 billion individuals will be online _ up from the 2.9 billion currently on the Web. If equipped with Web literacy education, these new Internet users could unlock tremendous social and economic opportunities. Mark will discuss the importance of Web literacy and explore examples.
column7: Inform people of the magnitude of the web literacy gap that exists today
column8: Provide an actionable approach to addressing it and highlight real-world examples of these learning tools in use
column9: Outline the social and economic impact of reducing web literacy

column1: Professional Development Online, Done Well!
column5: Nicole Dragisic (Region 18 Education Service Center), Leti Sandoval (Region 18 Education Service Center)
column6: Learn how to use a learning management system (LMS) to create easily digestible professional development (PD) pieces to address immediate needs. These highly accessible PD sessions can be completed during conference periods or breaks. Begin to engage the balance of communities around PD content areas that foster collaboration and PD requests.Review conscientious research around the utilization of an LMS with adult learners in compulsory and non-compulsory learning environments. Leverage marketing strategies in the delivery of learning objectives in a way that will critically connect with adult learners.
column7: Utilize the latest conscientious research to create effective professional development for educators within an LMS.
column8: Foster evangelist communities around PD topics.
column9: Appropriate a marketing mentality to ensure educators are implementing PD concepts within their classroom.

column1: Success with Microcredentialing in Maker Education
column5: Lisa Regalla (Maker Ed), Jessica Parker (Sonoma State University)
column6: Peer communities matter. With ever-increasing opportunities to engage in maker events and activities, micro-credentialing recognizes and validates a growing ecology of diverse professional learning opportunities that support peer-to-peer learning, a key tenant of maker education. This talk will engage participants in a discussion around the value of micro-credentialing within maker education and also share points of opportunity, such as access, equity, and partnerships, as well as discord within the Maker Movement. We will highlight the Maker Certificate Program at Sonoma State University and Maker Ed_s Make Corps program as examples micro-credentialing within informal learning.
column7: Gain a greater understanding of the opportunities and challenges of micro-credentialing within maker communities.
column8: Gain insight on how micro-credentials recognize and validate learning on multiple levels.
column9: Leave with ideas of potential partnerships to explore how micro-credentials could fit within your maker educator community.

column1: Teachers Need Personalized Learning Too
column5: Sebastian  Cognetta (Aveson Charter Schools), Kate Bean (Aveson Charter Schools)
column6: How can teachers be expected to personalize learning for students when their own learning is presented in a decades old model where everyone learns the same content, in the same room and at the same time? How can we expect them to deliver learning differently when they are not taught in a way that honors their individual strengths and challenges? This conversation will address current professional development models and provide a framework for developing personalized mastery learning experiences that will change educators_ mindset about their own learning, help them experience personalized mastery learning for themselves and be prepared to offer it to their students.
column7: Identify the mindset and processes required to shift classrooms, schools and teacher training to a more personalized learning experience for all.
column8: Study and discuss one school_s journey to ensuring Personalized Mastery Learning for students & Personalized Professional Development for educators.
column9: Explore components of Personalized Professional Development, identify individual goals & plans to personalize learning for themselves & their students

column1: The Past, Present & Future of Learning Exchange
column5: David Brake (LRNGO, INC.)
column6: In 1970, Denis Detzel returned to Chicago from Mexico after attending a series of educational seminars that took place at Ivan Illich's Center for Intercultural Documentation (CIDOC), and co-founded the Learning Exchange (TLE) with G. Robert Lewis at Northwestern University.  What happened next was a ten year odyssey of connecting people to teach and learn from each other that grew to 30,000 strong locally, and helped spawn a movement that grew to roughly 300,000 nationally.  The technology they used?  Hand-written 3x5 cards and a telephone.  Could there be a need for a movement like this today?
column7: Participants will be introduced to the learning exchange concept and history of the learning exchange movement.
column8: Participants will discuss benefits and challenges of scalable one-to-one learning systems in the context of bridging inequities in adult education.
column9: Participants will discuss the human dynamic & reciprocity of one-to-one learning, and whether people can improve as teachers & learners by practicing.

column1: The State of the University
column5: Jeffrey Selingo (Georgia Institute of Technology), Richard DeMillo (Georgia Institute of Technology)
column6: What_s broken in American universities and how can we save them? With college debt at an all-time high and record numbers of students looking for alternatives to the traditional experience, the long-established higher education system in American is in trouble. But what can educators and concerned parents do to save a system in sharp decline? Hear Rich DeMillo, the Director of Georgia Tech_s Center for 21st Century Universities, and Jeff Selingo, a journalist and author of College (Un)Bound, explore the state of today_s university and the ways that technology and education champions are turning the tide for higher education in America.
column7: Gain an understanding of the specific issues that are plaguing the American university system.
column8: Learn about the _band of innovators_ who are seeking alternatives to the traditional university experience.
column9: Explore a new vision for the future of American universities.

column1: Big Data in Education
column5: Jose Blackorby (SRI International), Martin Mckay (Texthelp)
column6: We live in the age of big data. Google anticipates what we want to search for while Amazon anticipates what we want to buy. Now, thanks to cloud based learning tools this information is becoming available in the world of education. This gives us access to how millions of students are using online tools and if they are making a difference. The speakers will discuss how big data is opening up a new world of research opportunities and what that means for educators, students and software developers in the not too distant future.
column7: Learn how big data is becoming part of the education market.
column8: Identify the types of data now available in education settings.
column9: Summarize how this new information can impact student performance and software development.

column1: Data detectives- the equation on school choice
column5: Elisabeth O'Bryan (GreatSchools.org), India Swearingen (GreatSchools.org)
column6: Choosing a school for a child is one of the most important decisions a parent can make. But what surprising things do families value when choosing the best school?ÿWe've learned a lot about what parents, teachers and school officials value most in a great school and would love to unearth mysteries including:1) The surprising things parents really value when it comes to choosing a school for their child.2) Why do school officials like to keep tabs on "competition"?3) Do people only write reviews when they are upset (hint: you'd be surprised)? Through analysis of web data, customer feedback and text analysis of school reviews, GreatSchools' sheds light on these mysteries.ÿ
column7: Participants will understand the reasons behind the decisions that families make about schools through data and analysis.
column8: Participants will understand how they can use this data to support their own admissions process.
column9: Participants will understand what's trending for parents and school searchers.

column1: Data Driven Instruction- Leaving Excel at Home
column5: John Ruff (ScribeSense), Kerry Gallagher (St. John's Preparatory Academy )
column6: If you_re an educator, you know the drill. You arrive at a faculty meeting only to discover the topic is data-driven analysis. You can feel your eyes glaze over and your brain switch into hibernation mode. But wait! Data is not a dirty word. Teachers have the power to gather, analyze, and inform instruction from data they create with their students in their classrooms. Rather than thinking of data as a giant spreadsheet sent down from state-mandated testing agencies, educators should feel empowered to use data to transform learning for the children they serve every day. If you_ve ever tried exit tickets, you_ve used data. Data-driven instructional planning can be easy, and we will show how.
column7: Teachers will be able to leave the session with at least 3-4 tools that they can take back to their classrooms and utilize to become data driven.
column8: Teachers will understand why using data in the classroom daily is important, and easier than they ever imagined.
column9: Administrators will understand what key components must be present for their end-users (teachers) when determining what tools to purchase.

column1: How Twitter is Changing The Politics of Education
column5: Alan Daly (UC San Diego), Jonathan Supovitz (Consortium for Policy Research in Education)
column6: The authors presents an interactive website in which they analyzed almost 200,000 tweets containing #commoncore over a key 6-month period of shifting public opinion in order to understand how twitter is influencing the politics of education. We start by examining the gigantic network of ~50,000 distinct tweeters using a social network perspective that emphasizes how peoples' twitter behavior groups them into distinct sub-communities.  We then hone in on the most influential actors, analyzing their tweet content and the language that they use to convey their messages. The talk concludes with a discussion of the changing role of media, social interactions, and education policy formation.
column7: How social media like Twitter are changing the debate around education policies that influence the policy making.
column8: Ways in which we can analyze Twitter from a multi-dimensional perspective.
column9: The importance of taking a social perspective when examining education reform activities.

column1: The Big Bang Theory of Student Data Impact
column5: Kelly Calhoun (Gartner)
column6: The universe of K12 student educational data has exploded in size and complexity, as new demands come into play.  Student information systems, learning management systems, instructional management systems _ definitions are in flux, and CIOs are faced with building an ecosystem that makes sense for a future of personalized learning and adaptive technologies.  A new, broader view of the student data universe is needed to help develop those strategies of the future.
column7: Audience will gain insight into the future directions of student data and how to strategize for that
column8: Audience will gain insight into potential new learning technologies and how they might fit in this new data environment
column9: Audience will gain insight into the growing significance of analytics in education, and how this will shape the data demands of the future.

column1: Using Data to Improve Education Outcomes
column5: Jessica  Wodatch  (Two Rivers Public Charter School), Scott  Pearson  (DC Public Charter School Board )
column6: PCSB and DC Public Charter Schools are _trend-setters_ in the field of educational data collection and information management. The Board and the schools have worked hard to set up systems of data collection that allow for easy public access to information about the DC education system, improved data analysis and information gathering for school programs, as well as for overall improved systems management for each school campus and the board.
column7: Provide the audience with examples of these new systems and feedback on how to implement them in their own schools/businesses.
column8: Provide the audience with the skills needed to analyze data.
column9: Provide the audience with tools that they can use to convert these skills to all aspects of their professional life.

column1: Using data to improve school climate
column5: Lorna Hermosura (edMosphere)
column6: Research shows that a positive school climate is related to higher student attendance, higher student motivation, improved academic achievement and fewer disciplinary problems. School climate is dynamic. It differs from day to day and from one student to another. But most school climate measurement tools are administered just once per year and to a random sampling of students. This workshop will demonstrate the value of using real-time technology to regularly connect with every student on how they experience school.
column7: Attendees will learn how about edMosphere, a real-time technology tool that engages every student around school climate issues.
column8: Attendees will hear how a teacher and a principal implemented edMosphere to improve school climate and student outcomes.
column9: Attendees will learn about the benefits of using real-time technology to proactively address student needs.

column1: What the Pell? New Data on Pell Grad Rates
column5: Lynn Jennings (The Education Trust), Andrew Nichols (The Education Trust)
column6: For the first time ever, data on the college completion outcomes for students who receive a Pell Grant have been compiled for roughly 1,200 institutions across the United States.This groundbreaking report presents hard-edge data on why improving college outcomes for low-income students is critically important for our nation_s health and economic mobility. Researchers from The Education Trust will present the data, including case studies of specific institutions, and recommend policy changes that can help improve outcomes for low-income students.
column7: Understanding of the new data, its utility and limitations
column8: Meaningful discussion of the state of higher education outcomes for low-income students
column9: Policy recommendations to improve collection and access of Pell Grant student outcomes to better inform future policy debates

column1: Yelp as a Platform for Open Data
column5: Susan DeVore (Premier, Inc.), Luther Lowe (Yelp)
column6: Open government has made data more available, but it_s still hard to find this information. What happens when the sites people already use, like Yelp, ingest public data and make it more discoverable? Consumers have more info, businesses are held more accountable, and everybody wins. Yelp data can also make governments smarter, help businesses and industries improve, and positively impact economies. From sharing medical statistics and Department of Education data to tracing foodborne illness, there_s huge potential for good through more open data.
column7: To show why open data is more effective by putting information in places consumers are already searching for it online.
column8: To understand how insights from companies like Yelp can be used to improve local economies and fuel research into consumer behavior.
column9: To understand the impact on businesses of making public information like restaurant health scores and ER wait times easy to find online.

column1: A creative approach to school readiness
column5: Alison Masutani (Partners in Development Foundation), Kristine Van Vonderen (YCMA of the USA)
column6: Partners in Development and the YMCA collaborated to use the PIDF research based Tutu and Me Traveling Preschool to YMCAs across the country using a simple and sustainable program model aimed at low income and newcomer populations. The two-pronged approach helps informal caregivers understand how they can support school readiness in the home environment and prepares children birth to five for kindergarten using interactive interest centers that children and adults particpate in together. The program uses nationally recognised evaluation models to track outcomes and has a long track record of proven success in both cognitive and social-emotional readiness outcomes.
column7: Understand the innovative approach to ensure low income and newcomer populations succeed in school while honoring their cultural heritage.
column8: Learn how research and evalution support learning goals and help track outcomes, using recognized national models.
column9: Discover how adaptations based on local community needs can be effectively used while maintaining program fidelity.
column10: family friend and neighbor care, kindergarten readiness

column1: Common Core 2.0!  What teachers want CCSS to be!
column5: kurt schwengel (Franklin School)
column6: I would like to lead a fun and exciting discussion about what the CCSS would look like if it were actually created BY CLASSROOM TEACHERS!  We have all read the common core standards and most of us teachers shake our head at them.  Let's create a new set of standards for the elementary school level (pre-k thru 5th grade)
column7: review (and laugh at) the existing common core standards
column8: create NEW common core standards
column9: figure out a way to change the CCSS to reflect what teachers actually want!

column1: Deeper Learning: Lessons from Early Childhood
column5: Karen Walker (Dallas Association for the Education of Young Children), Josh Thompson (Texas A&M University-Commerce)
column6: Transformation in education is upon us. Children learning in 21st Century classrooms and schools need innovators and intellectual thought leaders to accompany them on their journey of inquiry, not technocrats or test prep. Infusing deeper learning into lessons and activities requires flexible teachers, full of insight into student learning, human development, and the powers of language and literacies to create learners competent to inquire, investigate, and innovate. These characteristics exemplify Early Childhood educators. We've been following the child for more than a century. It makes one wonder: What deeper learning occurs when school innovation takes lessons from Early Childhood?
column7: Explore child centered principles of early learning (Montessori, Reggio, developmentally appropriate practice, family regard, language acquisition)
column8: Identify possible terms to rename/reframe Early Learning to better capture the powerful opportunity to transform all of education: del Jardin
column9: Align principles of early learning with robust transformation efforts (Deeper Learning, Expeditionary Learning, Challenge-based, Character Education)

column1: Using Neuroscience to Better Reach Early Learners
column5: Manjari Patel (MIND Research Institute), Monae Gascon (MIND Research Institute)
column6: Interested in introducing young learners to mathematics in a way that builds the critical thinkers and problem solvers of tomorrow? A better understanding of the science of learning can support the development of the persistence needed to tackle tough challenges and the curiosity to find solutions in unique ways. Discover how young students learn math concepts through songs, chants, software, and hands-on activities.
column7: A better understanding of how early learners process information.
column8: How to engage early learners in order to build inquisitive and dedicated math students.
column9: Discover what blended learning actually looks like in the early years.

column1: Activism in Education
column5: Naomi Shelton (UNCF), Chris Stewart (Education Post)
column6: An emerging wave of education reform organizations are working to pull students, parents, and community leaders into larger policy debates around school reform and mobilize them to lobby policymakers, testify in front of school boards, & vote for candidates. Involvement among parents & community leaders is crucial to pushing education reform forward.  During the session we will engage in dialogue that will provide some major takeaways that can be applied on the ground in communities to foster vibrant networks, highlight policy victories, &  help to support and demonstrate why their issues matter.
column7: Provide information  that can be applied on the ground in communities to foster vibrant networks
column8: Learn how to engage student parents around community advocacy
column9: Learn valuable reform strategies from education activists

column1: After School Learning: Opportunity for Impact
column5: Klara Crean (Boys & Girls Clubs of Sonoma Valley)
column6: Learning happens not only in schools, but also after school and during summer. A lot of low income students lack access to enrichment opportunities that are available to middle income students. Frequently, these are important experiences that make a difference for achievement and success, both in school and life. In this session, we will discuss how schools and community non-profits can collaborate to provide innovative after school and summer programs for low income students in order to promote learning and help close the opportunity gap.
column7: Examine conditions for successful collaboration between public schools and youth-focused community organizations
column8: Discuss opportunities and challenges in designing innovative programs with limited resources
column9: Share specific examples of innovative programs designed to promote engagement and learning

column1: American Grit: A docudrama on student experiences
column5: Brooke Haycock (The Education Trust)
column6: Weaving data with narrative from more than 300 interviews with youth, educators, and industry leaders, American Grit whips into a fever pitch a 100-year-old debate about the role of secondary schools in America and what _ and whose _ children need to succeed. Follow cousins Deja and Darnell from high school deep into post-industrial America as their experiences expose the fault lines in the rhetoric of college and career readiness _for all_ that swallow too many students and shake the very foundation of American prosperity. After, attendees will be invited into a conversation on how to use the narrative to spark discussions on college and career readiness in schools and communities.
column7: Provide participants with insight into the experiences of students and the rift between the rhetoric of college and career readiness and reality.
column8: Expose participants to a unique form of advocacy through stories mixed with data, and invite conversation on critical issues.
column9: Leave with additional resources on issues related to educational equity and college and career readiness.

column1: Arrested Development v. Parental Partners
column5: La Dailey (University of NV, Reno)
column6: This is a core conversation about the parents' roles in the education process and what happens when relationships sour.More than that, it is a conversation about organizational change and the possibility of moving forward with child centered education.The conversation facilitator, a parent and an educator, has been arrested for trying to attend a school board meeting.  Investigations have found his child's school district out of compliance with more than 20 state and federal regulations. A human centered would provide a more positive path. This conversation will explore how parents and educators might better work together. And how both might actually have fun in the process.
column7: Attendees will be able to articulate basic principles of child centered education.
column8: Attendees will participate in brainstorming child centered alternatives methods of working with parents
column9: Attendees will be able to articulate why parental relationships sometimes deteriorate into negative confrontation.

column1: Build Digital Profiles from Graduation Portfolios
column5: Azadeh Noorbaloochi (Chariho Regional District ), Craig MacKenzie (Chariho Regional High School)
column6: This presentation proposes the idea of using graduation expectations, particularly those embedded in high school graduation portfolios, to help students build a digital profile to promote their college and career readiness.  Through connecting their experience to portfolio expectations, high school students graduate with a living, electronic document that provides multi-media evidence of their readiness to succeed in their post-secondary experience.  This Digital Profile is the product of a 1:1 learning experience grounded in blended learning strategies at Chariho Regional High School.
column7: Provide schools a strategy for adding value and meaning to their graduation portfolio by providing students opportunities build a digital profile.
column8: Provide students with a resource to promote their expertise and readiness through creative and personalized use of technology.
column9: Provide schools with a vehicle for reinforcing 21st Century Skills and tangible evidence of learning.

column1: Building a Community of Trust in Education
column5: Senchel Matthews (Achievement School District), L. Arthi Krishnaswami (RyeCatcher Education PBC)
column6: Education never rests. Streets, buses and stores are all classrooms. Neighbors, coaches, and siblings are all teachers. A holistic education supports the whole child_academics, behavior, social and emotional learning, and health and wellness_in school, at home, and in the community. RyeCatcher and the Achievement School District, Memphis, TN are building a digital _Community of Trust_, that brings together parents and families, support teams, in-school staff, and community caregivers. In this session, panelists will discuss the pilot, and how they use Rye to draft action plans, goals and interventions to implement in the classroom, and at home for students.
column7: This panel will describe "A Community of Trust in Education"--the stakeholders, their relationships, data collected, and privacy expectations.
column8: Understand the benefits of bringing together parents, families, schools, and communities in the student learning process in at-risk environments.
column9: The panel will explore the user-centered design and development process of an education technology platform through the example of the ASD and Rye.

column1: Building Education Cities - A How To Guide
column5: Chris Meyer (New Schools for Baton Rouge), Butch Trusty (Education Cities)
column6: Everyone has a role when it comes to building an education city - government agencies, school districts, nonprofits, educator training programs, community coalitions, principals, teachers. If only there was one organization that could harness this collective power, set an ambitious goal, and direct resources to ensure that every child in your city has access to a great school! The good news is these organizations - called harbormasters - do exist in cities across the country, and are making a huge impact. Let_s talk about if a harbormaster can help your city, the pros and cons of establishing a harbormaster organization, and how to get involved.
column7: Identify the characteristics that harbormasters across the country have in common.
column8: Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of the harbormaster approach.
column9: List the steps that can be taken to establish or get involved with a harbormaster organization in your city.

column1: D to the E: A "Car-Talk" for the Education Sector
column5: Dennis  Littky (Big Picture Learning), Elliot Washor (Big Picture Learning)
column6: Through knowledge, humor, and a little spice, Tom and Ray Magliozzi_s Car Talk defined the genre of making a less than comfortable topic approachable. Elliot Washor and Dennis Littky are ready to do the same for education. Washor and Littky, founders of Big Picture Learning, have never minced words about their vision for a more perfect, student-centered, public education system. Pick this podcast-esque discussion about what ails education and why the future is bright.
column7: Create an interactive discussion (one that mirrors effective classroom teaching and learning practices) between panel and audience.
column8: Audience members will learn from Washor and Littky_s 30+ year attempt to impact education reform; often successfully, sometimes not.
column9: Panelists themselves will learn. Audience questions and opinions will be what keeps the constantly evolving education reform discussion pool fresh.

column1: Edtech: The New Frontier
column5: Marlene Limon (Educandi LLC)
column6: In today's digital world, learning and the art of teaching takes on a whole new perspective as administrators, educators and families struggle to understand the importance of technology and education and more importantly, attempting to effectively implement various edtech resources/tools. Edtech is a rather new and emerging field which tackles common issues and concerns when trying to bridge the two separate frontiers of technology and education. In this session, participants will learn what edtech encompasses, how edtech pertains to education and what edtech resources are available within a community. Edtech is the new frontier. Are you ready to boldly go where no one has gone before?
column7: Participants will learn what edtech is and encompasses.
column8: Participants will learn how edtech relates to education.
column9: Participants will learn of edtech resources within a community at all levels (local, state, federal).

column1: Furthering Fair Schools through Fair Housing
column5: LeighAnn Smith (The George Washington University)
column6: Housing Policy = Education Policy. The logic behind this equation begins with an uncontroversial proposition: our K-12 schools primarily enroll students from the neighborhoods surrounding the building itself. Yet this uncontroversial proposition causes controversial problems. As many neighborhoods are comprised of members of the same race and social class, so too do our schools and classrooms become representative of divisions along these lines. However, a new rule from the Department of Housing & Urban Development offers an opportunity to address these challenges together, through the lens of both housing and education policies: to affirmatively further fair schools through fair housing.
column7: Analyze the relationship between school performance and neighborhood socioeconomic status.
column8: Summarize the new Affirmatively Furthering Fair Housing rule from the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and its use of education data.
column9: Collaboratively discuss the variety of roles for stakeholders to actively participate in furthering fair schools through fair housing policy.

column1: How to Choose The Right Online Course
column5: Pam Wells (Region 4 Education Service Center), Jana Jamail (Proximity Learning Inc)
column6: Deciding what type of online course is extremely important for each district and with so many options and jargon it is difficult to decide what program is best. We would like to discuss the different options and the top three styles of online learning that are best for students from all different learning requirements. Every students deserves a chance to learn what they want in a way that best fits their needs.
column7: Identifying different types of online courses
column8: What are the top three online programs for students
column9: How to implement the program that fits your needs

column1: Intrusive Innovations for College Success
column5: Ford Roosevelt (Project GRAD Los Angeles), Kate Stephenson (California State University Northridge)
column6: While college going among low-income, first generation students has increased in recent years, their post-secondary attainment rates have remained stagnant. Policymakers and educators have proposed several approaches for tackling this national challenge _ increased FAFSA completion, college counseling, academic rigor, near-peer mentoring, SEL, tighter K-12 and higher education alignment, and teacher professional development. One program in the second largest public school district in the nation has put ALL of those pieces together for bolstering college readiness and success. This program is showing promising outcomes for 800 students in a high-need, low-income corner of Los Angeles.
column7: Discuss a replicable model for cross-sector _ Non-profit, K-12, Higher Ed Institution _ collaboration that increases student success (grade 9 _ 16).
column8: Critically assess SEL as it specifically relates to the persistence barriers first generation and low-income students face.
column9: Examine evolving best practices and conventional wisdom _ from college access paradigms to the college success imperative.

column1: Let's crush the school to prison pipeline
column5: Jobi Cates (NACSA)
column6: You can't turn on the news or look at your Facebook without reading another tragic story about teens getting lost and either ending up a casualty of gun violence or mass incarceration.  There is a burgeoning movement around ending the "School to Prison Pipeline,"  but it is not yet large or powerful enough to stem the tide of kids getting swept away.  How can teachers, schools, districts and cities cut across traditional boundaries to keep kids from entering the School to Prison Pipeline?  It is easy to say, "that is someone else's problem," but the impact of mass incarceration impacts all of us.  In a cross-profession setting, we will work to determine how best to crush the STPP.
column7: Discover how all of our actions can either feed or close the School to Prison Pipeline, particularly school discipline policies and practices
column8: Uncover creative ways to work across traditional professional boundaries by meeting others who care about the "kids in the back of the class"
column9: Learn about models and movements that are springing up across the nation, taking away real-life examples that you can use

column1: Letting ELs in on it: Dynamic math for all!
column5: Philip Vahey (SRI International), Savitha Moorthy (SRI International)
column6: While many naively believe that math is a universal language that allows all students to access curriculum content, statistics show that English Learners are at a shocking disadvantage for math achievement. While _typical_ ways of teaching put English Learners at a disadvantage, dynamic representations offer the opportunity to disrupt the status quo. We will show how dynamic representations allow all learners, including English Learners, to access sophisticated math content and a higher quality learning experience than other methods.
column7: Attendees will learn about best practices in educational technology use when designing for all learners, including English Language Learners.
column8: Attendees will come away with an appreciation for the design of environments that can help all students learn complex math.
column9: Attendees will learn how research on basic cognitive functions informs how dynamic representation use can benefit all learners.

column1: Raising Access and Creating Equity in Education
column5: Alicia Perez (King-Chavez Community High School), Megan McCrary (King-Chavez Community High School)
column6: This conversation is about increasing access to instruction, skills, and experiences to promote equity in education and prepare students for the demands of a 21st Century school or workplace while also empowering them as members of a learning community, regardless of their circumstances-past or present. The conversation is about doing this in partnership with other professionals, parents, the larger community, schools, and organizations.
column7: Attendees will discuss and evaluate current access and equity in traditional education.
column8: Attendees will discuss and evaluate blended learning and project based learning as a means of increasing access to and promoting equity in education.
column9: Attendees will discuss and evaluate (hopefully apply) various learning strategies to try in their classrooms and develop a broader learning community.

column1: Rewriting the Story of Education in America
column5: Clint Smith (Harvard GSE), Austin Dannhaus (Free Range)
column6: Education in America is stuck between two competing narratives. These stories transcend party and class lines. They are stories that alternatively fight for or fight against the status quo. One says "keep doing what we're doing, just do it better." The other says "Let's rethink everything."As these contrasting visions of what education ought to look like continue to clash, students - especially students of color - will get caught in the middle. How do we honor our past as we build a better tomorrow?Join two educators - one a world-class poet and advocate, the other an entrepreneur - as they explore, through dialogue and spoken-word, a new narrative of opportunity through education.
column7: Understand the elements of effective storytelling and how it shapes what we believe about education in America.
column8: Understand the two dominant narratives about American education and ways they might be reconciled to create more opportunity for all children.
column9: Work together to develop a new understanding of the role of education in America and corresponding micro-stories to inform our advocacy.

column1: STEAM Inspired Girl Education
column5: Rayna Yaker (RYE Consulting), Shalini Patel (Inspire Girls Academy)
column6: Inspire Girls Academy is an independent PreK-8 based in Chicago. We are inspired to teach young scholars to challenge societal norms around STEAM, and prepare them to focus their passion and work toward impacting their communities and the world.Our curriculum focuses on building girls_ confidence so they can break boundaries, cultivate leadership skills, inspire success, and take risks. The importance of Arts in STEM, single gender education and holistic learning will be the key learning objectives discussed in an open conversation with educators and innovators.
column7: How Integrating Arts curriculum into STEM enables children to use both sides of their brain when problems solving and engaging the world around them.
column8: How girls in single gender education are more likely to take healthy risks and 6 times more likely to consider jobs in math, science, and technology.
column9: Education with a holistic perspective the development of every child_s intellectual, emotional, social, physical, artistic, and creative potential.

column1: Storytelling: The Key to Diversity in Education
column5: Virginia Cumberbatch (The University of Texas' Division of Diversity and Community Engagement)
column6: The University of Texas at Austin's decision to integrate its campus in 1950 is a part of a national narrative being documented and shared today through the "As We Saw It project." The As We Saw It project serves a blue print for using authentic storytelling to cultivate critical dialogue around diversity and inclusion at a time where college campuses and city streets experience racial hostility. This session will explore the branding tools and communication practices institutions of higher learning need to utilize to make their campuses more welcoming spaces for students from traditionally marginalized groups. Attendees will be exposed to key strategies and current and innovative projects.
column7: Educate attendees on effective storytelling and branding practices that attract a more diverse institutional community.
column8: Expand multi-cultural marketing practices beyond series of broad-stroke campaigns, into ongoing conversations across niche and mainstream channels.
column9: Expose attendees to the emerging interactive tools, platforms, and media spaces that support nuanced campaigns.

column1: The Call for Diversity in Technology and Education
column5: Jaime Casap (www.google.com/edu)
column6: Only 1 in 14 tech folks in Silicon Valley is Black/Latino. In all, less than 5% of the teams at Google, Facebook, Yahoo are Black/Latino. This isn_t just an issue with old tech companies; less than 2% of startup founders are Black or Latino. Only 13% of STEM degrees are held by Black or Latino workers. By 2020, the United States will have 1.4 million computer science jobs, according to estimates by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, with only 400,000 computer scientists to fill them. By the year 2043, the United States will be a majority-minority country. The need for diversity in tech is not an altruistic matter. Orgs who will endure are the ones who understand how diversity helps them.
column7: Understand the current situation of the lack of diversity in technology
column8: Develop strategies to help students of color become interested in computer science and other STEM fields.
column9: Highlight programs which educators can look at and implement in their schools today.

column1: Top Schools Close Gaps and Raise Achievement
column5: Karin Chenoweth (The Education Trust)
column6: Drawing on more than a decade of work by The Education Trust, writer-in-residence Karin Chenoweth shares the stories of high-performing schools that are doing the impossible _ or so many people think. These schools are educating large populations of children of color and children from low-income families to the highest levels of academic achievement.Take a whirlwind tour of a few schools from all over the country, through video interviews and lots of photos of their brilliant and energetic students, and hear how they get the results they get. (Hint: The adults in the buildings know the kids are capable of learning; it_s up to them to figure out how to teach.)
column7: A clear idea that the work of educating all children is possible
column8: Leave with at least some idea of how the work of educating all children can be done
column9: And empowered with additional resources to advocate for change in their schools and communities

column1: Two Americas Two Educations
column5: Paul Cummins (Coalition for Engaged Education)
column6: There is a great deal of discussion in the general press about the great divide in America between the so-called 1% and the "others." The haves and have nots. But there is a far too little discussion of the disastrous impact of this disparity in our public schools. Some young people receive every advantage while many receive only neglect and deprivation. By looking at school A (per pupil spending of $35,00 a year) and school B (public schools in a major U.S. city per pupil spending of $8,200) - we can see dramatic differences.
column7: To see clearly how the lack of funding plays out in many low income schools across the country.
column8: To learn what quality education includes - in curriculum - and what it costs.
column9: To see how inadequate funding need not be and how a shift in priorities could lead to a quality education for all children and youth.

column1: 21st Century Skills: what do employers care about?
column5: David Jaffa (Jaffa Foundation), Patricia Perlman-Dee (Manchester Business School)
column6: Employers complain that first jobbers have academic knowledge but lack practical work-ready skills. But what 21st century skills are genuinely valued by employers in a globalizing economy? How can we teach and certify these skills? And how can the education system keep up with the changing needs of the workplace?This session will present new in-depth research by Manchester Business School, UK into the key skills gaps among first jobbers identified by the Heads of Graduate Recruitment at 20 leading global corporations.The workshop format will invite participants to join and lead the conversation on how we can prepare a new generation for the workplace of tomorrow.
column7: Learn what 21st century skills are genuinely most valued by employers in a globalizing economy?
column8: Find out how can these skills be taught and certified?
column9: Find out how we can keep up with the changing needs of the workplace?

column1: Benefits of involving teachers in Ed Tech dev
column5: Elena Balint  (AFT)
column6: Educational Technology, while exciting and burgeoning, often times run into implementation barriers. One reason is that development and implementation does not include the community it should serve:  teachers, parents and even students. Sharemylesson.com, a site that provides materials to all educators and parents, with close to 1 Million users, is a recognized leader in the resource sharing industry. Find out from CMO Elena Balint, how and why SML infuses community  - causes and people - into their work to build a stronger and more effective educational resource for all.
column7: Learn how to be most effective in the community and the classroom
column8: How to make an impact with community schools
column9: Identify opportunities for teacher collaboration and engagement
column13: Educational Technology, while exciting and burgeoning, often times run into implementation barriers. One reason is that development and implementation does not include the community it should serve:  teachers, parents and even students. Sharemylesson.com, a site that provides materials to all educators and parents, with close to 1 Million users, is a recognized leader in the resource sharing industry. Find out from CMO Elena Balint, how and why SML infuses community  - causes and people - into their work to build a stronger and better product.

column1: Drawing Out Purpose Through Portfolios & Projects
column5: Chris Forster (Noble Impact), Chad Williamson (Noble Impact)
column6: America's education system is experiencing a crisis of relevancy. Students are asked to sit and consume content without clarity on the purpose of their education and the lessons delivered to them.Within the Noble Impact classroom, though, we ask students to produce relevant and meaningful content and experiences based on their values, passions, and personal stories. Students build digital portfolios and use them as a means for collaborating on and communicating about projects that are in line with what they care about.In this session, we'll share stories of how middle and high school students in the Noble Impact program used their digital portfolios to find purpose in their work.
column7: Learn how project-based learning paired with digital student portfolios can infuse purpose and relevancy into the classroom
column8: Understand which tools are available for implementing digital student portfolios within your school and/or classroom
column9: Grasp the impact that would be possible if all students were networked to scholars everywhere through their portfolios

column1: Edtech World Tour : Building Ecosystems
column5: Svenia Busson (Edtech World Tour), Audrey Jarre (Edtech World Tour)
column6: The EdTech World Tour is a 5-month research project through six countries to research on EdTech adoption around the globe. Our aim is to take into account how different elements of the system interact through dialogue with industry leaders, startups, policy makers, educators and students. To examine learning technology across a differentiated world that can grow to meet the various continent's learning needs of tomorrow and learn what sort of EdTech ecosystem is being built by thinkers and what values it reflects.With this panel, we want to shed light on our main findings across the countries we visited: France, Germany, UK, US, Chile, South Africa, Australia, South Korea & India.
column7: How can we bridge the gap between the realms of education and technologies through interaction with both worlds?
column8: EdTech does not have equal opportunity of adoption in the world - what can be done and who has a key role to play?
column9: What makes a community around edtech and helps building a powerful ecosystem in a given space, city, country?

column1: Hacking High School
column5: Ed Jones (CreditFlexibility.org)
column6: What if teens could learn what most interests them? Learn how and when they most need to; where, and from whom they can best succeed? Imagine if innovative teachers could reach teens as individuals, not in groups geographically and time-slot assigned.It's not only possible, it's been done by thousands.In a future where teens access far more innovative, community-connected learning, what might school look, feel, and sound like? If such innovation were given room to iterate and excel?The forthcoming book, Hacking High School details this future.It invites teens to accept this challenge, change the landscape of the American high school, and blaze a new path for those to follow.
column7: What, where, and how might students learn most, given access to new highly-rigorous, student-driven learning options?
column8: What if 40,000 students tried this? Then 400,000?
column9: What cultures, resources, and mechanics are needed to make this a viable, rigorous, creative set of choices?

column1: How to Build an EdTech Product that Doesn_t Suck
column5: Charlie Coglianese (Schoolrunner), Nicole Brenner (Collegiate Academies)
column6: Imagine the amount of time, energy, and money wasted by edtech companies who build a product only to find it solves a problem that doesn_t exist. In this session, Schoolrunner Founder and CEO Charlie Coglianese shares how he partnered with Nicole Brenner from Sci Academy in New Orleans to find the right problem and build the software to solve it.
column7: How to do customer discovery the right way in education
column8: How to establish a fast iteration processes
column9: How to build a team that aligns to the problem you_re trying to solve

column1: Ignite Success through Entrepreneurial Learning
column5: Edgardo Irizarry (Instituci¢n Educativa NETS), Susan Maher (Instituci¢n Educativa NETS)
column6: The Department of Education has stated_ _All students deserve a world-class, well rounded education...and entrepreneurship is an integral aspect of this complete education as we meet the goal of ensuring that all students graduate _ ready for college and career success_.  This is an area of opportunity in which experiential entrepreneurial learning validates education as the pathway to the attainment of professional goals and plays a significant role in breaking the grip of poverty.  Entrepreneurial learning gives students access to knowledge and relevant skills that improve their self-efficacy and effectiveness, and the intellectual and affective resources to overcome barriers they face.
column7: Learn how entrepreneurial learning engage students and validate their academic journey as it relates to college and career opportunities.
column8: Explore how students learn to recognize overlooked opportunities and gain improved self-esteem, knowledge, and insight to act instead of hesitate.
column9: Discover how to ignite our youth to become active participants in the development of innovative solutions relevant to their communities.

column1: Intuition: The Invisible, Untapped Resource
column5: Earamichia  Brown  (State of NY Office of State Inspector General ), Stacy Berman (The System by Stacy)
column6: When it comes to making big decisions about your business and life; reason and logic will only take you so far. Many of the greatest successes come down to a gut feeling or an intuition. What is this mystical power? Why is it so easy for some to harness and use? Follow Stacy Berman the modern day mystic as she walks entrepreneurs, startups and ambitious daydreamers through a series of experiences and case studies that will put the mystical powers of intuition into a language to understand and use.
column7: Cultivate your intuition.
column8: Learn the language of your intuition.
column9: Syncing the mind and heart to tap into your intuitive intelligence.

column1: Maker Ed + Youth Entrepreneurship =  Opportunity
column5: Nate Stell (The Possible Project), David Seller (The Possible Project)
column6: The Possible Project is an afterschool entrepreneurship program that teaches high school students to start and run their own businesses. We partnered with our local public housing authority and a leading biotech company to launch a Makerspace in the heart of a public housing development located next to Cambridge's thriving innovation economy. We are building paths for low-income youth into the 21st century economy through the following: 1) Hard tech and design training that students use to create products to take to market, 2) Partnerships with local businesses for paid real-world design and business operations projects; 3) Industry mentors who hone students_ skills and grow their networks.
column7: Learn how youth entrepreneurship provides a clear focus to approaching maker education: to create a design or product with market potential.
column8: Share how paid real-world projects with startup and established tech/biotech companies can intensify students_ learning experience and motivation.
column9: Identify other possibilities at the intersection of maker ed and entrepreneurship, and discuss this strategy_s limits for youth/career development.

column1: Re-imagining a Static Legacy Industry
column5: David Mandell (PivotDesk)
column6: Traditional industries are the way of the past with emerging technologies and companies seeking to disrupt a rigid space. How can businesses tap into what makes an industry successful and apply new learnings to transform old school concepts? What can we learn from other startups who have innovated a space that seemed static? This discussion will give an in-depth look at how we can use traditional concepts, technology and creative thinking to shift the direction of legacy industries.
column7: What makes an industry traditional and/or static?
column8: How can startups strategically use technology to become thought leaders within a space?
column9: Discuss how old business models and industries can be influenced by innovation

column1: Teachers as Entrepreneurs: Making the Leap
column5: John Raymond (ImpactLab), Dar Vanderbeck (Teach For America)
column6: Today_s teachers demand more pathways for their personal and professional growth. Some brave souls take the plunge and become entrepreneurs, forwarding their vision of what education could be or solving a persistent problem. This inclusive, guided conversation is designed for teachers considering this route. We will steer the group through different aspects of this shift - from personal (e.g. health) to professional (e.g. becoming your own boss) - while the conversation itself will be driven by attendees sharing their visions and asking questions. To enrich the experience, a diverse set of early-stage edupreneurs will be on hand to answer questions about realities they face each day.
column7: Help participants better understand what is involved in becoming an entrepreneur through sharing and exposure to real stories by real entrepreneurs.
column8: Introduce participants to the growing community of education entrepreneurship practitioners and supporters.
column9: Connect participants to an ongoing dialog about this professional pathway for teachers and encourage them to engage actively.

column1: Tech entrepreneurship in emerging countries
column5: Carlos Tames (Niumedia), Pedro Martinez (Startup Lab MX)
column6: How to help high schools students in emerging countries to see tech entrepreneurship as an alternative. We will discuss a highly successful program called "my first business" that was implemented in rural areas in Mexico. We will show the methodology we created to help students to start a profitable business and how to implement this methodology in your community.
column7: How to teach tech entrepreneurship in low income areas.
column8: Help the policy makers to create programs that engage the community.
column9: Learn new methodologies to help low income students start a business.

column1: The Art of Making Sh*t Happen
column5: Melinda Murphy (Federal)
column6: You have a great idea but now what?  We  will explore making your creative dream reality.
column7: Dammit, I'm stuck
column8: Get into their heads
column9: Get sh*t done
column12: how to get into their heads.

column1: Unsanctioned Professional Development
column5: Michael Kleba (North Shore High School), Josh Timlin (North Shore High School)
column6: Lots of professional development turns teachers off: it_s boring, management-centered, and transactional. It's "paint by numbers" learning, where teachers attend most seminars and meetings because they are required to. The problem? Teachers, fatigued by "proving" they are learning, lose interest in their own professional development. But most teachers actually want to learn and grow as professionals. Educators must also evolve and to hone their craft in this ever-changing landscape, but how? Join two teachers discussing UPD, a tool kit of techniques that puts teacher curiosity at the center of a teacher's growth. UPD helps equip (& energize) teachers to learn what they want, how they want.
column7: Explore methods to displace the transactional nature of PD with a growth mindset: how to hack PD to make your own teacher personalized learning
column8: Acquire research based techniques to keep your learning authentic, purposeful, and _off the radar_ even as you comply with your district requirements
