column9: Network with partners at this session to create (or practice creating) UPD teams at your school-- or this very conference

column1: What Africa taught us about innovation & education
column5: Pete Freeman (University of Notre Dame), Don Wettrick (Noblesville High School)
column6: For 10 weeks this summer, Don Wettrick and I set out to study female entrepreneurs and economic empowerment in southern Ghana. What we learned, however, is how many Africans can be entrepreneurial without being innovative. During our field work, we observed several schools that place a premium on teaching subservience rather than innovation. In this core conversation, we will discuss our takeaways: how innovation and entrepreneurial workshops can help women level the playing field across the world, and how changing the classroom dynamic in primary school can provide sustainable, positive results for future economic empowerment, and the lessons we can take away for our own educational system.
column7: Understand what innovation looks like in Africa.
column8: Extrapolate lessons learned on innovation from a multi-cultural point of view.
column9: Understand the importance of global collaboration.

column1: Creating and using a game in large lecture classes
column5: Jake Lenzen (Texas A&M Univeristy), Andre Thomas (Texas A&M University)
column6: In this session we will share our approach to designing, developing and evaluating a high quality interactive game for Art History classes. During the session we will demo our game and share lessons we learned during the design process, including putting together the right team, defining learning objectives for the game, rapid prototyping and final developing. Additionally we will cover what we have learned when using the game in large lecture classrooms and online classes.We will cover the material in a way that allows other educators to take our process and design, plan, develop and implement games in their classroom.
column7: Participants are able to describe the design and development process for creating a high quality game for their classroom, that students like to play.
column8: Participants are able to differentiate effective high quality learning games from those that are not effective or of insufficient quality.
column9: Participants are able to describe an effective strategy of deploying and using a game in their classroom.

column1: Scratch Arcade: Coding in Elementary School
column5: Cristina  Popescu (Comal ISD)
column6: Motivate students to reinforce academic content by empowering them to code their own video games! Using the M.I.T. developed Scratch platform, I'll share how my 3rd graders created a coding word wall and learned the essential components of a great game. Leveraging rewards, score keeping, game feedback and peer review, students  learned to revise their games and eventually invite gamers to their own arcade.
column7: Coding is attainable in the elementary classroom with the Scratch Platform and Apps.
column8: Leverage gaming to reinforce academic content.
column9: Allow students a platform to show their creativity, critical thinking skills and communicate with peers.

column1: Age-Based Learning is Irrelevant: Let's Change It!
column5: Stacci Barganz (Fort Atkinson School District)
column6: Today, learning based on ages and grades is becoming increasingly irrelevant and is not letting us meet the needs of anyone outside the middle of the bell curve.  In this session, we will explore some ideas to break out of the box and move forward with standards-based personalized learning.  Specific (and real) data will be shown for three grade 4th grade students with varied ability levels and learning needs, and participants will be invited to dream about providing an education that is 100% relevant in scope and sequence to 100% of students, 100% of the time.  This style of teaching/learning meets the needs of gifted, average, and struggling students and is more sustainable for educators.
column7: Participants will learn about alternate ways to "do school", not based on age.
column8: Participants will examine what a shift like this would look like for educators, for students, and for parents.
column9: Participants will understand the strengths and weaknesses of a system like this, and will be provided with appropriate resource ideas.

column1: Appealing to the second side of the marketplace (e
column5: Lenny  Rachitsky (Airbnb), Laura  Hughes (Airbnb)
column6: So often people focus on the customer experience side of the sharing economy, but equally important is the other half of the equation -- the drivers, the crafters, the lodging hosts, the dog walkers, grocery shoppers. Ease of use and functionality for the second side of the marketplace_s customers is vital to maintaining a diverse, competitive and rewarding environment that is mutually beneficial. Companies have had to be thoughtful about creating critical backend tools like dashboards, pricing, calendar, payments etc but more importantly they re-inventing the type of relationship that needs to be had with these _partners_ - one of mutual trust and continued learning.
column7: 1.     What are second side users attracted to in a platform?
column8: 2.     How to design a relationship for success?
column9: 3.      The pitfalls of not being a 'Partner' - with some fun anecdotes!

column1: Building a Personalized Learning Teacher
column5: Amy Pillizzi (Southport Elementary School), Jean Garrity (The Institute for Personalized Learning)
column6: As schools adopt competency-based, personalized, or student-centered learning models that are more responsive to the needs of every child, teachers must interact in new ways with students, peers, and the broader community. Yet most educator development systems don_t explicitly address the unique mindsets and skills that these teachers need. In this interactive session, explore issues, share ideas, and learn about recent work to define these educator competencies in ways that system leaders can act upon. Learn what steps some state leaders are already taking.
column7: Utilize new "Educator Competencies for Personalized Learning" resource to provide common language for describing mindsets, skills, and abilities
column8: Invoke personal experiences and engage in discussion to unpack current challenges and opportunities within educator workforce development systems
column9: Discuss current and potential changes to educator preparation, licensure, induction, PD, and evaluation to help build personalized learning teachers

column1: Change Mgmt Skills applied to Software Design
column5: Andre Perazzi Afonso (IBM), Daiane Lins (IBM)
column6: Provide an overview of how change management can be incorporated into application design, and how it can make applications easier for users to adopt and embrace.It comprises a basic understanding of organizational change management concepts, how change management can be applied during software develop (against traditional change mgmt approach) and how can designers and developers benefit from it.
column7: Change Management OverviewPresent the better change framework, focusing on communication, education and change behavior
column8: Innovative ways to apply change to designHow can designers and even developers apply change management concepts to software development
column9: Case study of how change management applied during software development

column1: Designing Edtech with Educator Voice
column5: Candace Flaherty (Mobility Labs, Inc.), Sean Perkins (Mobility Labs, Inc.)
column6: Creating great edtech products is hard. Creating them without the end user is impossible.We will discuss ways that educators can ensure their voices are being heard during the design and development of new products. This includes technology being developed internally at the district level and also software that edtech companies are creating for them. We will share how we  include educators in our design process and will invite technology/business leaders to talk about their own processes.
column7: Ways to get involved as a teacher, educator, or student in the design of new products and tools.
column8: How edtech companies can structure user feedback sessions and utilize them to enhance their products.
column9: The benefits of remote feedback and in person user interviews.

column1: Expelling Barriers to Competency-Based Education
column5: Kiran Kodithala (N2N Services Inc.)
column6: Competency-based education (CBE) has the potential to revolutionize education by focusing on the mastery of academic content rather than on compulsory seat time at a given time and place. This necessitates changes in how learning content and progress is administered, delivered, tracked and measured. Traditional student data and learning management systems do not mesh well with such non-standard approaches.  Institutions participating in CBE must balance a portfolio of diverse systems that create significant system integration challenges. We describe a flexible, adaptable middleware solution that overcomes integration hurdles and enables institutions to deliver on the promise of CBE.
column7: Understand the various technology challenges encountered by institutions when introducing and supporting non-traditional education models.
column8: Understand the changes and costs imposed upon an institution by introducing hybrid student information strategies based on disparate data sources.
column9: Explain the role that secure cloud-based (iPaaS) middleware can play in solving the integration problems and enabling CBE in traditional settings.

column1: Get Coding in Your No, Low, or High-Tech Classroom
column5: Jennifer  Sabourin (SAS Institute Inc), Lucy Kosturko (SAS Institute Inc.)
column6: Programming is one of today_s most sought after skills & consequently a beneficial skill to introduce to students of any age. However, getting started in this relatively new discipline can be daunting. There are also many misconceptions that K-12 computer science (CS) requires a large tech budget, a classroom full of iPads and robots, and a nerdy tech teacher. In this session, we dispel those myths as participants share their experiences with CS instruction & discuss strategies for teaching the fundamentals of coding. We will explore ideas for integrating coding instruction into no-, low-, and high-tech environments & show how CS can be implemented with varying levels of expertise & access.
column7: Technology aside, participants will discuss and identify the fundamental components and skills of coding.
column8: Using the first objective as a foundation, participants will discuss technology-agnostic classroom activities that build fundamental coding skills.
column9: Participants will get hands on with robots, apps, and other tools that enable coding instruction in a variety of tech settings.

column1: Growing Pains: Becoming a Design Focused Dev Team
column5: Jonathan Millar (IBM Design)
column6: What happens when you already have an established service or product and you want to become more designed focused? You hire a team of designers that completely redefine your UX and TADA!_ right? Well, not quite_ We will be exploring some of the growing pains that come with transforming an existing dev team to one that is ux and design focused. How do we build this? How do we integrate this? How do we think like designers now that they_re gone?
column7: Changing the way you think.Pains switching from functional to UX focused development.
column8: Changing the way you develop.Pains becoming agile and using modern tools and frameworks.
column9: Preparing for the future.(Future pains) What happens when your design team is gone.

column1: How old is that computer? Real world technical req
column5: Mike Olsen (Proctorio)
column6: As online education includes more and more online technologies how do schools create a set of technical requirements that are low enough to include everyone but high enough to utilize the required technology? What is "really" standard today in the way of computer and connection speeds? We will share what real student hardware and connection data looks like collected over the last two years and discuss ways various school address problems when a technology requires more than what a student has.
column7: Know and understand what real student computer and connection speeds look like.
column8: How to decide on the right balance for technical requirements for an online school.
column9: How to address a student who does not meet the minimum requirements for your online school.

column1: How to Make a University Film You'd Want to Watch
column5: Jerry Kisslinger (Columbia University Office of Alumni and Development), Joshua Seftel (Smartypants Pictures)
column6: How do you make a university film that you_d actually want to watch_ so that it captures your audience_s attention, delivers an emotional experience, and ultimately, drives action.Using one film -- _The Lenfest Effect_ -- as a case study, an award-winning filmmaker and an alumni and development executive share their success applying independent film and commercial storytelling techniques to a university film.Audiences will come away with a better understanding of the building blocks necessary to make a successful university film; great cast and interviews, strong story approach, creative visuals, and much more.
column7: The process of creating an entertaining and engaging university film from soup to nuts including budget, staff time, and working relationships.
column8: A fresh perspective on what makes powerful storytelling work, learn how to create more engaging content that alumni and donors actually want to watch.
column9: The larger framework of _storytelling_ will be deconstructed into its core principles to reveal how each one works to amplify and enhance the message.

column1: Increasing teachers' digital literacy in Sweden
column5: Peter Parnes (Lule University of Technology), Agneta Hedenstrm (Municipality of Lule )
column6: Society is becoming more and more computerised and the school system has to follow. Over the least 2 years, we have have been experimenting with how to increase K-12 teachers' digital literacy in Sweden and the city of Lule. This has been done through a number of the different sessions, workshops, courses in a collaboration between the municipality of Lule and Lule University of Technology. Three central themes have been applied: Computational Thinking, Making and attracting females to ICT. In this session we will present the challenges in increasing digital literacy, our various experiments and give the audience an insight into digitalisation in the Swedish school system.
column7: How to work with computational thinking and maker culture in K-12 education.
column8: How to work with inspiring and motivating teachers to change their way of teaching in relation to ICT and digitalisation in schools.
column9: How to increase the presence of females in the ICT-area, both in schools and in the industry.

column1: Let's Talk: The Good & Bad of Digital Citizenship
column5: Kat Stewart (Cable Impacts Foundation), Belinha De Abreu (Fairfield University)
column6: We propose to work on a collaborative and working document dealing with the premise/question: Digital Citizenship: Are Adults Making it Better or Worse? As a group, we will work together discussing the issues facing teachers, parents, administrators, and policy makers on the topic of digital citizenship and its impact in and out of schools. The issue facing all of us, but in particular our students, is that how we should act and behave on digital platforms is not always clear. In this session, we hope to dig deeper into the topic of digital citizenship by working on the questions faced by all across districts and schools in a global society.  Ultimately, we hope to elevate the conversation.
column7: Build a holistic view and understanding of national and international conversations/concerning digital citizenship.
column8: Bridging policy to practitioners on the issues of digital citizenship while raising awareness in order to bring greater understanding.
column9: Create a living/working document allowing participants to walk away with a tangible resource that they can take back to their counterparts.

column1: Making Tech Human in the School and District
column5: Troy Fischer (Newark Public Schools), Lucinda Taylor (Madison Park Business & Art Academy)
column6: Integrating technology into the classroom is one challenge; doing it throughout an entire school or district, especially with limited resources, is another. Administrators from underserved communities (the principal of a school with fully blended learning and the CIO of New Jersey_s largest district) contrast their experiences implementing technology on micro and macro levels. They reflect on lessons learned, challenges faced and how to lead their communities in adapting to new ways of teaching and learning.
column7: Learn strategies for integrating technology into urban schools on both a school-wide and district-wide level.
column8: Explore how administrators can best support _ and gain the support of _ teachers in implementing new tools and policies.
column9: Gain insights into preserving the human component of education interaction as instruction becomes increasingly digital.

column1: Step into Open Source Software!
column5: Jamie Carrington (Texas Department of Family and Protective Services), Jenell Paul (Texas Department of Family and Protective Services)
column6: In this training you will explore Open Source software, specifically Moodle. How The Texas Department of Family and Protective Services use Moodle to create and host staff training. Including instructions on _key_ Moodle functions, such as developing a course, posting materials, participating in activities, completing assignments, setting up course requirements, evaluations and certificates of participation. The training will conclude with a discussion on how to implement and support an open source application.
column7: The trainee will be able to define and understand Open Source Software.
column8: Trainee will recognize how to use Moodle as an example of activities and resources available for us in open source LMS software.
column9: The trainee can identify processes needed for Implementation and Support of Open Source Software.

column1: Student 2.0:  Capability beyond the coursework
column5: Sergio Villegas (NapaLearns/Napa County Office of Education)
column6: Following the explosion of wireless networks in schools and individual access to student devices, there came a mountain of cultural, physical, and technical changes that school must quickly adapt to.  One response to this need for change is the growth in the various role kids are playing in school that extend beyond the traditional role as students.  After framing this the problem with the group in the room, a collaborative conversation will be moderated between the various organizations represented in the room.  An opportunity to both share success and failures on the ever growing domain of the changing role of students at schools.
column7: How are students in your schools working to support teacher learning, training, and growth and what success and challenges have you encountered?
column8: How are students in your schools involved in the decision making process in your schools and what success and challenges have you encountered?
column9: How are your students working to develop professional content for your school/community and what successes and challenges have you encountered

column1: The Happiness Model: create super happy customers
column5: Christopher Hines (Crescent City Schools), Bonnie Savage (Schoolrunner)
column6: Traditionally, edtech has had a hard time supporting schools. Why? Startups are still using customer service techniques from the business world. Schools are not typical tech clients - they think differently and operate differently. Everything from pricing, to implementation, to important times of year operate outside of a traditional business. Their bottom line isn_t just a number, it_s improving the lives of their students. Schoolrunner set out to redefine their customer service model with schools, and create a new model of collaborative support: The Happiness Model. A model that makes their schools insanely happy & invested in the future of the company.
column7: Chris & Bonnie will introduce the Happiness Model of support.
column8: Bonnie will detail how EdTech companies work better with schools.
column9: Chris will teach participants how schools can work collaboratively with vendors.

column1: Tinkering For Teachers
column5: Eric Yoder (Tuscarora Intermediate Unit 11), Jigar Patel (Tuscarora Intermediate Unit 11)
column6: Our core conversation session will introduce teachers and curriculum leaders to tinkering and design thinking. We will explore how teachers can create a tinkering/design thinking workspace, how they can teach kids to work individually and collaboratively, and how teachers can adopt and implement these spaces in the classroom. Our discussion will address challenges to implementing tinkering and shifting the traditional classroom into a makerspace for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) learning.  We will share our experiences leading professional development workshops that introduce teachers and curriculum professionals to these concepts and strategies.
column7: Participants will identify the essential components of a tinkering workspace and discuss the student and teacher mindsets that make them successful.
column8: Participants will learn how to use tinkering and design thinking to embed authenticity into their existing curricula.
column9: Participants will develop strategies for generating buy-in among students, teachers, administrators, and parents.

column1: WeTeachNYC: Reimaging professional development
column5: Viraj Kamdar (NYC Department of Education), Angie Bedford-Jack (NYC Department of Education)
column6: The professional development of educators is widely regarded as a key component to creating successful schools and children; using technology to support professional development has gained increasing interest in recent years. New York City_s WeTeachNYC team will share illustrative stories and artifacts from their efforts to spread online/blended approaches to professional learning to over 80,000 educators. Three main work streams will be represented, including online/blended learning, digital resource strategy, and product development. Participants can count on engaging storytelling, actionable ideas, and a social media backchannel that will be used to drive whole group conversation.
column7: Help PD teams _blend_ their work
column8: Learn ways to introduce others to the compelixities of metadata
column9: Gain strategies for ensuring educational outcomes drive IT solutions

column1: What Will Deliver on the Promise of Ed-Tech?
column5: Neeru Khosla (CK-12)
column6: Education has been one of the last sectors to successfully adopt technology because its legacy infrastructure is complex and the expense has been prohibitive to district budgets. However, the wait may nearly be over as a variety of forces are combining to make the promise of ed-tech a reality for school districts nationwide. This session will delve into what will finally deliver on the promise of ed-tech and level the playing field for school districts, teachers and students worldwide.
column7: Discuss why education has been lagging behind other industries in technology adoption.
column8: Learn which promises of ed-tech are finally coming through for the industry.
column9: Understand how these new technologies will truly change classrooms as we know them and how school districts can implement them successfully.

column1: Where does computer science fit in the K-12 space?
column5: Kim Wilkens (St. Anne's-Belfield School), Zach Minster (St. Anne's-Belfield School)
column6: Computer science (CS) is part of all of our lives. Through the study of CS, students hone their design thinking, logical reasoning, and problem-solving skills in ways that can be applied to solving problems in each and every discipline. In today_s world, students must have a deeper understanding of the fundamentals of computing so they are empowered to take control of how tech will affect their lives, their culture, and their future.In this session, we will explore why integrating CS into the curriculum is critical in K-12 education, what CS looks like in the K-12 space and tips for getting started based on our experiences of launching the CS Initiative at St. Anne's-Belfield School.
column7: Discover why integrating computer science in the K-12 curriculum is so critical to our students_ future.
column8: Explore examples of what computer science looks like in the K-12 space.
column9: Learn tips & techniques for making computer science a component of your curricula.

column1: A Formula for Developing T-Shaped Students
column5: Brandon Smith (Ball State University), Ryan Bitzegaio (Ball State University)
column6: For years, employers have been seeking T-shaped employees (people with a depth of expertise in a field, and a breadth of cross-discipline understanding), but little has been done to alter higher education to accommodate this demand. At Ball State, the Digital Corps was formed to address this problem, and for nearly 10 years, it_s been churning out innovative work and highly-employable T-shaped students. This session will outline how the Digital Corps came to be and its model for success.
column7: Identify potential opportunities and benefits of developing an interdisciplinary student team at your institution.
column8: Learn about the structures and core values at the heart of a successful interdisciplinary student team.
column9: Discover the long-lasting impact that learning and working in an interdisciplinary environment has on student success.

column1: Augmented Reality: Engaging a Minecraft Generation
column5: Brad  Waid (DAQRI), Drew Minock (DAQRI)
column6: Why will kids sit for hours immersed in a Minecraft world, but have trouble staying engaged during class? As a group, we will discuss how new augmented reality (AR) tools give educators and students the power to: create meaningful learning experiences that combine the digital and physical worlds, build interactive experiences to show and share knowledge with a global audience, understand complex concepts, and retain information longer. Together will we address how we can take existing curriculums, and enhance them to appeal to the Minecraft Generation.
column7: Empower students,teachers,and administrators to use augmented reality to design and create powerful learning experiences for the Minecraft generation.
column8: Provide basic knowledge and skills set to create and integrate meaningful augmented reality experiences in the classroom, school, and community.
column9: Highlight the way educators and students are using augmented reality to comprehend learning complex concepts, and retain information easier.

column1: Cloud Based Instructor Led Training Games
column5: Seth Clark (Booz Allen Hamilton), Sandra Marshall (Booz Allen Hamilton)
column6: Cloud-based games utilizing HTML5 and responsive design make training more accessible to remote and live audiences alike. This solution also allows for incredible qualitative metrics and real-time interaction; allowing the instructor and designers to see where their audience is struggling and the engagement across the training.This session will include tips and tricks when working in a cloud environment, scaling for audience size, and distilling impactful metrics from the data available.
column7: Attendees will understand the value cloud computing can bring to learning activities.
column8: Attendees will get to test a cloud-based game in a live environment.
column9: Attendees will understand how to distill impactful data from the cloud solution and how those metrics can inform future training.

column1: Community Colleges: Leading through innovation
column5: Kurt Strand (McGraw-Hill Education), Anne Praderas Vance (Austin Community College)
column6: Community colleges play a critical role in preparing a large number of students for success in the workforce. However, they also face low graduation and retention rates, and nearly 50% of 2-year students enter remediation.Many community colleges have turned to adaptive learning to help improve results. Austin Community College's ACCelerator, a 600-seat facility built on the former site of Austin's Highland Mall, has garnered much attention for its ALEKS-powered approach to improving student outcomes.This session offers an in-depth look at how the ACCelerator and programs like it are helping community colleges fulfill their mission of helping all students achieve success.
column7: The important role of U.S. community colleges and the specific challenges they face, particularly in remediation.
column8: How adaptive learning accelerate students_ time in remediation, specifically in the emporium model.
column9: How Austin Community College's ACCelerator math lab has changed the learning experience for students, instructors and administrators.

column1: Developing the next generation for STEM careers.
column5: Donna Imam (Inteleaf), Lamia Imam (Inteleaf)
column6: Lack of women in STEM and leadership positions in hi-tech is the hot topic of discussion. Even names like Google and Facebook are unable to change this. This session will be led by two women - a successful product manager and entrepreneur from the tech industry and an experienced public policy specialist on how we can inspire the next generation of tech leaders. It will touch on their journey and give insights from success stories on how to make Math, Physics and Writing attractive to high school students - who will bring to market the technology of 2025.
column7: What educators today can do to create the next generation of innovators
column8: How to inspire young women to consider technology careers
column9: How to implement successful techniques from case studies into your high school program

column1: Digital Hubs: Branding & Engagement in Higher Ed
column5: Russ Shirley (Wright State University), Ike Brunner (Wright State University)
column6: This session will focus on teaching and doing social/digital media in higher education. More specifically, we will talk about our experiences, best practices and lessons learned in teaching undergraduate students how to use social media to their professional benefit and create an impactful personal brand as a result.The session will center on using a digital hub project as the core component of building students' digital/social media skills. We will discuss the 10 key elements of the digital hub, examples of successful student engagements, including using Hootsuite University as a social media management tool, and professional resume builder.
column7: Explain what a digital hub is and how it can be used in the higher education classroom to teach students professional branding & networking skills.
column8: Specify how to use social media platforms and related tools to build a platform for showcasing skills and for increasing student engagement.
column9: Show the importance of teaching social media & personal branding skills to undergraduates as they prepare for the business world.

column1: Digital Portfolios and College Admissions
column5: Will Herals (Coalition Application, Inc.), Mark Bridges (http://corp.collegenet.com)
column6: A digital portfolio can provides students the ability to centralize and curate the best of their school work as well as demonstrate engagement and academic abilities beyond the traditional metrics and serve both as a tool for learning as well as preparation for applying to college. A coalition of highly respected American public and private colleges and universities has begun the design and organization of such an online platform and hopes to recast the nature of applying to college in the 21st century.
column7: Learn about Digital portfolios and how they can be applied to Education.
column8: Learn about the Coalition and its objectives for improving the college application process.
column9: See the progress the Coalition has made in the past year of development, and learn about the goals for the future.

column1: Drivers Ed: Personalized Tier Based Teacher Traini
column5: Cari Orts (Marble Falls ISD), Adam Goodman (mfisd.txed.net)
column6: Do your teachers need GAFE Training wheels, are they ready for Driver's ED, or are they approaching Formula 1 speeds? If you're like us the answers are yes, yes, and yes! Follow along as we discuss how our professional development was differentiated to meet the varying needs of staff members. In our method, teachers' self-assess their knowledge of GAFE tools to find their tier and attend an activity based, learner-centered full day professional development. Let's move into the fast lane!
column7: Developing a teacher self-assessment on GAFE skills and knowledge.
column8: Planning a self-paced practicum to develop teachers use of GAFE in their environment.
column9: Promoting future use, and skill development.

column1: EdTech - a way to improve lives?
column5: Ole Jakob Bergfjord (Bergen University College), Tarjei Heggernes (Bergen University College)
column6: The hectic life. A semester goes by so fast, then there are papers and exams to be graded, research papers to be finished, new courses to be developed, and then back to square one. And if the course was not a disaster last time, it should work this semester as well. But, to quote our favourite truant: Life moves pretty fast. If you don_t stop to look around, you_ll miss it!That_s exactly what this conversation aims to do. It does not aim to be the _be all, end all_ on use of digital learning, but a summary of experiences from the last 7 years of integrating digital tools in a University College learning setting. The methods include blogging, digital peer evaluation and flipped classroom.
column7: How can digital learning methods can effect variables as percieved learning outcome, grades, attendance and overall satisfaction for students?
column8: What has changed in the attitudes and the ways students use the digital learning tools since 2009?
column9: Is it a good idea for the lecturer to digitize learning processes?

column1: Educator_s Dilemma: Defining Open in Education
column5: Anthony Salcito (Microsoft), Stephen Laster (McGraw-Hill Education)
column6: Open learning environments are not only in the best interest of students and educators; they are vital for survival in the new learning ecosystem. This is why open learning environments are gaining popularity among states, school districts and lawmakers. A new bipartisan amendment to the U.S. Senate_s rewrite of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act encourages the use of free, modifiable and openly licensed resources. But many education experts and policy advocates disagree on what it means to be truly open. Are open technology standards the key, or are free, open-source educational resources the defining factor of open technology in education? Or is it a mix of both?
column7: Debate how to define open learning, its future and why companies choose not to openly distribute content
column8: Understand why is digital content so often locked and restricted from developer, teacher and student modification and access
column9: How to develop an open ecosystem that ensures coherent and effective learning

column1: Engaging onlineEd through serious, casual games
column5: Brian Breslin (RefreshMiami, inc.), Renzo Weber (Simcase)
column6: The potential of online education remains unfulfilled. Current efforts to improve the fidelity of online video lectures do not address the passive student experience that underpins the lecture format. We believe that online education must embrace the full potential of digital technology, learn from the growth of the gaming industry, and strive to make the student experience an active one. This panel aims to explore how blending casual games mechanics, real-world case studies, and world-class professors can create active-learning digital content that spans general education and business education concepts. We will outline what worked, what didn_t, and why.
column7: Why serious, casual games will power the next evolution in OnlineEd.
column8: Why casual games provide the right balance of complexity, commitment, and flexibility.
column9: Why casual games can make hybrid learning on campus more attractive

column1: Enhancing Local History with Augmented Reality
column5: Heidi Larson (Education Development Center), Chris Dede (Harvard Graduate School of Education)
column6: With National Women_s History month now celebrated in March each year, schools are filling gaps in their textbooks with their own curricula. We'll show you how we worked with graduate and high school students, teachers, and the board of the Boston Women_s Heritage Trail to enhance the trail with augmented reality _ overlaying context, multimedia, and assessments on the statues and other static features of the trail _ aligned with high school history course objectives. What local history spot do you have in mind? Once you've seen what we've done with ours, let's think together about yours. The two video resources are from graduate students who helped developed a previous experience.
column7: Insights into Augmented Reality_s potential for engaging students with local women's history.
column8: Insights and ideas from co-attendees into how to create Augmented Reality in the field: Choosing a theme and platform, planning the experience, etc.
column9: Discussion of Benefits, Challenges, and Strategies for digital augmentation.

column1: Fair Use: Let it Transform You
column5: Renee Hobbs (Media Education Lab, University of Rhode Island), D.C. Vito (The LAMP)
column6: Learners of all ages are creating media as a way of learning. They use images, websites, graphics, videos, music and interactive media in their own creative work. But these new pedagogies also raise some eyebrows about copyright. When can students use images they have found online? Why should they use these materials? When students ask if they can use a pop song in their video, what do teachers, librarians and technology specialists say? In this session, you will learn how, why and when it is lawful to use copyrighted materials for digital learning (and ESPECIALLY when it is not). By understanding transformativeness, you will gain confidence in making a fair use determination.
column7: Understand and recognize the value and purpose of copyright law in the context of student multimedia creativity
column8: Apply fair use reasoning and the concept of transformativeness to specific contexts and situations that involve student learners as media makers
column9: Appreciate the role of education and advocacy in expanding public understanding of copyright and fair use in a digital age

column1: Finding a balance of offline and online tools
column5: Melissa  Davis (GoEnnounce)
column6: Are students spending too much time _online_? With the surge of edtech learning applications, are students getting access to a better education or are we enabling a generation that is becoming too connected? As educators and entrepreneurs, it is important to provide students with platforms that bring a balance of online and offline resources for college and career readiness. We_ll discuss the importance of integrating online tools with offline components to give students the right balance and maximum benefit.
column7: Understand fears, pro's and con's associated with too much technology in the classroom.
column8: Learn how to incorporate students' offline achievements into digital learning platforms to encourage additional offline learning and engagement.
column9: Participants will be shown examples of online tools that are empowering students for a better offline future.

column1: Fractions! Fractions! Learn All About _Em
column5: Erich Zeller (The MIND Research Institute)
column6: As we look at the next generation of education for our students, we also have to look at the next generation of development for our teachers. In this session, we dive into an innovative professional development structure that increases teachers' pedagogical content knowledge in mathematics while supporting its application in the classroom. Attendees will experience a research-based instructional sequence on fraction concepts designed to improve teachers_ content knowledge, instructional practices, and student engagement. Participants will learn the research behind CGI (Cognitively Guided Instruction) and how it can be incorporated to increase understanding.
column7: Participants will better understand how the science of learning can be embedded into professional development to increase student understanding.
column8: Participants will learn a structure that supports implementing rigorous, Common Core State Standards-aligned, problem solving.
column9: Participants will experience one complete lesson and then analyze work from other lessons in the sequence.

column1: From Rhetoric to College Readiness
column5: Tony Fong (WestEd), Nancy Brynelson (California State University Chancellor's Office)
column6: ERWC emphasizes the integration of interactive reading and writing processes and a rhetorical approach that fosters critical thinking and engagement through a relentless focus on the text. The ERWC Assignment Template presents a scaffolded process for helping students read, comprehend, and respond to nonfiction and literary texts. The yearlong course includes 12 modules, include expository and literary texts and move from prereading, through reading and postreading activities, to more formal writing assignments. Analytical thinking and reasoned debate are central to course pedagogy. Students are expected to read actively, engage in deep and critical discussions, and write effectively.
column7: Does the ERWC have a positive impact on the reading and writing skills of grade 12 students as measured through the English Placement Test (EPT)?
column8: Is the ERWC curriculum being implemented as intended, and what factors support or hinder fidelity of implementation?
column9: The integration of interactive reading and writing processes; rhetorical approach that fosters critical thinking and engagement.

column1: From strategic planning to strategic improv
column5: Daniel Gonzalez (Sapient Nitro), Andrew Gregoris (Sapient Nitro)
column6: A fundamental shift in how we think and act is underway. Businesses are struggling to stay relevant in a post-iPhone world. Technology has propelled us forwards, but traditional perspectives of strategy have held us back. In a world of extreme complexity and rapid change, we need to find a new way of thinking to create relevance and meaning for brands. Enter experience strategy. Its methodology borrows from traditional strategy, branding, technology and service design. Understanding people, business and brand needs and what technology can enable _ experience strategy adopts an iterative approach to create systems that empower people to co-design the future.
column7: Understand the new role of strategy in an agile world and the value of trying to set a direction in a world that constantly mutates into new things.
column8: Understand what experience strategy is, its tools, methods and techniques.
column9: Understand how experience strategy helps brands become experience-led

column1: Have Purpose: Building Business Relationships
column5: Charley Clark (Pea Ridge High School), Jon  Laffoon (Pea Ridge High School)
column6: Educational purpose is to prepare all students for college, career, & life; rather than limiting students to one track after graduation. To accomplish this purpose, business & higher education must be more than the traditional partner. Schools must build relationships where businesses & colleges are deeply invested in creating discovery-based curriculum, selecting instructors & providing site-based internships.This model allows students to gain core knowledge & build 21st century skills.
column7: Focus school_s educational purpose
column8: Identify local business partner opportunities in the surrounding communities
column9: Determine discovery-based curriculum that benefits students, partners, and community

column1: It's not about the Polar Bears
column5: Andrew  Winston (Ode Speaker Management)
column6: We are facing a time of unprecedented change, the big issues such as population growth, resource scarcity and technological shifts are presenting us with unmitigated risk, but also huge opportunities. Andrew Winston is the authority on how businesses can get ahead of this change curve and use it to access multi-trillion dollar markets.His practical blue print enables businesses to make the _Big Pivot_ from _business as usual_ to a world of opportunities where the big winners are those that move boldly forward, prioritising heretical innovation, long term planning and resilience.
column7: Build a Resilient Business -- In the face of climate change, resource constraints, and transparency, successful companies will pursue resilience.
column8: Strategies for retail and consumer goods - consumers can now ask questions about every product, where it came from, who made it and global impact
column9: Finding the Gold in Green --  Working green, but still making a profit

column1: Literacy & Inclusive Classrooms: Powered by EdTech
column5: Jennifer Pankowski (Pace University), Rich Johnson (NYC Department of Education)
column6: EdTech makes inclusive classrooms a reality. With an abundance of high-quality literacy resources online, teachers can deliver powerful, individualized education to every student, including English Language Learners and special education students. We_ll explore how universities are preparing teachers to use EdTech in inclusive classrooms and the powerful results they are having in schools, featuring Dr. Jennifer Pankowski, of Pace University, and Rich Johnson, a 5th grade teacher in the Bronx.
column7: Understanding of what _inclusive classrooms_ means, and how both general ed and special ed teachers can use the same content for all students
column8: How universities are enabling future teachers to enter inclusive classrooms able to navigate tools and resources to effectively teach literacy
column9: A list of resources to use in the classroom and a call to action for participants to keep in touch over the year and share best practices

column1: LMS: Extreme Makeover
column5: Melissa Greenwood (SmartBrief), Karen Billings (SIIA)
column6: Ask five educators to define "learning management system," and you_ll get five different answers. Viewed by some as a useful tool for teaching and learning and by others as a necessary evil, LMS evokes strong feelings among educators, administrators, and even the companies that create them. But the LMS is changing and so, too, is the way we define it. So what should we call it? To determine that, we must first discuss LMS challenges, including how curriculum and technology leaders can work together to achieve the same goals. This session will seek to build consensus around oft-ambiguous terminology and the advantages and challenges of these evolving digital learning platforms.
column7: How to bridge the gap and address the disconnect between curriculum and technology leaders.
column8: How to establish a common understanding of digital learning in districts by building consensus from school leaders around new edtech terminology.
column9: How educators, especially classroom teachers, can achieve their goals by using these new terms for digital learning platforms.

column1: MadLib This: The Curious Case of Lifelong Empathy
column5: Leigh Neier, PhD (University of Missouri), Stacy Neier, PhD (Loyola Chicago)
column6: What characteristics distinguish a lifelong learner? More importantly, can we teach these characteristics to motivate a student_s quest for personal and professional success? Experiential and service learning, internships, field research, and public scholarship provide a high impact platform for learning beyond the classroom. Yet, as teacher-leaders, what are next steps to leverage curiosity and empathy _ which often go unnoticed _ to optimize investment in personal development? Curiosity and empathy are no longer _nice to have_; rather, both are _need to know__ more critical to self-directed learning and emotional intelligence than ever before.
column7: To acknowledge opportunity in secondary and higher education settings to foster emotional intelligence by combining curiosity and empathy
column8: To address students_ resistant attitudes about ambiguity and uncertain situations through persuasive use of curiosity and empathy
column9: To encourage educators and stakeholders to see curiosity and empathy as the preferred combination to solve problems and encounter civic leadership

column1: Make It Stick:  Applying Marketing to Education
column5: Maggie Helon (Teaching Wheels Educational Consulting), Kendall Morris (Create Digital)
column6: In a world where we are constantly bombarded with messages, it is often difficult to cut through the noise for students and gain total focus on a lesson.  With insights from both the education and advertising worlds, we'll explore how to meet your educational goals for your students with marketing techniques.  The basic goals of advertising and teaching are the same.  Share information with someone and get them to move down a path of understanding and action as a result of that information.  This session will explore how to apply common marketing techniques of research, insights, strategy, planning, delivery, and measurement to your best practices as an educator.
column7: Develop an understanding of the phases of advertising planning.
column8: Apply advertising techniques to your lesson planning to capture student attention, improve retention and application of knowledge.
column9: Explore advertising through the eye of an educator to gain tactics that can be applied in the classroom.

column1: Making the Transition to Digital Curriculum
column5: Rene Le Bel (Knomadix Corporation)
column6: Most schools live in the PDF world.  This session will focus on one school district in Texas undergoing a transformation from the PDF world to the distribution of dynamic, interactive lessons on tablets.  Students are more engaged, confident and achieving at a higher level.  Teachers are able to easily deliver differentiated instruction to their classes.  Students receive automatic feedback on teacher created assignments.  Teachers now spend less time grading and more time doing what they like best - teaching.  Join me as we review one district making the transition to interactive digital curriculum.
column7: Show how one district is bringing a fantastic learning environment to digital natives.
column8: Show how one school district is transforming their existing PDF world into a digital curriculum.
column9: Show attendees how they can easily transform their existing PDF world into a digital curriculum for their own digital natives.

column1: Math Your Own Adventure: Game Design for Learning
column5: Ki Karou (MIND Research Institute)
column6: Since the dawn of computers, people have had a hope for what technology could do for education. One of these areas has been the use of games, which are phenomenal vehicles for learning -- they increase motivation, promote autonomy, and are designed around the absolute best learning tool: failure. Traditionally games have been used as a layer slapped on top of facts to memorize or practice. However, a new category of games is emerging, where the game is a living model of the lessons, and by playing the game, students are actually playing with and discovering how the core ideas of the new concept work. Come learn how to incorporate game-play in your classroom to maximize deeper learning.
column7: Participants will be able to create a game challenge for their own classroom that is designed to engage students in more meaningful ways.
column8: Participants will learn how playing and creating games helps students build schemas for important concepts.
column9: Participants will discover the reasons failure is critical to deeper learning, and how gameplay helps de-stigmatize failure.

column1: More than Robots: Building Life Skills & Cool Kids
column5: Gigi Johnson (Maremel Institute)
column6: How can we engage with long-form project based learning that is more than just teaching STEM skills and build interest?  Long-form challenge-based projects, like FIRST Tech Challenge, bring more than just learning STEM skills and robotics ideas to kids' heads.  It brings a different way of approaching problems and working together to change their hearts as well.  For 4 years, I've worked with 7th-12th graders and have watched them become someone different through their engagement with FIRST Tech Challenge.  As an educator that mostly works in higher education, it has inspired me to teach differently.  It also has inspired me to bring these ideas to SXSWedu for expansion and discussion.
column7: Through case studies, understand the impact in long-form project-based learning can help 7th-12th graders build non-tech skills and design-thinking
column8: Think about 4 ways to bring robotics and other STEM-focused PBL programs into traditional classroom environments.
column9: Rethink the roles of community members and outside learning resources into your afterschool or in-class STEM environments.

column1: No More Dioramas
column5: Jen Tew (Ronald Reagan Elementary), Lauren  Houser (Ronald Reagan Elementary)
column6: Are you looking for ways to enhance your instruction with K-5 students?! Well look no further! We will show you the power of using YouTube videos along with your current teaching practices to engage all learners and create personalized interactive instruction in your classroom. We will also discuss the simple strategies in creating a Genius Hour for young students and the power of social media to build a community of learners with colleagues and parents.
column7: I can implement the use of video in an engaging and interactive way to enhance the learning in my classroom.
column8: I can create and implement a classroom system of genius hour with my students.
column9: I can create and share student products and build a library for others to learn from.

column1: Owning the New Realities of the Classroom
column5: Jeremy  Friedman (Schoology )
column6: Current infrastructure cannot sustain the diversity of children who land in the same classroom.  Students on the higher functioning end of the autism spectrum, ESL students, and male and female students with different needs are all learning together as budgets are getting slashed. Understanding how to _own_ the changing dynamic of the new classroom is not something teachers and administrators can put off any longer. In this session, learn how to successfully work with the new realities of the changing classroom, to reach every student equally, provide an educational program that personalizes the learning experience, and break down walls to take back your classroom.
column7: Overcrowding and the complex nature of today_s classroom has changed how we need to engage with, and present information to, students.
column8: How to determine if your classroom/school is in need of a change; what questions teachers/admins need to consider as they_re taking back their classes
column9: Using the right tools, teachers and administrators can provide individualized learning at scale.

column1: Reinventing the Core: Signature Courses @ UTAustin
column5: Lori Holleran Steiker (The University of Texas at Austin), Patricia Moran Micks (UT Austin, First-Year Experience Office, School of Undergraduate Studies)
column6: The Signature Courses at UT Austin connect first-year students with distinguished faculty members_ passion, research and expertise. By way of these rigorous intellectual experiences, students develop college-level skills in research, writing, and discussion through an approach that is both interdisciplinary and contemporary. Signature Courses employ a distinct academic curriculum designed to transform high school students into collegiate thinkers. This session will provide information on the development of these core curriculum courses from idea to implementation. All participants will receive a complimentary copy of our recently published book, Signature Course Stories.
column7: Participants will understand the nuances and complexities of the program, and how it differs from a traditional 'College 101' course.
column8: Participants will leave with a step-by-step plan of engaging and finding support from faculty, staff, and students on their campus.
column9: Participants will be able to consider the following items: stakeholders; funding; undergrad curriculum; faculty involvement; quality vs. quantity.

column1: Rituals That Grow Belonging and Membership
column5: Peter Guttmacher (DC Trust for Youth)
column6: Young people vote with their feet. And all the "wisdom" in the world won't hold them if they don't feel at home.  In this session we will explore and share repeatable strategies/techniques for increasing their feeling of ownership in program or classroom culture.  Simple "rituals" that we can leverage to help them develop a stronger sense of Safety and Structure, Belonging and Membership and Self-Worth while they're in the bounded world we co-create with them. Come ready to share, steal and role play.
column7: Re-activate muscles of intentionality that we do not use as much (but perhaps should) in our day-to-day adult encounters
column8: Re-focus on some of the aspects of youth work that provide the greatest satisfaction -- and may have gotten us into the profession in the first place
column9: Reflect on what we can shape and what we can't -- and the role our programs can play in the larger scope of young people's lives

column1: Seven Cross-cultural Competencies for Educators
column5: Eun Y. Kim (CEO International), Edward Valdez (Learning List)
column6: According to a recent report, only 18% of teachers are ethnically diverse compared to 48% of students. Given changing demographics and global mobility, cross-cultural competence has become critical to instructional effectiveness. Multinationals have invested in innovative diversity/inclusion programs to maximize diverse talent. If schools were to benchmark corporate best practices, they will better serve their customers (students and parents). This session will analyze global diversity trends and identify cultural competencies for educators, including global mindset, literacy and intercultural communication skills. It will also address how to leverage technology and improve humanity for all.
column7: Recognize global diversity trends and their impact on the education industry.
column8: Evaluate corporate diversity/inclusion strategies for benchmarking innovative and effective programs.
column9: Practice cross-cultural competencies, including communication skills to improve teaching/learning effectiveness.

column1: Teachers: Help Students Conquer Employment, Now
column5: Brian Cunningham  (Bateman Group), Jeremy Friedman (Schoology)
column6: Starting in middle school, many students find the prospect of long-term education daunting, leading to detachment, dropouts and limited job prospects. Broward County, FL is changing the way students and teachers think about education early, through its LEEO (Linking Employment and Education Outcomes) program to ready students for - and excite them about - skilled employment after graduation. By teaching high-tech skills, connecting with mentors, and working with classmates across the world, students get the hard and soft skills they need to succeed in the workplace. Learn how expanding education beyond classroom will keep students in their seats, and how you can implement a LEEO program.
column7: Why vocational studies matter in today_s high tech world, and how skilled learning in high school can keep students in class
column8: How to engage your students with community leaders and classrooms around the world for a more impactful educational experience
column9: Which hard and soft skills will ready students for employment, and how to teach them in your classroom

column1: Teaching Rhetoric and Comp via Multimedia Texts
column5: Shawn Canney (Drew Charter School Senior Academy)
column6: The ability to read and interpret a variety of texts is becoming increasingly important.  However, as technology evolves, so does our definition of the word 'text.'  Students need to be able to read and interpret a variety of texts and incorporate them into a coherent essay.  The objective for this session is to show English teachers how technology can be used to teach writing instruction.  For example, students can analyze advertisements to determine target audience, medium, and speaker.  All of these elements are vital factors in understanding rhetoric and composition.  In addition, the use of multimedia can be extremely beneficial when working with reluctant readers and writers.
column7: Instructors will learn about the growing importance for our students to be able to decode multimedia texts.
column8: Instructors will learn how to view pieces of media and art and turn them into critical reading opportunities.
column9: Instructors will also learn how to use multimedia texts to teach different modes of writing.

column1: Teaching Teachers to Teach- say that 3 times fast
column5: Rayna Yaker (RYE Consulting), Karla Berry (Southern Illinois University )
column6: Graduate student instructors at research universities are often assigned teaching appointments even though they have little or no teaching experience or knowledge of classroom best practices. This conversation with attendees will discuss the evolution of the pilot program at Southern Illinois University to use badges to track, share, and reward performance toward certification in teaching for graduate students. SIU's Center for Teaching Excellence and curriculum engagement from RYE Consulting will share lessons learned and facilitate discussion of how badges as a micro-certification can reinforce engagement, motivation, and progress.
column7: Understand how digital badging can capture and communicate a student's knowledge and competencies
column8: Recognize the need for more thorough professional development for graduate instructors
column9: Learn from our first pilot and now our second iteration- how to plan and map a badge program

column1: Teaching the Teachers: Keeping Faculty Current
column5: Elise Mueller (Center for Instructional Technology ), Seth Anderson (Duke Center for Instructional Technology)
column6: 2015 marked the fifteenth anniversary of the Duke University Center for Instructional Technology's Faculty Showcase, an event designed to allow faculty members to demonstrate their use of innovative technology in the classroom to their colleagues.  This highly-successful program has served as an anchor of the department's strategy for keeping faculty up-to-date on the latest trends in educational technology.  Instructional technologists and forward-thinking faculty will enjoy this look back at past successes and failures, which provides a wealth of information about how best to share faculty experiences with educational technology innovation.
column7: Explain the process of developing a successful program for sharing faculty innovation experiences.
column8: Determine which broad themes successfully encourage faculty to innovate.
column9: Evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of various faculty showcase session styles.

column1: The Promise and Peril of Technology Disruption
column5: James Whittaker (Microsoft)
column6: Children entering school today have life expectancies decades longer than our own. They face unprecedented social, environmental, economic and technological challenges. They will be performing jobs whose titles have not yet been invented and pursue careers in fields that do not now exist. The skills they will need we do not possess and yet we will prepare them for all this anyway.Join distinguished engineer and futurist James Whittaker as he dives deep into the future that our children are facing. From the leading edge of the IoT, holograms and 3D printing to the future of quantum computing and hyper-intelligent machines. Predictions are made and possibilities are discussed.
column7: Attendees will understand how developing technology will impact society and change the way people work and play.
column8: Attendees will get a better view of what their students face in the careers likely to emerge because of technological advancement.
column9: Learn how leading edge research is pushing the education needs for future generations and be challenged to enter the conversation.

column1: The why factor. Motivation with a purpose.
column5: stephanie jones (Innersouldevelopment)
column6: I want to focus on the youth, our students help them understand that they are more then what they see outside there bedroom window, more than there environment around them. Help them to understand why they do the things that they do with results that they don't want but still continue the same routine.  I want to make them understand the "Laws of Attraction" and that whatever their greatest desires are they are able to attain it. I want to speak to them about mental visualization and the powerful creative mind and teach them about the higher facilities that they have at their disposal.  And that in them lies a seed of achievement and whatever the mind conceives and believe they can achieve.
column7: Human behavior- 3% of American actually think majority of us do things routinely we have a certain way we live our lives with negative consequences.
column8: Paradigm- These multitudes of habits, our core belief of life, they dictate our logic and our thoughts bringing us the results we get.
column9: How the mind works- This is very crucial, understanding the true nature of one self what makes us tick. Our thoughts determine who we are.

column1: Transformational Learning with Open Ed Resources
column5: Natalia Arredondo (SOLE Central ), Nishitha Andra (Skybrige Academy)
column6: Much has been explored about open education resources (OER) since Dr. Mitra_s TED talk, _Hole in the Wall Experiment._ OER are breaking all norms of learning in classrooms and providing the foundation for transformational experiences. During this session we will discuss the opportunities OER offer, and practiced pedagogical frameworks for using OER to promote student directed learning. You will hear directly from the classrooms of a pioneering progressive school, Skybridge Academy, and from around the world through the School in the Cloud, Dr. Mitra_s Self Organizing Learning Environments (SOLE) project. Sure to be a riveting conversation about evolution of classrooms and education.
column7: Pedagogical framework for using OER to design student directed and inquiry based learning.
column8: Exploring the new definition of the relationship between students and educators.
column9: Best practices for using OER

column1: Using Interaction Technology to Transform Learning
column5: Juraj Holub (sli.do)
column6: When technology is integrated seamlessly into the classroom, students become more engaged and empowered. They gain more control over their own participation and learning as well. Effective tech integration changes the class dynamics and enables student active learning. Don't come to learn, come to create and experience the interactive learning environment that you can build into your own classrooms. We'll explore the potential of live polls, digital crowd-sourcing strategies and elicit a peer-to-peer discussion.Join this session led by two interaction specialists to gain hands-on experience with the interactive tech tools and learn techniques for enhancing student learning.
column7: Learn how to integrate digital interaction tools seamlessly into your class design.
column8: Discover how to use live polls to encourage active learning and receive timely feedback.
column9: Learn how to build collaborative learning session with digital crowd-sourcing tools.

column1: Using Time to Its Fullest: 365/24/7 Learning
column5: Rachel Soto (Verona Schoolhouse)
column6: Kairos is Greek for: "the perfect, delicate, crucial moment; the fleeting rightness of time and place that creates the opportune atmosphere for action, words, or movement." Despite profound changes in technology, family schedules, economic pressures, and workplace demands, most students still attend schools with time constraints that don't account for these changes. These constraints create serious limitations and ignore much of what we know about how students learn and where learning happens. When all parties are empowered with tools and knowledge to recognize that every moment holds within it an opportunity for growth, time can be unlocked and used to its fullest.
column7: Explore "time suckers" in relation to school/education as experienced by students, families, and educators.
column8: Explore methods of interaction between students, parents, and educators that have used time efficiently and produced effective results.
column9: Explore meaningful ways to develop intrinsic and self-motivated ownership within students, parents, and educators.

column1: VARK: 4 Letters That Spell Out  Online Training
column5: Susan Brattberg (Global eTraining)
column6: Reading or watching video alone does very little to help retention, engagement and interactivity with the learning material. The VARK model is being revisited in the context on online training and education, as a personalized approach to general knowledge. This talk will explain VARK in the context of corporate and software eTraining, and critically assess its advantages. Topics discussed include the future of online training, the importance of understanding learning styles and the productivity gains form effective learning. For your training to _fit like a glove,_ it should be your own VARK glove you_re trying on.
column7: Describe and explain the elements of the VARK learning model
column8: Understand the practical application of using VARK for increased retention
column9: Understand the links between efficient learning and increased productivity

column1: What are we looking at and thinking?
column5: Christopher Jennings (Metropolitan State University of Denver)
column6: Eye tracking and brain wave analysis technology have been used by Researchers, UX Designers, Game Designers and Marketing/Advertising Professionals for several years now. How about using eye tracking and brain wave analysis technology as teaching tools? This session will illustrate how eye tracking and brain wave technologies can be used to teach and develop professionals in photography, news media layout, filmmaking, aviation as well as design professions. The session will present video and image examples of how we learn from what our audience, or professionals at various levels, are really looking at and thinking through the use of eye tracking and brain wave technology feedback.
column7: Illustrate the use of eye tracking and brain wave activity as a teaching tool.
column8: Discuss the data available from eye tracking and brain wave technologies.
column9: Determine the application of eye tracking and brain wave technologies for different areas of emphasis or professions.

column1: Why Teachers Need a Community for Lesson Plans
column5: Scott Delea (Inflexion Interactive), Ami  Turner (American Federation of Teachers)
column6: It_s no secret that today_s teachers are under an immense amount of pressure. In a recent survey conducted by the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), 73% of respondents said they often find work stressful. On top of that about half a million teachers leave the profession each year. If one thing is very clear it's that teachers need help and support!Through this session, attendees will learn about different resources, such as ShareMyLesson.com, that will connect them with teachers just like them, to share ideas and lesson plans. We also plan to provide them with time management and stress-coping mechanisms.
column7: Learn different ways to connect and collaborate with other teachers
column8: Learn different ways to deal with increasing job pressure
column9: Time management and stress-coping mechanisms

column1: YouTube Education
column5: Tyler Tarver (Bauxite School District)
column6: This session will focus on creating, organizing, marketing, and sharing videos created for any aspect of the education arena, and especially schools developing or maintaining a one-to-one environment. With the emerging development of online resources, learning, and delivery, building a library of user created and/or user organized content will be key to engaging and teaching today's learner. This will explain, show, and provide practical steps for utilizing the world's largest instructional tool (in a #baller way) from an experienced and proven educator with millions of views and thousands of subscribers.
column7: How and what to publish to YouTube
column8: Marketing yourself and your school/brand
column9: Building a community online and in the classroom

column1: Changing Attitudes about Technology Integration
column5: Adam Goodman (Marble Falls ISD), Cari Orts (Marble Falls ISD)
column6: Hear an Instructional Technologist's tale of conquering a school with little technology buy-in. After multiple attempts to win over the staff, learn which method has been most effective.
column7: How to change teachers preconceived ideas of an Instructional Technologist role on campus.
column8: Assessing campus and individual technology needs.
column9: Judging where time and resources are best expended.

column1: Community Engaged Schools: The future of Education
column5: Rex Miller (mindSHIFT), Joe Tankersley (Unique Visions)
column6: Gallup reports year after year that student engagement drops from 80% in 5th grade to 40% by the 12th. Teacher training for engagement results in sporadic improvements that prove unsustainable. A system where decision makers are disconnected from their stakeholders and processes are silo'd, mechanical and fragmented is designed to create disengagement. These conditions can be changed. The big idea is that community engagement creates engaged schools. This conclusion was reached by more than 70 educators, practitioners and business leaders after 18 months of hands-on exploration of how schools in some of the most challenging conditions created high engagement and superior results.
column7: To understand the difference and importance between creating individual capital (teacher training) and social capital (community engagement).
column8: To uncover the hidden values, attitudes behaviors and habits that may be perpetuating these conditions in your school and strategies to reverse them.
column9: To see and experience some of the tools and methods used to create community engaged schools.

column1: Do it Now: Our Future Depends on Personalization
column5: Anthony Kim (Education Elements)
column6: The pace of change is happening at a faster rate than ever before with technology. Yet our education system prevent us from being more responsive to this dynamic condition.What are the jobs of the future? Where will technological automation and the workforce meet? How can schools be more responsive to the future needs of our society?Based on the Personalized Learning Playbook, this session will provide participants with actionable ideas to take back to their districts and build up support for personalized learning.
column7: Participants will understand that personalized learning is an imperative.
column8: Participants will be able to build a case for personalized learning.
column9: Participants will leave with a new mindset around preparing students for the future.

column1: Engaged Learning in a Disengaged System
column5: Jack Hess (Institute for Coalition Building), Rex Miller (mindSHIFT)
column6: There are four primary resources that empower learning; funding, technology, well-trained teachers and social capital. The research of the K12 MindShift Initiative, made up of more than 30 educational organizations and 70 leaders, found the least explored of the four is also the most effective and resilient resource, social capital. We will share the results of communities that have a developed stakeholder approach and learn how they built it along with challenges they overcame. We will explain how this model can be adopted by any school regardless of their current state. Schools with high social capital displayed the following traits: a clear reason, desire, ability and setting to learn.
column7: How social capital create the conditions for an engaged learning environment and multiplies the effects of all other resources.
column8: Understanding the what, why and how for creating social capital.
column9: To get first hand experience with some of the methodologies and tools from some of the top practitioners in creating community engagement.

column1: FERPA for a Changing World
column5: Michael Hawes (U.S. Department of Education), Kathleen Styles (U.S. Department of Education)
column6: FERPA, the main federal law that protects student privacy, may be over 40 years old, but there has been a lot of activity at the federal, state, and local level on the issue of student privacy over the last year. This interactive session, led by the U.S. Department of Education's Chief Privacy Officer, will discuss recent legislative, regulatory, and policy developments relating to student privacy, and what they mean for you.
column7: Attendees will get an update on recent federal activity relating to student privacy.
column8: Attendees will learn how legislative and regulatory changes to FERPA may affect their use of student data.
column9: This session will highlight available resources that can assist educators, administrators, and vendors with their responsible use of student data.

column1: Fried: Keeping Teachers from Burning Out
column5: Vicki Ventura (EnvisionEd Consulting, LLC), Terice T Schneider (EnvisionEd Consulting, LLC)
column6: School systems spend countless hours and dollars providing professional development and technical training so that all teachers can instruct from the same bank of knowledge. When great educators quit because of burnout, everyone in the school, and truly in the profession, suffers.  What if we could prevent burnout? What if we could do it with a meager budget? Is it possible? Let_s talk about what works, including the latest brain research showing how humans can remain happy and productive in their chosen field.
column7: Participants will determine and discuss the signs of burnout.
column8: Participants will analyze what has worked in the past as well as the most current brain research on remaining happy and productive in the workplace.
column9: Participants will be able to devise a tentative plan for helping prevent burnout in their school system.

column1: Generation Z, seeking careers in STEM
column5: Mary Laturnau (Project Lead the Way), Suzanne Snow (University of New Hampshire InterOperability Laboratory (UNH-IOL))
