column6: Generation Z- Soon after making contact with loved ones a new born immediately enters the world of technology, as soon as the first mobile device takes a photo or measures it's vitals. After 5 years of handling and experiencing such technology, these kids have mastered many mobile apps and games, most likely have created code or their own robot and, have been able to connect with their devices as if it were a family member. GenZer's  grow up getting advice and answers from technology. Let's collaborate to bring their knowledge and creativity together and provide GenZer's with hands on learning opportunities and the social culture they need to succeed and make the world a better place!
column7: What do GenZer's know and why does it matter?Attendees will learn more about how Gen Zer's learn and what equity they can bring to an organization.
column8: How to connect with Gen Z- Attendees will learn how to make connections, foster creativity & social skills by coaching and providing opportunities.
column9: Create and or Discover opportunities for GenZLearn how to make education part of your business and how to find the right talent in Gen Z.

column1: ICYMI: Becoming a Social Media Ninja
column5: Catherine Wedgwood (Getting Smart), Caroline Vander Ark (Getting Smart)
column6: Do you know what the majority of these mean: BRB, PRT, Pressed, TBT, Beetweet, TL;DR? If you do, then you are ready to let us take you to the next level of smart social media application. We_ll provide strategies and best practice for a variety of social media platforms available, then work with you to identify and commit to implementing at least one S.M.A.R.T. next step toward enhancing your personal brand and improving online engagement. Bring your device to this session to play along!
column7: An overview of best practices for using different social media platforms, with a personal _next step_ takeaway.
column8: Take your social practices to the next level and become a social media thought leader for your colleagues.
column9: Discover a new platform you may not be using that could help build your personal brand, professional network and PD opportunities.

column1: Nonprofit Digitarians: A Love Story
column5: Adriana Edwards-Johnson (Pioneer Library System), Hayley Moore (Phase 2)
column6: Have you ever seen a nonprofit attempt to tap into their digital potential? They follow all the _useful_ free how-tos out there _ yet they lack business savviness to take it to the next level. For a nonprofit, the potential to expand services is almost within reach, but you are missing that secret link to bring it to fruition. Partnerships between nonprofits and tech companies can be a success. Sure, challenges will emerge when addressing the needs of a sector with limited resources, like libraries, museums and schools. This session will provide insights into the creation of a one of a kind library mobile application specifically designed to appeal to a growing digitarian library community.
column7: How to convey the value in building complex solutions to nonprofit organization's stakeholders.
column8: How to work with third party vendors to build support around an integrated solution.
column9: How to ensure adoption rates for the solution are high to maximize return on investment.

column1: School Based Management/Shared Decision Making.
column5: Allan Bonilla (Corwin Press)
column6: Learn how to implement a school-wide culture of Shared Decision Making, leading to the development of teacher leaders. Smart delegation leading to complete collaboration and impactful change is the foundation of School Based Management. Evidence based strategies from a successful Miami school will be shared by a Miami-Dade Principal of the Year.
column7: Participants will understand the positive benefits of SBM/SDM.
column8: Participants will learn how to initiate a SBM/SDM model at their own schools.
column9: Participants will learn the components of a SBM/SDM model which leads to a collaborative school environment.

column1: School Emergency Plans, The Choreography of Action
column5: Albert Samano III (Fortress, Inc.), Triana Fontecha (Fort Bend Independent School District)
column6: This session motivates and trains educators in the area of school emergency planning by:- Presenting elements of a sustainable school emergency plan and developing plans that adhere to best practices  - Identifying the types of teams that are required for developing an emergency plan, the types of personnel on each team and the best manner to set up teams to ensure success-Empowering educators to a call to action _Educators will be duty-bound to return to their schools and say, _I know what a strong program should look like and I want to help build one at my school._
column7: Participants will support a sense of diligence to advance a school emergency plan, as well as the overarching planning process.
column8: Participants will understand the fundamental elements of a school emergency plan as they are developed utilizing industry best practices.
column9: Participants will understand the types of teams required, and the successful manner for setting up teams needed to develop a school emergency plan.

column1: Social Media: Legal Pitfalls and Best Practices
column5: Lena  Engel (Rogers, Morris, & Grover), Diana Benner (Texas Computer Education Association)
column6: Social media is here to stay but knowing how it can impact your district is critical. Join an attorney and an educator for a candid conversation surrounding the top legal pitfalls of social media for school districts as well as best practices for implementing social media in your district. Topics such as managing the use of social media through district-owned technology resources, implementing social media and developing policies regarding its use, and responding legally to student and employee use of social media off campus will be discussed.
column7: Discuss legal pitfalls related to social media in schools.
column8: Gain an understanding of the legal considerations related to the use of social media by students and employees both on and off campus.
column9: Examine resources for developing policies regarding social media use.

column1: Software tools that talk for teachers that inspire
column5: Gautam Sethi (Douglas County (Colo.) School District), Chris Lawson (Douglas County (Colo.) School District)
column6: InspirED Innovation is an integrated suite of web-based software tools to assist teachers and leaders in delivering a World Class Education to more than 67,000 students. There are currently tools for instructional planning, certified staff evaluation, professional development, student learning objective tracking. Originating from dynamic teacher and leader dashboards, InspirED Innovation is built to the specifications of the educational paradigm shifters in Douglas County (Colo.) School District.Core Conversation focus will be on unpacking the methodology of successfully designing, developing, and delivering iterative, custom software solutions in the public education space.
column7: Learn how the 3rd largest school district in Colorado is forging new ground with a custom-developed suite of tools for teachers and leaders
column8: Unpack the methodology and practices that have engendered continued success and stakeholder buy-in
column9: Consider whether a "build-your-own" approach is the best option for you and your district

column1: Taming the external forces of institutional change
column5: Michael Reeser (Texas State Technical College), Gayle Wooten (TSTC)
column6: This session idea is the combining of both research-based information and the first hand experience of transforming an educational institution.  The session is based on the transformational change of Texas State Technical College and a dissertation research project involving statistical testing of an organizational change theory based on data collected from TSTC.  Together, the presenters will provide the statistical basis leading to the a-ha moment of how leaders struggle with change in educational institutions, as well as providing attendees a first hand account of how a leader can meet the challenges.
column7: Attendees will learn about recent research that supports the role of external forces on the leaders of educational institutions.
column8: Attendees will learn from a leader of Texas' technical college system about how to work with the external environment for the good of the institution.
column9: Attendees will learn about implementing transformational change within an higher education institution.

column1: Using a Flat Organizational Structure in Education
column5: Reina Utsunomiya (NYCDOE), Natalie Ferrell (New York City Dept of Education)
column6: How do you tackle an issue like inequity when you are just one team within a larger hierarchy? How do we avoid becoming stuck in silos and losing sight of the larger goal for our kids?  Join us for a dialogue on how a team focusing on redesigning high schools in NYC is moving to a more _flat_ structure and the impact it has on staff and team culture. You will learn basic concepts of a _flat_ organizational structure, what the team has been test-driving, and explore how you can apply these tenets and re-energize your own organization.
column7: Learn about the concepts of a _flat_ organizational structure and what conditions to have in place for it to work.
column8: Learn strategies used by an NYC team to shift decision-making and management, and review sample exercises used to in their transition process.
column9: Explore if 'going flat' will make the impact you want for your work. Learn steps to begin infusing aspects of it that's meaningful for your colleagues

column1: What if Everyone Wanted to be a Teacher?
column5: David Rosenberg (Education Resource Strategies)
column6: What if teaching were the most attractive, compelling profession in the nation?For all our progress in education reform, we have failed to make teaching a fundamentally more appealing profession. Teacher pipelines are shrinking. Attrition, including among top teachers, is rising. And student need continues to grow.Using real teacher data, this session will explore the costs of failing to retain top teachers; how we can pre-empt their departure; and how system leaders can forge a path toward becoming "employers of choice" for great teachers.We have the potential to make teaching the most attractive, compelling profession in the nation. For our students, we must. Will we succeed?
column7: Understand the costs - for students and for the system - of failing to attract and retain highly effective teachers
column8: Explore an approach for understanding what differentiates the experience of happy/loyal teachers from miserable teachers in a given system
column9: Be prepared to develop and initiate strategies with the potential to make your system the most compelling place for great teachers to work

column1: Who Cares About Your School's Brand?
column5: Dan Day (Brandtenders: Your People Are Your Brand.)
column6: Think branding is just for companies?Your school has the same presence in the community as the nearest Starbucks, McDonald's or Chipotle, and it continually faces the perceptions--good or otherwise--of others.How do you communicate the realities of your institution, your BRAND?Dan Day takes you on a journey from legendary brands to the most important brand in the world: you.Learn how to craft a Brand Statement for your organization and help people communicate that message in their own style, creating engagement that earns results by making sure your brand stands out in the communities you serve.
column7: Learn the three building blocks to a strong localized brand for your school
column8: Learn to build a Brand Statement for your school, and how individual contributors can sync up with that message
column9: Learn to communicate your school's brand effectively and consistently by identifying and adapting to the four communication _styles_

column1: 3D Printing: A Learning Space with Open Access
column5: Douglas Higgins (Colgate University), Sarah Kunze (Colgate University)
column6: This session will investigate topics related to the creation of learning spaces that support open access to 3D modeling and printing. We will consider key factors (e.g., application, physical space, equipment, support, etc.) that influence the development of these spaces. Our talk will kick off with a brief overview of our institution's experiences followed by a guided group discussion. Grab a mic to share you opinion, or interact with Twitter to submit questions and / or comments, and engage in the conversation. Take this opportunity to get your questions answered, or share the lessons you have learned.
column7: Discuss key factors to consider for the implementation of open-access learning spaces for 3D modeling and printing.
column8: Identify best practices for a successful open-access 3D modeling and printing learning space.
column9: Connect with colleagues, and develop a network of institutions and individuals, to share information and resources around 3D modeling and printing.

column1: Agency and inquiry in project-based learning
column5: Alan Snyder (Lehigh University), Sarah Stanlick (Lehigh University)
column6: We will focus on creating learning environments that shift student identity from knowledge consumer to active and purposeful seeker and problem-solver.  We will share evidence from our own work that an unleashing of agency, along with habits of mind typically associated with deep involvement in research, can be achieved in by immersion in a conducive environment and setting the expectation that students determine their own goals and their own paths to achieve them. We will then invite participants to explore how they can construct environments and establish practices that awaken both inquiry and enterprise in students and can be brought to scale in their institutional settings.
column7: Participants will recognize how students' innate interest in effecting positive change creates context and motivation for deeper learning.
column8: Participants will identify conditions under which student ownership gives rise to full accountability to their work and to each other.
column9: Participants will leave with enhanced understanding of conditions they wish to create at their institutions and critical questions to be considered.

column1: Building a community of STEAMers
column5: Kathy Wicks (The Urbana Free Library), Adriana O'Brien (Wolfram Research)
column6: What does a STEAM community look like?  How do you inspire and lead your community members and colleagues to form one?Explore ideas and proven concepts with dedicated community members (The Urbana Free Library and Wolfram Research), who have provided a wide range of successful workshops to increase awareness of STEAM topics. Through joint collaboration and independently, these organizations have supported 2-hour, half-day, 1-week, and 8-week long workshops for elementary and secondary students. In this session, we_ll go from top to bottom to address how to develop, implement and market programs down to the nitty-gritty of activities used to engage and inspire students.
column7: Review successful strategies for implementing STEM-based activities for a variety of learning environments.
column8: Discuss approaches to introducing coding to elementary and secondary students.
column9: Explore methods of how to increase community involvement in STEM-based programs.

column1: Co-Design: Campus, Interrupted
column5: Bree Trevena (Creative Victoria), Alexandra Lawlor (University of Melbourne)
column6: Collaborative design and operation of education spaces can open unexpected doors to intuitive, connected and resilient learning. They can also be a tough sell in a climate of shrinking resources and growing need.This conversation navigates the tensions and possibilities of going a step beyond inviting students, academics, campus professionals and community members to a take seat at the table and instead offering to let them set it. Speakers will take participants through case studies of artists embedded in STEMM research hubs, Aboriginal communities sitting down with campus architects and exactly what happens when you ask the community to set a university's strategic direction.
column7: Understand how co-design can empower students, teachers and professional staff to co-produce high quality collaborative learning outcomes.
column8: Evaluate the short, medium and long-term impact of supported co-design on learning and engagement for students, teachers and professional staff.
column9: Challenge normative design and process of _effective_ and _efficient_ learning and auxiliary spaces.

column1: Dickinson Makes - Connecting Campus Makerspaces
column5: Brenda Landis (Dickinson College), Andrew Petrus (Dickinson College)
column6: Do you want to build a makerspace? Chances are, you probably already have multiples ones on campus. By connecting spaces your school has already invested in, you can make resources on campus more accessible, streamline the training process and build community between faculty, staff and students while encouraging a culture of making and entrepreneurial thinking. Dickinson Makes (#dsonmakes) is an online resource highlighting campus makerspaces, organizing information about equipment and training available and organizing related workshops and talks. An overview of the program will be presented followed by an audience discussion about how it can be replicated elsewhere.
column7: Outline core elements (equipment, expertise, sample projects) in a variety of makerspaces already found at many schools.
column8: Analyze how Dickinson approached this initiative including timeline, outreach, prototyping and piloting.
column9: Examine how other schools would be able to replicate this endeavor through discussion with audience attendees.

column1: Digital Learning In and Ouside of School
column5: Chris Dede (Harvard Graduate School of Education), Donna Alvermann (University of Georgia)
column6: Two leading researchers discuss current trends in digital learning_both in school and out. As Donna Alvermann will describe, many teens have rich on-line lives, using their devices for self-expression, civic action, debate, and community building. To Chris Dede, those qualities_engagement, purpose, collaboration_are precisely what make digital tools so promising for classroom use: Teachers are more effective when they have tools that help them engage students in debate, problem-solving, collaboration, and reflection. For both speakers, important questions remain: In the digital world, how much can be learned on one_s own, and where does skilled classroom instruction fit into the picture?
column7: Review and discuss recent research on adolescents' out-of-school uses of digital technology to learn, express themselves, and connect.
column8: Review and discuss recent research on the ways in which digital media can empower classroom teachers to help students learn deeply.
column9: Generate lively discussion of the ways in which students' in- and out-of-school uses of digital media do and do not complement one another.

column1: Failing Sucessfully in a School: True Confessions
column5: Kayli  McAuley (Skybridge Academy), Ariel Dochstader Miller  (Skybrige Academy)
column6: Many are talking about the value of failure in education but it is rarely discussed in terms of implementation in school environments. In this session, we will explore the necessary ingredients that allow failure to be an invaluable learning experience. A school director and student will present their points of view about what embracing failure means and what it actually looks like on the ground to have academic vitality and the celebration of failure go hand in hand. The audience will be encouraged to share their own stories and we will outline strategies to fail successfully in schools together.
column7: Parents and educators will learn about the failure learning curve
column8: How to cultivate an environment where students begin to take responsibility for their own learning process
column9: How to cultivating resilient learners who are comfortable in expanding their knowledge and experience through failure

column1: From Library to Innovation and Design Center
column5: Marci Milius (Douglas County School District), Linda Conway (Douglas County School District)
column6: In Douglas County Schools there is a ground swell of transformations going on. Join us in a conversation about how we transformed our district level library into an Innovation and Design Center and expanded our services. Learn how to get started and create a movement to shift environments and instructional practices. Discussions will also include how learning environments support new instructional practices. We will dissect some transformation projects completed so that you develop ideas to transform your spaces to support your modern learners. This conversation will help you create a plan and a vision for design to better accommodate the needs of learners.
column7: Participants will be able to develop a vision to start a movement for transformation of learning environments.
column8: Participants will learn how they can better design for modern learners.
column9: Participants will understand how learning environments support new instructional practices.

column1: Hi Tech + High Touch in the Writing Classroom
column5: Carol Barash (Story2), Eileen Murphy (ThinkCerca)
column6: Neuroscience, cognitive science, and technology are rapidly expanding both writing fluency and the teaching of writing. Through the data and experience of two programs that provide cognitive science based online writing interventions, this conversation explores how classroom teachers can simultaneously achieve measurable improvements in students_ writing and personalize writing instruction for diverse students and learning styles.
column7: Participants will learn specific ways that technology drives measurable writing improvements.
column8: Participants will explore how technology drives personalized teaching of writing in diverse classrooms.
column9: Participants will discuss future developments in the use of technology to teach writing in K12 and postsecondary classrooms.

column1: How to Kill the Promise of OER in 3 Easy Steps
column5: John Ittelson (California State University Monterey Bay), Brian  Ausland (Navigation North Learning)
column6: Yes, OER is a hot topic. But hot quickly turns to hype, when bad actors, unwitting evangelists, and policy wonks far from the classroom try to get out in front of promising practice and bear its banner. The need to define, evaluate, and vet OER on behalf of educators is an exercise taken up by those that do not understand its core construct and value. OER is an unruly and evolving ecosystem for sure. But teachers, long-trained in the ancient arts of scavenging and adapting are adept operators if given access to simple search, assembly and delivery tools instead of rubrics, guidelines, and vetting processes. Let's enable educator's role in enriching this ecosystem, and remove the polluters.
column7: Identify how some national efforts to support OER are unwittingly undermining its efficacy and implementation.
column8: Identify trends and methodologies used to combine teacher creativity with rich, digital resources to fully optimize OER's promise.
column9: Demonstrate the resulting OER aggregation and assembly models from a few programs that designed the right blend of educators and resources.

column1: How to Start Innovative High School Internships
column5: Jodi Kennedy (Gallup), Jim Collison (Gallup)
column6: College grads have found themselves underprepared and underemployed due to lack of experience. Tech jobs are going unfilled because of underqualified workers. How do we bridge this gap? Gallup_s Education Taskforce High School Innovation Program (GET HIP) bridges this gap through internships for high school students. GET HIP consists of 12 Saturday lessons spread throughout the school year followed by a 6 week paid summer internship. Students learn programming techniques while gaining valuable business experience. During this session, you will learn how to partner with local schools and businesses to create your own internship program in a practical, beneficial way to your community.
column7: Why internships for millennials will help grow your organization and your students
column8: How to partner education with business to practically deploy a standard internship model in 18 weeks
column9: Now go and benefit from our mistakes: Lessons learned in the first 2 years

column1: Scaling Down: The Microschool Movement in Austin
column5: Teri Sperry (Alt Ed Austin)
column6: As thought leaders and policymakers publicly debate the best ways to scale up innovation, microschools are quietly and effectively educating children in intentionally scaled-down environments. The microschool concept recently entered the public consciousness, thanks in part to celebrities like Elon Musk and James Cameron, who have made headlines with their own radically small schools. In this Core Conversation we will discuss two questions: How did Austin become a thriving hub of microschooling, where independent educators, representing many diverse models, serve students in dozens of small, personal learning environments? And what can the rest of the education world learn from them?
column7: Understand the conditions that make Austin's climate so favorable for the emergence of diverse and successful microschools
column8: Identify the primary factors that determine whether a microschool will thrive
column9: Discuss how microschool innovations can inform best practices in other educational environments

column1: SciTech Kids: Building Innovators in STEM
column5: Kim Magloire (SciTech Kids), Gabrielle Nafie (SciTech Kids )
column6: SciTech Kids nurtures a love of STEAM in children through engaging, hands-on experiences which unlock their imagination. We spark their innate creativity as they experiment, tinker, and create alongside scientists, engineers and designers who change how kids see themselves through mentoring in our after-school programs workshops and camp. Our kids launch satellites in space, 3D print food and design wearable tech devices. Join us and get hands-on experience from our founder and one of our SciTech Kids Ambassador, winner of Disney's Tomorrowland xPrize Challenge as they show you how to incorporate innovative STEAM activities into your schools that transform the lives of children.
column7: Demonstrate how to implement actual STEAM activities that work in our programs throughout New York City schools.
column8: Discuss how mentoring using STEM experts has a profound impact on the lesson, especially children from underserved or underrepresented populations
column9: Show how peer mentoring, using our SciTech Kids Ambassadors, inspireschildren to learn STEAM and enter STEAM contests and challenges

column1: Show Students Limitless Possibilities w/3D Design
column5: Torie Anderson (Autodesk, Inc.)
column6: Learn how educators and mentors alike are using free* access to software with free curricula made available through the Autodesk Design Academy and Design Academy iTunes U courses to inspire students in science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics subjects.
column7: Use Design Thinking to develop appropriate design parameters.
column8: Describe the importance of sketching and drawing to engineering design and other iterative processes.
column9: Utilize mathematics and dimensioning to establish viable design limits.

column1: Student Engagement in STEM using CubeSats in Space
column5: Maureen Silva (Ardusat)
column6: How do we get students excited about all areas of STEM? Give them access to Space! We provide hands-on tools for students that are creating, discovering, and analyzing data to greatly enhance their interest in STEM. We_ll share what we learned from our students of all ages, who created and ran their own real-world science experiments directly from CubeSats in Space. We_ll also be giving away an Ardusat Space Kit!
column7: Teach K-12 educators about the availability of Space innovation in the classroom
column8: Inspire educators to try more hands on Science experiments in the classroom with an emphasis on Data Visualization
column9: Discover the create minds students possess when given the opportunity to expand their reach in the classroom

column1: Mindset, Grit, and the Noncognitive Revolution
column5: Janna Peskett (Mindset Works), David Dockterman (Harvard Graduate School of Education)
column6: Two educators_deeply experienced in applying mindset research_lead a conversation with participants about the importance of developing a growth mindset in students and teachers, exhibiting grit, and how much "noncognitive" skills really matter for student success. Participants will reflect on their own mindsets, work with each other to articulate the gritty behaviors of good learners, explore ways to measure noncognitive beliefs and skills, and share mechanisms for infusing growth mindset thinking into rigorous content learning. The conversation structure will allow participants to learn from each other while clarifying definitions and understanding.
column7: develop a deep understanding of academic mindsets, including growth mindset
column8: establish a framework for the relationship between beliefs and academic behaviors, like grit
column9: come away with practical steps for infusing mindset into teaching and learning

column1: #noncognitivemetacognitivesoftskillsforsuccess
column5: Sarah Lench (Center for Innovation in Education)
column6: #Noncognitive, #metacognitive, or #21stCentury: whatever your nom du jour may be, "soft" skills are hot right now. But how do we translate this laudatory  hashtag rhetoric into good teaching or sound policy? We_ve been working with teachers, decision makers, and researchers from across the country to look at the development of a set of skills and dispositions essential for postsecondary success: collaboration, creativity, communication, and self-directed learning. In this session, we_ll talk about the challenges and opportunities educators are facing as they integrate these skills into curriculum and instruction, and we_ll address the system changes needed to accomplish this work.
column7: What are the contexts, conditions, cultures, and policies that foster the development of essential skills and dispositions? Inhibit them?
column8: How do we make visible - and assessable - the performance of essential skills and dispositions?
column9: How can essential skills and dispositions inform competency-based and personalized learning reforms?

column1: On-Tech and On-Task
column5: Allison Bruhn (University of Iowa), Ted Hasselbring (Vanderbilt University)
column6: Self-monitoring is a time-tested intervention for many students with behavior problems. However, self-monitoring via technology has not evolved in classrooms as it has in public health medicine. We will discuss several studies that show how middle school students with reading and behavioral problems used technology-based self-monitoring to improve behavior and academic skills_and how technology can improve existing self-monitoring methods to increase students' academic engagement.
column7: Learn how academic learning time is a function of engaged time, instructional time, and allocated time.
column8: Learn how self-monitoring can improve engaged time, and in turn, academic learning time.
column9: Learn how technology can enhance basic self-monitoring.

column1: Top-Notch Teaching for Struggling Kids
column5: Rachel Brody (Teach for America), Mark  Griffin (Understood)
column6: Kids with learning and attention issues are as smart as their peers, but they often don't reach their potential. 1 in 5 will drop out of school. Of kids in special education, only 60% will graduate from high school_and the vast majority of them have learning and attention issues. Join an expert from Teach For America and the founder of a leading private school for kids with learning disabilities for an interactive discussion: What are best methods to teach struggling students? What are the mindsets we need to cultivate among teachers to help kids with these issues succeed? What are the barriers to helping teachers understand both the issues and the proven techniques?
column7: Define critical teaching mindsets for kids with learning and attention issues
column8: Discuss how we can move toward a framework for teaching kids with learning and attention issues that is broadly applicable
column9: Identify best practices for teaching kids with learning and attention issues

column1: Are we over-testing PK-8th grade students?
column5: Todd Nesloney (The 3 Tech Ninjas), Shea Stanfield-McGarrah (Hurst-Euless-Bedford ISD)
column6: A debate is raging on whether or not over-testing is creating a toxic culture in schools. Is this in fact the case?Which educators believe that testing creates a data-rich environment that aids learning? Who believes the current testing environment can be improved? How?What solutions exist or could be created to reduce the feeling of over-testing in schools?
column7: Understand the impact of data and testing on PK-8th grade students
column8: Determine areas where assessments can be improved
column9: Explore good alternatives to today's testing environment and protocol

column1: SIF, LTI, WTF?
column5: Karen Fuller (Klein Independent School District), Jeff Patterson (Gaggle), Kevin Hogan (Tech & Learning)
column6: Join a lively discussion on the importance, or insignificance, of open frameworks and standards in edtech, including why attempts have failed in the past, what's ahead, how to ensure a return on investment, and what school districts really consider when evaluating vendors.
column7: What do industry standards, such as Schools Interoperability Framework (SIF), Common Cartridge and Learning Tools Interoperability (LTI), really mean?
column8: Should schools and vendors embrace these and/or other open frameworks and standards?
column9: How do K-12 education leaders view open frameworks and standards in edtech?

column1: How College is Failing Programmers & Entrepreneurs
column5: Nicholas Hahn (Austin Spark League), Dora  El¡as McAllister (Independent/Self-employed), Edwin Finch (Lignite)
column6: For programmers, designers, and entrepreneurs, the college track far less effective than real world experience. This debate puts a spotlight on the typical undergrad teaching methods being used in educating the next generation of creators. In the hot job markets of design and coding, the lack of hands-on and real-world experience for these trades is limiting the ability of recent graduates from landing their first career jobs. Should these students be focused on entrance into _the best colleges_ or should they be focused on finding the path in life where what they love, what they_re good at, and what pays well align? Come see 3 distinct perspectives discuss this emerging topic.
column7: Describe factors that increase the chance that students will find what_s important to them before they graduate from high school.
column8: Compare and contrast approaches to career exploration.
column9: Describe the approaches to learning that may be most appropriate for student to develop a robust core of 21st-century competencies.

column1: Why Film School?
column5: Sebastian  Crank (Emerson College), Stephen  Burnette (Mccallum High School), Tania Romero (Anderson High School)
column6: This panel will discuss the benefits and drawbacks of going to film school. The panel will be comprised of two high school students who are pro and against going to film school, two students currently at film schools (on is at Emerson and the other at UT), a high school teacher who teaches audio video production and one instructor at the Art Institute of Austin.  The discussion will address questions and concerns about the quality of the education that students receive at film school in contrast to going straight into the field and finding internships or jobs.
column7: Open the discussion about what students should expect from film school and what they should look for in a school.
column8: Discuss the benefits and drawbacks of going to film school.
column9: Discuss options for students not pursuing film school.

column1: From the university to the job market - Europe&US
column5: to be defined to be defined (University in the US), Veronica Sullo (Bocconi University), Marco Eylert (Johns Hopkins University - School of Advanced International Studies)
column6: 15 years after the Bologna Process was implemented in Europe and changed the higher education landscape more towards an American system, one of the major goals has still not been achieved _ the closer linkage of the Universities with the job market. Employers criticize the too theoretical academic teaching and the unpreparedness of young European graduates to enter the workforce, while students feel their job chances after the undergraduate degree are still limited. While governmental initiatives have been started to closer interlink the universities with the job market, American best practices could serve as role models to improve the orientation and offerings of universities.
column7: What are the university structures in the US that encourage practical learning and the collection of hands-on experiences during the curriculum?
column8: Is it a European mindset issue to consider undergrads to be unprepared for the job market, or is the American education more job market-oriented?
column9: What American best practices bridge the gap between the academic world and the job market and hence facilitate the students' entry into the workforce?

column1: Hernandez v Kim:Innovation in Charters v Districts
column5: Alex Hernandez (Charter School Growth Fund), Julia Freeland (Christensen Institute), Anthony Kim (Education Elements)
column6: Boxing gloves are on and the bets are starting early.  Join us for a fun-spirited debate around innovation and scale in charters vs. districts.Adoption of personalized learning with technology has begun to take off. While charters were early adopters, districts are now starting to transform at scale.  Alex Hernandez and Anthony Kim will debate who will rule supreme in the race  to innovate in charter schools and school districts. Moderated by Julia Freeland, we expect a bare knuckle bar brawl.Audience makes the call: who will win and why.
column7: Understand the history of personalized learning adoption over the past several years.
column8: Determine what supports and prevents scale in districts and charters.
column9: Choose where scale is the most likely to occur successfully and think about replicating conditions for success in all environments.

column1: Bachelor's Degree Required?
column5: Jared Huke (ChaiOne), NICK  HAHN (AUSTIN SPARK LEAGUE), Dora Elias McAllister (Self-employed)
column6: What if a high school student has developed the practical skills necessary to pursue a job with a large tech company, a hot start startup, or even to found their own business? Should they still go to college? Some say no; that employers are not looking for college degrees, but instead the quality of what have students have built. Others say that students that don't go to college will miss out. Who's right? During this debate, technologists argue that the format of the undergraduate college system is not suited for "creator" careers (design, development and entrepreneurship. A higher education professional argues that a degree is not optional, and is required for 21st century jobs.
column7: Describe the costs and benefits of a bachelor's degrees for technology-focused teenagers.
column8: Compare and contrast views on whether a bachelor's degree is  "worth it."
column9: Describe the approaches to learning that may be most appropriate for student to develop a robust core of 21st-century competencies.

column1: CEO Showdown: How will schools buy ebooks in 2020?
column5: Jason Singer (Curriculet), Gideon Stein (LightSail Education), Sara Schapiro (Digital Promise)
column6: As schools have begun transitioning to digital classroom and school libraries, they have encountered a varied and fast-evolving market for purchasing and using digital books. School leaders express concerns about the ambiguity around the best options for schools. Leading literacy solutions LightSail and Curriculet offer two different ebook purchase options to schools _ which is best? The leader of each company will present his vision for ebook purchasing in a session moderated by Sarah Schapiro of Digital Promise.
column7: Assist K-12 decision makers in determining how to purchase eBooks
column8: Illustrate which eBook model is best for specific needs
column9: Delineate costs associated with different eBook purchasing models

column1: To 1:1 or not
column5: James Kapptie (Park 6)
column6: Schools have been trying to find the silver bullet to fix education for years. In recent years technology has provided the needed ammunition for the next shot.  After the next gadget is bought questions get asked and the next gadget comes along.  We will discuss the current 1:1 movement and what are the benefits on students as compared to purposeful technology deployments.  We will discuss what roles students, teachers and community play in technology purchases and what are possible benefits of the different technology plans.This session will be break down myths and get to facts that can help schools better use and allocate resources.
column7: Technology impact on learning
column8: Measuring ROI
column9: Career ready

column1: Good for kids? How Children's Museums Decide
column5: Carol Tang (Children's Creativity Museum), Marilee Jennings (Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose), Laura Huerta Migus (Association of Children's Museums)
column6: Children's museums serve 31M visitors annually and are distributed in urban, rural, and suburban communities across the US. These learning venues can both reflect and shape our collective vision for what childhood and good parenting looks like.So how do children's museums translate research to practice? How do we make sense of research on child development and use it to inform exhibition and programming decisions? And perhaps most importantly, how can our sector deal with the opportunities, risks, and challenges in deploying technology for young children?Hear perspectives from a children's museum, a tech museum now serving young children, and the Association of Children's Museums.
column7: Become inspired by the unique learning opportunities provided by children's museums and their role in influencing parental behavior.
column8: Using case studies, understand different perspectives and solutions for designing exhibitions and programming for young children.
column9: Gain insight into how museums balance best practices, on-going research, staff capacity, parent expectations, and market demand in decision-making.

column1: Igniting a Practice Revolution
column5: Damon Williams (Boys & Girls Clubs of America), Sal Khan (Khan Academy), David Coleman (The College Board)
column6: At SXSW 2014, the College Board announced many changes to the SAT including the unprecedented partnership with Khan Academy to offer a free, personalized practice platform. This has sweeping implications for equity in our world. Students now have access to world-class tools for focused and productive practice. And dedicated practice is the key discipline required to face any endeavor students might face thereafter whether it_s botany, violin, or skateboarding. At SXSW 2016, the College Board, Khan Academy, Boys and Girls Clubs of America and  Orange County Public Schools will discuss how they teamed up to ignite a practice revolution, so that all students can know the feeling of being truly expert and accomplished.
column7: How deliberate practice based on personalized recommendations can lead to results
column8: How national partnerships are helping increase access to valuable tools
column9: How classroom work aligns to the new SAT

column1: Redesigning Learning for the 21st Century
column5: Connie Yowell (John D and Catherine T MacArthur Foundation)
column6: The digital era has ushered in a Cambrian moment of explosive change. Connected technologies are changing every aspect of our lives, including how children learn and what knowledge and skills they need to thrive in the 21st century. Connie Yowell, former Director of Education Programs at the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, is CEO of a new nonprofit designed to bring learning innovation to scale. Using digital technology to connect a city's in-school, out-of-school and online learning opportunities, it will open interest-driven pathways to college and career for all youth. The new startup will be a catalyst and convener of public, private, education and nonprofit organizations.
column7: Understand Connected Learning, a new pedagogy designed for the realities and the opportunities of the digital age.
column8: Learn how all youth can access powerful learning experiences that open doors to higher education, community service, internships and jobs.
column9: Discover new tools and resources that create learning opportunities, recognize achievements and help youth build competency and readiness for success.

column1: Silicon Valley + Education = Real Change?
column5: Max Ventilla (AltSchool)
column6: Why does Silicon Valley think it can impact education? With over $1.3 billion invested domestically in Edtech companies in 2014 alone, leading technologists and venture capitalists are placing a big bet on education. Max Ventilla, Founder/CEO of AltSchool, will debunk the hype, including applying a startup mindset to schools, empowering educators to become 21st century knowledge workers, bringing entrepreneurism into the classroom, and using technology that_s not screen time.
column7: Discuss technology_s role in empowering educators and school operators.
column8: Hear about AltSchool_s approach to building an educational ecosystem for educators and technologists to collaborate on problem-solving.
column9: Learn startup strategies for using feedback and data to drive improvement in the classroom and across schools.

column1: Indiana Jones and the Journey of Innovation
column5: Scott Ellis (The Learning Accelerator)
column6: America is on a journey of innovation to catalyze blended learning in schools nationwide. Join Scott Ellis, CEO of The Learning Accelerator, for a discussion of the progress we have made and what comes next: we have cultivated the enablers for scale like Internet connectivity and professional development, and over the coming months the focus will be on transforming teaching and learning in the classroom and then measuring impact. Bonus: discover how Indiana Jones will show us the path forward!
column7: Attendees will understand the trajectory for the national journey of innovation to design and implement blended learning.
column8: Attendees will see specific examples of implementation that will provide sufficient clarity that educators can replicate them in their schools.
column9: Attendees will see frameworks and analogies that will help them understand and describe the transformation happening across the country.

column1: Can Hip Hop Save Us? Youth & School Culture
column5: James Miles (Urban Arts Partnership), Brian  Mooney (Urban Arts Partnership), Audra The Rapper (Audra The Rapper), Mike  Render (Run the Jewels)
column6: Regardless of one_s nationality, ethnicity, and/or social class, everyone is familiar with, and has knowledge of, hip hop. Yet, hip hop culture, which is youth culture, is stigmatized, marginalized and prohibited from school settings. If youth culture is deemed irrelevant, does that affect their academic achievement and their self worth? Is there a correlation to the high school graduation rate? Curated by Urban Arts Partnership, this panel includes teachers, professors, and popular rappers where we pose this essential question: Can hip hop_s presence in social media and pop culture be leveraged to prepare students for careers and college?
column7: Participants will examine the relationship between youth culture and school culture
column8: Participants will delve deeply into the definitions of culturally responsive pedagogy and growth mindset and it's impact on communities of color
column9: Participants will explore strategies to engage students of all ages in and out of the classroom to build community and close the achievement gap.

column1: How to formatize the Finnish education miracle?
column5: Saku Tuominen (SCOOL)
column6: Finland has been one of the world leaders and forerunners in K12 -education. What can we learn from the Finnish model and how can we take this knowhow to the world?SCOOL is a Finnish company specializing in creating innovative education formats, testing and validating them in Finland and then making them global.At the moment we have 4  learning formats ranging from turning evening news into education material overnight to a media concept helping teachers to understand the changes happening outside of schools, from robotics to climate. We work together with key officials and leading education experts in Finland and our products are used in over 25 countries.
column7: A basic understanding of Finnish model - both past and the future
column8: A new way to approach learning material (format thinking).
column9: Making schools more global and international

column1: How Universities are Crowdsourcing Innovation
column5: Paul Fain (Inside higher Ed), Bernadette Gray-Little (University of Kansas), Michael  Crow (Arizona State University ), Mark Becker (Georgia State University)
column6: There was some eye rolling when 11 major public research universities (a sector normally competing in rankings and football) announced they were going to come together and share their successes and failures in order to scale innovation. Collaboration in education has often undelivered. But two years later, these 11 schools have developed a proven method to source and scale innovation. Come learn how 11 seemingly _frenemies_ are closing the innovation gap to serve their students.  They_ll talk about how they_re quickly testing new technologies and approaches, sharing what_s working, and deploying successful ideas across some of the largest universities in the country.
column7: Articulate the benefits of a collaborative approach for scaling evidence-based innovations across U.S. colleges and universities.
column8: Gain insight from experience in deploying cutting-edge data analytics approaches at scale.
column9: Understand opportunities for partnering with higher ed leaders and adopting new innovations to accelerate impact on student success.

column1: Effective SEL: From Classroom to Community
column5: Joseph Erardi (Newtown School District ), Jessica Berlinski (Personalized Learning Games), Jeremy  Richman (The Avielle Foundation), Joan  Duffell  (Committee for Children/Second Step)
column6: Kids come to school with a lot of feelings: fear, anxiety, abandonment and confusion. As educators, we teach SEL skills like empathy, persistence and problem-solving to support them, but too often kids find themselves on playgrounds, sports teams and even in homes where these skills are not valued or modeled. We're changing that. Join us as we share the 4 key components of Spark, a community-wide SEL initiative currently being implemented in Newtown, CT: in-person SEL training, game-based assessment and personalized skill-building, community and parent training, and brain health education. We'll share how they work together, how we know they work, and how they can work for you. Join us!
column7: Administrators and educators will learn how to implement SEL community-wide to support their work in schools.
column8: Administrators and educators will learn how to easily assess, monitor progress and personalize SEL instruction in schools for greatest efficacy.
column9: Administrators and educators will learn more about brain science and why teaching it in concert with SEL fosters safer school climates.

column1: BackFromTheFuture:how to deal with tech-excitement
column5: Paolo Cardini (RISD-Rhode Island School of Design)
column6: The advent of new tools always provokes an uncontrolled and irrational enthusiasm that often leads initially to pointless outcomes and immature solutions. Looking at the state of the art of digital production, from 3d printing to Big Data, is evident that the spread of a new accessible resource is faster than the time needed to understand its real meaning. Neuropsychology defines this feeling as "arousal", a particular state of being respondent to excitement, a thrilling push to experience something new without any particular plan or rationale. How to deal with this and how to manage progress in a more responsible and conscious way?
column7: how new technologies can be linked back to human activity and rise awareness about their consequent social implications.
column8: how to menage a new model of education based on uncertainty and  learning by doing
column9: how to speculate on present and future technologies to critically progress toward a desirable future

column1: Crowdsourcing a Children's Book About the Internet
column5: Ioana Literat (Teachers College, Columbia University)
column6: The vast majority of children's books about the Internet paint a bleak picture of addiction, cyberbullying, privacy abuse, catfishing, piracy, and so on. In an effort to tell a different and more positive story, I successfully crowdsourced the writing and illustration of a children's book about digital culture (starring Hashtag the Snail!), collecting 4200 creative submissions via Mechanical Turk. In this session, I describe the implementation and outcome of this creative experiment, and I present my conclusions about the conditions that best foster creative participation in large-scale educational projects online.
column7: How should children's literature address contemporary topics related to digital culture in a manner that is educational, fun and ethical?
column8: Is it possible to crowdsource the entire development of a children's book online? What are some of the opportunities and challenges involved?
column9: What are some of the ethical considerations that need to be taken into account when crowdsourcing creative tasks online?

column1: Getting Youth Actively Involved Not Acting Out
column5: Gage Cass Woodle (Mythic Bridge)
column6: For youth coming from at-risk situations, their futures can seem pretty bleak. Getting youth involved with and passionate about the arts is a way to engage, empower and prepare them for the real world; as technology advances we are constantly in need of new content creators. And thats where we step in. This panel will illuminate the need for more arts education as well as the steps we are taking to help develop the next generation of creators. By providing the access and opportunity for these youth to experiment with cutting edge equipment in a safe environment with a supportive community, our youth not only learn technical skills necessary for production, but also critical life skills.
column7: To illuminate the positive effects that arts education have on at-risk youth.
column8: To show how important a positive mentor can be to an at-risk youth.
column9: To inspire all youth to get behind the idea of it being 'cool to care' - to create an environment where social issues are championed by the youth

column1: How to make an urban school district Arts-Rich
column5: Brent Hasty (MINDPOP)
column6: This session presents a framework for how to use collective impact strategies to transform the way schools and the creative community collaborate through creative learning and the arts. Using concrete examples from the Austin experience, the session will offer a model for bringing education, the arts, philanthropy and higher education together to create an arts-rich environment for kids in and out of school. Practical, theoretical and not boring.
column7: Learn how Austin created its system wide creative learning initiative.
column8: Learn how you can build your own creative learning initiative.
column9: Learn some tips and tricks for building a system-wide creative learning initiative.

column1: Learning in the Cinema? The results are in...
column5: Ruari Elkington (Queensland University of Technology)
column6: We innately recognise the cinema as a privileged space for engaging with sound and vision. Not the only way, or the best way, but undeniably a unique way to impact audiences.This impact is felt by any casual cinemagoer - and it has always been harnessed for education audiences. Despite this long history of cinema and education it is now difficult for many educators to mount a case with administration that learning in the cinema is more than just _going to the movies_. This session highlights emerging research that equips educators to better argue for what they already know. Engaging and impactful learning experiences can, and should, happen in the cinema.
column7: Audiovisual content is not in short supply-our attention is. Cinema provides a uniquely engaging and impactful space where focussed learning can occur
column8: Practical and logistical barriers to using cinema as a learning space are growing. Clear strategies and quality research are needed to support it
column9: New research can equip educators to better make the case with administrators for the efficacy of informal learning environments such as cinema

column1: Beyond scores. Looking at patterns in the mistakes
column5: Belmer Negrillo (IDEO)
column6: Scores are useful as a common metric of performance, but they are insufficient to provide personalized and real-time education. Adaptive Learning based on scores is a reactive logic that by definition is always behind. Algorithms should be proactive during the learning process, observing patterns in the mistakes to reveal student_s current mental model, and adjusting content and intensity to promote evolution. Learn what happened when Lemann Foundation in Brazil and IDEO teamed up to improve early literacy for children aged 5-7. Together we developed a digital platform, capable of running on an MVP tablet now serving thousands of students and assisting teachers with diagnostic and activities
column7: Personalized and real-time education requires finding patterns in the mistakes, not simply accounting of right answers.
column8: Enable open-ended answers and mistakes to happen if you want to have an window into what students are thinking and provide an accurate diagnostic.
column9: We need to go deeper into studies on how people learn, and how mental models evolve in the psychogenesis of learning.

column1: Burn Your Tests: Student Choice & Assessment
column5: Lawrence Reiff (Roslyn Public Schools)
column6: To often we focus on tests and essays as means for assessing our students.  In the end, all we_ve assessed is that our students know how to take a test or write a four paragraph essay.  Have we really assessed what they_ve learned? When we give our students choice in expressing their understanding, they will almost always impress.  See how you can throw away your bubble sheets and lined paper. Learn how to assess your students based on a real metric: their creativity and true understanding of the subject matter.  Best of all, educators will walk away with ideas that they can apply as soon as they return to their classrooms.
column7: Gain an understanding that traditional assessment methods do not truly measure understanding for all learners
column8: Explore alternative assessment methods that employ a variety of technologies.
column9: Understand the role that rubrics and one-on-one conferencing play in alternate forms of student assessment.

column1: Curricular Mapping from the Passenger's Seat
column5: Terra Schehr (Loyola Univ MD)
column6: Faculty are accustomed to curricular mapping: identifying points in the curriculum where learning outcomes are introduced to students, engaged at a deep level, and where students should be able to demonstrate mastery with each outcome. In doing so, faculty are in the driver_s seat, mapping the way for students. What happens when we ask the passengers_the students_about their ride?  For each of their four years of study, a subset of undergraduates in the class of 2012 completed curricular maps for the courses they took and the general education outcomes of the University.  The resulting data provide a multi-layered understanding of how students experience general education.
column7: understand a new and innovative framework with which to assess student experiences of general education curricula
column8: be able to construct curricular matrices to use in their institutional settings
column9: analyze the data to assess student engagement with general education outcomes, coverage of outcomes across courses, and salience of engagement

column1: 3 Classes Virtual Reality Will Transform
column5: Tony Diepenbrock (Learn Immersive)
column6: How will Virtual Reality (VR) shape the future of education? Why ditch the language immersion program for an Oculus-powered simulation? When will Styrofoam models of molecules be replaced by interactive games that provide students a first-person perspective as an atom?In this session, I share an insider's guide on how to best incorporate VR in classrooms today, and how to create your own VR content that students will love.
column7: How to best incorporate VR into a curriculum
column8: Explore how to create incredible VR experiences for students today
column9: Understand what effects VR has on a student's brain

column1: Cultivating Resilience: Functionality of Failure
column5: Luisa Frias (luluSYNC)
column6: The good inevitability fail. The great fail forward, fast and furious. The distinction is not merely the failure rate, frequency, or the severity of the damage. Resilience breeds when you slowly rise up, gladiator-style. The true success indicator is having the ability to translate devastations into lessons, and then into discernible actions, perpetually modified for the intended target. Life as an action student requires adaptability and flexibility, as change is constant. Success is thus determined by how comprehensive contingency plans are and how reactions to change are managed. This skill-set of calculated resilience is needed.  could be the difference between successful  ventures.
column7: Failure: Take calculated risks and unabashed chances.Dive in headfirst, but have a healthy aversion to uncertainty. Perfectionism is the enemy.
column8: Forward: Learn. Make mistakes only once. Do not beredundant in solutions that did not work (definition ofinsanity).Mentally exercise possibilities
column9: Fast and Furious: Speed is of essence when decisions aretantamount to execution. However, informed decisionsmust occur. Metrics matter.

column1: Designing Environments to Increase Creativity
column5: Amy Jorgensen (Massachusetts College of Art and Design)
column6: The ability to switch from analytic thought mode to associative thought mode is critical to creativity, a skill known as contextual focus. When a person is in need of a solution, he/she must defocus attention and enter into more associative form of thought in order to make new connections. In this expansive state, one loosens thought structure to allow new ideas or insights to occur. In the modern day university or office environment, there are very few opportunities that foster a shift in state of mind. We are encouraged to focus, not de-focus.There are simple manipulations of space and sound that facilitate a shift in mental state and have been proven to lead to an increase in creativity.
column7: To expand our understanding of the creative state and the neurological processes that precipitate the formation of an "idea".
column8: To augment the value of shifting into a more relaxed brainwave state in order to provide fertile ground for creative thought.
column9: To provide solutions for creative blocks and revolutionize the protocol for problem solving in the classroom and office setting.

column1: eBooks and Mushy Brains: Debunking eReading Myths
column5: Jordan Schugar (West Chester University of Pennsylvania)
column6: Reading on an iPad will not cause your brain to go to mush, even if the Huffington Post publishes headlines like _Sorry eBooks, These 9 Studies Show Why Print is Better_ (February, 2015). The good news is that these stories are nothing more than click-bait intended to instill the same fear and panic that exaggerated shark attacks have on beachgoers. The bad news is that it can be difficult to separate the wheat from the chaff. However, emerging research related to eReading confounds common sense. And, the negative stereotypes associated with eTexts only serves to perpetuate conventions that screen time is corrupting the intellectual and imaginative potential of young, impressionable brains.
column7: Participants will be able to summarize the current educational research associated with eReading and digital texts.
column8: Participants will be able to describe the different genres and qualities of digital texts (narrative, expositional, pleasure reading, etc).
column9: Participants will be able to summarize and describe the relationship between production and consumption of digital content on mobile devices.

column1: How content management can help Brazilian students
column5: Larissa Coelho (Descomplica)
column6: How content management can play a mediator role between brazilian lower classes student_s demands of preparation to ENEM (a major college_s entrance exam in Brazil), the kind of content requested by it, and the traditional teacher available at schools? The idea is to use the content matrix given by ENEM_s board to help both teacher and student, the first to elaborate and conduce the online class, and the second to have guidance trough inductive thinking of competencies and abilities. This kind of class is builded up by choosing current themes and gathering different types of media, image and text, all to guide the student that has already studied basics trough critical and conscious thought.
column7: Understand the Brazilian matriz of knowledge asked by ENEM's board.
column8: Comprehand how traditional kind of teacher may not be able to help further than they do on preparation to this kind of exam.
column9: Elucidate how content management can help both parts, teacher and student, to build an inductive kind of content, focusing the online class.

column1: Isn't Everyone an Autodidact?
column5: Jack West (Hapara)
column6: School is changing. National standards, a healthy shift in the national conversation toward deeper learning and critical thinking, and education technology that empowers teachers to focus on higher value interactions are all supporting time tested pedagogies that empower learners and accelerate learning. In this session, Jack West, Senior Research Analyst with Hapara, will share the findings of meta research on interventions that accelerate learning and review a case study of a New Zealand school cluster whose student empowering practices have resulted in statistically significant student improvement in critical thinking.
column7: Participants will learn what teaching and learning practices large international meta-studies indicate have the largest impact on learning.
column8: Participants will learn what research looks like in practice for a public school system in Auckland, New Zealand.
column9: Participants will learn how to use a Uk- Foundation produced intervention evaluation tool to guide decision making that supports accelerated learning.

column1: Media Design for Learners using Multimedia Theory
column5: Aaron Dewald (University of Utah S.J. Quinney College of Law)
column6: We_re going to delve into the learning science literature to talk about ways in which we can create educational media using learning science theory to best engage the cognitive processes of our learners. Specifically, we_ll talk about the objectives of learning science in digital learning, four principles that will inform and guide the development of online multimedia, and an informed, cost-effective process for assembling multimedia that is used in online learning environments.
column7: Learn about learning science based multimedia principles
column8: Apply multimedia theory to real-world teaching and learning environments
column9: Understand the role of learning science in blended, online, or MOOC-based learning environments

column1: Why Every Child Deserves a Cognitive Assessment
column5: Nancy Weinstein (Mindprint Learning)
column6: How can educators effectively differentiate instruction if they don't fully understand differences in how students learn? And how can we expect students to understand themselves as learners and self-advocate if we never provide them with objective insight into how they learn best and what they need to be successful?We will discuss how a self-administered online cognitive assessment can be an efficient and effective tool to give educators the information they need to understand what each \student needs to be successful. We will explain how teachers can use that information to differentiate instruction for each learner and give students the language to self-advocate when needed.
column7: Create an understanding of the importance of cognitive skills in learning with an emphasis on how they differ from academic skills.
column8: Create an awareness of new, online methods of evaluating cognitive skills and how they can be efficiently and affordably implemented for all learners.
column9: Provide specific examples of how we should use an understanding of students' learning strengths and needs to effectively differentiate instruction.

column1: Accelerated Change + Future of Work
column5: Heather McGowan (HE McGowan)
column6: Accelerated technological change and expanding globalization have transformed the future of work where anything mentally routine can and will be replaced by automation. This creates tectonic shifts in both education and workforce development needs.  There has never been a more important time to understand context around work, industry, and the economy. Numerous sources assess aspects of these changes in isolation but I offer a succinct presentation that synthesizes and visualize these shifts across five essential dimensions  - technological, economic, educational, vocational, and social - with frameworks that communicate these collective impacts on industry, business, and education.
column7: Participants will gain greater understanding of the future workforce skills
column8: Participants will gain greater understanding of the impacts of technological change.
column9: Participants will gain greater understanding of ways to reframe general or liberal ed for the VUCA (volatile, uncertain, complex, ambiguous) future

column1: Aging: The Opportunity For Continuing Education
column5: Judi Bonilla (Advocates For Aging  Cares)
column6: The headlines scream, _Millennial generation is bigger, more diverse than boomers._ Another reads, _10 million Americans turn age 65 everyday._ What_s missing from the headlines? A dialogue on the need for continuing education programs to introduce business and health promotion classes for adult learners for all ages.Continuing Education leaders are uniquely poised to bridge the information gap for an aging population. Remember, in 2050 as the youngest baby boomers reach age 85, their oldest millennial grandchildren will be ready to receive their AARP cards. Select this proposal and transform the conversation about aging.
column7: Attendees gain an understanding of the value of advocating for educational programs to meet the needs of an aging population.
column8: Attendees identify programs in entrepreneurism, health promotion, public health and safety, targeting lifelong learners.
column9: Attendees recognize potential partners for collaboration and networking opportunities.

column1: Classroom Filming on a Budget
column5: Aaron Soffin (Relay Graduate School of Education)
column6: Watching yourself teach is among the best ways to reflect upon and improve your teaching. In this session, you'll learn how to capture high-quality classroom video, by yourself and on a budget. For coaches who want to watch footage with their teachers, or teachers who want to film themselves, this session will give you the knowledge you need to get started.Can you use your phone to film? Do you need a microphone? Where should you put the camera? We'll answer these questions and get you ready to start filming on Monday morning.
column7: Learn key takeaways for making your video high-quality.
column8: Determine the equipment you need to get started filming in your classroom.
column9: Compare examples of classroom video to help you get started filming yourself.

column1: Find Your Twitter PLN: An Edchat Love Story
column5: Candace Flaherty (Mobility Labs)
column6: Twitter for teacher professional development? You bet! Teachers have been connecting on Twitter through live Twitter events called edchats, where they can collaborate, mentor/be mentored, discuss education, and share resources. This session will help audience members navigate the Twitterverse to access quality professional learning and build their personal learning network (PLN). We will also discuss resources to moderate, analyze, and grow edchats as well as the potential impact of edchats on teacher professional development.
column7: You will learn about how educators are using Twitter and edchats to expand their knowledge and skills.
column8: You'll learn about the impact of edchats on teachers as well as what this could mean for the future of professional development.
column9: You'll understand how to grow an edchat and develop a PLN to connect to other rockstar teachers.

column1: Goocus: mobile higher education for everyone
column5: Satoshi Yamawaki (Castalia.Co.,Ltd)
column6: Development of mobile networks allows to faster connect people together than with fixed networks. Based on the spread of mobile devices, we developed a social mobile learning platform dedicated to anyone seeking knowledge and which adapt to the learners : Goocus.This smartphone application has been implemented in different business and companies in Japan and is spreading among educational institutions in developing countries, and mostly in Northern Africa.As a side tool, or entirely integrated to the learning, following the traditional way or emerging ones, Goocus allows the increase the learning experiences, create and habit of learning following each one's pace and help the retention.
column7: Social learning to support a sustainable knowledge, improving the share of experience and competitions necessary for the retention of knowledge
column8: Learning as an habit inserted in each one's life and matching with the lifestyle and learning profile through the mobile technologies
column9: Mobile learning is integrated in the future of learning, improving the flexibility and the contact between students and teachers
column10: edutainment education mobile learning application smartphone tablet

column1: Modernizing the True Measure of Learning
column5: Matthew Pittinsky (Parchment)
column6: 20 years ago, credentials were limited to two ends of our workforce: the 35-40% who obtained a college degree and blue-collar workers who held a trade certification. Now, completing some form of higher education is critical to accomplish basic social, economic and professional goals. And, the U.S. Census Bureau reports that 1 in 4 Americans has some form of certification or license distinct from an academic credential.But the question remains: How does a growing pool of qualified workers demonstrate proof of competency across disciplines that didn_t exist ten years ago?Matthew Pittinsky will explain why it is time to move credentials online making them more functional and portable.
column7: Discover how technology is changing credentials
column8: Learn how we can make credentials the true measure of learning
column9: Understand what needs to be done to modernize the credential infrastructure

column1: MOOCs for Sale: Finding Meaning in the Medium
column5: Charles Isbell (College of Computing)
column6: MOOCs were once hailed as the kind of tech disruption that would bring a traditional institution_in this case, higher education--down in flaming ruin, perhaps within only a few short years! Yeah, that didn't happen. But MOOCs are far from worthless. Georgia Tech, University of Illinois-UC, and University of Wisconsin have all launched low- to lower-cost degree programs based on the MOOC format, not to mention the dozens of "traditional" online programs that continue to flourish. Hear from a leader at Georgia Tech, the first university to jump boldly into the world of MOOCs-for-degree-credit, about what the future may hold and how this is all extremely good news for technology innovators.
column7: Become familiar with the new ways MOOCs are being utilized in higher education.
column8: Explore the idea of a low-cost MOOC-based degree program and what that might look like.
column9: Discover the role that tech innovators and entrepreneurs might take in redefining the possibilities of the MOOC format.

column1: Teacher Led Professional Learning
column5: Matthew Courtney (Bluegrass Center for Teacher Quality)
column6: The way we train and grow teachers in America is broken.  The existing systems are too expensive.  They disrespect the professionals in the room and ignore the current research related to adult learning. Teacher led professional learning is the key to the future.  In this session, we will pull back the curtain and showcase the amazing things that can happen when teacher experts are given control over their own learning and the learning of their peers.
column7: Participants will gain an understanding of the current state of teacher professional learning.
column8: Participants will be exposed to an existing model of teacher led professional learning.
column9: Participants will explore and imagine the future of teacher led professional learning and discuss barriers and solutions for implementation.

column1: The Modern Doctorate: Intellectual Risk Takers
column5: Kari Whaley (University of Central Florida Doctoral Candidate)
column6: Doctoral degrees are no longer simply a training ground for the next generation of academics. The doctorate has evolved from the conventional PhD undertaken within academic environment. Higher ed doctoral study has ascended the classic styles of theory, to a level where immediate implementation is possible & research can be absorbed & applied to the workplace in real-time.In today_s information age, industry depends on the hybrid that encompasses capabilities of the PhD & multi-disciplinary expert.  Shifts in technology have encouraged a shift in education and preparation, and now emerging from the synergistic approach of the modern doctorate comes a scholar-practitioner.
column7: Discover how universities and companies can leverage the innovation and new knowledge these degrees produce.
column8: Explore the ways in which modern doctorates study scientifically-based research in order to make theory directly relevant to industry.
