column9: Learn how to contribute to the framework of the 'Mod Doc'.

column1: Training the world's surgeons in Virtual Reality
column5: Edward Miller (Medical Realities)
column6: Two-thirds of the world's population have no access to safe and affordable surgery, which means that over 18 million people are dying from treatable conditions every year. A key challenge in addressing this issue is training enough surgical practitioners to meet demand.The relative low cost of virtual reality headsets, such as the Oculus Rift, present a profound opportunity to provide first class surgical training to anybody, anywhere in the world regardless of physical location or financial background. In this session, we will explore past efforts to bring virtual reality into the healthcare system and present a future vision where virtual reality is woven into the fabric of care.
column7: To understand the profound impact virtual reality will have in the healthcare industry.
column8: To understand and contextualize the global need for safe and affordable surgical healthcare.
column9: To demonstrate how existing content is using virtual reality to provide surgical and healthcare training.

column1: Content studios: the who's and how to's
column5: Laurie Close (Ogilvy & Mather)
column6: Have you ever wondered how content is made? Who are the brains behind that up-to-the-minute reactive content? Where do they work? What do they look like? Around the world Ogilvy & Mather manages and operates 36 content studios and counting. Operationally these studios cover a broad range of clients, target audiences, content types and publishing models all achieved by pulling together a bespoke team from every aspect of the Ogilvy family. This talk provides an insight into editorial planning, rapid content creation, social data and analytics monitoring, paid distribution capabilities, and how to bring a responsive content studio to life.
column7: An understanding of _always on_ social content to long-form, medium and heavy episodic content that may live beyond social.
column8: The key points in curating a responsive content team.
column9: How to give consumers content that adds value to their lives, and in return adds value to a brand.

column1: data2decide: measurement for school improvement
column5: Sarah Rand (AIR)
column6: We translate education data to help school districts know if what they_re doing is working and worth it, so leaders can make smart decisions.In today_s educational environment, school districts collect an increasing amount of data about their students. At the same time, tighter budgets make it difficult to invest in the personnel and tools to put that data to use. Data2Decide at American Institutes for Research (AIR) puts our organization_s statistical experience and content knowledge to work on school districts' existing data to provide objective, research-based analyses at a cost that school districts can afford.
column7: For superintendents and school boards: We help you plan and make decisions.
column8: For school principals and program leads: We help you see the larger picture of your programs and engage in and communicate about your data.
column9: For research and data leads: We reduce data waste and we enhance your capacity and reduce burden.

column1: Massive AI is Coming - You Ain't Seen Nothin' Yet!
column5: Andrew Moore (Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science)
column6: With Q&A technology powering Siri, Cortana, Google Voice Search, IBM Watson, and others, ubiquitous Star Trek-style computers will soon be answering complex questions better than friends or experts. AI will open up exciting new opportunities in healthcare, learning, safety, and convenience. We will show how AI works and prove that by embracing it, we can improve and save lives.
column7: The future of humanity and its relationship with AI: participants will learn about where AI is headed and how it will benefit society.
column8: Where AI is going: participants will get a view of our exciting future with robots, smart systems, and everything in between.
column9: Participants will gain an understanding of the REAL challenges and opportunities facing _intelligent machines,_ and why fears of AI are misplaced.

column1: Neuroscience + Big Data = Efficient Recruiting
column5: Frida Polli (pymetrics)
column6: The past two decades have given way to advances in neuroscience. Our understanding of the brain continues to improve, giving researchers novel ways to assess cognitive and personality traits. Big data is becoming bigger and broader, impacting new segments of our lives each and every day. Over the past few years, an increasing number of companies have begun gathering and analyzing vast amounts of data to identify patterns, predict human behavior and make recommendations.This presentation will explore how the confluence of predictive technology and neuroscience-based assessments is helping people find optimal career paths and companies hire in a smarter, more diverse way.
column7: Extensive neuroscience research continues to further our understanding of the brain, enabling us to assess cognitive traits more accurately.
column8: Recommendation engines have become one of the most common applications of big data, influencing a variety of the decisions we make on a daily basis.
column9: Applying unbiased data science algorithms and neuroscience to recruiting can help candidates and companies find each other based on compatibility.

column1: What the Public Wants from Our Schools
column5: Joshua Starr (PDK International)
column6: This session will present the most recent findings - and 47 years of trend data - of the annual PDK/Gallup poll on the public's attitudes towards public education. We have unique, compelling and unbiased data that should inform policy makers, leaders, the public and practitioners. Participants will gain a deep understanding of what parents and the public want from their schools. Our data also shows differences between different demographic groups and is the starting point for a deep conversation about where our schools should focus in the future.
column7: Participants will develop an understanding of the public's general attitudes towards public education.
column8: Participants will develop an understanding of attitudes towards current issues as well as trend data.
column9: Participants will develop an understanding of different perspectives about public education based on demographic breakdowns.

column1: Computer Science a creative boost for our Students
column5: Willy Leloutre (Coding School)
column6: I'm a french developer, social entrepreneur & trainer since several years. I teach computer science in primary, secondary school, higher & business professionals education in France. I created educational programmes involving computer sciences and the program of the National Education. This experiment aims to encourage creativity from an early age, and placed our future generations as producers and not consumers of technology. I would like to present how young French are introduced to computer sciences, and especially what are the creative interests. Finally, by comparison, how young Asians and Europeans have integrated these skills.
column7: Why and how computer sciences promote creativity
column8: Accessibility and variability of IT education in the world
column9: Measuring the cognitive impact of these lessons for our children

column1: Internships 2.0: A True Partnership w/Millenials
column5: Gabe Kosowitz (Smithsonian Institution )
column6: Helping other business groups/associations understand a better way to "bring on an intern".  Instead of having them grab the coffee or enter the latest data into excel, use their mind/way of consuming media to your advantage.  So many companies are trying to reach this elusive audience but are struggling to understand their way of live and how quickly the trends change.  By tasking this challenge to young and talented minds, the company can gain insight and receive tangible deliverables all while developing a future workforce pipeline.  Creating this type of partnership with a university or college will allow the "win, win" to continue for years to come.  Case study: Discovery Comm.
column7: Understand the importance of partnering with a local university/college to develop more than the average internship program
column8: See the advantage of letting millennials try to solve some of your biggest problems.
column9: Be able to take a tangible plan back to your company or institution of how to revamp your idea of the intern

column1: Johnny Can't Read, So We Remain a Nation at Risk
column5: Patrick Riccards (Eduflack)
column6: Despite the adoption of Common Core and the strengthening of learning standards, nearly a third of fourth graders unable to read proficiently. Too many kids can't read, and we know why. Moreover, we know what we should be doing about it.This session will provide an overview of what we know is most effective in teaching young children to read, while providing a specific path for teachers and parents on how best to get it into our classrooms. By challenging the status quo in education, we can ensure that Johnny can read. And in doing so, we can shift from being a nation at risk to one where every child is truly college and career ready. (Spoiler, it requires literacy skills.)
column7: Provide an overview of what is most effective in teaching young children to read, according to decades of research
column8: Offer parents and educators a roadmap for how to get research-proven instruction into all elementary school classrooms across the nation
column9: Ensure that we know "good reading instruction" when we see it, so we aren't fooled by those promising "alignment," but not offering it

column1: Kids Are People: A Radical Idea
column5: Jens Peter de Pedro (Toca Boca)
column6: Lego, Minecraft and Toca Boca are three Scandinavian brands that are at the top of the charts in their respective categories. This is no coincidence, argues Toca Boca Creative Lead, Jens Peter de Pedro (JP). These toys and games trust children's capabilities and provide them with the opportunity to act freely inside well-designed systems. JP will speak to how this inclination to trust children stems from the Scandinavian egalitarian culture, which is less ageist in regards to children. In order for society and education to move forward, we need to fight harder against the prejudice towards children and give kids more freedom.
column7: What can we learn from the success of so many Scandinavian kids brands (Lego, Minecraft and Toca Boca)?
column8: What are adultism and childism, and how do these apply to kids today?
column9: In a world where there_s so much fear about kid_s safety and pressure on kids to succeed, why should we be giving them more freedom instead of less?

column1: Let's Play: Educational Games for Early Childhood
column5: Candace Flaherty (Mobility Labs)
column6: We'll be focusing on how to make games great learning tools and what to consider when designing or evaluating games and self-guided learning tools for young children. At Mobility Labs, our areas of expertise include early childhood education, curriculum development, blended learning, game design, UI/UX design, mobile app development, web app development, and user testing, enabling us to explore this problem from a variety of perspectives.
column7: You'll find out the benefits and challenges of using games to learn.
column8: You'll learn how to evaluate existing products to determine whether they meet your learners' needs and fit well in your classroom.
column9: You'll learn strategies for using games for learning at home and in the classroom.

column1: Library Media Mentors Transform
column5: Andrew Medlar (Association for Library Service to Children)
column6: Learn how the Association for Library Service to Children_s commitment to bridging the 30 million word gap and supporting expanded broadband access to underserved communities place libraries at the natural intersection of early learning, digital media and community transformation. Children_s librarians, in the important role of Media Mentor, are the trusted conduit for families to experience and navigate the wealth of media available to them and their young children. Libraries incorporate media of all types into the menu of high quality content and services they offer while modeling positive parent-child engagement strategies_ critical to fostering educational success.
column7: How to identify and support the roles librarians serve as Media Mentors to families in your community
column8: Evidence-based guidelines for media usage with young children
column9: How to partner with libraries to enrich your family engagement effort and support the goals of your educational program

column1: 0% of fictional princesses are engineers
column5: Sophie Deen (Bright Little Labs)
column6: 40% of kids don_t know milk comes from a cow; 13% of the STEM workforce are women; workers in Bangalore get paid 13p an hour; the planet is dying and kids watch too much rubbish TV. Meet Detective Dot, a 9 year old coder and the heroine of our animations. Dot tells the human story of where our stuff come from (eg. a t-shirt finding it_s way back to the cotton fields of Uzbekistan via China & the UK) and inspires kids to ask questions like _who made this, where_s it from and what impact does this have on the environment?_ You_ll see a 5 min story & you_ll learn how Dot is inspiring kids to make a fairer world and how we_re harnessing pester power with a global avaaz.org-like movement of kids.
column7: How to teach tough subjects to a tough audience (under 12s). Explore topics like fair trade and sustainability without being boring.
column8: Understand what fictional princesses and coders have in common, what they don_t, and how to question stereotypes in stories.
column9: How to harness pester power at scale through avaaz.org junior and teach kids about data science at the same time.

column1: Closing Tech Talent Gap with Adult Growth Mindsets
column5: Kathleen Mullaney (Udacity)
column6: Consider the future of education age equality. We encourage children to adopt a growth mindset. Yet as adults we tend toward a fixed mindset, hindering our potential for adaptation. There is a widening gap between tech talent and jobs. And technical skills are within reach for people from all walks of life. But all too often would-be students wrongly assume that the chance for a technical career expires after college. This session will share the stories of three professionals on three continents who overcame stereotypes and completely transformed their careers to become successful developers. Hear surprising new data on what works - and what doesn't - in technical online education.
column7: Learn how a growth vs. fixed mindset affects adults and consider situations where you've had each mindset.
column8: Understand how adopting growth mindsets as adults impacts career growth, and help close the tech talent gap in a matter of months instead of decades.
column9: Consider how intervention in an adult_s cognitive processes to adopt a growth mindset can lead them to change careers or gain new skills at any age.

column1: College Is(n't) for Everyone
column5: Gabriel  Fotsing (The College Initiative)
column6: College isn't for everyone. Too often when people state that college isn_t for _everyone_ they neglect to realize there are many groups of people that may have a deep desire for college, but simply lack the toolkit, the support, and the encouragement to actualize the dream of going to college. What happens when students are given the tools and mentorship needed? What happens to communities and local economies when more college grads are funneled into the workforce? This session will address the root causes of education inequality and share a vision of future success when students are given the right tools and attention.
column7: Understand the root cause of education inequality and the grim future of students who have no access to college mentorship.
column8: Show the incredible opportunities students gain when just a handful of people make a concerted effort to show them the path to college readiness.
column9: Illuminate a vision of the future where individuals decide if college is for them, rather than society and controlling entities.

column1: Communication Access for Deaf Students & Employees
column5: Svetlana Kouznetsova (Independent)
column6: Hearing loss is very stigmatized and makes many deaf and hard of hearing students and employees reluctant to ask for communication access services. Not all of them have same hearing and communication abilities and preferences and may not get the proper accommodations. They are often frustrated with access to education and employment. Also, there are many educational materials such as videos that are not accessible via quality captions. The speaker will share her first hand experience as a deaf student and employee, show examples of frustrations of people like her, and discuss what can be done to improve quality communication and information access in education.
column7: What are hearing and communication abilities and preferences of deaf and hard of hearing students and employees?
column8: What does it take to become a communication access provider (interpreter, captioner, notetaker) and why quality is important?
column9: How quality communication and information access benefits not just deaf and hard of hearing students and employees, but also educational institutions?

column1: Cutting through the Noise on Student Testing
column5: Greg Richmond (National Association of Charter School Authorizers)
column6: You have probably heard a lot of noise about standardized tests and it can be vexing. Loud and persistent voices from all sides are weighing in on the topic. There are legitimate concerns about the potential damage testing may be doing to teachers, students, and classrooms. But there are legitimate benefits that often get lost in the debate. Charter schools across the country are refining the use of limited, smart tests to gauge learning and make adjustments. Come hear more about how smart testing can help close the achievement gap and improve educational outcomes for all of our students.
column7: Understand the different opinions about standardized testing and the opt-out movement.
column8: Learn about strategies charter schools are using to improve student learning.
column9: Learn about actions you can take to ensure public schools are working for all our children.

column1: Disrupting Education in Latinamerca
column5: Jorge Restrepo (Hypercubus)
column6: Latin American countries aren't often prevalent on lists of countries with the highest quality of education. Governments have tried to react to this reality by making efforts using traditional concepts. However, many people are taking independent actions in order to change this reality, generating a movement. Though still in its infancy, this movement is achieving significant results and has a chance to generate a big change in the coming years, this moving moves away from traditional education.
column7: Show the actions that are taking place in Latin America, disruptive actions for better education for all (poor people, rural village...)
column8: Invite to Co-create new actions  in order to get this moving be stronger and with worldwide impact.
column9: Create a bridge between north and south in order to develop a new education worldwide

column1: How can one educator change a student's life?
column5: Barrett Taylor (Saint Louis Public Schools)
column6: On average, African American boys read at the same level as white eighth-grade males.  Not being able to read on level has a connection between the school to prison pipeline. With recent issues in Ferguson and Baltimore, access to a quality education  for all students is at the forefront of our society. This EDtalk will focus on one central question: How can educator change a student's life?
column7: After this EDtalk, participants will be able to identify and recognize issues of equity impacting African American boys.
column8: After this EDtalk, participants will change their own professional practice to help all students succeed and be able to have conversations on race.
column9: After this EDtalk, participants will use information to help bring change to the lives of African American boys in their own classes.

column1: How Social Media Can Unlock Students_ Potential
column5: Ted Gonder (Moneythink)
column6: The application of behavioral economics has taken the world by storm_but how can we leverage these lessons to improve education and create not simply educated, but capable students? Ted will explore how Moneythink, a nonprofit providing digital tools to increase financial literacy and capability in American youth, has created a social media app that leverages social networks to nudge students to make healthier financial decisions that in turn become lifelong habits. Join Ted as he shares examples from nonprofits and technology companies alike to learn how to leverage the behavioral economics of social media to not simply build knowledge, but build skills and healthy habits among students.
column7: Discover the interplay between behavioral economics and social networks in building healthy behaviors
column8: Discover how social networks can provide instant gratification in exchange for delayed gratification
column9: Discover how best practices in this rapidly expanding field can be leveraged by any organization or company

column1: If #BlackLivesMatter, be a friend in deed
column5: Sharhonda Bossier (Education Cities)
column6: When ESEA or charter schools are under fire, people of color are asked to testify, rally or march in support of key reform priorities. But when the children and families of the same communities are victims of murder or senseless violence, the majority of education reformers fall silent.Communities of color need friends in deed - those that show up during hard times without being asked or expecting anything in return. Learn some simple ways to show your support for the communities you serve when they need you, not just when you need them.
column7: Decide what tactics you should deploy to build authentic relationships with communities of color.
column8: Recruit others to join you in becoming a friend in deed to communities of color in your city.
column9: Build authentic, meaningful relationships with and become a friend in deed to communities of color in your city.

column1: Improvement: Learning Fast to Implement Well
column5: Alicia Grunow (The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching)
column6: Learning to Improve, a new book by Bryk, Gomez, Grunow, & LeMahieu, details how Networked Improvement Communities (NICs) offer a new model for improving our schools. It highlights how NICs_organized to solve a single shared problem_can accelerate improvements even further and actively engage many different individuals and institutions in the process. The authors offer a new paradigm for R&D in education, one where the field moves from _implementing fast and learning slow_ to _learning fast to implement well._ Examples include reducing the high rates of failure among students in community college remedial math courses and strategies for improving feedback to novice teachers.
column7: Continuous improvement will be presented as a concrete policy option for addressing real problems of practice in education.
column8: Participants will leave with a clear understanding of the power of improvement networks and their role in accelerating improvement.
column9: Participants will be given a framework (the 6 principles described in the book) for understanding the basics of improvement science.

column1: Innovating to Diversify the Tech Pipeline!
column5: Ryan Seashore (CodeNow)
column6: With the emergence of the learn-to-code movement how can we ensure diversifying the talent pipeline in tech is one of our goals? Lowering the barriers normally associated with technology by exposing students to programming at an age when they are beginning to explore future options and opportunities is critical.  I_ll share our experience engaging companies, tech professionals, educators, and students in a successful collaboration to address this issue. I_ll talk about the ways the different resources each posses and the power of peer-to-peer learning can be used to bring coding to underrepresented youth and cultivate a spirited and diverse tech workforce.
column7: Insights from creating programs for underrepresented youth
column8: Feedback that helps ensure we meet our goals
column9: Lessons than can be applied to other programs

column1: Manufacturing a way out of the Gender Gap in STEM
column5: Danielle Applestone (Other Machine Co.)
column6: Ubiquitous access to tools will create a diverse of pool of STEAM professionals. By giving students opportunities to explore technology in environments where they feel comfortable, a more balanced group will develop mastery. We already see a blended community growing around desktop manufacturing tools, specifically desktop milling machines, which are portable versions of high-precision manufacturing tools. Students go from design to engineering to manufacturing and back, using math, art, engineering, design, and electronics skills. The future of brilliant design in areas as impactful as medical devices and the Internet of Things hinges upon this powerful interdisciplinary technical literacy.
column7: Professional tools need to be everywhere so that a more diverse cross-section of people have access to them and can learn where they feel comfortable.
column8: Solving the problems of the future requires raising a generation of people who can dance between many disciplines: math, engineering, art, design, etc
column9: 3D printing is only one part of the puzzle. Learning to use manufacturing tools allows students to understand how solutions might get made at scale.

column1: Music meets tech: Everybody can become a musician
column5: Gijs Bekenkamp (Chordify)
column6: To create equality in music education, one needs to realize that it is not simply about teaching people but about providing the right conditions in which they can learn.In the pre-tech era, the conditions for those learning an instrument to become competent musicians were far from optimal. Three serious problems stood in the way.1) Dependency on teachers2) Availability of music scores3) AffordabilityIn this Future15 session, we will take you on a tour of emerging music tech companies, smart algorithms and gaming solutions that optimise the conditions for everybody to become the best musician they can be.
column7: The pre-tech problems that existed in music education
column8: Tour of present day problem solvers
column9: Improvements that need to be made to further optimise teaching equality in music education

column1: Quality Education through Affordable Technologies
column5: Neil D'souza (Zaya Learning Labs)
column6: The idea of the session is to talk about how education in the developing world is evolving with the help of affordable technologies. To understand how, with the help of technology, learning methods like blended learning are being implemented. Also, to talk about what kind of unique challenges the developing world faces during the implementation of such practices, and what are the best solutions that are being developed.
column7: How technology can narrow the achievement gap existing in the developing world?
column8: What kind of technologies are being implemented in those parts of the world?
column9: How will the Internet and quality content help narrow the achievement gap in the developing world?

column1: Transforming The Teaching Profession
column5: Tyler Thigpen (The Transforming Teaching Project at Harvard)
column6: What if we had great teaching in every classroom? What if knowledge about good teaching was readily available and easy to access? What if there was an intentional, coherent pipeline through which teachers build knowledge, skill, and expertise? The Transforming Teaching Project aims to revolutionize the way teaching is organized, supported, and regarded in the United States. We work with a growing coalition of teacher training programs, higher education institutions, non-profits, funding organizations, state and district agencies, teacher unions, and others committed to working in concert with one another to deliver transformative change to the teaching profession.
column7: To describe three components needed to transform the teaching profession--develop R&D, create a social learning system, and build the policy ecosystem
column8: To understand how education organizations are working together to professionalize teaching in ways that lead to greater quality in every classroom
column9: To share how individuals and organizations can help to deliver transformative change to the teaching profession

column1: You Matter! Creating a Student Advisory Board
column5: Dana Grossman Leeman   (Simmons College)
column6: Students matter, but may feel invisible to administration. How do students - online and on campus, partake in shared governance in order to improve the quality of a program and the student experience? In July 2014, Simmons College launched SocialWork@Simmons, an online Master of Social Work program. In 2015 all students were surveyed to assess their needs. One common theme emerged: a wish to have a collective voice. Program director, and Professor, Dr. Dana Grossman Leeman shares her experiences working with students to create a Student Advisory Board, and how it was empowered to advocate on behalf of students with regard to curriculum, professional development, and community building.
column7: Explore how student collaboration with administration deepened student investment to the online community and legitimized their needs as constituents.
column8: To elucidate the practical complexities of creating a structure for shared governance in an online program that has multiple starts each year.
column9: Show how creating an advisory board engendered a sense of political voice and empowerment in students- skills intrinsic to professional social work.

column1: Coffee_s for Closers: How to Succeed in Edtech
column5: Paul Mumma (Cerego LLC)
column6: Starting an edtech company is not for the casual or short term entrepreneur. Education is a unique industry, and one where the contemporary tech ideals of disruption and rapid, iterative pace of development are often at odds with the more measured and entrenched traditions of academia and its layers of bureaucracy. For mission-driven companies, the opportunity to have meaningful and transformative effects on education outweighs the challenges, but passion alone can_t drive success.This panel of successful edtech entrepreneurs tackles the business behind the blackboard, discussing how to close deals, strike necessary partnerships, and develop long-term strategy for your company.
column7: Discuss how to articulate and pursue a company_s mission through entrepreneurialism in edtech.
column8: Provide first-hand insight into how edtech deals are closed successfully and authentically.
column9: Explain how to map short-term business development goals to long-term strategy.

column1: Connecting Edupreneurs to Creative Pros
column5: Alli Dunn (4.0 Schools)
column6: What do you do if you_re a teacher who has an idea for a venture that involves tech? Where do you go? In an extremely connected world, education is profoundly disconnected. Many teachers are dissuaded from pursuing their tech solutions because they lack access to the expertise to bring it into reality.Outside of education lies a surplus of professionals with specialized skill sets that are interested in helping, but do not know where to go to apply their skills.This Future 15 will cover strategies for breaking down the silos in and out of education, including building partnerships across industries, how you can use this in your community, and what we_ve learned in New York City so far.
column7: Understand the opportunity that exists in major cities to connect education entrepreneurs to professionals with specific skills.
column8: How to apply best practices and other learnings from the NYC professional skill-based volunteer network to other communities around the country.
column9: Understanding of the knowledge gap barriers that keep education innovation from being fully realized.

column1: Dyslexics Are Hardwired for Entrepreneurship
column5: Tiffany Sunday (Dillon 5 LLC)
column6: The first part of the session would discuss the research by Dr. Julie Logan and Thomas West that demonstrates a strong link between dyslexia and entrepreneurship.  Much of the focus in education is on the weaknesses of dyslexia; however, many dyslexics are successful business owners and entrepreneurs. The second part of the session is educating the audience about the key characteristics that dyslexics possess and how these characteristics are invaluable as business owner and entrepreneur.  The third part discusses the importance of teaching dyslexic students business ownership skills. The session will conclude with resources that educators can use to teach dyslexic students.
column7: Educate professionals, individuals, schools, and companies about the strong link between dyslexia and entrepreneurship.
column8: Encourage educators, groups, and schools to teach entrepreneurship skills to dyslexic students.
column9: To shift the focus from the weaknesses of dyslexia to what dyslexics can achieve.

column1: Educate Africa:Investing in Market Based Solutions
column5: Irene D. Pritzker (IDP Foundation, Inc)
column6: The mission of the IDP Foundation is to support impact enterprises that provide sustainable, affordable, quality education solutions for schools in developing countries. Based on the results of a needs assessment soon to be underway in Ghana, we will be using the Future 15 platform to make a call to action inviting the education community to bring their new and emerging ideas to help tackle the serious education issues in Africa. We believe philanthropic capital can be used effectively to push forward groundbreaking ideas that revolutionize education and assist country level efforts in meeting the UN's Education 2020 agenda.
column7: Brief overview of the IDP Foundation's Rising Schools Program in Ghana and how it inspired this new project.
column8: The challenges facing schools in developing nations, specifically Ghana, and where innovative market based solutions are needed.
column9: How our call to action for social impact enterprises could scale to assist countries in meeting Education 2020 set forth by the UN in Sept 2015.

column1: Experiential Learning in Startups: Miami OH in SF
column5: Glenn Platt (Armstrong Institute for Interactive Media Studies)
column6: For the past five years, Miami University's Armstrong Institute for Interactive Media Studies has brought students to San Francisco for a full-semester of apprenticeship with digital startups, coupled with weekly visits with/to leaders in the Bay Area digital innovation space. Networking training, growth hacking basics, and more prepare students for a transformative immersive learning experience. Miami is the first undergrad program to do this and has pioneered this semester-long experience. Alums of the program, now at Uber, EventBrite, Twillio, TubeMogul, etc. speak to the power of experience and the new role of higher education - to curate experience and frame opportunities.
column7: How to structure an entrepreneurial and digitally-focused experiential learning program.
column8: Develop a new understanding of the role of higher ed - as experience designers.
column9: Valuing alternative industry relationships with higher education

column1: Fostering an entrepreneurial culture in schools
column5: Pilar Gaitan (The Entrepreneurial Learning Initiative)
column6: Culture is a key component to the success of any school system... but not just any culture. And in today's dynamic world, the pressures school systems face require educators to identify problems, devise ideas, and manifest solutions, across schools and staffs, while remaining developmentally and educationally appropriate for students -- not an easy task. This session will explore entrepreneurship, its role in school culture, and you can use it to empower administrators, educators, and students to achieve their goals and exceed their own expectations.
column7: Define and deconstruct entrepreneurship and its connection to education
column8: Examine the frameworks and structures of today's schools and identify opportunities for change and growth
column9: Determine how entrepreneurial thinking can be absorbed into the systems and cultures of today's schools

column1: How to Recruit Working Adults to College
column5: Samantha Sherman (PelotonU)
column6: This session will explore effective ways to recruit working adults back to school. Oftentimes university enrollment funnels for nontraditional students are smaller in comparison to traditional students, but trends show that nontraditional students are becoming the new traditional. Finding qualified leads is difficult, but there are creative ways to connect with adults that are rarely tapped into. Learn how to leverage community-based programs to assist with your recruitment efforts.
column7: What does a nontraditional college student look like?
column8: What are effective ways to recruit working adults to college?
column9: How can I implement these recruiting strategies for my program?

column1: IoT & Big Data in Pleasure
column5: Soumyadip Rakshit (MysteryVibe)
column6: Imagine a bedroom where 'Things' are enchanted - where complex tech was hidden behind beautiful design. Where 'Things' worked seamlessly together to create an immersive personal experience that took you away from work & stress and turned you on in a matter of seconds.
column7: User-centric empowering design & technology
column8: How the environment matters in our personal pleasure
column9: Need for people to talk more openly and demand more from sex-lives

column1: Leaders in Education Technology
column5: Edward Hanapole (Kaplan, Inc.)
column6: The pace of edtech innovation in the last decade has been astounding. As startups race to find the next big solution, we need to stop and ask ourselves: what does this mean for the overall edtech landscape? How do we pick the winning hand? Join us in this session to learn more about how leaders in the field are building on existing ideas and solutions to create a positive network effect.
column7: Attendees will able to see the future of edtech as enabler of personalized adaptive learning
column8: Attendees will learn about the network effect of combining point solutions to create a new product
column9: Attendees will gain an understanding of how tech innovations from other industries can be incorporated to solve problems in education

column1: Obtaining Rapid Growth
column5: Matthew Pollard (Rapid Growth Coach)
column6: Learn to work a little smarter and a little harder in the short term, to get out of the day-to-day trenches that entrepreneurs blindly charged into. To achieve this, Matthew takes participants through his real-life discovery of a three-step niche marketing process, helping participants to understand why they can_t and shouldn_t be everything to everyone, how to craft a unified message the that intrigues prospects to want to know more as well as helping participant to understand the power of finding and communicating the right message to a true market niche; customers that support their brand and communicate their unique message to others.
column7: Learn how to truly differentiate from the competition.
column8: Discover a niche market of willing and motivated-to-buy customers.
column9: Uncover how to create customers that create customers.

column1: Promoviendo la cultura del emprendimiento
column5: Pilar Gaitan (The Entrepreneurial Learning Initiative)
column6: La cultura es un componente fundamental para el xito de cualquier sistema educativo_ pero no cualquier cultura.  Y en el mundo din mico de hoy, las presiones que deben enfrentar los sistemas educativos, requieren que los educadores identifiquen problemas, conciban ideas y manifiesten ideas, al interior de la institution educativa, de quienes trabajan y le dan vida a las mismas; mientras se mantienen apropiadas para sus estudiantes a nivel educacional y organizacional.  se explorar  el emprendimiento, su rol en la cultura escolar y como se puede utilizar para empoderar al equipo administativo, educadores y estudiantes a  alcanzar sus metas e ir m s all  de sus propias expectativas.
column7: Definir y decosntruir el emprendimiento y su conexi¢n con la education.
column8: Examinar los marcos y estructuras en las instituciones educativas de hoy, identificando oportunidades de cambio y crecimiento.
column9: Determinar como el pensamiento emprendedor puede ser absorbido y acogido en los sistemas y culturas de las escuelas de hoy.

column1: Social Entrepreneurship-Learn to Change the World
column5: Karishma Galani (American School of Bombay)
column6: Social Entrepreneurship is the business of learning to turn our student_s _unreasonable expectations_ into the sustainable businesses the world needs while growing the skills and knowledge our students require. Our students and our world can_t wait! Hear about how the American School of Bombay seeks to (and how your school can) empower students to gather and learn to create businesses with a social impact, through creating a student-led Social Entrepreneurship Summit.
column7: Learn a framework for social entrepreneurship and its' importance to create sustainable social impact.
column8: Learn how students can drive and lead their own initiatives through an example of the student-led Social Entrepreneurship Summit.
column9: Learn about ideas and current practices for starting a social entrepreneurship movement on your campus.

column1: Teaching Women Entrepreneurs: Tips from WIN Lab
column5: Susan Duffy (Babson College)
column6: Entrepreneurship education is not _one size fits all._ This session shares practical tips on creating _alternative spaces_ that support the entrepreneurial development of women. The Babson College Women Innovating Now (WIN) Lab, underpinned by social learning theory, creates a highly collaborative and rigorous approach to building the confidence and competence necessary to launch and grow high potential ventures. Creating a TRIBE is the key to motivation, accountability and transformation for entrepreneurs of all kinds to achieve success.
column7: Learn the WIN Lab model of venture acceleration
column8: Explore four keys to building entrepreneurial self-efficacy
column9: Identify success metrics for internal entrepreneurship education programs

column1: The Blueprint for creating Student Entrepreneurs
column5: Don Wettrick (Noblesville High School)
column6: In this "Power 15" I want to spark a conversation as to why education needs an "Innovation class." For the past four years I have offered this class and the results speak for themselves- four patents, student guest lectures to Stanford, product design seminars, etc. In this short format lecture, I want to briefly (and passionately) explain why schools MUST provide an innovation lab, or class to the curriculum. I want to highlight not only the student projects that were successful, but also the valuable lessons we learned on failure. Lastly, I want to conclude with a "call to arms" in adopting such a class, and an invitation for my students to help aid them in setting a plan in action.
column7: Schools need to foster innovation. Doing so leads to the path of the entrepreneurial experience. Being a "good student" doesn't prepare our students.
column8: How to build an "Innovation class," and the culture that must be put into place to do so.
column9: Information on where you can learn more and connect with teachers and students who are leading the way.

column1: Why There Aren_t More Female Entrepreneurs
column5: Sunny Washington (Ardusat)
column6: Women account for 50% of the educated US population, but only 20% of the entrepreneurs. There_s been steady growth in this but it will take decades for there to be equal representation. The lack of girls pursuing STEM degrees has a major impact on this statistic. In this session, we_ll look at what we can do in education can do to help foster an environment of entrepreneurs for girls.
column7: Participants will understand the entrepreneurial landscape and how it_s represented by gender.
column8: Participants will understand how STEM in education impacts the number of females representing the entrepreneur landscape.
column9: Participants will understand what best practices can be implemented to influence positive change.

column1: 3D Gaming - Perfect Tool To Learn a Trade
column5: Doug Donovan (Interplay Learning)
column6: How do we fill the US Workforce middle-skills gap?  How do we interest 18 year-olds in classic trades that can't be sent overseas like Electrical, Heating Ventilation Air Conditioning (HVAC), Manufacturing, Code Inspection, Energy Auditors, where good careers are to be found?  3D gaming is a great place to start.  Come experience numerous training games that look and feel like "Call of Duty" but instead of killing the bad guys, you are learning your trade.  Ever wire a virtual house?  Ever control a virtual 6 axis robot? Come by and learn about how gaming is meeting the needs of the next generation of service technicians, apprentices and career- focused middle skills workers.
column7: Learn creative ways to engage students in middle skills careers and workforce development
column8: Learn how 3D gaming technology can bring life to "tired" trades
column9: Learn how career certification organizations are looking to 3D gaming as an assessment tool

column1: Game Designers, Also Known as Teachers
column5: Kaolin McEvoy (Lexington Public Schools)
column6: How do teachers weigh the relevance and effectiveness of analog versus digital tools? The cornucopia of digital learning, including coding, leaves teachers wondering if they_re advancing the revolution or just doing tech for tech_s sake. This talk will explore how a software, which allows teachers to build real-time, multi-player simultaneous games, could be as simple as building a lesson plan. Instead of using ready-made, content specific games, teachers should have access to a gaming toolkit, with digital and analog parts. Teacher use of drag and drop players, events and decisions, all catered to their students_ learning needs, should be as easy as creating any collaborative activity.
column7: Provide a series of recipes for mixing digital and analog tools to enrich student learning.
column8: Articulate framework, and specific scenarios, for gaming software to underscore how teacher created games service curricula, and visa versa.
column9: Show how software equips student and teacher data analysis, enables feedback, and leads to new solutions and challenges, including student efficacy.

column1: Learning resources with 3D: Changing textbooks
column5: Ondrej Homola (Corinth)
column6: As one of the most awarded K-12 EdTech startups in 2015, we_re helping teachers and students adopt technology in their every day experience. With access to educational resources enriched with visuals previously reserved to the gaming industry, students in 109 countries can learn STEM, critical thinking, problem solving and 21st century learning skills with great motivation. We'll share inspiring lesson activities from wonderful educators from all around the world and talk about surprising outcomes. We need the thought leaders at SXSW to understand and join this new movement from a flat world to a three dimensional universe. So tag along as we need you for the learning revolution!
column7: Learn about the value of latest publishing technologies (e.g. 3D imaginery, 3D print, Augmented Reality) and its benefits for the learning process.
column8: Show the full potential of hardware in everyday classroom with enhanced learning resources.
column9: Preparing lesson plans and captivating learning resources thanks to integration to productivity tools.

column1: Retention & Engagement Through Mobile Gamification
column5: Scott Reinke (Ball State University)
column6: Ball State Achievements is a new app launched in fall of 2014 for Ball State University (BSU) students that gamifies the entire college experience. Students can explore the app and find "Achievements" to complete such as visiting their academic advisor or attending a football game. When students complete achievements, they are rewarded with "Experience" and "Bennies" which allow them to purchase real world swag from the Ball State Bookstore.In this presentation, you'll learn how we used core principles of good game design to drive students to engage with University resources and increase their chances of overall success at Ball State University.
column7: Core principles of game design.
column8: How to create an engaging interactive experience for students.
column9: How to get good feedback and iterate on an interactive student engagement program.

column1: 10 Lessons Teachers Can Learn from Marketers
column5: Stephan Bayer (sofatutor.com)
column6: What do good teachers and good marketers have in common? Good marketers sell the benefit of a product and great marketers involve as many senses as possible. As an educator and as a marketer you have to think beyond your product to reach your students.In 2008 Stephan Bayer started his EdTech company. A company whose success is based on teachers who produce valuable content and on marketing experts who know how to address users. Over the years those two teams started to work closer together and share insights with each other. Shortly after, the teachers applied marketing learnings in their lessons. The results: the students involvement went up, churn rates went down and grades got better.
column7: How do marketing experts address students in general?
column8: Which marketing methods can be applied in teaching?
column9: How does the implementation of marketing methods affect your students?

column1: Coding the Common Core
column5: David Dulberger (Washington County Public Schools)
column6: As the advisor of an after school coding club at a 1:1 Apple Distinguished School and a 5th grade magnet teacher, I am beyond eager to share strategies for infusing coding into the Common Core Curriculum. During this presentation, I will help teachers to establish purposeful routines for coding in the classroom. I will model and the use of a variety of resources that can be used including iOS applications, web based programs, unplugged activities, Lego robotics, and more. My presentation will delve into ways that these resources can support essential curriculum. Attendees will walk away with the coding confidence they need to return to their classrooms/schools with a #KidsCanCode mentality.
column7: How does coding connect to the Common Core and other curricula?
column8: How can I assess student_s coding abilities and differentiate the learning process for them?
column9: How do I stay current with the _coding curriculum" and best practices for teaching programming?

column1: Flying Cars Would Be Nice in the On-Demand Economy
column5: Brooks Rainwater (National League of Cities)
column6: The sharing economy has delivered us things we already have only better. It's time for the new stuff we have been promised in sci fi for generations. This talk will be an extrapolation on the research I have done in this space, the conversations I have had with leading thinkers, politicians and more, focused on thinking about what is next and how we get there. It won't only be research based though, a healthy dose of fun and mischief is necessary.
column7: Future transportation ideas that the on-demand environment can help precipitate, like personal transport options - driverless cars to connected pods.
column8: Logistics of on-demand goods within minutes and how it happens.
column9: Public transportation innovations shaped in partnership with the tech industry that barely resembles current buses/subways.

column1: Go Global! Live Streaming in Blended Learning
column5: Stephanie Castle (United Nations International School)
column6: In blended learning environments there is some element of student control over time, place, path or pace.  Video is often used asynchronously here, whereas live streaming can allow for both synchronous and asynchronous use.  There are multiple live streaming platforms available with a variety of features.  This session aims to simplify and present one multi-device live streaming platform whose features have been evaluated to specifically support its effective use as a tool with students in future blended learning environments.  Attendees will see an example of how this live streaming tool has been used to engage over 50 students worldwide in intensive synchronous study using online gaming.
column7: Identify a multi-device live streaming platform which has been evaluated for its effective use with students.
column8: Explore the features of a live streaming platform that make it a beneficial tool in blended learning.
column9: Discuss an example of how live streaming has been used to engage students in synchronous study using online gaming.

column1: How the WSJ helps you master business English
column5: Paul Jackson (Newsmart)
column6: English is a now pre-requisite for international business and for self advancement globally. But learning a new language is challenging. It's hard to stay motivated and find the time to study.In response, the Wall Street Journal created a new digital teaching service called Newsmart. It combines daily news content from the Journal, the expertise of a professional Learning Team and gamification to help ambitious professionals master business English.It addresses the issue of motivation directly by the use of 'hyper-relevant' content and people's instincts to compete and win badges and points.This session will outline why the WSJ created Newsmart and what it has learnt.
column7: Why news content is the perfect vehicle for addressing the problem of motivation in language learning, and education in general.
column8: Why news organisations have a bright future in EdTech and the English as a Foreign Language (EFL) sector in particular.
column9: Why partnerships between media companies and learning specialists (in this case the WSJ and ELTJam) can be key to new product innovation in EdTech.

column1: How to connect educators and a TV channel
column5: Dbora  Garcia (Canal Futura)
column6: In this session the speaker intends to present the Canal Futura Educators Council that was created in May, 2014, highlighting the strategies that are being used to gather more than 4,000 educators from all over Brazil to share and discuss new ideas, themes and methodologies in a creative and learning environment on Facebook. Since the creation of the group Canal Futura was able to produce journalism stories that emerged from the teachers, to launch educational campaings based on their ideas and suggestions, to create a video workshop designed specifically for teachers as well as to collect testimonials of the educational use they implement in the school using Canal Futuraïs contents.
column7: learn about the possibilities of a social network with educational purposes
column8: identify the limits and challenges of a community online
column9: contribute to work collaboratively among teachers using the Facebook
column10: educators, social network, facebook, brazilian teachers

column1: Inviting the Public Back into Public Education
column5: Troy Miller (Iowa BIG)
column6: How can we prepare students for the _real world_ when many of the future jobs they will tackle have yet to be created, and those that currently exist, already experience radical upheaval and elimination? The answer is to invite the public back into public education. As a rapidly changing world increases the need for authentic and contextualized education, we must embed students in real businesses, nonprofits, government organizations, and co-work spaces with real-world professionals and Initiatives. This "Initiative Based Learning" infuses teachers and students alike with a new zeal for teaching and learning, while Partners experience a multitude of benefits.
column7: Learn how to change mind-sets both publicly and within your school walls to garner the support and participation you need.
column8: Understand Partner participation levels such as Projects, Mentors, Professional Development, Work Space, and Funding.
column9: Learn from actual experiences at Iowa BIG, illustrating both best practices as well as pitfalls to avoid.

column1: Navigating a Sea of Teacher Evaluation Data
column5: Libby Fischer (Whetstone Education)
column6: Performance management in K-12 education has evolved more in the last 10 years than in the last 100. Schools are collecting an ocean of data about teacher performance, and sharing that data with their State DOE for compliance. But how can they make these data points actionable and measure good teaching beyond a 1-5 scale? Qualitative teacher data could be transformationally useful in measuring teacher growth if we were able to visualize and measure it in valid, reliable ways. How can ed tech solutions take cues from social media to help school leaders pull out the highest leverage information and empower users to support teacher growth based on a more holistic picture of teacher performance?
column7: What is qualitative data? Understanding the differences between qualitative and quantitative data in teacher evaluation.
column8: How to use qualitative data to create a more holistic picture of teacher performance and identify trends that cannot be scored on a 1-5 scale.
column9: How technology can empower all stakeholders in the teacher evaluation process.

column1: School Innovation: Lone Geniuses Need Not Apply
column5: Scot Hoffman (American School of Bombay)
column6: Sustained innovation for relevant learning can_t be done by lone geniuses, think tanks, or even other schools. Sustained Innovation requires a system that engages educators like you to do the inspiring everyday work of building a culture of innovation in your context by exploring, studying, prototyping, researching and scaling new innovations your school and your students need. Lone Geniuses need not apply.
column7: Learn about a system for sustaining innovation for relevant learning
column8: Learn about essential conditions for successful school innovation
column9: Learn how to strategically grow a school culture that sustains innovation

column1: Student Resilience in Higher Ed
column5: Adina Glickman (Stanford University)
column6: Academic resilience can be seen as a capacity to reflect on and learn from the normal failures and setbacks that accompany a college education. Educators can help students grow their resilience by both considering how they communicate a "fixed" or "growth" mindset, but also by developing and modeling their own narratives around academic, personal, and professional failure and resilience. Participants will be invited to reflect on and share with one other participant an experience they've encountered that helped them develop resilience. They will then refine this narrative as preparation for sharing with students at a later time. This exercise was developed by The Stanford Resilience Project.
column7: Learn about the 5-stage process of developing resilience
column8: Learn about the 3 types of failures students commonly experience
column9: Develop a narrative that can be modeled for students

column1: Teacher Perception of 1:1 Technology
column5: Stacy Gherardi (Berwyn South District 100)
column6: Although studies have demonstrated that teacher beliefs, initial training, and ongoing support is critical to the success of any technology initiative, we know little about how teachers perceive technology initiatives once they have been fully established.  The session shares the experiences of teachers in one low-income school district which is currently in its 5th year of 1:1 implementation.  While the district has earned accolades as a distinguished program, teacher perceptions and sentiments around the program are surprisingly mixed.  By sharing their thoughts and voices, this session aims to identify critical factors which shape post-implementation teacher perceptions of such programs.
column7: Understand approaches to 1:1 implementation that have led to effective use of laptops in a low-income school district
column8: Explore the relevance of teacher perceptions in implementation
column9: Identify critical factors which shape teachers' post-implementation perceptions of 1:1 technology

column1: Teacher Voice in the Design Process
column5: Candace Flaherty (Mobility Labs)
column6: Ever wondered what design thinking or user-centered design in education technology products are?  Are you interested in getting involved with the development of edtech products?  At this session, we will discuss ways that educators can ensure their voices are being heard during the design and development of new products.
column7: You'll learn what design thinking and human centered design in education technology products are.
column8: You'll find out how teachers can get involved in the design process of edtech products and tools.
column9: You'll know what to expect from an involved feedback process for an edtech product.

column1: The College Media Hub
column5: Shane Tilton (Ohio Northern University)
column6: Ohio Northern University (ONU) created a new program "Multimedia Journalism" as a response to the change the media economy. Part of this change meant folding the newspaper into the rest of the media at ONU and publishing a digital edition, instead of print.The framework for the fifteen minutes would begin with my understanding of the current state of college media and college journalism. This would be followed by the brief discussion of the journalism program at ONU, including a short history of the program. The next step would be a description of the current media program and our five-year plan for the program. Finally, the plan is to discuss the lessons learned during the transition.
column7: Applying a model of the campus media hub to multiple institutions of higher learning.
column8: Analyzing the student-run media platform of a typical college and understanding how those platforms can fit together.
column9: Selecting the most effective solution when it comes to media education at the college level.

column1: Virtual Reality at the British Museum
column5: Lizzie Edwards (The British Museum)
column6: What is the value of virtual reality environments for learning by schools and families? In August 2015 the Samsung Digital Discovery Centre at the British Museum explored this question on the ground and in-action with our family visitors by hosting a _Virtual Reality Weekend_. During the weekend, families were able to explore the Museum_s first virtual reality environment, a Bronze Age round house, set within a landscape, that presented 3D scans of three real objects from this period in history.This workshop will share the findings from our virtual reality weekend and subsequent audience testing, demonstrating and discussing the value of virtual environments for teaching and learning.
column7: How virtual reality environments can enhance teaching and learning
column8: How-to process of creating a VR environment
column9: How Museums can enhance understanding of their collections using new technologies

column1: WordPress for Schools - Saving Taxpayer Dollars
column5: Cameron Barrett (Newark Public Schools)
column6: Learn how NJ's largest public school district (Newark Public Schools) migrated from an expensive vendor-controlled content management system to WordPress, cutting our web site operating budget in half three years in a row. By switching to open source technologies, we gained complete control over our web sites and are now building applications and tools on top of WordPress that better service our district. A complete case study (that can serve as a model for your district) will be presented.
column7: How to save taxpayer dollars by migrating to open source technologies.
column8: How to use WordPress for more than just a content management system: mobile apps, enrollment systems, learning management systems, etc.
column9: Learn some concrete facts and figures you can use when talking with your administrators, board members and technology departments.

column1: CommonLit: A Teacher-Led Innovation
column5: Michelle Brown (CommonLit, Inc.)
column6: CommonLit is a nonprofit ed tech company that delivers high-quality instructional materials. At CommonLit.org, teachers, parents, literacy directors, or after-school tutors can access a free collection of the best news articles, short stories, historical documents, poems, and scientific articles--all organized by the themes that students love to discuss. The result is a proven framework for reading, writing, and speaking that truly drives student engagement. CommonLit was named the winner of the 2015 TFA Social Innovation Award. In this session, CommonLit founder Michelle Brown will demo the resource, and discuss the research that inspired the model.
column7: 1. Access the tools on the CommonLit site
column8: 2. Get inspired by ways to incorporate CommonLit in the classroom
column9: 3. Learn about the research and trends that inspired CommonLit

column1: Education is the Next Punk Rock
column5: Martin Atkins (SAE Chicago)
column6: Martin Atkins will discuss his experience as punk turned educator and how his punk mentality has informed his innovative attitude to education. Atkins will share student success stories, teaching philosophies, classroom management techniques correlating the punk rock mentality to increased learning outcomes and retention. By challenging both student and teacher to question everything, especially authority, a more dynamic, learning-centered classroom is born... plus he's giving away muffins!
column7: Think of your syllabus and course outline as a set list. Fireworks week one, formula for gun powder week 5.
column8: Implement "hands-on_ and _project-based_ learning and manage the chaos that inevitably ensues.
column9: Replace the traditional approach to learning with non-linear and flipped classrooms.

column1: Emergent Literacy Through Engaging Conversations
column5: Anne Cunningham (UC Berkeley)
column6: Teacher Lesson Study, a form of professional development, has been shown to significantly improve teaching techniques and classroom management. Through video footage, discussion, and demonstration, this session will map out the mechanics of the Teacher Lesson Study model for emergent literacy and provide concrete strategies to implement them in your school. A three-year study of PreK-K teachers who participated in our Teacher Lesson Study project will also be shared.
column7: To provide an overview of each content area of the Teacher Lesson Study: oral language, phonological awareness, alphabetics, and quality instruction.
column8: How Teacher Lesson Study supports the following: activity modeling; solving problems that arise in the classroom; cohesive teacher engagement.
column9: To promote relation-based professional development opportunities to foster deep and engaging conversations about teacher beliefs, and more.

column1: Empowering Student Authors with eBook Publication
column5: Karen Bosch (Southfield Christian School)
column6: Educators will be surprised how easy it is for students to create eBooks with rich multimedia content simply by using an iPad. This session will share a process that allows learners of all ages to create and publish eBooks for an authentic global audience. We will look at examples of individual and collaborative student books.  Resources and hints for managing projects and publishing will be shared.
column7: Learners will engage in a purposeful writing experience for an authentic audience.
column8: Learners will use multimedia components such as images, audio, and video to illustrate and enhance their writing.
column9: Learners will make global connections with an audience through publication of their writing.

column1: Gen Z- Stop Talking About and Start Engaging Them
column5: Carolyn Kent (Ologie)
column6: Gen Z: the status-quo-challenger generation. The change-the-world generation. The true digital natives (sorry, Millennials). The world is buzzing about what Gen Z thinks, feels, does, texts, and tweets, but it's time for some real talk. Welcome to your Gen Z primer. It will help you understand what defines them: technology, family life, entertainment, education, and everything in between. We must explore new ways of connecting with them. They have a perspective, a voice, and a readiness to make a difference. We have some suggestions for how to engage tomorrow's college students.
column7: Understand how Gen Z is different from Millennials, and what has shaped their world
column8: Learn best practices for engaging Gen Z on different topics and in different contexts
column9: Learn about the trends impacting the next five years

column1: Hire a Teacher, Not a Tech Integration Specialist
column5: Sara  Speicher (Hopkins School District)
column6: The role of a technology integration specialist is to help teachers best utilize the multitude of tech tools available to improve student performance and engage learners. However, staffing this position often takes good teachers out of the classroom. Instead of using this typical model, administrators should look for teachers that will share the both roles. This keeps quality teachers in the classroom, where they can _practice what they preach_ and also stay in tune with the needs and the demands of the profession. Hear how one district is having success with this model.
column7: Learn the rationale of having a dual role of a teacher and technology integration specialist.
column8: Learn the background of the team that serves a K-12 model across 9 schools and the roles of tech integration specialists serve in the district.
column9: Identify challenges and benefits of having a model in this manner.

column1: No One Cares About Standards - We Want Skills
column5: Harvey  Chism (Expanded Success Initiative )
column6: Outside the realm of K-12 education, standards have no meaning. Focusing on skills is tangible and transferable for students. The General Electric (GE) Skills Lab Pilot is funded by the GE Foundation to enhance the scope of skill-building experiences designed to prepare students for college and career success. By shifting the focus from standards to skills, educators and collaborating partners, along with industry representatives, co-design and deliver contextualized performance tasks that promote students_ mastery of 21st century skills. This initiative is a unique example of how education and industry can challenge the existing paradigm to provide students authentic learning experiences.
column7: Understanding the role of external school partners in skills-based college and career preparation efforts.
column8: Learn how to enhance diverse and authentic learning experiences through 21st century skill integration.
column9: Learn about innovations and strategies to develop and deepen expanded learning opportunity programs.

column1: Open education with design thinking
column5: Priscila Gonsales (Educadigital Institute)
column6: Design Thinking is a good opportunity for education because it brings a teacher and student centered philosophy. It is based on three basic values: empathy, collaboration and experimentation. It's perfect to enable teacher_s _digital literacy,_ the proficiency and familiarity with the web. This includes training teachers to conduct research on the internet, collaborate online, and once they start to produce materials, the responsibilities and rights due to them as authors of content. Teachers and students need to learn broader, more comprehensive internet skills, which are essential to research and any content production, rather than solely learning certain specific subjects.
column7: Empathy: the exercise of putting oneself in the place of students to understand the challenges and opportunities of education in a digital culture.
column8: Collaboration: centered on the free exchange of ideas and experiences, and the collaborative potential posed by the internet.
column9: Experimentation: letting the students an teachers plan their own objectives for the production they will be present and create it by themselves

column1: Peer to Peer Learning for a Truly Global Education
column5: Joe Troyen (PenPal Schools)
column6: Rapidly expanding internet access, especially in the developing world, makes it possible for students to connect from across countries, socioeconomic backgrounds, and ideologies. Through first-person accounts and live streaming from teachers and students around the world, we_ll explore how peer-to-peer learning is changing the way that students understand the world, practice languages, and share perspectives. We_ll review the latest collaborative learning tools, analyze the data to evaluate the impact of connected global education on learning outcomes, and examine how students_ experiences broaden their perspectives and form the foundation for a more peaceful and collaborative planet.
column7: Explore how standards-aligned curriculum is being integrated into online exchanges to create substantive learning experiences
column8: Review tools that bring project-based learning online to foster global collaboration
column9: Understand the effects of global collaboration on student learning outcomes, worldviews, and perspectives

column1: Personalized Online Courses
column5: Bhavneet Chahal (GoSkills.com)
column6: One of the biggest issues facing self-directed online learning is the loss of motivation and as a result, industry-wide staggeringly low course completion rates (1-10%). Personalized online courses is one way to combat this problem. Solutions to increase engagement include adaptive testing to surface relevant content, customizing content based on individual needs, personalized messages of encouragement, goal setting and peer accountability as an incentive to complete tasks. Personalization provides a persistent connection to the student to maximize engagement and benefits the student by encouraging them to make progress through achieving small, reachable goals.
column7: Why online course completion rates are so low: Common obstacles in achieving your learning goals online.
column8: Creating an environment where the student can make significant, measurable progress in learning.
column9: How personalization can be used in online courses to increase engagement.

column1: Six Word Stories, Six Unique Shots
column5: Don Goble (Ladue School District)
column6: Explore an activity that brings the writing process to life with digital storytelling. A simple six-word story, created as a video with six unique camera shots or photos set to music or narration, allows students the ability to tell a powerful visual story. This presentation will guide educators through a unique project that addresses the fundamentals of filmmaking as well as the digital storytelling process, with a major focus on multiple modalities.
column7: Students will engage in the multimedia digital storytelling process to enhance their writing.
column8: Students will be exposed to media literacy through a creation and consumption process.
column9: Students will be asked to utilize multiple modalities to successfully complete the project and reflect upon the experience.

column1: Soft Skills & Surviving the Maelstrom
column5: Devin O'Bryan (IBM)
column6: How can students gain an edge in some of the most hotly contested job markets? What qualities are hiring managers now looking toward to separate "good" from "great"?Maelstrom is IBM's premier internship experience, created with the intention to train and subsequently hire the best talent in higher education. Through the lens of Maelstrom, program creator Devin O'Bryan will discuss the role that soft skills, self-judgement, and mindfulness have played in creating a dynamic internship experience that is challenging college professors just as much as the interns who directly take part in the experience.
column7: Students will walk away energized, optimistic about their future careers, and armed with first steps to apply the ideas discussed.
column8: Educators will come to understand of the impact self-judgement has on both a classroom setting & the likelihood of their students being hired.
column9: Administrators will leave with a greater understanding of what professional hiring looks like for students (K-12/Higher Ed) in the next 5 years.

column1: Stories of Building a Math Curriculum
column5: Zach Hurdle (Skybridge Academy)
column6: At a school emerging into the Austin Alt Ed scene going into its fifth year, the real challenge is building a math program that is different and innovative while still engaging and exciting, but also getting kids to learn what they need going forward. This conversation will give the audience a few specific project ideas, some references to get more interesting lessons, tales of what has worked and what hasn't, what makes our curriculum different in terms of material and style, and a general storyline of what it takes to build a curriculum from nothing.
column7: a general idea of what we have been building at my institution
column8: the successes and failures of creating your own curriculum
column9: a few classroom thinking project assignments and where to find them

column1: Syllabi are Evil and They Must Die
column5: Glenn Stutzky (Michigan State University, School of Social Work)
column6: If you want your students to see what's already been seen, know what's already known, go where we've been going - this is not the session for you. But, if you want to go somewhere new - see colors beyond red, green, and blue - then stop on by and lend and ear, you might be amazed or frightened by what you hear.But don't be afraid, for you shall find the most amazing things from creative minds set free to fly - once untethered from the syllabi.The education system has over tested, evaluated, and bored the love of learning and creativity right out of children. This session is dedicated to to proclaiming the end of the Era where Syllabi ruled and heralds what is coming.
column7: To illustrate that learning emerges from curiosity, inquisitiveness, and the passion where teachers and students are co-educators.
column8: To explore how the organic nature of learning demands space and freedom from external artificial constraints.
column9: To dramatize that Syllabi are Evil and They Must Die - a funeral service will be held at the conclusion of the session.

column1: Teaching the Weird Way
column5: Doug Robertson (Gresham-Barlow School District)
column6: Using tricks and techniques developed and tested in classrooms from CA to HI to OR, I will help teachers see the positive in their classrooms.
