Through classroom and personal stories and sharing, we will find that all students deserve empathy and acceptance.Teaching and learning should be a joyful experience for everyone involved, from student to teacher to admin to parent. Teachers will be more willing to experiment and stretch their creative wings in their rooms to better serve each and every student after this motivational, interactive, and informative session. There will also be puppets.
column7: Teachers will develop a deeper appreciation for allowing teacher and student creativity to flourish freely in the classroom.
column8: Teachers will see the value of a 5:1 Positive:Negative Reinforcement system that stresses positive attitudes through the school.
column9: Teachers will see the value and fun a puppet brings to a classroom, allowing students more freedom of expression.

column1: Teaching with an Entrepreneur's Mindset
column5: Matthew Horan (Dallas ISD)
column6: In the landscape of more administrative pressure, the focus on testing, and the micromanaging that results from it, teachers are more burdened than ever before. This presentation is to help teachers by incorporating the mindsets of entrepreneurs and intrapreneurs.
column7: Attendees Will Be Able To apply the Entrepreneur's Mindset to teaching.
column8: Attendees Will Be Able To understand the importance of risk-taking in teaching.
column9: Attendees Will Be Able To apply the Entrepreneur's Mindset to teaching and understand the importance of risk-taking.

column1: The Consumer Tech Trends Impacting Edu In 2016
column5: James Cross (MediaCore)
column6: Education doesn't exist in a vacuum_and advances in consumer tech and behaviors are changing learning forever. The Millennials and Gen Z-ers who are sat in our classrooms right now have driven much of this rapid change _ and in this fast-paced session, we'll cover 2016's top consumer trends _ exploring their impact on the learning landscape, and how we can leverage these trends as educators and entrepreneurs.How will cord-cutting affect the education industry? Why will Facebook's unbundling of its apps kill the traditional LMS? What does Taylor Swift have in common with top-tier schools? Why are mobile and UX so critical for the learning apps of the future? Find out in this session.
column7: What are 2016's key consumer trends? How are Millenials and Gen Z-ers consuming content and using technology in new ways?
column8: How will these trends impact on the learning landscape of the future? How will the current way of doing things be disrupted?
column9: How can we 'skate ahead of the puck' by leveraging these new trends and behaviors, as educators and edtech entrepreneurs?

column1: The Future of the Networked Classroom
column5: Christina  Carrion (Nepris, Inc)
column6: Your mobile technology has the ability to connect classrooms in ways that were once unimagined. What educators do to leverage the opportunities to network with professionals in the STEMcareers is our focus. The Networked Classroom of today is expansive and offers students the opportunities to connect virtually with industry professionals to engage in presentations, ask questions to panels of experts and breaks down barriers related to logistics and time. The Networked Classroom identifies tools to bring its content and curriculum to the real world and provide authentic learning experiences to the classroom straight from industry experts.
column7: Provide educational equity opportunities to students by connecting virtually to experts, discussing best practices and engaging learning spaces.
column8: Demonstrate opportunities for educators to use web tools to grow their Industry Professional Network.Provide educational equity opportunities to students by connecting virtually to experts, discussing best practices and engaging learning spaces.
column9: Describe learning spaces of the digital generation- videoconferencing, hands-on opportunities for learning and growing a professional learning network

column1: The New Reality of Education - Incorporating AR/VR
column5: Dhan Balachand (Sulon Technologies Inc.)
column6: Education is set to be transformed by virtual and augmented reality, but much is still unclear about how quickly that shift will take place and to what depth the technology will be integrated into the education system. This exciting new medium has huge advantages over traditional print and digital methods of teaching, allowing the classroom to take on a life of its own and span far beyond the four walls it is enclosed by. Students with learning styles previously underserved by traditional curriculum can be reintegrated into the classroom in a manner that prepares them for success and eases the strain on educators.
column7: How can augmented and virtual reality be used within the classroom?
column8: What is experiential learning and what does it mean for students?
column9: How is the technology being used within the classroom today and what does the shift look like over the coming years?

column1: WhoClass: The MOOC That's Bigger on the Inside
column5: Anthony Rotolo (Syracuse University)
column6: #WhoClass, or "Doctor Who in the Digital Age," is a Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) on the history and cultural impact of the British science fiction series, "Doctor Who," which has attracted thousands of students and worldwide media coverage. #WhoClass leverages a unique set of online learning techniques developed by Prof. Rotolo of the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications at Syracuse University. In this session, Prof. Rotolo will break down the elements of #WhoClass to explain how this "unearthly course" grew from a "mild curiosity on a college campus" into a global learning experience that is truly "bigger on the inside." (A special mini-session of #WhoClass will be included)
column7: A Madman with a Class: Learn the key elements of Prof. Rotolo's social media teaching strategy and how to apply these tools to your own course idea.
column8: Timey-wimey Tools: The Doctor has his TARDIS and Sonic Screwdriver. Learn about the tools YOU can use to teach (and travel) across space and time.
column9: ALLONS-Y! See for yourself how it all works with a special mini-session of #WhoClass! Learn about the amazing history of Doctor Who. Cosplay welcome!

column1: Will you next doctor be trained online?
column5: Emily  Foote (ApprenNet, Inc.)
column6: Can something as hands-on and complex as medical science be taught remotely? In 2011, the National Science Foundation awarded ApprenNet a grant to build a platform that would allow instructors to bring to the magic of face-to-face skills training to an online world. In 2015, instructors from across the world use ApprenNet to not only teach hard skills, but also soft skills. Learn how you can use it too.
column7: Understand how to leverage different learning pedagogies into an online format
column8: Translate curriculum designed for in person sessions to an online format
column9: Design compelling video based learning exercises for hard and soft skills

column1: A Story of Trailblazing A Local Education Solution
column5: Hadass Sheffer (The Graduate! Network )
column6: 3 people in Philadelphia had an idea _What if every college dropout had the resources to return and finish their degree?_ Hadass Sheffer, President of the Graduate! Network and founding Executive Director of Graduate! Philadelphia, will share how she and her fellow trailblazers in Philadelphia went from designing a local solution, growing a national movement and scaling/implementing a locally based national solution.  This session will share applicable take-aways on how to change the conversation, create a local solution and build a national movement. From rallying the troops, launching Graduate! Philadelphia in 2008 and currently scaling a coast-to-coast national model.
column7: What does it mean to trailblaze and implement a successful, sustainable community-focused educational solution?
column8: What does it mean to scale? Asking the tough but essential first questions.
column9: How do you keep innovating, sustaining and growing? Strategies for being the hub for building a community of learning and growing.

column1: Beyond the Achievement Gap: Why Do We Educate?
column5: Kriste Dragon (Citizens of the World Charter Schools)
column6: Are our schools designed to prevent another Ferguson or Charleston? Are we leading and working in schools that we would send our own children to? Academic proficiency, as measured by standardized tests, have come to wholly define success in America today. But other traits are just as important and need to be discussed, measured and valued in the same way. It is also important that our kids value difference, build connections and are compassionate and courageous. They need to consider the needs of others and the greater good. Schools can support a more cohesive and peaceful society, but we need to consider why we educate in the first place and what an impactful education requires.
column7: Grapple with the question, "Why do we educate?" and evaluate whether our schools are currently designed in alignment with our answers.
column8: Impact and expand the conversation about what an excellent education contains, requires, and accomplishes.
column9: Push our collective thinking on what we believe the "residuals" of a K-12 education are and/or should be so that our students realize their potential.

column1: Building an Urban School Leaders Network
column5: Greg  Schermbeck (Self)
column6: Where is leadership development within high-impact schools in high-poverty communities? School leaders need coaches and thought-partners in order to navigate the challenging waters of high-poverty schools. However, one of the largest barriers preventing this is communication. This session will present the Urban School Leaders Network; a social, web-based platform that allows school Leaders to collaborate privately and securely to solve their toughest problems. Join this session and you will be invited to become part of this inaugural collaborative and our hope is we all extend this conversation into our communities.
column7: Create a network for attendees to share best practices that help address the toughest challenges facing high poverty urban schools.
column8: Attendees will take part in a collaborative discussion about how we can get school leaders to reach out to one another when facing challenges.
column9: Attendees will provide feedback to enhance the Urban School Leaders Network which will serve as a communication tool for everyone beyond the session.

column1: Cross-Sector Leadership to Accelerate Innovation
column5: Sunanna Chand (Remake Learning Council)
column6: Picture a classroom. Rectangular desks neatly facing one direction, pencils scribbling dutifully on notebook paper. Now imagine industry-leading design thinkers turning rectangle desks circular.  Imagine Kindergarteners working with Higher Ed to scribble sketches of closed circuits as they prepare to tinker with lights and switches.These future-forward, cross-sector educational opportunities are stewarded by leaders with power to spark and sustain regional networks that fuel creative collaboration.  Learn how your region will benefit when local executives from government, education, philanthropy, industry, and nonprofits collide and converse to accelerate learning innovation.
column7: Attendees will be able to explain how cross-sector leadership fuels learning innovation in one example city: Pittsburgh, PA.
column8: Attendees will be able to identify key leaders in their own local learning ecosystems that could collaborate to advance learning innovation.
column9: Attendees will be able to design an action plan to create a future-forward, cross-sector collaborative group of executives in their local context.

column1: How to Build a University in the 21st Century
column5: Cynthia Teniente-Matson (Texas A&M University-San Antonio)
column6: What should higher education look like in the 21st century? What innovations would allow a university to better serve its community? These are the sorts of questions currently being asked at Texas A&M University-San Antonio, which finds itself faced with a unique opportunity. The young university has served as an upper-division institution since its founding in 2009. But in the fall of 2016, it will welcome its first-ever freshman and sophomore classes. This expansion has the potential to transform the historically underserved South San Antonio area, so it is crucial that it be done right. The university's president will discuss the promise and the challenge of creating a new university.
column7: Explore new, innovative strategies for operating a university
column8: Examine which current practices in higher education provide opportunities to respond to community needs to scale
column9: Forecast the coming changes, challenges and opportunities that will affect all universities

column1: Jessica Hanson-First Year Rogue Principal
column5: Jessica  Hanson (Walnut Creek Elementary)
column6: After finishing my first year as an elementary school principal, I learned that to lead I must first fail. We cannot learn, grow, or get better without making some mistakes. Once we learn to let go of the "get it right" obsession we free ourselves of ever getting anything "wrong" again. Learn to love the learning, the process, the mistakes, and then we can find the big wins in our schools. If we want to inspire a generation of passionate, hard-working individuals then we need to teach them like no other generation. By first, telling them to get it wrong.
column7: Leading by example
column8: Failure in teaching and learning
column9: Inspiring change in schools

column1: Kids As Champions of Change - One Book at a Time
column5: Kyra Citron (Charles Lafitte Foundation)
column6: Kids have a voice, a role, and the power of change to help better their communities. This session shows how the Charles Lafitte Foundation's Kid's Corner program, which is run by kids, gives young activists the Champions of Change Book Drive program model to organize local book drives. The session covers how to teach kids to conduct book drives: from choosing local charities that will receive the books to delivering hundreds/thousands of volumes. Teen Kyra Citron, Kid's Corner Director, has run three book drives and collected a total of 10,000 books that were donated to the Bridge of Books Foundation. She shares her knowledge and experience with other kids and adults who teach/mentor them.
column7: How do kids have the power to change the world through community service, volunteerism and philanthropy?
column8: How can collecting and donating books reinforce the importance of reading and volunteerism -- and why is this a great way to fulfill community service
column9: How does demonstrating a passion for youth literacy via performing community service especially-well suits kids aspiring to apply to college?

column1: Mind the Resource Gap: Collaboration Across States
column5: Pat Bush (Delaware Department of Education)
column6: MSTC, the Multi-State Technology Collaborative, was formed by IT leads in ten state education agencies. Come hear directly from one of the group's state leads and about their commitment to work together to develop and share effective solutions for their agencies_ information and technology needs. These states have created an innovative compact to leverage each other_s work.  As today_s education strategies focus on faster data systems with greater functionality than ever before, states struggle to reach multiple competing objectives while often facing diminishing resources.  Through the MSTC model, states can share expertise that will have the biggest impact in providing classroom support.
column7: Understand how the MSTC model is structured to reduce risk and cost.
column8: Examine current progress and future work of MSTC through their state partnerships.
column9: Discuss how to create IT collaboration opportunities for state and local education agencies within and across states.

column1: Sustaining Results:  Moving the Profession Forward
column5: Joe Ten Brook (Austin Achieve Public Schools)
column6: This session is based on the idea that achieving results is not helpful if teachers do not stay in their positions for longer periods and is based on own personal narrative of quickly moving up and out of the classroom to school leadership.  In my talk I reflect on the shift toward standards, data-driven instruction, and begin to think about what we can do to keep teachers where they are without lowering the bar.  Sustainability is the backdrop as I talk about technology, social issues, teacher development, and always starting with the question "what is best for students"?
column7: Teachers and administrators will be able to reflect on the sustainability practices in their own schools and consider what keeps teachers teaching.
column8: Attendees will be able to contribute to the brainstorm on how to use technology and development to balance the sustainability equation.
column9: Attendees will be able to ask the tough questions and have the difficult conversations in order to do what is right for students.

column1: Early education: be your child_s first teacher
column5: Magda Dybal (Frugoton Ltd.)
column6: What do you need to know about kids_ learning and how to use your teachable moments effectively? Children are born with a natural sense of curiosity and learn best through their everyday experiences with the people they love and trust, and when the learning is fun. When parents know early development stages and how their children learn, they can effectively and effortlessly stimulate their growth and intellectual development. In this session we will talk about parents as first teachers for their children, and how to stimulate and develop kids_ intellectual development at any given stage. We_ll also talk how to use everyday situations for learning purposes.
column7: Home is an supplemental solution for a classroom-based education and may be one of the best settings for early childhood education.
column8: Children learn best through their everyday experiences _ _teachable moments_ with the people they love and trust, and when the learning is fun.
column9: Knowing how a child learns and important stages of his/her early development helps to stimulate their intellectual growth and development.

column1: How Do We Help 250 Million Children Learn to Read?
column5: Ross Wehner (TabLab)
column6: A problem as big as climate change are the 250 million children world-wide -- 40 percent of the total -- who cannot read, write or do basic math, according to the United Nations. Surprisingly, most of these kids are in school but not learning. More than building new schools, we need to transform the schools we already have. TabLab (www.tablabeducation.org) is an affordable, scalable school transformation program designed around the challenges of rural schools: funding, teacher training, and the Digital Divide. TabLab leverages local teacher trainers and offline tablet technology to transform schools. Our pilots in Costa Rica, Tanzania and rural USA are producing measurable learning gains.
column7: Explore the global educational crisis world-wide, including the 250 million children world-wide who cannot read, wrote or do basic math.
column8: Analyze past efforts to transform rural schools, such as One Laptop Per Child, and understand their shortcomings.
column9: Explore affordable and scalable solutions such as TabLab, which leverage offline technology and local teacher trainers.

column1: How online tools are changing Korean Education
column5: taewoo kim (Classting)
column6: Many people think that Korean education is one of the best education system in the world. Even Obama praises Korean education system several times. In reality, however, Korean education has many problems. In Korea, students have to study 24/7 and they only can sleep 4~5 hours/day. It`s too competitive and they`re just trying to memory everything to go to good university. They don`t know why they have to study. Even some students are killing themselves due to heavy stress. Nowadays, however, many teachers,students are trying to change this situation and they`re using online tools such as Classting to make it better. I`ll introduce how they`re using online tools in their classroom.
column7: Learn the reality of Korean education system and what is its merits and problems.
column8: What kinds of tools are used in Korean classroom and how they`re using it to make their classroom become better
column9: What you can learn from Korean education and how you can innovate your class with online tools.

column1: How Retail Creates Vibrancy & Activates Campuses
column5: Matthew Stein (MSC Retail)
column6: People know Austin for 6th street; food trucks; the co-op: experiences like these communicate the essence of Austin and its university. As institutions continue to evolve with technology, student populations, research, and beyond, every campus in the country has an opportunity to provide similar experiences. Unique places add vibrancy to the community, helping to attract and retain top talent while providing students and the community at large with the best possible resources. How? Strategic retail is one essential slice of the pie. Considering all users and their needs, plus the quality and character of an institution, third parties can light up a community with diverse, effective retail.
column7: Studies show that on-campus living promotes higher success rates in graduation. Vibrant places for students and the greater community are essential.
column8: Retail should communicate the quality and character of an institution; with offerings for not just students, but staff, visitors, alumni, and beyond.
column9: Institutions and students can benefit from innovative partnerships with nearby anchor institutions, like healthcare systems, or local businesses.

column1: Identity in the Making with Early Adolescents
column5: Jennifer Wyld (Oregon State University)
column6: This talk will give an overview of a research study exploring how the interest, identity work, and understanding of technology was impacted for a group of youth in an under-resourced community by a 9 week after school game design program.  The importance of creating third spaces/figured worlds for youth to re-figure their relationship with technology and the use of authentic tools and practices in doing this work will be described.  This study included an exploration of the personal, physical, and socio-cultural contexts for learning with a focus on how important characteristics of a Maker experience can be implemented in any setting.
column7: For participants to discover how a 9 week after school Maker experience impacted youths' interest, identity work, and understanding of technology
column8: For participants to explore how any setting can incorporate qualities important for a Maker experience
column9: For participants to relate Maker qualities to the National Research Council's strands of Science Learning

column1: STEM & Makerspaces On A Budget
column5: Meredith Martin (Mantua Township Schools)
column6: So you want to start a STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, & Math) or Makerspace program, but are concerned about costs and space.  In this session, you will learn how to utilize inexpensive and free items to stock your lab or Makerspace and provide engaging educational activities for your students.  From dollar stores to donations to everyday recyclables, you will find a variety of ways to get hands on without breaking the budget.  We will also look at some of the challenges of space for these programs and look at several creative ways to implement STEM and Makerspaces without a dedicated room or lab.  You will leave with a toolkit of resources, ideas and lessons to get started with.
column7: Learn about a variety of free and lot-cost methods for stocking a STEM lab or Makerspace.
column8: Develop creative ways of implementing STEM and Makerspace programs without a dedicated space.
column9: Acquire a collection of simple, low cost lessons and activities you can use in your schools right away.

column1: Student collaboration across social media
column5: Ferdinand Harmsen (bindrs)
column6: Why are students not using the sophisticated collaboration tool your school or university offers to them? Often it's because it doesn't connect with their daily on-line activities that are mostly taking place on social media. Your tool is another world to them and the hurdles to get in are rather high. This session will present a collaboration webapp that does connect to social media and even supports collaboration across social networks. It brings collaboration projects to your students on their own preferred set of social media, instead of asking them to come over to another world outside their own.Results will be presented from trials at schools and universities in the US and Europe.
column7: You will learn that social media are effective channels to involve students in co-creation group projects as well as to keep them involved.
column8: You will learn this doesn't mean the whole project is out in the open. Social media can be used for private collaboration.
column9: You will learn that cross-social co-creation projects can be productive, fun and safe for your students.

column1: The Arrival of 3D Virtual Tourism
column5: David Boardman (URCV)
column6: TITLE: Saving, and Rebuilding the World_s Most Beloved Landmarks DESCRIPTION: A demonstration of how photogrammetry is capturing and saving the world's landmarks in 3D.The technology, and use of photogrammetry has moved beyond gaming and Hollywood. URCV has already processed billions of images through the cloud via world-scale stereo modeling technology. These include models of landmarks, archeological digs, and entire cities based on datasets ranging from a few million images, to 100 million images. URCV has partnered with UNC  and reconstructed 3D models of the landmarks of the entire world in 6 days. What are the future possibilities for 3D in business and conservation?
column7: What is photogrammetry?
column8: How 3D is being utilized today, using massive data-sets.
column9: Future applications that will harness massive data sets and photogrammetry.

column1: Think Create Share & Grow in School Library Spaces
column5: Suzanna Panter (Henrico County Public Schools)
column6: Henrico County school libraries are national award-winning spaces where students think, create, share, and grow. In this session participants will explore how Henrico school libraries evolved into community hubs where students learn to collaborate, communicate, research, and make. From hands-on participation in the designing of library spaces to promoting job-embedded staff development by co-teaching with content teachers, Henrico_s school librarians are transforming learning. Participants will get an up-close look at Henrico_s innovative school library program model and leave with ideas on how to implement positive changes in their own school library.
column7: Participants will be able to evaluate their library space for its ability to provide students with inspiration to think, create, share, and grow.
column8: Participants will be able to develop three concrete ideas they can implement to insure a transformation in their school library.
column9: Participants will learn how co-teaching with the school librarian can create innovative learning opportunities for students and staff.

column1: Why School Libraries Matter in The Information Age
column5: Mark Danforth (BookAround)
column6: What can libraries look like in the information age? This Core Conversation examines some of the the biggest classrooms in our public and private school systems: libraries. Libraries face fierce competition for audience engagement and funding. In three parts, we_ll explore libraries through structured case studies and audience participation.  We_ll discuss what successful libraries across the country look like, what instructional strategies and technologies have lead to positive student outcomes, and how librarians can use grants and resources to build a community of engaged advocates.
column7: Participants will discuss the physical layout of of successful libraries and consider ways to enhance the physical space in their community's library.
column8: Participants will explore instructional strategies and technologies that both support student learning outcomes and community development.
column9: Participants will explore resources, grants, and partnership opportunities that can help libraries compete with spaces that vie for student attention.

column1: Hacker, Curator, Maker: Gen Z Learning Culture
column5: Pamela Pavliscak (Change Sciences)
column6: The kids of Generation Z challenge assumptions about education. It's not just that they are digital natives. A culture of learning and creativity is deeply embedded into their everyday technology practices. They are insatiable learners. They just approach it differently. Three cultures of learning, inside and outside of school, define this generation_hacking, curating, and making. Based on diaries and interviews with hundreds of kids, tweens, and teens, this session tells the story of how Gen Z learns in their own words and with examples from their own experiences. Come away with new inspiration for engaging Generation Z.
column7: Understand how Zs like to learn outside, and sometimes inside, of school from the perspective of kids, tweens, and teens.
column8: Consider how to build on the culture of learning that is already embedded in the everyday practices of Generation Z.
column9: Share examples of projects that engage each of the three learning practices_hacker, curator, and maker.

column1: Autism: A Father_s Perspective
column5: Jack Gallagher (Couplabob Productions, Inc.)
column6: Jack Gallagher is a comedian and former elementary educator whose son, Liam, is a 19-year-old with autism.In his keynote, _Insight into Autism: A Father_s Perspective,_ Gallagher presents a moving portrayal of a parent struggling to understand a child who he comes to realize is truly amazing. Drawn from his personal experience and training as an educator, his story illustrates that sometimes when pushed to the limit, we learn new lessons and discover new ways of approaching complex situations. His inspiring story will underscore how parents and educators, when working in unison, can build understanding, perspective and celebration.
column7: Few people truly understand autism.  This presentation introduces them to Liam, a truly unique and different person.
column8: My journey with Liam has changed me for the better in 100 ways.  As a former educator, I share the techniques I learned to help Liam succeed.
column9: Attendees will better understand, accept, appreciate and enjoy the differences that make people interesting, unique and truly cool.

column1: Empowering Exceptional Students through Advocacy
column5: Katie Schellenberg (Beyond Tutoring)
column6: On career panels, I_ve typically been categorized as lawyer or teacher, but recently, sitting in front of a group first generation college-bound high schoolers, I was struck by my label: advocate. When I inquired as to whether the kids would know what an advocate does, I was shocked by the facilitator_s response. She said, "Yes, of course they know what an advocate is; half of them want to be advocates."How can we address students' - particularly those with exceptionalities - growing desire to advocate for themselves and their peers with mindfulness and intention? By teaching the art of graceful and respectful argument and persuasion to parents, educators and students from K to College.
column7: Students will be able to meaningfully and skillfully advocate on their own behalf, academically.
column8: Parents will be able to meaningfully advocate for the student_s interests in the academic sphere and beyond.
column9: Teachers will be able to teach their students respectful advocacy that can extend to the classroom, the school, their communities and the world.

column1: Inclusion is a Growth Industry
column5: Torrie  Dunlap (Kids Included Together)
column6: We can all agree that the future is going to require the talents of innovative thinkers, doers and leaders. Currently, we have an untapped resource in the disability community, who are under-utilized and under-represented. By focusing on creating inclusive environments for children with and without disabilities we can start now to build a future where we leverage diverse talents, and where today_s kids of all abilities are tomorrow_s business, education, community and political leaders.
column7: Participants will be able to apply the concept of inclusion to one environment in their own community.
column8: Participants will be able to describe three benefits of community inclusion.
column9: Participants will be able to compare the current state of disability inclusion with a future vision for change.

column1: Capture the Data of Experience
column5: Craig Wiggins (Advanced Distributed Learning), Margaret Roth (Yet Analytics)
column6: As new technologies emerge, it can be a challenge to gather data from all of those sources to really capture the learning experience.The Experience API (xAPI) is an open source specification designed specifically for this use - gathering data from all sources to really represent what is happening and how it is happening in a learning environment.Learn about what xAPI is, how it works, and how you can use it to collect and analyze data from any source to capture the data of experience - and more importantly how you can use it to design for experience-centered learning.
column7: What is xAPI? How can we use xAPI to capture formative as well as summative learning data?
column8: How can we capture the data of experience? How can we design for experience-centered learning?
column9: How do we use xAPI to solve the interoperability to challenges of technologies, learning systems, and connected environments?

column1: EdTech_Exacerbating Inequity or Driving Solutions?
column5: Deepak  Subramony  (Kansas State University), Brian  Dixon (Kapor Capital ), Tonika  Clayton (New Schools Venture Fund), Sabina Bharwani (Teach For America)
column6: Survey_s up, and the answer_s just not clear. Despite the tremendous surge of optimism hailing technology as the great equalizer of educational opportunity, a growing body of evidence indicates that in many cases, technology is having the opposite effect. It is increasing the knowledge gap between affluent and low-income students, between white students and students of color, and between the school and life-ready and the less-prepared.  Where are we falling short? What blind spots have we missed? Leaders in EdTech share their experience at the intersection of technology and educational equity and identify opportunities and common pitfalls for entrepreneurs and school leaders.
column7: Critically survey the systemic influence of EdTech across K-12 schools and focus especially on low-income schools and students of color.
column8: Challenge the idea that instructional technologies are culturally neutral and examine how this belief has shaped the current EdTech landscape.
column9: Recognize we've just begun to comprehend implications of assuming EdTech plays out evenly in all communities;generate solutions for K-12 stakeholders.

column1: Angels and Edtech: A Match Made in Heaven?
column5: Jean Hammond (LearnLaunch), Frank Bonsal III  (Towson University ), Jim Connor (First Focus Learning Systems)
column6: Edtech entrepreneurs need to find early stage funding and angels are often a fit.  But education is lacking on both sides. Angels need to understand the range of opportunities and market growth profile.  Entrepreneurs need to show market traction that can scale.Edtech offers a unique investment opportunity but many angels stay clear due to market complexity and slow market up take.  VC funds are growing but often concentrated in firms selling direct to consumers not schools.Tech enables changes in education as this large, competitive Industry undergoes change.
column7: What types of edtech firms can gain angel investment.
column8: Traction for edtech .. how do we measure it?  How will we know this edtech solution can scale?
column9: How can more angels learn more about the industry and the edtech investment community?

column1: Creating and Delivering What Teachers Really Want
column5: Shanika Hope (McGraw-Hill Education), Randy Wilhelm (Knovation)
column6: You_ve got the best idea for an education product. Ever. It_s innovative! It_s disruptive! It's Common Core-aligned! But is it solving the real-world problems of teachers and learners? AAP PreK-12 Learning Group members have been developing successful, high-quality educational resources for decades. We've assembled a dream team, led by moderator Michael Jay, to help you think through product development, marketing, and procurement. You'll leave with expert tips for building vibrant and effective learning tools; a firmer grasp on reaching your target audience(s) with just the right message; and exclusive insights into the complicated_and evolving_world of buying cycles, adoption, RFPs, etc.
column7: Learn what disruptions are at play (or should be) in the product development process to ensure successful learning tools reach today's classrooms.
column8: Marketing is not a dirty word. Learn to embrace and implement strategies for cutting through the marketing noise with messages that resonate.
column9: Learn how to navigate the current procurement landscape as well as potential changes on the horizon.

column1: EdTech getting global
column5: Ian Fordham (EdTech UK), Don Burton (Edge EdTech), Fernando  Valenzuela (Cengage Learning), Avi Warshavsky (MindCET-  www.mindcet.org)
column6: Innovation in education is being accelerated by the impact of the entrepreneurial culture. This session presents a joint venture between EdTech accelerators from different parts of the globe (Israel, Spain, UK, Mexico, US, Japan, India) to showcase the strength of international alliances in order to meet the needs of educational systems dealing with a connected world. They will share their experience of building the local and global EdTech Startup ecosystem. Session 1: Presentation of each accelerator and their joint venture - GESAwards; Session 2: Pitch of 5 startups and feedback from each accelerator focusing on the startup feasibility in each of the different edu markets. Audience Q&A.
column7: Entrepreneurial culture effect on education content development and gotomarket strategies
column8: Startup edu products/services significant influence on teachers' and education institutions' approach to the digital world and internet culture
column9: Innovation in Education being accelerated by global EdTech connections and consequent cultural impact on teachers and students

column1: EdTech Japan to the World
column5: Masahiro Sato (Digital Hollywood University)
column6: Panel discussion to talk about the current trend of edtech in Japan. Speakers will be edtech / education experts from education companies, investors, start-ups and the government. Main topics include trending innovations, edtech ecosystem, international expansion, investment opportunities, etc. Japan is an unique market, and there is a huge potential for edtech innovation. It also means opportunities to make businesses successful and profitable.
column7: Gain general knowledge of how Japanese edtech ecosystem has been evolving.
column8: Learn uniqueness and strengths of Japanese edtech start-ups and potential to the global expansion.
column9: Know how the Japanese government, corporations and start-ups are collaborating to promote edtech in Japan and internationally

column1: Insights for EdTech Innovators & Investors
column5: Benjamin Vedrenne-Cloquet (EdTechXGlobal), Charles McIntyre (EdTechXGlobal)
column6: Co-Founders of EdTechXGlobal will share perspective into the international EdTech ecosystem by highlighting trends, landmark investment opportunities and innovative startups from around the world. Join the organisers of the leading EdTech summit series in Europe and Asia to hear more about what's next for the global education technology industry.
column7: Key Investment Opportunities in EdTech
column8: Innovative Education Startups & Technologies
column9: Trends within the Global EdTech Ecosystem

column1: Parents: How to get the holy grail consumer
column5: Sehreen Noor Ali (Noodle), Marie McNeely (Liquid Agency), Erica  Gruen (Quantum Media)
column6: The parent market is a holy grail for companies selling anything from strollers to snacks. By engaging the parent consumer, brands not only capture high intent purchasers, but also establish brand loyalty amongst kids as their future consumers. We're at an interesting moment in business: both boomers and millennials are parents with money to spend, yet each behave with its own set of consumer preferences and parenting styles. This panel will explore what education brands can do to attract more parents and what the shifting demographics between gender, ethnicity, and age means for their marketing strategies in the digital age.
column7: To learn different preferences within the parents market, particularly in terms of age, gender, & ethnicity
column8: To understand how consumer & retail brands engage(d) parents and how these lessons apply today
column9: To identify the opportunity for education brands to connect more easily with parents

column1: Solving for Why: The Future of EdTech
column5: Andrew Smith Lewis (Cerego)
column6: In _Start with Why,_ Simon Sinek argues that we often focus on the wrong things, on WHAT and HOW instead of WHY. In the current edtech environment, getting to the why of learning is more imperative than ever. Prominent innovations have thus far focused on what (content) and are developing how (learning methodologies), but to truly transform education and achieve meaningful learning, we must first return to the essential question of why.In this talk, Cerego founder Andrew Smith Lewis explores present and future visions of edtech, addressing the why behind the future of learning and strategies to foster student motivation through better data, assessment, guidance, access, and technology.
column7: What methodological approaches can we develop to understand the "why" behind our education technologies and their future.
column8: How can we think about and design technology experiences that inspire learners and achieve compelling engagement?
column9: How can technology empower and inspire learners, and address the crises of the contemporary education environment?

column1: Future of EdTech: Consolidation or Fragmentation
column5: Adam Bellow (eduTecher, eduClipper), Steven Anderson (Web20Classroom), Eric Sheninger (International Center for Leadership in Education), Karen Cator (Digital Promise)
column6: Where is the market going? Where do you want it to go? Will the future hold a simpler, all-in-one management system for schools, or will the proliferation of new technologies lead to more fragmentation and complexity? What resources do school and district leaders need to address today's challenges and have the flexibility to meet future demands? This panel will explore these questions and more in a lively discussion on the future of edtech and building a foundation for accelerating student learning.
column7: Empower educators to share ideas, opinions and needs to shape the future of technology in education
column8: Foster a collaborative community of educators, entrepreneurs, and others to work toward common goals
column9: Investigate promising innovations and leadership practices in school and district management and operations as the hub of learning

column1: How to Make EdTech Purchasing Painless & Effective
column5: Adam  Fried (Harrington Park School District), Laura Nelson (Derry Cooperative School District), Bharani Rajakumar (LearnBop), John Carver (Howard-Winneshiek Community Schools)
column6: American K-12 schools spend $70 billion on curriculum and technology every year, with a great deal going to education technology purchases_and yet we still don_t have established best practices for purchasing edtech. This panel will feature actionable advice from 3 K-12 superintendents and 1 CEO of an edtech startup to make edtech purchasing predictable and mutually beneficial for districts and entrepreneurs. The goal of the conversation is to provide actionable advice for administrators to avoid wasting money and improve student outcomes, and to provide edtech entrepreneurs insight and strategic advice to understand what districts want and how to help them achieve it.
column7: Identify funding channels and models for implementing innovation in schools.
column8: Lay out specific steps admins can take to get in-depth advice on edtech procurement from admins in similar jobs and districts.
column9: Chart clear paths for evaluating, implementing, and incorporating education technology into existing district and school processes.

column1: Museum Technology & Strategy
column5: Koven Smith (Blanton Museum of Art)
column6: I will provide career guidance and advice for attendees curious about entering the cultural heritage technology sector, those with practical questions about deploying technology in museums, or early career professionals looking for work in the museum field.
column7: Attendees will learn how to position themselves for success in the cultural heritage technology field.
column8: Attendees will learn common problems that befall technology implementations in museums.
column9: Attendees will gain a greater understanding of the politics and cultures of museums, and how to use that understanding to their advantage.

column1: Chipotle For Lunch?
column5: DJ Roberts (SXSWedu), greg Rosenbaum (sxsw)
column6: In order to address the growing state of hunger in the office, this session will focus on fulfilling one on mankind's most basic needs: nourishment. Attendees will have the opportunity to discuss dining options, implement a selection strategy and, inevitably, settle for Chipotle Mexican Grill.
column7: Food
column8: Conversation
column9: Food

column1: Design Thinking & Improvisation Mentoring
column5: Dan Ryder (Mt. Blue High School)
column6: Adopting an improvisational mindset around acceptance, communication, and trust, can transform your approach to the increasingly complex challenges facing education today, whether matters of the classroom, the building, or the system as a whole.  Add a design thinking lens of empathy-fueled human centered problem solving, and you find yourself with a dynamic toolkit for managing and making change. Let an English teacher, improviser, and design thinker from the western foothills of Maine guide you through that wilderness of awesome.

column1: Practical Cognitive Enhancement
column5: Brant Cortright (California Institute of Integral Studies)
column6: Your rate of neurogenesis is the most important bio marker of brain health you've never heard of. Neurogenesis is the birth of new brain cells, and it's continuous throughout the lifespan, but it's rate declines in middle age and again in old age. Low rates of neurogenesis are associated with anxiety, stress, depression, cognitive decits and memory problems. High rates of neurogenesis with the opposite - cognitive enhancement, rapid learning, protection from stress and depression. Learn how to increase your rate of neurogenesis five times with dramatic improvements in life quality, memory, cognitive ability and emotional resilience.
column7: Learn what neurogenesis is and why it's so key to optimal brain health.
column8: Learn ten simple practices to increase your rate of neurogenesis.
column9: Learn how to avoid the everyday, common neurotoxins that slow neurogenesis and bring about cognitive decline and Alzhemer's.

column1: Psych researcher and Khan Academy Content Creator
column5: Brooke Miller (The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Brooke Miller is a PhD Student in Psychology at the University of Texas at Austin where she studies the role that authenticity plays in informal science education. Brooke has taught at the college level using the "flipped classroom" model, replacing standard lectures with custom online content and in-classroom activities. Brooke also works as a Health and Medicine content creator at Khan Academy where she creates video content related to the social sciences.Talk to me about: Flipping the classroom (higher education) Online content creation (KSV- Khan Style Videos) Integrating psychology research in schools and classrooms
column7: Individuals attending the mentor sessions will learn strategies for implementing blended learning in the classroom
column8: Individuals attending the mentor sessions will learn how to create online educational content in the form of blackboard style (or "Khan Style") video
column9: Individuals attending the mentor sessions will learn how to integrate current psychological and educaitonal research in schools and classrooms

column1: Professionally Pivoting
column5: Matt Howeth (Civitas Learning)
column6: I taught elementary school for three years. Then I decided to take a massive leap into the technology space. I didn't know anything about technology before "jumping in", and I learned a lot along the way. I would like to pass on some tidbits I gathered to those who are thinking about making the same jump.
column7: How to Pivot from Education Professional to Working in EdTech
column8: How to Network (and Bypass the Application Process)
column9: How to Position your Experience to be noticed by Technologists

column1: Mentor-Carla Romney: STEM for All
column5: Carla Romney (Fordham University)
column6: We will explore trends and challenges in STEM teaching and learning, including NGSS, at the K-12, undergraduate and graduate levels. My particular area of expertise is the application of mobile platforms for STEM education- bringing learning to the learner on his/her terms. From bringing your own device (smartphone or tablet) to bringing a mobile full-fledged molecular biology lab to students, all mobile technologies can improve student engagement and learning.
column7: Participants will gain new insights into mobile technology applications for learning.
column8: Participants will understand the benefits and challenges of mobile learning.
column9: Participants will share their experiences and build their professional network.

column1: Edtech Entrepreneur Mentor
column5: Karen Greenleaf (Google)
column6: I am eager to identify and nurture emerging edtech companies that encourage authentic curiosity, promote project-based learning, and help learners make connections with real-world issues.  I've worked in the edtech industry for over 10 years in product and business development roles at academic publisher and educational services companies. I have a deep understanding about the complexities of and opportunities in the education market.I've served as a mentor to the 2015 Hult Prize finalists whose mission is to solve the lack of quality early childhood education in urban slums. I have also mentored companies in Boston's LearnLaunch community of edtech entrepreneurs.

column1: How to Become an Entrepreneur
column5: Roxana Crane (SXSW), Gaby DeLeon (SXSW)
column6: I want to educate my audience on the do's and dont's of creating your own business. Many people love the idea of working for themselves, but not many know the steps to get there or the responsibility that comes with it.
column7: Timing is everything
column8: Don't rule out collaboration
column9: Be careful with your budget

column1: Launching "Big Picture Learning" in your community
column5: Andrew Frishman (Big Picture Learning)
column6: Big Picture Learning_s (BPL) vision is to catalyze vital changes in K-Adult education by generating and sustaining innovative, personalized learning environments that work in tandem with the real world of their greater community.   At the core of Big Picture Learning_s mission is a commitment to equity for all students, especially underserved urban students, and the expectation that these students can achieve success.  Big Picture Learning designs innovative learning environments, researches and replicates new models for learning, and trains educators to serve as leaders in their schools and communities. Come connect with Co-Executive Director to discuss how to bring this to your community.
column7: Gain deeper understanding of the community assets necessary to launch and sustain an innovative personalized learning environment in a public school.
column8: Discover how to gage public appetite and community support for catalyzing innovation via an "edge to the middle" strategy and movement.
column9: Collaborate on the development of a plan to meld and leverage community resources for the launch of educational innovation.

column1: Let's talk: K-12, app dev, and good decisions!
column5: Reshan Richards (Teachers College, Columbia University)
column6: During the mentorship time, I will share my own insights and give feedback on ideas and directions related to anything from entrepreneurship, to software development, to educational research, to K-20 school environments. I have been sitting at the intersection of these elements for the past few years with my work at Montclair Kimberley Academy, Teachers College (Columbia University), and Explain Everything. I am excited to share my experiences and offer advice and perspectives to teachers who may have an idea for building something on their own, to developers trying to make an impact on the lives of learners, and to institutional leaders who are trying to make sense of the ed tech world.
column7: Are you a teacher with an idea for an app to use in education? I'll provide you with ideas for how to get it off the ground!
column8: Are you a developer trying to make difference in the lives of young people? I'll share how to stay grounded in the reality of schools & students!
column9: Are you a school leader trying to make ed tech decisions to best serve your students and teachers? Together we'll tackle your latest problem!

column1: Moving from the Classroom to an EdTech Startup
column5: Claire Varner (HSTRY)
column6: Thinking of leaving the classroom to enter the world of edtech? Talk to someone who made the transition and is ready to share her knowledge in order to help you do the same. This is your chance to ask questions about transferable skills, learn how to network, and consider the financial aspects of making a career change.
column7: Learn what you need to know before leaving the classroom.
column8: Evaluate your transferable skills.
column9: Get tips for landing a job at a startup.

column1: Overcoming Work
column5: Ben Spear (Human Experience)
column6: Work just isn't working anymore. Packaging our aspirations into discrete units called "jobs" and "careers" is a holdover from the Industrial Age. Managers coopt knowledge like a scarce raw material and treat people like workers on a factory line. But the most successful organizations_and the most productive people_know that, in the Network Age information is ubiquitous and the real trick is creating new ideas. I'd like to offer a session wherein I break down the best ways forward for young professionals to hack this confused economy and lead our society into a new age of greatness.
column7: Develop actionable methods for inquiry
column8: Understand what you want to do
column9: Apply these insights to existing challenges in the economy

column1: The Secret Ingredients of Great EdTech
column5: Erin Wilkey Oh (Common Sense Education)
column6: What are the secret ingredients of great edtech products? How can you offer a quality learning product that meets the needs of students, teachers, and administrators? Get answers to your questions in this mentor session with Erin Wilkey Oh, Executive Editor for Common Sense Graphite. Erin and the Graphite editors have evaluated the learning design of almost 2,000 edtech products using a teacher-trusted, research-backed rubric. And with help from the Common Sense teacher community's 7,000 from-the-field reviews, Graphite editors have learned precisely what teachers and schools need. You_ll also receive advice on monetizing products, protecting student privacy, product development, and more.
column7: Participants will receive expert tips and guidance on what makes a digital tool great for learning.
column8: Participants will get tailored, product-specific advice on product design/development, quality, student privacy, and monetization.
column9: Participants will identify ways they can improve their existing or in-development edtech product.

column1: Concept to Product Education
column5: Paul Toprac (GAMMA Program, University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Do you have an idea that will change education but don't know how to make it into a product?  Your idea may be a service or it may be tangible.  Either way you can productized your offering to make it compelling to buyers.  We can approach the development of your offering using design thinking and help you achieve on your way to success.
column7: Productize your concept
column8: Understand your product development methodology
column9: Use design thinking to achieve success

column1: From Star Wars to Schools: Marketing 101
column5: Leo Olebe (GreatSchools)
column6: Learn the latest tools, tips, tricks and techniques for getting the word out about your mission and work. Leo Olebe, VP Marketing at GreatSchools, will share what he has learned over the last 20 years as an entertainment and non-profit marketing executive.
column7: Learn marketing techniques to get your company's work recognized.
column8: Secure marketing tips to enhance your company's profile.
column9: Obtain tools to help highlight your company's products to the right people.
column11: marketing, communications, public relations, publicity, tourism, travel, nonprofit

column1: Got User? 10min with a Brooklyn Middle Schooler
column5: Grace O'Shea (NYC Department of Education)
column6: K-12 public school users are available.What if you had ten minutes to interact with a user from a title I, fully integrated middle school in Brooklyn, NY? What if you could watch a student interact with your product directly? What if you could conduct an empathy interview to immediately explore a design iteration? What if you could crowdsource insights to shape your marketing approach? What if you could observe and question a middle school classroom using Google Hangouts? What if you could test a design with a user outlying your typical region, developmental range, or demographic?Attendees have the opportunity to shape session format and user audience based on desired learning outcomes.
column7: Implement design thinking at the school level
column8: Utilize a teacher user to yield design insights
column9: Utilize middle school student users to yield design insights

column1: Mentor-Sarah Morris
column5: Sarah Morris (Nucleus Learning Network )
column6: Sarah Morris is a librarian with a decade of experience working as an educator and program coordinator in museums, libraries, schools, and higher education environments. She has developed and managed STEAM and digital literacy programs for learners ranging from elementary school students to college students, and has created and administered trainings for diverse groups of educators. In 2014, Sarah co-founded Nucleus Learning Network, a non-profit dedicated to supporting, connecting, and empowering learners, educators, and mentors interested in strengthening Austin's innovative learning community.  Sarah has a Master's in Information Science from the University of Texas at Austin.
column7: Digital literacy education
column8: Developing outreach programming and partnerships for libraries
column9: STEAM education

column1: ORD, LAX, JFK Teaching & Learning in Urban America
column5: Melissa  Parenti (St. John's University)
column6: This session merges theory, practice and relevance and is designed as a mentor opportunity for teachers looking to discuss the rewards and challenges that many educators face in the urban PK-12 learning environment.  With nearly 20 years of experience teaching and training teachers in Chicago (ORD), Los Angeles (LAX) and New York City (JFK), insights will be shared related to those practices and expectations that look similar and different in the landscape of America's urban classrooms.  A framework containing the tenants of a successful educator will be shared, as well as practice in acquiring the skills necessary to pursue ongoing professional growth.
column7: Acquire a framework for successful classroom teaching in any environment
column8: Acquire an understanding of consistent challenges of classroom teaching in urban environments
column9: Acquire skills for effectively pursuing continued professional growth

column1: Research and Innovation in Mobile Learning
column5: Scott McQuiggan (SAS Institute)
column6: Higher-order thinking skills (HOTS) are in high demand. Mobile learning offers resources for creativity, critical thinking, communication and problem-solving for today_s classroom. In this session, I'd love to discuss - strategies for using mobile learning to cultivate HOTS, - themes discussed in our recent book, Mobile Learning: A Handbook for Developers, Educators & Learners, and - share lessons learned in the development of free edtech. The mobile learning marketplace can be overwhelming. How can we help educators & parents with limited time and resources decide which edtech will help their particular students build appropriate skills?
column7: Discuss emerging trends in education and the role of edtech and mobile in particular.
column8: Discuss the increasing critical relationship between developers and educators to support innovation in mobile learning and edtech.
column9: Discuss the development and deployment of free educational software and apps around the world.

column1: YouTube for Educators: Advice From a Top Creator
column5: Harry Jho (Sockeye Media LLC)
column6: How can you take advantage of the tremendous opportunity YouTube_s dynamic environment offers educators and students?  Knowing how to use tools available on the platform makes it possible to expand your reach and educate a global audience. In these mentor sessions, a leading creator shares tips and anecdotes for successful channel management with opportunities for questions, discussion and one-on-one guidance.
column7: Learn to strategically upload educational videos to build rich curriculum on YouTube.
column8: Learn how YouTube analytics allows you to see how online learners interact with your content and learn how it allows you to measure your reach.
column9: Increase your visibility by cleaning up video meta-data: make informed choices about titles, descriptions, tags and other customizable features.

column1: Blending Joy into the Classroom
column5: Cindy Elsberry (Achieve3000)
column6: Learn how blended learning can serve as the catalyst for creating a personalized, student-centered learning environment - thus bringing joy to all who inhabit our classrooms.  Expand the reach of innovators, by transforming classroom practice and creating learning environments that foster the acquisition of next generation skills and habits of mind, resulting in deeper learning experiences and improved student outcomes. Explore ways to establish risk-free environments that foster an innovation culture.  The digital workplace demands new skills from our young people and blended learning can serve as the vehicle for the transformational change needed to create schools of the future today.
column7: To create an awareness of the declining student engagement that occurs the longer students are in school and the causes for this decline.
column8: To understand the potential of blended learning strategies to empower teachers and to deepen learning for students.
column9: To realize the urgency of personalizing learning to authentically engage students.

column1: Leveraging Gang Strengths to Empower Youth
column5: Cesar Cruz (Homies Empowerment)
column6: Co-founder of Homies Empowerment, veteran educator of 20+ years Cesar A. Cruz will lead a discussion of how to utilize gang strengths to empower young people who are disconnected from school. Mr. Cruz is currently on-residency at Homeboy Industries in Los Angeles, CA. with Father Greg Boyle and is completing his doctorate degree in Educational Leadership from Harvard University. He is the author of multiple books including "Bang for Freedom." In this workshop participants will gain the knowledge of how to apply gang values to school settings to create a place of family, love and community for those youth on the margins who don't feel connected to schools at all.
column7: 1. Participants will be able to identify positive gang strengths and values and apply them to school settings.
column8: 2. Participants will be able to take gang values and assess their own practice and develop plans to reach youth on the margins.
column9: 3. Participants will be introduced to the Homies Empowerment Theory of Youth Development.

column1: Tyler DeWitt as a Mentor
column5: Tyler DeWitt (Self-Employed)
column6: I would love to be a mentor for SXSWedu 2016! I have a wide range of experience in educational technology, STEM education, and video instruction and flipping the classroom. I served as a mentor in 2015, and I love to share my knowledge with others, and give them advice however I can. In terms of my background, I am the creator of one of the most popular educational channels on YouTube, where I teach Chemistry, Biology, and Physics. I have taught high school science and English in both the United States and South Korea. I speak frequently around the world talking about strategies for STEM teaching, flipping the classroom, and how to use technology to teach metacognition and cognitive process.
column7: How to create videos students can learn from
column8: Making STEM education authentic and engaging
column9: Strategies for using technology to teach metacognition and cognitive process

column1: Strategies for Entrepreneurial Leaders
column5: Ilene Leff (Leff Management Consulting LLC)
column6: Lots of people have new ideas for making change in their organizations, in their careers, in their communities.  The big question is: How can we get things done and make change happen?This session will offer approaches to making your ideas reality.As a mentor I will respond to audience questions and offer recommendations to those seeking advice.Based on experience as - Senior Advisor to Ashoka with the theme "Everyone a Changemaker" - Management consultant with McKinsey advising companies on making change- HR head of Fortune 200 company- Clinton administration appointed official implementing the first satellite distance learning capability- A teacher.
column7: To offer experience in leading innovations inside and outside organizations
column8: How to make ideas happen
column9: To respond to audience questions and ideas about leading change

column1: Supersize Your PD: Student Edition
column5: Christy Fennewald (St. Stephen's Episcopal School)
column6: Need help with professional development? Why not have students lead it? Attendees will learn the story of how one school used students to help transform professional development. In this presentation, learners will discover ways to revitalize professional development at your school as well as harness student voice. Challenge students to do good. After a year of challenging tech discipline issues with students, one school decided to challenge students to do good. So, they started a tech club that no only performed beta-testing, but led teacher professional development. Students decided upon what teacher needed to learn. Attendees will discuss ways to harness student power and change PD.
column7: Learners will create initial framework for student-led professional development.
column8: Learners will collaborate and discuss professional development needs.
column9: Learners will develop framework for capturing student leaders.

column1: The Competitive Advantage: Business Operations
column5: Asha Aravindakshan (Blue Tiger Labs)
column6: Operational leaders are the glue that hold organizations together, but often undervalued, especially in scaling enterprises, like charter schools or startups. As a founder, learn if it is right time to hire a pair of experienced hands, what type of skills to look for and how to best onboard this individual. For my operational peers, learn proven tips to highlight your talents across functional areas, like strategy, finance, technology, human resources, marketing, and performance management, determine your transferable skills from your current sector to the education arena and diagnose weak areas to bolster them in 2015. You_ll come away excited to take control of your career path!
column7: Let's find ways that you can maintain employee morale, demonstrate accountability to your stakeholders and increase transparency among the team.
column8: You have a vast network that can help you in may ways. Let's talk about how to best leverage your advisory board to move your idea forward.
column9: Learn functions to outsource, designate to another staffer or need to hire in order to free you up OR surround yourself with trust colleagues to help.

column1: Unleash Your School's Superpower- Teacher Teams!
column5: Emily Land (Arlington Community Schools)
column6: Schools are brimming with talented teachers and brilliant ideas, but how can you bring those things together in a way that produces powerful change? Professional Learning Communities! By making time for teachers to work undistracted, side by side in collective teams during the day, you give teachers the precious time they need to examine data, identify students by name & need, and team-develop an impactful plan to help each student reach their max potential. It_s how you structure the schedule and provide the tools to support your PLCs, that you_ll move your teachers from simple compliance to total commitment. Let a PLC Coach_better yet, let a PLC Coach who is also a teacher show you how!
column7: Attendees will learn how to create meaningful teacher teams in their buildings and districts to help members commit more deeply to student progress
column8: Attendees will gain perspective on what a PLC is and what a PLC is not and how this differentiation is important for progress and accountability
column9: Attendees will understand the power of PLC teams as they work together to improve student mastery on both an individual and school wide basis

column1: Creating High Impact Learning Environments
column5: Bill Latham (Contrax Furnishings)
column6: In the first 15 years of the 21st Century, the learning environment has already dramatically changed. 21st Century learners are vastly different in makeup, content delivery, and work habits from any previous group. Our aim is to immerse attendees in the research of changing educational practices, including case studies, interactions, and simulations to challenge traditional thinking. This session will address planning, materials, research, and relationships to show how they impact health, welfare, and interactions of the people in school. This session will also address the impact of light, fresh air, and human movement in the educational process.
column7: Knowledge and insight into the current research on how children learn.
column8: Appreciation for how the current generation prefers to learn, and insight into the soft skills employers want from workers.
column9: Ability to identify a high impact learning environment, and discuss the interrelation of learning and environment.

column1: Expert Q&A on Struggling Learners
column5: Bob Cunningham (Understood and the Robert Louis Stevenson School )
column6: She's smart but she's failing. He can concentrate on an art project for hours, but can't focus on his classwork. She hears what you're saying, but can't seem to follow your directions. You find him "annoying" you but you don't know why. It can be hard for teachers to understand all the ways learning and attention issues impact kids. If you have questions about a student or are you are the parent of a child with learning or attention issues, come and connect one-on-one with top-level experts. These professionals have worked in both public and private school settings and can provide real insights, tools and strategies for kids who are struggling to learn.
column7: Get feedback from a learning and attention issues expert on any academic, social/emotional issue you may be struggling with
column8: Share best practices and lessons learned from work supporting kids with learning and attention issues in the classroom

column1: A City-wide Collaborative for Music Education
column5: Frank  Machos (School District of Philadelphia), Aileen  Rimando (School District of Philadelphia), Daniel  Berkowitz (The Philadelphia Orchestra), Joseph Conyer (The Philadelphia Orchestra / Project 440 / All City Orchestra)
column6: How can a world-class orchestra, a premier academic institution, and a non-profit organization that promotes social entrepreneurship work together to serve one of America_s most fiscally challenged school districts? Leaders of the Philadelphia Orchestra, University of Pennsylvania, Project 440, and the School District of Philadelphia will show you. The inspiration? Music education_s undeniable benefits in a student_s social and emotional development combined with music_s role as a tool for social change. Hear from a group of creative partners whose mission is to change the narrative in education - to incite system-wide reform using music as the vehicle and collaboration as the model.
column7: Discover strategies for system-wide impact including the identifying, mapping, and maximizing of stakeholder knowledge in a collaborative network.
column8: Learn from this creative approach for imagining and articulating a vision with tangible, attainable benchmarks.
column9: Explore tools to turn ideas into action and strategies for approaching complex community issues using music as a vehicle for social change.

column1: Arts Education: Nothing Elective About It
column5: Dr. Brent Hasty (MINDPOP), Ayanna  Hudson (National Endowment for the Arts ), Mario  Rossero  (Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts), Jessica Handrik (Lincoln Center Education )
column6: Arts Education is changing the face of our classrooms and transforming student learning. The charge is being led by some of the most prestigious arts organizations in the country and their work is being supported by the NEA and scholars alike. There is a firm belief (and the data concurs) that instruction through and in the arts is essential for the development of the whole child; for every child. They provide unique experiences that combine the physical, mental, social, and emotional aspects of human existence. Participation in the arts maximizes critical thinking skills and creativity and prepares students to be successful, contributing members of society.
column7: Discover different programming models and perspectives from the leaders in the Arts Education field.
column8: Learn about recent trends in Arts Education, including the work happening around policy, assessment, and funding in the US.
column9: Understand how Arts Education is essential to the development of every child and is not just an "elective".

column1: Arts, Imagination & the End-of-Life Conversation
column5: Jenny  Lavery (Theatre En Bloc), Craig Hurwitz (The Final Acts Project), Adam Roberts (The Final Acts Project), Ira Byock (Institute for Human Caring Providence Health and Services )
column6: The role imagination plays for the patient facing end-of-life is an important one. Imagination will also reveal how the processes of illness and dying can offer meaningful opportunities for deeper acceptance and compassion. The Final Acts Project (TFAP) is an innovative, public health education initiative that serves as a catalyst to stimulate end-of-life discussion, planning and legacy-building, through the theater, creative arts and the humanities. The creative and performing arts are time-honored ways of sharing and disseminating valuable information. When issues are complex and difficult, interactive and imaginative storytelling becomes a forum for exploration and expression.
column7: Explore the role imagination can play for patients and their families during serious illness and at the end-of-life.
column8: Explore how the arts can strengthen and contribute to the end-of-life conversation that promotes earlier palliative care intervention and hospice care
column9: Explore the value of communities creating deep and ongoing end-of-life conversations through the arts that are inter-sectoral and multi-generational.

column1: Bringing Music Instruction Online
column5: Jay LeBoeuf (Real Industry ), Christianne Orto  (Manhattan School of Music ), Debbie Cavalier (Berklee Online - Berklee College of Music), Ajay Kapur (Kadenze)
column6: To date, learning to make music online has been a fragmented and individual process made up of DIY tutorials across various mediums. In this session, we_ll make a case for bringing proper music instruction online and examine why it has failed to find its place in the online education landscape. For one, educators face several challenges when shifting the material from a physical to virtual space. A lack of peer-to-peer collaboration and proper assessment are just a few of the problems that have prevented digital music instruction from reaching its potential. The tools to make this happen are available, and it_s time educators and institutions learn how to harness them.
column7: How do we properly measure and assess student work within creative technology and arts?
column8: Does student or work suffer any consequences by transferring classes to virtual environments that traditionally were taught in physical environments
column9: Is teaching arts online the way of the future with the continuous shift to digital? Are there possible repercussions to teaching arts courses online

column1: Classroom to the Community: Convergent Higher Edu
column5: Andrew Valdez (Palo Alto College), Joseph Lopez (University of the Incarnate Word), Josh Lightner (University of the Incarnate Word), Jeremy Zunker (10 BitWorks Hackerspace)
column6: Something special is happening in San Antonio, Texas. A program is evolving outside of the classroom and into the community. How is this happening? you might ask, is the best part.The Convergent Media program at University of the Incarnate Word, Dr. Joseph Lopez and his students take classroom projects and applying them to real world situations. Over time these students met frequently with numerous clients and outgrew the student group to form a non-profit collective of new media pioneers. The group became known professionally as The Convergent Media Collective. The distinguished B.A. &M.A. alumni of the program continue to give back to the program and remain active in the South Texas.
column7: Students, professors and alumni will learn to help instill creativity and innovation in a community by applying what they learn inside the classrooom.
