column8: Encourage students and alumni to continue to work together even passed graduation while producing work with meaning and significance.
column9: Create a program that transcends academia and overlaps with community engagement and corporate relations while helping students gain work experience.

column1: Digital Storytelling: Self and Other
column5: Shawnda  Birch (Independent consultant and musician), Paul Bernella (Austin Community College), Charlotte Gullick (Austin Community College)
column6: This session will explore the role compassion, empathy, deep listening, creativity, and technology play in the classroom. Discussion will include how developing personal experiences into compelling narratives builds and strengthens connections within the classroom, within the student body, and within the larger community. We will show examples that dive into the worst and best of the human experience, helping students come to know themselves so that they might more meaningfully connect to others.
column7: To showcase the power of technology and storytelling to build community.
column8: To share a diverse perspectives on the topic of digital storytelling.
column9: To demonstrate how personal stories are the cornerstone of an effective classroom.

column1: EduMusication: Career advice at high schools
column5: Gabe Kubanda (Epic Proportions Tour/EduMusication), Peter Sotos (Epic Proportions Tour), Richard Maxwell (Arcadia High School)
column6: Our "EduMusication" program brings bands into music classes on campus, to speak directly to the students about the various careers in the music industry, and to promote higher education.ÿ Students get to ask questions to rock stars, session players, video game composers, audio engineers, and more.ÿ It's quite an interactive and fun time for anyone considering a full time career in the music business.ÿ EduMusication:ÿhttps://youtu.be/vElauE3WT6Mÿ
column7: How to monetize your art, and make a viable career out of your passion and skills.
column8: How to present yourself to other industry professionals.
column9: Common Pitfalls to avoid when breaking into the music business

column1: Film as an Agent of Change in Education
column5: Rich Henrich (Santa Fe University of Art and Design), Chris Eyre (Film School Chair/Film Director), Justice Whitaker (Santa Fe University of Art and Design)
column6: In this Session Santa Fe University of Art and Design faculty members and filmmakers Chris Eyre, Rich Hienrich, and Justice Whitaker will discuss different techniques and tools used to bring social change into the classroom. The session will provide an opportunity for participants to discuss community social issues while panel members explore how these issues can be addressed through media production. The session is designed to inspire and motivate Educators, Activists, and Filmmakers to continue sharing knowledge to combat social injustices through technology and media production in education institutions.
column7: Participants will understand ways film and media can be tools for social change
column8: Participants will learn tools and techniques to discuss social change through media production
column9: Participants will learn how to enable youth passion to activate student ambition towards film projects for social change

column1: Fuel4Steam: Brain Benefits and Tools for Music Ed
column5: Gabriella Musacchia (University of the Pacific, Stanford University), Trell  Thomas (VH1 Save The Music), Alex Khalil (University of California, San Diego), Alesha Bishop (AB Consulting)
column6: The STEAM (Science Technology Engineering ARTS and Math) movement blends science and the arts in public education. However, it is often unclear how educators, agencies and parents can make an impact. This panel offers three approaches. Experts will describe cutting-edge brain research that supports Music Ed, cross-disciplinary learning tools for DIY music integration and a toolkit to resources for bringing music to your community and schools.
column7: After this panel, you should be able to understand, remember and paraphrase facts about how music education benefits the brain & supports STEM skills.
column8: Examples of DIY tools, apps & projects that combine music & science should enable you to implement or create STEAM learning opportunities of your own
column9: VH1_s _Save the Music_ toolkit identifies key sources, networks & resources that can help instate, reinstate or expand core music ed in a community.

column1: Get Girls to Write, Produce and Direct!
column5: Rebecca Mauldin (ImprovEd Shakespeare), Liliana Sweeten (Girl Improved), Andee Kinzy (Girl Improved), Zia Kinzy (Girl Improved)
column6: How do we change the way girls are represented in media? By teaching them to write, produce and direct! This panel will be a discussion between adolescent girls and their mentor, highlighting the challenges, successes and pitfalls of working with different generations to create content for the future. Girl Improved began as a year-long experiment in theatre and is segueing into short, narrative films. This panel is a chance to hear first-hand from the girls who led the project. They are ready to share their experience with others and to receive feedback on how to expand the mission.
column7: To raise awareness of the lack of positive female representation in media today.
column8: To share techniques used by Girl Improved to put adolescents in charge of content creation.
column9: To evangelize the mission of Girl Improved and find other enthusiastic supporters.

column1: Post-Digital Millennials & An Arts/Tech Education
column5: Stephanie  Rothenberg (Department of Art at SUNY Buffalo), Carla Gannis (Dept of Digital Arts, Pratt Institute), Michael  Rees (William Patterson University), De Angela  Duff (NYU School of Engineering)
column6: How do we effectively teach new intersections between art and technology in the 21st century? First we must recognize that students in their teens and 20_s use technology at higher rates than people from other generations and exhibit intense mental plasticity. They are browsers, innovators, producers, and nomads. As students engage new relationships and communication in a fluid, post-digital era we must facilitate their synthetic and organic creativity. Mel Alexenberg defines _postdigital art_ as _artworks that address the humanization of digital technologies through interplay between digital, biological, cultural, and spiritual systems...between virtual and augmented reality._
column7: Understanding that post-digital does not signify "after digital," instead it describes a more fluid relationship between the digital and the physical.
column8: There is no dominant orientation for arts/tech edu. Our media rich age flows across physical, technological, historical, and creative boundaries.
column9: How, as educators, to contribute to the development of the _T-shaped_ creative individual, one with breadth of experience and depth of knowledge.

column1: Remix Culture: Music and Beyond
column5: Andrew Luck (Foundry10), Jeff Kashiwa (Foundry10), Tom Swanson (Foundry10), Lisa Castaneda (Foundry10)
column6: What if Bach, Chopin and Beethoven had the tools to capture, modify, transpose and recreate the voices and visions of inspiration from the moment they began composing?  What if they could actually touch the sound they imagined or heard, see it, and spontaneously generate new ideas?  Today we have the tools to capture and dissect the spirit of sound - the voices of the greatest artists recorded and preserved.  Over a century of recorded sound exists, and the technology of digital music gives us the ability to connect, dissect, interact, harmonize and resonate with it.  We brought this to the composers of tomorrow, and now we want to share the results.
column7: Attendees will actively consider the types of learning that occur in a remix driven curriculum and how it impacts student learning.
column8: Attendees will be explore the options available to them to implement a similar course in their own school or community.
column9: Attendees will consider curriculum, course timing, and learn about online resources to enable any teacher to run a remixing course.

column1: Revolutionizing Education: Technology & the Arts
column5: Philip Wiser (Hearst), Minerva Tantoco (New York City), Michael Wiggins (Urban Arts Partnership), Philip Courtney (Urban Arts Partnership)
column6: The education revolution is underway; driven by technology and the arts. Recently, a high school student asked Phil Wiser, CTO of Hearst, about his mission. His answer? "I want to help the world blur the lines between arts & technology." On a panel at Google, Minerva Tantoco, CTO of NYC, reminded educators that we are preparing students "for jobs that don't exist yet." Education Revolution explores the potential of strategic partnerships between schools, artists, the tech sector, and government. Panelists will help us imagine the catalytic role that technology and arts can play in the transformation of our public schools; envisioning radical changes in the way students learn.
column7: To discover the key role of the tech savvy arts educator as a catalytic agent for school turnaround, and positive disruption.
column8: To examine the root causes of the tech equity gap and identify how  cross-sector arts and tech partnerships can increase access for all students.
column9: To learn how to create synergistic arts and technology partnerships with the power to radically transform public school classrooms.

column1: Sheriff Bus to Library: How Kids Remix Social Good
column5: Kristie Obrecht (B.F. Yancey Elementary School), Amy Shaffer (The Wonderment), Ryan Skubic (Crispin Porter + Bogusky), Jenn Cook (Kidnected World)
column6: A group of kids and teachers in rural Guatemala had an idea: what if you could turn a bus into a library to serve kids in areas without access to books or supplies? Through unified online and offline community collaboration, the world got involved to turn this idea into reality_ and one transformed 1988 sheriff bus later, things got pretty awesome.In an era of connectivity, even young kids can have an active role in changing the world in new ways. Using the magic sheriff library bus as a model, we_ll explore how our classrooms and libraries can support kids_ use of technology and creativity to build a new sense of belonging and create meaningful impact in a global community.
column7: How to use global connection and impact as a vehicle for creative excitement and inquiry.
column8: How to use technology to merge making, PBL and global collaboration with emotional learning and social good.
column9: How partners can collaborate across communities, countries and industries to bring innovative opportunities and experiences to kids.

column1: The importance of storytelling
column5: Teri  Schwartz (UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television)
column6: Teri Schwartz, Dean of UCLA's School of Theater, Film and Television, is a working film producer and now heads one of the world's most prestigious film schools.  Her emphasis is on storytelling and she would be an ideal panelist for any panels that address the importance of storytelling as content becomes more prevalent.
column7: How to create stories that are universal in theme.
column8: How to create stories that speak to diversity.
column9: How to provide education on an interdisciplinary basis.

column1: The Tide is Turning for Music Education
column5: Barbara Murray (New York City Department of Education), Bob Morrison (Quadrant Arts Education Research), David Wish (Little Kids Rock)
column6: While the benefits of music education are better understood than ever, budget cuts are decimating music programs in US public schools. However, reduced funding is not the only obstacle that impedes students_ access to music education. The time has come to not only preserve, but to expand music education in schools. A new instrumental music program that focuses on teaching popular musical on instruments including guitar, bass, keyboard, drums, vocals & computers has emerged. _Modern Band_ is currently available to 2.2 Million students in school districts nationwide and the funding has come privately through a nonprofit called Little Kids Rock. Universities are adapting as well, in major ways!
column7: Undertand the research behind the benefits of music education for kids & the current state of arts education in public schools and higher education
column8: Identify ways in which public school districts can turn to nonprofits for funding for resources, professional development and expanded curricula.
column9: Examine how universities can further the movement through the addition of methods classes for music ed majors & joint funding initiatives/partnerships

column1: Artificial Intelligence facilitated learning
column5: Patti Smith (Querium), Douglas Stein (Metacog), Dee Kanejiya (Cognii)
column6: This session will discuss the use of advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence to improve the quality of education. AI technologies are widely used for general purposes such as Siri, Cortana and Google Now, but can we use virtual learning assistants that help students improve their conceptual understanding? The panelists will bring different perspectives and different usages such as natural language processing for writing assessment, machine learning for math learning and using simulations and analytics to understand students' learning levels.
column7: Using Siri-like technology to engage students
column8: Formative assessment of constructed responses
column9: Using learning analytics for adaptive personalized instruction

column1: Assessment Technology: Equity for Everyone?
column5: Amy Ogan (Carnegie Mellon University), Richard Schwerdtfeger (IBM Software), Ann Smisko (Dallas Independent School District), Joanna Gorin (Educational Testing Service)
column6: Technology is invading the classroom, but how is it affecting education equity? Assistive technologies increase access for special needs populations, automated internet based tutors reach learners across the globe, and virtual environments engage students who struggle with traditional instruction. Still, access is not universal and assessments play a crucial role in understanding where inequity exists. This panel will use haptics, virtual manipulables, and adaptive tutors to demonstrate the state of assessment technology, how it exposes inequities, and helps improve equity.
column7: Gain insight into the world of technology based assessment (TBA) and assistive technology. Learn about developments, opportunities and challenges.
column8: Experience TBAs from diverse ability and neurological backgrounds and discuss how to relate those experiences to standards of educational outcomes.
column9: Be inspired to think about assessment technology in terms of equity and develop new ideas for designing, deploying, and gainfully using it.

column1: Breaking the Standardized Test Addiction
column5: David Kuntz (Knewton), Diana Shulla-Cose (Perspectives Charter Schools), V. Elizabeth Owen (GlassLab Games), Anya Kamenetz (NPR)
column6: Anya Kamenetz (NPR) will lead a discussion about our standardized test obsession and then explore ways to break this addiction. Alternatives for schools to explore, include: 1) Performance-based assessments/ project-based learning, not tied to specific data points 2) The use of data/analytics to drive self-assessment and daily assessment and feedback 3) Assessment of social-emotional skills, human nature, self-report mechanisms, and student well-being as measurable outcomes 4) game-based assessment that can help to eliminate tests.
column7: Explore why America is test obsessed, and the dangers of relying too much on standardized testing results
column8: Show educators there are effective alternatives to testing by exploring the power of data, project-based learning, social-emotional learning & games
column9: Encourage teachers, education leaders, and administrators to imagine an educational world with fewer tests

column1: Designing tests to benefit students not the system
column5: Ben Grimley (Speak Agent, Inc.), Jessica Berlinski (Personalized Learning Games ), Kara Carpenter (Teachley), Edward Metz (US Department of Education, Institute of Education Sciences)
column6: We need to change school testing at the K-6 level. Many students spend so much time preparing for tests that they miss out on learning. Educators need a constant flow of information to be able to meet individual student needs, but today_s tests provide too little data, too late. They give a score that tells us nothing about students_ thought processes or how they deal with failure. So how should tests work? This panel will explore using real-time formative assessments to differentiate instruction, develop interventions for struggling learners and to reduce student stress by embedding tests into games. Audience participation will be encouraged!
column7: K-6 educators and administrators will learn about research-based tools for formative assessment that they can apply to their school or district.
column8: K-6 educators will be prepared to use data from Web and Mobile apps to differentiate instruction and individualize learning in math, language and SEL.
column9: K-6 educators and administrators will learn about ways to embed assessment into games and interactive activities that reduce student angst.

column1: Going 3D: An expanded view of student achievement
column5: Michelle Navarre (Polaris Charter Academy), Thabiti Brown (Codman Academy), Mark Conrad (Expeditionary Learning), Jeff Schulz (Bellwether Education Partner)
column6: As a nation, we have consensus that high-quality education should be about more than test scores. We know that social-emotional learning and high-quality work matter, too. But even as this 3D view of student achievement gains more acceptance, we are far from consensus on a clear and expanded definition of student success _ and how that definition should shape leading school practices. Join this panel to learn how top schools across the country are putting this 3D view into practice by creating classrooms that join academic scholarship to critical skills like perseverance, critical thinking, and an ethic of contribution to prepare students for success in college, career and citizenship.
column7: Learn about current efforts to create an expanded definition of student success that emphasizes holistic student outcomes.
column8: Explore instructional strategies and classroom practices that integrate an emphasis on knowledge and skills, character, and high-quality student work.
column9: Discover how top schools across the country use assessment to measure progress across the three dimensions of student achievement.

column1: GPA is Not Predictive of Job Performance
column5: John Noble (Koru), Tony Wagner (Harvard University), Paul Freedman (Entangled Ventures), Kristen Hamilton (Koru)
column6: Google published research last year as proof that a high GPA is not correlated with high performance in their experience. While this is becoming accepted as truth among employers, it has also begged the question: What is the better signal that employers are turning to to find the best post-college talent? Centered on the areas in which college career centers can help their students develop, this session will reveal seven competencies that are proving to be demonstrative of post-college entry-level job performance that employers look for and that college career centers can help foster. These competencies include a combination of skills and mindsets like grit and analytical rigor.
column7: Understand why traditional measures like GPA are increasingly being questioned as indicators of post-college, entry-level success by employers
column8: Identify the seven competencies from recent research and employer experience that can dramatically improve your students' success in their job search
column9: Understand ways to increase your students' success in securing meaningful career-track jobs after graduation by helping them hone their soft skills

column1: Insights from Brazil: Youth is not a monster.
column5: Renata Serafim (Talent Propaganda S/A)
column6: We were sick and tired of the ongoing manifests regarding the new generation that was made to change the world, the digital natives who would turn all labels upside down, and brands_ need to hop on the ark or risk drowning in the flood of youth. So, with a tripod and camera in hand, we selected 40 brazilian philosophers, anthropologists, psychologists, priests, famous YouTubers, movie directors, and politicians to openly talk about. All of the findings were confronted against 70 different samples of this feared species, from all ages and social classes. What did we find out? Youth is not a monster. Youth is about people and people don_t change that much from one generation to the other.
column7: What are the behaviors that make youth seem like something distant?
column8: What features are so intrinsic in human behavior that we can never lose track of?
column9: How can the economic and technologic sceneries mold behavior?

column1: Millenials: financial health & digital experiences
column5: Sunjay Pandey (Capital One Investing), Yvette Butler (Capital One Investing), Garrett Silver (Capital One Investing)
column6: While Millenials have reframed value to include great experiences (like travel), they still cite financial priorities that are common to all generations like paying down debt and saving for retirement.   And while Millenials will have the most buying power of any previous American generation, the dotcom bubble and Great recession have caused a distrust of the stock market and an avoidance of financial literacy.  By 2017, Millenials will make up the largest online audience. Firms will need to simplify the experience of budgeting, saving, planning, and investing by fusing technology and human solutions, allowing financial health to be a simple, integrated, and personalized part of daily life.
column7: Understand current Millenial saving and investing patterns and how this impacts their preparedness for major milestones and unexpected events.
column8: Learn how Millenials compare in their understanding of financial markets and expectations of consumer technology, apps, and engagement with brands.
column9: Learn how advice from humans, algorithms, and compelling user experiences can be combined to motivate Millenials and help improve financial health.

column1: Reverse Transfer: Past Credit = Degree Earned
column5: Brandi  Ford (Lone Star College System), Shelby Stanfield (The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: As many as 2 million students across the country could be awarded an associate_s degree through Reverse Transfer, the first national solution to enable four- and two-year institutions to securely and efficiently exchange student data.Reverse transfer of credits occurs when a four-year institution transfers student credits back to any two-year institution from which a student has transferred.UT Austin led this collaborative initiative with other top universities, and the National Student Clearinghouse. This panel will talk about how the program works, why it is needed, and who it will benefit.
column7: How does it work?
column8: Why is it needed?
column9: Who will this impact?

column1: The Future of Educational Assessment
column5: Jim Pellegrino (Learning Sciences Research Institute), Eva Baker (University of California, Los Angeles), Robert  Moses (The Algebra Project, Inc.), Randy Bennett (ETS)
column6: Since No Child Left Behind, assessment in K-12 education has been defined largely by mandated accountability testing. For efficiency, those tests have been largely multiple-choice ones given in paper-and-pencil format. Advances in technology, measurement, and the learning sciences, however, offer exciting possibilities for radically changing the design, content, format, and even the purposes of assessment, reorienting it from its current institutional focus toward the personalization of instruction. This panel will give perspectives on how assessment is (and isn't) likely to change so that it continues to serve institutional goals while also more effectively serving teaching and learning.
column7: To understand the functions of and audiences for assessment in K-12 education
column8: To understand the policy and political context, and how that context will affect the design and implementation of future K-12 assessment programs
column9: To understand how advances in technology (e.g., games, simulations), measurement, and the learning sciences will dramatically change K-12 assessment

column1: The Question is More Important than the Answer
column5: Patrick Burton (Centre d_ducation des adultes du Goland), Julie Willcott (Kennebec Valley Community College), Richard Perry (Bellmore Merrick Central High School District )
column6: The infusion of mobile technology into the classroom has made possible a shift in how we assess students.  Education is no longer about getting the single correct answer; it is about learning how to ask important questions.  Classrooms can now be challenge-based, inquiry-oriented, and project-centered.  Students  can delineate problems, propose solutions, and demonstrate their understanding in unique ways.  As teachers and administrators, we must reconsider how we assess student learning. Join us as we discuss why this change is important, provide examples of how it is happening in diverse classrooms, and answer your questions about the shift from correct answers to important questions.
column7: Why are traditional testing methods no longer relevant?
column8: What does the shift from the right answer to the right question look like in the classroom? Examples of technology-infused classrooms to be provided.
column9: How are students and teachers impacted by the change from correct answer to correct question?

column1: Throwing Out Grades for Better Student Learning
column5: Peter Bencivenga (Datacation), Michael Hernandez (Mira Costa High School), Starr Sackstein (NYC DOE - WJPS), Mark  Barnes (Hack Learning )
column6: Become engaged in the on-going discussion of best assessment practices for student learning. During our time together we will challenge the role of traditional grading systems and why they don't lend themselves to student success. Let's take the focus off the numbers and letters and place it where it belongs, on student metacognative awareness and reflection on growth of skills and content knowledge.
column7: To help educators understand why grading practices impact student learning
column8: To provide a dialogue to explore alternatives to what is currently being done
column9: To offer solutions for assessment practices to increase student learning

column1: Underprepared Students on the Pathway to Success
column5: Paul Fain (Inside Higher Ed), Charles Cook (Austin Community College), Jenna Cullinane (Charles A. Dana Center, The University of Texas at Austin), Evelyn Waiwaiole (Center for Community College Student Engagement, The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: In 2010, President Obama set two national educational goals: By 2020, America will once again have the highest proportion of college graduates in the world, and community colleges will graduate an additional five million students.  Since then, community colleges have been under increased pressure to improve student performance, retention, and, most importantly, completion _ all while 2/3 of students entering their doors are not prepared for college-level work. A "one size fits all" approach for these students won_t help reach the goal of five million more graduates.  Join leaders from the field as they discuss ways of changing the fundamental conversation surrounding this vital challenge.
column7: Hear findings from a new national study that focuses on the challenges facing underprepared students as they journey through community colleges.
column8: Listen to innovative approaches to developmental education being implemented at Austin Community College.
column9: Explore new directions for math education through curriculum and pathway models.

column1: Cognitive Tech: Reshaping How We Nurture HI
column5: Mary  Mullen  (Lovejoy Independent School District ), Alex Kaplan  (IBM), Penny Reinart (Office Depot )
column6: Cognitive technologies, have the potential to shape our classrooms, and directly impact the development of the entire education ecosystem. When cognitive tools are put in service of educators, it has the potential to reshape how we nurture human intelligence. But what exactly does that mean? How does that come to life in the classroom? And what are the drawbacks? During this session, hear from districts already deploying cognitive technology in the classroom alongside the folks who power it. And consider the power of _Watson_ in the classroom.
column7: How predictive analytics and cognitive technology will shape the K-12 ecosystem.
column8: Integration of cognitive technology begins at the district level and is dependent upon applications that drive improved student outcomes.
column9: Harness existing info to understand the whole student(behavior, attendance, skills mastery)to personalize learning and provide proactive measures

column1: Drugs and Your Brain
column5: Adron Harris (The University of Texas at Austin), Juan Dominguez (The University of Texas at Austin), Rueben Gonzales (The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: While the debilitating behavioral consequences of drug taking are well recognized, the extent to which it also affects brain function is poorly understood. The panel will be comprised of members of the University of Texas at Austin scientific community, with expertise in drug abuse and neuroscience. The target audience is wide, ranging from educators and students to members of the general public. Anyone with an interest in how different drugs of abuse (alcohol, cocaine, meth, etc) impact brain function and ultimately how these changes cause behavioral deficits leading to pathological conditions, like addiction, would benefit from attending this panel.
column7: How does the normal brain function?
column8: How do drugs of abuse change the normal brain?
column9: How do drug-induced changes to the brain cause addiction and ultimately negatively impact behavior?

column1: Era-Responsive Math=Coding+Reasoning+Collaboration
column5: Monica Valadez (De Zavala Elementary School), Mark Lai (University of Texas), Kevin Moore (the number lab)
column6: Despite the rising concern over the weakness of STEM education in the United States, most of our elementary math classrooms operate in much the same way as they did 100 years ago. How can we transform our elementary school classrooms to insure our children are globally competitive in an information economy?A practicing mathematician, a mathematics-focused micro-school founder, and an education reformist discuss deepening teachers_ mathematical thinking through their practice-based lab environment.  In additional, the panel will discuss their ongoing project to connect mathematical reasoning to Python coding for children K-6.
column7: Challenges in elementary mathematics classroom
column8: Practice-based lab environments as an impetus for change
column9: Computational thinking + math reasoning as an impetus for change

column1: Helicopter Parents & the Electronic Umbilical Cord
column5: Lee Bryant (Child Care Action Council), Gary  Neal (Trinity University), Erin Sumner (Trinity University), Bree McEwan (Western Illinois University)
column6: This panel explores the trend of helicopter parenting, which occurs when well-intended parents become detrimentally involved in their children's lives. Communication professors Bree McEwan and Erin Sumner will discuss how this affects educational outcomes and parent-child relational quality during college, while contemplating the role of technology as an electronic umbilical cord of hyperconnectivity. Early childhood educator Lee Ann Bryant will explore the early roots, while offering strategies to foster an age-appropriate level of involvement. Finally, Gary Neal will offer advice based on his experiences as a licensed psychologist and director of university counseling and health services.
column7: Understand the roots of helicopter parenting, such as parent-child hyperconnection, fear of failure, and the increased cost of education.
column8: Examine how helicopter parenting affects students' mental well-being, academic performance, and parental relationship quality
column9: Explore ways to foster a healthy and developmentally appropriate level of parent-child connection during childhood and into higher education.

column1: It's More Than Just Fun: The Power of Play
column5: Gwen Gordon (Gwen Gordon Play), Sally McConnell (KaBOOM!), Sunita Mohanty (Lumos Labs),  Bjrn  Jeffery  (Toca Boca)
column6: Increasingly, research is pointing to the clear benefits of play in early childhood. As researcher Kathy Hirsh-Pasek says: _The science is clear_ failing to preserve it in the lives of children could be a disaster._ Various types of play can reduce stress, facilitate social development, improve working memory, develop self-control and increase attention spans. At the same time, heavily structured learning environments & standardized testing are squeezing out room for time to play.This panel will explore different perspectives on what constitutes _a healthy breakfast_ of play: digital play, guided play, free play, and physical play.
column7: What are the benefits of play for children as they develop?
column8: What does the future of play hold?
column9: What are risks that endanger making time for children to do what comes most naturally - to make time for play?

column1: Move, Get Out The Way! Gen Z Students Take Control
column5: Tisha Green Rinker (Connections Education LLC), Shawn Talley (Performance Strategies, LLC), Student TBD (Texas Connections Academy@Houston)
column6: Born between 1990 and 2009, there are 4.6 million Generation Z_ers who are actively investigating professional experience by taking career technical education courses, college courses, and getting internships_before graduating high school. These digital, social, and global natives are entrepreneurs who are shaping their future while still in high school. Learn how these characteristics are creating a paradigm shift in education and the workplace by hearing from a Gen Z student, a director of  counseling services, and a Human Resources hiring expert.
column7: Learn the characteristics of Generation Z and how they are challenging traditional ways of thinking
column8: Understand the overarching trends of Gen Z and the implications for education and the workplace
column9: Discover what Gen Z aspirations are for their future.

column1: Skill Set + Mindset = Academic & Career Success
column5: David. T. Conley, Ph.D. (Center for Educational Policy Research), Paul G. Stoltz, Ph.D. (Peak Learning, Inc)
column6: More than ever before, students are expected to have the skills beyond literacy and numeracy that all learners need to be successful in life. David T. Conley, Ph.D. and Paul G. Stoltz, Ph.D. discuss how the development of skill set_learning, cognitive, & transition skills_can be connected to a gritty mindset to equip ALL students with the tools to succeed academically & professionally.  Dr. Conley_s _Four Keys to College Readiness_ (Think, Know, Act, Go) and Dr. Stoltz_s powerful GRIT_ construct (Growth, Resilience, Instinct, and Tenacity) provide a precise, actionable program for guaranteeing every student a better chance at academic achievement and career success.
column7: Define the concepts & value of the Four Keys and GRIT_ while engaging participants in active consideration of their own skill set and mindset
column8: Understand how skill set and mindset can be assessed and developed
column9: Explain the learner life cycle and the importance of growth from novice to expert

column1: Teaching Code is Not About Creating Programmers
column5: Jonathan Schor (codemonkey), Dan Leyzberg (Princeton University), Colleen Lewis (Harvey Mudd College), Grant Hosford (codeSpark)
column6: Global movements like Hour of Code have brought computer science into the mainstream. But those who work in the field firmly believe that the goal should not be to create millions of programmers. Rather, the entrepreneurs, teachers and academics behind the movement believe all students should learn how to leverage their own abilities through technology. Their research shows there are broad based benefits for all kids when they master concepts like sequencing and algorithmic thinking. This panel will look at how parents, teachers and professors can use the study of computer science to help students improve their problem solving abilities and gain confidence in themselves as digital creators.
column7: Discuss exactly how learning to code helps students develop problem solving abilities that will help them in any field
column8: Discuss the challenges of teaching kids to code and why it_s important for every student to have exposure to this 21st century skill
column9: Dive deep into the practical applications of learning to code

column1: The Myth of the Learning Style Holds Students Back
column5: James Stigler (UCLA), Ulrik Christensen (McGraw Hill Education)
column6: Many education experts argue that there are as many as 19 different learning styles. While this seems large, from a cognitive perspective, it does not even begin to scratch the surface on the millions of ways students can solve one problem. In fact, very few studies have found evidence of learning styles and the idea that students fit neatly in a certain style, such as auditory or visual learners, is counterproductive. Despite this, a recent international survey of teachers in the UK, China and other countries found that 96 percent of respondents believed in the notion of preferred learning styles.
column7: Debunk the myth of the learning style
column8: Deciphering if the learning style myth perpetuates poor performance
column9: Discussing how educators can accommodate millions of different learning styles without demotivating particular groups of students

column1: The Science of Learning II
column5: Susan Winslow (Macmillan Higher Education), Mariette DiChristina (Scientific American), Tyler  Cowen (George Mason University), Rob Lue (Harvard University)
column6: Are we just training drones? Or are our teaching methods positively connecting students to learning, leadership, and our future workforce? Hybrid or _blended" learning has emerged as a teaching method that increases student outcomes while lowering attrition rates. Combining traditional face-to-face instruction with online learning, however, is not just a skills competency, but an approach that connects to education, leadership, and creativity. This evolving vision of STEM and liberal arts education needs to create a system that allows progress to more effective learning and leadership. Speakers will discuss current data, solutions, and the far-reaching impact of hybrid learning.
column7: To gain a better understand of emerging hybrid models in higher education using new technologies and the resulting impact to STEM education.
column8: Gain insight into the range of impacts this approach has in and beyond the classroom, in our future leaders, innovators, workforce, and economy.
column9: Discussion of entrepreneurship and resulting structural changes driven by online education. Idea generation on ways to facilitate skills & creativity.

column1: America's Dirty Little Secret: The Skills Gap.
column5: Collin Gutman (WorkAmerica), Crystal Huang (ProSky, Inc.), Jim Deters (Galvanize), Ryan Craig (University Ventures)
column6: Since the advent of higher education, there has been a gap between employer needs and what higher education has provided.  Higher institutions have done their best to anticipate and meet labor market demand, but not always successfully, as demonstrated by the fact that over 4M jobs remain unfilled in the U.S.  Employers continue to complain that college graduates aren't adequately prepared for work.  In response, a new generation of companies and educational institutions has arisen aiming to bridge the divide between higher education and the labor market.  Bootcamps and top-up skills programs; will these new approaches unleash the productivity revolution we're all clamoring for?
column7: Develop a more in-depth understanding of where the skills gaps actually are.
column8: Get a closer look at how technology is helping match higher education institutions and employers.
column9: Understand how universities can partner to address critical workforce needs.

column1: Are They Learning? Competency-Based Student Voices
column5: Melanie Johnson (Patten University), Chris Ruiz-Edding (College for America), Willie Rushing (Western Governors University), Bernard Bull (Concordia University-Wisconsin)
column6: This panel will offer attendees the chance to hear from students enrolled in three different competency-based universities (College for America, Western Governors, and Patten University). Each student has previous experience in another higher education institution, and they will speak to the differences between their platforms, what_s proven difficult, and why they picked competency-based education compared to other options.If you_re thinking about sending students to a competency-based university or adding a program to your university, come hear students enrolled in three different programs discuss the advantages, challenges, and habits that have proven effective in their studies.
column7: How does competency-based higher education compare to other college options?
column8: What are the differences between competency-based universities?
column9: What weekly routines support successful adult learning in competency-based universities?

column1: Bootcamps : Re-Shaping Traditional Education
column5: Cahlan Sharp (DevMountain), John Richards (Startup Ignition), Krissy Weekley (DevMountain)
column6: The bootcamp market will grow by 2.4x, to an estimated 16,056 graduates in 2015, up from 6,740 in 2014.Kaplan's acquiring of Dev Bootcamp, a two-year-old school that offers nine-week crash courses to aspiring software developers is a sign that bootcamps may become bigger players in higher education.Bootcamps are expanding and, in some areas of education, are replacing the 4-year degree. I would suggest a Panel of Founders of multiple bootcamps in different areas of expertise.Coding Bootcamp // DevMountain // devmountain.comEntrepreneurship Bootcamp // Startup Ignition // startupignition.comDigital Marketing Bootcamp // Market Campus // marketcampus.com
column7: How bootcamps are changing the landscape and roadmap of higher education. It is evident by now that there is a paradigm shift.
column8: Are these bootcamps delivering a qualified workforce? Are these bootcamps working?
column9: How bootcamps are doing what higher ed and recruiting can_t.

column1: College or Bust? Redefining the Finish Line
column5: Kalani Leifer (CO-OP), Paris Woods (College Bridge), Lyel Resner (Flatiron School), Katie Beck (4.0 Schools)
column6: Research shows that a college degree dramatically expands opportunities, projected income, and social mobility for those who attain one.  Yet simultaneously, only 8% of students from low-income communities are graduating college, and those who start and don't finish are saddled with debt.  Some organizations continue to focus on increasing the college access and persistence rates, while others suggest that we should instead focus on preparing students to aim for financial independence and access to careers upon high school graduation.  This panel will bring together leaders from all sides of this debate to share how they're supporting students and how they define the "finish line".
column7: Panelists and audience will discuss and compare major levers for increasing student success in adulthood.
column8: Panelists and audience will examine the pros and cons of retaining college as a goal for all students.
column9: Panelists and audience will share the work of organizations testing new ways to both increase college and career success.

column1: Corporate Re-Education: Lessons from Higher Ed
column5: Ryan Anderson (University of Wisconsin-Extension), Management Consulting/HR Lead TBD (TBD), Alec  Couros  (University of Regina/Open Thinking Blog), John  Baker (D2L)
column6: On-the-job training is ending_it_s the era of on-the-job learning.But can business buy education? They_re trying _ spending more than $70B on corporate learning initiatives last year alone. Businesses are taking cues from experts in higher education to improve corporate learning models. And it_s working, with Fortune 100 leaders increasing employee retention by as much as 75 percent. This panel assembles corporate learning experts and leading educators to discuss the teaching technologies and methodologies that are most effective for improving corporate learning programs and how the higher ed model is actually leading the way for big business.
column7: How to retain top talent and foster employee growth by emulating education_s use of technology to boost teaching and learning.
column8: Ways to improve workforce retention by turning employee onboarding into an ongoing process rather than a moment-in-time event.
column9: Practical tips and best practices for employers seeking to implement a technology-based approach to employee onboarding and training.

column1: CS10K: Scaling Computer Science Teacher Training
column5: Carol Fletcher (Texas Regional Collaboratives for Excellence in Science and Mathematics Teaching), Michael Marder (The University of Texas at Austin), Calvin Lin (The University of Texas at Austin), Kimberly Hughes (The UTeach Institute)
column6: With a growing number of initiatives intended to bring computer science (CS) courses to high school classrooms nationwide, administrators are scrambling to train large numbers of teachers to meet local demands. This session brings together panelists with a diversity of perspectives on how best to meet NSF_s call to train 10,000 CS teachers nationwide. Panelists include a physics professor who co-directs a pre-service STEM teacher preparation program, a CS professor who led a team to develop one of the new CS Principles courses endorsed by NSF and College Board, and two organizational directors, one focused on in-service STEM teacher PD and one focused on scaling CS education and training.
column7: Attendees will be able to describe CS10K and related initiatives (e.g., Arkansas CS education legislation, Texas House Bill 5) and impacts in K-12.
column8: Attendees will be able to describe different pre- and in-service pathways for CS teacher preparation, professional development, and support.
column9: Attendees will be able to identify differences and rationales for College Board's new CS Principles course versus "traditional" introductions to CS.

column1: Cultivating Teacher Readiness in Next Gen Learning
column5: Liz Willen (The Hechinger Institute), Sanjay Sarma (MIT), Arthur Levine (Woodrow Wilson Foundation), Jessie Woolley-Wilson (DreamBox Learning)
column6: What is thwarting the successful adoption and scaling of digital learning? Discover why MIT_s Office of Digital Learning and the Woodrow Wilson Foundation_s Academy of Teaching and Learning have joined forces to reimagine and cultivate teacher readiness to advance STEM and support next gen learning. Educators need and deserve new approaches to continuous development and renewal, performance assessment and retention. It_s important to understand why the key to transformation in a rapidly evolving digital learning landscape is teacher engagement and teacher readiness.
column7: The ways in which innovations in adaptive learning are being applied and used to improve teacher preparation and professional development.
column8: How the transformation of learning opportunities and outcomes through innovative learning technologies impacts the K-20 spectrum.
column9: The reasons why teacher engagement and teacher readiness is the key to success in the evolving digital learning landscape.

column1: Debugging CS Ed w/ Public/Private Partnerships
column5: Erin Cannon (Google), Lori Ham (Microsoft), Alison Derbenwick Miller (Oracle), Carol Fletcher (TRC, The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Computer science (CS) is the only STEM area that has seen a DECREASE in high school course enrollment and college degrees over the last decade, in large part due to a lack of qualified CS teachers in high school. Companies who depend on a high tech workforce are trying to reverse this trend by investing in capacity building projects that will increase the number of teachers qualified to teach CS.  This presentation will highlight three innovative public/private partnerships between UT Austin_s Center for STEM Education and Oracle Academy, Google and Microsoft. Attendees will learn how to develop similar partnerships that can bring CS to traditionally underrepresented students nationwide.
column7: Session participants will learn how to access free online training in Java to teach AP Computer Science.
column8: Attendees will learn how the TEALS program supports new CS teachers and how to volunteer as a CS professional with TEALS.
column9: Attendees will learn how Google_s CS4HS project supports the new AP CS Principles course and how to start CS student clubs with the CS First Toolkit.

column1: Diplomas Optional: Jobs of the New Century
column5: Wan-Lae  Cheng (Markle Foundation), Alison Dorsey (LinkedIn), Maria Harper-Marinick (Maricopa County Community Colleges), David Kirkpatrick (Techonomy)
column6: Technology is profoundly altering the American labor market. Jobseekers struggle to connect their skills and experience with meaningful employment, while more than half the nation_s employers have difficulty finding skilled workers for available jobs. In this session we will discuss how the Rework America Connected partnership is creating a new and innovative skills-based marketplace to help many more Americans connect to good jobs, new career paths and training resources. Discover your place in tomorrow_s dynamic digital job market!
column7: Understand the Skills/training/jobs mismatch
column8: Explore Rework America Connected_s partnerships and platform
column9: Learn how Rework America Connected can be a model for national efforts

column1: Education for Employment
column5: Stavros Yiannouka (WISE)
column6: Are we preparing ourselves and the next generation for a truly global and disruptive world of work? (more details to be provided)
column7: TBD
column8: TBD
column9: TBD

column1: Find Your Twitter PLN: An Edchat Love Story
column5: Christina Esquivel (Mobility Labs)
column6: Twitter for teacher professional development? You bet! Teachers have been connecting on Twitter through live Twitter events called edchats, where they can collaborate, mentor/be mentored, discuss education, and share resources. This session will help audience members navigate the Twitterverse to access quality professional learning and build their personal learning network (PLN). We will also discuss resources to moderate, analyze, and grow edchats as well as the potential impact of edchats on teacher professional development.This panel will include Christina Esquivel as a moderator along with 1-2 edchat moderators and a representative from a non-profit.
column7: You will learn about how educators are using Twitter and edchats to improve their knowledge and skills.
column8: You'll learn about the impact of edchats on teachers as well as what this could mean for the future of professional development.
column9: You'll understand how to grow an edchat and develop a PLN to connect to other rockstar teachers.

column1: Good Thinking! The Science Of Teaching Science
column5: Brian Mandell (Smithsonian Science Education Center ), Marjee Chmiel (Smithsonian Science Education Center), Danielle  Gillis  (FableVision), Leigh  Hallisey (FableVision)
column6: The Smithsonian Science Education Center has partnered with FableVision Studios on "Good Thinking! The Science of Teaching Science," a new, original web series and professional development resource for science educators. Too often, valuable knowledge sits unused in inaccessible journals; Good Thinking! delves into the research to share the best ideas and practices with teachers in a fun, accessible way. Good Thinking! is able to reach teachers with targeted information to support their practices.
column7: Explore the potential for practical implementation of an animated web-series as part of a coherent and rigorous professional development plan.
column8: Investigate the learning science behind why our minds are designed to misunderstand science, & what educators can do about it.
column9: Discuss the need for an intersection of research and science with arts and entertainment in order to provide accessible information.

column1: Graduating to Digital-First Branding in Higher Ed
column5: Catherine Canney (MIT Sloan), Carol Keese (University of Virginia), Alexandra Day (The Juilliard School), Gene Lewis (Digital Pulp)
column6: Digital marketing strategies framed by modern, responsive and content-rich websites are becoming high-priority tools for schools to impact the decision-making of prospective students and supporters - and higher ed institutions face their own unique challenges. The importance of conveying a school_s essence, relevance in the world, and the future it can offer students is elemental. Hear from experts in marketing and communications from leading institutions discuss their greatest challenges and debate digital marketing strategies, including:- Digital-first branding- PSRM (Prospective Student Relationship Management)- Authenticity in experience content- User experience vs. immersion
column7: How to creative an effective digital-first branding strategy for your higher ed institution.
column8: How to innovate your higher ed institution's PSRM (Prospective Student Relationship Management) strategy.
column9: How to develop an experience content strategy to communicate more authentically with prospective students and supporters.

column1: How can online learning truly disrupt higher ed?
column5: Philip  Regier  (ASU Online and Extended Campus ), Tara Garcia Mathewson  (Education Dive ), Ajay Kapur (Kadenze )
column6: In this session we'll explore what we believe to be the most significant disruptors across higher education and amongst students and lifelong learners that make up the on-demand generation of present and future. As technological developments evolve to compliment traditional higher education, students can optimize their capacity to learn and minimize the financial burdens they face when attending 4 year higher education institutions. Every time a student enrolls, participates, and completes an online course on one of the dozens of online platforms currently available, they are casting a vote. With every vote cast, the opportunity grows to disrupt the traditional higher education ecosystem.
column7: Identify the most significant disruptors in higher education by bridging the gap between traditional and alternative forms of learning.
column8: Ways in which student work can be measured and assessed more fairly and accurately online.
column9: How educators can engage students in a virtual learning environment as you would in a physical environment.

column1: Microcredentials: Bridge from education to career
column5: Anya Kamenetz (http://www.npr.org/), Pat Wadors (http://www.mheducation.com/), David Levin (http://www.mheducation.com/)
column6: Higher ed is seeing the beginnings of a consumer-driven world in which the traditional constructs of education are replaced by unbundled offerings focused on competency-based learning and credentialing. Students fill shopping carts with portable, stackable credentials, allowing them to move through education more efficiently, demonstrate mastery at their own pace and focus on courses most relevant to their intended career. But how realistic is this vision of the future, and what may be lost on the way?Most higher ed institutions still have their feet planted firmly in traditional credentials. And some of most innovative institutions have not embraced competency-based learning.
column7: Discuss the drivers of the micro-credentialing trend and weigh the benefits and risks of this new model for education.
column8: Understand the type of learning ecosystem necessary to support micro-credentialing, and what this will mean for instructors and students.
column9: Outline what institutions must do to prepare for a world dominated by micro-credentialing.

column1: MOOCs & Teacher PD: Mindless Snack or Hearty Fare?
column5: Charlie Chung (Class Central), Nina Huntemann (edX), Glenn Kleiman (Friday Institute for Educational Innovation), Julia Stiglitz (Coursera)
column6: In our rapidly changing times, K-12 teachers are more in need of quality professional development (PD) resources than ever before. We know that a significant proportion of MOOC-takers are teachers, however, we know little else. How many are taking MOOCs for PD? Are they refreshing their knowledge, looking for materials to use in their classroom, observing teaching techniques, interacting with others? Is completion and/or certification an important goal, and are they receiving CEUs?The panelists will bring their insights and perspectives on these topics--you bring the questions. The overall goal is to foster discussion on how MOOCs can be better utilized to serve educator PD needs.
column7: To share what we know about how teachers are utilizing MOOCs for PD today, and the efforts of providers to offer relevant content/experiences
column8: To bring up or refine ideas on how MOOCs can better serve PD needs, via content selection, features or services, communications, etc.
column9: To discuss how MOOCs can be better incorporated into the PD ecosystem, including the role of certifications/CEUs, fees, district-level support, etc.

column1: Snapp, crackle, pop: Scholarship apps made easy
column5: Mike Baur (Michael & Susan Dell Foundation), Amy Weinstein (National Scholarship Providers Association), Daniel Hae-Dong Lee (The Common Application), Oscar Sweeten-Lopez (Michael & Susan Dell Foundation)
column6: There are two obstacles that hamper a low-income student_s ability to apply to college: time and money. Finding, researching and applying for scholarships takes time. A lot of it.  In addition, these students desperately need money offered by scholarships to be able to go to college. What if technology could solve this problem by reusing 60% of a student_s data in every application giving them back a large portion of their time and an opportunity to receive financial assistance?
column7: Introducing Scholar Snapp- a technology developed to solve this problem. How does it work? And how would a student find and use this technology?
column8: How will this technology affect matriculation to college? Will it affect the rate of low-income students applying to college?
column9: We know that some colleges come with sticker shock. Will students make different college decisions because they have access to more financial aid?

column1: Solo work and the rise of just-in-time learning
column5: Pete Janzow (Pearson), Kathleen Radionoff (Madison Area Technical College), Michael  Hopkins (The Solo Project), Sara Bartlett (Pearson VUE)
column6: 53 million people are already working independently as freelancers, indie professionals, creatives and free agents. That number is expected to grow to more than 50% of America_s workforce in the next decade. What are the characteristics and implications of the emerging solo workforce? And how can employers find soloists who have the right capabilities and experience?To make this new economy work, it will be critical to cultivate trust networks around what each worker can do, in a way that is verifiable and accessible. Enter: digital badges, the emerging standard for recognizing, managing and sharing work experience, learning achievements and professional competencies in the digital world.
column7: Understand the factors behind the new solo workforce + how to prepare for it
column8: Discuss the role of alternative credentials in empowering soloists to thrive in the workforce
column9: Learn how digital badges play a critical role in representing alternative credentials and building trust networks

column1: Students Unfiltered: Digital in the Classroom
column5: Elana  Golub (Northwestern University), Zak Malamed (Student Voice), JoAnna Zalkovsky (Navarro College), Matt Bilotti (Northeastern University)
column6: There's a multitude of digital tools available to students aimed at increasing engagement and improving student outcomes. But are students using these tools and to what extent?  Forget the BS, drop the sales pitch and join an interactive conversation that brings students - the MOST IMPORTANT part of the equation - to the spotlight. This session will seek to understand how technology's increasingly important role in the classroom impacts students. By asking critical questions, the conversation will help uncover what students want and don't want from digital and how to best integrate digital tools into the curriculum, ultimately resulting in higher engagement and better student outcomes.
column7: Ask the experts, students, what works with digital. Understand how to better integrate digital tools into curriculum to increase classroom success.
column8: What pain points do students face w/ tech-based learning? As the edtech marketplace explodes, how do we avoid using digital for digital's sake?
column9: How does student feedback drive design and development of tools? How can we adapt to virtual learning while still encouraging personal interactions?

column1: The Way of the SAMRai: EdTech Micro-Credentialing
column5: Israel Oliveros (Coachella Valley Unified School District), Darryl Adams (Coachella Valley Unified School District), Michelle Murphy (Coachella Valley Unified School District), Edward Simoneau (Coachella Valley Unified School District)
column6: This workshop provides a one-hour condensed version of CVUSD_s SAMRai, or SAMR Advanced Instructor, program. Participants will understand TPACK, SAMR, and Webb_s Depth of Knowledge to learn how they are all interconnected. Content, Pedagogy, and Technology must work intertwined to truly enhance student learning. Upon understanding how these areas work together, participants will learn strategies to help them effectively move up the SAMR Model. The final part of the session will allow participants to begin looking at lesson design and lesson task development, while also gaining insight from video lesson demonstrations and first-hand experiences from presenters and participants in attendance.
column7: How can I begin training my staff so they are aware of and able to use TPACK and SAMR strategies?
column8: How can I build an educational technology training program that provides a micro-credential for my staff?
column9: How can teachers utilize technology with their students to prepare them for the 21st Century and Common Core?

column1: Traditional vs. Competency-Based Learning Models
column5: Karen  Cator (Digital Promise), Paige Hoffman (DC Public Schools), Jason Lange (BloomBoard)
column6: From Credit Hours to Micro-credentials: Moving to a Competency-Based Professional Growth Model.In today_s world, it's important for teachers to adopt a lifelong learning mindset to continually expand their knowledge and improve student engagement. Continuous learning can come in many forms, and with or without the guidance of your principal or district. In this panel, we_ll explore traditional learning models and competency-based models of professional development. Is one better than the other, or should there be a balance? Can a shift be made? What are the implications? Join us for a lively discussion.
column7: Understand the difference between traditional learning models and competency-based models of learning.
column8: Identify strategies for how each model can be used throughout your school or district to empower professional growth.
column9: Reflect on implications for each model and how they would affect professional growth within your school or district.

column1: Two to Tango: Partnering the Future of Higher Ed
column5: Phillip Long (Research Communications), Pam Buffington (The Center for 21st Century Universities at the Georgia Institute of Technology), David Joyner (Udacity, The Georgia Institute of Technology)
column6: Today's college students live and learn in a fast-paced and digital world. Foreseeing the demand for a new type of classroom, online learning innovators Udacity, Coursera, and EdX have partnered with leaders in higher education to forge the future of affordable, high-quality alternatives to the on-campus degree. Hear from Phillip D. Long, Associate Vice Provost for Learning Sciences at UT Austin, Pam Buffington, Director of Platform Technologies at Georgia Tech's Center for 21st Universities, and David Joyner, a Course Developer for Udacity and Georgia Tech's online Master of Science in Computer Science, as they unpack what it looks like when industry and higher ed partner for the future.
column7: Gain an understanding of the development, innovation, and challenges that have propelled higher education towards online learning.
column8: Take away action items for educators, administrators, or entrepreneurs interested in pursuing this collaborative new educational model.
column9: Gather the ways in which online learning impacts students differently than the traditional lecture setting.

column1: 21st century teachers are the new data warriors
column5: Regina Riley (Education First), Cristina  Munoz (Education First), Brinton  Ramsey (Education First), Cheryl Niehaus (Michael & Susan Dell Foundation)
column6: Our ongoing national conversation about education data is often focused on standardized test scores and what they can tell us about student achievement.  But the most useful data to teachers is the much richer formative data they collect daily, while learning is taking place inside their classrooms.  Gathering, analyzing and acting on this data poses a set of challenges and opportunities quite different from the use of summative or benchmark standardized assessments.  This session will explore:
column7: With so much data available to teachers, how do they decide what_s most important and actionable? And then how do they alter their instruction?
column8: Classrooms have students at differing levels of proficiency. How do teachers manage individualizing/differentiating instruction for every student?
column9: Does technology play a role in formative assessment?  If so, to what extent does it aid teachers in collecting, analyzing and/or acting upon the data?

column1: A Data-Driven Culture: Who's Behind the Wheel?
column5: Gregory Firn (DreamBox Learning), Patricia Greco (School District of Menomonee Falls), Sharnell Jackson (Chicago Public Schools)
column6: Changing teaching methods and protocol isn_t easy. Making sense of the plethora of data isn_t either. It is critical to help teachers easily understand how to make sense of data usage and how to apply it to the classroom.  Recent reports show the need to shift the focus from data for informing, to the creation of a culture where data is embraced, effectively used, and for continued results in improved practices, programs, and student achievement. During this panel, learn how to drive with data, creating the culture needed to impact change in educators and students.
column7: Participants will learn how to use the right data to surface leading indicators in student achievement.
column8: Discover ways to leverage data to gain actionable insights at a district level.
column9: Gain insights on how to create and nurture a data driven culture in districts and schools.

column1: Align: Advanced Curriculum Alignment
column5: Julian Alssid (College for America), Joe Rodriguez (Texas State Technical College), Rex Peebles (Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board), Michael Bettersworth (Texas State Technical College)
column6: Join us for the unveiling of Align_a new advanced curriculum alignment tool designed by educators for educators. Translate learning outcomes into real-world skills. Engage industry directly to determine what competencies are most important. Collaborate with peers to optimize curriculum. Connect what you teach with careers so students succeed. This session features an expert panel discussing advancements in curriculum development, effective industry engagement strategies, and how educators can use Align to close skill gaps.
column7: Learn how to analyze, validate, and align your curriculum
column8: Engage industry advisors with custom online skills surveys
column9: Improve the employability of your students by optimizing curriculum

column1: Big Data vs. Frontline Analytics
column5: Dr. Wallace Boston (American Public University System), Gunnar  Counselman (Fidelis Education), Sharon van Wyk (Tutor.com and The Princeton Review)
column6: While big data indisputably has value for helping higher education actors understand how multiple factors influence student outcomes, frontline insights (or "small data") may prove to be a more effective way to understand exactly what students need. _Small data_ provide a human context to important insights about behavior and outcomes. In contrast to impersonal data associations, frontline insights are gathered directly from the students to inform instruction in real-time. In the world of frontline insights, today_s challenges become the focus of tomorrow_s lesson, ensuring students get the support they need when they need it.
column7: Understand the distinction between frontline insights and big data
column8: Discuss the benefits of frontline data and how it_s being used
column9: Debate the merits of each type of analytics; discuss how they can work together
column10: big data, analytics, student support, higher education

column1: Catalyst for Change: Measuring Family Engagement
column5: Lacy Wood (American Institue for Research), Kim Jones (One Green Apple), Queen Makkada (Queen's Parent Consulting and Advocacy Serviceulting), Joseph Fratoni (One Green Apple)
column6: We all know that family engagement is important to a student_s success, yet this cost-effective resource is underutilized, especially with the at-risk population. This can be attributed to the lack of simple, meaningful, objective metrics. You can_t manage what you can_t measure.This panel will discuss barriers to family engagement, what research shows to be the best practices, and how they are implemented in schools, if at all. The panel will discuss not only the importance of analyzing family engagement, but what and how do we measure, and who should receive this analysis. It will review currently available transformational concepts and technology that improve and measure engagement.
column7: Attendees will learn what types of family engagement work, and the barriers to FE, both financially, and structurally, in our school systems today.
column8: Attendees will learn what measurements should be analyzed, the difficulties in attaining these metrics, and who should receive this information.
column9: Attendees will learn the available options in the marketplace, their limitations and benefits, and a discussion on their usefulness.

column1: Creating Customized Student Career Pathways
column5: Raul Valentin (Comcast), Eloy Ortiz Oakley (Long Beach City College), Felix Ortiz (Viridis Learning)
column6: Community college students suffer from especially high attrition rates and confusion about what skills to obtain for the jobs they desire. Simultaneously, businesses suffer from a deficit of qualified talent, costing them billions of dollars each year. The solution to both problems depends on creating technological tools for tracking student performance and guiding them down career pathways constructed according to student interest and aptitude. A data-driven alignment of schools, students, and employers will help give greater clarity to the opportunities available to students and the needs of employers, thus producing a revived middle class.
column7: Demonstrate the value to students, administrators, and businesses of using algorithmic data analysis to build customized career pathways.
column8: Show how data-driven approaches to matching students with jobs are superior to current job-matching technologies like Monster.com or CareerBuilder.
column9: Show how deeper partnerships between educational organizations and employers benefit students and deliver qualified talent to businesses.

column1: Data Viz: Lessons You Can Use Now
column5: Jason LaTurner (American Institutes for Research), Karen Cornetto (New Teacher Center), Lisa Schmitt (Austin Independent School District), Stephanie Evergreen (Evergreen Data)
column6: Data visualization is not just about looking pretty. Pretty is the side effect of designing communications that align with how humans think, remember, and take action. Data visualization results in a clear message, the right graph type, and sharp design that showcases the story. Too often researchers have great information that few people see. After numerous attempts to create more appealing reports, we recognized our routine efforts fell short and called for change. The panel will discuss real-life applications and strategies to describe data in a meaningful way for a wide audience.These strategies are not software specific and will increase your capacity to use tools you already possess.
column7: Using detailed handouts, participants will be guided through a process to develop data visualizations that kick ass.
column8: Discuss examples that will increase your knowledge around principles of research-based data visualization and to shed archaic data delivery methods.
column9: To have guided conversations with colleagues/clients to identify how data can best be used to tell their story.

column1: Don't Work for Data; Make Data Work for You!
column5: Katrina Craft (Arkansas Department of Education), Caitlin Sharp (Ewing Marion Kauffman School)
column6: Education data systems are proliferating; educators have access to more student information than ever before. But for all the resources devoted to collection and production of data, relatively little has been devoted to helping educators better understand the data and know what to do once they have it. Our session will provide educators with knowledge and strategies for putting data to work in the classroom and the school building. Attendees will leave the session with a clear sense for how to make more effective and efficient use of data as they seek to improve classroom instruction and school operation.
column7: Hear about the challenges and successes in developing a data-driven culture and applying them in the classroom.
column8: See examples of data visualizations that work -- and do not work!
column9: Understand key strategies in developing a data-driven culture in a school or district.

column1: Drive Enrollment By Understanding Student Behavior
column5: Kristin  Coulter (Concordia University), Susan Fenton (UTHealth), Teri Crawford (San Jacinto College), Trisha Fields (Steel Branding)
column6: Competition is stronger than ever and students nowadays are faced with an overwhelming number of choices for college. So how can we still drive enrollment numbers higher? You have to get the attention of students at the right time, with the right message in their decision-making process. How do you know that you are targeting the right students? What's important to your target students? How are you going to best motivate them to consider your College? We have gathered a panel of experts from a Community College, a four-year University and a post-graduate program from University to discuss how they leverage student behavioral data and research in their marketing efforts to drive enrollment.
column7: Gain a better understanding of how to assess your target audience.
column8: Understand how to determine what is important to potential students.
column9: Learn how to best motivate your target student audience to apply and enroll.

column1: From Analytics to Action
column5: Roxanne Russell (Emory University), Mike Sharkey (Blue Canary), Phillip Long (University of Texas, Austin), David Lindrum (Soomo Learning)
column6: In spite of wide-spread interest in learning analytics, many educators are still uncertain about what data are available to them, whether these data are relevant to their specific contexts, and how to put available data to work in the classroom in a way that is aligned with their values as teachers.  This panel brings together thought leaders with experience in business, research, administration, teaching, and instructional design to discuss complexities involved in the use of learning analytics, explore the challenges associated with rethinking student success in the 21st century, and share some of the innovative ways they are using data to improve the lives of students today.
column7: Identify complexities and contemporary challenges facing the use of educational data to inform instructional design decisions
column8: Describe ways in which learning analytics provide an opportunity for instructors to gain a richer understanding of the needs of their students
column9: Share stories about how data has been used to inform instructional design, improve student outcomes, and stimulate thinking about student success

column1: Impact of Personalized Learning on Institutions
column5: Robert Manzer (American InterContinental University), Constance  Johnson (Colorado Technical University), Robert Hasel (Western University of Health Sciences ), Manoj Kulkarni (Realizeit)
column6: Personalized learning platforms produce rich data, deep analytics and insights that can transform institutional effectiveness operations.  Additionally, the right personalized learning platform can become the foundation for developing next generation digital learning environments. The session will explore the potential, detail the challenges and highlight the experience and journey of transformation in select higher-ed institutions.
column7: Understand how institutions can leverage platforms and analytics to improve learning and institutional effectiveness
column8: Identify role of personalized learning platforms in enabling next generation digital learning experiences
column9: Understand the challenges, critical success factors and practices through examples of implementations

column1: Insights from Outside
column5: David Kim (Ace Learning), Fred Singer (Echo360), Lisa Gelobter (United States Department of Education), Charles Thornburgh (Civitas Learning)
column6: Higher education finds itself at a unique tipping point, with a data analytics wave that is sweeping our nation_s higher education institutions.  Data that has been traditionally stored in silos is becoming visible and accessible to institutions, and rapidly advancing technology is translating data into information that institutions and students can use to better shape their learning journeys.
