Leaders that started their careers in other sectors are bringing their knowledge and expertise to unlock this potential for postsecondary institutions and students.  The journey is just beginning_join us for an inside look at what_s coming, including the personalization of higher education at scale.
column7: Understand the way technology and data analytics has transformed other sectors, including media, marketing, and retail.
column8: Determine the potential of these examples to impact the future model of higher education.
column9: Understand what higher education innovations are currently possible with the use of data.

column1: Is Access to Performance Data Good for Students?
column5: Lorena Barba (http://www.mheducation.com/), Ryan Baker (http://www.mheducation.com/), Jan  Plass (http://www.mheducation.com/), Alfred Essa (http://www.mheducation.com/)
column6: Student data and privacy is a sensitive subject in education. But many educators and students are realizing the value in extending performance and classroom data access to students. Moderated by Inside Higher Ed's Paul Fain, this session will explore the benefits of extending access to performance data to students.We know learning analytics can positively impact teaching and learning, but until now, this information has been put only in the hands of educators. New tools provide students with real-time access to their own learning analytics. But is this beneficial? Some say it_s empowering, but others argue it will open Pandora_s box by demotivating students and lowering confidence.
column7: Understand how to balance student privacy and data access, while improving learning outcomes
column8: Model the ideal industry-wide standards around how student data is managed and shared, and how to approach data literacy before extending access
column9: Determine how to present data in ways that respect learners of all levels and keep confidence high

column1: Practical Student Privacy
column5: Bret Cohen (Hogan Lovells), Andrew Bloom (McGraw-Hill Education), Casey Wardynski (Huntsville City Schools)
column6: Over the past few years, much has been debated in policy circles about how we can best protect the privacy of student data.  In the meanwhile, those on the front lines have had to handle daily questions about the safe and appropriate use technology in the classroom.  Join us for a conversation with different members of the student data ecosystem -- including educators, administrators, and EdTech -- about how, practically, they navigate the thicket of federal and state laws, privacy pledges, and parental expectations on an everyday basis.
column7: Learn what policies districts and schools are adopting to make sure that they consider privacy before using new technology in the classroom.
column8: Understand the complexities EdTech vendors face to comply with laws as they deliver services on a nationwide basis.
column9: Participate in an exercise where panelists consider the possible use of technology in the classroom, from the perspective of schools and EdTech.

column1: Putting Big Data into Action
column5: Greg Ratliff (Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation), Mark Milliron (Civitas Learning), Candace Thille (Stanford University), Tim Rennick (Georgia State University)
column6: Big Data is often touted as the next big idea to revolutionize higher education. But universities have had plenty of data for years_so what_s changed now? Are the data geeks and ed tech developers putting too much faith in data? Come learn how universities are pioneering their own way with data, and making surprising discoveries along the way. Hint: technology plays a supporting role.
column7: Articulate the benefits of a well-executed big data project, and the challenges along the way.
column8: Identify complexities and contemporary challenges facing the use of educational data to inform decisions
column9: Share stories and specific examples of how data has been used to inform key decisions, improve student outcomes, and stimulate thinking about stude

column1: Re-engineering the First Year for Student Success
column5: Timothy Renick (Georgia State University ), David Lindrum (Soomo Learning), Bror Saxberg (Kaplan), Laura Malcolm (Civitas Learning)
column6: We lose nearly one-third of all students during their first year of college, changing the trajectory of their lives and the lives of their children. How can we re-engineer the first year, using learning science and design thinking to graduate more students?  Do students need more remediation or less? More choices or fewer? Do faculty need to teach better or coach more?  Can we maintain academic rigor while helping struggling students? How can we elicit more student effort without triggering more dropouts? And how can we know which efforts are working? Panelists will lead a discussion of our findings.
column7: List the underlying causes of dropping out for college students.
column8: Analyze the high impact practices for increasing student success and the dilemmas inherent in each.
column9: Evaluate methods for testing and validating new practices in a local context.

column1: Show Me the Money! Education Spending 2.0
column5: Victor De La Paz (New Haven Public Schools), Arun Ramanathan (Pivot Learning), Noah Wepman (Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation), Jess Gartner (Allovue)
column6: There are plenty of great ideas and exciting new technology tools and approaches to education, such as blended learning. But unless it_s funded, it doesn_t really exist. As budgets shrink, districts are being much more careful about spending decisions. Is spending aligned with achievement? How can they stretch every dollar for student success? Who should be making decisions about budgets? Why does this matter to you? In this panel, you_ll learn how school district, non-profit, technology and foundation leaders are working together to help districts answer these questions.
column7: Identify top education finance challenges that K-12 districts face today.
column8: Outline the roadmap for successfully aligning spending to achievement
column9: Understand the components required for successfully implementing public finance transparency

column1: Something to Talk About
column5: Juan Cabrera (El Paso ISD), Julie Linn (Texans for Education Reform), Kim Alexander (Roscoe Collegiate Independent School District), Scott Woolstenhulme (Bonneville Joint School District)
column6: Student Data, often discussed and more often misunderstood. It's today_s #edchat hot button issue. We are talking about it. By the end of our session, our audience will understand the high value that great student data brings to the education table. We will illuminate how #eddata is used in the real world of public schools to meet a child where they are and accelerate learning. We will talk about how student data supports teachers, parents, and communities. Our panelists are superintendents, representing school districts from suburban, urban and rural areas of the country. They deal with unique demographics and distinctive challenges in supporting students across the learning continuum.
column7: How identifying and using student data supports and drives unique district initiatives, including the elimination of high-stakes testing
column8: The correct, consolidated data allows educators and learners to make informed decisions that drive individualized student goals
column9: Engage parents in the education process with clear information and understanding of their student's performance

column1: Standing in the STEM Gap
column5: Deborah Kerr (Sabre)
column6: The future belongs to the students we teach to speak geek.  Those who  analyze data, create new technologies and modernize existing ones.  These are the students who will succeed in this _on demand_ culture.  Deborah Kerr should know.  Kerr is Chief Product and Technology officer at Sabre©.  Sabre© technology powers one of the world_s largest industries _ travel. Systems work 24 hours a day, every day, processing more than 60,000 transactions a second at peak.  Sabre transformed & modernized the travel industry, with a history of _firsts_.  Hired by NASA Kerr became a rocket scientist at just 15 years old & believes consistent hands on STEM learning is the best path for under-represented.
column7: How Data & Analytic work is transforming the "on demand" culture
column8: Why corporate experts should stand in the gap and bring more under-represented students into the industry.
column9: The advantages of leveraging technology in education.

column1: Student Data Privacy: It Takes a Village
column5: Tony Porterfield (Edtechinfosec.org  ), L. Beatriz Arnillas (Houston Independent School District), Jennifer Medbery (Kickboard), Bill Fitzgerald (Common Sense Media)
column6: Online privacy has been a hotly contested and - at times - a highly emotional issue in the past few years. Recently, we have seen significant progress and a growth of awareness around student data privacy. This panel brings together student privacy advocates from district, parent, nonprofit, and vendor contexts to discuss the progression of their work on protecting student privacy, focusing on the importance of community effort and dialogue. Panelists will explore how districts and school communities can have meaningful dialogue and communication with key stakeholders to negotiate data stewardship.
column7: Participants will identify ways to foster meaningful and authentic dialogue among key stakeholders in student privacy matters.
column8: Participants will understand recent advancements in student data privacy that have been made by schools, districts, nonprofits, and developers.
column9: Participants will discuss how to address student privacy within educational innovation and systemic improvements in learner engagement and outcomes.

column1: The Accidental Consequences of Data Privacy Laws
column5: Donna Johnson (Delaware Department of Education), Dean Folkers (Nebraska Department of Education), Elana Zeide (New York University's Information Law Institute), Amelia Vance (National Association of State Boards of Education)
column6: Since 2013, more than 30 states have passed new student data privacy laws. While many of these laws are good, several have had accidental consequences: preventing students from applying for scholarships, stopping vital education research, and even keeping kindergarten and first grade teachers from talking to each other. This panel will present an overview of new state laws and policies, discuss some of the accidental consequences that have occurred, and teach the audience how they can ensure their state either avoids those consequences - or how they can fix them.
column7: Audience members will understand the trends in student data privacy laws and policies over the past 3 years.
column8: Audience members will understand the accidental consequences that can easily occur when creating a local or state data privacy law or policy.
column9: Audience members will come away with tools to avoid and to fix accidental consequences when creating and/or implementing local or state law or policy.

column1: The Measure of a MOOC: Metrics for Success
column5: Katie Richardson (Google), Lizzie Pace (Google), Chris Jennings (Google)
column6: In a large online course, it can be difficult to understand success beyond simple registration or completion numbers. This session will discuss what course metrics can easily be derived using Google Analytics. It will discuss methodologies for designing surveys that segment user data by various characteristics such as intent, experience level, or other custom parameters. It will guide participants on tracking the best engagement metrics, how to track custom events like videos or interactive demos, and monitoring course progress and feedback. It will also look at demographic data to guide strategies such as course marketing, translation, and technology platform decisions.
column7: What metrics and tracking you should use to measure online course engagement.
column8: How to design surveys to segment student analytics data.
column9: Understand demographic data in order to make course platform, translation, and marketing decisions.

column1: Using Real-Time, Big Data to Solve Social Problems
column5: Rayid Ghani (University of Chicago), Erin Brackney Kremkus (One Star Foundation), Sacha Litman (Fund for Big Data in Philanthropy and Measuring Success), Elizabeth Darling (One Star Foundation)
column6: The ability to link otherwise disconnected islands of data helps Netflix to offer personalized movie choices. It helps Amazon to recommend books for customers to buy. It can also help educational organizations to develop carefully designed solutions for under served populations. . By incorporating big data platforms, collective impact initiatives can achieve real, measurable impact. Our panelists have each built and operated first generation platforms. We will address key issues: collaboration between organizations toward data sharing agreements, linking data silos, real-time versus retrospective outcome evaluation, the true costs/time to develop/maintain the systems & how to pay for it
column7: Learn the benefits and challenges to expect as technology and data advances make these platforms easier to build and deploy
column8: Applicable techniques for how to internally sell, start and sustain big data initiatives through lessons learned (financial, legal, collaboration)
column9: Understand how collective impact (ecosystem wide efforts to support kids) can reach their full potential through real time, big data platforms

column1: What Do We Mean When We Ask if EdTech "Works_?
column5: Steven Hodas (Digital Promise), Betsy Corcoran (EdSurge), Chris Liang-Vergara (LEAP Innovations ), Kristen Swanson (BrightBytes)
column6: Everyone agrees: Let_s use tools that _work_ in our K-12 school. But then the complexity of the task sinks in:  What do we mean by _work_? What measures should we_or even could we_use? This is hardly a theoretical exercise. The people on this panel are involved in constructing _pilot programs_ and measuring _results_ for edtech implementations in schools throughout the US. This conversation will thoughtfully consider some tough questions. Among them: What do we really know about how to measure the effectiveness of edtech tools? What are the "results" that we_re trying to measure? How are the current pilots proceeding? What seems to be making a difference for a spectrum of learners?
column7: What are we trying to measure when we ask "What works?" in schools?
column8: What is the status of pilots going on to measure edtech effectiveness?
column9: Are we conducting these trials in an equity way, including all learners?

column1: What Higher Ed Can Learn from Uber and Airbnb
column5: Caroline Howard (Forbes), Jim  John (Beyond.com), Adam Markowitz (Portfolium), Ryan  Craig (University Ventures)
column6: Online learning, MOOCs, software-as-service_they_ve all promised to disrupt the university as we know it, yet after millions spent, have all fallen short. At the same time, other entrenched sectors, are quickly being re-imagined. Uber owns no vehicles and Airbnb isn_t in the business of putting sheets on hotel beds, yet the two have disrupted their industries. So what can higher ed learn from these models? Come find out why the magic isn_t a faster taxi or a cooler hotel room, but rather a collaborative marketplace that matches the haves of providers [think universities] with the needs of the customers [think labor markets].
column7: Hear from group of entrepreneurs and investors weigh in on the disconnect between higher education and the needs of the labor market.
column8: Gain a clear understanding of how human capital data and the evolution of collaborative marketplaces will potentially impact higher ed.
column9: Learn how higher ed institutions can and should respond to the impact of these changes, without losing the role of the university.

column1: What Social Media Says About Your School_s Climate
column5: Steven Healy (Margolis Healy), David Perry (Florida State University Police Department), John Woodmansee (Department of Education _ Connecticut Technical High School System), Chris  Danforth (The University of Vermont)
column6: What can social media tell us about our school communities? How can we harness social media to better protect schools and college campuses? During this session, moderated by Steven J. Healy, panelists will detail how the University of Vermont_s Hedonometer project is extracting real-time narratives on world events and what lessons educators can extrapolate about their community_s climate from social media data. Representatives from Florida State University and the Connecticut Technical High School System will also address the lessons they have learned by deploying a social media threat alert service into their day-to-day safety and security operations.
column7: Discover what you can learn about your school community_s climate by taking a close look at relevant social media activity.
column8: Learn how to harness social media to better protect school and college campuses from potential safety and security threats.
column9: Determine if deploying a social media threat alert service is right for your district or college.

column1: Why Closed Data Protocols Jeopardize Your Students
column5: Barbara Nesbitt (Pickens School District), Maurice Draggon (Orange County Public Schoolrs), Stanley Watts (ClassLink), Berj Akian (ClassLink)
column6: How do you protect your students_ personal data?  Parents are becoming increasingly concerned about their children_s information being transmitted to third parties, and are demanding that safeguards be in place.  The federal FERPA laws as well as even more stringent local requirements make these issues more pressing yet. Come see how the new OneRoster standard allows a school district to maintain granular control of their student data, determining how much data is released, and to whom.
column7: Learn about the privacy issues surrounding third party use of student data.
column8: Hear opinions from educators currently facing these challenges.
column9: Learn how the OneRoster standard lets districts specify what data is shared, and to whom.

column1: Beyond apps: early literacy gaming at its best
column5: Todd McMullin (Waterford Institute), Kimberley Sorensen (Waterford Institute), Mikkel Storm (Waterford Institute)
column6: Take a behind-the-scenes tour of the creative assembly line behind award-winning digital curriculum. From research to pedagogy to animation, our team will take attendees through curriculum development and technology to produce incredible learning outcomes for early learners. The process will highlight instructional design considerations when addressing the needs of every child, as well as an overview of today_s cutting-edge animation techniques.
column7: Identify the main educational gaps technology satisfies based on current case studies.
column8: Identify best practices in evaluating and implementing technology solutions.
column9: Get hands-on experience with award-winning technology that is proven successful in closing education gaps.

column1: Books to Pixels: Storytelling for Kids Today
column5: Joey Egger (Two Moos), James Kane (Two Moos), Tali Gal-On (Two Moos), Kylie Robertson (Penguin Random House Australia)
column6: Penguin Random House Australia and Two Moos partnered to develop "Toodle Moos", a digital-first storyworld for kids about a set of tiny loveable creatures who make their homes in the hidden corners, cupboards, nooks and crannies of your home. This panel includes the project teams from Penguin Random House Australia and Two Moos and will take the audience through how we developed the storyworld with a strategic focus on building for at audience who is 'digital-first' content. We_ll discuss the challenges, successes and outcomes for this cross platform format and how we see the digital first publishing format as a powerful way to develop a a cross platform IP and build a dediated audience.
column7: Developing a brand new children's educational IP that is multi-platform but created as "digital-first" content
column8: Embedding educational themes seamelessly across plaforms.
column9: Digital-First content and educational strategies

column1: Bridging the Literacy Gap: Tech in the Classroom
column5: Nader Qaimari (Follett Learning), Neal Shenoy (Speakaboos)
column6: Prior to entering the first grade, reading proficiency levels vary significantly from student to student. Technology can be a tremendous equalizer during the formative years of literacy to help students reach necessary milestones. However, access to digital devices and digital learning platforms often remains a challenge with resources continuing to be difficult to secure. With so many EdTech options available to educators, choosing the right tech for their classroom_s needs is magnified when resources are limited. How can educators determine which are not only the best, but the right choices for their students and what role can that technology play in developing literacy skills?
column7: What are the latest developments in EdTech for Early Childhood literacy?
column8: How can educators choose the right EdTech for their students to maximize resources?
column9: What role can technology play in supporting literacy and learning?

column1: Creating the World_s First Early Childhood Fab Lab
column5: Janice Morrison (Teaching Institute for Excellence in STEM), Paul Reynolds (FableVision), Elizabeth Rood (Bay Area Discovery Museum & Center for Childhood Creativity)
column6: Fab Labs are maker spaces that use digital design and fabrication (e.g. laser cutters and 3D printers) to build STEM skills and creativity. In winter 2016, The Bay Area Discovery Museum, in partnership with TIES and FableVision, launches the world_s first Fab Lab for young learners (ages 3-10) to help them navigate the design process from concept to production, and turn their ideas into reality. This session addresses the design principles of these spaces, lessons learned from this first prototype, and curricula suggestions aligned to NGSS and CCSS. Panelists will reflect on their experience in bringing such edtech maker spaces to our youngest learners in developmentally appropriate ways.
column7: Understand the power and possibility of using technology with very young children in developmentally appropriate ways.
column8: Learn from the nation_s first ECE Fab Lab prototype to consider how you can bring design and fabrication into your school, program, or classroom.
column9: Understand how math, computer science, and engineering practices can be meaningfully taught in Fab Labs with very young children.

column1: Extreme Learners and Transforming Education
column5: Marina  Gorbis (Institute for the Future), Milton Chen (George Lucas Educational Foundation), Marc Roth (The Learning Shelter), Nikhil  Goyal (N/A)
column6: Extreme learners are trailblazers of the new learning landscape. For them, it_s not about an exam score or degree_the process is the product. Extreme learners are powered by technology. They design their own curricula from online courses, get their hands dirty at community laboratories and hacker spaces, and seek out mentors. They help others learn, participating in an active learning exchange. They are teachers as much as they are learners.  Extreme learners harness a fast-expanding world of knowledge that is increasingly at their fingertips. They know that learning now can be done anywhere at anytime. They have learned how to learn.
column7: How can we best engage and empower young people in the learning process?
column8: How can we foster and nurture self-directed learners in the 21st century?
column9: What does the future of learning look like?

column1: From Research to Recess-Early Learning in Practice
column5: Kathleen Plocinik (Head Start, St. Jerome's), Kelly Fisher (Johns Hopkins Univeristy), Susan Magsamen (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt), David Dockterman (Harvard School of Education)
column6: A surge of multi-disciplinary research, from neuroscience to psychology to cognitive science, has demonstrated the increasingly vital importance of early education for healthy development and long-term success. But how do we translate research into practice across the myriad settings in which young children learn _ from the classroom to daycare to the home? How can evidence-based research help bridge the gap between formal and informal learning environments? What role should technology play? How do we ensure that all children have access to quality educational experiences? In this panel, experts in the science of early learning, practice and advocacy come together to discuss.
column7: Give a summary of recent research, from the role of neuroscience to technology and play; identify key challenges in translating research to practice.
column8: Explore how to bridge formal and informal learning spaces. Education takes a village: family, teachers, community.  How do we create equity for all?
column9: Examine the role that tech and media play in learning; identify how teachers and parents can collaborate to foster healthy learning on and offline.

column1: Inspiring Little Learners to Become Big Thinkers
column5: Craig Bach (Goddard Systems, Inc. ), Jean McKenzie (Fisher-Price), Helen Hadani (Center for Childhood Creativity), Jennifer Jipson (Cal Poly- San Luis Obispo)
column6: It_s no secret that the world is rapidly changing, and so are the skills needed to succeed. These 21st Century skills can be taught to young children _ even preschoolers _ yet the education method and mindset needs to evolve as much as the tools. Gone are the days of only ABC_s and 123_s. Hands-on discovery and experience are the keys to future success. How can we keep the spark for learning alive beyond preschool? A panel of education and early childhood development experts will share their perspective from research and practice on innovative and playful ways to inspire 21st Century learning, discussing how to build on children_s innate curiosity and critical thinking.
column7: Research and thinking on seeding 21st century skill-building with preschoolers, focused on creativity, learning approaches, and executive functions.
column8: Best practices in fostering these skills through play with young children in both formal and informal learning environments.
column9: An understanding of what physical and social environments can best stimulate the development of these 21st century skills.

column1: Invisible Assessment: What K-12 Can Learn from ECE
column5: Kai-le  Berke (Teaching Strategies), Vincent Constanza (New Jersey Department of Education), Lillian Mongeau (The Hechinger Report), Bev Perdue (DigiLearn)
column6: If you ask most teachers and parents about assessment, you_re going to get an earful of the negative aspects _ student stress, tests taking away from instructional time, etc. The purpose of assessments, however, is to provide insight on student performance _ it doesn_t require a kid filling out bubble sheets. But what if assessment was nearly invisible? Teachers in early childhood are already doing real-time, ongoing formative assessments focused on child development along a learning progression. This type of _whole child_ assessment powered by technology, centers on project-based, hands-on teaching and learning. Learn how invisible assessment enables teachers gain valuable insights.
column7: Learn how technology can support K-12 and early childhood assessment through real-time, project-based teaching and learning.
column8: Think about assessment in a different way, including the concept of 'invisible assessment', and how it empowers teachers to get real-time data.
column9: Learn about the role of policymakers and administrators to help scale innovative and effective practices across states and districts.

column1: Pay for Success: Next Big Bet in Early Learning?
column5: Katie Hamm (Center for American Progress), Bryan Bouroughs (Institute for Child Success), Chris Ellis (United Way of Salt Lake), Nicole Truhe (America Forward)
column6: Governments have invested in early learning for decades hoping to bridge the gap for at-risk kids and to make sure they start school on track. These investments have produced mixed results because not all early learning programs are created equal. Some work well, some partially work, and others don_t work at all. Yet government agencies continue to pay up front, based on their best predictions, regardless of a program's actual results.  Until now. Pay for Success is an innovative approach to driving government funding toward high-quality, effective programs that measurably improve lives and communities. Learn more about Pay for Success and how it can be applied in the early learning space.
column7: Understand the core elements of a Pay for Success project and get up-to-date details about a current Pay for Success early learning project.
column8: Hear how early learning programs have been funded/supported in the past and how Pay for Success is different.
column9: Brainstorm ways to use Pay for Success in early learning programs and consider the potential use of Pay for Success projects.

column1: Programming to Learn in Elementary Grades
column5: Axel  Reitzig (Innovation Center of the St. Vrain Valley School District), Leticia  Batista (Mckinna Elementary ), Sam Patterson (Gideon Hausner Jewish Day School)
column6: Three leading innovators in the field of programming as a medium for learning discuss how they use programming to amplify learning of core content as well as social skills and conflict resolution.  These teachers share how they have hacked platforms to craft digital learning experiences for students in grades K-5.  The platforms include robots, tablet computers, chromebooks and offline programming activities.  This is what learning looks like beyond the Hour of Code
column7: Participants will learn how to build a core content focused, code-based lesson using a variety of tools from robots to dance.
column8: Participants will learn about new and forthcoming programming and teaching tools.
column9: Participants will learn how even leveled programming apps can support foundational literacy and math skills, as proven by research.

column1: The Two-Gen Approach to Early Education
column5: Karen Yu (Sewanee: The University of the South), Emily Partin (Grundy County Schools), Linda Mayes (Yale Child Study Center), Karen Baicker (Scholastic)
column6: A collaborative in rural Tennessee, including the Yale Child Study Center, Sewanee University, Scholastic, and local Grundy County partners,  is addressing literacy and building resilience in the community through a multi-generational approach. Families of young children (birth to five) participate in a Family Coop with a master teacher using a customized curriculum that focuses on pride in place, storytelling, and exploring the local community. Literacy is modeled by a master teacher and caregivers have the opportunity to build social connections with each other  as they engage in the multigenerational curriculum.
column7: Learn about an innovative approach to building resilience in areas of isolation and poverty.
column8: Using a strength-based approach, the power of story, and place-based pedagogy, target the needs of children and their caregivers simultaneously.
column9: Explore the ways that a collaborative initiative grew organically by responding to the evolving needs of the community.

column1: Unlocking the Potential of PreK Parents
column5: Judy McCormick (P16Plus), Mica Clark-Peterek (Department of Human Services, Head Start Division), Lisa Delgado (Northside ISD), Kevin Roden (Pascal Learning)
column6: While most of the focus in the national push for PreK has been on providing platforms for formal early childhood learning, some communities are beginning to understand the power of reaching and equipping parents as part of their overall PreK strategies. San Antonio_s early childhood initiatives have emerged as a national leader in this space. This session will help you learn from the cutting edge practices being incubated in San Antonio to deepen and scale parent engagement.
column7: Hear an overview of innovative parent engagement strategies from across the country.
column8: Learn from a community who has tried many of these strategies.
column9: Learn how to duplicate these efforts in your own community.

column1: When Neuroscience Meets Education Policy
column5: Janice Gruendel (Yale University ), Samantha Aigner-Treworgy (The Ounce of Prevention), Kelly Etter (The Policy Equity Group), Faraz Farzin (Lumosity)
column6: The latest cognitive science and early childhood development research offers a unique opportunity to inform education policy. The executive function skills, critical for academic and social success, blossom during the early childhood years. Adverse early experiences can disrupt brain architecture and impair the development of these important skills. The panel will provide an overview of current research, focusing on the critical skills built in the first eight years of life that lay the foundation for later learning. Experts will offer examples of ways we can integrate developmental science into education policy, offering strategies to improve systems based on what we know about learning.
column7: Participants will gain a solid understanding of the evolving scientific research on executive function development.
column8: Participants will be provided examples of how developmental  science can be used to drive policy decisions.
column9: Participants will be given principles and strategies to translate knowledge of early childhood development into decision-making in their own context

column1: 1:1 Access and Personalized Learning
column5: Beth Duncan (Vista Unified School District, Rancho Minerva Middle School), Anna Lozano (Vista Unified School District, Rancho Minerva Middle School), Benjamin Gaines (Vista Unified School District, Rancho Minerva Middle School), Lisa Harrison (Vista Unified School District, Rancho Minerva Middle School)
column6: Being a 1:1 Digital Promise, Verizon Innovative Learning School led us to create courses incorporating ideas from Summit Public Schools and Project Based Learning as well as concepts of self directed learning that we have created ourselves allow our students to become more self directed and our teachers to take on the role of mentors and facilitators, providing 1:1 academic goal setting and emotional support to students as individuals. We are entering an age where it is possible ensure that every child walks away from their public school experience with an education customized just for them, and are excited to share these idea with other educators and administrators.
column7: Administrators and school leaders will walk away with concrete strategies for being leaders of change and transformation in their school.
column8: To incorporate personalized learning, project based learning, and competency based cognitive skills curriculum in a 1:1 public school.
column9: Create a system for academic goal setting and social and emotional mentoring to ensure continued student success in higher education and beyond.

column1: A Backpack, a GPS, and a Sherpa for Learning
column5: Ed Davies (DC Trust), Michael Robbins (Span Learning), Leslie Beller (MHA Labs)
column6: Supporting anytime-anywhere learning for ALL students requires a new frame for collaboration among schools, families, and community partners. Join a trio of skilled practitioners to explore how to equip young people with three tools for navigating learning in a digital world:+ A BACKPACK to own their learning data, carry it with them, and securely share it across school and community environments.+ A GPS to help figure out where they are on their learning path, where they want to go, and ways to get there.+ A SHERPA to guide them as they chart their course toward learning success and help them navigate challenges across school, home, community, and online environments.
column7: Learn how a new approach to learning data can help learners take charge of their learning.
column8: Learn how technology and collaboration can provide better "maps" for learning.
column9: Learn how existing learner support roles need to evolve to guide learning across school, home, community, and online environments

column1: A Community-Based Approach to Digital Equity in th
column5: Paul  Resta (University of Texas at Austin), Maria Vasquez (ACT), Robert McLaughlin (Education Development Center)
column6: Achieving digital equity involves more than access to low cost devices and connectivity. Rather, it requires a systemic and community-based approach involving a number of dimensions and partners.  We'll explore an approach, led by the Education Development Center and the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, in which educational and community leaders in the Rio Grande Valley are provided assistance by a consortium of educational and library organizations, communication carriers, technology companies, and educational resource providers to close the digital divide at home and in the community for low-income learners of all ages and their families, to foster educational and economic opportunity.
column7: Learn ways communities can provide equitable access to affordable broadband, devices, multilingual tech support, OER and other key resources.
column8: Help design a network of communities sharing best practices and resources for closing the divide for their lowest income learners and families.
column9: Learn strategies to engage banks in planning and implementing local digital equity investments.

column1: Achievement Unlocked: Recognize Informal Learning
column5: Amalia  Tonsor (Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh), Corey  Wittig (The Labs at Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh), Toby Greenwalt (Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh)
column6: Opportunities for learning exist in many places outside the classroom. How do you make this process visible to learners, employers and traditional education purveyors?This session includes an in depth exploration of The Labs @ Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh. We_ll share our framework for badges and badge rubrics, all of which are adaptable by other organizations.  We_ll also discuss the importance of community partnerships when developing badges and our participation in City of Learning.Session attendees will develop tools for growing the informal learning network in their community, and find ways to use learning badges to communicate their organization_s value to external stakeholders.
column7: How to document non-traditional learning experiences in a meaningful way
column8: How to design badges that speak to community learning goals
column9: Why it is important to create a badging system that can be used and recognized by multiple organizations in your community

column1: Activating Student Voices
column5: Piotr Bobkowski (University of Kansas), Nabiha Syed (Buzzfeed), Frank LoMonte (Student Press Law Center)
column6: Schools and colleges talk a good game on civic engagement, but when students actually engage to make change on their campuses, they're often met with threats and reprisals. Teen girls disproportionately absorb the brunt of this abuse, because they are disproportionately likely to engage on sensitive social issues that make schools nervous. "Active Voice" is a newly created campaign to unlock the power of student input into school decisionmaking by building a virtual mentorship community to help young women develop their full leadership potential. This panel will review new research about the adversity girls face, and propose solutions to make the school experience more empowering.
column7: Best governance practices for involving students in school policy decisions
column8: New developments in the law governing students' free-speech rights
column9: Strategies for empowering young women to be effective civic participants

column1: Advocacy & Data: Identifying & Activating Parents
column5: David Bresnahan-McRae (Social Driver), Justin Beland (Social Driver), Jack Fleming (The Education Trust)
column6: Set the scene: It has been 14 years since Congress passed the No Child Left Behind Act, and was seven years past due to reauthorize the law with updates from lessons learned.Educators, advocates, and policy makers all agree the law needs to be updated (though there is disagreement about how).Enter The Education Trust and Social Driver with a digital grassroots campaign to build support among low-income families and families of color to ensure that Congress holds true to the civil rights mission of the law and ensures #AllKidsMatter.See how we used data analytics through Facebook, Twitter, and Change.org to identify and activate over 1,000 parent advocates in target states.
column7: Learn how Ed Trust & Social Driver used data analytics (Google, Twitter, Facebook) to identify and target low-income parents and parents of color
column8: Learn how to use cookie tracking to develop custom retargeting for Twitter, Facebook, and Google ads to reinforce messaging
column9: See examples of turnkey Web tools developed to streamline action into as few steps as possible

column1: Bridging the College and Career Prep Divide
column5: Jennifer Mandel (Lockheed Martin), Richard  Montgomery (Star City Schools), Anne Jones (Project Lead The Way), Edward  Biedermann (The College Board)
column6: College readiness and career preparation are often two very different tracks that funnel students towards one path or another. Why should students have to choose? The end game of every academic program should be a rewarding career. And, with almost two-thirds of all jobs, and 92 percent of traditional STEM jobs, requiring some post-secondary education and training, educators must bridge the gap between college prep and skilled career preparation. Doing so requires a shift in school culture and participation at the district, community and industry level. In this session, speakers and attendees will discuss strategies that work to bring college and career preparation together-for all students.
column7: Best practices for combining rigorous post-secondary preparation with hands-on, applied learning
column8: Real strategies to change school culture
column9: Messages and signals communities and industry can send to make a difference

column1: Building Free and Open Education Communities
column5: joey lopez (University of the Incarnate Word), Mariah Villarreal (Putnam Museum and Science Center), Nicole Allen (SPARC), Walter Bender (Sugar Labs )
column6: Free and open education resources encourage critical interaction, innovation and collaboration on the part of the educator and learner by nature. Adopting and sustaining a free and open education system requires high level support and grassroot efforts. As educators, organizers and developers within the education ecosystem, we will share our experiences with free software, hardware and textbooks in informal and formal education networks. These resources change the dynamic between learners, educators and communities at large while bringing opportunities for cost savings.
column7: How to practically implement freely licensed materials in learning environments
column8: How to gain administrative support for freely licensed resources
column9: How to create easily accessible and consumable freely licensed resources

column1: College Prep 2.0
column5: Lisa Boarman (Howard County Public Schools), Joan Pack-Rowe (Cincinnati Public Schools), Chelette Stephenson (Yes Prep North Central), Kim Oppelt (Hobsons)
column6: Schools everywhere are under increasing pressure to graduate students prepared for success in college and beyond. But the sky isn_t falling! Educators are reinventing the way we prepare and motivate students for the future. In Cincinnati, the district has developed a playbook that provides students with PLPs. At Yes Prep North Central, the focus on college is deep in knowledge and celebration. And in Howard County MD, counselors are helping homeless students identify their strengths and turn them into careers and college majors. Come hear how creative educators are using technology and cutting-edge advising strategies to inspire our next generation.
column7: Participants will understand the pressure schools face to prepare students to be successful in college and career.
column8: Participants will how schools across the country are finding innovative methods to address career and college readiness.
column9: Participants will ask questions necessary in order to develop their own plan for success.

column1: Connecting Childhood Dreams and the Real World
column5: Stephen  Smith (Hobsons), Joy  Resmovits (LA Times), Yasmine  Arrington (ScholarCHIPS), Mike  Marriner (Roadtrip Nation)
column6: _What do you want to be when you grow up?_ Do you remember your answer? Are you doing what you_d hoped? This age-old question, in our opinion, isn_t taken seriously enough. Kids dream big_scientist, teacher, paramedic, author, game developer_and yet our education system doesn_t do enough to support those dreams. How can we bridge the gap between supporting wide-eyed passion and preparing learners in practical ways? It_s time to move past the either/or approach. Adults play an important role in ensuring students are equipped to chase a dream no matter how big. Come learn how we can help kids cultivate passions earlier, connect them to school, and build a roadmap to get there.
column7: Learn how a strengths-based approach to college prep can engage students earlier in their schooling, to help contextual their learning.
column8: Learn about the role of information--about careers, financial aid, college majors--in motivating students to pursue college and careers.
column9: Discover what strategies parents, teachers & counselors can use to help students connect their academic studies to their future goals.

column1: Connecting Classrooms with Industry Professionals
column5: Victor Villavicencio (LBJ High School), Angela  Matthews (Manor ISD), Melanie Flowers ( Samsung Austin Semiconductors), Sabari Raja (Nepris, Inc)
column6: Education policy changes like HB 5 in Texas are driving adoption of multiple career endorsements, project-based learning and state budgets are enabling STEM career pathways encouraging districts to find new ways to connect classrooms and industry. Teachers require tools that demonstrate the real-world application of course content to increase student engagement and provide workplace exposure. Join a diverse panel of industry leaders, school district administrators and educators to discuss the impact of authentic learning through real world relevance.
column7: Provide a foundation on the issues facingÿindustry andÿeducation in filling the STEM pipeline.
column8: Present perspectives from a classroom teacher, an industryÿprofessional, a district administratorÿand the owner of a company working toward solutions.
column9: Explore the barriers and possible solutions in how to make more effective connections betweenÿeducators and industry.

column1: Cradle to Career: Positioning Kids to Succeed
column5: Stephanie Doyle (Boston Defending Childhood Initiative), Rebekah Richards (Graduation Alliance), Christopher Yanov (Reality Changers), Reginald Javier (Public Consulting Group)
column6: Want to learn proven strategies that will position the children of your city to gain the physical, emotional, and cognitive preparedness to succeed? The six milestones of My Brother_s Keeper (MBK) are designed to ensure youth success throughout the nation. Through this Summit, you will engage in meaningful dialogue and share best practices that helps school districts, agencies, and community stakeholders advance the six goals of MBK. By facilitating knowledge sharing and hearing from experts, we will create a unique exchange on cradle-to-career best practices and walk away with action steps that advance the likelihood of success and opportunity for youth locally and nationally.
column7: Learn proven strategies that will position the children of your city to gain the physical, emotional, and cognitive preparedness to succeed.
column8: Facilitate meaningful dialogue and share best practices that help school districts and community stakeholders advance the six goals of MBK.
column9: Gain exposure to national best practices that are transforming educational and professional opportunities for youth in cities across the U.S.

column1: Crafting a Teacher Appraisal System
column5: Ryan  O'Donnell (Austin ISD, Educator Quality), Joann Taylor (Austin ISD, Educator Quality ), Trish Jarrott (Austin ISD, Educator Quality)
column6: Austin ISD has created a new teacher appraisal system committed to promoting professional growth for all teachers, encourage frequent and formative feedback, and to incorporate multiple indicators of success, including measures of student growth.  In this session, the panel will address the development of the Professional Pathways for Teachers Appraisal (PPfT); the components of the system- Instructional Practice, Student Growth, and Professional Growth and Responsibilities; the lessons learned from origination to present; and the support resources provided to teachers and administrators to impact student achievement.
column7: Participants will learn about the development of a new appraisal system that addresses all state and ESEA waiver requirements.
column8: Participants will explore each component of the PPFT appraisal system, and the adjustments the district has made since its implementation.
column9: Participants will review and explore the support resources for teachers and administrators in the PPfT system.

column1: Creating Community for Homebound Students
column5: Kevin Honeycutt (ESSDACK), John Matt (University of Montana), Cody Heitschmidt (Double Robotics)
column6: Medically homebound students don_t share the same experience as their fellow classmates of going to school in-person every day. They miss out on collaborating with other students on group projects, raising their hand to ask a question, and playing outside during recess - all important interactions that create a positive learning environment for students. Using Double, the telepresence robot, homebound students get the full classroom community experience. Join Double Robotics_ Cody Heitschmidt, University of Montana Department Chair John Matt, and K-12 educator Kevin Honeycutt as they discuss how telepresence technology is changing the way homebound students attend school.
column7: Homebound students learn and practice social skills
column8: Students learn sensitivity to homebound students
column9: Homebound students don_t fall behind in class

column1: Creating Thriving Community Schools
column5: Paul Cruz (Austin Independent School District), Ken Zarifis (Education Austin), Allen Weeks (Austin Voices for Education and Youth)
column6: Community Schools is a strategy to turn around struggling schools in our most challenged neighborhoods. It combines community partnerships, shared leadership, external supports and services and high-quality academic programs, and supports children where they are, no matter their needs. In Austin, several schools have made national news using this approach, and the idea is spreading in Texas. Nationally, over 5,000 schools are community schools. Find out why this works and how you can bring this to your community.
column7: Understand how community partnerships can support struggling schools.
column8: Understand how coordinated services can support students and families.
column9: Understand how the government, business and tech communities can be agents of transformation in our most challenging schools.

column1: Digital Diversity: Minorities Excelling in Tech
column5: Cori Coburn-Shiflett (GeorgeTown ISD), Shaina Glass (Aldine Independent School District), Abran Maldonado (NuSkool), Shelly Sanchez Terrell (30 Goals Challenge for Educators)
column6: Research shows minorities are underrepresented in the field of technology. Females and minorities who do make it soon leave the field. Through teacher leadership, knowledge, access, and training we can support more minorities to enrich the field. Inclusion and diversity leads to a broader perspective in solving problems with technology. This session is an open and honest discussion with four minority leaders in different educational technology leadership positions who share their movements, resources, and pose honest questions to the audience for a discussion of possible solutions. Collectively, we will share resources through the live session and backchannel.
column7: To promote the recruitment and retainment of minorities in the various fields of technology, especially in leadership positions.
column8: To share experiences and challenges to minorities in STEM and collaborate on possible solutions.
column9: To enlighten educators on how to utilize educational technology to celebrate cultural diversity and help minority students pursue STEM careers.

column1: #Digiverse: Minority Women in EdTech
column5: Shelly Sanchez Terrell (The 30 Goals Challenge for Teachers), Shaina Glass (Aldine Independent School District), Cori Coburn-Shiflett (Georgetown ISD), Sarah Thomas (Prince Georges County Public Schools)
column6: How can minority women overcome the unique challenges to become successful in edtech?  This session is an open and honest discussion with four minority women in different educational technology leadership positions, sharing their journeys and personal missions of empowerment for improving education for all.
column7: To promote the recruitment & retainment of women and minorities in the various fields of educational technology, especially in leadership positions.
column8: To share experiences and challenges to minority women in STEM & educational technology careers, and collaborate on possible solutions.
column9: To enlighten educators on how to utilize educational technology to celebrate cultural diversity & gender equality.

column1: Diversity is not a self-fulfilling prophecy
column5: Molly Brennan (Koya Leadership Partners), Julayne Virgil (Education Pioneers), Samantha Simmons (http://www.koyapartners.com), Pamela Inbasekaran (Relay Graduate School of Education)
column6: Despite increasing acceptance of the importance of diversity, there is a lack of dialogue and practical guidance about how to actually implement and sustain best practices that instill and advance organizational diversity. This session will enable a discussion that goes beyond theoretical talk about why diversity is important to provide specific, actionable steps organizations can take to build diverse, inclusive, and successful teams and environments. The session will cover everything from how to articulate diversity as an organizational value and vision to recruiting and training strategies, to building an environment that attracts diverse team members into the future.
column7: Provide tools and ideas for articulating diversity value that works for your organization and assessing organizational progress to date
column8: To promote best practices on how to weave diversity into hiring, training, and coaching practices
column9: To highlight that diversity is not a self fulfilling prophecy, organizations need to commit to a long-term, continually evolving discussion and vision

column1: Does Deeper Learning have a "Race Problem"?
column5: EquityFellow ToBeNamed (Deeper Learning Equity Fellows), Marc Chun (William and Flora Hewlett Foundation), Claire  Sylvan (Internationals Network for Public Schools), Carlos Moreno (Big Picture Learning)
column6: Last year, Harvard Professor Jal Mehta posed an interesting, if not slightly controversial, question in Education Week: _Does Deeper Learning have a race problem?_ intimating that best practices in progressive education are not effectively seeping to underserved communities; arguably those that need them most. To combat this issue, Big Picture Learning and Internationals Network for Public Schools established the Deeper Learning Equity Fellowship, designed to develop and strengthen leaders who might influence the policies and practices that expand access to Deeper Learning in public education across the country. This session will provide an update on our progress on this important effort.
column7: Begin answering the actual question: "Does Deeper Learning have a race problem?"
column8: Bring heightened awareness to this effort, this fellowship, and the conversation surrounding education, race, and equity at large.
column9: A role of the fellows is public engagement. To that end, one of the fellows themselves will learn the importance of this method of communication.

column1: EdTech_s Blind Spot: Closing the ELL Equity Gap
column5: Beverly Fine (BrainPOP), Jeff Knutson (Common Sense Education), Patricia Velazquez (Newsela), Katie McKay (University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Teachers and students can find edtech tools for nearly every subject, grade level, and skill. However, very few edtech tools specifically address the complex needs of English Language Learners (ELLs) and their teachers. ELLs are a growing yet underserved segment of the U.S. student population, and teaching these diverse learners presents unique and highly complex challenges. This panel brings together educators and industry experts to explore how digital tools can best serve ELLs. We_ll look at how teachers can use and repurpose existing tech tools, as well as how the edtech industry can innovate to provide new solutions, and possibly even revolutionize how we teach language acquisition.
column7: Address the challenges facing ELL students and their teachers, including the shortage of edtech tools designed specifically for ELL classrooms.
column8: Discuss strategies that teachers are currently using to teach ELLs, including the creative and innovative implementation of existing tech tools.
column9: Suggest ways edtech developers can innovate to address the complexities of ELL instruction, and look at what some are already doing in this space.

column1: Education Across America: A Town Hall with Mayors
column5: Laura Moser (Turnaround for Children)
column6: Across the country mayors are facing tremendous challenges on how to support their school districts in educating students to prepare them for college and career. Mayors are concerned with issues like graduation rates, kindergarten readiness, community involvement, and the changing classroom. Not only is the technology that supports a classroom changing, but students in a classroom are changing. Hear from three mayors on how they are addressing the challenges facing their communities and schools while remaining focused on supporting students as they work to achieve success in school and in life.
column7: Mayoral roles and engagement within a city's school district(s)
column8: Gain a local perspective on education different from one's own geography
column9: Understand how education fits into a mayors vision for his or her city.

column1: Education Equity in Crisis: How Tech Drives Change
column5: Bea Fernandez (San Diego Unified School District), Stevon Cook (Mission Bit), Natasha Quiroga (Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law)
column6: All students are entitled to equal access to a quality education but the majority of students are in poverty and attending under-resourced schools that struggle to provide an adequate, let alone, high quality education. This panel will discuss the value and impact of using technology to empower parents so they can advocate for the best education for their child and to support schools to work with parents as partners in their child_s education. Panelists will discuss these methods, bridging the digital divide, and ways to improve delivery and efficiency of parent and student engagement programs.
column7: To learn about tech methods addressing education equity
column8: To learn how to overcome challenges facing parents and schools in ensuring education equity for all

column1: Educators Rising: How to Grow Next-Gen Teachers
column5: Dan Brown (Educators Rising)
column6: All kids deserve highly skilled teachers. The next generation of every community's teachers is sitting right now on the student side of the desks. Over 60 percent of teachers teach within 20 miles of where they went to high school. Educators Rising is a national network that brings together partners from across the education sector to support rigorous, hands-on opportunities for bright young people to try out teaching. In this session, hear from student, teacher leader, and national voices on how communities are starting early- in high school- to broaden the tent for teacher recruitment and cultivate a pipeline of inspired, skilled new teachers.
column7: Understand the fractured current state of teacher recruitment and teacher development pipelines.
column8: Understand new, sustainable models to address communities' needs to cultivate and hire skilled teachers who are built to last.
column9: Understand next steps for implementing a high-quality "grow your own"

column1: Effective Learning Models for Opportunity Youth
column5: Tony Simmons (High School for Recording Arts), Aretha  Miller (Community Education Building), Robert Clark (YouthBuild Newark), Leslie Talbot (Talbot Consulting)
column6: Nearly 30% of young people ages 16-21 are neither in school nor working. This opportunity gap is both complex and taxing for educators, municipalities and local economies. Often, the challenges these opportunity youth encounter render traditional school, teaching, and learning models ineffective. Participants will learn about successful school models, instructional strategies, student supports and accountability measures that result in improved performance for over-age and under-credited young people. Best practices will be shared from our respective work with schools, districts, nonprofit and charter management organizations, authorizers and government agencies.
column7: Participants will take-away 5 school/program design elements proven effective in supporting the academic and nonacademic needs of opportunity youth.
column8: Participants will learn an effective strategy to identify academic and nonacademic accountability measures to improve program and practice.
column9: Participants will receive 5 tips on effective partnerships that improve teaching and learning, boost performance, and further long-term outcomes.
column10: opportunity youth, effective school models, over-age & under-credited

column1: Eliminate the Digital Divide: Build a 1:1 Program
column5: Edward Simoneau (Coachella Valley Unified School District), Israel Oliveros (Coachella Valley Unified School District), Michelle Murphy (Coachella Valley Unified School District), Darryl Adams (Coachella Valley Unified School District)
column6: From California to Maine, educators have acknowledged that mobile devices provided to all students and teachers afford users a dynamic, relevant, and individualized learning opportunity. Despite this fact, few have discussed the real world nuts and bolts process necessary to implement a district wide 1:1 mobile learning initiative from the ground up. This fast paced workshop will provide an overview of the Coachella Valley Unified School District_s 1:1 Mobile Learning Initiative and Measure X Bond, a voter approved bond used solely to purchase 20,000 iPads and and fund the infrastructure improvements necessary to implement a district-wide 1 to 1 mobile learning initiative.
column7: How do I to effectively educate my internal and external stakeholders regarding the benefits of 1:1 mobile learning?
column8: How do I create a culture of engagement and empowerment while asking staff to revamp curriculum and integrate dynamic mobile learning techniques?
column9: What are the steps involved for funding and implementing a 1:1 program that transforms our district to a 21st Century Learning Environment?

column1: Empowering Teachers as Leaders and Learners
column5: Tracy Huebner (WestEd), Sarah Catherine Moore (Center for Applied Linguistics), Brad Mitchell (Battelle for Kids), Barbara Hunter Cox (Arkansas Public School Resource Center (APSRC))
column6: Learning is social, but circumstances leave many teachers working in isolation. Teachers of rural students or English learners, in particular, rely on collegial help and quality professional learning to improve practice. Hear how three organizations use digital strategies to build networks of teacher leaders that effectively reach and support teachers working in challenging contexts. Panelists will share successful blended learning strategies, such as virtual coaching and badging, for empowering teachers as leaders and learners, while combatting isolation.
column7: Learn how organizations use technology and teacher leaders_empowered as content experts and coaches_to support teachers in challenging settings.
column8: Engage in discussion with organizations that foster teacher leadership to learn successful learning strategies and the pitfalls to avoid.
column9: Reflect and synthesize as a learning community how digital strategies, partnered with teacher expertise, can best support teachers across contexts.

column1: Equal Access: Leveling the Playing Field
column5: Monte Kalish (Connections Education LLC), Sheri Hardin (Mountain Education Charter School), Lea Ann Lockard ( Texas Connections Academy @ Houston (TCAH))
column6: Online K12 education is inherently designed to be free from barriers that restrict educational opportunity based on geography, disability, race, culture, or income. Online learning programs are typically not bound by neighborhood school districts, but are often available to students statewide,nationally, and around the world. This session will explore how to reach traditionally underserved students who are isolated geographically, economically, racially, and socially affording them equal access to high quality education.
column7: Learn how online programs can impact learning for traditionally underserved students and help close the digital divide and achievement gap.
column8: Understand the challenges and barriers to equal access, such as language, connectivity and hardware issues that may remain in low-income, minority,
column9: Discuss how equity influences our decisions from the classroom to the wider community and how educators can expand equal access to learning.

column1: Equitably Scaling Career Opportunities
column5: Jorge Guerra (Workforce Education Solutions), Lee Baker (Duke University), Kate Vawter (Arizona State University), Rya Conrad-Bradshaw (Fullbridge)
column6: Students will average an astounding 27 jobs over the course of their lifetimes. Add to that another 34% who are already part time or freelance (est. to grow to 60%)_and you can begin to see just how seismic a shift is underway. Further, there are growing expectations on colleges to deliver outcomes, and inequity across students options.In this panel, we will review solutions to scale equitable career opportunities for Higher Ed. Fullbridge will be joined by leaders from Miami Dade College, ASU, and Duke. The discussion will be centered around the importance of creating better solutions for getting all students prepared for the new work while still in college.
column7: Discuss the inequity in the gap between college and career, particularly for certain student populations, why it exists, and who is responsible.
column8: Identify scalable solutions that Higher Ed is currently implementing to solve for the inequity in the gap between college and career in the US.
column9: Learn how to design, implement, and track outcomes of Higher Ed scalable solutions from US and international examples.

column1: Erasing the Look and Feel of Poverty in Schools
column5: Jason Tomassini (Digital Promise), Raquel Parker (Maple Hill Elementary School), Ken Eastwood (Middletown City School District), Amy Creeden (Middletown City School District)
column6: In Middletown City School District, N.Y., 75 percent of students are living in poverty. And yet, more than 80 percent of students there graduate, up from 50 percent a decade ago. How has the district done it? By refusing to accept that because its students are less advantaged than their peers, they should accept a lesser education.In this panel, attendees will watch video from a new documentary produced about Middletown and interact with the district's leadership about how personalized learning supported by technology, in- and out-of-school support services, and a bold move to end social promotion is part of the effort to erase the look and feel of poverty in Middletown schools.
column7: The realities of working in a mid-sized school district where most students live in poverty and come from broken families.
column8: How technology and great teaching together can address the needs of low-income students and put them on a path to graduation.
column9: When a school district decides to end social promotion, what are the reactions from parents and practical considerations for teachers?

column1: Fish Out of Water No More: Women in EdTech
column5: Susan Amat (Venture Hive), Anne Spalding (Dev Bootcamp - San Francisco), Maia Sharpley (Kaplan, Inc.)
column6: It comes as no surprise that in the world of education, innovation and entrepreneurship, women in leadership roles are under-represented. Only a small percentage of women hold leadership roles in the higher education - roughly 15% of high school superintendents across the country are women. In information technology, women hold only 9% of management positions and account for only 14% of senior management positions at Silicon Valley startups. And in business, women hold just 16.9% of Fortune 500 board seats. To allow for real change, both men and women need to be involved in building environments that encourage an open dialogue on gender and leadership.
column7: Attendees will gain an understanding of ways in which diversity in leadership translates into success on the bottom-line
column8: Attendees will learn about the role of male advocates and allies in overcoming barriers to gender equality in edtech leadership
column9: Attendees will hear from women in leadership roles in edtech about how they are making strides in traditionally male-dominated fields

column1: From College to Jobs: MOOCs and Credentialing
column5: Jim McKelvey (LaunchCode), Anant  Agarwal (edX), Adrian  Sannier  (Arizona State University), Gabriel Kahn (Slate Magazine, USC Annenberg School of Journalism)
column6: Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) continue to gain traction around the world with millions of learners using free or low cost courses to earn new forms of credentials in higher education and in the job market. _From College to Jobs: MOOCs and Credentialing_ will focus onthe future of education and how learners are using online courses to earn both traditional college credits and new forms of credentials.
column7: Showcase a vision of new, creative forms of education credentials that are valuable assets in higher education and the job market.
column8: Discuss innovative initiatives and partnerships - Global Freshman Academy and LaunchCode - using online learning to earn credits and credentials.
column9: Look ahead to future forms of credentials and the roles they will play in people's lives.

column1: From South LA to the Ivy League
column5: Alvaro Quintero (Harvard University), Jose Rodriguez (Yale University), Leticia Reyes (Animo Pat Brown Charter High School), Joel Snyder (Green Dot Public Schools)
column6: Our panel will consist of two college freshmen and their high school guidance counselor.  These two students, from South Los Angeles, are both first-generation college students--one at Harvard and one at Yale.  Their stories are similar and different, completely unique yet indicative and telling of the broader challenges at hand.  These students, along with the Guidance counselor who helped them reach these schools, will reflect on the challenges throughout the process of applying to college, transitioning to college and finding support in their first year of college, as they approach the end of the first year in the Ivy League.
column7: Expose SXSW attendees to the personal experience of being a first-generation college student.
column8: Highlight the stories of incredible students and their journey to the Ivy League as first-generation college attendees.
column9: Bring the perspective of low-income and minority students at highly competitive universities to the SXSWedu attendees.

column1: Gaming Our Way to Equity
column5: Carolyn  Vanderbilt (Houston ISD), Farhan  Shah (Houston ISD), Barbara  Reyes (East Austin College Prep), Craig Shapiro (Crockett High School)
column6: Using video games as an entry-point makes computer science and STEM education fun and effective, creating positive change in disadvantaged students and our economic future. Developing these skills will enhance the career paths of non-traditional students, help fill the two million U.S. STEM job openings, and provide needed diversity in the tech industry.  Join a principal, district administrator, teacher, and student in an interactive discussion about the use of game design on Title I campuses to engage students in STEM education and the impact it has had on low-income and minority students.
column7: Learn how infusing gaming and game design help make computer science and STEM programs fun and engaging for students from diverse backgrounds
column8: Engage in a discussion on how effective STEM education can simultaneously address the achievement gap and prepare students for the jobs of the future
column9: Gather insights from educators and students in low-income schools on game design as an agent for positive change in their schools and lives

column1: Giving Hope: Overcoming Odds with Blended Learning
column5: Crystal Hill (Mooresville Graded School District), Kimberly Moritz (Randolph Central School District ), Gayle  White Wallace (Mount Vernon City School District), Robert Rayburn (Cesar Chavez Elementary School)
column6: We have a moral imperative to raise the bar for all kids to help them become college and career ready, but it_s important we do so by making instruction reachable through solid and robust personalized resources that focus on the area(s) each student needs to improve on. An expert panel will share their perspectives on effective tools, and strategies aimed at personalizing learning regardless of grade level, while increasing equity for English Language Learners and other disadvantaged students.
column7: How to create blended environments for disadvantaged students that personalize learning to meet them where they are, regardless of age or grade level.
column8: Gain knowledge of tools and resources for the classroom that help support strategies for intervention.
column9: Learn how schools have overcome barriers to improve student outcomes and opportunities for disenfranchised students.

column1: How Tech Can Help You Graduate Before You Go Broke
column5: Yathrib "BeBe" Ragsdale (George Mason University), Precious Smith (Howard University), Jeff Ray (Ellucian)
column6: In 2015, the average debt for graduating seniors with student loans was nearly $35,000, making last year_s class the most indebted ever. Student debt can be alleviated through more than personal finance initiatives; it starts with a deep technology investment made before students graduate. Higher ed institutions like Howard University are using technology to identify at-risk students early, collect and use student data, and build bridges between all campus stakeholders to help students get through school efficiently, successfully and on time. By shepherding students through the process, colleges and universities will help reduce debt loads while boosting the institution_s graduation rate.
column7: Learn how technology can help promote student success from day one on campus.
column8: Learn how students can take advantage of technology to get through school on time and reduce debt.
column9: Learn how institutions can increase their retention and graduation rates with technology.

column1: Improving College Access for Low-Income Students
column5: Caitlin Emma (Politico), Jamie Sears (The UBS Wealth Management Americas ), Dr. Terry Grier (Houston Independent School District), Bob Obrohta (Tennessee College Access and Success Network)
column6: Just 11 percent of first-generation, lower-income students will have degrees within six years of enrolling in a postsecondary institution. Many of these students have difficulty navigating the college admissions process and selecting schools that provide an adequately supportive learning environment. Moderated by Morning Education_s Caitlin Emma, this panel discussion will explore how K-12 educators can better prepare these students for advanced studies, as well as discuss how to improve the enrollment and graduation rates of these learners.
column7: Deep dive into the statistics on first-generation and low-income college students, and the causes behind these startling numbers.
column8: Learn how educators, corporations and other organizations can support students as they navigate the challenging college admissions process.
column9: Explore alternatives, success stories and case studies showcasing strategies for improving college enrollment numbers.

column1: Improving Low-Income Pipelines to College
column5: Lisa Fielder (College Forward), Todd Penner (Michael and Susan Dell Foundation), Chris Peterson (MIT), Rena Pacheco-Theard (Prepify)
column6: The score gap between low and high-income students on the SAT is ~400 points, and this is one of the factors that contributes to 74 percent of all top-tier college students coming from the upper quartile of the income bracket - only 3 percent from the bottom quartile. Most troubling, the Brookings Institute found that the vast majority of high-achieving, low-income students do not apply to any competitive college. So what can be done? This session will look at key players in the college acceptance and persistence field that are working to change these trends: a unique free test prep company, a top college admissions officer, and a college success driven non-profit.
column7: Overview of efforts at top colleges to recruit and support low-income students.
column8: Current efforts by community groups to increase college enrollment and persistence among underserved students.
column9: Social enterprise innovations to level the playing field, such as free SAT and ACT prep.

column1: Improving Programming Instruction in Public School
column5: Michael Preston (CSNYC), Diane Levitt (Cornell Tech), Reshma  Saujani (Girls Who Code), Gordon Smith (Codesters)
column6: Even though recent years have shown an upswing in interest around computer science courses, there are still fewer CS classes in secondary schools than there were in 2005. Many schools have computers in every classroom or have opted into 1-to-1 initiatives, but the number of students with access to high quality programming instruction has been decreasing in many schools. It is happening in particular to schools in our inner cities and rural environments and has primarily impacted students who are already underrepresented in the technology industry. This panel brings together four professionals from the fields of education and technology with diverse viewpoints to try to find solutions.
