column7: What does good programming instruction look like at the classroom level?
column8: How can we scale successful instructional practices around programming?
column9: How can we change the preconceived ideas of what coding is and who should be concerned with learning it?

column1: Innovation in Service of Equity
column5: Reina Utsunomiya (New York City Department of Education, Office of Postsecondary Readiness), Harvey Chism (New York City Department of Education), Jeremy Kraushar (Mastery Collaborative, NYC Office of Postsecondary Readiness), Joy Nolan (New York City Department of Education)
column6: A panel from the Model Redesign Team of NYCDOE_s Office of Postsecondary Readiness will share how we collaborate and innovate to level the playing field for urban students. Our team_s nationally recognized programs--P-TECH (9-14) schools and the Expanded Success Initiative--as well as newer initiates such as EPIC schools model, Mastery Collaborative, and General Electric (GE) Skills Lab Pilot--share values that play out across our distinct programs. Funders include Carnegie Foundation, NYC Mayor_s Office of Media & Entertainment, General Electric, and Open Society Foundation.
column7: Learn about innovative strategies employed by groups of middle and high schools aimed at promoting more responsive, equitable learning environments.
column8: Hear opinions/perspectives from P-TECH (9-14) schools, EPIC schools, Mastery Collaborative, & GE Grant on how to best increase equity in schools.
column9: Explore the potential of small and large scale grant-funded initiatives in schools and how multiple programs align their work around equity.

column1: It Takes A Village
column5: Kameelah Shaheed-Diallo (The Mind Trust), Dr. Jeffrey Woods (The Expectations Project), Sekou Biddle (UNCF)
column6: Raising the next generation is a shared responsibility. When families, communities and schools work together, students are more successful and the community as a whole benefits. In the fall of 2013, UNCF and The Mind Trust partnered to launch a series of conversations designed to engage the African American community in Indianapolis in authentic and meaningful dialogue around education reform.These conversations began as listening sessions and evolved into thoughtful discussions about prioritizing issues to drive education forward, together, as a community. We will dig into the yearlong partnership between UNCF and The Mind Trust by taking a look at wins and lessons learned from the ground.
column7: Continue the discussion and framework of what has happened in Indianapolis for building greater support and capacity in schools, homes and communities
column8: Generate ideas for how to bring your passion, talents, and energy to help students in your community and to make your neighborhood schools stronger.
column9: And new ways of how you can help young people in your neighborhood have a strong start and prepare for college and for their careers.

column1: Learning by Design in Workforce Development
column5: Dustin Stiver (The Sprout Fund), Vanessa Dodds (Three Rivers Workforce Investment Board), Bill Lucas (LUMA Institute), Tom Akiva (University of Pittsburgh School of Education)
column6: Most cities provide summer youth employment programs (SYEPs). These programs provide valuable work experience and reduce summer violence. Seeing the value, Pittsburgh made a serious investment in a new SYEP called "Learn and Earn".  This new SYEP serves 1900 participants and offers credentialed, multi-year learning pathways. Beyond basic skills, "Learn and Earn" focuses on formative questions and personal growth. Participants design their futures, consider social capital, and map economic networks. A cross-sector partnership will share its work as a case study for the future of SYEPs. The case study includes a new curriculum design, badging system, and long-term research study.
column7: Learn about how improved learning experiences in summer youth employment can address issues of educational equity.
column8: Get insight on detailed curriculum, badge, and research content to help inform program improvements in youth education and workforce development.
column9: Understand the primary challenges facing the improvement and implementation of learning experiences within youth employment programs.

column1: Let's Hack it Out: White Talk and Color Commentary
column5: Tracey Webb (Tracey Elizabeth Webb Associates), Kimberly  Bryant (Black Girls Code)
column6: Let_s Hack it Out:  White Talk and Color Commentary. West Contra Costa Unified School District in Northern California, in conjunction with Black Girls Code will provide an enlightening, engaging and perspective altering experience for the attendees at SXSWedu in 2016.  The two African American students (one male and one female) on the panel will be selected after a series of hackathons in the West Contra Costa Unified School District.  The district is highly representative of underserve populations who are traditionally excluded by lack of inclusion in the tech world. These students will arrive at SXSWedu after emersion into the world of coding, mentoring by engineers and coders.
column7: The audience will come to understand the impact of _unintended_ exclusion on African American students striving to be included in the tech economy.
column8: Conversation and commentary will be facilitated to outline clear actions that can be taken to engage African American students in tech career pursuits
column9: Call out and develop hidden talent in this underserved and often spurned student population.

column1: Leveling the Maker Playing Field: A National Plan
column5: Tim  Carrigan (Institute of Museum & Library Services), Teresa DeFlitch (Children's Museum of Pittsburgh ), Kathy Ishizuka (School Library Journal)
column6: A new model for integrating making into schools promises to expand opportunities for hands-on learning on a national scale. Join Tim Carrigan of the Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) and partner organizations, who will share insights about the framework to inform maker activities for learning_large and small. Attendees will gain perspective on making as an equity issue; how to build community through crowdfunding; and how to forge partnerships with local institutions, including public and school libraries. Also on hand will be the Children's Museum of Pittsburgh, which, with IMLS, is helping bring a maker program to 10 diverse schools and helping train master maker teachers.
column7: Gain understanding of a developing set of best practices for creating a sustainable maker program based on a new national framework.
column8: Glean expert tips on crowdfunding your maker programming and using these platforms to help build your community.
column9: Tap into a unique network, connecting with the library and museum community, to help enable making opportunities for a broader range of users.

column1: Making Computer Science Fundamental to K-12
column5: Hal Speed (Texas Alliance for Computer Science Education (TACSE)), Caroline King (Washington STEM), Rick Adrion (University of Massachusetts Amherst), Amy Hirotaka (Code.org)
column6: Computer science has become a fundamental skill in the digital era. Yet roughly 90 percent of schools do not teach it. State and local school districts need to adopt a broad vision to support and expand K-12 computer science education. This session will outline a comprehensive policy framework and actionable tools to increase access to computer science for all students in every school. The panel will include a national and multi-state perspective including representatives from Washington, Massachusetts and Texas.
column7: Learn how to advocate for clear computer science standards and the necessary leadership in state and local education authorities.
column8: Learn how to create the capacity to teach computer science through proper funding, professional development and teacher certification.
column9: Learn how to sustain a program by requiring all secondary schools to offer computer science and allowing it to satisfy graduation requirements.

column1: Making OER Work: Peer Learning in Public Libraries
column5: Andrea Saenz (Chicago Public Library), Mark Andersen (Chicago Public Library), Phillip Schmidt (MIT Media Lab)
column6: The full potential of online learning has not been realized; MOOC completion rates remain under 5% and many find solo online study too challenging.Chicago Public Library & Peer-2-Peer University have prototyped _Learning Circles_ to address this - peer-learning study groups for online courses in the local library. We_ve created online and offline infrastructure to provide a real-world wrapper around online learning.Results have been positive; a wider roll-out is underway and an open-source resource kit is in development to allow fast and cheap scaling. This panel will discuss results to date and the potential for leveraging public spaces like libraries to turbocharge online learning.
column7: Explore how libraries are ideally suited to complement online learning with offline support.
column8: Explore the learning design we're using - expanding access, increasing retention, and deepening learning: boosting MOOC completion rates 10x!
column9: Discuss the sustainability and scalability of this model with libraries and learning designers.

column1: Mapping Collaboration _A Project Management Primer
column5: Gabe Soumakian (Oxnard Union High School District), Helen  Soule (P21, Partnership for 21st Century Learning)
column6: School leaders and project managers may not often work together, but they should! School transformation necessitates connecting experts and community stakeholders who may not regularly work together. Find out how project management professionals and community members can facilitate 21st century learning and school improvement efforts thanks to a new tool developed by P21 and PMIEF. This brand new collaboration toolkit helps community leaders integrate PBL and project management into their local schools, partner with educators to implement learning projects in the classroom, and provide sought after work-based learning experiences for college, career and citizenship readiness.
column7: School leaders and project managers may not often work together, but they should! School transformation necessitates connecting experts and community
column8: Learn from practitioners in pilot areas where project management-integrated efforts have paid off for students and teachers
column9: Engage in discussion of best practices for building business, education and community coalitions that jumpstart and sustain school transformation conv

column1: MBK: Building Ladders Where They_re Needed Most
column5: Rick Purcell (Public Consulting Group)
column6: Although college and career readiness initiatives are prevalent throughout the country, how focused are they on the persistent gaps faced by young men of color? My Brother_s Keeper (MBK) is a collaborative, multi-disciplinary approach to build ladders of opportunity and unlock the full potential of our young people, specifically young men of color. Hear from school district leaders from some of the nation_s urban districts with the highest MBK populations as they share emerging best practices to open these gates of opportunity.
column7: Understand why you should know what My Brother's Keeper is and why you need to bring it to your school or district.
column8: Learn some of the best practices being implemented to help remove barriers and build bridges for young men of color.
column9: Understand how MBK has created solutions to the challenges that young men of color face as they prepare for college and careers.

column1: Mobile Learning + Place
column5: Cameron  Sinclair (Small Works), Sarah Mead (Trade), Julia  Stiglitz (coursera)
column6: Looking at learning in the mobile age and in context of the coming changes in distribution of education, educational effectiveness, relevance and accessibility. With the rise of Mobile (and even VR/Time/Wearables) as dominant computing system people are able to learn on the go, how will this change learning and make it more ubiquitous?  Panel will explore the way experts and professors can reach new audiences, in the field and on their travels in short formats via mobile or live. Also, exploring the way social media, tech and mobile is introducing knowledge and education to ever widening groups and bringing them to productivity and understanding.
column7: Understand how being/accessing mobile can effect learning + teaching,
column8: Create new networks/networking opportunity in this space.
column9: Open conversation with key players to imagine future of learning.

column1: Mobile Technology in the Classroom
column5: Okaikor Aryee-Price (SoJustEdu), Thomas  Ownes (Eagle Academy, Newark NJ), Alexander  Johnson (Seequ, Inc. ), John Kucyk (Seequ, Inc. )
column6: Enhancing the cultural and educational experience of youth across the globe. When mobile technology is readily available in the classroom, students are able to access the most up to date information. Technology has been noted to greatly increase student engagement and collaboration while providing a utility to deepen learning. Objective:1-Explore frictionless exchange of ideas and the apps that support inquiry based learning2-Identifying and celebrating diverse learning styles by bringing mobile technology to the classroom3-Increase student interaction while encouraging collaboration and community building amongst peers4-Special needs students and mobile apps an exploration
column7: How can mobile technology inspire the disengaged student?
column8: What are the benefits of using mobile technology for students, teachers and parents?
column9: How can mobile technology help reduce spending while increasing learning opportunities?

column1: No Seat Left Behind: The Backfill Debate
column5: Princess Lyles (Democracy Builders), Seth Andrew (Democracy Prep Public Schools)
column6: Explore the most divisive issue within the charter school community. Enrollment numbers from NYC and Washington, DC demonstrate that most students who withdraw or attrit from charter schools are not replaced, leaving empty seats in high-performing and high-demand classrooms. Charter schools refuse to _backfill_ for a number of reasons, but one is the perverse incentive structure set up by regulatory bodies. Panel will present topic and research.
column7: Participants will be able to describe the describe how backfilling relates to educational equity.
column8: Participants will be able to cite specific data surrounding the backfill debate.
column9: Participants will be able to suggest changes to the current incentive structures to better the charter sector as a whole.

column1: Online Collaboration with The Connectory
column5: Karen Peterson (National Girls Collaborative Project)
column6: The Connectory is a comprehensive database of youth-serving STEM programs and events built to help adults connect more young people to the wonders of STEM, and for program providers to collaborate with one another. The Connectory home page targets families and others seeking STEM opportunities, featuring a range of STEM opportunities for K-12 youth, including afterschool clubs, summer camps, and one-day events.  The panel will consist of representatives from these stakeholder groups to discuss the value of joining The Connectory.
column7: Participants will understand the value of the collaboration tools included in The Connectory and be able to use the tools for their own partnerships.
column8: Participants will explore strategies for effective collaborations.
column9: Participants will learn how to use The Connectory to further STEM education in their local regions.

column1: Opportunities & Options: Creating Career Pathways
column5: John White (Louisiana Department of Education )
column6: Superintendent John White will describe how the state of Louisiana partners with leaders in business and industry as well as local educators to create meaningful career pathways in high school for all kids. Through this effort, Louisiana is making sure every child is prepared with the skills and knowledge they need to go on to college or into the workforce after graduation.
column7: Demonstrate why career pathways are critical to make sure every child is prepared for college and careers.
column8: Highlight the important role business and industry play at the state and local level to design meaningful career pathways.
column9: Illustrate what career pathways in high school actually look like and how they support success for ALL kids.

column1: Opportunity Divide: Math as a Social Justice Lever
column5: Rohit Agarwal (Amazon Education), Dr. Nicol Howard (Chapman University), Stephanie Cerda (St. Gabriel_s Catholic School), Rafranz Davis (Lufkin ISD)
column6: Opportunity gaps, especially those linked to mathematics, persist at all levels of education. Algebra has become the gatekeeper for a college education and ultimately, a career. Although the majority of Americans believe math is the most important academic subject, students drop out at higher rates when introduced to harder STEM subjects. For African-American and Latino/a students, dropout rates are close to 40% compared to the national average of 27%. With inequalities in teacher preparation and Common Core implementation, do students really have equal access to higher level math? This panel will discuss inequalities in U.S. math education and the ways we can bridge the opportunity divide.
column7: Audience members will become aware of the vast opportunity divide in math education across racial and economic lines.
column8: Audience members will understand the root of the opportunity divide in math education and the various issues causing it.
column9: Audience members will learn solutions to bridging the opportunity divide in math, as well as formulate solutions to discuss with peers.

column1: Outcomes & Experiences in a City School District
column5: Eric Goldstein (One World Education), Brian J  Pick (DC Public Schools), Desiree Raught (DC Public Schools), Juan Gonzalez (DC Public Schools)
column6: While pockets of success exist in all urban school districts, few generate city-wide gains in numerous literacy skills aligned to CCSS across diverse populations. Join the Chief Academic Officer of DC Public Schools, One World Education, and a panel of teachers to learn about the Cornerstone Initiatives.  Panelists will discuss the program_s success and the replicable model that creates meaningful teaching and learning experiences and rigorous assessments that lead to academic outcomes.
column7: Analyze the framework and results of the first year of the Cornerstone Initiative in DC Public Schools.
column8: Generate administrative strategies to build a Cornerstone Initiative in an urban or rural school district.
column9: Review strategies for teachers from diverse schools to collaboratively design lessons and assessments.

column1: Privatizing the Public Sector: Is Education Next?
column5: Mike Kleba (Teachernomics), Nancy Letts (Nancy Letts, Educational Consultant ), Evan Mascagni (Going Public), Angelina Lopez (NYC Department of Education, Office of Innovation & EdTech)
column6: Public Education is the heart of our democracy. Our public schools remain an extraordinary place where people from different classes and different walks of life come together to learn, share ideas, and be afforded a fair opportunity to reach for the American dream. But a movement for the privatization of what have always been public institutions has been slowly yet profoundly changing this country. And now, profit seekers are turning their eyes to public education, threatening to turn schools into tax-funded, corporate enterprises. The panel will examine this profiteering, how it exacerbates social inequalities, and alternatives to privatization.
column7: To critically examine the role of for-profit interests in transforming public education.
column8: To understand the erosion of public education and growth of educational and social inequalities as a result of privatization.
column9: To spark dialogue about innovative alternatives to the for-profit agenda.

column1: Race & Class: The Power of Diverse Schools
column5: Elsa Dur (Rhode Island Mayoral Academies), Jonathan  Acosta (Blackstone Valley Prep Mayoral Academy), Halley  Potter (The Century Foundation), Katelyn Silva (Rhode Island Mayoral Academies)
column6: The national conversation on race and class is at an apex due to recent and continuing acts of violence against people of color, police brutality, & class divides. All the while, our American schools are becoming increasingly re-segregated. How can a post-racial society ever hope to be realized when our children do not even learn & play together side by side? This panel explores the power of bringing kids of diverse backgrounds together through K-12 schooling & the compelling research that supports the positive social and academic outcomes of it. For ex, children who are exposed to children of other races are less likely to be prejudiced as adults. That's powerful stuff! Let's talk about it.
column7: The audience will understand the growing problem of K-12 school re-segregation in the U.S.
column8: The audience will understand the research-based value of diverse schools both academically and socially, as well as for our broader society.
column9: The audience will have a clear understanding of examples of schools where this model is happening, working, and why, as well as the challenges.

column1: Redefining Pathways to Success:  Lessons from SE67
column5: Steve Bumbaugh (The CityBridge Foundation), Martece  Yates (I Have a Dream Program), Daniel  Porterfield, PhD (Franklin and Marshall College), Diana Kapp (San Francisco's Writer's Grotto)
column6: Our session will explore major themes impacting educational outcomes in high poverty urban areas, as revealed in the film 'Southeast 67.' The documentary chronicles a small, six year educational program in DC at the height of the crack epidemic, through the candid stories of three students over two decades. It captures the complex challenges facing kids in poverty, the potential impact of caring, holistic intervention over time and challenges current ed thinking. Panel features a dynamic student and one of the program's educators - both featured in the film - and a renowned higher education expert, moderated by a journalist. Film clips will be interspersed with discussion and audience Q&A.
column7: To gain a greater understanding of the pervasive toll of poverty and the extreme challenges facing students in transitioning into the middle class.
column8: To understand the critical role of holistic long-term relationships in determining a student_s educational outcome.
column9: To provoke thoughtful dialogue around new, evidence-based pathways to educational success for students growing up in poverty.

column1: Research in the Undergraduate Curriculum
column5: Eman Ghanem (University of Texas at Austin), Dennis Mishler (University of Texas at Austin), Ashay Rane (University of Texas at Austin), Erin Dolan (University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Calls for STEM education reform and workforce diversity emphasize engaging undergraduates in doing research. This usually occurs via internships with faculty, which are available to only a select few too late to influence their academic and career trajectories. Course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) solve this problem by involving groups of students in doing research in the context of a class. UT-Austin is home to the largest, single-institution CURE initiative in the country: the Freshman Research Initiative (FRI). This panel will present data on FRI effectiveness, and discuss opportunities and challenges inherent to involving teams of freshmen in doing STEM research.
column7: Recognize the influence of research experiences on undergraduate science majors' education and career decisions
column8: Identify the challenges to providing access to research experiences for all students
column9: Discover diverse ways of engaging undergraduate freshmen in science research that leads to discoveries and has relevance beyond the classroom

column1: Rock Enroll: Ideas on Encouraging College for All
column5: Bill Hopkins (Husch Blackwell and Foundation Board for BBBS), Virginia Fraire (Austin Community College), Brent  Fields (Big Brothers Big Sisters of Central Texas), John MacNary (Big Brothers Big Sisters of Central Texas)
column6: In 2015, SXSWedu and Big Brothers Big Sisters of Central Texas (BBBS) teamed up with Google Fiber to create the Rock Enroll initiative. Rock Enroll is a campaign designed to encourage high school students to take steps that will put them firmly on the path to postsecondary education attainment.This panel will discuss the unique challenges facing first-generation college students and the role non-profits, businesses and educational institutions can play to abate those challenges.
column7: The goals, successes, challenges and opportunities presented by the Rock Enroll initiative between SXSWedu, BBBS and Google Fiber.
column8: The mission of BBBS, the BBBS Scholarship Foundation and how BBBS collaborates with community partners to encourage students to succeed.
column9: The importance of collaborations between non-profits, businesses and learning institutions to successfully encourage post-secondary education.

column1: Sharing Educational Solutions Across Borders
column5: Katherine Onorato (Teach For All), Robie Dean (Georgetown University), Luis Miguel Reyes Loyola (Ensena Por Mexico), Eva Grajeda (Ensena Por Mexico)
column6: Through the example of a US-Mexico teacher exchange, this session demonstrates how education solutions are shareable across borders. Panelists will discuss how educators in different countries can learn from each other_s successes in addressing educational inequality. Classrooms Without Borders is an initiative of the US_Mexico Foundation that pairs Teach For America teachers with educators from Ense¤a por Mxico, both organizations are partners in the Teach For All network for collaborative professional development that includes co-teaching, resource exchanges, classroom and community immersion, and promoting educational equity for students in both countries.
column7: To further understand that educational inequity is a global problem
column8: To further understand that while contexts differ in different countries, the solutions are shareable
column9: Learn more about Teach For All and its approach to tackling education inequity

column1: Social Capital in Online Education
column5: Jim Shelton (2U Inc)
column6: Social connections are important when considering educational and career outcomes.  Who you know matters, and social capital is a core value proposition of postsecondary education. Innovations in online learning have made it possible for students_ networks to converge and expand by eliminating the geographical barriers of traditional on-campus education.  This session will explore networking and social capital in higher education and demonstrate the power online education has to close the achievement gap and enhance social mobility.
column7: To understand how networking and social capital can be achieved online and offline to reach educational and career outcomes.
column8: To discuss the traditional barriers of networking and how a blended degree program can overcome these.
column9: Explore the best ways to empower students to network in any setting and develop social capital best practices online and offline.

column1: Social/Gender inequality.Shaping 2030's workforce?
column5: Ian  Jeffers (Prince's Trust), Gemma Crothers (Kainos Group PLC), Christina  Wallace (AMNH), Joseph  Parkes (Cristo Rey)
column6: The Industry of today is Tech focused, yet approximately 35% of Irish students are leaving school with no qualifications and little digital awareness. This isn_t just an issue which is specific to Ireland, In the US over 25% of students fail to graduate from high school. To compete in a global workplace it_s vital that every student leaves Education with meaningful qualifications and IT skills appropriate to the job market.  It_s important that we enable the next generation to maximise their career potential. This session addresses Social and Gender Inequality in Education and how we can help students to overcome these issues.
column7: To encourage reflection and discussion of Social and Gender Inequality in Education.
column8: Information sharing, discussion of ways that Industry and non profits have tried to solve the issues faced by students in todays Education system.
column9: Consideration of future plans for tackling Inequality in Education

column1: Sparking Moments of Discovery through STEM Mentors
column5: Nick Hutchinson (US2020), Roxanne Garza (Citizen Schools), Balaji Ganapathy (Tata Consultancy Services), Kumar Garg (White House Office of Science and Technology Policy)
column6: By 2022, the U.S. will need more than 9 million professionals in STEM fields, but last year, there were 11 states where not a single African-American student took the Advanced Placement exam in computer science, and fewer than 20% of all test takers were female. This diversity gap is not only an equity issue, but an economic imperative. There are 16.5 million professionals in the STEM workforce. Why not leverage them to spark student interest and make connections between the classroom and careers? This panel will explore the opportunity to use technology to connect professionals with students, especially those historically underrepresented in STEM, to scale the STEM mentoring movement.
column7: Attendees will learn about what has and hasn_t worked in making connections between schools and industry professionals.
column8: Attendees will hear about ways they can use technology to help scale the STEM mentoring movement.
column9: Attendees will learn about examples of how nonprofits are currently partnering with schools and professionals to grow the STEM mentoring movement.

column1: Students on Diversity and Inclusivity in Schools
column5: Dawnya Johnson (Baltimore Intersection), Tara Subramaniam (Student Voice), Cristal Cruz (Good Shepherd Services, East Fordham Academy), Emet Tauber (Gay, Lesbian & Straight Education Network)
column6: Rising suicide rates, youth violence, sexism, racism and homophobia. Often the students who face these hurdles are some of those who suffer the most from their voice not being heard. This all-student panel will examine the effect of discrimination (based on differences in race, socioeconomic status, gender, sexual orientation etc) on student life.
column7: Understand the various factors inhibiting diversity and inclusivity on school campuses.
column8: Explore ways to overcome discrimination in our education system.
column9: Find ways to give voice to those who often go unheard, yet need to be heard most.

column1: Sustainable Educational Development Initiative In Africa
column5: Adekunbi  Adeoye (SESEWA Support Services), Niran  Adetoro (Tai Solarin University of Education), Paul  Crockett (Authess), Bridget  Teboh (University of Massachusetts-Dartmouth)
column6: Africa is experiencing an economic boom. Africa is predicted to have the largest economic growth of any continent over the next decade. As domestic industries, entrepreneurs,and foreign investors are taking advantage of this growth. We have envisions a time when educational incubators are setup across Africa so we want to step in with an educational plans for economic, social, and knowledge-based future in Africa. In the session, we will discuss about the major challenges facing education in Africa as poor quality, weak governance,inefficient distribution of resources and how we can make a positive difference in the life of children_s, families, and countries in Africa through Education.
column7: Strengthen higher education with a focus on professional preparedness, science, and technology in Africa.
column8: Connecting African communities with Global Partners to launch local sustainable schools and educational incubators.
column9: Align strategy for growth and employment by providing the system with capital capable of supporting economic growth through Educational programs.

column1: The "Dark Sci:" or Inclusive STEM and journalism
column5: Caleph  Wilson (University of Pennsylvania), Danielle  Lee (Cornell University), Jamila Bey (Women's Podcasting Network)
column6: Getting beyond the idea that science is conducted by a white dude in a lab coat, the National Science and Technology News Service is an organization which seeks to get more people involved in telling the science stories that impact us all.We aim to get more journalists telling stories of how science affects the world and its people, and we aim to get readers, viewers, listeners and students to understand that we are all scientists, and the next great problem to be solved could indeed be solved by someone who thinks she or he doesn't "look like a scientist.From gaming to grooming, and health care to space exploration, the way we understand our world requires that everyone take part.
column7: Idenifying how to tell science- rich stories.  Twitter is tech.  Cooking is chemistry and physics. Parenting is part biology. Reporters should say so!
column8: Seeing Oneself as a Scientist: How to make it obvious to cooks, hairstylists, pet lovers and gamers that they should be covered on science pages.
column9: No Pipeline Problem: Journalists to often don't think to call upon diverse scientists to help tell stories.  There are plenty out there to be found!

column1: The Best Way For Tech to Increase Math Learning Is
column5: Philip Vahey (SRI Education), Russell Shilling (U.S. Department of Education ), Zoran Popovic (University of Washington; Enlearn), Meera Vaidyanathan (TenMarks)
column6: Instructional technology use takes many forms. These include learning through adaptive games and problem sets, providing opportunities for collaborative interaction with dynamic representations, and providing students with a personalized 1-1 learning experience that presents each learner with the resources expected to best meet his or her needs. But which use of technology has the most potential to close the mathematics achievement gap and allow all students to reach their full potential? Each panelist will promote one use of technology as being the most productive for at-risk learners, followed by a moderated discussion in which the pros and cons of each method are considered.
column7: Attendees will learn about best practices in technology use for educational equality in mathematics.
column8: Attendees will learn about the tradeoffs in technology uses in classrooms.
column9: Attendees will come away with an appreciation for where to put efforts in their own technology-based projects.

column1: Vote for me! POTUS & the Politics of Higher Ed
column5: Shannan Butler (St. Edward's University), Lisa Barry (LaGuardia Community College), Kara  Laskowski (Shippensburg University), Corinne Weisgerber (St. Edward's University)
column6: With the 2016 presidential election in full swing, candidates are facing off on a number of key issues confronting the country. While education may not be the most pressing debate issue, the presidential campaign rhetoric nonetheless offers a unique glimpse at the ideas that are gaining traction among the electorate and provides a perfect opportunity to study the shaping of public discourse within the realm of education. This panel will examine the politics of pedagogy in an election year by taking a closer look at the candidates_ platforms and studying the implications on educational policy decisions.
column7: Compare the educational platforms of the 2016 presidential candidates.
column8: Examine the limits of debate with regards to the politics of pedagogy, that is, identify the current spectrum of acceptable stances on education.
column9: Examine the implications of presidential election media coverage which gives preference to some educational issues and leaves out others.

column1: We Need to Talk: Building Inclusive Communities
column5: Sara  Stone (Community Roots Charter School Community Roots), Cristen Carson Reat  (Easter Seals Greater Houston/BridgingApps), Lyn Pollard (Understood), Mark Barlet (AbleGamers)
column6: How do you define inclusion? Come hear from panelists of varying backgrounds who look at social justice through a special needs lens. Participants will learn how these experts use _inclusion_ to describe the act of intentionally creating and seeking diverse communities that welcome and support people with special needs to learn alongside their typically developing peers. Panelist will share their personal definitions, stories, best practices, and will invite others who may or may not share similar backgrounds to do the same. The conversation is not limited to special needs issues, as this practice of equal access, when authentically implemented, is impactful for all learners and communities.
column7: Unpack the idea of inclusion, weigh the effects and outcomes, retrace the history, and honor diverse definitions existing for many groups of people.
column8: Explore how inclusion, access, and social justice connect, and discuss how inclusion can empower and lead to better outcomes for all students.
column9: Define inclusive practices from varying perspectives and share ideas for best practices when building inclusive communities for all learners.

column1: What Does College and Career Readiness Mean?
column5: Marla White (Texas Instruments), Jason Faulk (University of North Texas at Dallas), Nicholas Cobb (Comfort and Joy), Laura Hayes (EdisonLearning)
column6: Come hear what college and career readiness means from the perspective of student, an admissions officer, a professor and a corporate recruiter.  Hear firsthand from various constituents what we as educators are doing well and what needs work. Join the conversation to generate new ideas for a seamless transition from education to employment.
column7: Identify  top  priorities of entry level hiring managers, the greatest successes and deficiencies they see in graduates and ideas to bridge the gap.
column8: Identify top priorities of admissions officers and professors, the greatest successes and challenges they see in students and ideas to bridge the gap.
column9: Identify the top priority of students, the greatest successes and deficiencies they noted in their education and new ideas to bridge the gap.

column1: _With Us, Not to Us_: Community Centered Reform
column5: Brian Bridges (UNCF), Chris Stewart (Education Post), Tiffany  Forrester  (BAEO)
column6: This panel will focus on research-based community centered reform which involves hearing from your community to advocate & make changes in education.  While these voices are marginally considered, a sincere inclusion of their perspective requires concerted effort among schools, non-profits, & researchers. In an era of _data driven decision making,_ it is imperative that reforms are substantiated by the experiences of the community.  This panel explores those voices & offers solutions to engage & collect data from communities & students for advocacy. By hearing from your community you can help change the educational landscape. When we invest and reach out to our community, the return is vast.
column7: Understand how to use community based research to inform advocacy
column8: Explore recent student and parent voice data regarding education reform issues
column9: Learn how to discuss research & data in a way to inform change and advocate for students

column1: Can Innovation Be Taught?
column5: Claudia Urrea (MIT Office of Digital Learning), Ken Zolot (BerkleeICE), Patrick McHugh (School of Engineering, Brown University), Aithan Shapira (MIT, School of the Museum of Fine Arts)
column6: Can innovative thinking, an intrinsically disruptive and elusive concept, be taught within formal, higher education?  What does it look like in the classroom? Or outside of it? Join leaders from creative / innovation labs at universities across the country to explore these questions. Panelists will discuss various approaches, including "making to think" where visual art leads to innovative thought, to utilizing music-based pedagogy as a means of spurring innovation in young minds.
column7: Participants will be able to identify indicators of innovative behaviors in students
column8: Participants will be able to compare different approaches on how to develop higher ed innovation programs
column9: Challenge popular narratives about how to best foster innovation in an academic setting

column1: Can Productivity & Health CoExist In StartUps?
column5: Jovanka Ciares (D-Gest and JovankaCiares.com)
column6: Can high levels of productivity and a healthy lifestyle co-exist? How do we hustle and get our work done without shortening our lifespan? Life as an entrepreneur is all about hustle and as we work hard to make an impact, paying attention to your diet and wellness practices may fall through the waste side. This panel will explore why is it important that this never happens and provides wellness tips to increase productivity at work. We will also provide tips to squeeze in a 300 calorie workout without leaving the office (prepare to sweat in your chair)!
column7: Why and how your StartUp may be killing you and what you can do to increase productivity even before you get to work.
column8: Tips to better recharge your _batteries_ throughout the day and foods (and herbs) that can provide the safest, healthiest energy bursts.
column9: The mini workouts that can help you burn up to 300 calories without leaving the office.

column1: Chegg Student Shark Tank
column5: Student TBD (Institution of Higher Education), Student TBD (Institution of Higher Education), Student TBD (Institution of Higher Educations), Dan Rosensweig (Chegg)
column6: Education Technology is in a golden age.  There is no shortage of ideas, startups, entrepreneurs or funding--with over $1.6 billion invested in 2014, a 71% annual increase.  Despite all the attention and fanfare around higher ed innovation, one important audience often remains left out of the conversation--the actual learner themselves, AKA students.  Are the tools and solutions investors are excited about the kinds of solutions students are looking for? What do students think are the biggest barriers? Come watch students put Silicon Valley_s entrepreneurs to the test, in a live shark tank competition.
column7: Learn about the student perspective regarding EdTech innovation: What is needed? What is useful?  What is a flop?
column8: Understand the types of technology that students are seeking in their learning experience.
column9: Determine the often missing link between entrepreneurs and students.

column1: Cross-Border Early Entrepreneur Education
column5: Sebastian Gomez (PROColombia), Kevin Koym (Tech Ranch), Robert Warren (Mean Eyed Cat Venture Labs)
column6: Tech Ranch and the Mean Eyed Cat Venture Labs have partnered together to help educate early-stage entrepreneurs in Manitoba and the Prairie Region of Canada. With the resources that global governments have to support startups, they want to ensure that these startups are truly prepared to grow and scale. How do we implement a training program across cultures and train the trainers to build bridges between the world and Austin?
column7: How do you apply proven US entrepreneurship practices in another culture?
column8: How will this training help Canadian firms to effectively use the funds provided by the government to scale their company?
column9: Can we effectively link startups in Canada and Austin to the benefit of both?

column1: CYOA: Build Your Own Edu Innovation Community
column5: Keaton Wadzinski (University of Virginia), John Raymond (ImpactLab), Caroline Hill (E. L. Haynes High School), David Fu (4.0 Schools)
column6: The organizer and speakers are individually building their education startup & innovation communities, as well as building a network of community builders around the country. In this session, we want to share with you our experiences from different stages in the process of building our education startup & innovation communities.We believe that by involving diverse stakeholders from entrepreneurs to educators across boundaries, we will be able to increase the pace of trying out new ideas, as well as refining and sharing the best of the ideas across the network.
column7: Actionable steps you can take to build your local education startup & innovation community
column8: Experiences and knowledge shared by people building these communities in New York, New Orleans and beyond
column9: Conversations and connections with like-minded folks who are aligned and believe in the power of community

column1: Don_t Go to College to Get a Job
column5: Brian Wong (Kiip), Katie Fang (http://www.schoolinks.com), Sid Krommenhoek (Peak Ventures)
column6: College education has traditionally geared students toward finding a high paying job and colleges then compete over job placement rate and average salary as indicators of their success.  Are today_s educators doing the right thing to foster creativity and competition to the betterment of the world? Together, I have Sid Krommenhoek, a college dropout that created and sold a 40MM dollar company, and Brian Wong, the youngest entrepreneur in the world to raise VC funding at age of nineteen and skipped four grades to discuss education and entrepreneurship.
column7: What education did not prepare them for their entrepreneurial path.
column8: How educators need to embrace a change in mentality and goals in order to prepare students with the diverse set of skills to become problem solvers.
column9: What can we do to get educational institutions to foster creativity and breed tomorrow's_ entrepreneurs.

column1: Education and Entrepreneurship: What, Why and How
column5: Vanessa Beary (Department of State), Daniel Moska Arreola (Instituto Tecnol¢gico y de Estudios Superiores de Monterrey (TDM)), Mark Hand (UnLtd USA), Thom Ruhe (The Entrepreneurial Learning Initiative)
column6: When most people hear the word 'entrepreneurship,' they think Silicon Valley startup OR they think owning a small business. Though these two narratives can be examples of entrepreneurship, they are not representative of the vast majority of entrepreneurship. So what is entrepreneurship, then, and what can be learned from it that is relevant for education? This panel is composed of professionals from a wide range of education, government, and for-profit organizations who will bring their diverse perspectives and experiences to explore what entrepreneurship is, why it's relevant for education, and how education professionals can begin incorporating its lessons into their work.
column7: Define and examine entrepreneurship and its impact in various educational and societal domains
column8: Consider the implications of educators engaging entrepreneurship and encouraging the development of entrepreneurial mindsets among students
column9: Explore possible approaches to incorporating entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial thinking into various education institutions and environments

column1: Education Savings Accounts: Flexible student funds
column5: Adam Peshek (Foundation for Excellence in Education), Katie Swingle (Mother), Grant Hewitt (Nevada State Treasurer's Office), Derrell Bradford (NYCAN)
column6: Education Savings Accounts are sweeping the nation, with nearly one million K-12 students eligible in 2016. ESAs are managed by parents, using funds deposited and monitored by the state, that can be used for tuition, tutoring, therapy, online courses, savings for higher education, exam fees, and many other approved uses. ESAs have the potential to transform the way education is funded and delivered, but their success depends on a robust environment of quality educational offerings. This panel will explore how ESAs work and why quality educational providers should be jumping at the chance to participate in these programs.
column7: Build awareness and deepen understanding of ESAs and how they work
column8: Discover how states are approaching ESA implementation
column9: Learn how this flexible funding offers new opportunities for learning providers

column1: Entrepreneur-Ready Skills: Essential for All
column5: Ann McMullan (Ann McMullan Educational Technology Consultant), David Bettner (Self), Jesse Pelayo (Leche Cafe and Bookstore), Cheryl Lemke (Metiri Group)
column6: How do we create tomorrow_s entrepreneurs?To thrive in today_s workforce, entrepreneurial skills are as essential as literacy, numeracy and the 21st Century Skills' 4Cs (Communication, Collaboration, Creative Problem Solving and Critical Thinking). The good news is that essential entrepreneurial skills are attainable for all students.Innovative K-12 educators are embedding these critical skill sets throughout multiple areas in K-12 education. Join the conversation with two successful entrepreneurs and two educators to share ideas and learn the essence of entrepreneurial skills and why they matter.
column7: Define the skills that are essential to today's entrepreneurial work force.
column8: Share strategies for K-12 teachers to use in their classrooms to leverage entrepreneurial skills for student success.
column9: Learn from two successful modern day entrepreneurs how the skills now being taught to teachers for classroom use impacted their own success stories.

column1: Entrepreneurial education to shape the new economy
column5: TBD TBD (TBD)
column6: TBD
column7: TBD
column8: TBD
column9: TBD

column1: Entrepreneurship: Building Purpose & Community
column5: Luis Gonzalez (Luis Guillermo Gonzalez Law), Analco Gonzalez (OCI Group), Olivia Travieso (OCI Group)
column6: In today's market all means of doing business must be forward thinking and creative. This eclectic panel will discuss how to start a business, how to utilize social media, and social purpose to set yourself apart and other tertiary issues as they pertain to these. OCI Group will address the issues of creating a social purpose through building upon a company's assets and LGG law will address legal issues as they relate to the industry. Experiences in ride sharing and civic engagement start ups will be utilized to create an interactive forum.
column7: Strategic planning and start up development
column8: Collaborative approaches for social purpose businesses
column9: Community engagement models and strategies

column1: Entrepreneurship: The Empowering Nature of Failure
column5: Thomas Leonard (Eanes Independent School District), Michael Miles (INCubatoredu), Margarita Geleske (Barrington 220 Educational Foudnation), Scott Arnett (Funtastech & Waco University)
column6: When is an entrepreneurship class not just a business class?  When the program is rigorously authentic, it is anything but business as usual. Barrington High School allowed community members to create an entrepreneurship program based on the real world.  The teaching team included business people as class coaches and mentors.  Students created business concepts and pitched to real sharks.  Both students and adults learned much more: failure means you_re trying, the marketplace demands better, and teachers/adults don_t know all the answers.We want to share our story of empowerment.  Pick us.
column7: Connect schools and community beyond traditional roles.
column8: Motivate schools to travel an authentic path to learning.
column9: Empower students to discover their own solutions and pathways to success.

column1: Foreign Sales: Tales from the Global Trenches
column5: Jonathan Schor (CodeMonkey Studios), Raphael Taieb (Le Livre Scolaire), Jon Smith (Pobble), Steven Hodas (CRPE)
column6: The different structure and regulation of school systems in different countries present different challenges and opportunities for EdTech startups.In this panel Steven Hodas will share his experience working on all sides of those dynamics, as a district vendor, Executive Director in the NYCDOE Office of Innovation, and as a startup advisor.He will interview EdTech entrepreneurs from around the globe on the lessons they've learned selling into markets in Israel, England, and France.
column7: Explore the challenges for EdTech startups selling to public school systems around the world.
column8: Learn how different paths to overcoming those challenges.
column9: Understand how investors should evaluate EdTech startups differently from other consumer or enterprise ventures in light of those dynamics.

column1: Frictionless Integration: Building Ed Products Schools Want and Teachers Need
column5: Katrina Stevens (U.S. Department of Education), Don Burton (EdgeTech), Steven Hodas (Digital Promise), Mark Miller (Boston)
column6: This session will bring together knowledge experts to help innovatorson all sides of the educational divide - those that are creatingproducts (entrepreneurs), those that use the products (educators), andthose that decide whether adoption will work in their school setting(administrators) - to answer the new age question of whether it ispossible to make testing, product feedback, procurement andimplementation more frictionless.
column7: Explore whether it is possible to make testing, product feedback, procurement and implementation in schools more frictionless
column8: Dissect the hurdles that exist for entrepreneurs, educators and administrators as they work to integrate tech in educational settings.
column9: Discuss how innovative thinkers can work together introduce technology in schools as seamlessly as possible.

column1: From K-12 to College: School Reimagined
column5: Will  Houghteling (Minerva), Max Ventilla (AltSchool), Michael  Staton  (Learn Capital)
column6: From SpaceX to Uber to AirBnB, everyday business people are transforming some of the oldest industries that just a decade ago seemed impenetrable. Consequently, that belief that organizational and operational complexity make certain institutions untouchable is disappearing. Is education next? Hear from innovators on the front lines of this movement who aren_t just building technology - they_re starting schools with audacious new approaches and the vision to bring education into the 21st century. Explore what's working, what isn't and how changes achieved in private institutions can impact the education ecosystem as a whole.
column7: From First Principles: How to strip the school experience down to the aspects that contribute directly to student learning and teacher satisfaction
column8: From Kindergarten to College: Learn why collaboration between all the stakeholders in the process is essential to creating meaningful, scalable change
column9: From Single Schools to an Entire Ecosystem: How benefits and insights achieved at individual schools can broadly impact the education system at large

column1: From Teacher to Team to Tech
column5: Emily Land (Arlington Community Schools), Dan Ryder (Mt. Blue High School), Kevin  Barnes (Mind Over Data)
column6: It_s 2015. Technology is everywhere in education. Yet go into almost any school, and you_ll find a stronghold of traditional processes that are still ruled by a paper fist. But you_ll also find teachers who have progressive ideas about how to streamline processes and change standard protocols to make them more effective. Oftentimes, it's not the fear of failure that stops teachers from making those great changes- it_s needing a team to help turn that idea into a reality. But what if a teacher took that leap? What if she built a team around her that was committed to change? Come find out how a teacher, some design thinking, and a software company teamed up to smash the status quo!
column7: Attendees will discover how traditional education processes led to the realization that typically paper-based systems can be digitized.
column8: Attendees will learn how a team of technology and teacher came together to create a new solution for old problem.
column9: Attendees will gain perspective about how design thinking helped guide the development of a teacher-designed software system.

column1: Fulfilling Your Fantasy
column5: Aaron  Rasmussen (MasterClass), David Rogier (MasterClass)
column6: Silicon Valley startup backed by Mayor Michael Bloomberg, the Redstone family, Robert Downey Jr, Serena Williams and Harrison Metal Capital (one of the top performing early stage venture capital firms in Silicon Valley) to make it possible for anyone in the world to learn from the very best. Online learning is a $107 billion global industry that is seeing double digit growth. Tapping into this fast-growing market, MasterClass takes a unique approach to online learning by being the first to work with globally-recognized instructors and Emmy and Academy Award winning directors to create a new kind of class. We can_t democratize genius, but we can democratize access to it.
column7: Learn from the world_s best. Breaking the fourth wall: How to merge entertainment with education.
column8: Your investor wrote you a million-dollar check. What do you do next? How to innovate when given the opportunity.
column9: Imagine learning photography from Annie Leibovitz or tennis from Serena Williams. We can_t democratize genius, but we can democratiz access to it.

column1: How Students Are Leading Social Innovation @UMich
column5: Angela Dillard (University of Michigan), Virginia Lozano (Leesta), Tyson Gersh (The Michigan Urban Farming Initiative), Jeff Sorensen (optiMize / University of Michigan)
column6: In Sept 2012, we were undergrad students at UMich, and we were frustrated.On campus, we saw students passionately discuss new ideas to take on societal challenges. But as semesters ended, far too few of us had taken action.We challenged students to ask 'why not me?' and take action. 3 yrs later, our movement is 500+ students strong with 100+ mentors to help us, ranging from local entrepreneurs to Jessica Alba's Honest Company.We run year-round programs and have raised $400k to incubate 95 student social ventures, ranging from urban farming to disability design to financial coaching. UMich hired us, and now it's our full-time job.Let's talk about how to do this at your school.
column7: Students: Learn how to rally a social innovation movement at your school -- including how to inspire belief, coordinate action, and gain support.
column8: Administrators: Learn how a student-designed and student-driven experiential learning program attracted the most highly engaged students at Michigan.
column9: Companies: Learn how today's students find purpose, what we want from our work, and how we're entrepreneurially aligning the two to make an impact.

column1: How Teacherpreneurs are Shaking Up Classrooms
column5: Jen Medbury (Kickboard), Dan Carroll (Clever), John Ruff (ScribeSense), Michael Cardona (Houston ISD)
column6: When teachers identify the issues they encounter on the front lines and are encouraged to develop their own solutions as "teacherpreneurs", Ed Tech innovation has the potential to become much more rich, precise and effective. In this panel, we_ll gather a diverse mix of educators to discuss their experiences with entrepreneurialism in the classroom. We will look both at the unique insight and drive teachers bring to the development and implementation of Ed Tech solutions as teacherpreneurs, as well as at the framework needed both at the district level and within the wider Ed Tech community to support teacherpreneurs in their journey from idea to product.
column7: Define the concept of teacherpreneur; help teachers who are interested in entrepreneurialism take their first steps in that direction.
column8: Pinpoint the ways in which administrators and the Ed Tech community can effectively support teacherpreneurs while still meeting district objectives.
column9: Drive home the idea that empowering teachers to create change will generate powerful solutions.

column1: How The Internet Changes What And How We Eat
column5: Nick Green (Thrive Market), Marion  Nestle (NYU), Roy  Choi (Refinery29), Elettra Wiedemann (Refinery29)
column6: The Internet has changed everything about how we live, both seen and unseen. Beyond viral videos and information access, the web is also changing the way we relate to, learn about, and consume food. The web has started to play an active role in shaping our food system and food trends, which has a larger impact on agriculture, commerce, and consumption. How does the _collective brain_ that is the web shape individual tastes and trends? This panel will look at all the unexpected ways that the internet is helping the next generation of entrepreneurs and food activists to remake the food system to accommodate both a rapidly changing world, and a new kind of customer.
column7: Looking critically at how food system is shaped by technology
column8: Informing people about issues at stake in food system today
column9: Revealing unexpected ways web has an impact on our collective food consumption habits

column1: How to Build Self-sustaining Learning Communities
column5: Bahiy Watson (The 1881 Research Institute), Aaron Frumin (unCommon Construction), Flor Serna (Electric Girls), Hassan Hassan (4.0 Schools)
column6: Most learning communities exist within the traditional boundaries of schools. We'll delve into four distinct models that are rethinking the constraints of talent, revenue and space to increase access and self-sustainability. Electric Girls is a community of middle school girls teaching each other to be leaders in STEM. UnCommon Construction cultivates high school apprentices who build houses and use the proceeds to provide scholarships. The 1881 School engages young African American New Orleanians in engineering projects that directly improve their neighborhoods. At 4.0, we equip early-stage entrepreneurs to build bold schools, tools and startups - and our alumni enable us to do so at scale.
column7: How might we leverage alumni to reinforce culture, increase rigor, and offset costs?
column8: How might we equip learners to finance their own education and reduce reliance on government funding, tuition, and philanthropy?
column9: How might community assets and needs influence what and where we teach?

column1: How to enter China's ed-tech market?
column5: Sophie Chen (JMDedu)
column6: We gather four representatives from major players in China's education market that is undergoing rapid changes: educator from one of the top high school that embraces education technology; entrepreneur that develop useful ed-tech tools; investor that incubate ed-tech projects; executive from big education company. From their different perspectives, we will talk about the landscape of China's education market and how to enter this huge market.
column7: Education technology landscape in China
column8: How to enter into the China's education market?
column9: Opportunities in China's education market

column1: Improving Security & Student Privacy in Ed-tech
column5: Chris Nims (AOL, Inc.), Dave Johnson (Arbonne International), Saad Alam (Citelighter)
column6: Citelighter is an edtech startup that has taken a unique approach to the issue of protecting student privacy/data, forming its own Security Advisory Board (SAB), comprised of seasoned security experts. The panel will include a discussion, moderated by Citelighter_s CEO, among the security experts from Citelighter_s SAB about the rapidly changing security landscape in education, and simple steps that end users (schools, students, teachers, parents, administrators, etc.), as well as edtech companies themselves (particularly startups), can take to better protect student privacy.
column7: How the security landscape has changed within the education industry and why it_s a problem that edtech companies and schools need to take seriously.
column8: The requirements of an edtech company in today_s security landscape and how to achieve them, as well as what schools should demand of their vendors.
column9: How to build a Security Advisory Board of experts from multiple industries and create the best possible security posture as an edtech company.

column1: InnovationU: Unlocking the University-as-Incubator
column5: Mitzi Montoya (Arizona State University), Perry  Samson (University of Michigan), Robert Pianta (University of Virginia), Dror Ben-Naim (Smart Sparrow)
column6: Universities develop and commercialize IP in critical areas, from medicine to particle physics. Yet, despite being the most well positioned for the task, universities have not played as big of a role in developing edtech. Instead of more technologies in search of a problem, university-grown innovation can help to develop user-focused solutions: technology made for educators, by educators. The university-as-innovation-playground approach allows entrepreneurs to prototype and iterate quickly with faculty and students on campus. Hear from academics-turned-entrepreneurs who have successfully used this approach to develop and launch technologies aimed at the biggest challenges in higher ed.
column7: Hear from a group of entrepreneurs and investors on their experiences launching successful education companies from universities.
column8: Learn how incubators are addressing the challenges among K12 leaders and edtech companies in the procurement process.
column9: Gain an understanding about the role edtech incubators will play in the future of both K12 and higher education.

column1: Interactive Student Entrepreneurship
column5: Jia  Jiang (Rejection Proof), Chris  Lopez (Austin Teen Entrepreneurship Program), Jason Freshly (The Fresh Idea Group)
column6: I would bring a venture capitalist, a marketing strategist and a student entrepreneurship mentor. I would choose four students from the crowd and bring them on stage. I would give them a product, let's say a laptop, then tell them to monetize this product, go through the process of making it a business with the help of the entrepreneurship mentor. From there, you go to the marketing strategist. You learn different methods of marketing your product in the best ways possible. After you've built your product and marketed it, you present it to the venture capitalist, somewhat like a shark tank. The ultimate goal would get the VC to "invest." This gives a hands on experience of entrepreneurship.
column7: Teach students how to build from their idea and turn it into a viable business, as well as present the process of proper business organization.
column8: Show students effective marketing tools that will allow for proper allocation of their ideas into specific markets.
column9: Show students how to introduce entrepreneurial ventures to prospective connections.
column10: students, movement, design, design thinking, creativity, innovation, entrepreneurship

column1: Join the Revolution in Higher Education
column5: Lisa  Gring-Pemble (George Mason University), Elwood Robinson (Winston Salem State University), Danielle Ripich (University of New England), Bryan Setser (2 Revolutions)
column6: What will it take to ignite a revolution in higher education and transform it into an industry that can leverage and impact the changing landscape of our society? This panel discussion will help define the ecosystem needed for this transformation. The panelists will share their vision for this revolution in higher education and discuss how to create effective networks that bring together a broad array of stakeholders; facilitate open exchange of ideas; and bridge cultural gaps between different groups to promote effective collaboration.
column7: Understand the dispositions of change and innovation.
column8: Learn strategies and tools to foster change and innovation.
column9: Co-construct practice by crowd-sourcing common solutions to higher ed change and innovation challenges.

column1: Making a Living and Making a Difference
column5: Jess Ekstrom (Headbands of Hope), Katelynn Lee (Suja Juice), Joe  Huff (LSTN), Sam Davidson (Batch USA)
column6: The connotations of words like charity, giving, service and philanthropy all point towards selflessness. For a lot of people, giving back means doing something good and getting nothing in return. But does it need to be this way? Why can_t you solve social issues and be profitable too? In this panel, we_ll explore the rise of socially responsible companies that are making a living and making a difference. Members of the panel will give their input on the rise of socially responsible companies and the revolution of the term "give." Additionally, ideas and different business models will be discussed on how to create a structure that helps a social issue and returns a profit too.
column7: When did the "for-purpose" revolution start? We'll explore what caused companies to add social aspects to their business model.
column8: What are the pros and cons between running a for-profit versus a non-profit business model?
column9: What are the keys to "success" in for-purpose companies?

column1: Merit Over Marketing _ Cutting Through the Clutter
column5: Sean Cavanagh (Education Week), Jamie Wilson (Denton ISD), Robert Pianta (University of Virginia Curry School of Education), Todd Bloom (Jefferson Education Accelerator)
column6: There_s a lot of noise to sift through in today_s ed tech marketplace, making it difficult to determine the best product offerings for school districts. With over 14,000 school districts in the U.S._each with their own unique needs and challenges_and a growing number of products in the market to choose from, how do we ensure leaders have the information they need to make the best decisions for their schools? How do we define merit? How will educators know when they see it?
column7: Hear from district leaders, educators, and entrepreneurs on what drives their decisions (merit vs. marketing) for adopting new technologies for the
column8: For educators to become better equipped to assess new ed tech tools
column9: For entrepreneurs to gain a clear understanding of what_s important and what evidence matters in describing new ed tech products

column1: New Learner + New Technology = New Business Model
column5: Lily Ladd (Blackboard, Inc. )
column6: In this time of great disruption, the only constant is change - the education industry is no exception. Over the past decade, we've witnessed many new approaches to traditional learning models, we've seen an explosion of educational technology to facilitate these new approaches, and we've talked for countless hours about the issues of affordability and access for learners. But we need to dig deeper on this last point and we'd like to do it from the perspective of the disrupters. This panel will bring together leaders from new and old companies/institutions to explore how they are changing their own business models to drive fundamental shifts in the cost/value business models for education.
column7: Understand the key trends/issues with the education cost/business models (K-12 and Higher Ed).
column8: Discover how new education companies are structuring their cost/value proposition differently to be successful with learners.
column9: Hear solutions that older companies are adapting to move their legacy business models to respond to changing trends and learner affordability needs.

column1: Partnerships in Competency-Based Higher Ed
column5: Scott Emerick (YouthBuild USA), Sarah  Saxton-Frump (PelotonU), Steve  Brown (College for America), Mike Larsson (Match Beyond)
column6: Increasingly, working adults are struggling to effectively juggle employment and post-secondary education. For students who need greater flexibility and additional support, programs that blend the flexibility of competency-based degrees alongside dedicated mentors provide a compelling alternative.This session will explore the working relationship between College for America and two programs that provide on the ground support for this competency-based university. Hear from practitioners who have worked alongside more than 200 students to provide added support so they can earn their degree.
column7: What are the barriers facing working adults in postsecondary education, and how does blended higher ed overcome the big ones?
column8: What does the experience look like for a student enrolled in a blended higher ed program?
column9: Okay, I_m intrigued. How can I launch a similar program in my own community?

column1: Pedagogy of Entrepreneurship: Creating Creators
column5: Cathlin Olszewski (Venture for America), Cristal Glangchai (VentureLab), Hetali Lodaya (VentureLab), Austin Crouse (4.0 Schools)
column6: Entrepreneurship isn't just an activity. It's a mindset that embraces comfort with ambiguity, personal benchmarking, and value creation with limited resources. It's surprisingly hard to teach. Despite new incubators and entrepreneurship resources appearing constantly, the share of new entrepreneurs ages 20-34 has fallen from 35% in 1996 to 23% in 2013 (Kauffman Foundation). Simply stated: lots of people are trying to teach entrepreneurship, but few are succeeding.4.0 Schools, Venture for America, and VentureLab are all teaching and creating new entrepreneurs in radically different ways. This will be a discussion to uncover the best ways to authentically create creators.
column7: How might we create experiences for young people that encourage them to fail gracefully in preparation for entrepreneurial careers?
column8: How might we encourage nascent entrepreneurs, at any stage of their life, to start small, involve others, and never quit?
column9: How might we create spaces for young entrepreneurs to 'apprentice' with seasoned veterans?

column1: Privacy, Tech, & Cloud: Opportunities & Challenges
column5: Michael Hawes (Privacy Technical Assistance Center, USDE), Ginger Gossman (Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board), Melissa Woo (University of Oregon), Cinda Christian (Austin Independent School District)
column6: Recent advancements in education technology have created new opportunities to leverage innovative technological solutions to improve both student outcomes and the broader educational experience. These innovations, however, also pose new challenges to protecting student privacy. This session will provide an opportunity for practitioners and policy makers in both K-12 and higher education to discuss these challenges and the solutions they have identified to mitigate them. An official from the U.S. Department of Education will also discuss implications for emerging education technology trends under FERPA and other federal privacy laws, and privacy and security best practice recommendations.
column7: Raise awareness about the Privacy Technical Assistance Center (PTAC), housed in USDE, and its available services.
column8: Understand the opportunities and challenges of leveraging innovative technological solutions to improve student outcomes.
column9: Identify methods to mitigate the challenges associated with innovative technological solutions.

column1: Romancing The Media - How To Pitch Your Startup
column5: Heather  Wagner  (Juice Consulting ), Natalie Cofield (Walker's Legacy )
column6: Attendees will learn how to effectively pitch their product, services, idea and more by finding out what the media wants and how to make it work for them. From pitching, to writing to the actual interview, attendees will learn what it takes to stand out.
column7: How to tell and sell your story.
column8: How Kim Kardashian uses Social Media to drive success - yes you can do it too.
column9: How to increase coverage on podcast, online and traditional media.

column1: Scaling in Education: Lessons from Tyton Growth50
column5: Gates Bryant (Tyton Partners), Andrew Grauer (Course Hero), Lane  Rankin (Illuminate Education), Jessie  Woolley-Wilson (DreamBox Learning)
column6: The education sector is experiencing an epic period of excitement and investment, fueling vibrant entrepreneurial activity.  The challenge for many is making the transition from start-up to scale, achieving broad-based awareness, adoption, and financial sustainability. CEOs of leading growth-stage companies, drawn from the Tyton Growth50, will share their lessons learned in driving scale and impact within their markets.
column7: Identify what it takes to achieve scale in the education sector.
column8: Understand challenges faced by growth-stage companies and insights for overcoming them.
column9: Identify strategies for balancing capital raising, revenue generation and stakeholder impact.

column1: Self-directed learning: Why it, why now?
column5: Rainesford Alexandra (The New School), Michael Crawford (The Entrepreneurial Learning Initiative), Matt Candler (4.0 Schools), Luba Vangelova (Self employed)
column6: The longer students stay in today_s school system, the less engaged they become. How is that possible? What_s going on here? This panel will examine one aspect of the learning experience that holds promise for helping students, educators, and administrators reignite the love of learning innate in all of us: self-directed learning. From multiple perspectives, this panel will explore key aspects of self-directed learning, its implications for students and society, and ways in which we all can begin to take more ownership in our learning and our lives.
column7: Compare and contrast self-directed learning with other approaches to learning
column8: Examine the implications of self-directed learning
column9: Identify ways to incorporate self-directed learning into classrooms, schools, districts, university systems, and lives

column1: Sharing Economy:Leveraging Existing Infrastructure
column5: David Mandell (PivotDesk)
column6: It is time to get out of the dark ages when it comes to the way we conduct business. The sharing economy is both a buzzword and a concept taking the world by storm, but how can it be applied to the existing business structures that have worked for hundreds of years? How can we find a middle ground of old processes and new money saving ways for consumers? Businesses need to change at the same pace as the speed of technology and innovation. This panel will give an in-depth look at how we can apply the sharing economy to the old fashion way businesses work.
column7: Integrating static industries with a dynamic new process that appeals to the end consumer
column8: The sharing economy does not necessarily mean taking jobs away
column9: How static businesses use tools already in place to leverage the sharing economy

column1: Shark Tank: Edu Edition
column5: Jason  Jones (ProfHacker), Paul Freedman (Entangled Ventures), Goldie Blumenstyk (Chronicle of Higher Education), Jeffrey Young (Chronicle of Higher Education)
column6: Back by popular demand, The Chronicle of Higher Education presents this pitch-a-thon that pays homage to the TV show, but with a twist. Our panel of experts brings a mix of viewpoints _ from a journalist, a college tech leader, and an entrepreneur -- weighing in on transformative ideas from companies, colleges, and other players for improving the college experience.
column7: Hear new ideas to solve problems for students or professors.
column8: Understand the practical challenges these new ideas face.
column9: Put innovative approaches in context.

column1: Social Entrepreneurship shaping Education
column5: TBD TBD (TBD)
column6: How are social enterprises impacting the world of education towards more relevance and innovation?More details to be provided
column7: TBC
