column8: TBC
column9: TBC

column1: Stories from Female Founders of STEM Games
column5: Anupama Redmond (Infinut), Kara  Carpenter (Infinut Software Inc.), Adriana Moscatelli (Play Works Studio), Julia Winter (Alchemie)
column6: Only 24% of STEM professionals are women. Only 11% of game designers are women. Only 10% of tech company founders are women. We're at the intersection of these ratios. Each of us brings a unique perspective to this conversation.We're choosing to change these ratios. Will you help us?
column7: Sharing founders' experiences from diverse ethnicities, locations, and professional backgrounds in technology and education.
column8: Looking at the balancing act of women leading teams and managing families at the same time.
column9: Inspiring women (and men who support them) to build companies to help students learn.

column1: Student Startup Pitches
column5: Erika Smith (Yale University)
column6: Entrepreneurship Yale Style - Changing the world through entrepreneurship.Representing 5 of Yale_s diverse startups in the seed stage ranging from  which range from web products to high-tech life sciences to consumer goods to new Ed. Tech ventures to environmental innovation in a shark-tank style pitch session.  Focus on opportunity for both on opportunity for financial return as well as impact.
column7: How can ideas that change the world  - ALSO make money?
column8: What are some of the resources that Yale has employed to launch these innovative concepts
column9: Learning about top technologies/ideas from Yale students/faculty

column1: Teaching the Startup Mentality
column5: Eric L. Adams (Brooklyn Borough President), Jim  Zahniser  (A. James Clark School of Engineering, University of Maryland), Jonathan Jaglom (MakerBot), Yolanda Valencia (Gulliver Schools)
column6: Traditional education teaches students to learn predefined steps so they can add two numbers, analyze a poem, or bake a pie. This approach worked in an economy that depended on assembly lines and fixed corporate policies. A new paradigm has emerged: the startup mindset. Successful entrepreneurs share a disregard of the status quo; a focus on possibilities; and a rejection of waterfall processes in favor of rapid iteration. How to teach startup thinking in the classroom? Only desktop 3D printing allows students to bring their ideas to life in a way that's high-fidelity, affordable, and fast. Thousands of educators have already embraced 3D printing to teach 21st century skills.
column7: Learn how the startup mindset can help students succeed in today's economy and why educators should embrace it.
column8: Discover how 3D printing can teach entrepreneurial skills, such as collaboration, problem solving, and design thinking.
column9: Hear from educators how they implemented 3D printing in the classroom and how their students benefited from it.

column1: The Next Hot Trend in Higher Ed:Incubating Success
column5: Hakan  Satiroglu (LearnLaunch), Bill Barke (MindBridge Partners)
column6: As nations embrace entrepreneurship and innovation as a tool for economic development, colleges & universities are asked to play a greater role in both encouraging student entrepreneurs and supporting broader entrepreneurial ecosystems. Given that these are relatively new roles for higher ed institutions, many challenges, both internal and external, must be addressed in order to develop, implement, and sustain programs that engage students, faculty, entrepreneurs, and investors. How can higher ed contribute to the development of entrepreneur-friendly ecosystems? How will we increase cross-institutional collaboration on a global scale? How can we use blended learning to support these ecosystems?
column7: How advancing these ecosystems can help universities recruit fresh talent, establish partnerships for success and growth?
column8: Discussion on challenges ahead, but providing lessons from international examples/best practices
column9: Impact of innovation on the future of learning

column1: The Rise of the Teacher Entrepreneur
column5: Trenton Goble (Mastery Connect), MaryJo Madda (Ed Surge), Rob Grimshaw (Tes Global)
column6: Teachers create incredible value everyday. Their insight is unparalleled. As we think about how to develop the tools and resources for the future of education, we need to ensure that teachers have much more than a voice at the table. We need to provide them with opportunities to develop their solutions and capture the value they create for students, families and schools.From hacked technology solutions to customized digital resources to top-notch lessons, teachers have tremendous resources that could benefit educators around the world. This panel explores opportunities for teachers to bring their innovations to market and add value to education beyond the walls of their classroom.
column7: Understand the ways that teachers create value and the opportunities for them to share with that with other teachers.
column8: Discuss the merits of monetizing teacher resources as a way for educators to create additional income.
column9: Imagine the future of innovation for teachers outside of their primary responsibilities in the classroom.

column1: Tiny Schools: Learning How to Prototype Innovative
column5: Vera  Triplett (The Noble Minds institute for Whole Child Learning ), Jonathan  Johnson (Rooted School), Kim  Gibson (NOLA Micro Schools), Matt  Candler (4.0 Schools)
column6: For the first 20 years of my career, I thought there was one way to launch new schools: find a proven leader, write a 400 page charter application, and get a foundation to give me a lot of money to replicate what already works. This process works if the school you want already exists, and if you have a lot of cash and time. If the school you want doesn_t exist, this process won_t work. That_s why we created the Tiny School Project, a process for prototyping new school models. In this session, we_ll talk to founders currently prototyping their innovative school models and learn about how this process can be used in the development of charter, private, and traditional public schools.
column7: Participants will understand what the process of prototyping a new school looks like and how it differs from the traditional new school launch process
column8: Participants will understand the ways Tiny Schools can be used to launch new school models in the charter, private, and traditional public school syst
column9: Participants will understand some of the key challenges and benefits for founders of new school models using the Tiny School process of development.

column1: We are all slave owners - what do we do about it?
column5: Mamie Gummer (Actress), Patrick  Gage (Carlson Hotels), Sarah-Jane Murray (Baylor University), Diana Mao (Nomi Network)
column6: There are 32 million slaves in the world today-- more than at any time in history, including even during the trans-Atlantic slave trade.Approximately 70 percent of the 32 million is attributed to labor trafficking. It is in the shirt you buy, coffee you drink and chocolate you eat.Join leaders across sector to hear what they are doing to fight human trafficking and modern day slavery. Moderator: Sarah-Jane MurrayPatrick Gage, Carlson HotelsBrooke Axtell, activist and survivorDiana Mao, Nomi NetworkMamie Gummer, actress
column7: Forms of human trafficking
column8: Different cross sector approaches to combating human trafficking
column9: How to combat human trafficking and modern day slavery

column1: What Schools & Startups Can Teach Each Other
column5: Charlie Coglianese (Schoolrunner), Bonnie Savage (Schoolrunner), Nicole Brenner (Collegiate Academies), Chris Hines (Crescent City Schools)
column6: The world_s smartest schools and smartest startups have more in common than you think. From building the perfect team to learning to fail fast, this panel explores what companies and schools can learn from one another in order to succeed.
column7: Best practices of bringing in school culture into tech startups
column8: What lessons can schools learn from a lean startup
column9: How can schools and startups create mutually educational relationships

column1: Why Higher Education Needs Rapid Prototyping
column5: Nick Ducoff (Northeastern University)
column6: People say, _Talk is cheap._ But when it comes to innovating in higher education, talk is expensive. The time we spend talking_plotting out meticulous plans, carefully aligned with governance processes_entrepreneurs are testing out the very hypotheses being discussed in abstract. Their nimbleness is allowing them to learn faster and for far less cash. Successful companies subscribe to a different doctrine. They _build, measure, learn__a formula colleges and universities can use to get ahead. How can you integrate rapid prototyping into your institution? What effect will it have on higher education? Let_s stop talking and make progress.
column7: Participants will discover how internal teams can bring innovation to higher education.
column8: Participants will develop a better understanding of why prototyping is important in higher education.
column9: Participants will learn how to articulate internally the value of prototyping.

column1: 21st century learning through Coding, Game-Design
column5: Mark Pavlyukovskyy (Piper), Robin Rath (PixelPress), Grant Hosford (Codespark), Deena Minwalla (co.lab)
column6: As the shift in education moves towards 21st century learning focusing on problem solving, design thinking and collaboration, games have become effective systems to address these skills.  Makerspaces provide hands-on learning environment where students can design, invent, build and create, but for some, they are expensive and complex. Alternatively games are being leveraged to teach kids to these skills.This panel brings together entrepreneurs developing learning games that explicitly teach coding, game-design and implicitly teach 21st century skills our children need to be successful.  This group will explore the unique role games play in the maker movement to promote 21st century learning.
column7: Assess how coding and game-design games help kids gain 21st century skills.
column8: Analyze how coding and game design games provide contextualized learning environments and allow kids to learn by doing.
column9: Understanding what the barriers are to bring 21st century learning games into the classroom and home.

column1: Contesting the test: game-based assessment
column5: Andreas Oranje (Educational Testing Service), Jodi Duron (Elgin Independent School District), Val Shute (Florida State University), Lindsay Grace (American University)
column6: There is a revolution unfolding in the land of Big Test. The people demand meaningful, richer information from engaging, intuitive experiences. A splinter group called Game Based Assessment is gaining popularity because their message resonates: blend principles of game design and cognitive science to create imaginary environments that adapt, challenge, and surprise while empowering the learner with evidence about their unique abilities. Revolutionaries, prove that you can do cool and credible at the same time!
column7: Find out what game based assessments (GBAs) are, what they are not, and how they differ from gamification and serious games.
column8: Learn how GBAs leverage intrinsic enjoyment to create compelling and engaging experiences that can hold up to standards for learning outcomes.
column9: Find out how GBAs are both shaping and responding to new goals for learning and assessment and take a glimpse into the future of assessment

column1: Deeper Game-Based Learning In and Out of Class
column5: Greg Toppo (USA Today), Peggy Sheehy (Suffern Middle School), Paul Darvasi (Royal St George's College), Jodi asbell-clarke (EdGE at TERC)
column6: Greg Toppo, author of The Game Believes in You brings together researchers and educators that are taking game-based learning (GBL) to the next level. Panelists include master educators who are transforming their practice using the games that kids play at home (e.g. World of Warcraft and Minecraft) as well as designers who are creating games with rich narrative and baked-in research methods to take game-based learning to the next level. The panelists will discuss what it takes to understand the learning that actually takes place in games and how to leverage in and out-of-school gameplay for rich and deeper classroom learning.
column7: The panel will discuss several different forms of GBL using a range from customized classroom games to commercial successes.
column8: The panel will discuss deeper implications of GBL for teaching - how to make bridges between game content and curricular content .
column9: The panel will discuss how game data logs can be used as formative assessments that can help teachers guide their practice.

column1: Does Digital Play Make Kids Smarter?
column5: Julie Shannan (Girlstart), Matt Frenz (GlassLab Games), Alex Klein (Kano Computing LTD.), Greg Toppo (USA Today)
column6: Want to learn? Start to play -- especially on the Internet, with Minecraft blocks or lines of code. Game-based learning is emerging into children_s daily lives and the educational institutions that surround us. Discover why and how this shift is taking place from the minds of those who are building and sharing it. This panel will discuss the advantages and challenges of game-based learning, how to implement it into the classroom and at home, and offer a forecast to what the future could look like.
column7: Learn about the advantages and challenges of game-based learning.
column8: Hear about the current impact of game-based learning, and what the future could look like.
column9: Understand how game mechanics are making products simpler, stickier, and more useful to beginners.

column1: Edu-gaming: Money, Morals and Games in Classrooms
column5: Jim Bower (Numedeon/Whyville), Louise Dube (iCivics), Lee Wilson (Filament Games), Alan Gershenfeld (eLine Media)
column6: This panel, moderated by Mitch Weisburgh, co-founder, Games4Ed, will explore various strategies to foster sustainable edugame development.  The panel will consider how learning game developers can fund classroom expansion leveraging such models as: sales to teachers/schools, app sales to parents, comprehensive curriculum, non-profit fundraising, sponsorships, and learning platforms. Using an ethical lens, the panel will reflect on what_s in the "teacher_s best interest" for adoption, including trade-offs between game quality and financial return.
column7: Game based learning evolution - will game based learning become a must-have core learning vs. a nice-to-have supplemental engagement?
column8: The ethical considerations raised in funding and building a market for game based learning through educational and consumer channels.
column9: What determines if a game is free, paid or freemium and the criteria educators can use to separate learning games from edutainment.

column1: Education @ Play: Level One
column5: Mark Blair (Douglas County School District (Colorado)), Chris Abbey (Douglas County School District (Colorado)), Brandon Peterson (Douglas County School District (Colorado))
column6: Join us as our group of adventurers explore the depths of implementing Game-Based/Game-Like Learning in a large North American School District, one classroom at a time. As a school district we are in early stages of collectively pursuing Game-Based Learning/Game-Like Learning as a support offering for our classroom educators, before and after school programs, and summer camps. We will share our lessons learned, pitfalls, areas of concerns and resources with this effort. Our panel will consist of members of the Douglas County School District's Professional Development, and School Technology and Innovation Team offering differing perspectives in delivery and support of this effort.
column7: Walk away with practical strategy for early integration of Game-Based Learning in the classroom.
column8: Empower students to seek out ways to leverage games to showcase their learning.
column9: Using games-based/game-like tools to stealthily assess student learning, and provide direct and recurring feedback.

column1: First Person Shooters vs. First Person Learning
column5: Rebecca Rufo-Tepper (Institute of Play), James Gee (Arizona State University), Greg Toppo (USA Today), Louise Dube (iCivics)
column6: By immersing them in content and concepts as active participants, games are changing children_s perspective of themselves as learners. They require students to see failure as learning and to leverage game rules vs. their own goals. They force them engage in model-based thinking, value collaboration, theory crafting, and collective intelligence -- and favor exploration, lateral thinking, and testing limits over routinized thinking, making effort and not luck as the basis of success. This panel will look at what_s working, what_s next approaches for reaching learners through games.
column7: How do games change how learners see themselves and change forms of interaction, collaboration, capacities and sense of self in classrooms?
column8: Students as _gamers_ can proactively contribute to teaching, learning, curriculum and classroom building -- and get teachers to think as designers
column9: The massive social interest driven systems of teaching, learning, modding and interaction built around games outside of school help reform classrooms.

column1: Games in the Classroom: The Boss Level
column5: Mat Frenz (GlassLab), Holly Miller (Sand Creek Elementary Student), Kristen DiCerbo (Pearson Research & Innovation Network), Greg Toppo (USA Today)
column6: Advocates of game-based learning for K-12 students cite the value of digital games to teach and reinforce skills that prepare students for college and career, such as collaboration, problem solving, creativity, and communication. However, many facets are untested and are not natural fits with the way classrooms work. This panel will debate the roles games can play in the classroom: the role of the teacher; personalization of content, and reporting on student learning.
column7: Understand when games are useful in the classroom
column8: Understand how and when to use games in the classroom to achieve instructional and learning goals
column9: Understand technology applications to make games more useful or practical for classroom teachers

column1: Gaming the System: Playful learning at school.
column5: Greg Toppo (USA Today), Kimberly Hiefte (Yale University), Alesha Bishop (Yogome), Alison Bryant (PlayScience)
column6: Educators, game developers, and others in the EdTech community are learning how to channel the power of gaming in the classroom and use it to help kids learn more effectively. In this session, you_ll learn about current research on games and education, including common misperceptions regarding games. You will learn more about how and why games work in the classroom. You will see concrete examples of games successfully used in the classroom, with data that supports their success. You will come away with new ideas for making any educational environment a more playful, engaging space _ for both teachers and students.
column7: Up-to-date knowledge of current research about gaming and education.
column8: Gain a better understanding of why and how games engage the brain to facilitate learning
column9: Concrete ideas for using games to enhance any educational environment

column1: Gotta beat Minecraft: How to co-design with kids
column5: Rachel Mercer (Made by Many), William Owen (Made by Many), Jon Marshall (MAP Project Office)
column6: Nowadays, we're competing for kids' attention between Netflix, YouTube, Angry Birds, and Minecraft - so it's incredibly important to take into consideration when designing software (or hardware) exactly what they want, need, and expect. Last year, a team of industrial engineers and software developers worked with kids to develop Hackaball, a smart ball with built-in sensors that detect motions like being dropped, bounced, shaken or held still. Through a paired app, kids as young as 6 can easily program and invent new games within seconds.  In this panel, we walk you through how we tested everything from longevity, to learning, to legibility with kids and their parents.
column7: Understand the co-design process; learning basic user research techniques and approaches specific to kids 12 and under
column8: Shared key learnings about kids expectations for educational products as shaped by current technology experiences and markets
column9: Shared techniques for testing experiences including: prototyping, interview processes, literacy tests, and more.

column1: Massive Online Learning Challenges
column5: Pamela Fox (Khan Academy), Alice Steinglass (Code.org), James Tynan (Khan Academy)
column6: The advent of free online learning platforms has enabled an entirely new teaching and learning tool. Massive Online Learning Challenges (MOLCs) are enabling students and teachers to compete and collaborate with millions of their peers.MOLCs can inspire students to tackle new concepts (think Hour of Code), and emerging pilots show they can also drive core academic improvements and transform student mindsets. However care is required when taking on MOLCs to avoid poorly structured incentives and to ensure equality of access.This session will be an inside look into three MOLCs, revealing data from Hour of Code, and math-based MOLC pilots in the US (Learnstorm) and Ireland (Mathletes).
column7: Participants will be able to distinguish between MOLCs and traditional learning competitions and explain the mechanics of a MOLC.
column8: Participants will be able to cite research and emerging pilot data showing the benefits of MOLCs in student agency, mindsets and academic outcomes.
column9: Participants will be able to outline potential drawbacks and dangers of MOLCs and pathways toward minimizing them.

column1: Zoombinis: Redux of a Popular Learning Game
column5: Scot Osterweil (Learning Games Network), Dr. Jodi Asbell-Clarke (EdGE at TERC), Gary Goldberger (FableVision Studios), David Libby (TERC)
column6: Zoombinis, the popular math & logic educational game, returns nearly 20 years after its 1996 release. Panelists reveal different insights on how to bring back an old favorite & how to measure and leverage game-based learning of computational thinking. How do you relaunch a successful product from the _90s & make it relevant for today_s generation? How do you leverage today_s research methods such as data mining to measure important learning in the game, such as computational thinking? How do you balance commercial impact with education for a popular learning game? Hear from designers, researchers, & developers to understand the choices that went into bringing back this popular learning game.
column7: The panel will show how the Zoombinis game experience supports STEM learning -- specifically math, logic, and computational thinking.
column8: Designers will discuss game and learning mechanics from the original 1990_s game, and how they were preserved in the 2015 version.
column9: Researchers will discuss how middle schoolers_ learning of computational thinking is measured in the game and supported in the classroom.

column1: A Year in EdTech Life: The Student Perspective
column5: Scott McQuiggan (SAS Institute, Inc), Jennifer Sabourin (SAS Institute, Inc), Lucy Kosturko (SAS Institute, Inc)
column6: We hear a lot from teachers and administrators about successful implementations of edtech, but what is the student experience really like? We_ve spent the past year following a diverse group of students across grade levels and tech implementations (1:1, BYOD, device carts). We_ll talk about what activities students find engaging, what components they remember and reflect upon, and what they think the biggest benefits and challenges of edtech in the classroom really are. We'll explore differences by grade level and type of tech implementation. We will also highlight areas where student experiences mirror those of their instructors, and places where they see things very differently.
column7: Participants will get a better understanding of the activities that students themselves find engaging, informative, and memorable.
column8: Participants will discuss and identify key differences in edtech experiences based on the type of classroom implementation (1:1, BYOD, device carts).
column9: Participants will discuss differences in teacher and student experiences and the underlying reasons behind these differences.

column1: Adapting "Adaptive Learning" for Real Schools
column5: Lisette Alves (Miami-Dade County Public Schools), Sandy Bartle Finocchi (Carnegie Learning), Julia Freeland (Clayton Christensen Institute), Steven Ritter (Carnegie Learning)
column6: Adaptive learning is all about adjusting to the differences between students. But traditional schools are organized around a group instruction model. There are benchmark exams, pacing guides and other constraints on how students can progress through a curriculum. The role of teachers changes when each student follows his or her own path.This panel will present research, policy and practitioner perspectives on how traditional school environments can balance institutional requirements and instructional practices to best support personalized learning that adapts to each student's abilities and preferences.
column7: Gain insight into the benefits of adaptive learning, but also the challenges for implementation in traditional schools
column8: Gain practical insights into how to make adaptive learning work in real classrooms
column9: Understand the policy and institutional challenges involved in implementing true adaptive learning.

column1: An EdTech Love Story: Developing with Educators
column5: John Ruff (ScribeSense), Craig Crisler (ScribeSense), Rene Sanchez (Cesar E. Chavez High School), Craig Shapiro (Crockett High School)
column6: As an educator, how many times have you used a software or technology supposedly developed with teachers and students in mind and been disappointed? Do you feel frustrated that the technology you currently use seems like it was not developed with an educator in mind?This panel discusses the impact of a collaborative approach to edtech development among all parties, from students to educators to developers. By elaborating on a real co-developed edtech product, we will discuss the power educators have in development & focusing on building connections between developers and end users. Participants will get empowered to be active partners in their own edtech development and outcomes.
column7: Understand the benefits of active engagement between edtech used (administrators, teachers, parents, and students) and developers.
column8: Recognize the dynamics of power among edtech developers and edtech users, highlighting the benefits of a collaborative approach.
column9: Possess actionable items to begin to create a meaningful dialogue with your own edtech developer and end users.

column1: Are We Helping Teachers to Personalize Learning?
column5: Rebecca Wolfe (Jobs for the Future), Charlote Danielson (The Danielson Group), Carmen Coleman (Center for Innovation in Education), Mary-Dean Barringer (Council of Chief State School Officers)
column6: As schools adopt competency-based, personalized, student-centered learning models that are more responsive to the needs of every child, teachers must interact in new ways with students, peers, and the broader community. But to what extent are educator development systems already addressing the unique mindsets and skills that these teachers need? What processes and resources are already in place to do so, and what are still needed? Guided by a  moderator, three field luminaries with varying perspectives and experiences will engage in friendly debate, share recently-released resources, and point to pathways forward.
column7: Understand the mindsets, skills, and abilities the educator workforce will need to thrive and help drive the transformation to personalized learning
column8: Identify where/how these skills are included in existing models of teacher quality, such as the Framework for Teaching and InTASC Teaching Standards
column9: Discuss current and potential changes to educator preparation, licensure, induction, PD, and evaluation to help build personalized learning teachers

column1: Beaba - Demystifying Cancer Through Design
column5: Jean Boechat (Beaba), Elisa Sassi (Elisa Sassi), Simone Mozzilli (Beaba)
column6: What is a catheter? How is chemo given? Myelo what?The oncological world is a parallel universe, made of white smocks, masks and many discoveries. Despite the large amount of information available today, they do not have quality. So we join patients, doctors and creative entrepreneurs to found Beaba, a nonprofit organization with the mission to demystify this environment, presenting information about cancer and its treatments in a way that is clear, objective and optimistic through design and information technology.
column7: The importance of adequate information.
column8: Sometimes, illustrations are better than the reality.
column9: Information still is the best way to save lives.

column1: Better Together: Collaborating for Student Success
column5: Tom Warmbrodt (Civitas Learning), Steve Hill (University of Texas System, Institute for Transformational Learning), Marni Baker Stein (University of Texas System, Institute for Transformational Learning), Phil Komarny (Robots and Pencils Inc.)
column6: A transformational educational model requires a different kind of technology solution. The University of Texas System has partnered with cutting-edge ed tech companies to create TEx, the Total Educational Experience. This ecosystem of technology and services was designed to support innovative competency-based initiatives across the UT System. With the launch of the first competency-based program at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley in Fall 2015, the panel will explore the successes, challenges and lessons learned from the first class of students to enroll in this first-of-its-kind hybrid program.
column7: Give insight into both the university and vendor perspectives of designing and building a new hybrid degree program through technology.
column8: Discuss how technology is being used to support goals of increased completion rates, increased student engagement and accelerated time to degrees.
column9: Explore the needs and problems driving the creation of this nontraditional model and plans to scale across multiple campuses.

column1: Building the Modern Student Support Continuum
column5: Amanda Mulfinger (Penn State World Campus), Pete  Wheelan (Inside Track), Sharon van Wyk (Tutor.com and The Princeton Review)
column6: The advising office and on-campus tutoring center have historically led student success initiatives on campus. As online education and technology play an ever-larger role, new solutions are supplementing the traditional _offline_ approach to student success. Online tutoring systems and other innovative solutions are creating a new student support continuum in online and residential higher education. But as the tools become more sophisticated, schools are seeing integration challenges. What is the return on investment for retention and graduation rates? How does each part of the equation work together? This panel focuses on strategies to create a seamless support system in this new landscape.
column7: Understand the landscape for new student success solutions in higher education
column8: Explore the elements and structure of a student support continuum
column9: Discuss strategies for implementation and best practices of student success initiatives
column10: higher education, student success, advising, tutoring

column1: Can Public Money Help Higher Ed Innovation?
column5: Martha Snyder (HCM Strategists), Juliet Garc¡a (University of Texas Americas Institute), Teresa Lubbers (Indiana Commissioner for Higher Education), Paul LeBlanc (Southern New Hampshire University)
column6: An organic discussion on how higher education institutions, policymakers and entrepreneurs can leverage public funding to encourage innovation.  Leading experts will discuss the state and federal funding levers that can be either opportunities or barriers to innovation in the field. Once these are identified, panel and audience members will discuss what actions institutions, policy makers and the innovators who want to work with them can pursue. The panel will include an interactive quiz at the outset and audience Q&A at the conclusion of the session.
column7: Understanding breadth of finance policy levers available to promote innovation in higher education.
column8: Identify which of these levers are opportunities and which are barriers to innovations.
column9: Outline a specific course of action that institutions, policymakers and entrepreneurs can pursue to improve how public financing supports innovation.

column1: Design Matters! Transforming Curriculum Delivery
column5: Lisa Katz (Howard County Public Schools), William Barnes (Howard County Public Schools), Julie Wray (Howard County Public Schools)
column6: Design Matters! Transforming K-12 Curriculum from Paper to Digital DeliveryThis session will explore how the Howard County Public School System's process and vision for digital learning innovation and design. The presenters will share how the ADDIE process and design thinking is being used to design and transform paper curriculum to digital delivery.  Presenters will highlight and share the instructional design process, responsive design templates, user feedback and lessons learned from implementation.
column7: Develop an understanding of the use of ADDIE and design thinking to influence the design of user experience for digital curriculum delivery.
column8: Explore design templates and strategies one school system used to transform curriculum from static paper to interactive online content.
column9: Explore the lessons learned from an accelerated roll out and implementation of digital curriculum with 5,000 educators and administrators

column1: Designing the Future of Healthcare
column5: Bon Ku (Thomas Jefferson University), Jose Gomez-Marquez (MIT), Joyce Lee (University of Michigan), Brian  McIntire (Think Brownstone)
column6: There has been a growing interest in using designers and design thinking within healthcare. Health systems are seeing the value in human-centered design to improve patient outcomes. In Feb 2015, Sidney Kimmel Medical College became the first medical school in the U.S. to launch a design thinking curriculum specifically for medical students. Learn how designers brought a new framework to problem-solving in healthcare. This diverse panel will share forward-thinking strategies for introducing design to students in health professions and healthcare providers. The panel will focus on incorporating DIY health technologies and human-centered design to improve patient experience and outcomes.
column7: Understand how design methodology can be used to solve healthcare challenges.
column8: Identify key factors for success and pitfalls in teaching design in a healthcare context.
column9: Learn how students and care providers can redesign health services, systems and medical devices.

column1: Do you know how ed tech is really used?
column5: Liane Wardlow (Pearson Research & Innovation Network), Aubrey Francisco (Digital Promise), Toyia Matthews (Irwin Academic Center), Gail Moran (Del Mar Union School District)
column6: Technology has the potential to fundamentally change instruction. However, related hype tends to focus on best case scenarios even though it is not clear that investments in technology have led to radical changes in instructional practice for most teachers. There is a mismatch between the promise and expectations of technology to act as a change agent and the ways it's actually used. This panel will discuss how technology is actually used and what steps we can take to spur innovation and change.
column7: Learn the most common uses of ed tech and how they match with the expected benefits
column8: Get advice on how to make the most of ed tech investments
column9: Learn the challenges--from a variety of demographics--faced when using instructional technology and how they break down barriers to foster change

column1: EdTech On a Shoe String Budget
column5: Brett Lee (Austin Independent School District), Jenell Paul (Texas Department of Family and Protective Services), Shetay Ashford (Technology 4 Life Institute)
column6: In this panel session, participants will learn about low-cost and cost-neutral approaches to implementing educational technology solutions in school districts, community-based settings, and governmental entities.  Specifically, participants will have an opportunity to explore and discuss practical examples of educational technology solutions in each sector using real-life organizations.  Participants will be introduced the AIDE process, which will serve as a roadmap to operationalizing and implementing educational technology in their own organizations.
column7: Learn various low-cost educational technology (edtech) solutions
column8: Develop an awareness of the usage of low-cost educational technology (edtech) in schools, community-based organizations, and government agencies
column9: Obtain resources for low-cost implementation and support of educational technology (edtech) solutions

column1: Effectively Preparing Students for the Workplace
column5: Kate Kazin (Southern New Hampshire University), Pete Wheelan (InsideTrack), Jim Deters (Galvanize), Candice Olson (Fullbridge)
column6: Students will average an astounding 27 jobs over the course of their lifetimes. Add to that the fact that another 30% will be part time, freelance or contract employees _ and you can begin to see just how seismic a shift is underway. The gap between college and career has never been wider and higher education institutions are feeling the pressure to better prepare their students. In this panel, we will take a look at how the gap between college and career began, what solutions are currently being implemented, and what the future of work could look like. Candice Olson, CEO of Fullbridge, will chat with executives from InsideTrack and Galvanize about how we can find a solution.
column7: Define the gap between college and career, why it exists, why it didn't exist before, and how we can work towards closing it
column8: Understand tangible solutions for preparing students for the modern workplace before, during, and after college
column9: Envision the future world of work. What are 21st century roles and responsibilities? What kind of competences are the most pressing and universal?

column1: Engaging industry and community for K20 innovation
column5: Mark Barnett (SASTEMIC), Jeff Branson (SparkFun Education), Michael DeGraff (UTeach Institute)
column6: UTeach is a secondary STEM teacher prep program that started at UT Austin in 1997 and has since been established in 44 universities across the country. In this panel we will discuss pathways for scaleable innovation in teacher preparation involving a large number of stakeholders with various motivations, resources, constraints, and passions. The main focus of the panel will be on two new initiatives to connect pre-service teachers to the burgeoning maker movement in education, something the NMC Horizon Report asserts is 2-3 years to adoption in higher ed. With this movement still a few years away in higher ed, how do we prepare future teachers for the spaces that already exist in K12?
column7: How can teacher prep programs work together to prepare teachers for a changing educational landscape?
column8: How can individuals, industry, and community leaders help prepare future teachers to teach in a way that reflects what we know about how people learn?
column9: How is the maker movement being adopted in the K-12 setting vs. institutions of higher education and what does that mean for future teachers?

column1: Engaging Students in the Fight Against Cancer
column5: Kristen Brewer (Girls' School of Austin), Iram Leon (Self-Employed), Ruth Rechis (LIVESTRONG Foundation)
column6: Talking with children about cancer is an increasingly common challenge for adults around the world.  Research shows that parents, school professionals, and other adults want developmentally appropriate support to help children cope with a cancer diagnosis and treatment; yet finding trusted resources to help children is challenging.  Through a multidisciplinary collaboration, we leveraged the strengths of partners from different fields to create a program that can facilitate age-appropriate education about cancer, empower adults to help children cope when a person they care about has cancer or another serious illness and empower children to take positive actions in the fight against cancer.
column7: Attendees will learn about research that demonstrates the importance of facilitating honest, age-appropriate communication with children about cancer.
column8: School professionals will increase their knowledge of resources to facilitate honest, age-appropriate communication with children about cancer.
column9: School professionals will feel more confident about ways to engage students of all ages in the fight against cancer.

column1: Finding Success in an Online Student Publication
column5: Dustin Binnicker (Canyon Vista Middle School), Kara Wilkinson (Canyon Vista Middle School)
column6: "Those who tell the stories rule the world." -Hopi American Indian proverb.The importance of journalism in middle school is often understated. This session goes over the best practices on how to create young storytellers, how to tell the story of your school each year in an engaging way, and how your publication can serve as a source of school pride. Speakers are educators and students who will share an award-winning publication that has demonstrated success. Audience members will leave inspired with easily-duplicated ideas, to take back to their school.
column7: Understand the importance of journalism in middle school while addressing the purpose of the class and how to set the day-to-day schedule.
column8: Learn how to motivate a student-led staff that produces quality content, worth publishing.
column9: Gain ideas on how to promote your publication and get tips on web hosting, video hosting, editing programs, social media, etc.

column1: Forging and sustaining great partnerships
column5: Bryan Twarek (San Francisco Unified School District), Brenda Darden Wilkerson (Chicago Public Schools), Heather King (Outlier Research & Evaluation), Alexandra Vlachakis (Code.org)
column6: Most educational initiatives partner with local- and state-level organizations to scale success. But engaging effectively with districts -- short and long-term -- can be tricky at best and downright frustrating at worst. In this interactive discussion, you_ll first hear from the three stakeholders in a district-partnership relationship: a non-profit seeking to partner with districts, a district administrator striving for a successful program, and an academic researcher evaluating effectiveness. You_ll learn best practices derived from real-world successful and disastrous district partnerships and discuss how to build your own.
column7: Explore best practices for creating and sustaining effective partnerships between organizations and districts
column8: Discuss the good, the bad and the ugly of district partnership models
column9: Review research on district partnership impact and effectiveness

column1: Freedom & Flexibility: How Fulton Schools Innovate
column5: Korynn  Schooley (Fulton County Schools), Mahnaz Charania (Fulton County Schools)
column6: What do we mean by _innovation_ and how can a district loosen the reigns to allow schools to innovate? In Fulton County Schools, Georgia_s largest charter district, we_ve begun to tackle these questions with promising success. Innovation in our district means identifying a new strategy or process to tackle an identified problem. It_s not innovation for the sake of innovation, but to help us meet our mission of supporting student success. How do we break the mold and support schools to innovation? The answer comes down to a structured program evaluation process that allows for continuous feedback and improvement and a warning bell if the strategy isn't having the intended impact.
column7: Discuss how a charter school district approach can use accountability and flexibility to accelerate the use of innovation in schools
column8: Learn about the role of School Governance Councils in creating a system of community-level collaboration personalized to students
column9: Understand the Fulton County Program Evaluation Strategy and how it is used to support schools in tracking their progress towards impacting student

column1: Going Global - Creative School Turnaround Strategy
column5: Antigone Peek (William H. Owen Elementary School), Helen Soule (P21, the Partnership for 21st Century Learning), David  Young (VIF International Education)
column6: Can going global be a successful school turnaround strategy and set schools on the path to 21st century learning? You bet! Find out how building a globally focused, student-centered engagement strategy combined with a global curriculum, a technology enabled environment and a robust professional learning community can result in impactful student outcomes for struggling communities.  P21 and VIF International Education bring together a panel of expert education leaders to share their stories of how going global helped their students be college, career and globally ready.
column7: Inspire participants to use global competence as a focus around which to build a successful school turnaround or school improvement plan.
column8: Share on-the-ground perspectives of global education as a powerful turnaround strategy for schools and engagement strategy for students and teachers.
column9: Share concrete strategies for creating technology enabled, global learning environments from P21_s exemplar schools network.

column1: GoPro Video in the Elementary Classroom
column5: Wendy  Shanafelt (Lake Travis Elementary), David Garcia (Lake Travis Elementary), Chareese Hatfield (Lake Travis Elementary), Amelia Moya (Lake Travis Elementary )
column6: As part of a grant pilot program, four elementary classrooms received a GoPro camera and grips to enhance the learning experience in a Title One school. The four panelists (two third grade and two fifth grade teachers) will share how their students used the devices to personalize their response to learning in both bilingual and general education classrooms. We will share student products, videos in lessons, and other invented uses of the GoPro cameras discovered so far this year. We would also love to hear your ideas of using video in the classroom as well as answer any questions.
column7: Share how students and teachers use GoPro cameras in the classroom.
column8: Demonstrate how video enhances student ownership and rigor of responses to content.
column9: Promote video as a tool to level the playing field for all students, regardless of language or economic background.

column1: Help Wanted: Education Innovators Needed
column5: Heather Anichini (The Chicago Public Education Fund), CPS Educators (Chicago Public Schools), Amy Vreeland (True School ), Amy  Huang (LEAP Innovations)
column6: Educator-led innovation has been the key to the groundbreaking improvements in student outcomes in Chicago over the past few years. By utilizing innovative concepts to develop an innovation-focused mindset, investing in whole-school transformation, and facilitating a relationship between educators and edtech entrepreneurs, leaders in the Chicago education ecosystem have created an environment for educators to develop high- and low-tech solutions to school and classroom challenges. The panelists have been pivotal in creating this ecosystem and investing in educator-led innovations.
column7: Convey the necessity of a shared vision and collaboration among all key stakeholders to sustain and scale meaningful change in education
column8: Highlight the importance, effectiveness and sustainability of educator-led innovation
column9: Give educators an opportunity to reflect on what makes an ecosystem effective in fostering innovation

column1: How do we know edtech works?
column5: Katrina Stevens (US DOE Dept of Ed Tech), Steve Ross (Johns Hopkins), Steve Hodas (Digital Promise), Eileen Rudden (LearnLaunch Institute)
column6: Educators want to select edtech tools which are research-based and have evidence of student learning.  Random control trials are expensive and often out of reach of early stage edupreneurs.  A new movement for _short cycle_ trials is trying to research digital courseware use  and analyze student learning gains .  What has been learned from this approach?
column7: Who is doing short cycle trials and how they are structured?
column8: What has been learned from this approach?
column9: How can it be applied by schools or districts?

column1: How Do We Track Which School Models Are Effective?
column5: Michael Horn (Clayton Christensen Institute), Mary Jo Madda (edsurge.com), Pam Moran (Albemarle County Public Schools), Alex Hernandez (Charter School Growth Fund)
column6: Microschools. Charters. "Innovation" zones. Chances are, you've read about these newer school models in the news. In most cases, these spaces are purported to give educators and administrators a place to experiment with teaching and learning. And even in the straight public school system, practices from makerspaces to virtual learning offer districts the opportunity to see how students learn in spaces beyond four-walled classrooms. But are these new models resulting in positive results for students, and how are we tracking whether or not these experiments are taking the hold we want them to? In fact, what is the end goal in mind--do we need one before we launch these experimental models?
column7: The general audience will hear and take away school model case studies (private, district public & charter) that account for student progress.
column8: Educators will consider and take away best practices in designing schools while backwards planning for student success.
column9: Administrators and school designers will recognize the merits and setbacks of elements of school model design.

column1: How I Implemented Digital Learning at Scale
column5: Dallas Dance (Baltimore County Public Schools ), Scott Drossos (McGraw-Hill Education ), JD Solomon (District Administrator )
column6: Many school districts have uneven transitions to ed tech, leaving administrators and community members looking for answers to the question: _what defines success and how will a district know it_s attaining success when moving from a status quo, paper-driven organization to a more progressive and engaging digital school system?_ Technology has the potential to redefine K-12 education and provide an unprecedented opportunity to improve outcomes. While technology will continue to advance in education, many districts still struggle with how to implement and use technology to re-engineer the learning experience. The stakes are high and moving the achievement needle for students is critical.
column7: To debate whether it is necessary to provide teachers with structured and unstructured digital content.
column8: How to create a digital learning environment that is accessible anytime and anywhere.
column9: How to fund teacher training to support new digital instructional practices.

column1: How Open Tech Standards Drive Student Achievement
column5: George Perreault (ClassLink), Barbara Nesbitt (Pickens School District), Jesus  Jara (Orange County Public Schools), Berj Akian (ClassLink)
column6: This panel will showcase the success they have achieved by leveraging open technology standards, providing a seamless experience for end users and letting educators get on with the business of teaching. Because access to the disparate platforms is cumbersome and frustrating, teachers and students need a better way to unlock the potential of a technology rich learning environment. Attendees in this session will take away specific examples of how open technology standards create safe, secure, and equitable access to the resources that matter most.
column7: Understand the challenges teachers face implementing a digital curriculum, and how open standards can help.
column8: Learn which open tech standards impact student achievement.
column9: Hear from districts that are using open standards to improve access to digital resources.

column1: How to Do Competency-Based Education Right
column5: Bobby Blanchard (The Dallas Morning News), Lisa Myers (Texas A&M University-Texarkana), Judith Sebesta (Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board), Mary Hendrix (Texas A&M University-Commerce)
column6: At colleges and universities around the country, there is an increasing interest in "competency-based education," in which credit is awarded based a students' demonstrated mastery of a skill rather than for the amount of time they sit in class. However, making the switch to this model can be more difficult than it sounds and there is a significant gap in the research on best practices for implementing it. In 2015, the Texas Legislature approved the creation of an Institute of Competency-Based. Individuals involved in its creation, along with other leaders in the field, will discuss what is known_and what they hope to learn_about this innovative approach.
column7: Share informative success stories and lessons learned from efforts to implement competency-based education at traditional universities
column8: Examine the currently available data on competency-based education and discuss what it might indicate about the future of the field.
column9: Discuss which areas and concepts require further research in order to make sure we are using best practices

column1: How to Make a Play in Competency-Based Education
column5: Valerie Truesdale (Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools), Morgan Hall (District of Columbia Public Schools), Pat Deklotz (Kettle Moraine School District)
column6: Schools across the country are recognizing that time spent in class does not necessarily equate to mastery of skills. Especially with the presence of technology, learning no longer needs to be confined to a time and place.In this panel discussion you will hear from three school districts making different plays to enable students to drive their learning, at their own pace, toward meeting defined competencies. They will share their experiences thus far, lessons learned, and the next plays they plan to make. If you_re interested in how to develop, advance, or refine a school model that is personalized and student-centered, this session is for you.
column7: How to build an understanding of CBE among stakeholders in order to use their inputs to construct a working model of CBE tailored to your students.
column8: How to scale CBE and build on models of flexible paces and pathways that may exist in pockets in your district.
column9: How to refine a CBE model and transition from learning targets to competencies so students can take ownership of their learning.

column1: iMade It: In-Class iPhone Video Projects
column5: Megan  Gaitan  (The University of the Incarnate Word - Communications Department), Charlie  Young (Alamo Colleges ), Maegan Pena (The University of the Incarnate Word - Communications Department)
column6: What is the most typical classroom rule no matter what grade you_re in? No cellphones. However, what if there is a class that actually requires you to have your phone out? Sounds like an alternate universe, but the objective of the class is to use your iPhone to make short, crisp and dynamic video projects that can be compared to DSLR quality work and the techniques that you learned can be later used in real and professional life.
column7: Camera basics such as aperture, shutter speed, ISO and simple recording tips that improves video quality for an iPhone video project.
column8: To give information about additional iPhone applications and technical equipment that could be used to enhance the quality of your video projects.
column9: To demonstrate basic techniques when editing within an iPhone and to introduce software to complete videos.

column1: Improving 3D printing workflow to boost learning
column5: Charles Wapner (American Library Association), Chris Walker (Element Robot LLC), Kathlin Ray (University of Nevada, Reno)
column6: 3D printing is taking off in libraries, schools and universities, expanding opportunities for creative learning and expression. But one of the biggest obstacles to helping all people benefit from this trend is a lack of capacity in these institutions _ in terms of physical space, equipment, technical know-how, broadband capacity and person power. How can these learning centers lead everyone onto the 3D printing on-ramp without creating a logjam? It's possible! Hear from a panel of burning souls from across the 3D printing world who have dedicated blood, sweat and tears to advancing the 3D revolution.
column7: Learn strategies for providing 3D printing in your library or education institution on a limited budget and with limited resources.
column8: Learn how to accomodate a large and growing number of users of your library or education institution's 3D equipment.
column9: Learn about specific networking solutions that can help your users seamlessly complete 3D printing projects.

column1: Innovations at the K12-Higher Ed Math Transition
column5: Pam Campbell (San Jacinto College District), Bill Holda (Kilgore College), Rey Garcia (Texas Association of Community Colleges), Monette McIver (The Charles A. Dana Center at the University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Pioneering leaders in Texas are working to improve higher education outcomes through innovations in high school transition courses and developmental mathematics education. Preliminary results of the New Mathways Project offer promise and are garnering national attention. These leaders are taking a comprehensive approach to improvement through systemic level initiatives that foster strong vertical alignment and the modernization of mathematics content. Come hear more about efforts to ensure a more successful transition from K12 through postsecondary putting students on a more direct path towards college completion.
column7: Participants will learn about the modernization of mathematics content and its implications for a smooth transition from high school to college.
column8: Participants will explore promising solutions like the New Mathways Project - a systemic and comprehensive approach to re-imagining developmental ed.
column9: Participants will gain a better understanding of historic developmental education mathematics and opportunities for improving it.

column1: Midwest STEM Alliance - Making a Difference!
column5: Steven Triplett (ACT), Paul  Ainslie (I-STEM Resource Network), Martha McCabe (Kansas City STEM Alliance), Jeff Weld (Iowa Governor's STEM Advisory Council)
column6: The Midwest STEM Alliance consists of STEM leaders from eleven Midwestern states and has garnered interest from STEM leaders across the country. The Alliance leaders work together to share best practices within their respective states and to overcome challenges. The goal within each state is to provide outstanding learning opportunities for students in the STEM arena. Members of the panel will share information about initiatives such as successful education/business partnerships,scale-up programs, connecting schools with industry, and implementing viable assessments and rubrics designed to validate program effectiveness. Audience interaction is encouraged.
column7: Provide an overview of collaborative efforts within the Midwest region to enhance STEM opportunities for all students.
column8: Discuss challenges and opportunities facing STEM leaders in building collaborative relationships with educators, business leaders, and legislators.
column9: Review how data assessment has become a critical component of STEM planning, efforts, programs, and sustainability.

column1: Modern Blanket Toss
column5: Mark Standley (Educating4Leadership), John Monahan (University of Alaska Fairbanks, Upward Bound), Pamela Lloyd (General Communications, Inc (GCI))
column6: Alaska EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) is helping students in five Alaska high schools to reach new heights.Together with Alaska Upward Bound, EPSCoR is administering _The Modern Blanket Toss,_ a program through which high school students perform experiments using unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The goal of the project is to increase the students_ interest in STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) fields as they undertake projects that are useful to their communities._We named this project after the Native tradition of the blanket toss, which enabled people to expand their horizons beyond their immediate surroundings,_ said Dr. John Monahan, Dire
column7: Program participants will be exposed to the possibilities of involving Unmanned Arial Vehicles (UAVs) in a wide variety of educational settings.
column8: Program participants will understand that you don't have to be an expert in quadcopters to use these high interest, learning magnets in the classroom.
column9: Program participants will hear numerous examples of ways that UAVs can be incorporated into the curriculum and used as positive community projects.

column1: Modern Social Studies: New Standards, New Tools
column5: Christine Sciascia (Mark Twain IS 239), DC Vito (The LAMP), Louise Dube (iCivics), Eric Contreras (New York City Dept of Ed)
column6: Social studies education provides a framework in which to develop a student's role in society. It is woven into literacy, civics, geography, history, and current events and provides a foundation for how students understand the world. But, are today_s students making these connections? Eric Contreras, developer of NYC_s new social studies curriculum, hosts a discussion with educators and nonprofit content creators who are re-imagining the social studies landscape to make this powerful subject more relevant and accessible to students through modern resources. Participants will have the opportunity to engage with the panelists and will receive supplemental materials and a list of resources.
column7: Knowledge of a variety of resources to use in social studies classrooms, including standards-aligned tools and strategies and across curricula.
column8: How to support development of engaging tools and content that helps students connect social studies to their lives inside and outside the classroom.
column9: Understanding of new developments in teaching and learning social studies, including how teachers can maximize their time and existing resources.

column1: _	Nurturing good college & career decision-making
column5: Clare  Bertrand (Jobs for the Future), Alvaro Aguila (LA CAUSA YouthBuild ), Olga  Merchan (YouthBuild USA), Elizandro  Umana (LA CAUSA YouthBuild)
column6: Studies show that when young people receive counseling that bridges college and career, they make better decisions about which postsecondary program of study they enter and are more likely to graduate. This panel will focus on how to put this career-connected postsecondary guidance into practice; discuss best approaches for supporting historically underserved, off-track young people in making postsecondary decisions that fit their academic and career goals; and share tools and resources (both digital and face-to-face) that can help counselors & educators implement these student-centered approaches.
column7: Understand how a _research & verify_ student-centered approach to college & career counseling can both engage students and build necessary skills.
column8: Hear in detail about how this counseling approach is being implemented at LA CAUSA YouthBuild in Los Angeles and other programs across the country.
column9: Consider _blended_ approaches to counseling that integrate tech and youth development principles.

column1: Our 1:1 Journey and the Culture of _Yes_
column5: Manuel Herrera (Affton School District), Adam  Jasinski (Affton School District), Valerie Bush (Affton School District)
column6: Before any laptop is purchased or any tablet is synced there are decisions, discussions, shifts and outside partnerships that should be occurring at every level of your district. You will hear from various stakeholder voices in one district and how their roles impacted the success of a 1:1 implementation. They will review the steps taken to effectively implement change that positively impacted the culture and created an environment of continuous improvement.
column7: Logistics and planning for a successful 1-1 implementation
column8: Changing culture to have a positive impact on learning
column9: Understanding the importance of student voice in the decision making process

column1: Parental Engagement & Creating STEM Communities
column5: Martin  Storksdieck (Center for Research on Lifelong STEM Learning), Heather B.  Weiss (Harvard Family Research Project), Amy  Kim (Iridescent)
column6: How do we better engage parents in STEM education? How do we create stronger STEM communities and ecosystems? In this session, panelists from diverse settings -- including the Harvard Family Research Project, a national science and engineering education non-profit, and the Center for Research on Lifelong STEM Learning -- will discuss their experiences engaging the entire family in STEM learning and offer insights for ways to engage and support parents in particular. This panel will focus on how to leverage parents_ influence as role models for their children in teaching 21st century skills as well as STEM concepts.
column7: Discuss how to engage parents in their children_s STEM education in the face of intimidation and unfamiliarity with STEM.
column8: Ways to inspire and prepare parents to lead their children_s education, with consideration of limited resources of many parents.
column9: Creating STEM communities with parents, teachers, scientists, engineers and children through mutual learning models.

column1: Pilot Teachers: The Wright way to fly
column5: Alik Cummings (I.S. 383 Philippa Schuyler), Steve McWade (Lovett Elementary School), Mariana Garcia Serrato (Herman Intermediate (Oak Grove School District))
column6: Teacher leaders in edtech pilots from across the country explain how to fly a plane while a company is building it and the district is trying to land it. What is the teacher role in R&D or evaluation?  When should companies and districts problem-solve and when do they need to sit down and listen? How do teachers claim their voice in a high-stakes pilot process? Teachers, come to learn from peers to improve your pilot practice. Edtech companies, district admin, and school leaders, come to understand how your decisions play out in the air.
column7: Hear how small choices can have a big impact on pilot outcomes.
column8: Learn how teachers navigate competing priorities, integrating promising edtech tools into their practice while keeping students first.
column9: Discuss how all partners can communicate what they really need for a successful pilot.

column1: PISA's Failed Club: Are Startups the Answer?
column5: ADOLFO SµNCHEZ (Colombian Ministry of Education), DANIEL RINCON (Tutorya)
column6: We will discuss how startups are becoming an alternatives to face the educational crisis within countries with the lowest results on PISA Results. Special focus will go to Latin American initiatives because this region captures almost all the slots at the bottom of the table. Besides the traditionally expected changes in public policies and a long list of announcements about _revolutionary_ educational programs claimed by governments during decades, we point toward what students, young professionals, common people propose and develop almost from scratch. Society_s concern about education could be the final answer.
column7: Recognize the the characteristics of Latin American educational systems and the focus of public policy in recent years.
column8: Learn what startups with remarkably limited resources are creating and implementing to improve the quality of education at the worst ranked countries.
column9: Identify scope results, limitations and feasibility of local startups leading the educational transformation.

column1: Promises and Perils of Open Learning for Kids
column5: Mimi  Ito (UC Irvine), Sarah Otts (Scratch), Tara Brown (Connected Camps), Chalon Bridges (DIY)
column6: How do you build a safe, open online learning community for kids? Learning thrives when kids have the agency to connect, collaborate, and share. With this comes unique challenges in maintaining a safe and friendly environment for kids with diverse backgrounds and interests. Hear from educators and community organizers from Scratch, DIY.org, and Connected Camps about the benefits and challenges of nurturing large scale open creative learning communities.
column7: Access: Why are interest-based pathways into coding valuable for increasing equity and access?
column8: Resources: What strategies create and support online learning communities that are kid-friendly, and welcoming to kids with diverse interests?
column9: Application: How can these strategies and resources be applied in both online and physical  learning environments?

column1: Protecting Student Privacy in the Digital World
column5: Thelma Almuena (Columbia Elementary), George Phillip (Stanley Clark School), Jennifer Carey (Ransom Everglades School), Ana Albir (Drawp Entertainment)
column6: With ubiquitous classroom technology, students_ privacy is an increasing concern. Federal laws, such as the Children_s Online Privacy Protection Act and the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act, are difficult to navigate but vital to protecting students_ rights. This panel will focus on demystifying the process, providing key strategies for lawfully implementing technology, and looking to the future of technology and education. Panelists include technology and school administrative leaders (at both public and private schools) as well as a software developer for PK-elementary tools.
column7: Gain an understanding of current Federal Privacy Laws that apply to schools.
column8: Understand how to vet and implement technology tools in schools.
column9: Understand the direction that privacy and educational technology will take in the future.

column1: Quality Matters: Building an Educator CMS
column5: Leslie Schneider (Amplify), Frank  Walsh (Amplify)
column6: How do you create a Content Management System (CMS) that guarantees high quality content that will benefit educators?  How do you maintain the system so that new content continues to be submitted and posted?There are many CMSs available to educators, but oftentimes the content is not high quality and cannot be used.  This session offers educators an opportunity to see for themselves how CMS can be created that guarantees high quality resources that will benefit educators, and ultimately, students.
column7: How to establish standards by which content can be judged
column8: How to establish a process for submitting, reviewing and providing feedback on resources
column9: How to continue to grow the CMS

column1: Robotics: The New Lettered Sport
column5: Morgan Smith (Texas Tribune), John  Sperry (Anderson High School, AISD ), John Graff  (National Instruments ), Ray  Almgren (FIRST in Texas)
column6: Textbooks and theory will always be in science and engineering education, but they shouldn_t be the only experience. If we want to inspire students in STEM and prepare them for future jobs, we have to provide hands-on experiences to keep them motivated. With the demand for impactful STEM programming in schools at an all-time high, states are starting to make robotics an official after-school program, similar to other popular programs. This panel of experts represents the tech industry, robotics and education. They will discuss the challenges and benefits of implementing competitive robotics programs state-wide and address how to keep the _robotics as a lettered sport_ movement going strong.
column7: What are the short- and long-terms benefits of students participating in robotics programs?
column8: What barriers exist to implementing competitive robotics programs as official after-school programs? How can we overcome these challenges?
column9: What are some best practices for states to follow in order to officially adopt competitive robotics programs?

column1: Scholarly Journals: Building & Engaging Community
column5: Isaac Gilman (Pacific University), Michele Gibney (Nova Southeastern University), Ventura Prez _  (University of Massachusetts Amherst), Ronald Chenail (Nova Southeastern University)
column6: Traditionally, academic journals were created and sustained by extant communities such as learned societies or professional organizations, but today independent scholars create journals to nurture or connect informal communities of practice, using a variety of access strategies and social media resources to build virtual networks of authors and readers. Drawing from pop culture, entertainment, and marketing, these contemporary editors will share their innovative means of engagement and networking.
column7: Learn how scholars are creating independent online journals as spaces for sharing knowledge and informing the practice of their communities.
column8: Engage with panelists to identify best practices for building and sustaining a community of authors and readers around a new journal.
column9: Walk away with practical strategies for identifying the need for a scholarly journal and building a _start-up_ community to address that need.

column1: Silent Standards Powering an Ed-Tech Ecosystem
column5: Ray Ackerlund (Skyward Inc), Karen Patch (SAS), Jason Morales (Microsoft), Troy Wheeler (Ed-Fi Alliance)
column6: How do you link data across an exploding number ed-tech apps in ways that provide meaningful insight for educators? Interoperability holds the key to this challenge and new community sourced technology makes this possible by organizing and cataloging data at the heart of district IT systems while remaining invisible to end users. This session will be an interactive demo of a variety Ed-Tech systems working together - bringing interoperability into the field of view for districts. See what a thriving ecosystem of compatible tools should look like, from backend support systems to teacher facing applications. What opportunities does this open up for students, educators, schools and districts?
column7: Learn how districts can bring new tools online in a matter of weeks instead of months or years while maintaining local of data stewardship.
column8: Learn how this approach gives educators them freedom to choose best-of-breed tools while the data standard itself remains invisible to the end user.
column9: Learn how widely adopted standards born of practical needs allows vendors to scale products and accelerate their business.

column1: Student Voice and Choice- Empowered Learning
column5: Sarah Martinez (Leander ISD), Tiffany Spicer (Leander ISD), Todd Washburn (Leander ISD), Wendy Jones (Leander ISD)
column6: How do you shift from teacher-led learning to student-owned learning?  Come explore the impact of collaboration between district instructional staff, technology staff, and campus staff on student learning. The secret to success does not belong with the device, but what you do with the device.  Come explore the instructional strategies and processes that shift ownership from teachers to students.  Build understanding from different perspectives on how the importance of collaboration, professional development, and teacher ownership of learning transform the learning environment to enhance students_ engagement and motivation for student ownership. Leave with ideas to take back to your district.
column7: Participants will understand the importance of aligning the pedagogy, digital tools and resources to thinking process within the content.
column8: Participants will explore the process of implementing a program that incorporates innovative teaching and learning strategies.
column9: Participants will identify the value different roles bring to changing the ownership of learning in a school district.

column1: Student-Centered Learning: 3 Whole-School Models
column5: Seth Webb (Compass Montessori School), Jane Shirley (Catapult Leadership), Christine Fleming (Denver Public School - Joe Shomaker Elementary), Jackson Westenskow (Institute of Play)
column6: There are many ways that teachers put students at the center of learning. But how do you design an entire school where inquiry, discovery and play form a core instructional model that ensures high achievement for all students? In this panel, 3 Colorado school leaders will share how they craft authentic contexts for learning based on their community_s needs. Learn about best practices for student-centered learning emerging from these innovative schools, where game design, a microeconomy, and environmental responsibility provide a new way of thinking about teaching, learning and leadership.
column7: Examine three unique school models that are successfully implementing student-centered learning.
column8: Gain an overview of how these new and existing schools designed instructional models to meet the specific needs of the populations they serve.
column9: Understand how these leaders intentionally built systems, structures, and communities that can sustain success over time.

column1: Teaching Integrated STEM in Teacher Education
column5: John Pascarella (USC Rossier School of Education), Anthony Maddox (USC Rossier School of Education), Fred Freking (USC Rossier School of Education), Corinne Hyde (USC Rossier School of Education)
column6: How do we utilize today_s digital landscape to create meaningful STEM  connections in both K-12 and teacher education curriculum? Changes to state and national standards now require teacher education programs to change their curriculum and fieldwork requirements for teaching STEM _ emphasizing an integrated approach to STEM's four core elements: Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics.The USC Rossier School of Education_s panel of professors, faculty and science experts will address this critical (and national) need for curriculum changes, and share their experience and expertise on how to develop a STEM curriculum for our next generation of teachers.
column7: Attendees will be able to summarize the differences between asynchronous and synchronous online learning
column8: Attendees will be able to describe and understand student work in an integrated STEM teacher education program
column9: Attendees will be able to discuss the challenges and strengths of an online STEM teacher education program

column1: The Case for the Classroom P&L
column5: Jamie Rosenberg (ClassWallet)
column6: As student populations have been growing, school budgets have been shrinking.  At least 34 states are spending less per student this school year than six years ago.Tasked to meet adequate yearly progress, educators are increasingly finding alternative ways to fund classroom resources.
