They are reaching out to class parents, social networks and education foundations, and reaching into their own pockets to the tune of several billion dollars a year.There are various facets involving accountability and transparency, and teacher empowerment.  The session will focus on how schools and educators should manage this reality in the most effective manner.
column7: How administrators and educators can save time and money
column8: The benefits of teacher budgeting and purchasing autonomy
column9: How teachers are driving more procurement decisions

column1: The Demise of the Local Public School
column5: Howard  Fuller (Institute for the Transformation of Learning), Alvin Roth (Stanford University), Thomas Toch (Georgetown University), Susan  Patrick (International Association for K12 Online Learning)
column6: A host of forces--school desegregation, technology, the rise of school choice and charter schools, among others--have contributed to the slow but steady demise of the traditional neighborhood public school over the past several decades. This panel discussion will explore the causes and consequences of the trend for students, parents and policymakers.
column7: Increasing understanding of a major shift in the delivery of public education
column8: Providing insights into the upside and potential downsides of the trend
column9: Helping parents navigate the new education landscape

column1: The Power of Experiencing College Before College
column5: Cathy Stacy (College of Natural Science), Julie Schell (Center for Teaching and Learning), Russell Young (Plano ISD)
column6: Research suggests that taking a dual-enrollment course while in high school improves the likelihood that a student will enroll, persist and complete college. The University of Texas at Austin_s signature dual-enrollment program, OnRamps, transforms traditional high school classrooms into spaces that expose students to authentic college experiences designed to level-set and develop the ways of thinking and knowing required to accelerate postsecondary success. OnRamps courses use student-centered pedagogies that train students for the higher-order cognitive activities, such as problem solving and application that they will need to excel in postsecondary environments.
column7: Participants will learn how school districts across the state are increasing the number and diversity of students taking dual-enrollment courses.
column8: Participants will learn how to enhance learner effectiveness by exposing students to online pedagogies that they will experience in college.
column9: Participants will learn the impact of preparing and fostering a cadre of teachers to teach dual-enrollment courses has across disciplines.

column1: The Science of a Liberal Arts Education
column5: Joshua Fost (Minerva Schools at KGI), Sultanna Krispil (Minerva Schools at KGI), Z. Mike Wang (Minerva Schools at KGI)
column6: What exactly is a liberal arts education?In Ancient Greece, a liberal arts education was considered essential for a person to ultimately become active in civic life. The belief was that individuals should have a strong foundation of general knowledge on a wide range of subjects, and importantly they should master transferrable critical thinking skills in order to contribute to society. What does it mean to deliver a world-class liberal arts education in the 21st century? Is it still valuable? Given advances in technology, mobility and scientific research into how the brain learns, what components are necessary today as part of a true liberal arts education?
column7: Discuss what a liberal arts education looks like today, and where it is headed -- bringing together the voices of students, faculty, and staff.
column8: Understand how advances in technology, mobility and _brain science_ are influencing what is deemed necessary as part of a liberal arts program today.
column9: Understand what brain science shows in terms of intentionally teaching key critical thinking skills.

column1: Through the Looking Glass: VR in Education
column5: Lisa Castaneda (foundry10), Nathan Bruno (Shorewood Highschool), Marc Pacampara (Foundry 10), Mark Suter (Pandora-Gilboa High School)
column6: Virtual reality enables students to do things that are just not possible in a normal classroom setting.  Exploring the bottom of the ocean or the plains of Mars has never been something students could do, until now.  To find the best use of VR, we ran case studies with teachers across the continent to see what they could do with VR, what worked, and what challenges they faced.  We will have two teachers and two educational researchers who will discuss the use, VR community, resources, and integration of VR across subject areas.  From Google Cardboard to Oculus to the Vive, VR is more than just a way to engage students; when well-designed it can enhance how students synthesize and learn.
column7: Participants will hear examples of effective VR implementation, and consider ways to implement VR into their own programs.
column8: Participants will discover where useful VR resources are available and connect to other educators interested and developing ideas for VR.
column9: Participants will explore the pros and cons of different popular VR technologies and their applications in the classroom setting.

column1: Utilizing Students to Support K12 Edtech
column5: Meghan Zigmond (Port Aransas ISD), John Baldo (4.0 Schools), Jennifer L Scheffer (Burlington Public Schools), Rudy Blanco (The Dreamyard Project)
column6: Have plenty of tech resources but lacking the human capital required for professional development and IT support? Edtech only works when it_s well-implemented. Come hear how K12 leaders from across the USA are creatively utilizing students to tackle this challenge. Walk out with resources to get student tech leadership started at your school site.
column7: Hear the stories of at least 3 student leadership models that have boosted human capital and led to successful edtech implementations.
column8: Understand the benefits of student tech leadership for both the student and the school site.
column9: Get tips and tricks on how to successfully implement a student tech leadership model at your school and avoid common pitfalls.

column1: 722 MILLION Math Problems! Games+Digital=Success
column5: Angela Perez (Harvey Elementary School, Kingsville ISD), Chara Harris (AISD), Adam Blair (Houston ISD), Louis Piconi (Think Through Math)
column6: What do you get when you add up the following?1,151 districts + 5,686 schools + 2.1 million students + 772M math problems + unquantifiable support from state education leaders Stumped? We_ll tell you: You get engaged students, higher assessment scores, and proof that kids can get excited about math! This is the story of Texas_ finest educators, an entrepreneur-turned-farmer, and a state-wide collaboration committed to making excellent digital learning content available across Texas. This panel features Texas educators alongside trusted partners discussing online learning, gamification, and how stakeholder buy-in is driving student success in the Lone Star State.
column7: Understand how gamification and quality digital learning is motivating students to do dramatically more math problems and achieve more on assessments.
column8: Discuss how to increase stakeholder engagement to ensure the success of large public-private partnerships.
column9: Understand how teachers are using competition to motive students to achieve more.

column1: A New Way to Deliver Course Content _ Apps
column5: Lorenzo Vallone (Mirum Agency), Phil Ice (American Public University System), Michael Schinelli (UNC Kenan-Flagler Business School), Karen McCavitt (Adobe Systems, Inc.)
column6: This panel will discuss how to engage learners, measure cognition and impact student outcomes through a new course content and curriculum delivery framework called course apps. Institutions are looking for new ways to integrate technology to help achieve teaching and learning goals. Pioneering universities have begun developing course apps to create, distribute and measure the effectiveness of learning experiences. Course apps deliver content through text, video, quizzes, interactive charts, discussion boards and more _ plus provide robust analytics. Representatives from UNC Kenan-Flagler and APUS will discuss their experiences, alongside a course app designer from Mirum. Moderated by Adobe.
column7: Learn how other universities are innovating their course delivery and learning analytics methods
column8: Gather new, actionable ideas for creating mobile and app-based learning content
column9: Discuss the important aspects to consider when thinking about and deploying mobile learning content for students

column1: Abstinence is Analog: Teaching Safe Techs
column5: David Westerman (North Dakota State University), Nicholas` Bowman (West Virginia University), Stephanie  Kelly (North Carolina A&T State University)
column6: We often assume that students, as _digital natives,_ have _natural_ abilities for communication technology. However, a recent study of ours suggests that students learn a great deal about tech from others. The pattern of learning falls in line with recent discussion of technology, especially social media, as distractions to education. Although threats exist, our team is concerned that the prominence of fear creates an unrealistic and dysfunctional view of technology and its uses, both in the classroom and out. Our panel will discuss uses and challenges and call for teachers to consider a more balanced approach to discussing and utilizing technologies for educational purposes.
column7: What are the positives and negatives of social media for education, relative to (and separate from) face-to-face interactions?
column8: How can teachers help students understand the positive and negatives of various communication technologies?
column9: How can we help students learn to _practice safe techs_ rather than practicing abstinence or catching Socio-Technological Distractions (STDs)?

column1: Adolescent Literacy: Can Games Move the Needle?
column5: Meesha Brown (Patalogos), Jen Groff (MIT Media Lab), Lisa  Holton (Classroom, Inc.)
column6: Are learning games the holy grail for re-engaging adolescents and teaching reading and writing skills in ways unlike any other modes of instruction? We_ll examine the research on literacy strategies for adolescents combined with the research on game design. There are three powerful points of intersection: creating active learning environments; building engagement and motivation; and leveraging learning technologies to aid in feedback, adaptivity, and interactivity. Hear from an instructional expert and educator coach, a researcher of games and new curriculum design, and a nonprofit leader and former publisher who aims to engage students where traditional instruction has not been successful.
column7: Understand the recommended strategies for improving adolescent literacy.
column8: Learn about features of game design that are particularly powerful to re-engage adolescents in the learning process.
column9: Dissect the best practices of adolescent literacy and game-based learning, and how they support one another to create powerful learning opportunities.

column1: Beyond the Classroom: Reality of Digital Tech
column5: Clark Poole (Rowan-Salisbury School System), Dave Saltmarsh (www.jamfsoftware.com), Andrew Smith (Rowan-Salisbury School System), Candace Salmon-Hosey (Rowan-Salisbury School System)
column6: As technology becomes more ingrained in our everyday lives, classrooms that reflect this trend have become key to educating students and maximizing student learning both in and out of the classroom. But with limited budgets and tools to create and implement a truly rich, interactive and collaborative learning experience, rolling out programs that utilize new technologies can be difficult.  In this session, learn first hand the successes and struggles districts and educators have faced when implementing and managing some of the most popular initiatives, such as an iPad 1:1 program, as well as other such programs that enable unique learning environments to prepare students for the world today.
column7: Participants will learn how state of the art classrooms are utilizing technology to create a different learning experience for students.
column8: Attendees will learn about successes and struggles of implementing programs, such as a iPad 1:1 program, from educators with first hand experience.
column9: Understand different factors for educators to consider when deciding what types of programs to implement and roll out in the classroom.

column1: Big Brother or Big Savior?
column5: Gary  Shattuck (Newton Public Schools ), Melissa  Jackson (Newton Public Schools), Wayne D'Orio (Scholastic)
column6: Is it inevitable that someday, rather soon, every classroom in every school is going to be videotaped? Sure that sounds crazy, but consider the experiences of the small, 23-school Newton County Schools in Georgia. This school put cameras in half their classrooms three years ago. They gave teachers full control over recording, including when to start, stop and most importantly, who could watch. Within two years, not only were all the teachers on board with the system, but others in the district were demanding their own cameras. The district has improved student behavior, sharpened the way teachers are assessed, and allowed students outside school to participate in class.
column7: How to implement a sensitive program such as taping every classroom everyday.
column8: Learn how teachers are using video to sharpen their skills before facing a formal assessment.
column9: See how this tool can help students study, by allowing them to play back lessons, or to monitor classes when they aren't physically in the building.

column1: Blended Learning: Lessons from the Front Lines
column5: Neal Bottom (Caliber Beta Academy), Sarah Gzesh (Leadership Public School), Donna Dela Calzada (Versal), Gregor Freund (Versal)
column6: There's a new generation of students in the classroom. Raised on apps/smartphones, they're tech-savvy. They expect a highly interactive and collaborative learning experience, and they_re connected with each other like never before.Teachers are rising to the challenge. They_re incorporating interactive technologies and blended learning techniques into daily instruction - producing and curating educational content to engage students.This session will feature three high school teachers on the front lines. You'll learn what works (including discussions around content, see sample) and what doesn't, and how to overcome obstacles like computer access. Expect a lively and informative panel.
column7: Learn how to quickly create and curate interactive online learning materials to keep students engaged.
column8: Learn how self-paced at-home online learning can help more students keep up, and free up classroom time for debates, labs, and reinforcement.
column9: Learn about the favorite tools/websites that help these three teachers bring blended learning into the classroom - enhancing instead of disrupting.

column1: Branching - the simple way to modify lessons
column5: Dan Hou (Huge), Elena Balint (American Federation of Teachers), Mark Stojack (Huge)
column6: Lesson plans are just the start. Many of the best teachers build on what's worked in the past, while tailoring materials to the specific needs of their students. In fact, a teacher's content is one of their greatest assets. But in a time starved world, how do teachers source materials and modify them in a quick and effective way? Branching is a concept adopted from the world of technology that is a super simple way for a teacher to modify another teacher's lesson plan. Come see how a single lesson upload turns into multiple branches off the same lesson. Improving overall quality as the teaching community iterates on lessons based on real world performance.
column7: Learn how to find and develop relevant lesson plans quicker and more effectively.
column8: Build real connections with other teaching professionals to elevate the quality of shared lesson plans.
column9: Learn how to use technology as a competitive advantage.

column1: Bridging Cultures Through Improvisational Comedy
column5: Linda Kawano (GroupOptima), Melissa Leone (Thermo Fisher Scientific), Marshall Shen (Context Media)
column6: Improvisation or _improv_ draws upon our intuition and authenticity, allows us to be ourselves, and, in the process, identify and embrace our strengths and talents _ all attributes we inherently possess.  Improv study teaches how to communicate more effectively, create an open dialog and listen in order to fully understand what is being said. The panelists, all scientists, multi-cultural and representing three generations _ Millennial, Gen X and Baby Boomer, will discuss how the fundamentals of improvisation can improve our relationships.  As graduates of The Second City Training Center Improv Program, the speakers continue to study and perform together at The Second City and IO in Chicago.
column7: Applying the fundamentals of improvisational comedy practice to improve communications and enhance cultural understanding.
column8: Learning the basics of comedic improvisation: How a simple improvisational game works.
column9: Applying improvisational comedy techniques and games to build effective collaborative teams & strong partnerships in the workplace and beyond.

column1: Chickens, Books & Games: Award-Winning Learning
column5: John Lodle (Belleville West High School ), Tasha Squires (O'Neill Middle School), Patrice Bryan (Maplewood Richmond Heights High School), Britten Follett (Follett School Solutions)
column6: Engaging students and getting them to truly care and participate_especially in middle school and high school_requires creativity, innovating thinking, and a willingness to approach learning from new perspectives. The true winners are the schools and districts whose learning programs take innovation to new levels and result in measurable improvement.Hear three award-winning, innovative programs and learn the steps necessary to move from traditional (yawn) teaching programs to one where students are eager to learn. The panelists will share before, during & after stories of their programs, including best practices and how all three showed marked improvement in student and school achievement.
column7: Hear stories of schools who have been nationally recognized for their innovative approaches, including a failing school that became a success model
column8: Get ideas & motivation to implement a learning program in keeping with 21st-century learning, from service learning, pleasure reading to gamification
column9: Hear the challenges faced and steps taken by teachers and librarians who successfully implemented a learning program that resulted in before unseen le

column1: Choose the right education partner for your school
column5: Eric  Gearhart (SkillsUSA), Ryan Kish (Alcoa Foundation), Edie  Frasier (STEMconnector)
column6: With the maker movement, robotics competitions, career and technical education training, STEM camps and more all vying for a school district_s limited budget, the decision maker must be armed with the best information to choose the right program. Nonprofits are increasingly supporting schools to expand curriculum and deliver new programs. Key questions: 1. How do you know what the right program is for your school and community? 3. How can a school assess national in-demand skills? 4. How can a school measure the value that a program might provide? 5. What is the right balance of programs, K-12?
column7: Know how to choose education partners that deliver in-demand skills
column8: Find new ways to measure success on a short-term and long-term basis
column9: Get a perspective on what is available to education institutions

column1: Creating educational video
column5: Tom McFadden (Science with Tom), Paul Anderson (Bozeman Science), Brooke Miller (The University of Texas at Austin), Tyler  DeWitt (YouTube)
column6: In this session, YouTube's top teachers will discuss the strategies that they use to create high quality educational video content. Come to this session to learn about the strategies these educators use to research, record, and edit their different styles of video. Additionally, this workshop will cover some common mistakes to avoid when creating educational content, and will review early mistakes made by the creators.
column7: After attending this panel teachers will understand how popular YouTube educators create their content
column8: After attending this panel teachers will be able to identify the software and equipment that can aid them in creating high quality video content
column9: After attending this panel teachers will be able to embark on their own content creation using the strategies discussed by the online educators

column1: Demonstration: How AI Will Change Teaching Forever
column5: Ryan Duques (TutaPoint Education)
column6: During this round-table discussion you will see how Artificial Intelligence will forever change the teaching landscape. Attendees will experience the benefits of a teaching assistant sitting in on every class, providing concept reinforcement, writing performance reports and providing the students with feedback and homework. Firms like New York City based TutaPoint are launching artificial intelligence solutions to derive student performance data in real-time during academic tutoring sessions that it conducts online.After a demonstration and brief use-case presentation there will be lively discussion and debate.
column7: Introduce the benefits of Artificial Intelligence use during teaching
column8: Dispel the myths behind AI use
column9: Discuss and debate how far schools and edtech firms should take AI into the education process

column1: Design Challenges in Your Makerspace
column5: Shawna Ford ( Weatherford ISD), Diana Rendina (Stewart Magnet School), Aaron Graves (Denton High School), Colleen Graves (Ryan High School)
column6: This panel is for fab lab facilitators, librarians, teachers, administrators, and educators who have already started thinking in terms of makerspaces, but need further help sustaining programming and instilling creative confidence into young tinkering minds. Each educator on the panel will provide insight and advice on instituting design challenges in your school makerspace at at any level. Our session will help you go beyond implementing a makerspace by shifting your students into the design thinking mindset.  We will also include tips on bringing elementary and secondary curriculum connections into makerspaces.
column7: Learn how to build, develop and cultivate a Maker culture within your school.
column8: Learn strategies for developing good prompts, creating challenge guidelines, promoting programming, and implementing a challenge with your students.
column9: Learn how to incorporate design thinking principles into student projects to develop a deeper understanding of the design process.

column1: Dyslexia - Now What? A Large District Takes Action
column5: Heather  Hardeman (Dyslexia Parent Network Austin), Dr. Rachel  Robillard PHD LSSP (Austin ISD), Robbi  Cooper (Decoding Dyslexia)
column6: Dyslexia effects approximately 17% of the student population. We will explore resources available to meet student and staff needs and find out how one of the largest districts in Texas is addressing this issue.
column7: What strategies work when addressing Dyslexia in public schools?
column8: What steps can large and small districts do to focus on better outcomes for Dyslexics?
column9: What resources are available to districts, teachers and students to support dyslexic learners in K-12?

column1: Ed Tech Certification: the Good, the Bad, the Ugly
column5: Andrew Gardner (BrainPOP and NYU), Jennifer  Kabaker (Digital Promise), Robert Miller (Volusia County Schools, Florida),  Lucy   Gray (Global Education Conference (globaledcon) and http://lucygrayconsulting.com/)
column6: Many companies develop educator certification programs to support marketing, advocacy & sales. These programs can help educators build product knowledge, PLNs, & personal brand. But these relationships can also be ethically nebulous, influencing purchasing decisions, advocacy efforts & more. This panel, comprised of teachers who have been certified by Google, Apple, BrainPOP, & others, is moderated by an educator who has both participated in & created these programs. We will explore how certification programs balance the needs of educators & companies, unpack the broader question _why certify?_, & probe into 3rd party certification efforts such as micro-credentials from Digital Promise.
column7: What role does certification and micro-credentialing offer in fueling innovation and transformation in the education landscape?
column8: Identify, debate and discuss similarities, differences, benefits, & costs of various educator certification programs.
column9: Identify key elements in an ideal certification program.

column1: EdTech: Increase Efficiency or Elevate Learning?
column5: Bobbi Kurshan (Graduate School of Education at The University of Pennsylvania), Kathy Benemann (Kiyo), David Kanter (Kanter Learning Design & Research), Lindsey Own (The Evergreen School)
column6: Should ed tech development focus on increasing efficiency in entrenched teaching routines, or on elevating research-based best practices? Teachers and ed tech developers struggle with both incorporating formal learning sciences research and with conducting their own research and pilot programs to drive forward innovative best practices. This interactive panel will explore how we - as a community of teachers, researchers, and developers - can address barriers to and opportunities for designing and implementing products that target innovative teaching practices for active student learning.
column7: What active-learning teaching practices could ed tech be designed to support at scale, and how are these embodied in 21st century standards?
column8: What support - tech and otherwise - do teachers need to apply research on active-learning teaching practices in their classrooms?
column9: To what extent has ed tech targeted its products to supporting such learning/teaching practices, and what are hypothesized barriers to doing so?

column1: Educators Flip the Classroom to Improve Engagement
column5: Terry Austin (Temple College), Matt Stoltzfus (Ohio State University)
column6: Over 95 percent of teachers who have flipped a lesson would recommend this method to others. This demonstrates the growth and effectiveness of the flipped learning model. In it, direct instruction moves from the group learning space to the individual learning space. The result is a dynamic, interactive learning environment where the educator guides students as they apply concepts and engage creatively in the subject matter. Attend this session to hear from professors as they explain how following this model has helped to improve student engagement, using online learning tools and a _bring your own device_ approach that provided them with real-time classroom intelligence and analytics.
column7: Learn about an interactive classroom tool that uses students_ smartphones, tablets, or laptops to engage them in a more sophisticated manner.
column8: Hear how the new model works to improve the students_ learning experience.
column9: Learn how professors are able to monitor students' performance, track modifications needed in their instruction, and adjust accordingly.

column1: Edutopia Bloggers Panel: Technology in PBL
column5: MaryBeth Hertz (Science Leadership Academy), Andrew Marcinek (Grafton Public Schools.), Suzie Boss (Edutopia, Buck Institute ), Andrew Miller (Buck Institute of Education, Edutopia)
column6: Learn the best ways to use technology in project-based learning and share tips and strategies with others. A panel of experienced Edutopia.org bloggers will discuss the role of technology in provoking, enhancing and supporting PBL. The session will be accompanied by a backchannel discussion and online polling.
column7: All educators will learn how to integrate specific technologies to improve their PBL classes.
column8: New educators will understand the basics of rigorous project-based learning from experts on the front lines.
column9: Experienced PBL educators will hear about best practices with using tech to improve student learning.

column1: Embracing Disruption to Reinvent the Classroom
column5: Alicia  Levi (PBS), Alice  Chen (Suzanne Middle School), Paul Eyler (Tyler ISD), Amanda  Kruysman  (Gold Mill Middle School)
column6: Today_s learners want engaging, personalized content. No longer can educators focus on one element of learning; instead they must provide exploratory opportunities across multiple areas and this reveals critical needs inside schools. With all of the pressures facing educators, how can they address the individual learner in every student? Join us as we take a firsthand look at how three schools in Texas, California, and South Carolina are embracing disruption to drive individual student learning and achievement.
column7: Gain an insider_s perspective on the evolving _edtech_ landscape.
column8: Learn how industry leaders are working together to develop meaningful content solutions that help educators maximize potential technology.
column9: Be exposed to a number of new tools and resources educators can use in the classroom to help drive student achievement.

column1: Embracing Tech to Teach CCSS & Improve Instruction
column5: Gary Abud (CCSSO), Jemelleh Coes (CCSSO), Sarah Wessling (CCSSO)
column6: The Common Core offers educators across the nation the opportunity to collaborate and share best practices. This session will look at how teachers of the year are using technology to enhance their practice and successfully teach Common Core. Panelists will share their unique strategies for integrating technology into the Common Core classroom, and provide audience members with strategies and tactics for teaching in a Common Core world.
column7: Highlight different ways educators are using technology in the classroom to enhance  and improve their instruction
column8: Explore how educators can implement standards with the help of technology
column9: Provide participants with ideas and tools for integrating technology into the classroom

column1: End the Dropout Crisis: Develop Student Mindsets
column5: Jeff Dunn (DeVry X), Jennifer Keup (National Resource Center for The First-Year Experience and Students in Transition), Robert Feldman (University of Massachusetts-Amherst), Karan Goel (GetSet Learning )
column6: 88% of students who drop out of college do so for non-academic reasons.  Four national leaders from different education sectors discuss cutting-edge approaches to improving persistence and graduation rates.  Solutions to be addressed include developing student growth mindsets through scalable technology, promoting student social networking and goal setting, and developing first-year programs that target student success.  These simple, data-driven, and scalable approaches offer the opportunity to change attitudes and behavior to produce dramatic improvements in student success.
column7: Explain key factors in America's college dropout rates. What's causing this? What methods have been tested and failed? We uncover what has not worked.
column8: Uncover how students can succeed in Higher Ed through a variety of proven, psychology-based techniques.
column9: Understand the most impactful, cost efficient, way to allow students to realize their potential: having a growth mindset instead a fixed mindset.

column1: Fair Use Awakens: Classrooms/Libraries/Communities
column5: Elizabeth Rosenblatt (Whittier Law School), Ebony Elizabeth Thomas (University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education), Heidi Tandy (Organization for Transformative Works)
column6: Follow-on works like fanfiction, fan films and fanart have instructional applications. Educators, museum curators and media specialists have incorporated follow-on works into curricula and projects for years, but some are using fanworks for the first time, facing concerns about legal issues. Do teachers invite legal trouble when they assign students to create follow-on works?  Does cosplay infringe on a multinational movie company's trademarks? Does a showcase of fanart in a local museum expose its Board or the students to a lawsuit? Fair Use is a lawful use of a copyright, but when and how does it apply? We'll workshop ways to safely and successfully use follow-on works with K-12 students.
column7: How can instructors successfully support students' educational goals and voices by using follow-on works to counteract silencing and censorship?
column8: How do follow-on works inspire interest in museums, community programs, sports, library activities, inter-student support and social justice.
column9: What legal issues involving privacy& intellectual property concern boards, administrators, parents and students, and how should they be addressed?

column1: Flipping the Classroom with YouTube_s Top Teachers
column5: Joelle  Murphy (Google), Patrick Jones (PatrickJMT), Tyler DeWitt (YouTube), Paul  Andersen (Bozeman Science)
column6: Flipped classrooms and video instructional content aren_t the magic solution for all the challenges in education. But if used thoughtfully, they can be powerful tools to allow the instructor to shift the pedagogical focus of teaching. Here, we_ll talk with the creators of three of YouTube_s most popular education channels, whose content covers Biology, Chemistry, Physics, and Math. Each of these creators is also an experienced classroom teacher, and they_ll talk about why and how they started making video, how they intend their videos to be used, how teachers can implement new instructional strategies for using video, and how pedagogy can meaningfully change in a flipped classroom.
column7: After attending this panel teachers will be able to identify elements of an effective video lesson.
column8: After attending this panel teachers will be able to implement new strategies for utilizing videos in the classroom.
column9: After attending this panel teachers will be able to explain how the flipped classroom can result in a meaningful pedagogical shift.

column1: How Project-Based Learning Inspires Curiosity
column5: Tina Garrett (Garland Independent School District), Deepika Kurup (Harvard College), Dr. Jim Jonza (3M), Kristin Hirst (Discovery Education)
column6: Project-based learning is a way to immerse students in STEM at an age when research says their interest in STEM declines. Thought-provoking challenges engage students in STEM and encourage creative thinking about solving tomorrow_s challenges. Meet the winner of the 2012 Discovery Education 3M Young Scientist Challenge who will discuss how it helped her develop an inexpensive method to clean water using solar power and launched her toward a path of success. Joining her are educators and scientists to discuss how these contests and the mentoring built into them inspire kids_ curiosity.
column7: Discuss the theories behind project-based learning and best practices for large- and small-scale initiatives.
column8: Show practically how project based learning inspires kids _ by talking to a student who can describe the process first-hand.
column9: Discuss ways to engage inspiring mentors in a way that immerses them into the education of kids who need it most.

column1: How Technology Is Changing University Recruiting
column5: Wahab Owolabi (Stanford University), Jeff  D'Andria (Stanford Univeristy), Jessica Gilmartin (Piazza)
column6: Hiring top students at universities is a talent war. We_ve gathered reps from Stanford and leading tech companies to offer their perspective and insight. The focus of the session is to share innovative strategies in sourcing, interviewing, closing and retaining university candidates. The Stanford Career Development Center is marching forward with Vision 2020, a connections model that integrates with technology to increase the opportunities for engagement between students and recruiters. The connections model creates an ecosystem that allows Universities to equally support both startups and well established tech giants as they use a more targeted approach to compete on campus.
column7: Attendees will take away actionable strategies to increase student visibility and engagement with recruiters by implementing a connections model.
column8: Founders, execs, and recruiters will gain insight on how to position their employer brand and develop talent pipelines at tier 1 universities.
column9: Founders, execs, and recruiters will learn best practices around leveraging technology and media to support their university recruiting efforts.

column1: How to Study Music Technology in the Classroom
column5: Patrick McGuire (Mountain Vista High School), Jeff Dupre (Show of Force), Warren Zanes (Rock and Roll Forever Foundation)
column6: A panel of Rock and Roll Forever Foundation staff, producers of the PBS series Soundbreaking, and classroom teachers will discuss how the history of music technology, the subject of the PBS series, can be approached in the classroom. The panel will discuss how non-music teachers can engage with issues and practices that have long been associated exclusively with music classrooms, with technology providing the means.Initiated by Beatles producer George Martin, Soundbreaking explores the history of recorded music. The series, and the online lesson plans accompanying it, discuss subjects including the development of electrical recording, multi-tracking, and the role of the record producer.
column7: Participants will consider a range of interdisciplinary approaches to address the history of music technology in non-music classrooms.
column8: Participants will be introduced to the educational resources available on teachrock.org, including lessons connected to the PBS Soundbreaking series.
column9: Participants will learn how teachrock.org and Soundbreaking learning materials can be adapted and modified to suit specific classroom needs.

column1: Impactful & Empowering: Storytelling for Learning
column5: David Poulson (Michigan State University, College of Communication Arts and Sciences), E. David Wong (Michigan State University, College of Education), Estrella Torrez (Michigan State University, Residential College in the Arts and Humanities), David Wheeler (Michigan State University, College of Communication Arts & Sciences)
column6: Storytelling is a bridge to learning and a powerful mechanism for connecting people and communities. It helps to translate complex or unfamiliar subjects, empowering the storyteller with the ability to share a transformative experience with the listener. Storytelling helps teachers to teach better, researchers to communicate more clearly, and students to connect classroom experiences with their daily lives. Panelists will discuss their work with learners in storytelling and how it has promoted self confidence, self awareness, and integrated thinking. Participants will learn how to integrate storytelling into their teaching with practical strategies for assessing their impacts.
column7: Understand the influence of cultural expression contained in student stories on instructor responsiveness
column8: Understand how stories (can) impart a narrative on learners
column9: Exposure to translational tools that connect course-based learning to lived experience through storytelling

column1: Incorporating Social Media Certification in Class
column5: Karen Freberg (University of Louisville), Carolyn Kim (Biola University), Emily Kinsky (West Texas A&M University), Matthew Kushin (Shepherd University)
column6: Highlighting the social media certification program from Hootsuite University, this panel demonstrates how professors can work with students to sharpen digital skills in today_s rapidly changing media environment. We will share our research into professor, employer and student perspectives of the program. As professors who have both researched and used Hootsuite University in our classes, we will share key skills, tips, and takeaways for enhancing the social media savvy of students or employees.
column7: Explore the challenges both students and professors face in a rapidly changing media environment
column8: Share research insights into social media certification training in the college classroom and receptivity to training among students and professionals
column9: Share best practices for integrating Hootsuite University into a social media education program for the classroom or professional training

column1: Innovative Educators: What we do, what we need,
column5: Melissa  Zaikos (Insrinsic Schools), Colleen Collins (CICS West Belden), Tim Carnahan (LEAP Innovations)
column6: Using video, personal stories, and artifacts from their own experiences, this session will give entrepreneurs and educators alike access to innovative teachers from different school models in Chicago who are leading the nation at implementing personalized learning in their classrooms. Participants will see classrooms in action, hear tales about successes and challenges, and talk with teacher-mentors about how they are personalizing instruction for students right now.
column7: Share readiness markers for a successful personalized learning classroom, including IT, administrative support, and class culture
column8: Celebrate the varied needs and approaches to success in classrooms, and how to overcome constraints that appear to inhibit innovation
column9: Understand how to create a class culture that fosters and leverages student agency, ownership and motivation

column1: It's Easy: Bring Quality Coding Ed to Your School
column5: Steven Prescott (Madison Academic High School), Vicki DeLoach (Jackson-Madison County School System), Ben Ferguson (Personnel Placements Holdings, LLC), William Donnell (theCO)
column6: Learn how a rural Tennessee region is successfully tackling coding education for all and building a workforce for the future. In less than 60 days, a public school system went from teaching obsolete programming languages to Swift (iOS), Rails and UX. The program is not only breaking down gender and race barriers in technology but pulling students together across public, private and county lines _ all with the goal of building a region where programming is the dominant second language. Attendees will be given a playbook and the resources needed to do the same thing in their community.
column7: Learn how you can bring high quality coding education into your area regardless of expertise, local funding or community demographics.
column8: Learn where to start and how long it will take.
column9: Learn how just one person can jumpstart the effort.

column1: Keeping it Real: EdTech to Teach Real-World Skills
column5: Edys Quellmalz (WestEd), Carl Swartz (MetaMetrics), Steve Ferrara (Pearson Research & Innovation Network)
column6: Most K12 classrooms are not equipped to teach real world skills students need to be successful in the workplace. Real-world skills like communication, critical thinking, and collaboration cannot be taught in a single course by a single teacher and conventional methods cannot assess them. But new innovations in education technology can. This panel of experts will demo tools that teach and measure 21st century skills. These cool tech tools help students learn science, collaboration, and literacy skills they need to be successful.
column7: Attendees will learn about the frameworks behind the innovative tools
column8: Participants will get a peak at what developers discovered during research and development of the tools that can be applied to the classroom
column9: Participants will see demos of innovative tools that both exist and are under development

column1: LeaPing Into Adaptive Learning in Pharmacy
column5: JoeJane Student (College of Pharmacy - University of Texas at Austin), Natalia Malesa (College of Pharmacy - University of Texas at Austin), Patrick Davis (University of Texas College of Pharmacy), Phil Long (University of Texas at Austin)
column6: The University of Texas at Austin_s Doctor of Pharmacy program allows students to apply with 60 credit hours, but many come with higher degrees. The variance in entry-level knowledge has led instructors in the first year to lament the remediation that must accompany the core first year teaching. This panel will present a project on adaptive learning providing incoming students personalized learning pathways through four content areas. The adaptive learning environment delivered faculty-identified content, dynamically personalized to learner needs. Data collected before and after addressed a number of non-cognitive measures (mindset, math anxiety) in addition to content knowledge gains.
column7: Describe the context that led to the project and identify similar opportunities in other contexts.
column8: Explain considerations that must be taken into account when creating content and assessments to enable adaptive learning.
column9: Reflect on the impacts of the project from the points of view of implementers and learners.

column1: Lights, Buzzers, ButterflyBots & Girls in STEM
column5: Katelyn Wamsted (Girlstart), Joanne Baptista (Houston Zoo), Tricia Berry (The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: From blinking lights and buzzers on dough creatures to flittering butterfly bots, explore research-based best practice projects and strategies designed to excite girls about STEM careers. Learn the PBS _SciGirls Seven_, Proven Strategies for Engaging Girls in STEM, and tips for being an effective STEM role model (and for finding STEM role models). Discover innovative girl-friendly twists to hands-on STEM activities and collaboration ideas from Texas Girls Collaborative Project organizations such as the Women in Engineering Program at The University of Texas at Austin, Girlstart, Informal Science Learning Associates of Laredo (ISLA), the Girl Scouts of Central Texas, and the Houston Zoo.
column7: Participants will understand and be able to apply the PBS SciGirls Seven: Proven Strategies for Engaging Girls in STEM.
column8: Participants will experience and understand best-practice facilitation techniques at least three girl-friendly STEM activities incorporating circuits.
column9: Participants will know where to find STEM role models, how to be an amazing role model, and tips for successful STEM role model-student interactions.

column1: Lights, Camera, Lecture: Producing a Better MOOC
column5: Jodi Beggs (Northeastern University), Chris  Metzler (Tilapia Film), Roman Hardgrave (Marginal Revolution University), Jeffrey  Young (The Chronicle of Higher Education)
column6: With more players entering the MOOC space each day, what does it take to produce an online course that_s a cut above the rest? This session is a candid discussion with a filmmaker, producer, professor, and edtech journalist about the good, the bad, and the ugly of producing educational videos. Participants will hear about how to combine the subject matter expertise of a professor with the production expertise of a producer, the elements of an effective script, whether fancy animations actually help people learn, and whether all videos need to qualify as _edutainment._
column7: Learn from specific examples and case studies about what works and doesn't work when producing educational videos.
column8: Explore what makes a great video different from a great lecture. Learn how to use visuals, sound effects, and music.
column9: Identify the best apps and tools for creating educational videos -- from high production quality to videos on a tight budget.

column1: LX Design: Because Learning Design Requires UX
column5: Jessica Knott (Michigan State University), Joyce Seitzinger (Academic Tribe), Phil Denman (San Diego State University), Myra Travin (UNIVentures)
column6: Education technology has reigned in our classrooms, lecture halls  training rooms for the last 25 years. The online learning industry is estimated to be worth US$ 107 million by Forbes. Despite this, in 2015 what we offer our learners pales when compared with the personalized, flexible & usable user experiences they get in almost any other industry.We can learn from them by returning our focus on the learner experience. LX Design needs to become our rallying cry.Four learning designers from 4 different contexts & 2 different continents will discuss how adopting user experience methods in learning design may lead education out of its rut. Panel attendees will learn the basic tenets of
column7: Challenge the ability of current learning tools, learning systems and learning design methods to deliver a rich learner experience
column8: Explore the use of user experience design and methodologies in educational and training contexts
column9: Continue to build a learner experience design (LXDesign) community

column1: Making Online Student Safety a Priority
column5: Diana Graber (CyberWise), Kathy Boehle (Gaggle), Luann Hughes (Temple Independent School District)
column6: A free and open internet is not an option for our students, but walled gardens don't protect them either. Every school needs a digital playground monitored by adults with plenty of open gates. When something happens, it becomes a "teachable moment," ultimately incorporating digital citizenship into a curriculum. Hear helpful tips on adding digital citizenship into your curriculum, real-life stories about how potentially harmful student situations were avoided and much more.
column7: What is your students' safety worth?
column8: What controls are available in popular (and free) tools used by schools today? How much are educators responsible for how students use these tools?
column9: How can you add digital citizenship to K-12 curriculum and help prepare students to navigate the information superhighway safely and confidently?

column1: Middle School Math: Moving from Agony to Awesome
column5: Tim Hudson (DreamBox Learning), Rafranz Davis (Lufkin ISD), Karim Ani (Mathalicious)
column6: Most middle school students would rather eat broccoli than do math. Unfortunately, what they think it means to "do math" is a far cry from both what mathematicians really do and how countless professionals "do math" to impact their communities and the world. Join this panel for a discussion about how to support the math achievement of all middle school students even though they're at a unique time in their psychosocial and mathematical development. Hear perspectives from experienced practitioners and leaders about how middle school students can engage mathematics more purposefully in classrooms and with digital tools. Learn how to make mathematics thought-provoking rather than mind-numbing.
column7: Math classes and use of learning technologies should enable students to understand mathematics more deeply and impact their world more profoundly.
column8: The way mathematics is presented in class and with technology influences if, when, and how students think deeply about math and its relevance.
column9: To improve math achievement and enjoyment, schools and math classes must foster a culture of inquiry, critical thinking, and community impact.

column1: MOOCs4Change:Open Edu for Social/Health Impact
column5: Sarah Bishop-Root (Foundation for Excellence in Education), Paul Kruchoski (United States Department of State), Dr. Karen Webb (University of California), Fred Mednick (Teachers Without Borders)
column6: MOOCs as a vehicle to increase global access to quality education has been a hot topic. However, what if MOOCs can be used as a tool to raise issue awareness, facilitate social change or improve quality of lives on a global scale? In this panel session you will learn about four distinct initiatives that are using MOOCs to make social/health impact. Join us to get inspired to develop your own MOOC for change and learn about: _The State Department_s MOOC Camps_Teachers Without Borders MOOC: Educating Girls _UC Division of Agriculture and Natural Resources MOOC: Developing a Foodbank Nutrition Policy_The Foundation for Excellence in Education_s  MOOC initiative: EdPolicy Leaders Online
column7: Upon completion of this session participants will learn and get inspired about four diverse initiatives that are using MOOCs for social impact
column8: Upon completion of this session, the participant will gain ideas from challenges, successes and lessons learned from each MOOC initiative
column9: Upon completion of the session, participants will get their questions answered as they evaluate the use of MOOCs for impact in their own area of focus

column1: Museums Give Teachers Control to Create
column5: Melissa Wadman (Smithsonian Institution), Brian Ausland (Navigation North Learning Solutions), Ashley  Naranjo (Smithsonian Institution)
column6: Museums are often overlooked as a resource for K-12 educators beyond the occasional field trip. Museums have the opportunity to play a major role in the OER realm with their large repositories of digital material including digitized collections as well as lesson plans and other online content. Come and learn about the possibilities museums hold for the K-12 world allowing educators and learners to become authors of their own learning content using museum resources and objects. One such example is the Smithsonian_s newly launched Learning Lab which allows educators to create their own learning experiences with the Smithsonian_s digitized collections and educational materials.
column7: Museums are a vast repository of primary sources and digital assets for K-12 classroom beyond the physical visit.
column8: Museum digital resources and content are an integral part of the OER framework allowing for the ability to adapt and customize instruction.
column9: The Smithsonian Learning Lab provides access to digital resources with tools to personalize instruction based on need, ability and context.

column1: Navigating Digital Content Through Knowledge Maps
column5: Nili Bartley (Hopkington School), Dr. Brian  Friedlander (College of St. Elizabeth), Lynne Anderson-Inman (Univestity of Oregon)
column6: How can educators maximize the wealth of digital content at students' fingertips to build lasting knowledge and foster critical thinking? This three-member panel explores the potential for online knowledge mapping to promote effective, student-centered learning across multiple forms of digital media. Discover ways to apply knowledge mapping to personalized learning environments and support authentic assessment. Learn how to support transmedia navigation, enabling students to access diverse online content and synthesize it into visual representations of key concepts and their inter-relationships.
column7: Learn how knowledge mapping can be used to construct personalized knowledge from various media sources.
column8: Learn how embedded supports such as keywords and links between maps and media help to scaffold student engagement and foster higher-order thinking.
column9: Discover ways to apply knowledge mapping to personalized learning environments and support authentic assessment.

column1: Off Script: Writing And Narrative As A Game
column5: Les Simpson (Manor ISD), Stephen Hood (Storium), Leonard Balsera (Evil Hat Productions), Holly Fain-Jackson (Manor New Technology High School)
column6: Written communication is a critical skill for student success, but can it be fun?Yes!This panel examines two inventive classroom projects that turned writing and narrative into a game at the internationally recognized Manor New Technology High School.Learn an analog approach to gaming stories through dice, pencils, paper, and lots of imagination!Get a sneak peek at a new online game built around collaborative writing!Hear how student work has had an impact in the gaming industry!Ask questions of the teachers and the game designers!See the data that proves all this isn't "just fluff"!Yes, writing can be fun... and this session will be, too.
column7: How to use analog and digital games in class to improve student creativity, narrative, and writing skills.
column8: How to assess analog and digital gaming to ensure learning is taking place.
column9: Insight and strategies into managing a classroom full of active gamers.

column1: Ownership Yields Growth: A View From 5th Grade
column5: Caroline Student (National Presbyterian School), Karen Parent (Education Design Lab), Keenan Woods (National Presbyterian School), Steve Silvius (Three Ring)
column6: Parent-teacher conferences are an important part of education, but they are missing a key player: students! Research shows that when students have the opportunity to take ownership of their work, it deepens their engagement with the content and expands their love of learning. This session will explore how one 5th grade classroom in Washington, DC has started conducting student-led conferences to allow students to compile examples of their work that highlight their success and areas of growth. A parent and student will join their EdTech specialist on the panel to discuss the variety of outcomes experienced both in the classroom and at home.
column7: Learn how NPS is empowering their fifth grade students to identify and track learning goals using their own work, through photos, audio and video.
column8: Understand the outcomes that teachers and students are seeing in the classroom, and parents are experiencing at home _and how they come together.
column9: Develop a plan for implementing student-led conferences on your own, with concrete examples of how NPS succeeded in this and why it_s valuable.

column1: Panther Transformation- the PV Story
column5: Amy Allen (Parker-varney Elem School), Katie Foyle (Parker-varney Elem School), Susan Austin (Parker-varney Elem School), Kelly  Callanan (Parker-varney Elem School)
column6: Not only was Parker-Varney Elementary School in Manchester, NH  in a rut years ago, it was struggling. The school was in the dreaded _school improvement_ process because of many factors and it needed change.Change is what it got. Administration, teachers, parents and students created a new vision of personalized learning for everyone. The staff began focusing on student data in a meaningful way.  They redesigned the school day, adding more time for teacher collaboration. This new vision included teachers taking risks and releasing the responsibility of learning to their students. In 2015, we were named NH School of Excellence.
column7: After this session, participants will identify key turnaround strategies in school reform
column8: After this session participants will understand the process of design prototyping from the staff and student perspective.
column9: After this session participants will understand how that redesigning time can bring great change to a school community.

column1: Passion and Purpose: Social Justice for Change
column5: Kristin Ziemke (Big Shoulders Fund), Denise Hutchison (Kaleidoscope Youth Center ), Katharine Hale (Arlington Public Schools), Michael Hernandez (Mira Costa High School)
column6: Too often, students are assigned dumpster projects--those with little personal connection that end up in the trash after grading.  We know that the best way to foster deep learning is through authentic experiences that build upon students' passions.  Given our social-political climate, we believe that students should be self-advocates for the concerns of their community and use digital tools to tell personal stories about race, gender and economic inequities.  The panel will share successful social justice practices from elementary through college and discuss ways to empower students to have a positive impact on their community, themselves and society.
column7: Define _social justice_ and how it aligns to standards-based curriculum across the grades.
column8: Walk through the evolution of several social justice projects and how they affected students.
column9: Discuss challenges and best practices for implementing social justice projects in classrooms of all levels.

column1: Personalized Learning: Pasadena_s Story of Change
column5: Jordan  Arbuckle (Pasadena Independent School District), Melissa  Allen (Pasadena Independent School District), Jessica Agus (Summit Public Schools), Vickie Vallet-McWilliams (Pasadena Independent School District)
column6: Is personalized learning for all students? Schools across the country are saying yes.  Pasadena Independent School District has partnered with Summit Public Schools, a California-based Charter Management Organization to personalize learning in Pasadena.  With coaching and support from Summit mentors, three schools (one high school, one intermediate school and one middle school) have piloted practices of a NextGen School Model. Participants will share their stories and experiences developing this partnership, steps taken to adopt a new approach to learning/teaching, training teachers and staff, and communicating the vision to families.
column7: Understand the transition from a teacher-directed instructional model to a student-directed model.
column8: Analyze the challenges of a district pilot program and district-CMO partnership.
column9: Evaluate initial progress at the classroom, school, and district level.

column1: Power Up STEM Professional Development with Games
column5: Victoria Van Voorhis (Second Avenue Learning), Scott Brewster (Triad Interactive Media), Richard Van Eck (The University of North Dakota), Mitch Weisburgh (Games4Ed )
column6: Digital content developers and educational researchers discuss using games to enhance professional development for teachers. This transformative model is designed to better prepare teachers to motivate and teach in STEM areas. Teachers engage in robust, interactive game worlds to obtain crucial conceptual and procedural content understanding while enjoying console quality gaming experiences. Then, it_s only a matter of time before they_ll power up learning in the classroom.
column7: Better preparing teachers to teach STEM topics
column8: Preparing teachers to adopt gaming as a core practice within their teaching
column9: Empowering teachers to become "teacher-gamers" capable of passing passion for STEM and gaming back to the classroom

column1: Preparing Future Innovators for the IoT Era
column5: Kipp Bradford (The Kippworks), Tim Bajarin  (Creative Strategies ), Kimberly  Hughes (UTeach Institute), Ray Hsu (National Instruments )
column6: IoT, Maker and STEM. We read about these every day, but what do they mean for education? Today, everything is smart, connected, multi-functional and increasingly complex. This phenomenon is the Internet of Things (IoT), and it_s impacting the workforce in a big way. Because of the IoT, today_s students _ tomorrow_s innovators _ will need to be prepared for increasingly complex jobs. And the skills and tools they will need for these jobs are different from what they_ve needed in the past. Join STEM, Maker and IoT movement leaders from industry and education to explore how to leverage Maker and STEM best practices inside and outside the classroom to help prepare our students for the IoT.
column7: How will the Internet of Things impact the jobs of the future and the skills required for these jobs?
column8: What tools and resources are available for educators to prepare students?
column9: How can we leverage the Maker movement to help prepare our students for the jobs of tomorrow?

column1: RAISEup Texas: Closing the Achievement Gap
column5: Susan Dawson (E3 Alliance), Teri Clement (Hays CISD- Simon Middle School), Matt Pope (E3 Alliance)
column6: Participants will learn about RAISEup Texas, a collaborative effort to transform middle school teaching and learning. It is changing how middle school students learn and meet high standards for college and career-readiness by implementing instructional strategies that help all students learn and achieve, in every subject and every classroom. Presenters will detail the compelling data from the demonstration project where struggling students had ten times as many point gains over the three years compared to their nationally-normed peers from across the country who started at the same level. The expansion plan of RAISEup is currently implemented and will potentially impact 28,000 students.
column7: Participants will learn about the RAISEup demonstration project and the incredible data for the participating schools and struggling learners.
column8: Participants will be exposed to instructional strategies and school-wide systems that dramatically improve teaching and learning.
column9: Participants will gain knowledge of the current expansion of RAISEup and how to potentially be involved in transforming their schools.

column1: Ready, Set, Change: It's Time for Online Learning
column5: Matthew Conway (Derby Public Schools), Jennifer Beagan (Allegheny Intermediate Unit), Shannon Goodsell (Casa Grande Union High School District), Sari Factor (Edgenuity)
column6: Online and blended learning have finally delivered on technology_s promise to personalize the learning experience for all students. From student control over pace to data that customizes unique learning paths, online learning meets students where they are at to ensure academic success. In this session, a panel of several highly experienced, innovative district administrators will share their insights on how to implement online programs that meet students_ unique learning styles and raise the bar for achievement across rural, urban and suburban districts. Hear lessons learned and best practices that will ensure students, teachers, and the entire school community can be successful.
column7: Discover how online and blended learning offers unique opportunities to personalize learning and foster student achievement.
column8: Hear firsthand lessons learned and best practices from school district superintendents from across the country.
column9: Understand the important, but evolving, role that teachers play in a blended and online classroom.

column1: Reengineering Education the Garland Way
column5: Scott Kinney (Discovery Education), Mida Milligan (Garland Independent School District), Nelson Orta (Garland Independent School District), Tina Garrett (Garland Independent School District)
column6: By combining rigorous instruction, technological innovation, and college/career preparation, Texas_ Garland ISD (GISD) is making each student ready for their future. Hear directly from GISD educators about how they collaborated with stakeholders across the school system and their community to reengineer teaching and learning in their district to create the unique blend of curriculum, pedagogy and digital ecosystems that is now known as the _Garland Way._
column7: Discuss Garland as a case study: What specific problems was Garland facing, and how are they similar to what districts everywhere face.
column8: Step-by-step accounting of how Garland transformed itself and discussion on how other districts can do the same.
column9: Discussion of results and the Garland Way as it evolves into the future.

column1: Reimagine Education: Abandoning Age-Based Learning
column5: Roger Cook (Taylor County Schools ), Dr. Marina Walne (EduStart LLC), Stephan Turnipseed (LEGO Education)
column6: Our education system is fundamentally stagnant and it is time that it is overhauled. The aged-based education structure worked well for most of the 20th century, but it has now run its course and will leave students ill prepared for the careers of the future. To improve the outlook for students, we must put them first and move towards a mastery system, where students graduate when they demonstrate a deep knowledge of the subject matter. Join this panel discussion to learn how school systems can implement a _learner-centered paradigm_ where students complete day to day tasks at their own pace until they have mastered the curriculum, ensuring they are prepared with a Network Age education.
column7: Create an open-wall learning experience by partnering with organizations to provide students with real-life experiences, evaluations and feedback.
column8: Implement an assessment for learning _ providing formative, real-time and diagnostic insights for students.
column9: Leverage technology solutions to provide various daily tasks and individualized work for each student_s needs.

column1: Scaling Personalized Learning
column5: Karen Cator (Digital Promise), Aaryn  Schmuhl (Henry County Schools), Jimmy Sarakatsannis (McKinsey & Company)
column6: We know personalized learning_meeting each student where they are with what they need at the right time_is the holy grail of education. It has existed for generations, from 1:1 tutors to Montessori. Now, new technologies are enabling the development of powerful _blended_ models, with early evidence suggesting students can learn in these environments at 1.5x the pace compared to "traditional" approaches. But success stories are still few and scaling this type of instruction is difficult. How can school system leaders accelerate widespread adoption of these innovative models?
column7: Learn what various stakeholders can do to establish a proper vision for their organization for personalized learning.
column8: Understand the obstacles that the system faces when implementing and scaling personalized learning.
column9: Learn how to overcome common challenges to the scaling of personalized learning.

column1: School_s Out, So Let The Learning Continue
column5: Debbi Jarvis (Pepco Holdings, Inc.), Dr. Cindy Moss (Discovery Education), Henry Saxon (Boys and Girls Club of America), Gina Warner (National AfterSchool Association)
column6: Classrooms are no longer the only place for learning. Afterschool programs are now more powerful than ever as they are key opportunities to get kids engaged in STEM, the arts, and other subjects. Moderated by the Executive Director of the National AfterSchool Association, this panel discussion will convene leaders from Discovery Education, Pepco Holdings, Inc. and Boys & Girls Clubs of America to explore the myriad opportunities open to kids outside of the classroom.
column7: Discuss why learning must continue when the school bell ends and how digital learning can play a huge role.
column8: Explore the benefits of afterschool, supplemental, experiential and project-based learning _ and some of the best programs available.
column9: Explore how in-school and afterschool work together, and how supplemental programs build STEM skills that enhance in-school learning and teachings.

column1: Schools Not Jails, Education Not Incarceration
column5: Alfred  McAllister (University of Texas School of Public Health), Bianca Neal (ReRoute Music Group), SaulPaul _ (ReRoute Music Group)
column6: Rappers & music artists have successfully engaged youth audiences by being authentic and raw. As a result, they have gained influence in largely at-risk youth communities. In this train the trainer session, SaulPaul, A Musician with a Message, will share how you can draw on this technique to engage students in a relevant way that produces positive results. As one of the nation's top at-risk youth specialists, SaulPaul will also share how you can strengthen your cultural competency skills in working with at-risk populations.  This panel will feature data collected on SaulPaul's 15 city educational tour as well as feature an interview with renowned UT's School of Public Health Dr. McAllister.
column7: What are the challenges and opportunities for engaging African American and Latino at-risk students in an educational environment? With social media?
column8: What role can rich media content play in sparking higher education enrollment and admissions among African American and Latino at-risk students?
column9: How can we create interactive and engaging media for young African American and Latino at-risk students to expose them to career opportunities?

column1: Secondary PBL and the 21st Century Work Force?
column5: Gerhard Deffner (Self Employed), Whitney Williams (McKinney Independent School District)
column6: Use of Instructional Technology in the secondary classroom enables students to explore the implications of "old knowledge" through new applications such as research, interviews, cultural experts, and media analysis.
column7: For students - bridging the gap between themes in literature and modern life
column8: For educators - understanding the motivational potential of self - directed learning
column9: For the business audience - recognizing the skills of self directed learners

column1: Shakespeare v. Skills- Should it be Hire Learning?
column5: Mark Barnes (Brilliant or Insane), Michael Mathews (Oral Roberts University), Jeff Alderson (Eduventures), John  Baker (D2L)
column6: Can business and education co-exist? Should higher ed focus on educating or is their _job_ to train the future workforce? Are the goals mutually exclusive?These are loaded, heated questions. Higher ed is failing to provide students with the skills needed to thrive in the modern workplace _ at least that is what the majority of employers believe. Higher ed, however, believes differently. It_s a global debate. What_s higher ed_s job? Should educators be focused on training students for the workforce versus providing a broader liberal arts education? This panel of educators and business leaders will debate this globally contentious issue and discuss how higher ed can close the skills gap.
column7: Is it truly higher ed_s job to get students ready for jobs, or is it to educate students?
column8: Can higher ed can work with businesses and stay autonomous and uncorrupted in their pursuit of educating?
column9: How models like competency-based education provide a pathway to improving graduate employability.

column1: Student Loan Counseling: Tech, Policy, & Practice
column5: Raul Lerma (El Paso Community College), Megan McClean (NASFAA), Bryan Ashton (The Ohio State University), Jeff Webster (TG)
column6: Although often just transitioning to financial independence, today's postsecondary students are increasingly compelled to navigate the complexities of student loan borrowing and repayment, but they do so with the assistance of mandatory counseling. Student loan counseling sits at the intersection of three principle forces: the statutes that govern it; the online materials that deliver it; and the institutions that can also establish counseling programs. A policy expert, a researcher, and two practitioners will discuss findings from a study examining each of these constituent parts and offering recommendations for a more effective student loan counseling system.
column7: What are key principles of effectiveness for online counseling materials?
column8: What kinds of innovative programs have institutions implemented to provide more effective counseling to their borrowers?
column9: How have policy decisions structured the current loan counseling experience, and how can they improve it going forward?

column1: Student's Digital Footprint vs Student Privacy
column5: Girish  Venkat (Thrively), Darri  Stephens  (Common Sense Media ), Brad  Waid  (Self ), Melissa  Davis (GoEnnounce)
column6: What's the balance between teaching students how to have a positive digital footprint vs. limiting student data online for privacy protection purposes?Can we teach students to use their own data effectively online for college and career readiness or is there too much risk when it comes to privacy laws?  With the surge of innovative products putting student data out there, what should we be "policing" and limiting, and what should we be encouraging and mentoring students to use safely?   Join us to discuss the pro's and cons of teaching students to brand themselves online with digital learning & e-portfolio tools and what this means when it comes to putting this student data out there
column7: Participants will gain a broader understanding of the types of digital learning and e-portfolio tools out there for students to "brand themselves".
column8: Participants will gain an understanding of how student led digital tools can better prepare students for college & career readiness.
column9: Participants will walk away understanding the types of information students are giving these platforms and what to caution against.

column1: Tackling Words & Images Critically with Students
column5: Emily Keating (Jacob Burns Film Center), Michele Haiken (Rye Middle School), Steve Siden (Actively Learn)
column6: As the historically static world of text, and the dynamic visual media worlds are converging, students are reading more and more on a screen than in a paper text, and are required to transfer reading skills to visual media. Technology and schooling continue to evolve, teachers must continue to support/equip students with literacy skills needed to participate, engage, and succeed in our global and digital society. To do so, students must develop skills to read in print and online, decode these messages, and critically think about text and media. The diverse panel will address strategies and techniques for teaching students to read texts critically and deepen comprehension of digital texts.
column7: Participants will be able to identify & distinguish the differences between _digital literacy_ _visual literacy_ and _ functional literacy_
column8: Participants will be introduced to (provided with) new strategies & practices that help teach visual & text literacy.
column9: Participants will be prepared to engage in critical conversations around reading, critical thinking, and digital media at their school.

column1: Teacher & Student Real Talk: Personalized Learning
column5: Chris  Rush (New Classrooms), Seth Reynolds (Parthenon EY)
column6: Does tech in the classroom deprive students of social interaction and quality instruction? What is the teacher experience leading classrooms with blended learning? Should schools partner with an outside organization to provide instruction? What are the key resources? It_s time we heard from students and teachers on the front lines in personalized learning. A student, a teacher, and a new school model leader will discuss their experience in an Elizabeth, New Jersey public school.With a $3M Investing in Innovation grant, Elizabeth Public Schools partners with nonprofit New Classrooms_ Teach to One: Math, providing live, online, and collaborative instruction for personalized learning.
column7: Audience will examine the reimagined personalized learning environment through the day-to-day experience of students and teachers
column8: Discuss the challenges to teachers and students in transitioning from the traditional model of learning to a personalized learning environment
column9: Audience will explore the emerging paradigm of schools and third party organizations partnering to meet the unique needs of students

column1: Teaching History by Celebrating Ancestors Online
column5: Cindy  Maguire (Arts Action Group), Thomas Campbell (Adelphi University), Terrence  Ross (Adelphi University)
column6: Shared Roots is devoted to teaching history by researching and then celebrating ancestors via a social networking site (sharedroots.net). The panel will explain how this project has been implemented at Adelphi University. Student work will be screened and the classroom approach will be detailed.
