Work will also be screened from the project_s outreach to underserved populations, in particular the Sahrawi of Western Sahara, whose ancestor stories are being added to the historical archive through the Shared Roots site.  Panelists will walk educators through how to use the site with their students.
column7: Learn how to use a social networking site for educational purposes. Education needs to capitalize on what young people gravitate to.
column8: See potential for teaching history through grounding it in researching an ancestor.
column9: Understand the need for archiving the ancestors of marginalized cultures.  There is no absolute truth. All memories of all cultures must be recorded.

column1: Teaching STEM Through Sports and Games
column5: Ahmad Nassar (NFL Players, Inc.), Lori McFarling (Discovery Education), A current NFL player to be confirmed closer to the conference date N/A (National Football League ), Daryl Holt (EA Studios)
column6: Baseball can teach statistics. Football can teach physics and force. Basketball can teach aerodynamics. Discovery Education, NFL Players Association and Electronic Arts (which recently released an educational version of its iconic Madden Football franchise) will host a panel about how we can engage kids in the fundamentals of science and other subjects through the use of sports-centric interactives. Joining them will be an NFL player, who will discuss what he_s learned about STEM from his work on the field.
column7: Discussion of why games and sports and popular titles are key to grabbing the attention of young learners.
column8: Give concrete examples of science in sports that teachers in attendance can use when they return to their classrooms.
column9: How to discuss with naysayers the merits of using a popular consumer video game as an educational tool.

column1: Tech & Teachers: Friend or Foe?
column5: Daisy Dyer Duerr (Former principal of St. Paul Public Schools, Turn-around Consultant), Kerry  Gallagher (St. John's Preparatory School), Milton Bryant (Ketcham Elementary), Greg Toppo (USA Today)
column6: National news media often puts tech and teachers at odds. This panel explores what is actually happening in today's classrooms. Are teachers concerned about the national debate on data privacy? Or that they will be replaced by tech? How does technology impact them in the real-world? Can ed tech play a role in both high need and rural districts? A few of the best-known teachers on social media from a diverse range of schools will join USA Today_s lead education reporter to explore whether the media is getting it right. They_ll share classroom tips, explain how to find the right tools and resources, and answer your questions.
column7: Identify arguments and issues about ed tech commonly raised in the media and understand all aspects of the debate.
column8: Take home concrete examples on the ways technology is helping teachers and principals do more in their schools, including ways to copy their success.
column9: Understand the various ways teachers are using tech in socioeconomic and geographically diverse settings.

column1: Tech+MediaLit = Critical Production
column5: Ann McMullan (Ann McMullan Educational Technology Consultant), Tessa Jolls (Center for Media Literacy), Brad Koepenick (iLeadSchools)
column6: Using technology does not stand alone as a teaching strategy. Students need to be able to think critically and responsibly as they use technology, whether to express themselves and to participate in the global village through social media or through coding and games. Media literacy provides the skills of critical analysis necessary to decode and encode media -- anytime, anywhere.  See how to use a research-based media literacy framework, which can easily be coupled with technology in the classroom to empower students to be critical consumers, producers and participants in the media world.  This panel will address the tech, medialit and production know-how needed for classrooms today.
column7: Learn the basic frameworks for media literacy and a brief summary of the longitudinal research behind classroom implementation.
column8: Hear how a California Charter School Teacher of the Year gets outstanding results through production, while teaching media literacy, using technology.
column9: Find out how technology and technology budgets can be used to enable critical thinking through media literacy instruction in school districts.

column1: The Math Wars are Over_And Digital Won
column5: Justin Metzger (Carroll County Public Schools), Marty Creel (Discovery Education), Mark Schommer (D.C. Everest Area School District), Matt Larson (The National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM) )
column6: The public dialogue on math education has for years been dominated by various camps backing one pedagogy or another. However, the advent of a new generation of digital resources has empowered classroom teachers to go beyond pedagogy and tailor instruction to fit the needs of individual students.  Hear the perspectives of various educators as they discuss how digital content ultimately won the _Math Wars._
column7: Discuss the evolution of the math wars _ from the 80s until now
column8: Look at why digital tools are more effective with today_s digital natives
column9: Explore different models of integrating digital learning into math classes

column1: The Meriden "Miracle"
column5: Randi  Weingarten (American Federation of Teachers), Erin  Benham (Meriden Public Schools), Mark  Benigni (Meriden Public Schools), Wayne D'Orio (Scholastic)
column6: For decades, school administrators and teachers_ unions have fought about money, control, and basically anything else that constitutes education. So when a union and an administration get along, it's uncommon. When they do so while suffering through five straight years without a budget increase, it's rare. When they do both of those, collaborate on numerous initiatives and raise student achievement in multiple ways, it's singular. Meriden, CT, is the unlikely spot where all this happens. Superintendent Mark Benigni and union president Erin Benham have created a model partnership, but AFT president Randi Weingarten will explain how this common-sense model can take hold across the country.
column7: Learn how unions and administration can collaborate on progressive initiatives, such as extended learning time and Saturday academies.
column8: See how school districts can shift funding from traditional expenses such as textbooks to technology and digital content.
column9: Discover how partnering with teachers can create future leaders, boost PD offerings, and maintain a pipeline of new talent for classrooms.

column1: The Myth of Magical Devices
column5: Sabba Quidwai (Keck School of Medicine of USC), Michael Cohen (Harkham Hillel Hebrew Academy), Carl Hooker (Eanes ISD)
column6: Like the magic lamp, it_s easy to believe that a device will automatically ignite a sense of excitement, engagement and exceptionally engaged learning. What happens when your three wishes run out? When the magical excitement of technology in the classroom wears off? Initially it may seem that technology makes your classroom awesome, focused, calm and organized, however ultimately it_s not about the device but how we as educators transform the learning experiences in our classroom. The real magical force in your classroom is the experience that you create using technology to shift from talking about one another, to with one another, as independent, confident, and successful learners.
column7: Define and distinguish between student empowerment through innovation versus technology integration.
column8: Discuss strategies for educators to better support student independence, critical thinking, problem solving, and communication skills with technology.
column9: Learn how to leverage film, photography, audio, music, and animation to generate powerful and clear evidence of learning that make students proud.

column1: The Paradigm Shift of a Global Classroom
column5: Liz Meredith (St. Clairsville-Richland City Schools), Anders Enstrm (Enstrom Education and stra Grundskolan), Brian Jones (GlobalCOlab), Ayelet Segal (TouchCast)
column6: This past year, students from around the world came together to collaborate on world issues affecting their communities, taking the concept of global learning and turning it into a reality. In GlobalCOlab (GCL), Students teaching students from around the world, has connected students and educators from different cultures and religions from around the world to cross-cut disciplines, curricula, and traditional subjects to empower participants through student-led and student-created topics. These topics are based around global issues affecting each student_s community. GCL educators will discuss the need for an educational paradigm shift towards a global classroom in a one hour panel format.
column7: Learning crosscuts all subject matter and can only be fully realized through connecting students to real world experiences and people.
column8: GCL not only provides the conceptual shift in education, but re-imagines the classroom into a border-less and subject-less world the user creates.
column9: The goal is to stress the process of learning in order to provide students the preparation needed to enter tomorrow_s workforce.

column1: The Potential Power of OER
column5: Tracy Weeks (NCDPI), Layla Bonnot (CCSSO), Karl Nelson (The K-12 OER Collaborative), Diana Suddreth (Utah State Office of Education)
column6: Although states have been individually pursuing opportunities in open educational resources (OER) for years, the CCSS adoption in 46 states has expanded the conversation to considering how states can leverage OER to better support common standards and expectations across states. After all, one of the advantages to common, higher standards is that resources and instructional materials can be shared more broadly, across states and between educators. This session will explore the leadership occurring in state education agencies to create systems that facilitate the sharing of digital instructional materials through OER and other partnerships.
column7: Learn about efforts to increase access and use of digital materials to support implementation of standards and further instructional improvement.
column8: Hear from SEA staff on the importance of making materials as available and accessible to educators as possible to enable instructional improvement.
column9: Hear about currently available digital materials as well as the work of the K-12 OER Collaborative.

column1: The Power of Student Voice in Today_s Classroom
column5: Shanna Peeples (CCSSO)
column6: _When you bring student voice into your lesson, that is when you get a great leap of creativity and innovation,_ says 2015 National Teacher of the Year Shanna Peeples of Amarillo, Texas. In this session, Peeples will be joined by two of her former students to show how she has incorporated student voice into her instruction to the great benefit of her students _ and her teaching practice. The conversation will foster new ideas and strategies all teachers can take back to their classroom.
column7: Understand the power of student voice in daily instruction, what it looks like and how it benefits students.
column8: Show how teachers can incorporate student voice in their instruction while still teaching to content standards.
column9: See how incorporating student voice connects to deeper learning, project-based learning and the critical skills every child needs when they graduate.

column1: The Rather Prize: The Best Idea to Improve TX Edu
column5: Martin Rather (The Rather Prize), Dan Rather (News and Guts), TBD TBD (The Rather Prize)
column6: The Rather Prize is a $10k prize given to the person behind the best idea to improve education in the state of Texas. The statewide prize is open to students, teachers, and administrators in Texas. After being selected, we hope to present the winner at SXSWedu, and their idea will be evaluated by Rice University.For our session, the prizewinner will present their idea as part of a discussion with Dan Rather, TV journalist and Rather Prize co-founder, and Martin Rather, Rather Prize Operational Director. We will begin with a discussion of Dan Rather's Texan education, shifting to Martin Rather discussing the Rather Prize details, and then the winner's presentation followed by an open Q&A.
column7: For our audience to learn about the best idea to improve Texas education from those who are living it on a daily basis.
column8: We want to promote future discussion of ideas and projects by highlighting our opportunity to those who may not have yet heard of the Rather Prize.
column9: We want people to know what worked for our Prize, what didn't, and how we can all continue to raise the bar on TX education and competitive prizes.

column1: The Rise of Coding Schools: Changing the landscape
column5: Pamela Greenberg (HackReactor), Jeff  Wolinsky  (MakerSquare), Harsh Patel (MakerSquare), Joel Burton (Hackbright)
column6: Many of us have heard about software engineering immersives (or bootcamps), but how much does the general public really know about this new phenomenon?  The Rise of Coding Schools aims to demystify coding schools.  We will describe the instructional techniques employed, and give examples of how the industry is driven by student outcomes.  Attendees will learn how students can learn complex skills at an accelerated pace, and join the workforce much faster than traditionally expected.  The panel will include both executives and instructors, and looks to give attendees an inside look at the industry.
column7: What kind of people enroll in code schools?
column8: How do teaching styles differ between coding schools and universities?
column9: Are code school graduates successful in the job market?

column1: The Story Telling Beast: Narrative Frames Learnin
column5: Lisa  Palmieri (The Ellis School), Michael Matera (University School of Milwaukee), Chris Davis (Colegio Nueva Granada)
column6: Narrative, embedded in our cognitive architecture, frames the way we learn.  We investigate the commonalities in the design of learning environments in design thinking projects, fantasy narrative in gamification, contextualized social innovation projects, and how the documentation of learning creates its own narrative.  Our case based studies detail the narrative structure elements necessary for students to immerse, define, and manipulate their environments as agents of their own learning.
column7: Identify and compare narrative structure in learning environments - design thinking, social innovation, gamification, and documentary.
column8: Understand the role of transmedia in learning environment design, how multimodal learning unlocks agency.
column9: Explore how story creates the aesthetic, ethical, affective link to learning.

column1: The Subtle Psychology of Motivation and Learning
column5: David Yeager (The University of Texas at Austin), Andrew Butler (The University of Texas at Austin), Rachel Beattie (The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching), Andrew Krumm (SRI International)
column6: Psychological experiments have developed novel methods that havesurprising effects on motivation and learning, but how can you use theseto transform learning?  This session will present the most interestinginsights from research on the science of human motivation and learning.Each member of the panel will share their unique, practical case studies.Both attendees and panelists will participate in discussions about howresearch on the psychology of motivation has been and can be used to get breakthrough results for the toughest problems in education.
column7: Participants will learn about the newest research on the science of the psychology of motivation and learning
column8: Participants will learn how the psychology of motivation has been used to transform learning in a variety of learning contexts
column9: Participants will understand how to apply motivational psychology in educational settings

column1: The Whale Project II: Arts-Based Learning
column5: Jeremy  Goldbogen (Stanford University), Tamara Goldbogen (Weber State University)
column6: Scientists, Artists, and Educators across the country are joining forces on an arts-based, experiential science learning initiative. Working together on a conference, the team modeled the process of arts integration, utilizing proven effective teaching strategies, to spark teacher and student excitement about science, art, and the world around them through arts-integrated science curricula. This talk will highlight the process of structuring an arts integration experience as a professional learning experience for K-12 educators. Touchstones for our talk will the 2015 WSU Arts Integration Conference, plans for the 2016 Conference, and pertinent arts education research findings.
column7: Exploring the potential of this type of educational collaboration to forge connections between higher education and K-12 institutions
column8: Examine STEM from an arts based perspective
column9: Model and engage teachers in thinking in more holistic ways

column1: Thinking Not Boredom: Inspire Nonfiction Readers
column5: Kristin Ziemke (Big Shoulders Fund), Christopher Lehman (The Educator Collaborative), Sara Ahmed (Harlem Village Academy)
column6: _Open to page 178, copy the words in bold print, tomorrow we_ll be discussing the lifecycle of a plant__ STOP RIGHT THERE. The study of nonfiction shouldn_t be filled with note-taking and boredom. Instead it should be an opportunity to spark curiosity and wonder as student interest and passion guide the curriculum. This session will share stories from the classroom and strategies for using choice and voice to engage learners across the grades. Join nationally recognized literacy leaders as they pair text, images, media and web tools to reimagine instruction, add layers of interaction and inspire students to read, write and think.
column7: Demonstrate ways that educators can enhance their teaching of nonfiction and media literacy with creation and collaboration web tools.
column8: Explore mindsets regarding nonfiction and alternatives that support more engaging and rigorous curriculum development and instruction.
column9: Provide practical, research-based strategies educators can implement "tomorrow" with their students.

column1: Transforming Education: "Bytes" vs. "Prix fixe"?
column5: Lisa Hansel (Core Knowledge Foundation), Jeff Katzman (Core Learning Exchange), Jeanne Imbriale (Baltimore County Public Schools)
column6: Which do you prefer: Tapas or Master Chef Menu Prix Fixe?  In the classroom, do you mix and match bite-size resources to keep students engaged, or adhere to a cohesive curriculum of proven efficacy?  As edtech providers aggregate huge libraries of snackable content, teachers have unprecedented flexibility to design a custom learning experience for each student. But does breaking an education down into chunks allow learners to build a foundation of essential knowledge and master complex skills?  Add your voice to the debate on personalization and the transformation of teaching and learning.
column7: Understand the benefits and drawbacks of "bite-size" educational content.
column8: Discuss the role of personalized learning in teaching content knowledge and complex skills.
column9: Consider the balance between building shared knowledge and accommodating diverse student backgrounds.

column1: Turning a 1000:1 learner educator ratio to 1:1
column5: Rayna Yaker (RYE Consulting), Will  Wong (Devry Inc. ), Simeon Schnapper (Youtopia), Ravi Pilla (StudyCloud)
column6: College students are paying nearly $1 for every minute of class time. Devry, StudyCloud, Youtopia and RYE Consulting are pioneering peer to peer learning and engagement strategies to effectively bring the educator to student ratio down to 1:1. Educators will learn how to utilize technology to improve learning outcomes. Entrepreneurs will learn how these startups are evolving their products to empower learners worldwide.
column7: How leading online institutions are utilizing technology to engage learners.
column8: How startups are shaping their products to ensure high learning outcomes for students.
column9: Higher education trends that will shape how students will learn with each other and their instructors.

column1: Using Comics & Graphic Novels in K-12 Teaching
column5: Ronell Whitaker (Community High School District 218), Eric Kallenborn  (Community High School District 218), Dr. Katie Monnin (University of North Florida), Nader Qaimari (Follett School Solutions)
column6: Comic books and graphic novels have long been thought of as entertainment, but they can also be excellent learning tools. Katie Monnin, author of many popular texts about teaching graphic novels in 21st-century classrooms, will share how comics and graphic novels help kids learn key literacy skills. Monnin will discuss how graphic novels can help with building complex reading skills, making inferences, what ages and grades are best suited for using comic books and how they can be used with early learners. Two seasoned educators who rely upon graphic novels in their curriculum will share how they've used these tools (with success) to reach kids who might otherwise fall through the cracks.
column7: Learn how comics & graphic novels can be used as a point of reference to bridge what students already know with what they have yet to learn
column8: Hear ways the panelists use comics/graphic novels to help struggling readers, at risk students, & others who may not learn best from traditional tools
column9: Attendees will learn how these tools boost learning, create new memory pathways, and how they promote verbal skills and memory

column1: Using Digital to Expand the Historical Narrative
column5: Scott Abbott (DC Public Schools), Chris Layton (Oak Ridge Schools), Kelli Campbell (Discovery Education), Joe Sangillo (Montgomery County Public Schools)
column6: US history is the collective story of all Americans.  Through digital content, educators are now empowered to explore with their students the stories of the men, women, places, and events often left out of the historical narrative by traditional textbooks.  Hear from educator and blogger Joe Sangillo and educators around the country on how to they are utilizing digital content to transform social studies education and make every voice in US history heard.
column7: Explore the challenges that schools, teachers and parents have faced in terms of teaching and engaging kids in social studies in recent years
column8: Look at how digital content is being utilized to reinvigorate the topic and bring history to life
column9: Discuss models of digital integration with traditional classrooms

column1: Using Video to Put Teachers in the Driver's Seat
column5: Angele Hodges (Ft. Worth Independent School District), Abby Kirschner (TNTP), Shannon Lindstedt (TNTP), Robert Ovalle (Pinellas County Schools)
column6: Teachers often have people observe their classrooms_but they never have the chance to see themselves in action. Can video put teachers in the driver_s seat? If teachers film their own classrooms, and get feedback on the video virtually from a coach, will they be motivated to change their practice? That_s what TNTP is exploring with an elementary school in Florida, and a middle school in Texas. Teachers film themselves twice per month, and connect in teams to give each other feedback in addition to working with a virtual coach. Here, the principals, teachers and virtual coaches reflect on their experiences_both successes and pitfalls_and discuss whether video can improve teacher practice.
column7: The principals will share their vision for the work, how it went, and what they might approach differently in using video and virtual work again.
column8: A teacher shares what the experience was like, including the valuable pieces as well as the pitfalls, and how it ultimately affected student learning.
column9: A virtual coach shares her take on if and how this work helped to move teacher practice, and how coaching virtually compares to in-person coaching

column1: Virtual Reality: A New World of Learning
column5: David Scott (Upper Grand District School Board), Elizabeth Lytle (zSpace), Rebecca Girard (Notre Dame High School), Ben Schrom  (Google )
column6: Virtual reality (VR) is changing the way today's _digital generation_ interacts with information and is already expanding the walls of classrooms. Experience for yourself the impact that VR is having in learning spaces around the world. Join us in a conversation about these experiences and discuss the questions that are emerging as VR technology continues to develop: How does VR have a direct impact on learning? What happens when the WOW wears off? Doesn_t VR create isolation and remove students from the learning environment? How will educators and students be a part of VR content creation? As educators, innovators, and content creators, we look forward to engaging with you and your question
column7: Discover how virtual reality redefines learning by doing experiences in the classroom.
column8: Explore how virtual reality technologies increase interaction and expand social engagement in the classroom.
column9: Describe how exploration and student-directed, hands-on approaches in VR support active and deep learning.

column1: What Floats Your Boat? A Learning Festival
column5: Sarah O'Leary ( Museum of Fine Arts, Boston), Corrina Strecker (Ann Arbor Hands On Science Museum), Jason Robertshaw (Mote Marine Laboratory), janet zanetis (Center for Interactive Learning & Collaboration)
column6: In 2015, a global collaboration of museums, science centers and cultural organizations joined together to offer a first-of-its-kind festival of learning to classrooms around the world. Using interactive video and web-based platforms, these content providers are connecting with thousands of teachers and students to deliver live, accessible, inquiry-driven, standards-based programs. See what lessons were learned with our first festival, "What Floats Your Boat?", and hear from a panel of informal educators who reached across the firewall to impact student learning. Get a sneak peek at future festivals and find out how you can get on board.
column7: Learn about a giant, collaborative project that is inclusive of all learners everywhere.  Discover how to participate in the projects to come!
column8: Using existing classroom infrastructure learn how to participate in synchronous video collaborations through web-based solutions.
column9: Learn how to find engaging, standards-based, interactive programs with highly knowledgable museum educators to insure deep learning for your students.

column1: What_s Your Story? A K12, Higher Ed Partnership
column5: Ed Madison (University of Oregon ), NICOLE KRAFT (The Ohio State University), Steve  Douglass (Lake Forest High School), Dominic Pettine (Albuquerque Public Schools )
column6: The challenge across education is to engage learners of all ages, to help them see relevance and become invested in their own education, and to navigate an ever wider and deeper academic pool in a meaningful way. Too often, higher ed and K-12 tackle these issues from isolated and separate positions--but no more. This panel will address how, by using technology, K12 and higher ed can develop a narrative curriculum that spans both of their domains and allows students to learn through their own digital storytelling techniques. This collaborative technique will help serve the learner as a whole--from early development all the way through to career readiness.
column7: To identify and explore the benefits of a K12, Higher Ed partnership and how its serves the whole learner.
column8: To illustrate different styles of digital narrative and storytelling, and how they can inspire student learning across curriculum.
column9: To identify technologies that will help teachers at every level better engage with and inspire learning in their own students.

column1: Why Startups Should Hire My High School Students
column5: Dave Ferrero (Vulcan, Inc.), Scott Swaaley (High Tech High ), Michael Wierusz (Northshore School District ), Regan Drew (Riverpoint Academy)
column6: Can your students sell a closet organizing app, make a steampunk violin, or design a high school of the future?The first teachers to be named Allen Distinguished Educators (ADE) focus on developing students with a passion for becoming designers, builders and entrepreneurs. Through innovative teaching methods, new education technologies and hands-on projects, these teachers are bringing students to engineering and entrepreneurship _ subjects that reflect the interests of the creator of the ADE program, philanthropist and entrepreneur Paul G. Allen. The ADEs will discuss their methods for student interaction, teacher collaboration, how to overcome obstacles, and best practices.
column7: Methods for bringing engineering and entrepreneurship into the classroom
column8: Best practices in project-based learning
column9: Examples of teacher-led classroom innovation

column1: Will Smartphones Replace Textbooks?
column5: Steven Hornik (University of Central Florida), Brooke Hermanson (Baltimore Polytechnic Institute), William Jeffery (Fort Bend ISD), Mia Quagliarello (Flipboard)
column6: Students today are glued to their screens, but how can they use their smartphones for something that's actually making them smart? When used for group curation, phones can supercharge a curriculum, raise class participation and creativity, and bring current events to a generation who thought they didn't care about the news. When students share articles together, they understand abstract concepts through real-world examples and feel more invested in their own education. These teachers have cracked the code on using Flipboard Magazines to empower their students and turn those ever-present phones into tools for meaningful learning.
column7: Understanding the role curation can play in education, critical thinking and personal development.
column8: Understanding the key tools for curation in the classroom and how smartphones can be used in education.
column9: Understanding best practices for curation in the classroom, including real teacher success stories.

column1: Wired and unplugged CS: blended learning in practi
column5: Thor Prichard (Clarity Innovations), Kimberly Lane (Lancaster ISD), Alice Steinglass (https://www.linkedin.com/in/alicesteinglass), Josh Caldwell (Code.org)
column6: For many, teaching technology by definition means students sitting at computers every day, but for a truly engaging and equitable experience, sometimes the best bet is to get unplugged. At Code.org we blend offline lessons with online instruction to build stronger learning experiences, and our research shows that students who engage in these blended courses with a classroom teacher are up to twice as likely to persist and succeed. These lessons are, for many, the key to bringing non-traditional students into CS. Join us to discuss three aspects of building a blended learning environment: managing the classroom, designing curriculum, and building software to support in classroom activities.
column7: Review best practices for designing effective blended learning curricula
column8: Compare and contrast methods for designing and building engaging technology for students
column9: Discuss how to launch a successful blended learning program in your own school or district

column1: #140Character Culture: Schoolwide Twitter Adoption
column5: Chris Casal (Heathcote Elementary School ), Pam Moran (Edutopia/ The George Lucas Educational Foundation), Joseph Manko (Liberty Elementary School), Elana  Leoni (Edutopia/ The George Lucas Educational Foundation)
column6: Many educators use Twitter for professional development but can it also be used to create a strong school culture? In this interactive session, you'll hear from schools that have successfully used Twitter to increase collaboration and transparency. And that's not just it...we'll show you how to actually get started with practical tips from teachers and principals in the field.
column7: Attendees will walk away with tactical tips and tricks to get started using Twitter to fuel school collaboration.
column8: A collection of links and resources, a step-by-step guide to get started, social media guidelines, and many ideas to incentivize educators.
column9: Security concerns along with simple ways to make the case with easy wins will also be given (and crowdsourced from the room).

column1: 60x30TX - The Future of Higher Education in Texas
column5: Woody Hunt (Hunt Industies), Karan Watson (Texas A&M University), Raymund Paredes (Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board), Eva Sage-Gavin (Aspen Institute)
column6: Texas must increase student success through the combined expertise and resources of many stakeholders. The state's new higher edu strategic plan, 60x30TX, strives for 60 percent of the 25- to 34-year-old Texas workforce to hold a certificate or degree by 2030. Through collaborative efforts, Texas institutions of higher education will have more opportunities to develop their unique institutional identities, which will enrich both Texas and Texans. This panel discussion will focus on how the 60x30TX plan will take bold steps toward helping Texas meet the needs of its workforce, communities and individuals. Texas has a diverse population; the goal is to have a diverse and educated population.
column7: Recognize that public and private good can't be separate efforts.
column8: Learn why college (certificates, associate's, bachelor's and graduate degrees) is worth it
column9: Understand how achieving both attainment and completion, having marketable skills, and controlling student debt will have a positive impact on us all

column1: A New Narrative: Storytelling for Social Change
column5: Jaime Aquino (New Leaders), Nadia Lopez (Mott Hall Bridges Academy), Debra Wexler (New Leaders), Syreeta Gates (August Martin HS)
column6: In education, data is king. But when engaging supporters, an inspiring story can be more powerful. This is true whether building a shared vision for a school community or externalizing that to mobilize change.Last winter, Principal Nadia Lopez won national attention when a student was interviewed for the Humans of NY blog. But even before, she partnered with Syreeta Gates to empower students to tell their story of Brownsville in a digital magazine. They'll share practical lessons from their experience with representatives from New Leaders, who aim to foster & share stories like these to transform public understanding about the vital importance of leadership in creating vibrant schools.
column7: Understand the value of storytelling to build a strong school culture and engage external supporters in that effort.
column8: Know how to shape your story based on audience, goals, and medium.
column9: Learn practical tips you can apply to strategically build your storytelling audience from internal to external stakeholders using a variety of media.

column1: Addressing the Work-Based Learning Deficit
column5: Dr. Borgen Vargas (Rochester City School District), Sue Breckenridge (North Carolina Business Committee for Education)
column6: How well did the skills you gained through education align with your career pathway? Appropriate alignment of educational skills and career pathways is a critical challenge facing graduates and businesses alike. This session will feature Career and Technical Education leaders from North Carolina and New York as they share successful models aligning career pathways to graduates with appropriate skills. Representatives from both the state and school districts will lead participants in a conversation on how to successfully address the work-based learning deficit.
column7: Attendees will learn about successful ways align career pathways to graduates with appropriate skills.
column8: Attendees will better understand how to create meaningful pathways for career tracks within their education systems.
column9: Attendees will leave with a network to turn to as they consider rethinking the design of the current career pathways in their districts.

column1: Agents of Change: Educators Making Systemic Impact
column5: Christopher Todd (Connecticut Department of Education), Rebecca Kockler (Louisiana Department of Education), Paul Ferrari (CCSSO)
column6: Lessons from high-achieving and fast-improving school systems around the world all concur that educator engagement is a critical factor in successful implementation of reform. Today, as states around the country shift to more demanding college- and career-ready standards and higher expectations for educators, it is more important than ever to enable teachers to be involved in the development and refinement of policies that directly impact their daily work. This session will provide an overview of what state education agencies are doing to elevate and engage with educators, while also showcasing strategies and tactics educators can use to lead change at the state level.
column7: Participants will learn about the landscape of educator engagement happening at the state policy level.
column8: Participants will hear panelists tell real life stories about the rewards and challenges associated with supporting teacher leadership.
column9: Participants will receive strategies, tactics, and opportunities to either lead as educators, or to support educators to be agents of change.

column1: ALA's Superintendent Leadership Academy
column5: Maria Vasquez (ACT), Jose Lopez (Association of Latino Administrators and Superintendents), Veronica Rivera (Association of Latino Administrators and Superintendents), Michael  Hinojosa (Association of Latino Administrators and Superintendents)
column6: Creating an effective leadership academy involves more than access to successful leadership. Rather, it requires a systemic and will rounded approach.  The presentation describes an approach, led by The Association of Latino Administrators and Superintendents (ALAS) and ACT, in which selected administrators are provided assistance and expertise through the Superintendents Leadership Academy (SLA) by a consortium of Superintendents and partners. The SLA is the first of its kind in the U.S. to focus on preparing the next generation of Latino school system leaders with the skills necessary to address the needs of a diverse student population. In this interactive session, we'll explore how this
column7: Learn how SLA improves and expands opportunities for emerging school system leaders by providing coaching, mentoring, and support.
column8: Learn about the necessary skills to become a superintendent of high poverty and minority serving school systems.
column9: Learn ways in which strategic partnerships can provide equitable access to research, support, and other key resources to SLA.

column1: Begging for Disruption: EdTech Procurement
column5: Hal Friedlander (New York City Department of Education), Harold Levy (Jack Kent Cooke Foundation), Celina Morgan-Standard (The New York Academy of Sciences)
column6: EdTech Procurement is broken. American K-12 schools spend over $20 billion annually on instructional materials for students. This money is often spent without any measure of the impact on students.  As a result, schools unintentionally waste public funds, provide students inferior or inappropriate materials, and perpetuate a system that makes it difficult for new, more effective curricula and instructional materials to break into the market, chilling investor interest in building -solutions.Our panel will shed light on:-          Opportunities & new models to unlock K-12 edtech market-          Innovations that can make edtech procurement more transparent and      responsive
column7: Participants will learn about innovative approaches to procurement _ including new paradigms and cooperative purchasing models.
column8: Participants will understand how they can better introduce new products into the market stream of school procurement.
column9: Participants will be exposed to existing best practices _ which they can replicate or deploy in their work.

column1: Beyond Buzz: Credentialing & Competency Revolution
column5: Scott Kinney (Capella University), Jake Schwartz (General Assembly), Holly Zanville (Lumina Foundation), Goldie Blumenstyk (The Chronicle of Higher Education)
column6: Policymakers have longed called for a system of higher education that is better aligned to fit the goals of the student and meet employer_s workforce needs.   After years of talk, change is upon us. National efforts are underway to rethink credentials, while accelerated learning and competency-based education are beginning to achieve measurable and significant outcomes.  Several large questions remain. Is it truly scalable?  Will this be the _revolution_ where higher education is forced to meet the demands? Is this really what higher education and our society really need?
column7: Understand the current landscape and demand for alternative credentials and competency-based education
column8: Explore the challenge of scaling current models and the potential "tower of babel" problem
column9: Learn how credentials and competencies fit into the broader goals of higher education.

column1: Boot Camp for Building a Student Privacy Program
column5: Teddy Hartman (Howard County Public School System), Ira Gluck (PRIVO), Paige Kowalski (Data Quality Campaign), Kobie Pruitt (Future of Privacy Forum)
column6: "Enough debating privacy! Now let's act!" This panel will focus on the nuts and bolts of creating a comprehensive privacy program. For Schools and Districts looking to comply with Fair Information Practices, FERPA, COPPA, PPRA, and new state laws, while writing strong contracts and meeting parental expectations _ the challenge is one of focus and expertise. This panel will provide an intense information-packed _boot camp_ style experience to give participants practical tools, tips, tactics - and the basic knowledge base - to build, implement, and execute a student data privacy program.
column7: Walk away with tools, tips, and tactics for building a student privacy program!
column8: Gain a working knowledge of privacy principles, laws, and technological safeguards.
column9: Dive into the conflicting value trade-offs between data-driven leadership and privacy.

column1: Breaking the University From the Inside Out
column5: Paul Freedman (Entangled Ventures), Sean Hobson (Arizona State University), Josh Kim (Dartmouth College), Allison Dulin Salisbury (EdSurge)
column6: Higher education does plenty of R&D on everything from anthropology to zoology but it lacks frameworks for incubating, testing and implementing ideas about teaching and learning within universities. To foment _more than incremental_ change, some schools are creating safe-to-fail sandboxes where academics can run pilots with edtech entrepreneurs and measure the effects of those experiments. This session will highlight examples of these emerging R&D models and ask two questions: How can we intentionally design universities to change fast--even as fast as the needs of students themselves are changing? And what is the role of edtech organizations--either for-profit or not--in these sandboxes?
column7: Higher Education ADMINISTRATORS will explore frameworks for incubating, testing and implementing ideas about teaching and learning within universities
column8: ENTREPRENEURS will explore how to be effective partners for pilots and change efforts within the university
column9: All participants will explore the need for and value of "safe-to-fail" sandboxes within the university

column1: Can You Hear Me Now? The Power of Student Voice
column5: Kristen Swanson (Bright Bytes), kasey bell (Region 10 ESC/Shake Up Learning), Chris Aviles (Fair Haven Schools)
column6: In education, students are our greatest resource, and often offer the greatest insight into the classroom. Creating learning communities where our children serve as active participants is critical to future success. However, we often miss the mark. Have you ever asked a student about their learning experiences? The results can be eye-opening! Research shows that only 44 percent of students believe they have a voice in decision making, and this dips to as low as 34 percent in the 12th grade (www.stuvoice.org). Join a celebrated panel of students and educators as we discuss ways to incorporate student voice into the school culture, classroom, professional learning and beyond.
column7: Explore and discuss examples of ways that student voice has been used in instructional design, school culture, and professional learning.
column8: Design protocols, products, or systems for student empowerment at your school or district.
column9: Discuss opportunities for student panels and collaborations in your school or district.

column1: Collaborating and Learning Through Technology
column5: Robert Dillon (Affton School District), Andrew Marcinek (Grafton Public Schools), Kristina Doubet (Corwin Press), Eric Carbaugh (Corwin Press)
column6: Technology has never been more ubiquitous in schools. Spending for educational technology is at an all time high as more teachers and students have access to devices than ever before. With all of these available resources making their way into schools, the focus must now turn to how this technology is used, and what outcomes should be expected from an investment in these resources. This panel will explore this issue while focusing on the themes of innovation, collaboration, community, and learning. Participants will engage in an active discussion exploring the vast potential--and pitfalls--of the growth of educational technology.
column7: Participants will understand that educational technology offers great potential, but also great responsibility.
column8: Participants will evaluate various avenues for increasing innovation, collaboration, community, and learning.
column9: Participants will critically examine the role of technology in schools.

column1: Create Successful Partnerships for Student Success
column5: Jordan Meranus (Ellevation), Tyler Bosmeny (Clever), Renee Foster (Curriculum Associates)
column6: How can you _avoid the hype_ and work with an EdTech company to create a partnership that focuses on student growth and progress? What should you be looking for in a product or service to make sure you_re getting the results you_re paying for and not making the mistakes that other districts have made? This session will provide practical tips for evaluating EdTech companies and organizations by looking at things like company promise, level of service, product training, cost of acquisition, support, focus on results and more.
column7: Understand how to measure and hold a company accountable for student achievement and success
column8: Learn how cut through promotional tactics to distinguish the best and most cost effective tools and resources for your school.
column9: Learn how to work with companies to establish successful partnerships that impact teaching and learning.

column1: Cubed: Learning x Spaces x Staff = Greatest Impact
column5: Konrad Judd (Huckabee & Associates), David Truitt (West Independent School District), Shannon Buerk (Engage Learning, Inc.), Bruce Gearing (Dripping Springs Independent School District)
column6: There is clear benefit to students, teachers and campus culture when resources are invested to design a learning model, spaces that allow for interactive and collaborative learning as well as recruiting and retaining exceptional staff. Investments made independently and added together provide value but can create limitations. When the three are developed together, the impact to the students, teachers and campus culture are exponential.  Many ISDs, including Dripping Springs and West, have begun getting _cubed_ and are in different stages of development.  Learn about institutions across TX who have taken steps toward reaching their greatest impact and find out how you can take the first step.
column7: Understand the impact on people and campus culture through independent development of a learning model, learning spaces and campus staff
column8: Understand the exponential value in the simultaneous development of a learning model, learning spaces and campus staff
column9: Learn about pathways institutions have used to realize the exponential value and how their ideas could be used by other institutions

column1: Culture By Design
column5: Trey Boden (Mount Vernon Presbyterian School), Ashley Auspelmyer (Richland School District 2 Westwood High School), Eric Chagala (Vista Innovation & Design Academy (VIDA)), Margaret Powers (The Episcopal Academy)
column6: Design thinking has almost become a buzzword in progressive education, but what does _design_ as a manifesto actually benefit the culture and practice of educators? How does people-centered problem solving work out in the professional development of a staff? What role does design thinking play in brand strategy and strategic planning for schools? In this panel hear examples from the current context of four design-minded educators from across the country who believe that empathetic practices will cause schools to grow as teams and impact local communities in a big way. Q&A and tweetup to follow.
column7: Design thinking has almost become a buzzword in progressive education, but what does _design_ as a manifesto actually benefit the culture & practice?
column8: How might we utilize the tenets of Design Thinking to cultivate a culture of innovation within the school environment?
column9: How might we envision schools breaking down social barriers in communities using people-centered design?

column1: Democratizing the Use of Video in Education
column5: Adam Hagan (Purdue University), Perry Fetterman (Kaltura), Justin Beck (Kaltura)
column6: Video is everywhere - transforming the way we learn, work, shop, communicate, collaborate and entertain. In education, video can be found at the very center of all the latest trends: Online and Hybrid Learning, Distance Learning, BYOD, MOOCs and SPOCs, and Flipped Classroom experiences. Educational institutions have adopted video across the board: for teaching and learning, research, marketing, admissions, public affairs and workforce training. Adopting and deploying best practices for video holds the potential for both short and long-term benefits: streamlined admissions, increased retention, and improved learning outcomes.
column7: Panelists will discuss the key driving forces propelling the use of video and how video is being used to accelerate and enhance the learning process.
column8: Panelists will examine what value video creates and how it supports the latest trends in education.
column9: Lastly, panelists will discuss best practices that could improve outcomes with the use of video.

column1: Digital Equity Beyond the Classroom
column5: Michael Flood (Kajeet), Jaime Casap (Google), Keith Krueger (CoSN - Consortium for School Networking)
column6: Anytime, anywhere learning is a frequent vision for digital education.  Yet 5 million households with school-age children do not have high-speed internet service at home. Low-income households _ and especially black and Hispanic ones _ make up a disproportionate share of that 5 million.  Alarmingly, over 80% of school district technology leaders report that they have no strategies to address off-campus access.  Hear how some educational leaders, mayors, business and philanthropic leaders are coming together to address this critical challenge.  Join in a thought-provoking discussion of how to start a conversation in your community.
column7: Learn about the state of digital inequities driving the "homework gap".
column8: Hear about innovative new partnerships that are happening involving education leaders and their communities to address digital equity.
column9: Discuss successful strategies and tools for starting this conversation in your community.

column1: Driving Student Voice in Educational Design
column5: Ashley Simon (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Courtney Brousseau (University of California Berkeley), Maria  Cardenas (XQ: The Super School Project), Owen Brown (Jim Hill High School)
column6: The most common voice left out of education is that of students. Three XQ student ambassadors will participate in a student guided conversation about  today_s American High School, and how change must involve student perspectives. The first part of the panel will be a discussion of what is happening in high school today, and how and where we are failing to prepare students, in order to create a representative picture of what could change. The students will also offer their own ideas for what can be different. The second part of the panel will be opened to the audience who can query the students to test their ideas and thoughts by asking the opinion of the student _focus group._
column7: Discover what students think about their schools today.
column8: Discover ideas about how schools can change to better meet the needs of students.
column9: Explore ideas for innovation in schools using real students as a focus group.
column10: students, movement, design, design thinking, creativity, innovation, entrepreneurship

column1: Educator Voice Will Revolutionize Ed Purchasing
column5: Christina Quattrocchi (EdSurge), Nicole Neal (Noodle Markets), Rohit Agarwal (Amazon ), Patrick Larkin (Burlington Public Schools)
column6: The forces of social sharing have revolutionized many industries, and education is having its transformational moment! Known and new platforms allow educators to share product reviews and feedback with an increasingly broad audience. The educational materials industry _ in which purchasing has historically been driven by word of mouth _ is being altered by the national-scale amplification of those peer influences. Hear from leaders at the cutting edge of those changes _ from education leaders pioneering the educator voice movement as well as organizations whose platforms facilitate national-level sharing among educators.
column7: Understand the major platforms available to educators for sharing feedback on educational materials: companies, media, social media, and beyond
column8: Learn about the emerging platforms and national-scale sharing opportunities in the education space
column9: Understand how the educational materials market may be altered and shaped by these growing educator voice infuences

column1: Empowering healthy employees, students & community
column5: Dr. Charles Dupree (Fort Bend ISD), Steve Amos (Million Mile Month), Dr. Esteban Lopez (Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas), Deborah  Vollmer Dahlke (TX A&M University )
column6: Administrators juggle many responsibilities, from employee well-being to growing health care costs. Research shows increase in physical activity leads to a change in physical and cognitive health. The panel will discuss a free, easy to implement program available for any organization; addressing employee wellness and healthy lifestyles for students and their families. Participants adopt a common goal; community is fostered; cultural change is facilitated; with the potential to lower health care costs while improving teacher and student performance.Gaming techniques, group challenges, documentation and tracking, online materials to support and incent progress will be discussed.
column7: Communicate practical wellness program examples for administrators to easily implement, to engage employees and students in healthier actions.
column8: Understand how wellness programs can effectively reduce costs, improve performance, and promote community; highlighting various design points
column9: Share best practices:  how educators can implement a wellness program that provides results and promotes employee and student accountability.
column10: employees, health, wellness, fitness, leadership, community engagement

column1: Finding the Medium
column5: Jose Luis Vilson (New York Public Schools), Gabe Kleinman (Medium), Frederick Hess (American Enterprise Institute), Randi Weingarten (American Federation of Teachers)
column6: The education debate has become a political football. From Washington to Silicon Valley, policymakers, hedge-fund managers, tech millionaires and more set a debate about education policy that is grounded more in personal opinion than evidence or lived experience. And all too often, the voices of those on the front lines--educators and school staff--are drowned out.We're using innovative approaches with the Medium platform to elevate the voices of teachers, and engage them in meaningful dialogue with policymakers and other interested parties to help bridge the divide and ensure that educators and schools have a voice in finding solutions--not simply having "solutions" forced on them.
column7: Learn about the conversation features and engagement opportunities available to create substantive debate on the Medium platform
column8: Hear from leaders and rank-and-file teachers about the experience of engaging in a platform built to lift up substance and suppress trolling
column9: Show how a meaningful debate can take place both online and offline around a highly-contested subject.

column1: From the Classroom to Social Media to Congress
column5: Marla Kilfoyle (Badass Teachers Association), Randi Weingarten (American Federation of Teachers)
column6: How can an idea go from the water cooler conversation to federal legislation? As teachers took the conversation about frustration from on-the-job pressures to social media, activists and leaders took notice. The Badass Teachers Association and the American Federation of Teachers ran an online survey, collecting more than 30,000 responses from rank-and-file educators from across the country. The survey showed clearly that teachers love their work, but feel under-appreciated, unsupported and unfairly singled out for blame. And then, we worked with U.S. Senators to craft policy that would allow districts to use federal funds to study work stress and its impact on the classroom.
column7: Review the survey results and learn about the pressures rank-and-file educators feel on the job.
column8: Look at the history of the survey, and study what we can learn about how established organizations and online communities can collaborate.
column9: How did this make it into legislation? It was no sure thing to get this amendment authored, much less included in the Senate bill.

column1: Higher Ed Alliances: Nailing the Sweet Spot
column5: Kent Chabotar (Guilford College), Michael Thomas (New England Board of Higher Education), Stephanie Bell-Rose (TIAA-CREF Institute)
column6: The majority of CFOs surveyed by Inside Higher Ed in 2015 agree that media reports suggesting that higher ed is in the midst of a financial crisis are accurate. To thrive in this environment, colleges and universities need to adopt a strategic orientation to collaboration rather than going it alone. They can create a new breed of alliance that goes well beyond old-style consortia but steers clear of complicated full-on mergers. Higher ed leaders can apply lessons learned from the literature on strategic alliances in other industries to enhance their competitive positioning_and be more responsive to the public demand to educate more students at lower cost without sacrificing quality.
column7: Learn key design principles for positioning institutions in the sweet spot on the spectrum between old-style consortia and complicated mergers.
column8: Catalyze your institution_s ability to proactively and successfully pursue new forms of collaborations and alliances.
column9: Understand the barriers to change and innovation in higher education.

column1: How Iowa partners expand STEM opportunities to all
column5: Kim Reynolds (State of Iowa), Jeff  Weld (Iowa Governor's STEM Advisory Council), Linda Rosen (Change the Equation)
column6: A unique public/private partnership in Iowa is dramatically expanding young people_s access to opportunities in STEM (science, technology, engineering and math.)  A bipartisan, Governor-led STEM council made up of legislators, educators, business, nonprofits, students, and families is working to bring some of the nation_s most effective STEM education programs to a quarter of the state_s K-12 students. Learn how state leaders can join forces to supercharge their collective impact on young people.
column7: Understand how public/private partnerships can maximize impact of limited resources by promoting broad access to education programs with proven impact
column8: Understand how to make a strong public case for state-level collaboration among leading stakeholders from across the political spectrum.
column9: Learn specific strategies from Iowa that can be applied in other states.

column1: How to Better Navigate the Ed-Tech Market
column5: S. Dallas Dance (Baltimore County Public Schools), Phil Martin (Digital Promise), Ryan Imbriale (Baltimore County Public Schools), Molly Hensley-Clancy (Buzzfeed)
column6: Some of the highest-profile and most common mistakes in education technology adoption can be boiled down to a simple, but often overlooked, challenge: how schools and tech providers navigate the marketplace.School districts are struggling to put the right tools and resources in the hands of teachers and students. Product developers are frustrated by limited information and antiquated procurement processes.This panel will examine what causes these ed-tech purchasing pitfalls and how schools can avoid them, including perspectives from Baltimore County Public Schools, which is planning an ambitious digital transformation for more than 100,000 students.
column7: Recognize the realities, opportunities, and challenges for both schools and product developers navigating the ed-tech market
column8: Understand how schools are working with organizations to strategically implement products in the classroom
column9: Apply lessons learned to your own navigation of the ed-tech market

column1: How to Network the Learning Landscape in Your City
column5: Cathy Lewis Long (The Sprout Fund), Katrina Stevens (Office of Educational Technology), Peter Hirshberg (Re:imagine Group, City Innovate Foundation), Sara Schapiro (Digital Promise)
column6: Picture a classroom: Rows of desks and students, pencils moving dutifully on paper.Now imagine students moving seamlessly between shop class, art studio, and computer lab to produce their own entrepreneurial products. Imagine Kindergarteners hacking electronic toys using circuit kits. Imagine teens turning their local library into a laboratory for creative learning with digital technology.These innovative, cross-sector educational opportunities are made possible by network leaders who inspire novel collaboration among diverse education stakeholders.  Learn how communities across the country have sparked learning innovation and develop a plan to build a network in your community.
column7: Participants will identify the ingredients of a successful innovative education network and the preliminary steps necessary to initiate a network.
column8: Participants will brainstorm ideas of how to apply network best practices in their community, and workshop these ideas with other participants.
column9: Participants will develop a preliminary action plan enumerating first steps to bring networked innovation to their local context post-conference.

column1: Innovative School Partnerships
column5: Carmel Borders (Tapestry Foundation), Michelle Wallis (Austin Independent School District), Mary Riggs (Andy Roddick Foundation), Craig Shapiro (Crockett High School, Austin Independent School District)
column6: Successful partnerships require courageous leadership, strong relationships, excellent stewardship and a focus on results. Participants will hear lessons learned from partnerships in Austin ISD. A philanthropist will highlight the partnership behind Austin_s social and emotional learning initiative, which puts social and emotional skills on par with core academic subjects and reaches 85,000 students. A campus leader will share the work that launched a campus mental health clinic and Austin_s first K-12 entrepreneurship curriculum. An Austin-based foundation will share its approach to strategic and robust out-of-school time support focused on increasing attendance and family engagement.
column7: Learn about successful models of school and district partnerships.
column8: Explore methods principals use to build, maintain and support partnerships.
column9: Hear a funder perspective on elements of successful partnerships and leveraging investments in school programs.

column1: It_s Your School_s Story, So YOU Tell It!
column5: Jacob Hanson (PR with Panache!), Chris Piehler (THE Journal), Tom Murray (Alliance for Excellent Education), Darryl Adams (Coachella Valley Unified School District)
column6: As a school or district leader, have you felt that your story goes untold?  Or worse yet, that someone else is telling it for you and NOT telling it right?  Information is so readily available, literally all is in the palm of your students_, parents_ and community_s hands, so what_s stopping YOU from telling YOUR own your schools' story?  Educators need to SHOUT successes from the rooftops, but it isn't that easy.  At the end of the day, there_s much more good than bad in education, why so much negative in the media? Let_s start changing the conversation.  It_s up to us to ensure the good is heard above all else.
column7: To help educators & administrators communicate all the good that is happening in schools internally, with the community and beyond.
column8: To further understanding of the impact that telling student & staff success stories  can have on school/district culture
column9: To change the "education conversations" within the media, our education system is not broken, just walk in to a school and see for yourself!

column1: Keeping Student Data Safe: Who_s Responsible?
column5: Tom Ryan (eLearn Institute), Donna Williamson (Mountain Brook Schools), Aaron Hughes (Gaggle)
column6: The collection, maintenance and use of student personal information is a BIG deal. Should a school or vendor be responsible for keeping student data safe? How about both? Learn what school leaders and edtech companies can do to protect student data. The discussion will include what options currently exist and why initiatives have failed in the past._ Future of Privacy Forum & Software and Information Industry Association Student Privacy Pledge_ Safeguarding American Families from Exposure by Keeping Information and Data Secure (SAFE KIDS) Act_ Transparent & Open Student Data Policies_ Consortium for School Networking's Trusted Learning Environment_ Service Organization Controls
column7: What is student data?
column8: Is taking a Student Privacy Pledge and creating a Student Data Policy enough?
column9: What can the edtech community learn from other industries regarding data best practices?

column1: Kids Voices Count
column5: Student  One  (XQ: The Super School Project )
column6: The most common voice left out of education is that of the students themselves. XQ would bring 5-10 student ambassadors from our roadshow to SXSW edu and put them_and only them on a moderated panel. The panel would offer all SXSW edu attendees to hear from students themselves about their experiences with public education, their hopes for the future and their perspectives. Pale should include a question and answer session. Students will represent communities across the country.
column7: Understand student perspectives on public education, especially high school, and the way school decisions are made.
column8: Discover how to elevate student voice in school decision-making.
column9: Learn how students want to be engaged with education issues.

column1: Leading the Pack in Social and Educational Change
column5: Shekira  Dennis (Independent), Marvin  Pierre (Kipp Polaris College Preparatory Academy for Boys), Wykesha  Hayes (Keey Group), Chrystal Rivers (The Keey Group)
column6: Leading the Pack in Social and Educational Change is about providing tangible solutions to students, parents, non-profits, leaders and communities desiring to make sound current and future decisions, as well as impact.
column7: The value of social change across all functions of society
column8: Social principles significant to improving youth, families, schools, and communities
column9: Life long learning, innovation and collaboration for the greater good

column1: Leveraging Faculty Thought Leadership
column5: Dave Shaw (Arrow Media), Mischelle Diaz (St. Edward's University), Sara Villanueva (St. Edward's University), Ryann Collier (Arrow Media)
column6: Universities are the ultimate source for subject matter experts and relevant content on dozens of newsworthy and timely topics. By adapting earned media strategies and putting faculty experts on center stage, communication teams can curate and place content that supports brand awareness, lead generation, conversion and audience retention. We_ll explain how to work with faculty members, place their expert content as earned media, and then repurpose that content through social media and email marketing to target student prospects, and create thought leadership in a measurable way.
column7: How to shift media strategies to make better use of faculty and staff member experts, and why faculty members should consider this collaboration.
column8: How can media relations efforts that focus on faculty member experts can support content marketing at a university.
column9: How to identify the best experts within a university, position them as thought leaders and match them up with reporters who need them for stories.

column1: Librarians as Change Agents: Digital Leaders
column5: Joseph South (Department of Education), Jennifer Boudrye (District of Columbia Public Schools), Mark Ray (Vancouver Public Schools), Britten Follett (Follett School Solutions)
column6: Schools are in the midst of a digital transformation. Thanks to increased access to devices, new media and digital content, the classroom is disrupted. Future-ready kids need to be creators, curators, connectors, & communicators. Future ready teachers need to design, facilitate & enable new ways of learning. Enter future ready librarians_friendly guides to help students and teachers navigate the digital shift.While some districts are cutting librarians, others are empowering librarians and expanding their roles to provide strategic leadership. As change agents, librarians can lead, teach and support digital citizenship, information literacy, digital content creation and curation.
column7: How to learn from some districts, superintendents & educational leaders who support & promote the idea that great districts have great librarians
column8: The panel will explore critical challenges for schools like digital citizenship, information literacy, and student & teacher use of digital tools
column9: Attendees will hear examples of new roles that teacher librarians can play, and how librarians can better prepare for teaching 21st century skills

column1: Making Higher Ed Work for K-12
column5: Morgan Smith (The Texas Tribune), Wesley Brown (Marlin Elementary School), Anna Fox (Tarleton State University), Mary Gonzalez (Texas A&M University-Kingsville)
column6: Universities are increasingly being called upon to partner with school districts that are struggling or could use assistance. But with collaboration can come challenges. In 2013, for example, Texas A&M University-Kingsville partnered with the Premont Independent School District, which was nearly shutdown in 2011. More recently, Tarleton State University entered into a partnership with Marlin Independent School District  as part of the latter's effort to transform into a successful and sustainable learning environment for students. Participants in both of these efforts will discuss how school districts can get the most out of such arrangements and lessons they've learned along the way.
column7: Outline best practices for school districts and universities working together to improve K-12 education
column8: Detail potential challenges participants in such arrangements might face and how to avoid or overcome them
column9: Illustrate how higher education institutions can be a resource for school districts and how they can be utilized most effectively

column1: Making IT Matter in Education
column5: Mark Blair (http://www.dcsdk12.org), Chris Lawson (Douglas County School District), Linda Conway (http://www.dcsdk12.org), Gautam Sethi (Douglas County School District)
column6: Douglas County (Colo.) School District_s IT Division created a specialized learning support team to actively empower and support teachers in leveraging technology to meet the personalized learning needs of more than 67,000 21st century learners. We are the design thinkers, school technology partners, learning environment designers, and learning architects that form the nexus of innovative thinking with the goal of transforming learning, spaces, and people.
column7: Deconstruct the challenges you may encounter with transforming learning, spaces, and people.
column8: Discover strategies to better partner with your schools to understand their unique technology needs.
column9: Explore the power of developing scalable blueprints that showcase your impact on learning.

column1: Meet Chicago_s Education Innovation Power Players
column5: Melissa Zaikos (Intrinsic Schools), Jennifer Droste Yagan (Impact Engine), Amy Huang (LEAP Innovations), Heather Anichini (The Chicago Public Education Fund)
column6: Chicago is a large urban district that_s beating the odds when it comes to innovation in education. Despite the district_s massive size and many contextual challenges, players_both public and private_are working together in Chicago to create an ecosystem to support educator-led innovation across the city. Three of the city_s most dynamic leaders are women with diverse backgrounds and experiences that are dedicated to improving the lives of the nearly 400,000 students in Chicago through innovations in teaching and learning.This session will allow participants to hear from female leaders in education paving the way for educator-led innovation to accelerate students_ achievement.
column7: Understand how Chicago stakeholders have created a large-scale movement to provide innovation in Chicago public schools_both neighborhood and charter
column8: Convey the necessity of a shared vision among all key stakeholders to sustain and scale meaningful change in education
column9: Appreciation for the power of female leadership in education both within and outside of the school building

column1: Miami-Dade is a Leader in Food/Nutrition Literacy
column5: Penny Parham (Miami-Dade County Public Schools), Deborah Karcher (Miami-Dade County Public Schools), Alberto Carvalho (Miami-Dade County Public Schools), Addie Broyles (Austin American Statesman)
column6: Currently, 1 in 3 kids are obese/overweight; which has serious implications.CDC reports that healthy students learn better. If schools have a culture of wellness & teachers are modeling healthy habits, students can take control of their health & future. Miami-Dade County Public Schools (M-DCPS) are educating the whole student population through partnership programs, gaming and technology. In addition to the various wellness programs (nutrition, cooking and mindfulness) M-DCPS is piloting a nutritional gaming application on devices in fall 2015 semester. By working systemically, individuals can inspire healthy behavioral changes, increase confidence & make educational gains.
column7: Superintendent_s role has evolved beyond teaching academic proficiency to include teaching responsibility, respect & life skills.
column8: Schools are responsible for keeping students healthy in order to support learning. To gain school support for programs, easy integration is key.
column9: Technology can provide an engaging, effective online platform for nutrition/cooking education that offers a standalone or supportive experience.

column1: MInority Operated Companies -- How to Make it Work
column5: Frank  Donner (BLKBX Creative Group)
column6: Running a business isn't easy.  Finding the perfect staff isn't either.  Doing them both at the same time and creating an atmosphere that is both inclusive and creative is a key to success.  Breaking down color barriers, glass ceilings or any other minority roadblocks offers a company the opportunity to expand their reach and exceed their goals.
column7: How diversity in the workplace translates to success
column8: Forming the perfect team
column9: Finding the right candidate

column1: Moving the Needle: Innovation and Change in EdTech
column5: Kecia  Ray (Center for Digital Education), Sheryl Nussbaum-Beach (Powerful Learning Practice, LLC), Kari Stubbs PhD (BrainPOP), S. Dallas Dance, PhD (Baltimore County Public Schools)
column6: Join representatives from the ISTE board of directors (International Society for Technology in Education) for a spirited discussion related to the future of learning. Leveraging the Horizon K12 report_s 2015 edition for key trends accelerating the adoption of technology to guide the discussion, these ed tech industry leaders will debate and discuss systemic solutions from diverse vantage points. Plus, the audience will be invited to ask tough questions and join this engaging conversation.
column7: What can we (as ISTE board members & audience participants) do to fuel innovation and transformation in the education technology landscape?
column8: Debate and discuss key trends accelerating adoption of technology in our schools as identified by the Horizon Report 2015 edition.
column9: Explore anticipated shifts to deeper learning approaches, students as creators, collaborative learning approaches, and rethinking how schools work.

column1: Next-Gen Learning in Next-Gen Environments
column5: Margaret Roth (Yet Analytics), Craig Wiggins (Advanced Distributed Learning), Beth Rabbit (The Learning Accelerator), Shawn Rubin (Highlander Institute)
column6: We all live in a connected world - to varying degrees, and in ever changing ways. This connectedness has yet to truly permeate the learning environment. New tools and approaches are needed to support the kinds of learning environments that we will all use in the future - collaborative, blended, dynamic, connected learning environments that extend beyond the classroom to the community and world around us.This panel represents leaders in the connected learning and learning infrastructure space, and will share with the audience some of the findings that have come out of early implementations and pilots of blended learning and other connected learning environments and technologies.
column7: What kinds of blended learning environments are currently possible?What kinds of connected learning environments are currently possible?
column8: How can you get started implementing a blended learning environment? How can you get started implementing a connected learning environment?
column9: How does data interoperability shape the future of blended and connected learning environments?

column1: Preventing School Shootings
