column5: Dennis Van Roekel  (National Education Association ), Amy Bruns (The VIVA Project, Excent), Katherine "Katie" Doerr-Morosky (The VIVA Project, University of Texas Austin), Paul Toner (The VIVA Project)
column6: Ever since Columbine, preventing school shootings has been a part of the national conversation. After another tragic school shooting at Sandy Hook in 2012, teachers from nine states came together to tackle the issue of school violence, proving that even the toughest problems can be approached collaboratively. This panel will discuss their recommendations to the White House, US Secretary of Education and the NEA on providing education leaders with practical solutions for creating safer schools.
column7: Share the collective wisdom of classroom educators with divergent opinions on the topic of school violence, including guns in schools.
column8: Model how real teachers are using their firsthand expertise to inform education leaders and policymakers on the issues educators face in their schools
column9: Discuss the recommendations to help prevent future school shootings.
column10: school shootings, guns in school, school safety, teacher leadership, school culture, schools in communities, student mental health

column1: Real Examples: Teacher-Entrepreneur Collaboration
column5: Steve Isaacs (William Annin Middle School ), Talia Arbit (Edcite ), Michelle  Grezner (Ocean Avenue Elementary School), Emily Gover (Imagine Easy Solutions)
column6: Creating better EdTech means fostering collaboration between teachers and EdTech entrepreneurs. At SXSW 2015, the team behind the Twitter community #edtechbridge asked educators and EdTech creators how to extend collaboration beyond 140 characters. This year, a panel of #edtechbridge community members will share their experiences working together outside of Twitter. The panel comprises two teachers and two EdTech developers who have forged mutually beneficial relationships that influenced the development and successful classroom integration of products. Panelists will give advice on navigating, understanding, and respecting teacher and EdTech cultures in order to make great EdTech together.
column7: What does an authentic collaboration between an educator and an EdTech company look like? We will examine case studies.
column8: What are the pitfalls of collaborating on EdTech and how can we avoid them? Panelist will share personal experiences and advice.
column9: How can we encourage more teacher-EdTech creator collaboration? We will host a discussion how to foster a community of collaboration going forward.

column1: Reinventing the Stale, Boring Thing We Call School
column5: Kristina Peters (State of Nebraska), Tanya Avrith (Amplified IT), Kristen  Ziemke (The Educator Collaborative, LLC), Robert  Dillon (Affton School District)
column6: As educators and innovators talk about 20% time as a way to build passion in schools, a question emerges. Why don't we fix the 80% time that is stale, awful, rotten, and boring for kids? The voices of SXSW need to be passionate, incredible educators that can speak about the current student experience. This panel is filled with incredible female voices that know excellence in learning. They will provide a candid, quirky, and powerful ideas about how we can dump legacy school and empower kids with the learning that they need to fill their souls with the solutions that we need to solve the big, hairy, scary problems of our planet. Come listen to these women opine about the right way for kids
column7: Expose the pain of learning for so many students throughout the country through the stories of powerful female educator voices.
column8: Splash the audience with hope, joy, and ideas surrounding the power of classrooms that place students in the center and empower youth & adult learners
column9: Support the diverse audience with potential solutions that can scale across a system through the unique lens of this female leaders in education.

column1: Retrofitting Colleges for Lifelong Learning
column5: Allan Ludgate (Deloitte Consulting LLP), Tiffany Fishman (Deloitte Services LLP), Jennifer Murphy (Ohio University), Linsey Sledge (Ohio University)
column6: Fracture lines can be seen everywhere in America_s higher education system, from changing reasons for attending college to a significant mismatch between the skills employers seek and those students possess upon graduation. These pressures are fueling innovation across the higher education ecosystem. The question facing colleges and universities is how to marry the best of a liberal arts education while focusing on student outcomes to effectively adapt higher education for lifelong learning. Join  Ohio University and Deloitte Consulting to explore the emerging higher education landscape and one university_s response.
column7: Explore the emerging higher education landscape befitting of the digital age and of today_s tech-savvy students.
column8: Learn how Ohio University is responding to pressures and changes in the higher education landscape while focusing on student outcomes.
column9: Discuss how higher education institutions and businesses can collaborate to close the skills gap and promote student success.

column1: Rock Enrollment Marketing with Emerging Tech
column5: Jeff  Johnson (Primacy), Melissa Tait (Primacy), Kim Frisch (Regis University)
column6: Colleges, take note: cool new tech is _in_ and to be an enrollment marketing superstar requires working it into your strategy. While the education sector is typically hesitant to embrace _what_s next,_ forward-thinking institutions are already taking bold steps toward digital natives to enhance enrollment marketing via compelling, interactive prospect experiences. Panelists will offer an inside glimpse at Regis University_s digital marketing strategy, explaining how to revolutionize enrollment processes w/ next-gen technologies (think: drones, Oculus Rift & RFID). The results will have attendees rushing to take the stage and rock enrollment marketing.
column7: Unearth today_s coolest marketing technologies
column8: Discover how these new technologies can be used to better connect with prospective students via personalized engagement
column9: Walk away with best practices for implementing these tools into your enrollment marketing strategy

column1: Scaling Innovation Through Four Lenses
column5: James Rickabaugh (The Institute for Personalized Learning), Jeffrey Taege (School District of Waukesha), Jennifer Poon (Council of Chief State School Officers), Matt Williams (KnowledgeWorks Foundation)
column6: When does an innovation stop being new and become the _new normal_? How do projects and pilots grow into scale and stability? This session will explore these questions from a national, regional, state, and local level, from policy development to instructional strategies. Managing change at each of these levels is important -- and every stakeholder believes their level is the most important. Yet, all are interdependent. We_ll explore together the right balance to impact educational outcomes.
column7: Understand the range of outcomes generated at a policy level through instructional innovation.
column8: Share best practices for bringing innovation to scale.
column9: Managing change in a school environment.

column1: Show Me the Money: Driving Fiscal Sustainability
column5: Sara Goldrick-Rab (University of Wisconsin - Madison), Patrick Rossol-Allison (Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation), Scott Carlson (The Chronicle of Higher Education), Maria Anguiano (University of California at Riverside)
column6: Nearly one in five business officers said their institutions are likely to shut down in the coming decades._ Despite awarding doctorates in finance and economics, our industry doesn_t have a sustainable funding model. Is Sweet Briar the canary in the coal mine, or an anomaly? We will discuss the real economic challenges facing universities, the kinds of leadership it will require to pivot to a sustainable future, and what institutions can do to address the challenges ahead
column7: Evaluate activity-based costing as a framework for financial analysis and decision-making.
column8: Understand the complexity of making broad finance decisions to increase student outcomes.
column9: Share stories and insights from advancing new models of higher ed finance thinking.

column1: Sunshine, Sand & Education
column5: Eveline  Pierre (Miami Caribbean Code )
column6: From the US Census in 2004,  50 percent of  Florida residence are from the Caribbean. The session will engage the participants on discussing the innovation that is happening in the Caribbean region and how South Florida is an intrinsic thread who can be the leader in the connectivity of this region via education.
column7: How can Miami and the Caribbean be cross regional leaders in provide new ways of education.
column8: How can Miami help with innovation in the Caribbean regions
column9: Setting up platforms to help spawn innovation in education

column1: Taking Action on Student Privacy
column5: Paulina Haduong (Berkman Institute for Internet and Society at Harvard Law), David Katz (Nelson Mullins), Steve Smith (Cambridge Public Schools), Robert Curtin (Pip Learning Technologies)
column6: This will be a panel discussion on the current progress schools and industry experts are making to shift the topic of student privacy from simply a "hot conversation", to specific and actionable steps that schools can take to protect students online.  Representatives from school districts, law firms, and industry organizations will share their progress and key lessons learned, and will provide insights into how schools can protect student privacy while still embracing innovation.
column7: Current state of Student Privacy legislation
column8: Specific actions Schools are taking to protect student privacy
column9: Industry initiatives regarding privacy

column1: Tearing Down Barriers to Customized Learning
column5: Donald Clayton (Mountain Brook Junior High), Missy Brooks (Mountain Brook Schools), Donna  Williamson (Mountain Brook Schools), Adam Johnson (Mountain Brook Schools)
column6: Hear one district's story of how they are tearing down the barriers of  time, fear of student voice and ownership, traditional classroom and teaching models, and a bureaucratic system. Mountain Brook Schools began the Metamorphosis project several years ago to discover the pathway to customized learning for every one of its students and to become a true learning organization. In this session attendees will explore customized learning, the difference between bureaucratic and learning organizations, flexible learning spaces (digital and physical), interdisciplinary learning models, and a new take on professional development.
column7: Identify the barriers to customized learning.
column8: Share ideas for empowering all learners (teachers and students) to take risks and have a growth mindset.
column9: Understand the difference between bureaucratic and  learning organizations in order to create a pull culture rather than a top-down push.

column1: The $@#! No One Tells You About Procurement
column5: Dilara Sayeed (Golden Apple Foundation), Ellen Dorr (Highline Public Schools), Pablo Mejia (www.edsurge.com), Steven  Ross (Johns Hopkins University Center for Research and Reform in Education)
column6: We_ve all heard the same old story about procurement. It usually goes something like this: teachers don_t have enough voice in decision making; procurement is stymied by complicated rules; it_s hard to find out which tools fit specific needs. But there's a lot more at play: reputations, competing and conflicting stakeholders, and the struggle for company survival. In this panel, EdSurge will give you a peak behind the procurement curtain and uncover what gets in the way of getting great tools to teachers. Our panel will share the secrets to making procurement work, their struggles and the reality of what procurement looks like on the ground.
column7: Learn about the tension that companies and schools face when trying to get the best tools in the hands of teachers.
column8: Identify progressive procurement practices that are good for both schools and companies, and why they aren't happening everywhere.
column9: Discuss innovative ideas to make sure teachers get the tools they need, administrators do due diligence and companies have a fair shot.

column1: The Dog Ate My Charger: Overcoming EdTech Barriers
column5: Sherry Hage (Charter Schools USA), Ted Brodheim (Samsung), Maia Sharpley (Kaplan, Inc.), Karl Rectanus (Lea(R)n)
column6: From real-time cloud-based assessments to augmented reality, we are surrounded by new educational technologies that are drastically changing teaching and learning. But how ready are we to use these technologies to our advantage in order to improve student outcomes? Join this conversation to understand which barriers we need to overcome to successfully implement edtech in K-12 and higher education. Through real-world examples and case studies, this session will transform how you approach edtech in your classroom or workplace.
column7: Attendees will gain an understanding of the role and importance of ensuring that education technology tools support student outcomes
column8: Attendees will hear about how education professionals are successfully adapting to innovative technologies
column9: Attendees will participate in a discussion on how the barriers to edtech are different in higher education and K-12

column1: The Next Generation of Science Teachers
column5: Carolyn Hayes (NSTA), Natacia Campbell (Victor J. Andrew High School), David L. Evans (NSTA)
column6: 1957_s Sputnik launch created concern for the nation_s security. That concern sparked a revolution in education, giving teachers the autonomy, respect and resources to teach science to future leaders and workers. Now the landscape is starkly different requiring them to defend science as well as teach. They now need to navigate high stakes testing, address skepticism on topics like climate change, fight for classroom instruction time, and keep up with students who live and breathe in a tech- and social media-savvy world, all while inspiring students. It_s not the 50_s anymore, but the challenges to U.S. leadership are just as dire. Teachers must be leaders and advocates for science education.
column7: Empower science educators to become leaders and advocates for the profession and for science education
column8: Build awareness among education stakeholders about the importance of science education in our world and the important role of science teachers
column9: Highlight the important role of scientists and scientific research in establishing the content that is taught in the science classroom

column1: The Rise of Research-Based Decisions in Education
column5: Laura Wentworth  (Stanford-SFUSD Partnership; California Education Partners), Vivian  Tseng (William T. Grant Foundation ), Sean Reardon (Stanford University Graduate School of Education), Guadalupe  Guerrero (San Francisco Unified School District )
column6: More educators are turning to research as a source of evidence to consider in decision-making. Yet, many research institutions are not designed to produce useful research for educators. What could school districts, universities, and funders do about this dilemma? A panel of four experts will discuss the value of research practice partnerships as a means to produce research that helps scale improvements in education.
column7: Understand the value of university-district partnerships.
column8: Understand policies and practices that support a university-school collaboration.
column9: Identify influential stakeholders and roles they fill when engaging in research-practice partnerships.

column1: The Science of Teacher Hiring
column5: Shelley Redinger (Spokane Public Schools), Tennille Jeffries-Simmons (Spokane Public Schools), Dan  Goldhaber (The Center for Education Data & Research), Wayne D'Orio (Scholastic)
column6: Roughly 600,000 teachers are hired each year in the United States. So if there's one task you would imagine principals and superintendents are good at, it's hiring the right candidate. That's not even close to true. In fact, the vast majority of teachers hired are chosen by factors that are proven not to have any influence in how well they teach children, such as grade-point average and where they went to school. Learn how Spokane Public Schools in Washington, with the help of researcher Dan Goldhaber, has changed its hiring practices to snare the best candidates and subsequently improve student achievement.
column7: Learn how to intelligently investigate your hiring practices, from how every candidate is routed to what questions to ask during interviews.
column8: One small change that Spokane made that paid big dividends was speeding up its hiring process. This allowed them to grab better candidates faster.
column9: Discover what today's research says about job candidates, using metrics from Google, to other school districts.

column1: Think Rethink! CrowdSourcing Innovation
column5: Mike  Marriner  (Road Trip Nation ), Michelle  Kydd Lee  (Think It Up Advisory Board / Creative Artists Agency ), Elena  Hale  (MAL For Good / XQ Super School Project ), Keith  Yamashita  (XQ Institute / SY Partners )
column6: As cultural attention increases for interest-driven learning experiences, new movements invite fresh thinking and support from the crowd - and ask: what happens when great ideas are not just heard, but valued, supported, and even funded.  When we encourage, respect and validate student voice, grow collaborations between students, teachers, within and across communities _ how will crowdsourced support help shape the future of how we learn? Architects of XQ: The Super School Project, Think It Up, and Road Trip Nation share how each group draws on the power of the crowd in their missions to help students uncover their passions, and in the call for American ingenuity to move education forward.
column7: Empowering collaborations - between students and teachers, everyday people and popular culture to help drive excellence in American education.
column8: How can "the crowd" leverage immediate and practical help with better learning experiences now - and shape the vision for new American high schools?
column9: How whole communities get involved to help students uncover passions, pathways to future studies and careers; and share talents to rethink high school

column1: Three Colleges Across the Country Driving Access &
column5: Charles Cook (Austin Community College), Bea Awaoniyi (Sante Fe College), Marilynn Spaventa (Santa Barbara City College)
column6: This panel discussion will highlight innovative and promising practices that are leading access and change in three award-winning community colleges from California, Florida, and Texas.  Leadership from Santa Fe College (2015 Aspen Prize Winner), Santa Barbara City College (2013 Aspen Prize Winner), and Austin Community College (Achieving the Dream Leader College) will highlight successful programs and brainstorm ideas to continue the momentum for student success in community colleges.
column7: Identify the leading opportunities that can drive student access and success in community colleges
column8: Understand the biggest threats to change in community colleges
column9: Recognize ways successful programs be scaled and adapted throughout different states and systems
column10: community college; student success; higher education leadership

column1: Time to Stop, Collaborate, and listen.
column5: Bridget Burns (University Innovation Alliance), Barb Allen (Committee for Institutional Cooperation), Candace  Thille  (Open Learning Initiative and Stanford)
column6: Going it alone has gotten higher education as far as it will. We need to join forces to accelerate ideas across sectors, platforms, universities, and schools. This session will detail the hard challenges any new collaboration faces, how to form effective national and regional collaboratives, and how edtech and higher ed can collaborate to magnify our impact.This panel features a range of collaborative perspectives including one of higher ed's oldest (CIC), newest (UIA), and most unique (OLI).
column7: Understand the core challenges and unique characteristics of successful collaboratives.
column8: Gain insight from experienced collaborative leaders advancing broad national objectives.
column9: Share stories, wins, and failures experienced along the way to uniting behind a broad challenge

column1: Transforming EDU with iPads and mobile solutions
column5: Gregg  Cox (Lynn University), Kevin Ross (Lynn University), Christian Boniforti (Lynn University)
column6: In 2013 Lynn University embarked in a transformational change across the university by adopting iPads, mobile technologies and digital solutions in its teaching and learning environment.  Every Lynn student receives an iPad mini and utilizes iTunesU and multi-touch ebooks as the main teaching and learning digital environment.  Lynn is now developing over 30 faculty curated and authored iBooks and replaced more than 70% of its textbooks.  This commitment and adoption of mobile technologies has allowed Lynn to reimagine the college experience.
column7: Faculty development strategies and incentives incorporated
column8: Mobile deployment strategies and lessons learned
column9: Defining a new commitment and culture change across the university

column1: What Higher Ed_s Top 10 IT Issues Mean for You
column5: Susan  Grajek (EDUCAUSE), Brad Wheeler (Indiana University), Keith McIntosh (Ithaca College), Stephen diFilipo (Milwaukee School of Engineering)
column6: Higher education IT and institutional leaders use EDUCAUSE_s annual Top 10 IT Issues to inform their IT strategic and set priorities. With so much change facing higher education and affecting IT, this north star has never been more important. Technology's transformative impact on teaching and learning as well as on administration and the IT profession itself are all top of mind. Analytics, privacy, and big data are also having a major impact.  Join EDUCAUSE and leading CIOs in higher education debate 2016's trends and their implications.
column7: Learn how IT goes hand in hand with institutional strategy, and how the top 10 IT issues are affecting institutions differently.
column8: Form an opinion: Are institutions, governments, and vendors really addressing the biggest challenges and opportunities?
column9: Influence your institution: Leave the session with a better understanding of the big issues and suggestions for how to address them.

column1: Where Are All the Women in Educational Leadership?
column5: Jenni Donohoo (Literacy Gains), Sonja Alexander (Insight Education Group), Peter DeWitt (Corwin), Jennifer Abrams (Corwin)
column6: Over seventy percent of the education workforce consists of women, yet the number of women in leadership positions falls far short of that statistic. Despite a preponderance of inspiring women in education, we do not hear about them nearly as often as we should because the pulpit seems to be dominated by men. Women in education influence everyone in the field through their research, opinions and experiences, and have helped fight bad reform, create more innovative practices in the classroom, and unify voices around the country if not the world. This panel will explore the explore the gender imbalance in educational leadership and what we can all to do address it.
column7: Explore the dynamics around the lack of women in education leadership positions
column8: Hear from several women in education leadership as they share their journeys, barriers to success, and recommendations for the future
column9: Understand how to improve the practices or your school, district, or organization to support the presence of more women in leadership

column1: Who Gets the Money: Why Invest in EdTech Startups
column5: Michael Freedman (Vocabulary.com), Eileen Murphy Buckley (ThinkCERCA), Nader Qaimari (Follett Learning), Britten Follett (Follett School Solutions)
column6: How does a worldwide company with money to invest decide what ed tech start ups or entrepreneurs are a right fit? Furthermore, how do start ups choose the right investors to help them maximize their efforts? A number of strategic funding sources are increasingly available. Knowing if a start up becomes an extension of the investor's existing business or if it takes on a different operating role can be a deal maker or breaker.This informative panel includes representatives from two ed tech start ups, (both received large investments) and a corporate executive who helps make investment decisions for its $50 million fund. The panelists will discuss how & why they made their partnerships.
column7: Attendees will hear how one corporation determines when to invest in startups and entrepreneurs, and the criteria it uses in making those decisions
column8: Learn what qualities make a startup or entrepreneur attractive to an investing company; how the startup operates in order to become a business partner
column9: Attendees will learn how a startup changes and grows after investment, and the path both investor and investee take after infusion of operating income

column1: Will Privacy Fears Derail EdTech Innovation?
column5: Dana Greenspan (Ventura County Office of Education), Paulina Haduong (Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University), Paulina Haduong (Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University), Alan Simpson (iKeepSafe.org)
column6: Calls for new student data privacy laws are growing in Congress and state legislatures. Policymakers are hearing from parents _ some with reasonable concerns, and others who may be driven by advocates stoking privacy fears.Educators and edtech innovators need to address parent concerns, because a rush to enact new privacy regulations may make hinder access to personalized learning and other edtech innovations, especially in underserved communities where students and schools can benefit most from technology. We_ll help you explain how smart data use helps students and schools, and how student data is used and protected, so you can strengthen parent trust and confidence in edtech.
column7: Understand FERPA, COPPA and the push for new state and federal student privacy laws.
column8: Learn how K12 educators can find edtech tools and products that support privacy.
column9: Discuss ways to communicate effectively about privacy and the value of edtech innovation with parents, students and other stakeholders.

column1: Wired and Weird: Skills for Ed Tech Leaders
column5: Mike Jamerson (Bartholomew Consolidated School Corporation), Larry Johnson, Ph.D. (New Media Consortium), Victor Valdez (Pflugerville Independent School District ), Sheryl Romero Abshire, Ph.D. (Calcasieu Parish Public Schools)
column6: What are the wired and weird skills ed tech leaders really need today? What are the key emerging technology trends for learning?  Join an engaging conversation with innovative technology leaders about the CoSN Framework of Essential Skills for Chief Technology Officers, the first-ever aspirational leadership certification (CETLtm). Learn about the latest and greatest emerging technology trends for K12 as showcased in the  NMC/CoSN K12 Horizon Report and their relevance for technology leaders.
column7: Technology leaders will learn about the essential skills needed to lead and implement successful technology initiatives.
column8: Participants will gain insight into the key emerging technology trends and challenges in education.
column9: Technology leaders will network with their peers in engaged conversations about using technology to transform learning.

column1: Accelerating Personalized Learning
column5: Donald  Buckley (Aruliden and Tools-at-Schools), Aaron  Kaswell (Middle School 88), Ailene Altman Mitchell (Middle School 88)
column6: We know students must be immersed in environments that will enable them to develop critical, creative problem solving skills: skills to imagine the possibilities; find success in failure; and ultimately come up with solutions that will orchestrate change in the future they will live.Our presentation outlines customized and personalized instructional practices, how to build and strengthen teacher teams and implement digital content through all subject areas to increase applied critical thinking skills.  Our solution is The Accelerator, a design thinking course that offers advanced STEAM learning opportunities and the practical application of skills to real world problems.
column7: Customized curricula to meet the needs of each school
column8: Interactive, integrated and personalized, blended learning content in science, math, social studies, literacy and technology
column9: Integrated interdisciplinary applied learning projects embedded in the common core standards

column1: Achieving Clarity through Double Vision
column5: Clarissa Layland (Granbury ISD), Jimmy Layland (PJ's Lawn Care & Landscaping), Judy Gentry (Granbury), Tim McClure (Huckabee)
column6: Double Vision is the simultaneous perception of two images, usually overlapping, of a single scene or object. When Granbury ISD set out to change their secondary education, those involved provided strategic and visionary overlays to the design, culture and curriculum. These meaningful overlays provided a layered perspective, ultimately influencing transformation. We will explore various strands of double vision from four very different perspectives_ student, educator, architect & business owner.
column7: Partnerships _ Understand how developing partnerships throughout the community plays a significant role in transformation.
column8: Strategic Planning _ Learn the layers of developing a strategic plan that will ultimately provide for an engaging and powerful result.
column9: Power of Inclusion _ Not just collaboration, but knowing and understanding all the stakeholders and their perspectives.

column1: Announcing the Knight News Challenge on Libraries
column5: Alexis Rossi (Internet Archive), Jill Bourne (City of San Jose), Philipp  Schmidt (Peer 2 Peer University), Shana Kimball (The New York Public Library )
column6: From February 20 - March 24, Knight Foundation's News Challenge on Libraries will be open for applications offering innovative projects a share of $3 million. Join Knight Foundation_s Media Innovation team and a selection of past library challenge winners to learn about trends they_re seeing and for tips on applying for a grant.
column7: Better understand Knight Foundation_s objectives for the next News Challenge on Libraries and how to apply for a grant.
column8: Highlight past winners and learn about the innovative ways they are transforming libraries.
column9: Discuss trends and themes happening within the space.

column1: Beyond Walls: Art Museums and Online Learning
column5: Bruce Friend (International Association for K-12 Online Learning), Emily Kotecki (North Carolina Museum of Art), Claire Moore (The Metropolitan Museum of Art), Anne Kraybill (Crystal Bridges Museum of Art)
column6: Museums are using technology to dramatically expand their reach and impact audiences in new ways. Whereas historically, art museums have played a supplementary role in education, both onsite through field trips and off site through reproductions, innovations in technology have enabled museums to explore new program formats that provide choice and personalized experiences for learners. This moderated discussion with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Crystal Bridges Museum of Art and the North Carolina Museum of Art will explore ways online, flipped and blended learning models are used to enhance and enrich student and teacher learning.
column7: Describe the strengths and limitations of various learning environments (art museums, classrooms, and online).
column8: Identify several possibilities for blending two or more learning environments to maximize impact.
column9: Generate one concrete idea they plan to try out.

column1: Building Trust Through Peer Collaboration
column5: John  Farrelly (Edgecombe County Schools), Julie Keane (VIF International Education), Lauren Hanford (VIF International Education), Lucas Blair (Little Bird Games)
column6: This panel will present VIF_s Process Lab, one of thirteen 2015 Digital Media and Learning Competition Trust Challenge winning projects focused on creating innovative tools and systems to foster trust in online learning environments. VIF_s Process Lab marries peer/expert feedback to support robust teacher collaborations and digital badging to acknowledge learning achievements within a trusted professional learning community. Teachers create personalized professional learning pathways identifying content areas in which they wish to excel and incrementally engaging with formal training and peer-to-peer collaborations and reviews.
column7: Participants will learn the primary components of the VIF Process Lab and how others might appropriate the lab design for other learning environments.
column8: Participants will have the opportunity to review a digital badging system that both satisfies and disrupts traditional school district PD requirements
column9: Participants will learn how effective, online peer feedback and review contributes to vibrant and creative maker spaces for teachers.

column1: Collaborate Innovate Adapt for Magic in Higher Ed
column5: Franny Lee (ProQuest SIPX), Scott Lubeck (Bert Davis Executive Search), Dale Johnson (Arizona State University), Amin Qazi (Unizen)
column6: Higher ed today is characterized by rising expectations, new tools, and innovative formats_all to improve the lives of students_to put a little magic in their lives. Three experts seek quality education that_s efficient, effective, and affordable. A unique consortia uses collaboration to explore new methodologies, platforms, and services. A new technology integrates diverse systems to lower course materials costs and give instructors new student engagement tools. A new model offers students a faster, more flexible degree with online courses for credit. Join our interactive session and sprinkle in your experience and insights to help us create some powerful magic in higher education.
column7: learn about actual new approaches that universities are using to explore ways to create high quality, affordable educational experiences for students
column8: learn how these different approaches can be used together to give instructors, librarians, and administrators new insights into student engagement
column9: learn how to get involved in "the quest for education magic" at your institution and beyond

column1: Collaboration Culture by Design
column5: Amy Edmondson (Harvard Business School), Eric Hirst (The University of Texas at Austin), Alex O'Briant (Ennead Architects)
column6: Collaboration is a fundamental human endeavor: people work together to achieve things they cannot achieve alone. Increasingly, new learning spaces and school curricula are shaped by a team-based model of collaborative engagement, and collaboration as a concept is all the rage. But how do we move beyond the _collaboration_ buzzword? What are the components of a well-designed collaboration culture that fosters meaningful and productive group interactions? And how do we measure success? This panel will explore the ways that design and institutional culture can merge to create intellectual communities that prioritize learning over teaching and teamwork over individual achievement.
column7: Identify the components of a successful collaboration.
column8: Learn basic design strategies for enabling collaboration.
column9: Determine ways to measure success.

column1: Creating, Innovating: STEM Learning Afterschool
column5: Zelda Quiller Waymer (South Carolina Afterschool Alliance), Jim Chesire (Imagine Science), Hillary Salmons (Providence After School Alliance), Ron Ottinger (Noyce Foundation)
column6: Innovation, creativity and discovery are the cornerstones of engaged STEM learning. Afterschool and summer opportunities open up a world of possibility and excitement, providing children and youth with the space to explore their STEM interests while having fun and developing key 21st century skills for success. With more and more STEM-related jobs are being created, now is the time to prepare our students _ afterschool and summer learning opportunities are an integral component to the STEM solution. Speakers will share examples of how they are involved in transformational partnerships, investments and systems created to support the goal of inspiring and preparing our future STEM workforce.
column7: Panel discussants will give an overview of how STEM afterschool programs keep youth engaged and provide the space to explore their own interests.
column8: Participants will discuss best practices and lessons learned about developing STEM systems and innovative partnerships that help to support the field.
column9: Participants will consider strategies used by foundations, programs and networks that help youth gain access to supports that develop STEM skills.

column1: Design patters for hackerspaces
column5: Stefania Druga (HacKIDemia), Holly  Hudson  (nycresistor)
column6: A panel about design patterns for hackerspaces/makerspaces as a response to the common question: how to set up your own Hacker Space ? The initial guide of Design Patterns was based on more than 10 years of experience with setting up and running a Hacker Spac and made as part of the Chaos Communication Camp 2007. As these community spaces and movements evolved we want to raise the questions of design patterns for diversity, collaboration and inclusion with various members of the hackerspaces, makerspaces, fablabs.
column7: Learn what are the main challenges in running a community space.
column8: Learn how to overcome them and what are the most common problems/solutions.
column9: Learn how the maker/hacker communities have evolved over time and where are they headed.

column1: Designing Future-Proofed Maker Spaces
column5: Phil King (Katherine Delmar Burke School), Mike Matthews (Katherine Delmar Burke School), Jenny Howland (Katherine Delmar Burke School), Nayo Brooks (Katherine Delmar Burke School)
column6: From tinkering labs to fabrication studios, _maker spaces_ are popping up at schools worldwide. Some question if these new classrooms are a passing fad or if they represent the future of hands-on learning. Leaders in the maker ed movement from Katherine Delmar Burke School will share how they transformed 2 existing classrooms into cutting edge maker spaces over the course of a summer without a major construction project or capital campaign. Hear 9 guiding principles, grounded in student-centered learning & research-based pedagogy, that they used to create _The Makery_ at Burke_s - flexible, dynamic, & ever-evolving learning spaces designed to be both relevant today & stand the test of time.
column7: Articulate why maker spaces are relevant to 21st century learning.
column8: Establish guiding principles for designing a future-proofed maker space - one that, by design, is able to meet ever-changing and evolving needs.
column9: Identify potential pitfalls that need to be considered in order to ensure that money is well spent developing and staffing maker spaces.

column1: Get the Highest Return on Your Biggest Investment
column5: Raj Bajan (iontuition)
column6: The stress of getting into college is still present for most high school students, but another one that is on the rise is being able to pay for the dream college once acceptance has been achieved as well as the student debt that may be looming after graduation. Ceannate CEO, Balaji Rajan, would like to discuss the importance of educating high school admission counselors, students and parents on what factors should be considered before making the big investment of higher education. He would like to speak on issues such as financial aid, majors, salary out of college, college debt and how to reduce it as fast as possible.
column7: Help students and families take control of their education and finances with helpful tools and counseling.
column8: How are current and former students are faring, where graduates are employed and what they are earning from specific universities?
column9: Students need and deserve tools that will help ensure that the time and money they spend pursuing a college degree or credential is worth it.

column1: Great Moments in Teaching. Really?
column5: Arthur Levine (Woodrow Wilson Foundation), Jeffrey Young (Chronicle of Higher Education)
column6: Presented by The Chronicle of Higher Education (and inspired by Mystery Science Theater 3000), this session will feature short video clips of professors using a variety of teaching approaches, while a panel of (sometimes irreverent) experts and audience members provide running commentary on what works and what doesn_t.
column7: See examples of best practices in classroom teaching.
column8: Discuss teaching techniques with experts and peers.
column9: Hear trends in teaching approaches and the results of new research on teaching effectiveness.

column1: Hacking Education Through Libraries
column5: Miguel  Figueroa (Center for the Future of Libraries, ALA), Joyce Valenza (Rutgers University), Bud Hunt (Clearview Library District), Carolyn Foote (Eanes ISD)
column6: What is the value added of school libraries going forward? Librarians are a powerful tool for hacking change in the culture and changing practice of a school environment.  Explore ways that librarians can be change agents and how they can facilitate and address such issues as: equity, access, social justice, informal and self-directed learning (free-range learning), meaningful student communication products, digital workflow and the development of new literacies. A rapid fire presentation followed by Q & A will explore trends and potential partnerships for librarians and school leadership.
column7: Explore new potentials that libraries and teacher librarians to add to the education of students and the learning culture of our schools.
column8: Discover how librarians are change agents in areas of social equity, access,  informal learning and developing literacies.
column9: Consider how librarians are engaged partners in addressing the digital transformation of schools.

column1: If These Walls Could Talk!
column5: Valerie Lewis (AppleSeed Learning)
column6: In this session, I would love to have a panel of guests have an interactive session and discussion on remodeling the classroom, school building or adding on to an existing space where creativity can run wild! Administrators, Teachers, and School Board Members would need to see the added value in designing a space to prepare students for NOW skills in career and workplaces. Teachers can draw and innovate what would be ideal for their students and have a gallery walk by attendees on an ideal space.
column7: SChool districts recognize the importance of designing a space that is opposite of the traditional blueprint.
column8: Teachers recognize that they can start small with little to no money on redesigning their space beyond moving the furniture and adding colorful paper
column9: For NOW skills to be effective they have to be practiced in our "training grounds" and other learning spaces.

column1: Inspiring Innovation With Makerspace Curriculum
column5: Mark Hatch (TechShop)
column6: Hands-on education systems like the Montessori method have proven to be more productive and agile than current rigid approaches, and directly appeal to the natural curiosity of children. The maker movement aims to make new technologies accessible to everyone so they can innovate and create a vibrant, collaborative community of global problem-solvers. Making, producing, experimenting, designing and building should be part of the everyday environment, especially in the classroom where children are learning to collaborate and interact with peers. By embracing the lessons of the maker movement, educators can revamp the best student-centered teaching practices to engage learners of all ages.
column7: To showcase how the maker movement can translate to classroom teaching
column8: To discuss how encouraging innovation at an early age is the key to solving global problems
column9: To highlight how the maker movement is reinvigorating educational programming

column1: Netflix of Learning: Unlimited Student Support
column5: Philip Cutler (GradeSlam), Emrecan Dogan (Scorebeyond), Ned Renzi (Birchmere Ventures)
column6: Technology has completely changed the way that the world communicates, collaborates and interacts. The purpose of this panel would be to discuss the different avenues that now exist to provide students with unlimited access to resources that help them succeed academically. With 24/7 supplementary support, students, teachers and parents can always be certain that the necessary online resources are available to help the students excel. Using "Netflix" style unlimited models, many services have been successful at offering adapted worksheets, tutorial videos and private tutoring for students.
column7: To help inform teachers and administrators of the online services that currently exist and help move the unlimited learning market forward.
column8: Technological advances that have enabled the widespread accessibility of unlimited supplementary services.
column9: To showcase current stage of the unlimited supplementary services.

column1: No Barriers: Models for Making in Your Community
column5: Trevor  Taylor (The University of the Arts ), Robin Gose (Thinkery), Sam Dean (Amazeum), Sarah Koik (Haas Center for Public Service , Stanford University)
column6: The maker movement promises to provide several unique access points for STEM learning and creative expression for our communities. Making provides a rich foundation for inventive, iterative play; key ingredients to innovative thinking and 21st century skills. However, without significant planning, capital and a dedicated space, many communities' ideas for makerspaces tend to fizzle out. In this session we will look at different approaches to making and makerspaces, addressing some of the barriers of entry for beginning a community makerspace and demonstrate a framework that will help community leaders and educators start making with their communities, no matter what their current resources.
column7: Compare various models for makerspaces - dedicated spaces, annual festivals, afterschool programs, traveling activities.
column8: Understand the types of learning that can occur in a makerspace - inventive, iterative, collaborative play, process based learning, learner-driven.
column9: Learn to create and implement tangible goals for DIY makerspaces on almost any budget. What_s required - tools, latest technology, dedicated space?

column1: Not Your Grandpa's Shop: Reimagining Makerspaces
column5: Liz Nugent (Autodesk), Joya Balk (San Francisco Unified School District), Deirdre Cerminaro (IDEO), Karen Kaun (Makeosity)
column6: Makerspace (n.): a space for people to create, invent and learn. We hear a lot about makerspaces - the importance of 21st century skills, fostering creativity and innovation - but to many schools, creating a makerspace is daunting. What kind of space is right for our school? Where do we find the budget or time? How do we get students excited about using it? Join us to learn from educators and designers who built makerspaces (physical and virtual) to inspire students to create, invent and learn.
column7: Challenge your idea of a makerspace
column8: Get inspired from others_ success stories
column9: Gather tips on how to get started

column1: Principles of Design: Not Another Makerspace Talk
column5: Andrew Kim (Steelcase), Katie Faulkner (NADAAA), Peter Hutton (Beaver Country Day School)
column6: Educators need to look for ways to prepare students for the "real world" _ so why not allow the real world to serve as inspiration for school and classroom design? All schools can _ and should _ look beyond traditional classrooms (and makerspaces) to better facilitate learning.This panel will explore successful ways to create an educational environment that fosters learning across every situation, subject, and grade, as well tips on overcoming challenges of the design process.
column7: Understand the impact school & classroom design have on learning, and the benefits students receive from a non-traditional educational setting.
column8: Learn how _ even with a small budget _ educators can improve a school_s design to facilitate students_ learning and overall classroom experiences.
column9: Gain insight into what existing learning space designs have and have not worked well at Beaver, and understand the challenges of the design process.

column1: Putting the Public Back into Public Universities
column5: Kaethe  Selkirk (University of Texas at Austin School of Architecture), Jim Walker (University of Texas at Austin Office of Sustainability), Robert Young (University of Texas at Austin School of Architecture), Katherine  Lieberknecht (University of Texas at Austin School of Architecture)
column6: Putting the Public Back into Public Universities means creating inclusive learning spaces that empower people to become both students and teachers. Texas CityLab (TCL) creates these spaces by transforming Texas cities into classrooms. Multi-disciplinary students connect with Texas communities to jointly research and develop sustainability solutions grounded in place. Join us to discuss how local and University expertise can unite to strengthen shared problem solving in cities.
column7: Discover how to strengthen place-based sustainability.
column8: Learn best practices for uniting local and expert knowledge.
column9: Gain tools for incorporating the public back into your learning space.

column1: Spaces to Support Connected Makers and Learners
column5: Becky Calzada (Leander ISD), Michelle Cooper (White Oak ISD), Melissa Techman (Albemarle County Public Schools, Charlottesville, Virginia)
column6: School libraries as innovative, maker learning hubs provide opportunities to tinker, create, and explore. Makerspaces and learning commons stand as thriving counter-examples to the academic passivity that test-driven school cultures often suffer from. Flexible, inviting spaces support students_ authentic interests, deeper learning, support reading and publishing, and involve students as productive, creative members of the school community. This panel will discuss a range of design options, but the focus is supporting beginner and _Maker 2.0_  activities. Attendees will come away with resources for space design changes, as well as ideas for new approaches to challenging students as learners.
column7: Learning space designs provide opportunities for authentic student learning.
column8: Student voice and student ownership of learning provide opportunities for high engagement.
column9: Providing Makerspace activities that engage students.

column1: STEM: More than Pi in the Sky
column5: Atish Banerjea (NBCUniversal)
column6: The shortage of students entering the science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) fields is well documented. Can celebrating tech holidays, such as Pi Day, make STEM fields more approachable and exciting to fresh graduates? Governments, companies, non-profits are competing for the same limited resource: technical employees. In this panel, speakers from private and public entities will discuss the moving the needle in growing more technical talent.
column7: How can companies more effectively market STEM careers to students?
column8: What can we do to move the needle in growing more technical talent?
column9: How can we make technical fields more approachable for employees who already have a non-technical career?
column12: diversity. inclusion. community engagement. technology innovation. venture capital. coding. education.

column1: The 9 Million Ways the Smithsonian Loves Education
column5: Brian Ausland (Navigation North Learning), Melissa  Wadman (Smithsonian Center for Learning and Digital Access), Darren  Milligan (Smithsonian Center for Learning and Digital Access)
column6: Having spent 4 years researching educator and learner use of the Smithsonian's 9+ million digitized objects, the Smithsonian Center for Learning and Digital Access has forged an incredible new model for OER publishing and usability with the Smithsonian Learning Lab. As a national partner on the US Dept. of ED's Learning Registry, the Smithsonian has just become the single largest resource contributor and has integrated a series of tools that allow educators to also create and publish using both Smithsonian resources and other OER sources. The Smithsonian challenges other repository-holders to join them in freeing their resources and inviting our nation's teachers and learners to the party.
column7: Recognize the need to release your resources in a way that educators and learners can remix, reuse, and republish for their own needs.
column8: Organize your team around the efficacy of the objects, and allow educators and learners the role of creating instructional context and content.
column9: Understand how a community of empowered consumers and learning authors can inform your agency's ongoing focus and resource allocations.

column1: The Social (Media) Lives of College Students
column5: Paul Eaton (Sam Houston State University), Adam Gismondi (Boston College), Josie Ahlquist (Independent), Paul Gordon Brown (Fashion Institute of Technology)
column6: Ever wonder what_s really going on when college students enter social media spaces?  From leadership, to civic engagement, to their growth and development as a person, this panel session incorporates the perspectives of four educational scholars  who interviewed, surveyed, and liked their way through the data to share some of their insights and takeaways about the college student experience.  This isn_t a dry panel reporting out facts and figures, but one where real student voices will help inform participants understanding of what it means to grow up and experience college with social media.
column7: Gain an understanding about how college students view themselves online and how this is impacted by various social media spaces.
column8: Leave with tangible ideas and guideposts for promoting student learning in social media and hybridized spaces.
column9: Understand how students utilize social media and how their interactions in these spaces impact their personal development, leadership, and learning.

column1: The Technology Test Kitchen: Learning by Doing
column5: Robbie Melton (Tennessee Board of Regents), Phylise Banner (Union Graduate College), Frank Tomsic (Rush University), Jessica Knott (Michigan State University)
column6: In response to a demand for more community-of-practice approach at faculty development seminars, a group of educators designed a new learning space concept _ the Technology Test Kitchen. The Technology Test Kitchen is a makerspace where participants are guided by "chefs" who talk about design, discuss "recipes" (quick how-to guides), utilize apps, brainstorm curriculum strategies, explore new media, and provide 1:1, hands-on sharing with learning technologies.This session will delve into the Technology Test Kitchen and provide direction on how to successfully showcase this approach at your school, using resources developed by the Technology Test Kitchen pioneer "chefs".
column7: Develop a makerspace model where teachers and learners can discover, explore and apply pedagogically based applications of learning technologies.
column8: Access and contribute to a growing collection of Technology Test Kitchen recipes (Creative Commons License Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike).
column9: Facilitate a constructivist approach to integrating technology into teaching and learning at all levels.

column1: Think Outside The Book
column5: Beatriz Arnillas (Houston ISD), Randy Wilhelm (Knovation), Diana Bidulescu (Houston ISD)
column6: As districts build student-centered learning environments, we must reimagine a digital ecosystem that nurtures the human brain capacity to gather, organize data and find real life applications. Houston Independent School District integrated Knovation's OER collection in the district's learning management system to provide access to educator-vetted, standards-aligned, contextualized learning resources, making full use of OER to streamline access to curriculum resources that every child needs. We will share a framework to move from a one-book-per-class mentality to curating content and providing channels to a world of resources that encourage student choice. Let_s think outside the book!
column7: Understanding how digital content best supports student-driven learning
column8: Where can educators find digital content that is relevant, engaging and vetted
column9: How to combine Open Education Resources with pre-existent content to enhance learning and encourage students expression

column1: Turning Students Into Creators and Coders
column5: Sunanna Chand (Remake Learning), Aileen Owens (South Fayette School District), Sara Schapiro (Digital Promise), Todd Keruskin (Elizabeth Forward School District)
column6: We all know it's important to prepare students to become the creators, tinkerers, and innovators of tomorrow. It's easier said than done. How can schools break out of traditional education models and truly embed making and programming into teaching and learning? This is the challenge that Pittsburgh-area schools, entrepreneurs, and community organizations are addressing head on. Through this hands-on panel, attendees will get a close look at how South Fayette and Elizabeth Forward school districts are incorporating coding, engineering, and manufacturing into their curriculum for all students from kindergarten to graduation.
column7: A model for embedding computational thinking and maker education into a K-12 curriculum.
column8: A look at what early research in these districts says about the impact of STEM pathways for students.
column9: An understanding of how to prepare students for future careers while also fostering creative expression through technology.

column1: #WhyMyHighSchoolDoesntSuck
column5: Mickey Revenaugh (Pearson ISDD)
column6: Hear from students who went from hating high school in a traditional setting -- finding learning irrelevant and boring -- to discovering innovative, new blended and virtual high schools where personalized learning, choice, engagement, collaboration and technology make learning relevant and motivating. Learn first-hand from the student panel about their _Version 2.0_ schools and why they went from hating to loving high school.
column7: Learn how students develop pathways to success building on their individual strengths and interests in a safe online setting.
column8: Discover how students in virtual and blended programs connect with each other and the larger school community.
column9: Understand how personalized learning and student engagement make learning relevant and motivating.

column1: Youth engagement & self led learning at CoderDojo
column5: Garima Singh (CoderDojo Round Rock), Mary Moloney (The CoderDojo Foundation)
column6: CoderDojo is a global volunteer movement of free programming clubs for young people aged 7-17. There are 750 Dojos in 59 countries around the world. At CoderDojo young people learn how to code, develop websites, apps, games and explore technology. Our vision is a world where every child and young person has the opportunity to build technology skills, learn to code and to be creative in a safe and social environment.This panel will feature CoderDojo Foundation CEO Mary Moloney talking with CoderDojo Round Rock Champion, Garima Singh (17) and other CoderDojo Youth members about their experiences with self led, peer to peer learning at CoderDojo.
column7: A focus on peer learning, youth mentoring and self led learning with an emphasis on helping others, showing how coding is a force for change.
column8: Youth mentoring and empowerment: giving young people the confidence to mentor and share their knowledge with others, reinforcing their knowledge.
column9: How to engage and empower young people through technology and education.

column1: Changemaker Ed: Transforming How Kids Grow Up
column5: Tom s Alvarez III (Beats Rhymes and Life), Luis Perales (Changemaker High School), Bobbi Macdonald (City Neighbors Charter School), West Willmore (Rainbow Community School)
column6: We live in a world of uncertainty defined by rapid change. While we do not know what tomorrow's problems will be, we know we will need everyone equipped to deal with them. Educators are uniquely positioned to empower students to be changemakers - able to collaborate, create, and act empathetically in ambiguous and changing environments. In this session, we bring together a dynamic panel pioneering innovative ways of empowering youth to be agents of change in the world. Drawing on diverse experiences and approaches, panelists will discuss why we must transform the way in which kids grow up and how they are doing it in their own schools and communities.
column7: Appreciate students' potential to act as agents of change in their communities and the world.
column8: Recognize why we must teach empathy and changemaking in schools to transform the way kids grow up in today's world.
column9: Gain insight into how school communities can empower students to be changemakers and the tools to begin that process in your own classroom.

column1: How Can Media Teach Character & Life Skills?
column5: Yalda Uhls (Common Sense Media), Darla Anderson (Pixar), Richard Weissbourd (Harvard University)
column6: Media can affect children's social and emotional learning (SEL), which has implications for moral development and achievement. So, in partnership with the John Templeton Foundation and Bezos Family Foundation, Common Sense has developed tools-- SEL-sensitive ratings & write-ups of visual and interactive media-- to enrich children's character virtues and life skills. This session will distinguish virtues from skills and articulate how both are vital for healthy functioning. Next, it will review how stories (e.g., campfire tales, video game simulations) influence SEL. Last, it will demonstrate how parents, teachers and kids can use Common Sense's tools to find inspirational, educational media.
column7: Participants will be able to compare/contrast character virtues and life skills as well as list examples of both.
column8: Participants will be able to explain how stories influence character development and model life skills.
column9: Participants will be able to use Common Sense tools and software that empower users to choose media mindfully.

column1: Power of Partnerships on Student Learning
column5: Steve Mesler (Classroom Champions), Leticia Barr (Foundation for Advancing Alcohol Responsibility), Jerome Clemons (Imagine Hope Community Charter School - Tolson Campus ), Ralph Blackman (Foundation for Advancing Alcohol Responsibility (Responsibility.org))
column6: Innovative partnerships are cost-effective ways to provide teachers with necessary tools to create strong relationships between teachers, students, and stakeholders invested in a child_s education. This panel explores effective partnerships, including how to find and implement programs that benefit student learners in low-income areas around the country and world through innovative uses of technology. We_ll discuss challenges and best practices for collaborations with schools, teachers, and parents, examine the success of nonprofit partnerships, explore virtual mentorship using Skype and Google Hangouts, and the value of metrics in gauging effective programs.
column7: Learn best practices for finding, establishing, and implementing successful educational partnerships to benefit student learning.
column8: Explore cost-effective partnerships incorporating innovative uses of technology to change behaviors and attitudes in lower income communities
column9: Understand how global partnerships provide interdisciplinary instruction to positively impact student attitudes and behaviors about underage drinking

column1: Tech + SEL = happy/healthy parents/children
column5: Sam Chaudhary (ClassDojo), David  Padilla (KCBS 740 San Francisco), Bill  Jackson (GreatSchools)
column6: Research shows that students with higher levels of emotional intelligence are more engaged in the classroom, and do better academically. They are also most likely to find success later in life in the workplace and at home. Technology can bring new content and tools that will help parents teach their children how to resolve conflicts, foster positive relationships and build emotional intelligence.  The panelists will discuss the importance, and future of technology's role in distributing social, emotional learning tools to teachers, parents and children.
column7: Understand how social, emotional learning tools helps parents and children.
column8: Learn how to use technology for your benefit in the area of social, emotional learning tools.
column9: Learn how to foster higher levels of emotional intelligence through technology and SEL tools.

column1: Better Financial Support for Special Education
column5: Tony Brown (Public Consulting Group)
column6: Strapped for cash, school districts bear a high burden supporting special needs students with no common conversation on how to guide future investments for this at-risk population. Join this interactive discussion and help us define a _Special Education Investment Baseline_ and share best practices on how to prepare special needs students for college and career readiness. We encourage you to bring your best ideas to tackle this challenge facing our communities, schools, states, and more.
column7: Discuss and define a current baseline for special education investments and identify expected outcomes from those investments.
column8: Gain exposure to national best practices for better preparing special education students for college and career readiness.
column9: Learn about research projects that are helping guide future investments in the special education arena.

column1: Gimmick or Teaching Tool: Apple Watch in Education
column5: Monica Burns (Class Tech Tips, LLC), Paul Hamilton (Matthew Flinders Anglican College), Luis Perez Phd (consultant), Courtney Pepe (A. Harry Moore School of New Jersey City University)
column6: Is the Apple Watch a gimmick or teaching tool?  This panel will offer 4 unique perspectives on how the Apple Watch can be used in a variety of educational settings.  We will share the stories of how the Apple Watch has been used to improve independence, accessibility, and quality of life for visually impaired students, hearing impaired students, and students who are in wheelchairs.  We will showcase how the Apple Watch integrates with other emergent tech such as iBeacons and Augmented Reality.  The Apple Watch can be a powerful tool for 21st century storytelling & data collection in global learning spaces. Latest ed tech fad? Come hear our stories about the Apple Watch and make up your mind.
column7: Participants will be able to understand the implications for wearable technology in diverse learning environments.
column8: Participants will be able to explore the the Apple Watch integration into the the iBeacon technology ecosystem.
column9: Participants will be able to identify the potential for the Apple Watch to collect data and create stories in an educational setting.

column1: I Am More Powerful: Storytelling for All
column5: Mark Coppin (Anne Carlsen Center), Mark Dohn (Independent Educational Technology Consultant), Luis Perez (Independent Educational Consultant)
column6: This session will focus on digital storytelling as a powerful tool for providing a voice for all learners. Accessibility options built into iOS and OS X, as well as a range of apps, make it possible for all learners to find their voice and creative expression. When learners have a voice and their experiences are valued and validated, they are more engaged and invested in learning. A number of accessible apps for video and audio creation will be demonstrated in this session, along with examples of how learners are using these apps to share their experiences of empowerment with the rest of the world.
column7: Identify elements of  effective digital story telling, including visual literacy, digital citizenship and social engagement.
column8: Use universal design features built into iOS and OS X as well as apps in order to provide flexible learning supports for diverse learners.
column9: Identify design best practices for developing digital content that leverages the universal design features built into iOS and OS X to empower all lear

column1: Optimizing Ed: UDL, Tech & Personalized Learning
column5: Alexander (Sasha) Evans (University of Vermont), Wayne Grant ( Intel Corp), Gabrielle Rappolt-Schlichtmann (CAST), David Dockterman (Harvard Graduate School of Education)
column6: Exciting personalized classrooms are the gold standard, advancing learning for all students. Technology breakthroughs and cutting-edge advances have enabled classrooms to implement Universal Design for Learning (UDL) and to reach the kids who are truly struggling, while improving the classroom experience for everyone. Experts from CAST, Harvard and Intel, as well a student with dyslexia, will discuss UDL as a framework for optimizing teaching and learning for all students, especially those with diagnosed and undiagnosed disabilities. We'll also explore technologies as ways to create personalized classrooms that level the learning field so all kids can succeed.
column7: How to leverage technologies to create classrooms that provide differentiated teaching
column8: Barriers to successfully implementing UDL principles in the classroom
column9: Benefits of implementing UDL/personalized learning for kids with learning and attention issues and for all kids.

column1: Social Robotics: Future of Autism Intervention in
column5: Pamela Rollins (The University of Texas at Dallas), Michelle  McFarlin (White Rock Autism)
column6: With appearances on CNN and Univision, Milo the humanoid robot has captured the attention of the world. Designed to facilitate and teach social and emotional behavior to improve engagement for children with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD), Milo is a pioneering autism intervention tool for educators, therapists and parents. Strong research and identified evidence-based best practice show children with ASD are more engaged with Milo than with therapists. Ongoing research focuses on using the robot to facilitate understanding of social situations and generalization to humans. Join autism experts to learn about the benefits of and latest research on social robotics for autism intervention.
column7: Gain a background in social robotics for autism intervention
column8: Learn how social robotics is currently being used in schools
column9: Acquire latest research on using social robotics for autism intervention

column1: The Achievement Gap for Struggling Learners
column5: Jim Wendorf (National Center for Learning Disabilities ), Markay Winston (Chicago Public Schools), Margaret  McLeod (National Council of La Raza )
column6: The one in five kids with disabilities living in poverty face unique challenges. The best practices known to experts in the special education community aren't always widely available to those in greatest need. At the same time, services available to students in low-income settings don't always focus on the needs of those with these issues. Join renowned leaders_from Chicago Public Schools, and the country's largest Hispanic Civil Rights organization_as we explore how the special education community can work together with the education reform and anti-poverty communities to make sure all kids_no matter demographic or learning profile_have an equal chance at success in school, work and life.
column7: Understand the unique set of challenges facing kids with learning and attention issues coming from low-income, high-need backgrounds
column8: Take "lessons learned" from programs bringing best practices in supporting learning and attention issues to kids living in high-need settings
column9: Highlight ways the special education and broader education reform movements can work together to achieve a common set of goals to support all kids

column1: Why YOU Should Care About Special Education
column5: Sarah  Schlessinger (Teachers College Inclusive Classrooms Project), Melissa Corto (Education Modified), Kevin  Custer (Arc Capital ), Bruce Wexler (Yale School of Medicine)
column6: From research in neuro-diversity and technology, to federal policy and classroom practice, what we know about Special Education has changed dramatically over the past ten years- and everyone should care, including YOU. No matter what role you play in education, the information on this panel is relevant to all. The educational, societal, and economical implications of investing in, researching, and innovating in the field of special education are enormous. Come hear from experts in the field- top research institutions, leading venture firms, educators, and entrepreneurs- to learn why special education is important to YOU and why now is the time to get involved in the movement.
column7: What are the societal / economical implications of innovating and implementing special education services?
column8: Why invest in special education and technology?
column9: What has changed and why is now the time to care?

column1: Mobile Archives: Preserving Community Memories
column5: Trevor Owens (Institute of Museum and Library Services), Emily  Gore (Digital Public Library of America ), Jon Voss (Historypin), Dean  Haddock (StoryCorps)
column6: Libraries are essential institutions for serving 21st century information needs, but they are also at risk. Modern information flows have challenged what libraries mean to communities and individuals. Technologists, librarians and allies explore how we can use mobile digital archiving to transform community engagement and bridge the digital divide.
column7: Highlight the role libraries play as facilitators of community engagement with digital tools.
column8: Explore ways that libraries have expanded to meet communities and audiences where they are.
column9: Share methods libraries are using to adapt to the digital age and how to apply those techniques to other civic institutions struggling to do so.

column1: Beyond SELFie: Unlocking Student Voice & Vision
column5: Vanessa Perez (Lawton Public Schools)
column6: With cameras in many students_ pockets and filters at their fingertips, photography can be an instant gratification game scored by _likes_ and _follows_ on social media. How can we teach our students to create photographs with deeper meaning and inspire critical thinking? Join us for a quick interactive session, with a concentration on minimal editing and using technique over equipment, to see how looking through a camera lens can strengthen student perception and expression.
column7: Explore examples of student photography with themes including Obstacles, Service, Joy, Mine, Nature, Distance, Self-Portrait, and Heritage.
column8: Learn strategies for creating an environment where students feel comfortable exploring and effectively communicating how their views through photos.
column9: Copyright can be difficult for students to navigate. We will demonstrate how we facilitate student understanding of use and the public domain.

column1: Produce and livestream from iPad with Padcaster
column5: Josh Apter  (The Padcaster)
column6: Where video production and live broadcasting in schools was once cost prohibitive and complicated, now using new media tools like Apple's iPad and the Padcaster, it's affordable, mobile, and easy to master. Our goal is to teach people how to shoot, edit, share, and stream high quality video using only an iPad and The Padcaster. The Padcaster is a multifunctional iPad case that turns Apple's tablet into an all-in-one easy-to-use mobile production studio for a surprisingly low cost.  Access to this rapidly evolving technology gives the power of content creation and visual communication to students everywhere.
column7: To discuss the many advantages of using mobile devices to create content and live broadcast in an educational setting.
column8: To demonstrate the ease of hands-on shooting, editing, sharing, and live streaming high quality video from the iPad.
column9: To continue the conversation about how to affordably incorporate technology and the arts into all schools.

column1: The Mystery Box Challenge
column5: Heather Roesner (Children's Creativity Museum)
column6: The Children's Creativity Museum in SF is dedicated to nurturing a creative mindset in all children and families.  One of our most impactful activities is the Mystery Box Challenge. Using a box of "mystery ingredients," children and adults are given age-appropriate design challenges. This simple activity can be used to effectively build creative confidence, encourage risk-taking, practice perseverance, and employ critical thinking.  We will share activities you can implement with free or low-cost materials to fit with any content material. We will also share tips on encouraging reflection and asking open-ended questions.
column7: Examine the importance of fostering creativity in young people
column8: Apply and adapt the activity to diferent content areas
column9: Discuss best practices in asking open-ended questions and encouraging creativity in all participants.

column1: The New School of the Air: Audio Drama
column5: David LeMaster (San Jacinto College), Patience Wieland (University of Texas-Medical Branch)
column6: Audio drama: it's not just readers theatre or the domain of the speech department, and it's no longer the "old time radio" of the past. Using low cost technology like podcasting, or putting on an inexpensive live show, educators can use audio drama in their classrooms and communities.  Want to help your students' language skills, while also improving their ability to analyze media? Need to find a way of integrating oral or social history into your classroom? Looking to encourage healthy habits and creativity? Audio drama can help with these challenges and more.
column7: Plan an audio drama module for your classroom, a short podcast experiment created by your students, or a one-night-only theatrical production.
column8: Synthesize other topics or learning goals with the use of audio drama: history, health prevention, media analysis and more.
column9: Experiment with and learn to assemble organic, easy to make sound effects, created live on a Foley sound table.

column1: Pymetrics Sorting Cap: Discover Your Ideal Career
column5: Frida Polli (Pymetrics)
column6: Pymetrics (https://www.pymetrics.com) will give an introduction to the machine-learning and neuroscience technology powering pymetrics, a career discovery platform and career matchmaking tool. Attendees will play 12-20 neuroscience games, each of which measures a set of cognitive, emotional, or social attributes. Attendees will discover their detailed neuroscience profile, and will also discover their ideal careers based on their similarity to top performers in a wide array of industries and individual companies.
column7: Develop self-awareness of attendees' cognitive, emotional, and social strengths.
