column8: Discover companies and industries that attendees would be most likely to succeed in.
column9: Introductory understanding of behavioral neuroscience concepts and applications of neuroscience to HR.

column1: Using Attention as a GPS System for Learning
column5: Sheryl Abshire (Calcasieu Parish Public Schools), Steve Miller (Nervanix)
column6: Attendees will receive a brief overview of the relevant research on the neuroscience of learning.  A hands-on demonstration of biosensor technology, coupled with advanced software, will show attendees how this new system serves as a "GPS for Learning" by re-directing learners to sections of content where they "zoned out".  The presenters will summarize evidence to support new advances in neuroscience and share results from recent feasibility studies conducted in Calcasieu Parish, LA.   This hands-on session will introduce attendees to the exciting concept of _Attention Adaptivity_ and how it improves learning outcomes by fostering meta-cognition and student ownership of the learning process.
column7: Share the benefits of neuroscience-based eLearning solutions.
column8: Provide a real-time demonstration of attention measurement and the ability to re-direct learners to specific content where they were not focused.
column9: Discuss the varied benefits of neuroscience-inspired technology solutions and how to scale them for school-based implementation

column1: Collaborative Empathy: Teaching for Learning
column5: Caroline Bucker (Idealiza Tools & Methods), Lisa Jasinski (Trinity University), Lisa Jasinskidelete! (Trinity University)
column6: The first step in the design thinking process - a creative problem solving approach from engineering - is to empathize with the individuals who use your products. Our experiences applying design thinking methods in schools (both k-12 and higher ed) in the US and Brazil provide tools and strategies educators can use to empathize with their learners. We will share interviewing strategies to gather helpful information and provide an _Empathy Map,_ a simple tool to organize learners_ explicit statements and the educator_s inferences, to inform pedagogical choices and innovations, such as how to use best classroom time, space, and assignments according to learners_ preferences/needs.
column7: Teachers will learn to _think a designer_ and empower their students to shape the learning process, activities, and environments
column8: Participants will practice interviewing for empathy techniques with learners.
column9: Participants will sort learners' experiences (both expressed and inferred) into an Empathy Map, a simple tool to analyze qualitative data.

column1: Exploring Open Play for O-5 year olds
column5: Amber Creger (Arlington Heigths Memorial Library)
column6: Influence by the twelve different kinds of play, workshop attendees will engage in activities that demonstrate how to incorporate play options that support the development early literacy skills. Attendee's should come knowing that we will make a mess and embrace the process side of the experience.
column7: Participants will leave knowing how to identify the twelve different kinds of play.
column8: Participants will be able to develop age appropriate hands-on activities based on these 12 kinds of play for their young customers to engage in.
column9: Participants will be able to scale the content of this session to meet the needs of their customers and their institutions.

column1: Invent Your Own Internet of Things: STEAM and IoT
column5: Joachim Horn (SAM Labs), David Weiss (www.samlabs.me)
column6: Join SAM Labs and you'll be creating your own wireless Internet of Things inventions while learning Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Mathematics skills. No coding, no wires. You_ll be shown how to use SAM Labs' kits to instantly create wireless systems and connect them to the Internet without any coding skills needed. You'll be learning how to use our wireless blocks and simple app to understand the basics of programming, logics, the Internet of Things and engineering. You'll be inventing in no time, whether expert of beginner.
column7: Programming - SAM Labs' drag-and-drop app empowers you to visually program and connect different sensors together. Learn about logic gates and more.
column8: Making/ Problem solving - Using different wireless blocks you will quickly be able to combine them to produce your own smart inventions in minutes.
column9: Understanding Internet of Things - Understand how Internet of Things works and how it will impact the future of education.

column1: Optimizing curriculum for iPad
column5: Mikkel Storm (Waterford Institute)
column6: Changing platforms for digital curriculum is much more complex than it looks. During this session, attendees will get a behind-the-scenes view into transforming curriculum from a desktop computer environment to a more deeply personal experience through touch-screen enabled technology. Attendees will gain insight into both age-appropriate practices such as uses of color, music and scaffolding lessons, and developing the cross-platform software that powers it. Underlying this hands-on session is the ideology that technology is simply the delivery system and should be used mindfully to enhance human experiences, streamline process, and eliminate menial tasks for teachers.
column7: Identify the main educational gaps technology satisfies based on current case studies.
column8: Understand the complexities behind designing and building effective learning software.
column9: Gain hands-on experience with award-winning technology proven successful in closing education gaps for more than three decades.

column1: Promising Practices in Early Childhood Development
column5: Heather Gann (Public Consulting Group), Jamie Kilpatrick (Public Consulting Group)
column6: _Early and often,_ is a phrase we have to learn from when it comes to identifying linkages between early childhood and early success in education. No greater tool exists in helping a child get off to greater success than tapping into early childhood professionals that have direct knowledge about the support a child needs. Once at risk students are identified in early learning programs, quality interventions can be implemented. However as they transition to early grades, critical information is lost. This session will offer success stories of promising practices in communities that have created strong linkages between community based early childhood programs and early grade experience.
column7: Attendees will understand some of the key predictors and linkages between early childhood and success in early education.
column8: Attendees will learn how to build stronger linkages between early childhood programs and early education.
column9: Attendees will leave inspired and armed with ideas, strategies and the knowledge to enhance their early childhood education programs.

column1: Totally Awesome Technology Tools
column5: Amy  Storer (Montgomery ISD)
column6: In this session, we will explore various technology tools that have transformed our classrooms.  From Google Cardboard to Twitter and Skype, we will show how we are breaking down the four walls of our classroom each and every day!
column7: We will learn how to use Google Cardboard in an elementary classroom setting.
column8: I will show the attendants how Twitter has transformed my classroom as well as create long lasting professional connections.
column9: We will explore how video conferencing can elevate and enhance the classroom experience.

column1: Climb & Learn About Mt. Kilimanjaro from Anywhere!
column5: Judy Kuan (Adventure to Fitness), Elisa Hinojosa (Adventure to Fitness)
column6: Adventure to Fitness will provide a live demo of our innovative blended learning, Common Core State Standards-aligned, educational fitness program for pre-K to Grade 5 kids!We will present classroom engagement tools focused on keeping kids active while helping them learn more effectively. General classroom, special education, physical education, English Language Learners, before/after school programs, summer camps - we'll cover it all. We will be streaming one of our most popular Adventure Videos - "Conquering Kilimanjaro" as a case study. Join us for session filled with healthy learning & fun! We'll be having a raffle with some awesome prizes. We'd love to see you there!
column7: Learn new classroom set-ups and techniques to help students advance through "educational+healthy" activities according to their unique abilities.
column8: Learn "flipped" learning techniques to help your students close the "healthy habits" & general learning loop in their school and home lives.
column9: Integrate these techniques into a holistic, allð-inclusive, and outcomes-oriented teaching & wellness strategy at your school and district!

column1: 4 Ways to Engage Students Using Adventure Learning
column5: Allan Staker (Brain Chase Productions, LLC)
column6: This hands-on playground will use a basic math lesson to demonstrate four principles of "adventure learning_ and how it can engage students in the classroom. First, participants will use rich multimedia to embark on a global search for a mysterious artifact. To advance in their quest, the audience will need to solve a basic currency conversion puzzle using real coins from seven different countries. Participants will then use the results of their work to answer a riddle, allowing them to move forward and unlock the prize. At each step of the journey, we'll reflect on how "adventure learning" principles can help students internalize even the simplest of lesson plans.
column7: Send participants on an international quest to recover a missing artifact using a combination of hands-on manipulables and rich multimedia.
column8: Convert a simple math exercise into an elaborate puzzle that requires hands-on currency conversion using real international coins.
column9: Demonstrate four actionable principles of "adventure learning," and discuss how these principles can be incorporated in the classroom.

column1: Developing Empathic Thinkers Via Tabletop Games
column5: Justin Devane (Teachers College, Columbia University), Jessica Yusaitis Pike (Center for Technology and School Change, Teachers College, Columbia University)
column6: Games have evolved from a supplemental classroom tool to a legitimate solution for engaging students in content. Unfortunately, practice is still behind rhetoric. Meanwhile, _content_ largely remains limited to core subject areas, while social-emotional learning and philosophical/critical thinking remain ancillary. In this session, participants will explore the capacity of games to prepare the critical, empathic thinkers of tomorrow through hands-on playtesting of a university-developed tabletop game. Participants will also experiment with redesigning game components that meet specific student needs, and provide feedback on incorporating these elements in their day-to-day instruction.
column7: Participants will briefly discuss the potential of games as a conduit for engaging students in philosophical and critical thinking.
column8: Participants will engage in a hands-on, table-top gaming experience that addresses social-emotional interaction and collective decision-making.
column9: Participants will experiment with designing game components that meet the needs of their specific students and adapt to day-to-day instruction.

column1: Game Design: The 21st Century Skills Accelerator
column5: Danielle Burnett (GameSalad, Inc.), Dan Magaha (GameSalad, Inc.)
column6: There is broad agreement that we must foster 21st Century Skills in our students.  But how do we best achieve this goal?Game development is a medium through which teachers can accelerate the development of these skills. Whether you want to emphasize individual productivity or group dynamics, critical or analytical thinking, game development is the ideal platform for future-proofing our children_s education. And best of all, it_s an engaging activity that all students love to do!In this session, we'll cover some of the ways game development can be used in the classroom effectively, do some paper prototyping as a group, and rapidly build our game using GameSalad software.
column7: Learn how the principles and practices of game development foster various 21st Century Skills.
column8: Learn about different ways you can use game development in your classroom to level up your students' 21st Century skills.
column9: Experience some of these practices in a rapid group game prototyping session.

column1: How to Breed a Dragon: Playing games to teach STEM
column5: Jeremy Friedberg (Spongelab Interaction), Joseph Wilson (Spongelab Interactive)
column6: The nature of the scientific process lends itself well to open-ended games. Scientists often begin with a question or puzzle, and then investigate through a series of experiments with the goal of collecting data on what works. Similarly, good games have a "quest" structure which allows them to fail rapidly, learn, and get closer to solving the puzzle. In biology, games such as "Dragon Breeder" allow players to learn the basics of genetic by taking care of their very own dragon. Spongelab.com's platform has dozens of such games that engage students in the process of science.
column7: Understand the importance of using games to engage students in the learning process
column8: Understand the parralels between scientific investigation and game-play
column9: Understand the power of integrating games across an entire district for the purpose of gathering engagement and comprehension data

column1: Improving Teamwork by Playing with Wooden Blocks
column5: Tina Chou (Bentley University)
column6: Let's go low-tech and play with some wooden blocks! In this session, everyone will form teams and play a few rounds of Instructures. Directions are simple: two teams use wooden blocks to build a structure from a blueprint. However, the person with the blueprint guides their team using only verbal instructions. This fun and competitive game has many parallels to how people establish ways of working and building products. With a few rule changes, it also mirrors the messy process of figuring out how to do something while you're doing it. After playing the game, we will talk about how this activity can improve communication skills and build trust among small teams.
column7: run a team-building activity where every member takes turns being the person in charge and needs to communicate verbally with their team
column8: learn the importance of naming conventions and speaking the same "language" while working together to accomplish specific tasks
column9: develop and improve a team process on the fly through quick iterations that simulate working together to build a product in a short timeframe

column1: NBA Math Hoops: Creating Math Champions
column5: Nick Monzi (Learn Fresh Education Co.)
column6: In this fast-paced and hands-on session, educators and students will dive into the NBA Math Hoops board game, mobile app, and classroom curriculum. All components of the experience are tied to Common Core Standards and 21st Century Learning Skills, and provide students with an exciting and fresh perspective on the subject of math. Teachers will be able to learn how they can link into Math Hoops community programs, currently available in a number of NBA markets across the country!
column7: Learn the basic classroom rules of the NBA Math Hoops board game.
column8: Identify a range of strategies for implementing the game in the classroom and after-school space.
column9: Learn how to connect to new and existing NBA Math Hoops community programs, featuring direct partnerships with NBA teams.

column1: Play to Learn: Aha Moments Together
column5: Catherine Pitcher (MonstRpreneur LLC), John-Michael  Scott (MonstRpreneur LLC)
column6: Attendees will have first hand experience playing a game developed to present opportunities for Aha moments on every turn.  A short overview of the integration of games, Aha moments, and learning will preface an hands-on experience playing.  A debriefing will highlight key moments in the game, and the objective of play being an effective medium for both insights and a demystification of a new experience.
column7: Game players will be able to convey how games elicit insights, or Aha! moments, and how these moments impact learning and retention.
column8: Game players will be able to recognize when they've had an Aha! moment while playing the game.
column9: Game players will be able to recognize when they've had an Aha! moment outside of the game.

column1: Towards a National Learning Economy
column5: Mindy Feldbaum (ACT Foundation)
column6: At the heart of our economy are Americans who are working learners: people fueled by curiosity, hustle, and the quest for life satisfaction. They work and learn at the same time, whether through formal education or skills training or personal development, and currently represent 77% of postsecondary learners. Working learners represent the greatest opportunity for increased economic mobility, equity, and growth and the challenge of the next decade will be to develop a National Learning Economy to support them.  The session begins with a 3-minute video scenario about working learners in 2026. Then, participants will be invited to share their ideas for the National Learning Economy.
column7: Understanding working learners and their challenges in today's world
column8: Recognizing the emerging learning economy and what it will look like in the next decade
column9: How you can help working learners achieve education and career success

column1: Virtual Exchange Meets Virtual Reality
column5: Chris Plutte (Global Nomads Group )
column6: Technology allows us to connect communities we may otherwise never encounter, offering the ability to approach the world with greater empathy. Virtual exchanges and virtual reality provides the incredible opportunity to make the nightly news come alive.We_d like to showcase our collaboration with  Nonny de la Pe¤a_s lab at USC combining virtual reality with virtual exchange through a project entitled Reimagine: Syria.  Students from Los Angeles were _dropped into_ a virtual reality recreation to understand the realities of the Syrian crisis. GNG connected these students with Syrian refugee youth in Amman, Jordan.  Participants will have the opportunity to be _immersed_ in a simulation.
column7: To investigate virtual reality and virtual exchange can play in fostering understanding, build empathy, and global citizenship
column8: To showcase the transformative nature of virtual reality, by being able to _walk in someone else_s shoes_.
column9: To explore how technology is opening the world, and connecting people who previously were unable to engage in live academic-based exchange.

column1: K-12 Robotics: Evolution from Simplebots to ASIMO
column5: David Held (Poughkeepsie Day School)
column6: Many schools are wrestling with how to integrate a Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math (STEAM) program into their K-12 curriculum. This Playground Hands On session provides you with the parts you need to start off with making a Simplebot. Join the group and handcraft a Simplebot and watch it swarm with the other bots.You will learn, while making your bot, by listening to how a school can use the framework of robotics to build a rich, creative and challenging curriculum from Simplebots and Bee-Bots to Lego Mindstorms, Roombas and First Tech Challenge. Learn to engage students independently and in teams with real life challenges and projects.
column7: Overview of the use of robotics as a teaching tool in the K-12 curriculum, from learning how a simple circuit works to basic mechanics and programing.
column8: Build a simple robot using a motor, battery, tape and recycled materials demonstrating how easy and fun it is to learn a simple circuit.
column9: Learn to engage students in Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Math (STEAM) program through innovation, creativity, teamwork and sharing ideas.

column1: The Miseducation of Beats, Hooks, and Lyrics!
column5: Elliot Gann (Today's Future Sound), Raphael Travis (FlowStory, PLLC)
column6: For education to truly flourish, we must unpack the multitude of potential uses of music in the classroom. It must also be done in the most straightforward and meaningful way possible, so that parents, teachers, counselors, and administrators see, hear and understand music's value in young people_s lives. Hip Hop, is often saddled with a negative stigma and thus its interdisciplinary breadth and depth is only realized by the most astute educators. FlowStory and Today's Future Sound have used beats, hooks, and lyrics as the foundation of a wide range of strategies for learning and growth. Perceptions of Hip Hop culture are flipped on their head with multiple uses across multiple platforms.
column7: In what ways can Hip Hop be used to promote the full range of what education means?
column8: Who are the interdisciplinary stakeholders that can best capitalize upon using Hip Hop as a resource within educational systems?
column9: What are the multiple platforms, both web-based and live, that capitalize on Hip Hop's uses and the skills of stakeholders serving today's students?

column1: 3D printing applications
column5: Alyson Nelson (Nikola Tesla STEM High School)
column6: Our STEM high school deploys a school wide program to use 3D printing across grades and disciplines.  We want to share out successes and invite participants into the conversation on using 3D printing to engage new interactive projects.
column7: Participants will review some of the more successful projects and assess those projects that needed evaluation.
column8: Participants will be able to leverage learning for more students with some project ideas.
column9: Participants will collaborate on a shared space for 3D printing resources.

column1: Bringing Activity-Based Learning to New Heights
column5: Tamu Thomas Walker (Educational Partnerships), Johnny  Wells (Sulphur Springs ISD and Destination Imagination)
column6: Step into the shoes of a student and accept a hands-on challenge geared towards developing 21st Century Learning skills. Destination Imagination and Public Consulting Group have joined forces to help teachers bring problem solving and STEM based environments into every classroom. Flexible thinking and problem solving are critical skills for students to develop. So, accept the challenge to join this session, and see how you and your student_s inner problem solver can be ignited!
column7: Discover ways to renew enthusiasm for science, technology, engineering, and math in your classroom.
column8: Learn fun and engaging ways to develop 21st century learning and innovation skills within your students.
column9: Become a better teacher by challenging your own flexible thinking and persistence for problem solving, and then apply it in the classroom.

column1: Capture it, it will last longer!
column5: Justin  McCutcheon (Cattura Video), Mair DeMarco (NYITCOM)
column6: Lecture capture is one of the most dominant uses to boost learning. Students and professors come to expect lecture capture as a learning tool, and many institutions now offer lecture capture for their courses.  Participants will hear a case study that walks through process of choosing and implementing a new academic video resource system.  Learn how you can record content as well as broadcast live media and metadata directly to your LMS in a fully automated way, use multi-source capture, chapter your content, and much more.
column7: After this session, participants will understand and be able to identify the elements of lecture capture.
column8: The participants will understand the value in lecture capture, automation and simple tools to accomplish their video goals.
column9: Selected audience members will participate hands-on to assist in the creation of a sample lecture capture system in under 30 minutes.

column1: Creative Learning: Constructive Self-Expression
column5: Theresa Wood (Austin ISD), Sloan McLain (MINDPOP)
column6: Teachers, administrators, and non-academic professionals are using creative teaching strategies from the Creative Learning Initiative (CLI) to build community and impact learning. These CLI strategies based in the arts and digital media are drastically transforming teaching and learning in Austin ISD. This school year alone, over 2,500 administrators and teachers have participated in CLI trainings to learn and apply these techniques, realizing their potential to engage students, deepen understanding, and make learning more personal and fun! This hands-on session will actively explore versatile, easy-to-learn creative teaching strategies that can be used in a variety of places and spaces.
column7: Experience the impact of creative learning strategies.
column8: Identify components of an effective creative learning strategy.
column9: Reflect on the value of creative learning in schools.

column1: Crowdsourcing STEM Teaching Excellence
column5: Melanie  Moore (KDK Harman Foundation ), Nate  McClennen (ImproveClass)
column6: Teaching can be a lonely experience, but technology tools are allowing us to create collaborative systems to improve performance. In summer of 2015, the KDK Harman Foundation implemented a pilot program to support teacher growth and development through an anonymous, video-based, feedback system for 15 summer STEM programs in Central Texas. Using a social, web-based technology, teachers from each program uploaded videos from classrooms and received peer feedback from others within the online network. During this presentation, we will demonstrate the system, the learning experiences, and invite the audience to observe STEM lessons and provide feedback on the teaching practice.
column7: Increase the frequency and quality of teacher feedback in schools and informal STEM education programs.
column8: Use technology and social networks to increase collaboration between teachers and programs implementing similar STEM curriculum.
column9: Explore how video-based teacher portfolios support and augment strong professional development programs.

column1: Hands-on Science with Low-Cost Materials
column5: Heather Beem (Practical Education Network)
column6: Under resource constraints, science teachers often feel limited to sketching on the blackboard. Through our work with junior and senior high school teachers in Sub-Saharan Africa, we have developed hundreds of science activities using low-cost, locally available materials. In this session, we will showcase several of our most popular activities, allowing participants to see science come to life using such everyday materials as food, flower petals, and water bottles.
column7: Participants believe that conducting hands-on activities is possible using everyday materials.
column8: Participants become aware of the innovative activities being developed by teachers in the developing world.
column9: Participants learn at least one activity they feel comfortable replicating on their own.

column1: Jumpstart Your School_s Maker Culture
column5: John Kilbane (American School of Bombay)
column6: Discover how to jumpstart your school_s maker culture by engaging parents, students and teachers in learning through making. Then, learn how to grow maker culture by developing curriculum and assessing the impact of making and tinkering. During this workshop you will learn about and takeaway; a maker framework, a making and tinkering guide for teachers,  a making and tinkering guide for parents, guidance for professional development, and tools for assessing impacts of learning through making.
column7: Learn about materials, space, electronics and kits that will help move maker forward in a school.
column8: Learn a strategy we used to accelerate our maker culture and how you can use it also.
column9: Learn via hands-on experience with some maker project and event ideas as well as explore some maker materials.

column1: Learning to Nurture Designers
column5: Pedro Reynolds-Cuellar (D-Lab, MIT), Jessica Huang (D-Lab, Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
column6: Anyone can learn a creative design process for tackling challenges, but not everyone has the opportunity to do so. Join the MIT D-Lab's youth program as we explore a few strategies to build creative capacity in schools and communities, in an attempt to democratize design! We will share examples and lessons learned from collaborating with preK-12 educators and students in greater Boston, Colombia, Ghana and beyond. There is plenty of design curricula available online, so this session will focus on supportive ecosystems for design content: creating enabling environments, facilitating diverse design teams, and connecting learners with resources to continue making their ideas into reality.
column7: Participants will learn strategies for building environments and mindsets that encourage creativity and enable design work
column8: Participants will learn strategies for facilitating diverse teams in doing design projects
column9: Participants will learn strategies for gathering resources to support learners in continuing to pursue design interests
column16: SXSWedu Programming Proposal / Jessica Huang /  Playground Hands OnHello Jessica Huang.This e-mail pertains to your 2016 SXSWedu proposal:'Learning to nurture designers'Congratulations! Your proposal has been accepted to SXSWedu 2016. We received a large amount of outstanding proposals via the SXSW PanelPicker, being selected for the event means that your idea was one of the best of the best.Your session has been accepted under the following attributes noted below. Keep in mind that some of the information may have changed from your original submission based on guidance from the Advisory Board and SXSWedu Staff. By confirming your involvement, you agree to any updates reflected and will implement any feedback:Track: Instructional StrategiesFormat: Playground Hands OnPlease read the following information carefully as it is very, very important.____________________________________________________________________________WHAT HAPPENS NEXT?WE NEED YOUR CONFIRMATION REPLY. Your plans may have changed since you sent in your proposal. So, please let us know if you still, in fact, would like to participate in SXSW EDU 2016 by visiting this link and following a few simple instructions:https://secure.sxsw.com/session_acceptance_confirmation/sign.php?token=79058058455Please confirm your participation via the above link within 7 days of 1/12/2016. If you do not confirm your participation, then we will assume you can no longer speak at SXSW EDU.____________________________________________________________________________

column1: Prompt Me: Translating the Writing Prompt
column5: Howard Fooksman (Michigan State University, Department of Writing, Rhetoric and American Culture)
column6: We've created a new piece of academic technology, PromptMe, a program designed to create meaningful conversations between instructors and students around writing assignment sheets. Drawing on our experiences as graduate students and writing teachers, we took our understanding of how communication moves from instructors to students (and back) through the design and interpretation of writing prompts to create an application that facilitate the creation, conversation and translation of assignment prompts. We hope to use this session to showcase the beta version of the technology, solicit user feedback, and explain the underlying research.
column7: Be able to create, edit, and distribute writing prompts through PromptMe.
column8: Use PromptMe to conduct conversations about academic language, learning objectives, and student assessment.
column9: Demonstrate how technology can support existing pedagogical approaches.

column1: Putting into practice languages, inquiry, & design
column5: Mateo Bolivar (Magellan International School), Tod Baker (Magellan International School)
column6: Let's develop in our students the skills that people at work leverage to be happy and productive. In this hands-on workshop, we will experience languages and design thinking driven by an inquiry-based approach to teaching and learning. We will see how being bilingual or multilingual helps us to communicate effectively; design thinking shows us how to iterate on ideas (even bad ones); and an inquiry-based approach gives us the support we need to learn languages and design solutions. In other words, this is an exploration of one way we can help students find that sweet spot where their passions, skills, and work come together.
column7: Further your understanding of multilingualism in education and at work.
column8: Apply the design cycle and design thinking to solve a problem.
column9: Strengthen your approach to creativity, productivity, and making through inquiry.

column1: Straight from the Students' Desk: Maker Experience
column5: Stephanie Cerda (St. Gabriel's Catholic School)
column6: This interactive student-led experience will give participants the chance to explore and create in order to learn by doing!  Students will share their favorite tools and best practices for thoughtfully integrating technology in support of making in the classroom.
column7: To give educators the opportunity to tinker with apps and other digital tools that support makerspaces
column8: To share best practices and strategies for technology integration in a maker-friendly classroom
column9: To expose educators to the student-led professional development model

column1: Student created animation increases understanding
column5: Stephanie Castle (United Nations International School), Wes Molyneaux (New Trier High School)
column6: This session is designed to provide a hands-on experience of using stop motion on the iPad.  Participants will see exemplars from the classroom to illustrate how stop motion has been used to allow students to creatively express their understanding of complex processes.  Participant will engage in using the iPads to create a simple guided stop motion animation.  This practical experience will demonstrate how teachers can apply this activity to assess student learning in their own classrooms.  A wide variety of application in different subjects will be shared and concluding student interviews will describe the capacity this has to improve student learning.
column7: Illustrate how stop motion animation can be used by students to show understanding of complex processes
column8: Utilize the iPad to create a simple stop motion animation
column9: Demonstrate how stop motion animation can be used by teachers to assess student learning

column1: The Fresh Holodeck 2.0: Culturally Responsive Tech
column5: Jamel Mims (Urban Arts Partnership), Armando Somoza (Urban Arts Partnership)
column6: In the world of #Edtech, new technology is itself often considered the solution to student engagement. However, no matter how groundbreaking, technology is only a tool - unevenly accessible urban youth - and just as disengaging if improperly facilitated.  Following the success of last year's demo at SXSWEdu, Fresh Ed returns with The Fresh Holodeck 2.0, an interactive classroom where students self-direct their learning, featuring all original hip hop music.  We've added more content & adapted more technology for classroom use: augmented reality apps, makey-makeys, LittleBits sensors, and of course, karaoke - to engage the user in a culturally responsive, interactive classroom experience.
column7: Participants will experience an interactive classroom that uses technology, youth culture, and hip hop to place students in an immersive environment.
column8: Participants will learn about culturally responsive technology: placing youth at the center of the classroom and using tech to augment the experience.
column9: Participants will take away tips & strategies on how to construct their own 'Holodeck' by adapting existing technology for use inside the classroom .

column1: Get Out! Sincerely, Your Motor and Creative Skills
column5: Tommaso Lana (Tommaso Lana Coaching. Education. Consulting.)
column6: How do we provide fantastic learning opportunities for children in their schools_ outdoor environments? How do we enable them to open their eyes, senses and minds to movement, play, exploration and creativity in a self-guided way?At The Preschool Museum, Falkensee, Germany, I mixed Italian vibes from the Reggio Emilia Approach and poetical levity of the German _Experimental Outdoor Education_. With the help of local children and no money, we built a landscape where kids aged 1 to 8, using simple natural elements (wood, rocks, soil & wind), are able to foster their curiosity, perceptual and motor skills, knowledge and empathy.This zero budget approach can be implemented in every school!
column7: You_ll discover and try out ideas, methods and approaches for nurturing children_s creativity, motor and social skills outside the classroom.
column8: You_ll experience the tremendous pedagogical potential of natural elements in your schoolyard or pre-K and daycare center outdoor area.
column9: You_ll learn how to develop new settings that will allow children to engage in a variety of projects outside the classroom, without a budget.

column1: #makingofamaker
column5: Andrea Keller (Irving ISD)
column6: As adults we are in a world full of lists, tasks and deadlines.  We are encouraging our youth to think outside the box and create, but are we giving ourselves the same opportunity.  Join this fast paced session as Andrea reviews her #summerofcreating and how it has led into the #makingofamaker  This hands on session will allow attendees to be creators and look at regular objects in a different manner.
column7: Explore what creating might look like for adults.
column8: Strategies for being a maker in daily life and also in school.
column9: Create an item from materials that are brought, or make a digital component

column1: No-tech Intro Activities for High-tech Makerspaces
column5: Shaunna Smith (Texas State University, College of Education)
column6: High-tech tools are often synonymous with makerspaces (i.e. 3D printers, CNC machines, and Arduinos). However, in the educational setting it is increasingly difficult to acquire these high-tech tools to support advanced student exploration. This is particularly true in some K-12 settings that do not have the same access to and/or budget to support the purchase and sustainability of such high-tech tools. By reconsidering ways of using easily accessible tools (i.e. Hot glue guns, rotary cutting tools, simple machines) we can provide entry point activities that engage equitable multidisciplinary learning experiences and highlight purposeful connections to more advanced high-tech tools.
column7: Create low-tech 3D prints and reconsider what it means to "print in 3D" by exploring hot glue guns for drawing, printmaking, and sculpture.
column8: Examine issues of equity and access in the educational makerspace community.
column9: Explore affordances of high-tech makerspace tools and identify charateristics and processes that connect to content learning outcomes.

column1: When Social Media Enters Classroom Texts (Really!)
column5: Jessica Reid-Sliwerski (LightSail Education)
column6: Hear tales from the cutting edge of education technology: LightSail has brought Facebook-style social media chats into classrooms and ELA texts _ for the first time! Hear what LightSail learned while deploying these revolutionary new features in K-12 classrooms _ and try these features for yourself _ in a presentation by Lightsail CAO Jessica Reid Sliwerski.
column7: Literacy instruction scaffolding
column8: Growth mindset
column9: Community and social learning

column1: Learning & Attention Issues Through a Child's Eyes
column5: Priscilla  Rodriguez  (Poses Family Foundation), Alexander (Sasha) Evans (University of Vermont)
column6: It's one thing to read about how a learning or attention issue can affect a child. It's another thing to actually see it through a child's eyes. In this session, see what the 1 in 5 kids who have learning and attention issues struggle with each day. Using one-of-a-kind simulations and videos, you can experience what it feels like to have issues with reading, writing, attention and focus. Find out firsthand how frustrating it can be when your hand won't write what your brain is telling it to write or when you can't complete a simple task even when you're trying to pay attention. Hear directly from students about their experiences and the strategies they've used to succeed.
column7: Experience how it feels to struggle with learning
column8: Gain an understanding of kids with learning and attention issues
column9: Learn how technology can be used to generate empathy

column1: Techtastic Ways To Support Special Needs Students
column5: Diana Benner (TCEA), Jose Meza (TCEA)
column6: Teaching students who are English language learners or have special needs can be intimidating. How can we get a jump start on helping our students learn? Come visit our playground to explore and participate in differentiated activities that will help learners of all abilities flourish. Technology activity trading cards, which contain links to resources, accommodations, and  lesson ideas for various subject areas and grade levels, will be available for participants.
column7: Explore unique ways in which students of different skill levels can participate in specially designed activities.
column8: Participate in activities that support special needs and ESL/ELL learners.
column9: Share resources of where participants can continue learning outside the playground session.

column1: Today I feel... a mobile application
column5: Rich Richards (Public Consulting Group), Greg Schermbeck (Self)
column6: Few teachers and counselors have the resources to mitigate violent behavior before it enters the classroom. Get hands-on exposure to the development of a mobile application that children with disabilities access daily prior to entering the classroom. This app proactively guides children through a series of questions making behavioral data immediately available to case managers as a student enters the classroom. We invite you to be part of a collaborative think tank as we work through practical and functional elements of this app. Attendees will leave inspired and familiar with the process of turning obstacles into ideas and ideas to fruition.
column7: Attendees will understand the need forpreventative check-ins with students who have disabilities.
column8: Attendees will understand the operational challenges that often disallow teachers and counselors from gathering this crucial data.
column9: Attendees will see how our mobile-app solves this issue.

column1: Art for Literacy_s Sake
column5: David Ciulla (ReadWorks), Carla Hinojosa (The Girls' School of Austin)
column6: In a world of high-stakes tests focusing on Math & ELA, the arts are often neglected, with severe consequences for reading comprehension! Surprising to many, K-12 students need meaningful knowledge of the arts to become proficient, college-ready readers. And exposure to the arts inspires students and fosters empathy and critical thinking skills, further improving reading skills.This talk will demonstrate how to use arts content and activities to meet ELA standards, sharing just enough cognitive science research to illustrate the impact of the arts on reading. Finally, the audience will participate in a curation activity to reinforce the ideas and to have a takeaway to use in the classroom.
column7: Learn how to use fine arts and performing arts content and activities to meet state ELA standards and improve reading.
column8: Understand the cognitive science research behind why the arts can deeply impact reading, especially in closing the achievement gap.
column9: Learn where to find free, premium quality online content for the arts to be used to meet ELA standards, build empathy, and inspire students.

column1: The Plug-In Studio: A Mobile Art + Tech Classroom
column5: Kerry  Richardson (The Plug-In Studio), Steve Ciampaglia (The Plug-In Studio)
column6: The Plug-In Studio (http://pluginstudio.net/) is a self-contained and entirely portable art and technology classroom.  We bring artist-teachers, laptops, materials and curriculum, and plug into the existing physical sites of partner organizations to provide free after school classes and workshops to underserved children and teens in the communities where they live. Students create contemporary art_interactive kinetic sculpture, art videogames, augmented reality graffiti_that integrates design, engineering, programming, robotics, and electronics skills. The Plug-In Studio is also a curriculum incubator for developing effective strategies for teaching art and technology to urban populations.
column7: Learn how contemporary artists integrate technology into their practice.
column8: Learn successful strategies for introducing art and technology concepts to urban youth.
column9: Learn how informal, community-based education models can provide curriculum that students are not receiving in their formal education.

column1: The Street Arcade: Socially Engaged Videogames
column5: Steve Ciampaglia (The Plug-In Studio), Kerry Richardson (The Plug-In Studio)
column6: The Street Arcade is a community-based, public new media art project that uses the creation of original videogames as a platform for young people to express themselves and engage their communities in dialogue. Teen artists from Chicago_s South Side harness the power of art and programming for social change through videogames about white privilege, racial profiling, immigration, and other issues. The games are projected onto the exterior of a building in an outdoor Street Arcade; passersby use retro-style red knob joysticks and buttons to play. Join teaching artists Kerry Richardson and Steve Ciampaglia as they share their experiences as the lead artists on this collaborative project.
column7: Learn how new media artists use videogames to address social issues and challenge commercial videogame conventions.
column8: Learn how the creation of videogames can facilitate artistic expression, foster community dialogue and encourage social change.
column9: Learn effective strategies for teaching videogame production to urban teens who are underserved in art and technology education programming.

column1: Suds Not Buds: David vs. Goliath as told thru Beer
column5: Devin Quinn (Deep Focus)
column6: This session is intended to reach anyone/everyone who is or has thought about the intersection of effective marketing and craft beer. I'll explore the most successful branding and marketing efforts of craft breweries in America. Microbrew beer is booming, and slowly but surely taking down industry mainstays like Miller-Coors. With more custom products many breweries are able to accomplish huge YOY sales grown and sustained advocacy by branding themselves in extremely appealing ways. Craft beer is exploding and dragging the marketing industry up by the boot straps. Let's determine how they're able to use marketing to unleash the most impassioned and vocal fans in any industry or sector.
column7: How are craft breweries creating legions of hyper-loyal brand advocates?
column8: What lessons can we learn from and scale that craft beer marketers employ to move product?
column9: Will craft beer eventually overtake large scale brewers in the US? Will mainstays of the brewing industry retaliate, and if so, how? Will it work?

column1: Building a Hovercraft as a Framework for STEAM and
column5: Parker Thomas (Mirus Labs)
column6: This talk will describe how STEAM Factory, a family makerspace in Oakland, California, used the process of building a 30 mph, 2 passenger hovercraft to demonstrate that STEAM is not a series of disparate disciplines only accessible through abstract concepts, but rather a language we can use to interact and shape the world around us.  The talk will focus on how we explicitly tied STEAM concepts into our build, how we used tools to develop the judgment to approach new situations thoughtfully and carefully and how we incorporated design challenges to develop our participants_ confidence and competence to shape the world.
column7: How to demonstrate that STEAM is a language we use to interact and shape the world around us
column8: How to manage a large, multistage project with students varying in ages from 8 to 55
column9: How to use a large project to gradually build confidence and competence to shape the world around us

column1: 40 Years Later, How Far Have we Come
column5: Dr. Scott Stage (NC State University), Dr. Jeffrey Braden (NC State University)
column6: Can research help us predict student success from the components of an Individualized Education Plan (IEP)? Armed with IEP data from tens of thousands of students, N. C. State University researchers are using Big Data to answer this question. It has been over 40 years since the Education for All Handicapped Children Act was passed, but how much have we learned about improving outcomes for students with exceptional education needs. This collaboration between the N. C Department of Public Instruction and Public Consulting Group seeks to answer questions about the efficacy of individual IEP components on a student_s academic assessment outcomes and we invite you to join in the conversation.
column7: Understand how data analytics can be used as predictors of success for students in special education.
column8: Share ideas and discuss how data can help us understand and evaluate the efficacy of a student's Individual Education Plan (IEP).
column9: Learn more about how North Carolina is leading the charge in using Big Data to rethink how institutions can support students with special needs.

column1: Therapy, Tech & The Truth: Behavior Change in 2016
column5: Roger Vilardaga, PHD (Dept. of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences of the University of Washington), Brian Marr (Smashing Ideas)
column6: Can a mobile application help you keep your teeth for life? Could it help the severely mentally ill quit smoking? How about helping autistic children create healthy habits that were never previously attainable through traditional parenting and medical techniques? We are on the cusp of having doctors prescribe a mobile application as part of patient therapy. In a presentation delivered by Vilardaga and Marr, the co-presenters will discuss highly anticipated, purpose-driven, breakthrough digital platforms that support positive reinforcement and enable healthy habits.
column7: How the technology market is on the cusp of creating digital experiences that build healthy habits and provide healthcare providers
column8: Designing for Children: Harnessing Smashing Ideas_ proprietary POV called the _power of play_ to teach children healthy habits from the start
column9: Tailoring UX to the cognitively undeveloped, those new to technology or those who have illnesses that impact their ability to use touch screens_

column1: Jumpstart our Kid_s Future _ Let's Talk Technical
column5: Melissa Jawaharlal (STEM Center USA), Lavanya Jawaharlal (STEM Center USA)
column6: We will discuss the importance of technology literacy and how it affects the next generation.  No matter what field a student pursues, a basic understanding of our modern world is vital for individual confidence and the forward movement of our modern society. While some programs introduce students to STEM fields in middle school and high school, these opportunities often come too late to be effective. Learning begins with the ABCs, and so should technology literacy. Through early learning and hands-on education, young children are more excited to learn about how houses are built, cell phones work, and cars move.
column7: Discuss the importance of increasing technology awareness at an early age through hands-on learning.
column8: Explore a holistic, comprehensive education for K-12 students to get them excited about STEM fields and concepts.
column9: Consider the benefits of interfacing daily activities such as learning the ABCs with technical terms, experiments, and activities.

column1: See2Achieve: Virtual Reality, Vision and Learning
column5: Jennifer Simonson (Boulder Valley Vision Therapy), Len Scrogan (University of Colorado-Denver)
column6: Healthy vision deeply influences a child_s achievement in reading, learning, success in sports, and future career choices. Hear from both an educational technologist and a doctor of optometry and vision therapy as we show how virtual reality is fostering unanticipated benefits for vision health and learning; and how new mobile 3D technology is being used to screen for and improve early childhood vision with real results in the classroom.e
column7: See how virtual reality is fostering unanticipated benefits for vision health and learning
column8: See how new mobile 3D technology is being used to screen for and improve early childhood vision, leading to greater classroom success at early ages
column9: Learn the connections between a child's ability to read successfully and how our eyes work when viewing 3D virtual reality

column1: The Invisible Teacher: Empower Your Students
column5: Ricky Board (Hommel elementary)
column6: In this session I'd like to share my ideas and experience on how to become an invisible teachers.  By invisible teacher I mean how you can leverage the tools and technology in the classroom to empower student centered learning.  By using these tools affectively teachers can let the students take control of their learning.  Using these tools we can tap into children natural abilities and curiosities to drive their learning.  Learn how to use these tools to give students the power to create and explore new concepts.  Discover how to use technology to empower students through creativity.
column7: Learn what it means to step back as a teacher and let your students take control of their learning.
column8: Learn some practical ideas on how to implement these changes in your classroom.
column9: Learn some great technology tools that will get your students creating.

column1: Connect Industry Professionals to Every Classroom
column5: Christina Carrion (Nepris, Inc), Sabari Raja (Nepris, Inc)
column6: Are you a connectED educator with a vast network of fellow educators? What happens when you want to connect with industry professionals for Genius hour, PBL, and Choose2Matter? Does you network shrink? Come join us to discover how your Industry Professional Network can grow with a simple click of the button. Connecting with Industry Professionals has never been easier.
column7: Provide educational equity opportunities to students by connecting virtually to experts, discussing best practices and engaging learning spaces.
column8: Demonstrate opportunities for educators to use web tools to grow their Industry Professional Network.
column9: Describe learning spaces of the digital generation- videoconferencing, hands-on opportunities for learning and growing a professional learning network

column1: Don't Fear the Tweeter
column5: NICOLE Kraft (The Ohio State University)
column6: Social media is the main communication tool for students across age levels, but most teachers want them to check mobile devices and social media tools at the door, for fear they overwhelm learning goals. The key is engage students with social media, by utilizing it for research, learning and class engagement. This session will discuss how social media like Twitter, Instagram, Faceook & Pinterest are used for learning good, not evil, through established and cutting-edge techniques and tools.
column7: Audience members will discuss and see how students engage in social media and how it has become a cornerstone of their communication interactions.
column8: Audience members will learn and be engaged in hands-on social media techniques that can be utilized in the class to engage students in learning.
column9: Audience members will be engaged in a dialogue to develop additional techniques through hands-on learning for specialized topics.

column1: No More Yoda Heads: 3D Printing 4 Diverse Learners
column5: Tricia DeGiulio (Museum of Science), Lisa Wadors Verne (Benetech), Charlie Wapner (American Library Association), Colin  Rice (Rice Academy)
column6: Research suggests that 3D objects are important for learning and reinforcing complex spatial concepts that are difficult to convey or explore in any other way (e.g., cells and DNA). Although many schools have access to 3D printing technology, many machines are underutilized and used to print novelty items.  In this session, learn about new collaborations with libraries and museums to help support teachers in providing multi-modal access to complex STEM topics as well as utilizing student talent to create innovative learning tools.
column7: How to use 3D printed tactiles to increase multi-modal access to curriculum
column8: How to leverage libraries and museums as an addition education resource
column9: How to utilize the talents students in the school

column1: The Undercovered: a research about women in STEM
column5: Susanne Kehoane (IBM research), Nicola Palmarini (IBM Research)
column6: I am finalizing my research-book The Undercovered (Le Infiltrate in italian) which will be published firstly in Italy (and in Italian) on february 2015 by EGEA-Bocconi University Press. The book is a reportage about why only 12-14% of women access to STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) academic studies and following careers. The research aims to explore the reasons behind and also invistigate how the world would be if more women were in research and coding, given the tech world we are growing in. The format also includes a series of video interviews which will be cut in a 10 mins short movie.
column7: Learn why so few women access to STEM education and then succeed in STEM carreers.
column8: Learn how the world would be if more women would design the next tech services and products.
column9: Learn how to overcome the gender gap in STEM by those who succeed.

column1: How to Choose the right Entrepreneurship Education
column5: Isabel Gadala (Junto Studio)
column6: During this playground talk we will explore the different entrepreneurial options that exist outside of a traditional MBA or business degree. We will look in detail at programs such as Singularity University, Draper University of Heroes, Acton School of Business, Exosphere, among others and see what each one brings to the table and how they compare.
column7: What are the alternatives to business school that exist for students who want to be entrepreneurs?
column8: What questions you should be asking when considering an alternative program?
column9: How can you finance attending a short-term program?

column1: Human centered design between humans
column5: Carolina Rodr¡guez (Soulsight)
column6: Why do we keep talking about business models when we should be talking about relationship models? When we talk about Human Centered Design we should actually mean it. Putting people at the heart of our models should always be a priority. The basis of Human Centered Design is the creation of solutions that help satisfy unmet needs, but not every solution needs to be strictly profitable. During this session we will explore how designing for humans implies a different mindset. One that aims to truly empathize with what people aspire to, and building connections with what we also aspire to. It_s about what we have in common, not only about the business I want to get from you.
column7: Understand the value of relationship building as the key for successful business models
column8: Discover the power of empathy
column9: Inspire new entrepreneurs to make their ideas even more meaningful in today's context

column1: Self-Publishing for Everyone!
column5: Bea Leiderman (Goochland County Public Schools), Harry St.Ours (Montgomery College)
column6: You probably have a complete textbook worth of materials locked up in course lessons and syllabi, all ready to publish right now. Or perhaps you'd like to share those lecture notes and slideshow presentations that you_ve been working on for years. Or maybe you have the next Great American Novel languishing away in a drawer. So what are you waiting for?Learn how authors, educators and students design, compile and publish professional-level print and electronic books, for free or for profit. Take control of your authoring and publishing life, and join us in a fast-paced session where we explore the exciting world of Self-Publishing for Everyone!
column7: Learn how to leverage your expertise and share your passion by creating compelling, customized books without relying on impersonal publishers.
column8: Discover how to create new resources, remix existing and collaboratively-created content, and build a digital library that serves *your* unique needs.
column9: Explore how to find an audience beyond the classroom for your customized textbooks, professional publications, fiction, non-fiction and more.

column1: Student-Lead Solutions to Funding Innovation
column5: Megan Walsh (Schoola)
column6: SXSWedu is full of exciting ways to leverage the Maker Movement, gamification, SEL & more to ignite student engagement & improve outcomes. But innovative programs often have complex funding needs & require equally innovative approaches to budget management. Don_t let the unsexy task of accounting for equipment obsolescence & training curb your enthusiasm. Bring your budget challenges to our problem solving session - we_ll discuss how to use the power of the crowd to cement buy-in, rustle up resources & distribute responsibility to ensure long-term success. Learn how to connect student, parental, & community networks into a web of support under any innovative leap you endeavor to take.
column7: Student-Lead Campaigning - Ignite your most authentic spokesforce to improve their engagement & garner public support.
column8: Connecting Community - Coagulating local resources to improve the lifespan of your investment.
column9: Creative Reuse - Unlock the hidden value in existing resources.

column1: The STE(A)M Truck Story: Mobile Making
column5: Jason Martin (Community Guilds), Stephanie Wilson Itelman (Bellwether Education Partners)
column6: Mobile making is picking up speed across the country and the STE(A)M Truck is leading the way. As a young organization, Community Guilds redesigned an old truck and outfitted it with high- and low-tech tools. This mobile model can close the opportunity gap by bringing an engaging program focused on _making_ to youth who need this the most, while improving grit, self-confidence, and other non-cognitive factors that boost their odds of future success. Through a recent strategic planning process, they have worked to hone their plan for scaling their work in addition to transforming the way that teachers teach STEM. Come gain ideas for creating your own mobile makerspace.
column7: Learn tips for creating your own mobile makerspace
column8: Learn about the challenges and tradeoffs of developing plans to scale
column9: Learn about engaging both students AND teachers to transform teaching and learning

column1: How 2 escape the trap & put your life on fleek!!
column5: Herm Gilmore (SiC Studios )
column6: _In summary, the _conventional path_ has become so narrow, that it hardly even exists_. This quote is taken from one of my favorite articles that sums up the job market in 2013 called -  _Young People are Screwed_ Here_s how to survive_ on Pando (https://pando.com/2013/01/09/young-people-are-screwed-heres-how-to-survive/). The article is a little dated, and the bleak outlook has turned out to not be as bad as predicted (Thanks Obama :P). However, it still touched on some key advice that is good for anyone. In my pep talk, I try to connect with gen Y and point them in the right direction, while also revealing some tools that they didn_t even know they had.
column7: What are you worth? What to expect - Set a reasonable target an go for it!
column8: Who's looking for you? What companies to target? What can I do in the tech world?
column9: How to come up... How to focus... Eat, Sleep, Study, Rave, Repeat

column1: Level Up Your Classroom: Tools for Gamification
column5: Julie Gilberg (Art Institute of Pittsburgh, Online Division)
column6: Gamification is a powerful tool in an educator_s toolbox. Any person born after 1971 has grown up playing video games. As educators, we are better able to engage our students by using a language with which they are familiar. Games use tricks that are commonplace to educators; fostering competition, providing instantaneous feedback, and giving praise when students progress. Games can provide extrinsic motivation to help beginning students engage with course material.  Learning basic foundations skills, such as critiquing art, can seem like a chore to a beginning student. Gamification provides a way to help make practicing these basic skills enjoyable, and eventually intrinsically rewarding.
column7: This presentation will outline strategies developed in the online classroom for adding game elements to art foundations curriculum.
column8: Critique Kudos, a game that teaches students about critiques, will be presented. The game_s effect on learning outcomes will also be explored.
column9: Lastly, this presentation will review easy technologies, such as Twine, for interacting with students and building games around learning objectives.

column1: Minecraft in the Classroom - A Case Study
column5: Mark Nagurski (CultureTECH), Adam Clarke (WONDERQUEST)
column6: In March 2015, Northern Ireland became the first region in the world to introduce Minecraft as an educational tool into all of its post-primary schools - reaching a potential 50,000 young people annually. In this session the team behind the project will discuss how the programme has developed, the pros and cons of Minecraft as an educational tool, its efficacy and the challenges they've encountered. We'll also draw insight from content creator Adam Clarke - known to young children around the world as Wizard Keen - whose incredibly popular Minecraft-based YouTube series WONDERQUEST is engaging young audiences in core curriculum subjects through animation and gameplay.
column7: Attendees will gain insight into how Minecraft and other similar games can be used in education, including real-world insight from the project.
column8: Attendees will understand the likely challenges involved at a administrative level in developing a large-scale game-based education project
column9: Attendees will learn about adapting content from other media sources, and finding new uses for that content in the classroom.

column1: Real Science, Games, & You: Explore with NOVA Labs
column5: Ralph Bouquet (WGBH)
column6: NOVA Labs (pbs.org/nova/labs) is a new digital platform from the producers of PBS_s NOVA that engages teens and lifelong learners in games, interactives, and videos that foster authentic scientific exploration. In this talk, we will explore how scientists, game developers, and content producers work together to create an experience that challenges students to predict solar storms, build RNA molecules, explore the biodiversity of life on Earth, and more. We will also showcase the games and videos from the NOVA Labs and discuss how educators are using NOVA Labs as a learning and engagement tool in classrooms across the country.
column7: Explain how scientists, game developers, and content producers can work together to create science games that are engaging and impactful to learning
column8: Discuss how to take popular gaming mechanisms and genres and apply them to science games that teach content and skills
column9: Learn how educators are currently using science games like NOVA Labs as a learning and engagement tool in classrooms across the country

column1: Why Your Learning Game Will Probably Suck
column5: Dan  Norton (Filament Games)
column6: Not all learning games are created equally. Whether games fail commercially or due to design pitfalls, there_s no secret formula or cheat code that results in fame and fortune. Creating successful learning games is a daunting task that many have failed at. Most learning games are deficient as games, as learning tools, or both. During this session we_ll share with you how 10 years of experiences, including both successes and failures, have shaped our thinking about learning game design and development. We_ll also share some of the best practices we_ve learned along the way.
column7: Attendees will learn the pitfalls of learning game design
column8: Attendees will learn how to avoid missteps while creating real learning games
column9: Attendees will learn best practices for great learning game creation

column1: Data Quality: A Human Capital or Tech Challenge?
column5: Jim McGlynn (Public Consulting Group), Dr. Bari Erlichson (New Jersey State Department of Education)
column6: Big Data Initiatives invite states to think holistically about the impact of data on policy, programs, and instructional practice. By focusing on investments in _people_ as much as _technology_ in a recent big data initiative, the NJ Department of Education is successfully harnessing and using data more effectively. Informed by the lessons learned from the expansive New Jersey SMART initiative, this session will outline implementation guidelines that participants can take back and apply to their respective states.
column7: Understand Big Data from a holistic lens which considers both the Human Capital and Technology sides of the equation.
column8: Learn implementation best practices to be used for large technology projects in the education industry.
column9: Understand how to harness and use data in a way that will have the greatest impact on policy, programs, and instructional practices.

column1: Learning in the Third Dimension
column5: John LaRose (3Doodler), Daniel Cowen (3Doodler)
column6: When the 3Doodler first launched, we were focused on our Kickstarter community and early adopters; education was not, at that time, a big part of our day-to-day. But educators from all around the world sought us out and began telling us incredible stories about how they used the 3Doodler in the classroom.In this talk, we_ll tell the story of the inspiring educators who are using our handheld 3D-printing pen to add new dimensions to their teaching, including:- bridging the gender gap in STEM subjects;- engaging visual learners;- fostering development of computational thinking without a computer; and- intuitive, hands-on differentiated teaching in physics and geometry.
column7: Learn strategies to bridge the gender gap and allow differentiated learning that appeals to both visual and kinaesthetic learners.
column8: Learn how to drive highly engaged, intuitive understanding of STEM subjects such as physics, engineering, and geometry.
column9: Learn how to engage with other educators around the globe who have added a new dimension to their teaching!

column1: Mind the Gadget Gap: Browser-based robotics
column5: Bruno Panara (Google), Marten  van Wezel (Google)
column6: Chrogramming is an offline app for programming using a basic Chrome browser. Using Blockly or JavaScript code and colorful tutorials to guide students to program instructions, the tool then either sends the commands to actual robots, or simulates them with the Turtle Graphics Viewer. The Chrogramming creators will walk you through typical EDU use cases in a short Playground session, illustrating CS Education via Chromebooks in spite of spotty Wifi and limited hardware resources.
column7: Successfully access, create and launch Blockly programs to move robots around
column8: Demonstrate robot pairing process using Bluetooth technology; run programs for the robot to follow with and without internet access.
column9: Identify educational resources, example projects, tutorial creation, additional  input/output modules and community engagement options online.

column1: Beyond the Classroom: Reality of Digital Tech
column5: Dave Saltmarsh (JAMF Software), Candace Salmon-Hosey (Rowan-Salisbury School System)
column6: As technology becomes more ingrained in our everyday lives, classrooms that reflect this trend have become key to educating students and maximizing student learning both in and out of the classroom. But with limited budgets and tools to create and implement a truly rich, interactive and collaborative learning experience, rolling out programs that utilize new technologies can be difficult.  In this session, learn first hand the successes and struggles districts and educators have faced when implementing and managing some of the most popular initiatives, such as an iPad 1:1 program, as well as other such programs that enable unique learning environments to prepare students for the world today.
column7: Participants will learn how state of the art classrooms are utilizing technology to create a different learning experience for students.
column8: Attendees will learn about successes and struggles of implementing programs, such as a iPad 1:1 program, from educators with first hand experience.
column9: Understand different factors for educators to consider when deciding what types of programs to implement and roll out in the classroom.

column1: Coding _ It_s Elementary!
column5: Breigh Rhodes (Zachary Schools), Stephan Turnipseed (LEGO Education)
column6: Coding isn_t just a subject that helps students learn STEM; it_s a language that imparts valuable life skills. From teaching logical reasoning, sequencing and modeling to honing analytical skills, many are pushing for coding curriculum to be implemented in schools across the country to help shape tomorrow_s creative problems and help fill jobs of the future. Access to computer science and engineering should start at a young age, while the playing field is still level. This Playground Talk will explore the use of coding in the classroom and how it can be used to inspire creative thinking and practical skills among students of all ages.
column7: See how easily coding and STEM can be integrated into all levels of curriculum.
column8: Learn real-world tips for integrating coding and hands-on STEM to create a deep learning experience.
column9: Understand how coding drives 21st century skill development.

column1: Coding _ It_s Elementary!
column5: Domino Eddy (Pioneer Crossing Elementary), Angela (Allen) Matthews (Manor ISD)
column6: Coding isn_t just a subject that helps student learn STEM; it_s a language that imparts valuable life skills. From teaching logical reasoning, sequencing and modeling to honing analytical skills, many are pushing for coding curriculum to be implemented in schools across the country to help shape tomorrow_s creative problems and help fill jobs of the future. Access to computer science and engineering should start at a young age, while the playing field is still level. This Playground Talk will explore the use of coding in the classroom and how it can be used to inspire creative thinking and practical skills among students of all ages.
column7: See how easily coding and STEM can be integrated into all levels of curriculum
column8: Learn real-world tips for integrating coding and hands-on STEM to create a deep learning experience
column9: Understand how coding drives 21st century skill development

column1: Digital Literacy: A Blended / Competency Approach
column5: Guy Ballard (NTHS 219), Philip Lacey (NTHS 219)
column6: It is often assumed today_s students are skilled in technology. But, the majority of students do not enter high school prepared to learn and succeed in a 21st century learning environment. How can schools ensure students have mastered the necessary skills to be digitally literate and thrive in a 1:1 district? Learn how we developed a blended, competency-based Digital Literacy Program using ready made content (from Atomic Learning) to provide our incoming freshman with a common knowledge base to address this concern and help them succeed in a tech rich environment.
column7: Participants will gain an understanding of how and why to implement blended programs in a traditional setting to increase options for students.
column8: Participants will have the opportunity to view the use of blended and competency-based learning to address digital literacy.
column9: Participants will gain understanding of and strategies for developing a Digital Literacy Program curriculum using existing resources.

column1: Enhancing Visual Literacy Through Mobile Animation
column5: Joseph Summerhays (Animation Chefs), Ben Summerhays (Animation Chefs)
column6: Explore one of the oldest forms of filmmaking remade for tablet-based media literacy: learn how to put the art of stop motion animation to use in the classroom with the iPad.Everyone (especially children) must increase their visual and media literacy in our media saturated world. Educators in math, writing, reading, science, and the arts will witness the ease with which an audience-generated stop motion animation can come to life. This entertaining presentation will demonstrate how straight forward digital storytelling with tablets can be.Participants will walk away knowing how to tap into students_ minds and enthusiasm via digital storytelling on mobile apps.
column7: To show how producing a mobile device-based stop motion film project can cross over into all academic subject areas.
column8: To wow the audience with the ease, speed and efficiency of working with the media creation shortcuts and methods demonstrated by the Animation Chefs.
column9: To demonstrate how off-the-shelf apps can be orchestrated to invent meaning with a blend of handmade meets hi-tech workflow.

column1: Facilitating Cool Student-Led Online Projects
column5: Carlos Cuadra (Versal), Allison Wagda (Versal)
column6: It's no secret that guiding a student on a path to self-driven discovery is one of the more powerful ways to ensure subject-area mastery. When a person has an "ah ha" moment - the moment where dots connect and the brain lights up - information tends to stick.Take this sense of discovery and adventure to a new level. Challenge students to research a topic on their own (or in teams), and then ask them to take responsibility for teaching that concept to other students.Collaborative and interactive creation tools like Versal are ideal for projects. We'll show how teachers are outlining online lessons and sending students off on a journey of creativity, discovery and responsibility.
column7: Learn best practices for creating student-led teaching projects, balancing structure with the freedom to be creative.
column8: Learn how online tools can offer students the ability to learn how to formulate concepts with greater dimension/interactivity vs. a flat presentation.
column9: Learn ways students can leverage the Web to research and curate reliable, interesting content to back up a thesis.

column1: Flipped Teacher Driven Professional Learning
column5: Sarah Ledon (Nevada Virtual Academy)
column6: A teacher driven professional learning approach builds capacity and sustainability within schools.  A flipped learning platform invites a variety of educator groupings to collaborate and plan across grade and content areas.  The research base for the flipped professional learning centers on the Plan-Do-Study-Act model for teacher driven learning.
