By empowering teacher leaders to lead professional learning through the model, teachers have the resources, time, and support to implement sustainable change in classrooms and schools.
column7: Participants will learn how to effectively initiate a teacher driven professional learning model within a school or district.
column8: Participants will learn how to determine professional learning topics and how to replicate the Plan-Do-Study-Act model of professional development.
column9: Participants will identify key components to build teacher driven professional learning and steps for implementation.

column1: Go Bananas with Music Tinkering in the Classroom
column5: Mitch Chaiet (Dub Academy), Laurie Lyons (Dub Academy)
column6: Make computer science and engineering fun! Do away wtechnologyith long, boring talks about integers and arrays and give kids the hands-on electronics experience they deserve. By combining the inherent fun of making and tinkering with a popular topic most kids are fluent with _  electronic dance music _ coding comes easy and electronics become cool. Let Dub Academy show you the successes we_ve had with our hands on _Music Modding_ STEAM curriculum, and how you can incorporate music and tinkering into your own classroom.
column7: To explore the benefits of tinkering for children and to teach educators how to integrate tinkering into their lessons in a fun and engaging way.
column8: To show that topics that are perceived as dry or boring can be taught through fun and engaging mediums and give examples of how we have done so.
column9: To illustrate that computers are more than 1s & 0s and that applying DIY, artistic mindsets to coding and engineering can increase student engagement.

column1: Growing Minds & Food in Milwaukee Public School
column5: MPS student MPS Student (Milwaukee Public Schools), Matt Ray (Fernwood Montessori School)
column6: During this session, learn about (1) what it takes for an inner-city public school district to develop a true hands-on, experiential STEM education program for students, and (2) the impact urban farming can have on student learning and achievement. Through video and an in-person presentation by a teacher and student team from Milwaukee Public Schools (MPS), participants will hear about how the Urban Schools Aquaponics (USA) Initiative has helped to engage a diverse student population in STEM and 21st Century learning, as well as about how others might be able to replicate similar initiatives.
column7: Understand what aquaponics is and how it can be applied to a classroom setting
column8: Understand and appreciate the learning benefits of an urban farming program
column9: Learn about what it takes to start an urban farming program, including public/private partnerships, and how to replicate in other school settings

column1: Hello Texas. Hello California. Hello World.
column5: Josh Davis (Downey Unified School District), Jennifer Mitchell (Lamar Consolidated ISD)
column6: As a teacher, how do you give your students authentic experience in practicing 21st century skills?  Join us as we take a look at how 2 teachers embraced this challenge and ran with it!  Using Skype and OneNote to facilitate knowledge construction and communication between the classrooms, these teachers and their students went on a journey of becoming true 21st century learners.
column7: Examine how digital collaboration creates true 21st century learners
column8: Gain an understanding of how Skype can be used to facilitate communication and collaboration between classes across the country and around the world
column9: Gain an understanding of how OneNote can be used to create collaborative spaces

column1: How Learning Works with Quick Exercise
column5: Dav Clark (Berkeley Institute for Data Science (BIDS)), Yoshi A. Okamoto (SHO-zemi Innovation Ventures)
column6: SHO-zemi has utilized a method unusual in Japan which they've coined Quick Exercises. This internally developed and refined method has enabled SHO-zemi teachers to train the "skill of understanding," by taking students along a guided path where they get to see clearly what it is like to understand or not understand.Berkeley Institute for Data Science (BIDS) worked with SHO-zemi to identify a particularly rich opportunity at the intensive study camp for five hundred 9th graders for high impact data collection with mobile tablets, which allowed for fine-grained assessment of a student_s experience throughout the day.We'd like to share a result of experience sampling and our insights.
column7: Cognitive measures, and measures of student mood and emotional state throughout the day will provide an accurate way to predict student performance.
column8: Quick Exercises may train executive function by providing appropriate challenges for students to practice maintaining focus and thinking quickly.
column9: There are ways to train the skill of understanding by taking students along a guided path where they get to see clearly what it is like to understand.

column1: How moving from STEM to STEAM will save the world.
column5: anah sikorsky (Ann Richards School for Young Women Leaders), kristina waugh (Ann Richards School for Young Women Leaders)
column6: We believe our girls will change the world and they believe it, too. We_ll share why a leading school in STEM education is purposefully adding the Arts into our school-wide curriculum. As an all-girls public school we recognize the need for women in STEM fields and will share how by combining the Arts with problem solving we_re developing young women leaders who have the needed mindsets to change their world.
column7: Explore why integrating the Arts into STEM is imperative to producing ethically minded scientist and engineers.
column8: Share example projects that allow students to develop the mindset of an innovator by combining the Arts with the more analytical aspects of STEM.
column9: Examine how combining the Arts with STEM will allow students to understand not just the "how" but also to question the "why" behind their decisions.

column1: Innovations for a Million Students
column5: Dave Ferrero  (Vulcan Inc / Paul G. Allen Family Foundation)
column6: The Allen Distinguished Educator awards aims to transform the teaching of engineering, entrepreneurship, and computer science in the U.S. and reach a million students over the next three years. To do that, the program will highlight the work of innovative teachers and using their examples to encourage and enable other educators to adopt their practices. Learn from how we put together this program and the lessons from the first groups of Allen Distinguished Educators, which was inspired by and funded by entrepreneur and philanthropist Paul G. Allen.
column7: How to empower teachers ready to try new things.
column8: How to reach educators and parents curious about new approaches.
column9: How to inspire teachers and parents who have yet to experience the power of pioneering approaches.

column1: Interdisciplinary Concepts + Tech in Design School
column5: Margarita Benitez (University of Akron), Markus Vogl (University of Akron)
column6: Teaching design has been fueled by technological changes and although critical design thinking has been fostered, interdisciplinary, boundary-breaking approaches between design, technology and art have been slow to penetrate current curriculum. Innovation occurs at the intersection of disciplines and we are committed to bringing this into our classroom via our teaching. This playground talk shares our interdisciplinary philosophies of teaching in respective design schools (Fashion Design and Graphic Design) and how we integrate these frameworks, concepts, and technologies into our coursework.
column7: Making better designers by exploring technologies initially outside of their comfort zones and respective disciplines.
column8: Integrating interdisciplinary approaches into student's design work.
column9: Augmenting critical thinking by integrating interdisciplinary concepts, vocabulary, and processes.

column1: Made by Girls: Building Tech Confidence in Girls
column5: Peggy  Lee (Digital Media Academy), Shane White (Digital Media Academy)
column6: This year at DMA, we developed a Girls in Tech initiative called Made By Girls. The first step was to create a girls-only version of our Introduction to Programming with Java course. We ran Made by Girls at 5 locations throughout the nation and Canada, led by female instructors and TAs committed to serving as Role Models. We dedicated ourselves to changing the culture of CS in our classrooms to combat 3 large barriers 1) negative stereotypes, 2) lack of role models, 3) self doubt and isolation. We also wondered what would happen if we implemented these changes in our co-ed course as well. Come see examples of the tools we used and let us share what we found.
column7: Communicate better practices for engaging girls in underrepresented subjects.
column8: Share findings on how those better practices can be applied to all students.
column9: Discuss the experiences of our female leadership in the classroom - the impact of being a role model.

column1: Mentor Up: Intergenerational Volunteerism
column5: Alicia Wallace (AARP Foundation)
column6: Everyone has benefited from the guidance, nurturing and mentoring from an older adult in their life.  We want to provide you with the chance to do the same for them! Mentor Up, an AARP Foundation program, focuses on intergenerational volunteering. Our aim is to provide young adults with opportunities to help older adults stay connected and adjust to the many challenges they face in today_s changing world. Mentor Up frequently works with other organizations rooted in service and driven by social missions. Together, we are able to bring new skills, companionship and quality time to the generation that paved the way.
column7: Participants will learn about existing ways youth can volunteer time to prevent social isolation by keeping seniors connected
column8: Participants will learn about the grant, scholarship and reward opportunities Mentor Up can offer youth organizations
column9: Participants will hear inspiring stories about how intergenerational volunteerism is rewarding for all involved

column1: Online Resources & Data-Based Lesson Planning
column5: Leti Sandoval (Region 18 Education Service Center), Nicole Dragisic (Region 18 Education Service Center)
column6: There are a wealth of online resources available for instructors to build into their lessons. Selecting strategies and resources that correctly align to the rigor and content of your student objectives, historical student needs (identified using data), and that are proven by research can be a daunting task. In this session you will learn the best sources for conscientious and reliable resources that fit the needs of your students. We will investigate strategies for using this method for both proactive and reactive student interventions.Takeaway digital resources will be provided with instructions on how to pull the reports needed from most major educational data management systems.
column7: Analyze data to proactively or reactively adjust lessons to better fit student needs using online resources.
column8: Recognize where to locate quality instructional resources and strategies online.
column9: Justify the value of instructional strategies or resources found online and align them directly to student needs.

column1: Parenting for Powerful Learning
column5: Bonnie Lathram (Getting Smart), Tom  Vander Ark (Getting Smart)
column6: What happens when you ask parents to describe the powerful learning experiences they want for their kids? They want student-centered, highly-engaged learning. Come ready to learn more about student-centered learning & ready to explore ideas for experiences that promote it. Are you a parent? Leave inspired and armed with resources for becoming a Smart Parent who knows how to create and advocate for powerful learning! Are you creating learning opportunities for kids? Find out what families want!
column7: Describe how to recognize and create powerful, student-centered learning at home and at school.
column8: Learn how to evaluate _student-centeredness_ by taking a trip around the SxSWedu Playground.
column9: Discuss ways in which parents, students and teachers can come together to create more powerful, student-centered learning opportunities.

column1: Robots are not scary! Hands-on robots for everyone
column5: Beth Cohen (Dakota Valley Elementary School), Christie Veitch (Modular Robotics)
column6: Cubelets are a fast and easy way to inspire students to become better thinkers.  At Modular Robotics we work with students and educators all over the world harnessing that fun, engagement, and immediate feedback students find in Cubelets to learn and apply 21st century skills. This session will demonstrate how to use robots to teach everything from literacy to life science and from engineering to art. We will present hands-on means of implementing Cubelets to teach literacy, life-science, computational thinking, design thinking, and more! We'll share methods of creating student-centered learning with hands-on technology, and differentiated learning environments that include fun.
column7: Demonstrate the ease and fun of Cubelets to educators so that adding robotics is "not scary!" for teachers and instructors, regardless of background
column8: Presenting concrete examples of ways to teach diverse topics with hands-on robotics and Cubelets, as well as ways to teach cross-curricularly
column9: Share results including student engagement, learning of concepts, and demonstrable 21st century skills

column1: School Projects with Arduino Brains
column5: Andy Forest (STEAMLabs)
column6: Learn how STEAMLabs has brought high tech maker education into the classroom by having students design a museum exhibit to teach about the power system. The students used 21st century skills to create a project combining Arduino coding on a Particle board, 3D printing, web design and electronics.The model downloads live xml power production data and visualizes the mix from the different sources over time with a 3D-printed LED display. A web interface allows the visitor to update the LEDs to view how the mix changes over time.By building this model and using it to teach adults and kids about the power system, the kids truly became confident experts on this topic.
column7: See how the standard curriculum can be taught with 21st century methods of creativity, innovation, self-directed and project-based learning.
column8: Learn how to integrate maker technologies such as robotics, 3D printing and electronics into the classroom.
column9: Get tips on finding the tech experts you need to assist you in the classroom.

column1: The Secrests of the Top Korean EdTech Teachers
column5: Jina Yun (Classting)
column6: South Korea is well recognized and praised for its Education and technology; however, on the other hand, the hierarchical structure and intense competition in Education have been criticized for discouraging creativity and innovation. Many teachers in EdTech act as revolutionary leaders and work in their own way to create a better, enjoyable environment for learning. From kindergarten to highschool (and colleges), find out how the Korean teachers adopt various teaching strategies using Classting to provide better learning experience to every student.
column7: Learn how the Korean teachers lead innovation in education
column8: Explore strategies that create enjoyable learning experience
column9: Effective tools used by Korean EdTech teachers

column1: Using 360§ Spherical Video as a Teaching Tool
column5: Bethanne Tobey (North Carolina State University), Mike Cuales (North Carolina State University)
column6: Educators, researchers and design teams continue to look for innovative solutions to better support lab-based and field-based instruction in online learning environments. The emergence of interactive 360§ video capture and virtual reality technologies (i.e. Google cardboard) have provided new approaches for delivering instruction. Students can observe (visually and aurally) an environment while retaining the ability to look around in any direction on a variety of devices.This session provides a demonstration of a virtual reality field-based simulation. We will share our lessons learned on these projects and involve participants in the ongoing conversation of virtual reality in education.
column7: Describe 360§ video capture and virtual reality technologies and its potential impact and drawbacks for the delivery of instructional.
column8: Observe the workflow used in field-based instructional scenarios that incorporate 360§ video capture and virtual reality technology.
column9: Discuss different applications and potential for the use of 360§ video and virtual reality technologies for lab-based and field-based instruction.

column1: Grassroots Guide to Crafting a 21st Century School
column5: Kellie Marino (Travis Heights Elementary), Erika Nu¤ez (Travis Heights Elementary)
column6: In 2011, Educators and Parents of Travis Heights Elementary in Austin, TX embarked on a journey to transform their district managed public school into a campus-based, community-led, in-district charter. Throughout these changes, our school maintains it's diverse population standing as a Title 1, public campus. Join us as we guide you through our grassroots movement to craft a 21st Century school. We will guide you on how to spark interest in the community, motivate stakeholders, develop a framework, and the messy process of embracing change while planning for the future.
column7: I can describe how to use parent groups and teacher leaders to spark interest in the community for a new type of school.
column8: I can understand the process of research and ideation for crafting a 21st century community school within a district.
column9: I can motivate educators through professional development and modeling to embrace new freedoms in order to affect change in the school.

column1: Choose Your Own Adventure: Guided Online Support
column5: Sally Amen (The University of Texas at Austin), Kristin Harvey (The University of Texas at Austin)
column6: There are an abundance of online learning resources available but most are either disorganized lists of topics or prescribed sequences of content. We_ve created a resource platform that provides a scaffolded framework guiding users to tailored content and tutorial videos. Educators from all areas can re-think what online learning looks like, without advanced programming skills or access to specialized course platforms. We will discuss the simple keys to creating an open source site that guides students to the specific information they want and need.
column7: Consider new ways to engage students online by determining what your users will want out of your site.
column8: Envision how to create a _choose your own adventure_ site for your discipline by brainstorming scaffolded questions to guide users.
column9: Learn how to build a site with an open source website creation tool without needing a programmer or restrictive and potentially expensive platforms.

column1: Connecting Communities: Beyond Social Networking
column5: Melissa Ingber (Stevens Initiative, The Aspen Institute), Francesca Carpenter (Qatar Foundation International)
column6: Do you want to expand access to K-16 global education and improve students_ global competencies?  Have you considered a virtual exchange that connects your classroom to others around the world? Not sure what a virtual exchange is or why it is important? Interested in learning more about how others have successfully run synchronous exchanges across multiple time differences? Hear from practitioners and supporters as they lead an interactive session that includes participants from classes or programs using virtual exchange.  Led by staff from the Qatar Foundation International and the Stevens Initiative of The Aspen Institute.
column7: Explore the benefits and challenges of conducting a virtual exchange, including technological, psychological and logistical.
column8: Learn best methods in virtual exchange and how to engage with educators around the world looking to connect with classrooms in the US by participating
column9: Learn about the Stevens Initiative Award Competition and how your organization can apply for a grant to conduct virtual exchange programs.

column1: Creating Spaces to Foster Innovation
column5: Tricia Edwards (Smithsonian's Lemelson Center for the Study of Invention and Innovation)
column6: Makerspaces are all the rage right now. But how do you design a space that_s both functional and inspiring? This session focuses on the elements of a successful maker environment: one that fosters creativity and innovation while also being practical for those working in and managing the space. The speaker will share findings from research conducted by the Smithsonian_s Lemelson Center for the Study of Invention and Innovation on innovative environments, and show how these ideas can play out in a classroom, library, museum or other educational context.
column7: Participants will understand what makerspaces are and the benefits of creating a space to foster innovative activity.
column8: Participants will gain an understanding of the elements that go into a successful "space of innovation."
column9: Participants will gain an understanding of how to apply these elements to create a functional space.

column1: StudyOnBoard
column5: Page Heller (StudyOnBoard)
column6: Retention of students in the STEAM subjects (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Mathematics) is low in the United States. Professors in higher education and Teachers in K-12 are actively looking for ways to keep students in their disciplines. Today, research has shown a strong correlation between student interaction when studying outside the classroom and their grades. I believe we can improve retention if students perform better in the classroom. They will perform better if they have a convenient way to study wit their friends. This session discusses a product that is a convenient online whiteboard for students to use in studying with their friends.
column7: Literature review on student study habits.
column8: Learn the correlation between student peer interaction and performance in the classroom.
column9: Learn of a new platform making it convenient for students to study together.

column1: Motivate!  Incentivize!  Reward!  PBIS!
column5: Cynthia  Harrington (Team(You))
column6: What if all your students were engaged  - in themselves, their classmates, their environment?  What if they were intrinsically motivated to participate and excited to do so?  What if a brain-science methodology could help support them and diminish teacher time in managing the classroom?  Positive Behavior Supports are not new to the classroom -  what is new is how to make the supports fun and the data collection automatic.
column7: Teachers and principals will learn the role of feedback as revealed in recent neuroscience studies
column8: Participants will take away five proactive behavioral supports that prevent interventions
column9: Engagement tools integrate with LMS and discipline foundations; learn how the latest technology makes this possible

column1: Dogs Matter!
column5: Sally Bair (Sally Bair Solutions)
column6: This session will share some of the key roles dogs can play in our lives in hopes of expanding the amount of dogs and their handlers who participate in these roles locally, nationally and globally.
column7: List roles dogs successfully play in human lives.
column8: Repeat an example of how dogs can successfully interact with humans.
column9: Recall resources to use to become trained team.

column1: The Rankers on College Rankings: Why We Do It
column5: Jordan Matsudaira (Cornell University), Rob Franek (The Princeton Review), Kim Clark (Money Magazine), Katie Bardaro (PayScale)
column6: Love them or hate them, college rankings are here to stay. This panel of college rankers will address various criticisms of the rankings, talk about how they differ, and speak to how they can be used as a valuable tool for prospective students (and their parents). We'll also talk about the scaled-back effort around the Dept. of Education's Postsecondary Institution Ratings System (PIRS) with the former Chief Economist of Obama's Council of Economic Advisers -- why the federal government thought holding colleges accountable for outcomes was important and why the strategy shifted.
column7: Inside look at the college rankings
column8: How the college rankings differ and why
column9: Gain some perspective on federal college ratings shift

column1: Education Politics in the 2016 Election
column5: Campbell Brown (The Seventy Four)
column6: Education Politics in the 2016 Presidential Election would consist of a panel of high profile political reporters discussing the biggest K-12 education issues facing America _ and how to make this more of a focus of the 2016 election cycle. Despite education consistently rating in polls as a top tier issue by voters, education has received limited attention during recent election cycles. This campaign has the potential to break the mold due to differences over Common Core among Republicans; Obama's legacy and Race to the Top; Jeb Bush's focus on education; and some candidates calling for abolishment of Dept. of Education.
column7: Learn how America's education policies might shape the next presidential election
column8: Gain insight on the candidates' position on K-12 education
column9: Top five education issues voters need to know about

column1: K-12 Education Policy: New ESSA Enables PL + CBE
column5: Paul Leather (New Hampshire Department of Education), Lillian Pace (KnoweldgeWorks), Susan Patrick (iNACOL)
column6: The new Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) gives states increased flexibility. This represents a marked shift in federal control to states, presenting state and local stakeholders with an important opportunity to redefine what student success looks like and the goals of our nation_s education system.  This session will identify key opportunities within the Every Student Succeeds Act for new systems of assessments and accountability that support personalized learning (PL) and competency-based education (CBE). Panelists will focus specifically on critical next steps for state and local leaders as well as strategies for maintaining the law_s fundamental commitment to equity for all students.
column7: Understand ESEA Reauthorization and next steps;
column8: Identify key opportunities for systemic change, closing achievement gaps and ensuring equity;
column9: Understand innovative assessments pilot in new law in support of student success, personalized learning and competency-based education systems.

column1: Linking Dropout Rates to Economic Recovery
column5: Greg Vaughn (Texas Association of Workforce Boards), Dan Huberty (Texas House of Representatives), Marie DeMego (Graduation Alliance), Drew Scheberle (Austin Chamber of Commerce)
column6: Initiatives to increase graduation are underway nationwide, but students who have dropped out are still being left behind. The window for earning a diploma has closed on tens of millions of Americans who have _aged-out,_ leaving them underprepared for the demands of the workforce and often bound in poverty. It_s not just a social issue; these underserved populations represent a cost totaling trillions in the coming decades. We can curb that trend with smart, cost-effective workforce development initiatives, but we have to act now. We_ll discuss innovative ideas that reengage adult students, reactivate their potential, and prevent them from being left behind in the 21st century economy.
column7: Understand the economic impact of working-age adults without a high school diploma
column8: Relate to the challenges of historic efforts to reengage working-age adults
column9: Learn about the early successes of new public and private initiatives targeting this population

column1: The Future of Socioeconomic School Integration
column5: Richard Kahlenberg (The Century Foundation), John King (US Department of Education), Christopher Suarez (Williams & Connolly LLP), Nikole Hannah Jones (New York Times Magazine)
column6: This panel will address future efforts to encourage socioeconomic equality in schools by addressing how to move toward a world in which no child will attend a school of high poverty--schools in which more than 50% of the students are poor. The panel will discuss recent efforts to encourage school integration nationwide by creating magnet schools, adopting inter-district transfer programs, and other district-wide strategies for achieving socioeconomic diversity. The panel will address possible policy solutions for the future that could be implemented at either the federal or state level to improve the economic and racial diversity of schools.
column7: Understand the current problem and reality attached to economic isolation in schools, and how this impacts meaningful education reform.
column8: Understand creative efforts that districts and states have employed to address socioeconomic school segregation, and the origin of such efforts.
column9: Learn about new ways to encourage socioeconomic school integration so that it can be a meaningful tool for reform at the state and national levels.

column1: Is Education Policy Stifling Digital Innovation?
column5: Bob Wise (Alliance for Excellent Education ), Dallas Dance (Baltimore County Public Schools), Heath Morrison (McGraw Hill Education), Caitlin Emma (Politico)
column6: As digital innovation and technology continues to reshape the classroom and unlock possibilities for teachers and students, we need policies that can support and accelerate that innovation toward improving student outcomes. What those policies should look like _ and the ultimate goals of the policy environment overall _ continues to be the sticking point:  from tackling funding to student and teacher assessment to making decisions about technology buying and implementation. Can we agree on fundamental education technology policy objectives? And can we find the right ways to get there quickly?
column7: The ways state governments can better address funding challenges so schools can both obtain and then implement technology
column8: How educators, technology companies and policy-makers can work together to protect student privacy and data
column9: What we can learn from policies that work in the U.S. and around the world

column1: The Common Core: Defend, Bury or Transform?
column5: John Katzman (Noodle), Valerie Strauss (Washington Post), Michael Petrilli (Thomas B. Fordham Institute)
column6: For over twenty five years, the US has made academic standards a key component of K-12 reform, and is now five years into a multi-billion dollar effort to revamp K-12 learning through the Common Core. However, that effort is under attack from the left and right, and faces a new challenge in the form of parental opt-outs from testing. Join us for a debate about whether to defend the Common Core, bury it, or transform it into something better.
column7: Does Common Core narrow curricula, hinder individualized learning, infantilize teachers, and suck the joy from learning?
column8: Does Common Core set needed evidence-based standards for what students should know to succeed in college and the workforce?
column9: Is Common Core the basis of something good that we should transform into something better?

column1: Developing and Charting the California Way
column5: Todd Groves (West Contra Costa Unified School District), David Rattray (Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce), Linda Darling-Hammond (Learning Policy Institute), Tom Torlakson (California Department of Education)
column6: California has built broad support for educational changes that have sparked divisive battles in other states. The _California Way_ involves stakeholder alignment that starts with the highest levels of state government and includes deep work with innovative labor-management partnerships. The panel will analyze the inter-relationships between the _what_ of CA_s approach (new standards, new funding models, new accountability system) and the _how_ of California_s work (innovative team-based, collaborative models). Panelists will provide first-hand insight into the exciting potential and successes to date, as well as the sometimes difficult struggles encountered by California.
column7: Understand the breadth of change underway in California with new standards, funding models, and continuous improvement systems
column8: Gain appreciation for the linkage between the content and process of change
column9: Reflect on the national and other state significance of the California experience

column1: Straight Talk from Teachers on EdTech Policy
column5: Matt Worthington (KIPP Austin), Kerry Gallagher (St John's Preparatory School), Beverly Perdue (Former Governor of North Carolina)
column6: Policymakers can have a big impact on what happens in the classroom_both good and bad, if you ask educators. Today, there's a lot of exciting innovation taking place in classrooms across the county. And teachers and principals are at the crux of it. So how can policy support or hinder innovation? Join a former governor for a frank conversation with administrators and teachers about ed tech policy issues of the day. From data privacy to Bring Your Own Device models to broadband access, savvy, policy-smart educators will share their perspective on policy discussions and give real world insights on how federal and state policy impact their work.
column7: Understand what ed tech issues are being debated at the local, state, and federal level.
column8: Get the pros and cons on ed tech policies being considered, from the perspective of practicing educators.
column9: Find out how recent and forthcoming changes to state and federal education laws will shape and change the classroom.

column1: Creativity and the Arts as a Catalyst for Change
column5: Sherri  Kushner (Chute Middle School), Malissa  Shriver (Turnaround Arts: California), Robert Hoang (Hayward Unified School District)
column6: After years of being relegated to _nice to have_ status, the arts are now recognized as both a vital component of a complete education and a strategic tool for targeting a wide range of school challenges and opportunities. In this session, hear examples of how the arts are having an impact on school-wide issues like attendance and parent engagement, as well as the issues students face like building self-confidence and addressing conflict. In small groups, explore the potential barriers and key success factors to art integration while participating in a hands-on art activity that can be replicated at your school.
column7: Explore the role creativity and the arts can play as a catalyst for change.
column8: Hear examples of best practices and success stories from expert teachers.
column9: Experience a cross-curricular, multi-age art lesson in action and learn how to implement it with your students and colleagues.

column1: What is M.O.L.I.E.
column5: Christopher Irvin  (Michigan State University, IT Services Teaching and Learning Technology), Glenn Stutzky (Michigan State University, School of Social Work), Keesa Johnson (Michigan State University, IT Services Teaching and Learning Technology)
column6: M.O.L.I.E. (Multimedia Online Learning Immersive Experience)/_mal,lee/ Noun, Singular. An innovative pedagogical approach that embeds high quality academic content in a highly polished interactive environment. It combines story telling, social media, gaming, film making, and our constant blood lust for all things technological and pop culture. Verb, Singular. To engage the larger academic community to go beyond what's already been done, exploring and experimenting with new learning approaches where students are co-educators and co-learners.
column7: What a M.O.L.I.E. is and learning how it came into existence by exploring the individual parts that make up the very first M.O.L.I.E.
column8: What it takes to create your own M.O.L.I.E. by collaborating with others to form your own collective and produce its unique sound.
column9: Inspiration to take the first step towards creating a M.O.L.I.E.

column1: Making Better Teacher Data Dashboards
column5: Kevin Miklasz (BrainPOP), Charlotte Duncan (Learning Games Network)
column6: Many current educational data dashboards have failed to capture teacher needs and gain widespread use in the classroom. At the same time, embedded assessment and data capture from educational games and other complex tools is on the rise. As more data becomes available, we need to get better at making sense of it, and that sense-making activity needs to be informed by teachers. But it_s not exactly clear what issues data dashboards should solve, and subsequently, what data and design will help solve those issues. We will use a group brainstorming activity to generate teacher-informed design prompts, which our respective teams will then take into consideration in the design of our dashboards.
column7: Both participants and presenters will develop a collective understanding about some of the unique challenges involved in designing data dashboards.
column8: Participants will gain some understanding of how to engage in design thinking practices to solve problems.
column9: Participants will understand the complex range of products, data, and needs of organizations that are designing next generation learning products.

column1: Privacy Flash Forward: Today_s Students Tomorrow
column5: Dalia Topelson Ritvo (Berkman Center for Internet & Society), Paulina Haduong  (Berkman Center for Internet & Society), Leah Plunkett (UNH School of Law)
column6: Today_s kindergartners start school surrounded by robots, performance trackers, and other technologies aimed at helping them, monitoring them, and investigating them. As these students grow, will technology act to empower them or is it creating a digital dossier they can_t shake? Join the Student Privacy Initiative at Harvard_s Berkman Center for Internet & Society to explore the impact ed tech is likely to have on the futures of today_s students both in the classroom and beyond.
column7: To assess the positive and negative long-term learning and privacy implications of widespread use of ed tech in the classroom.
column8: To identify pro-active measures to be taken to ensure that the use of these technologies weighs more in favor of the benefits instead of the costs
column9: To consider and establish strategies for avoiding or resolving student privacy concerns that are likely to arise in the future.

column1: Using data to Start Students Off Strong
column5: Marica  Ballinger (Lorain County Community College), Michael  Bettersworth (Texas State Technical College ), Lara Couturier, PhD (Jobs for The Future)
column6: Community colleges are faced with increasing pressures to improve student outcomes while facing budget cuts and gaps in resources. Using predictive analytics and innovative approaches to labor market information (LMI) can help colleges better support their students. Predictive analytics helps identify and target the support services individual students need to persevere, and LMI can help to advise, place and prepare students for programs that align with their career interests.   This session will introduce new approaches to data as a tool for better decision making and focus on small sessions geared to sharing lessons and knowledge from the field.
column7: How to use predictive analytics to streamline and target support services for students.
column8: How to use LMI at intake to help students make academic choices in line with labor market demand.
column9: Learn how the colleges are gaining stakeholder alignment around implementing and using extensive data programs.

column1: Developing Education Equality - Can PD Do It?
column5: Alvin Crawford (Knowledge Delivery Systems), Karen Symms Gallagher (University of Southern California), Linda Darling-Hammond (Stanford )
column6: As awareness of disparity in educational opportunity grows, teachers are being asked to do more to address it in their classrooms. Education equity is already included in the education and training new teachers are getting today. But what about the more than 3 million teachers already on the job? With professional development efforts already stretched, what can be done to ensure veteran teachers understand, and are trained to address, education equity?
column7: Understanding the limits and pressures of current PD programs and what it means for education goals like equity.
column8: Exploring new ways of creating and delivering equity training and PD - ways that have been shown to work.
column9: Understanding the need to get equity lessons and training into the hands of classroom teachers immediately.

column1: Educators & Business Leaders: Start Collaborating!
column5: Michael Pino (General Electric Management Development Institute), Bob  Kelner (Laureate Education, Inc.), Emily Crawford (Laureate Education, Inc.)
column6: Educators and Employers: Start collaborating to meet the needs of the Modern Student/Employee!The Situation: Today_s student is evolving, aspiring to learn and demanding a _classroom_ makeover. Today_s students are also employees. They are multi-generational, more experienced, technologically astute, and socioeconomically and racially diverse. They are aspiring to be lifelong learners and demanding a _learning_ transformation from Higher Education and Corporate Learning! The Problem: Educators give themselves an A+ on how well they_re preparing students for success in the workplace, but business leaders give them a failing grade! Why the disparity? What to do about the conundrum?
column7: Engage in an interactive discussion with a panel of educational experts regarding the relationship between higher ed institutions and businesses.
column8: Examine how to leverage innovative academic partnerships to meet the needs and demands of today's students, who are also active full-time employees.
column9: Explore an award-winning approach for designing, aligning, and deploying a performance-driven, engaging, relevant educational solution.

column1: Meeting the Needs of Trans* Kids
column5: Jessica Floresta (Widener University), Erin Crabill (Widener University)
column6: The cultural climate and the law have become more accommodating towards the rights and needs of transgender people. People are more comfortable sharing their true gender identity with their families and friends, which ultimately leads to the need to transition publicly. As educators, we need to be aware of these needs, too, so that we can create nurturing learning environments for all of our students. This workshop aims to explain the concept of gender variance, highlight some of the cultural and legal struggles transgender individuals experience, and help educators brainstorm how they can best serve these students in their home educational settings.
column7: Understand how school significant non-discrimination laws such as the Equal Access Act and Title IX protect transgender students from discrimination.
column8: Become sensitive to the range of individual and cultural differences around gender non-conformity experienced by faculty, students, parents and others
column9: Collaborate using own professional ethical values and knowledge to create an environment that encourages diversity and non-discrimination for all.

column1: Merit Over Marketing _ Cutting Through the Clutter of Ed Tech
column5: Daron Calhoun II (Egun Veneration Transcribing and Consulting), Cassandra Ogbevire (University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education)
column6: Storytelling is the oldest form of teaching and is both an art form and a means of communication. Stories can be therapeutic in times of crises to help youth deal with difficult issues such as violence, abuse, or death. Similarly, Hip-Hop storytelling serves as a medium for urban youth and provides insight into their cultural values. Many urban students are faced with adult responsibilities that hinder their learning in the classroom. In this session, participants will go on an interactive journey as characters from Hip-Hop_s most poignant storytellers. Most importantly, they will will gain a better understanding of the challenges their urban students encounter on a daily basis.
column7: To illuminate the power of Hip-Hop narratives to create therapeutic and liberating spaces in urban classrooms.
column8: To explore meaningful literacy practices rooted in Hip-Hop that will help strengthen youth_s social, intellectual, and linguistic competencies.
column9: To awaken participant_s inner storyteller abilities through guided creative exercises incorporating the 5 elements of Hip-Hop.

column1: New Model Increases Diversity in International Ed
column5: Eliza  Pesuit (Global Glimpse)
column6: In this session we will explore a new model to address the opportunity gap for low income youth. Global Glimpse works in partnership with diverse public high schools to close the achievement gap through immersion abroad and leadership development that prepare low income youth for success in the global economy. Our curriculum develops global competence, civic engagement, youth leadership, and college readiness, inspiring and empowering youth to become agents of change in their local communities and in the greater global community. In this interactive session you will gain an understanding of our innovative model and develop skills to facilitate service learning and leadership workshops.
column7: Participants understand the impact of unequal access to out of the classroom learning opportunities on outcomes for low income youth
column8: Participants learn about a new model for immersive global education and gain skills to implement components of the model in their classrooms
column9: Participants develop a clear understanding of the difference between "community service" and "service learning" in an international context

column1: Self-governing For Quality and Value
column5: Colleen Broderick (Donnell Kay Foundation), Bryan Setser (2Revolutions), Gretchen  Morgan (Colorado Department of Education)
column6: Most would agree that the one-size-fits-all model of education is obsolete. To serve today's learner well, we need to coordinate people and resources in new, dynamic ways that empower all learners to meet their needs by bundling together opportunities of quality and value. This session invites participants to generate ideas for engaging learners, families, educators and employers in providing feedback that impacts the caliber of options within the system.
column7: Explore case studies of organizations making good use of initial and ongoing user feedback
column8: Examine and prioritize the needs and values of various potential users of the  system
column9: Employ design thinking protocols to generate ideas that empower stakeholders to collectively assess the quality and value of learning opportunities

column1: The Equitable Leader: Principal as Advocate
column5: Ty Davidson (Travis High School), Amy Lloyd (Austin ISD - Cunningham Elementary), Angela Ward (Austin ISD)
column6: The Austin ISD Principals' Council on Race & Equity (est. 6/2013) recogizes the crucial role the principal plays in the elimination of inequity in discipline, special education, staffing, advanced academics, graduation rates, college, career, and life. Our conversation will be framed around supportive tools, strategies and, skills in which stakeholders can engage to develop an inclusive, welcoming and supportive climate for all.
column7: Understand inequitable systemic "isms" that continue to plague educational institutions.
column8: Identify powerful partnerships at your disposal as an educational leader to dismantle inequities and end disparate learning opportunities.
column9: Engage in the use of a cultural proficiency tool and recognize the impact to student's lives of remaining blind to the difference in your institution.

column1: Keeping the Ed in EdTech
column5: James Vinson (V-Chain Solutions), Sabina  Bharwani (Teach for America), Sean Duffy (EdTech Action)
column6: The lack of educator involvement in in the early stages of the EdTech development process has led to a culture of solutions looking for problems. By connecting the real users of EdTech products (teachers, students, administrators, parents) with the creators of the tools (entrepreneurs, programmers, developers), we can begin to create scaleable EdTech tools from the ground up that provide solutions to defined problems. Through a moderated conversation, we will continue to explore ways to involve students, teachers, administrators, and parents in the EdTech development process to create tools that solve the most pressing problems in education.
column7: Discuss the inherent risks and rewards of involving students and educators in the development process.
column8: Discuss the role and responsibilities of schools and developers in reducing friction and the 'red tape' to innovate and implement new EdTech tools.
column9: Discuss how structures can be created to allow entrepreneurs access to  classrooms and build private-public partnerships between schools and industry.

column1: Selling BIG Ideas to Executives Who Hate Risk
column5: Julie Fast (Self), Dorian Simpson (Planning Innovations)
column6: Designers, engineers, developers and other innovative folks have great ideas, but often fail to get support and project funding for even the most promising opportunities. Why? They fail to meet the needs of notoriously risk-averse executives. Words are heard, _You must present a business case with market analysis, customer research, revenue forecasts, etc.' but innovators often struggle to convince these executives to fund their ideas. Through entertaining, humorous and engaging theater style dialogues (along with audience participation), we share pitching disasters contrasted with pitching techniques that lead to funding and the fruition of an innovator's ideas.
column7: How do I present my ideas so that executives and investors say, "I want to invest time and money in that idea!"?
column8: How do I gather and present the right data so executives and investors will accept the inherent risk of new ideas?
column9: How do I survive the funding 'inquisition' when asking for resources for my ideas?

column1: Successful Scaling 101
column5: Rebecca Goldberg (Bellwether Education Partners), Becky Crowe (Bellwether Education Partners)
column6: There are very few support options for leaders that are interested in scaling their models, as they pivot from operating one or two high achieving schools, programs, or geographies to building a successful growing organization. We have seen first-hand how a lack of clear strategic direction gets in the way of developing effective talent systems, and that a lack of talent systems gets in the way of effective implementation of a strategic plan. Come to this session to explore how planning and diagnostic tools can help you push your organizational approach to growth, with the support of your peers and an education-focused non-profit that brings processes and tools from the private sector.
column7: Participants will identify and problem-solve around key challenge areas for their organizations
column8: Participants will think through the intersection of strategic planning and talent planning for their organizations
column9: Participants will learn about planning tools and supports for scaling

column1: Adopting games-balancing edu & commercial concerns
column5: Peggy Sheehy (Ramapo Central School District), Jason Rosenblum (St. Edward's University), Karel Millenaar (Fource Labs)
column6: We know that adopting games in the classroom can promote learning, foster critical inquiry provide agency and engage students in their own learning. Digital and analog strategies can work together to make this happen. We know that game designers can make games and educators can adopt them. How do we pair one with the other? How can this happen in ways that are commercially sustainable? We propose to use a gameful process to identify and tackle barriers to adoption, design, technical and commercial concerns in an engaging, gameful and highly interactive session.
column7: To address how curricular design, classroom engagement, professional development and commercial dynamics impact support of games as teaching tools.
column8: To address: what counts as games & what they should 'do' to better fit between other tools and methods in education.
column9: To address: how we can empower teachers to adopt playfulness, games and design in their daily classroom practices.

column1: The Economics of Serious Games in Education
column5: Laurence Cocco (Games4Ed, Inc.), Victoria Van Voorhis (Second Avenue Learning), Scott Brewster (Triad Interactive Media)
column6: How can we create a sustainable economic ecosystem for serious games in U.S. education? This problem-solving panel discussion will explore the barriers to entry for serious game developers looking to produce high quality, high impact games for the K-12 education market. Victoria Van Voorhis, CEO of Second Avenue Learning, and Dr. Scott Brewster of Triad Interactive Media will invite the audience to discuss the factors influencing game-buying decisions, examine current practices (at what cost, free?), and begin to set the stage for an approach that more quickly and easily brings great games and students together.
column7: Participants will leave the session with a clear understanding of barriers to the K-12 education market, from a developer's perspective.
column8: Panel members and participants will identify possible solutions and paths forward toward building a sustainable economic ecosystem.
column9: Participants will begin to explore the potential pitfalls of the "free" and "freemium" approach to games.

column1: Beyond shiny objects: from technology to outcomes
column5: Julie Schell (The University of Texas at Austin), Alec Lazarescu (LearnBop), Brian Lukoff (Stealth ed-tech startup)
column6: Technology can provide enhanced opportunities for individualized student learning. Yet too often, it_s a _shiny object_ with lots of promise but limited results. Fancy tech alone will never lead to the desired student outcomes. In this panel, an edtech industry professional, a hybrid educator/edtech entrepreneur, and a professor teaching about tech and innovation in higher ed will share product-agnostic experiences about successful implementations of technology supporting pedagogy. Together the panelists and attendees will collaborate to discuss the diverse perspectives of the combined group and lay a foundation for an open source guide for effective tech usage in educational environments.
column7: Educators will be able to identify potential pitfalls and necessary considerations of adding technology-based classroom supplements.
column8: Educators will be able to develop strategies for melding education technologies with pedagogies backed by research to improve student outcomes.
column9: Educators will be able to develop strategies for adapting technology to suit and benefit the specific needs of their student population.

column1: Flipped classes can't be avoided. so don't.
column5: Darren Westenhaver (Flipped Marketing Inc.)
column6: Flipped classes disrupt the education system from Kindergarten through advanced degrees. As the trend continues it becomes unavoidable so why not find out what tools are available and start flipping classes now? Universities_including the best universities in the country_offer online or blended degrees for everything from an MBA to a PhD. Cornell University and USC have programs dedicated to Marketing Strategy and Hotel Management and the University of Texas offers a Masters of Science in Technology Commercialization in a blended format. What tools are they using to make this format effective and attract tuition dollars away from brick and mortar institutions?
column7: See examples of flipped classes from High School and Higher Ed.
column8: Show what tools and best practices are available for flipping classes.
column9: Watch as we walk one participant through getting started with flipping their class.

column1: How Do We Give Teachers More Time?
column5: Michelle Blanchet (The Educators' Lab)
column6: When I ask teachers what prevents them from being innovative, time tends to be the universal culprit. Educators already have a packed schedule; so how can we help them redesign the school day and have enough time to dedicate to innovation, problem-solving, and personalized learning without burning out? This problem-solver workshop aims to use a hackathon style format to get groups thinking about how time could be better managed in schools so that teachers can, realistically, get things done. Groups will be expected to identify common 'time wasters' and develop strategies and solutions to combat inefficient use of time so that educators can better utilize each school day.
column7: Issue Awareness - Case study to demonstrate the teacher time crunch and how this issue impacts teaching and learning.
column8: Experience - Hackathon style workshop that promotes team building and problem solving in a structured, multi-setting framework. Take it, share it!
column9: Create - Strategies and solutions that could address the time issue and be recommended to teachers, schools, and districts.

column1: Issues Building an Innovative School
column5: Amy Stornaiuolo (University of Pennsylvania), Jessica Shupik (The U School), Sophie Date (The U School)
column6: We are transforming how students experience school in Philadelphia. At The U School, students are given real world opportunities to apply knowledge and fulfill their greatest potential. In our pilot years, this work has presented many challenges. Our goal is to integrate problem-based learning and design spaces into a competency-based high school. Our guiding vision is "We Love. We Dream. We Do." But how can we break ingrained habits and paradigms in order to change the way that students experience school? During this Problem Solver session, we will collaborate with K-12 administrators, teachers, and students who are doing, or want to do, school differently.
column7: Engage in the design thinking process to envision how school can be done differently.
column8: Explore how to structure asynchronous education for open-enrollment, public schools.
column9: Use personal narratives from The U School to empower students to change the way they experience school and the world.

column1: Learner-Centered Design: Principles and Partners
column5: K.Rebecca  Runyon (Pearson), Dan Shapera (Pearson), Angela Barrus (Pearson)
column6: In today_s competitive learning landscape, it is vital to bring target learners to the design table early and often to validate expert design decisions. Design-based research tools and processes can be employed effectively at any level of an organization prior to major investments being made in learning experiences that are not well aligned to learner needs and/or are not able to effectively impact learner outcomes.Understanding students_ learning strategies using learner-centered, participatory design combined with learning science research principles provides a solid evidence base to inform efficacious learning intervention design and delivery.
column7: Utilize design thinking tool sets to create a common language among learners and learning designers.
column8: Discuss validation strategies and processes that generate informed learner perceptions and recommendations.
column9: Facilitate quality brainstorming that leverages designers_ and learners_ personal and professional development goals.

column1: Swapping sides of the bed: Driving Change Adoption
column5: Lora Cover (Cleveland Metropolitan School Distrist), Xiomara Padamsee (Bellwether Education Partners)
column6: We are creatures of habit. Knowing what to expect gives us control and comfort. But we know that in order for us to better meet student needs today, we need to face, and implement, significant change. We also know that when we are truly invested in the vision of what needs to happen, we can successfully get to the other side. The goal is to minimize decline in performance during the transition and maximize speed to adoption by building and sustaining stakeholder commitment. Through a real-time case example of one school district_s transformation and your own real-time challenges, come join us to learn about what you can do to manage change successfully in your organization.
column7: Participants will learn about the key steps to change management
column8: Participants will learn about strategies for successful stakeholder engagement
column9: Participants will identify actions they can take to manage change in their own organizations

column1: Are Your Students Ready for the Creative Economy?
column5: Erica Muhl (USC ), Villy Wang (BAYCAT), Mark Martin (St Marks Church of England Academy)
column6: According to the Department of Labor, 65% of current students will spend their careers in jobs that have yet to be invented. To succeed in tomorrow_s workforce, we must equip students with the kind of skills that will never appear on a standardized test -- creativity, adaptability, collaborative decision-making, and problem-solving. In this session you will hear from experts who are approaching this type of education in a variety of ways. Then, we will challenge you to work in small groups to define other strategies for how we can ensure our students are ready for the creative economy.
column7: Explore successful models that effectively prepare students for the future.
column8: Develop solutions for your own practice.
column9: Network and collaborate with peers to redesign how we prepare youth for the creative economy.

column1: Bye PD, Hello LX: Connect, Design, Share
column5: Megan Mead (Getting Smart), Caroline Vander Ark (Getting Smart )
column6: Why LX over PD? With Learner Experience (LX), we listen, iterate, collaborate and utilize high tech and high touch solutions to learn together. Today, you_re the learner. Bring your creativity, an open mind and devices to fully immerse in LX. You_ll craft an essential question to guide your inquiry, act on what matters by identifying core values, dive into the LX process and share the results of your investigation to leverage high impact at SXSWedu and beyond. You_ll also hone those qualitative and quantitative reasoning skills, immerse yourself in data and wrestle with big questions. Come for the peanut M&M_s and leave with LX and a project that impacts your school or organization.
column7: Model the learner experience process
column8: Identify a question or challenge and work with tools (and each other) to solve it
column9: Create a project that has deep impact at SXSWedu and beyond

column1: Creating Edu Materials for Emotional Resonance
column5: Kim Ducharme (CAST), Jason Gorman (Six Red Marbles), Margaret Weigel (Six Red Marbles)
column6: The best learning experiences are driven by emotions that sustain the learner and remain impactful long after completion. This session explores the important role emotions and engagement play in learning, and provides tools for identifying and integrating these natural learner responses into your own work. New insights from neuroscience frame real-world examples of best practices and hands-on activities to teach you ways to work with learner challenges that can inform and strengthen engagement and outcomes. You will leave with techniques to help you mitigate emotional blockers and cultivate more effective, powerful, and resonant learning experiences.
column7: Share research & working examples that highlight the importance of positive emotional responses and mitigating negative ones in any learning setting.
column8: Guide participants through a series of activities based on real-world challenges with respect to engagement, emotions, learning, and cognition.
column9: Provide participants with the tools to apply these techniques to their own curriculum development processes.

column1: Engagement and Motivation in Distance Learning
column5: Rozy Parlette (University of North Florida), Julie  Fuller (University of North Florida), Rick  L'Ecuyer (University of North Florida)
column6: What motivates students to continue in an online course? What design and instructional elements engage students in an online environment? There are no easy answers to these difficult questions, but through a dialogue that covers tools for engagement, scaffolding and delivery strategies to enhance student motivation, universal design for learning (UDL) and accessibility, as well as authentic assessments participants will workshop innovative strategies to solve these challenges. Session takeaways will be based on the collective knowledge of the participants and their contributions to the conversation.
column7: Identify solutions to increase engagement in distance learning environments
column8: Develop scaffolding and delivery strategies that enhance student motivation in distance learning environments
column9: Recognize potential pitfalls in engagement related to accessibility and universal design in distance learning environments

column1: Learn Like Experience Designers: Educate by Doing
column5: Dan Shipley (Jackrabbit Mobile)
column6: New learning models are emerging that allow students to receive higher scores than they do in traditional classrooms. In these emerging pedagogies, teachers are recontextualized as coaches, facilitators, and mentors working to guide the student_s own experiential exploration.A variety of language is used describe these new learning models, including challenge-based learning, flipped classrooms, and 21st Century Literacy. With the widespread adoption of learning management systems, now even public institutions are shifting toward education that is driven by student curiosity.
column7: Explain Why Designers Learn by Doing and use Experiential education techniques
column8: Explore techniques for Flipped Classroom and offer Student Driven learning activities
column9: Explain why these tools are flexible  and responsive to changing conditions

column1: Lipstick on a Pig: PD that Brings Home the Bacon
column5: Greg Garner (North Carolina State University), Abbey Futrell (The William and Ida Friday Institute for Educational Innovation), Tracy Clark (EdTechWomen Austin)
column6: We saw that eye roll. There_s no hope for professional development, right? It_s kind of like vegetarian bacon: nice try, but just not the same. Presenters are great at using pretty slideshows and hamming it up, but that_s just lipstick on a pig. Are we practicing what we preach? Help us cook up a new recipe to make professional learning an engaging, productive experience. Bring home the bacon to your schools and businesses and change the face of learning.
column7: Stop eating from the slop trough of bad strategies!
column8: Join our collaborative cooking class to create a new PD recipe book using only fresh ingredients.
column9: Bring home the bacon to your organization and change PD for good.

column1: Creating Community: Crowdsourcing best practices
column5: Melissa Jones (Code.org), Matt Niemitz (Adobe), Rachelle Wooten (Fort Bend Independent School District)
column6: Most professional learning communities (PLC) designed for education fall flat or fail before they ever get off the ground. In this interactive session, we_ll explore what motivates teachers to engage in community. As an educator, how can you influence the growth of communities you participate in? And as a community manager, how can you design strategies that not only drive engagement but also change teacher practice? The output of our discussion will be a set of recommendations for educators and community managers alike on how best to create communities that thrive.
column7: Brainstorm design principles for PL community building
column8: Discuss how community strategies support and sustain initiatives at different types of organizations
column9: Identify a set of best practices for building and growing PL communities

column1: How to Make Sure Your Network is Networked
column5: Eva Mejia (Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching), Paul LeMahieu (Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching), Emma Parkerson (National Board for Professional Teaching Standards)
column6: The problems within education are too big for any individual to solve alone. The potential power of collective action is increasingly well understood, but how to create a network often remains elusive. In this problem solver session, you will collaborate with current leaders of networked improvement communities and other attendees to brainstorm solutions to some of the common problems and questions that arise when working in networks. Through this session, we will generate know-how on connecting learning generated across different sites, creating agreement between multiple stakeholders on a common aim, and leveraging research and practical expertise, so you can truly work as a network.
column7: Identify key concepts and tools that should be part of your network development toolkit.
column8: Understand the functions and possible structures for a network hub.
column9: Practice applying the networked improvement community framework to your context and problem.

column1: KILLING FATHER TIME. The Rebranding of Aging
column5: Tuck  Kamin (Design Your Age)
column6: Time to rip a hole in the way we see aging.  See new ideas created in the arts, business, real estate and innovation out the wazoo. But most of all a seismic shift introducing new archetypes of why being older has value. See the latest solutions by Age Scientists in unlocking aging. The rise of age diverse communities. Meet some extraordinary individuals in their 20's, 30's  and a group of 90 year olds still creating innovative work. This discussion with Age Scientist. Award winning branding strategist. Social scientist and humorists is all design to murder the way we see aging and reveal the serious side to the positive aspects of aging. Have panelists or can join other discussion.
column7: Create new value perception of aging.
column8: See how there are enormous new economic opportunities in aging.
column9: How to rethink, rebrand and create new ideas as you age.

column1: Putting People of Color at the Center of Design
column5: Brandon  Corley  (EPIC South High School), John  Clemente  (Department of Education, Expanded Success Initiative), Prejhane Williams (Urban School for Design and Construction )
column6: Participants will utilize a design thinking process to explore some of the real challenges faced by school designers and leaders who recently opened three innovative schools in NYC. This interactive work will be paired with the telling of the story of the Expanded Success Initiative and its mission. Participants will engage in brainstorming, a _How Might We?_ protocol, and prototyping and revision work around challenges related to student-centered school design. A debriefing session will allow for a discussion tailored to the needs of the participants.
column7: Participants will be able to access strategies for connecting human-centered design principles to address education-related challenges.
column8: Participants will be able to access strategies for connecting human-centered design principles to address education related challenges.
column9: Participants will engage in the design thinking process and be able to utilize the process for their own work.

column1: Transform Your Organization with Design Thinking
column5: Alyssa Gallagher (Los Altos School District), Kami Thordarson (Los Altos School District)
column6: The intersection of leadership & design offers unique opportunities.  What if leaders started thinking like designers?  Thinking like a designer means being more aware of the world around you, taking the time to empathize with your users, creating new solutions for the future, and taking action to implement those solutions.  As a leader in your organization, turn off your automatic pilot using design thinking.  With this as a framework, learn to focus on your approach, your intention, and the process by which you lead.  Revel in the mess and embrace a set of developing practices and mindsets that improve your ability to lead differently.
column7: Explore the power of _Vuja De,_ the ability to look at the familiar and see them anew.
column8: Apply design thinking to solve systems level challenges, reframing obstacles and embracing constraints with intentional design.
column9: Engage in practices that will help develop a designer mindset as a leader and walk away with a personalized action plan for getting started.

column1: Design 1 Space - 60 Students, 3 Teachers, 3 Modes
column5: Michael Horn (Clayton Christensen Institute), Lawrence Kearns (Wheeler Kearns Architects)
column6: Because blended-learning schools leverage multiple modes of learning, their spatial needs differ.  At a minimum, they need spaces designed for different types of personalized learning.We'll take you on a Design Sprint to investigate how a large community of learners can share the same physical space. In Understanding, you'll plot the learner's experience using the 5 E's that apply to any user experience.During Diverge/Converge, each team will start with a different space configuration. Teams will be given 3D-printed manipulatives to model solutions that can be photographed and shared out to the larger group.  We'll deliberate on which solutions warrant Prototyping and Validation.
column7: Use "The 5 E's" to portray the learner experience during individual, peer-to-peer, and teacher-led small group learning
column8: Identify adjacencies, groupings, and navigation aids that allow large groups students and teachers to learn effectively in the same physical space
column9: Use a four-step Design Sprint to develop new types of learning habitats

column1: Design Thinking the Whole School
column5: Alex Owens (Bricolage Academy), Jasmine  Araujo (Bricolage Academy), Rich Crandall (Hasso Plattner Institute of Design at Stanford)
column6: Bricolage Academy is a school that develops innovation among its students, but we recently realized we did not expect much creative problem solving from our staff.  That all changed when the Bricolage team took a 'design thinking' approach to solving the school's biggest challenges.In this session, classroom teachers and educators trained in design thinking will share their experiences reforming and redesigning everything at a school site: from the teachers lounge to recess to parent engagement.Participants will apply their lessons-learned and start solving challenges currently limiting their own schools and organizations.
column7: Attendees will describe the challenges and benefits of employing a human-centered approach to solving school design problems.
column8: Attendees will employ the mindsets and practices needed to develop ownership and creative thinking among the whole school staff.
column9: Attendees will leave with one prototype solution to a problem their school currently faces.

column1: Introducing CuriosityStream
column5: Rob Burk (CuriosityStream)
column6: Imagine the progress and innovation we could achieve if we never lost our curiosity about the world around us - the possibilities would remain limitless. CuriosityStream delivers "deep dive" content in the areas of science, technology, civilization and the human spirit to engage audiences keen to understand our ever-changing and infinitely fascinating world. Launched as the world's first ad-free SVOD service for the incurably curious, CuriosityStream provides an affordable online destination that informs, enlightens and inspires viewers with premium factual shows. At SXSW edu, the CuriosityStream team will showcase the service with the premiere of a new series and free subscriptions.
column7: Share Incredible Content
column8: Educate About Service
column9: Offer Free Adoption

column1: Explore your world with Google Expeditions
column5: Jennifer Holland (Google Inc.)
column6: Google Expeditions: Taking your students places a school bus can't goThree teachers (2 K-12 and have one higher ed professor) who've built virtual field trips with Google Expeditions share tips on creating great virtual content for your classes. They'll take you on the field trips they build, and talk about how to integrate VR content into your curriculum.
column7: Learn how to incorporate Google Expeditions into your curriculum
column8: Identify ways to bring to life your existing lessons leveraging virtual reality
column9: Create truly immersive and transformational Expeditions that excite and engage your students

column1: Google Classroom: Mission control for your class
column5: Jennifer Holland (Google)
column6: Google Classroom is your mission control for teachers and students. Create classes, distribute assignments, send feedback, and see everything in one place. Find out what's new and how to get started.
column7: What is Classroom? What does it do? What are its features?
column8: What does it look like to use Classroom in practice in an actual classroom?
column9: How do I get started?

column1: The Bootcamp: Kicking Faculty Innovation into Gear
column5: Leslie Kennedy (California State University Chancellors Office), Carrie O'Donnell (Cafe Learn ), Dean Florez (Balance BPR)
column6: Join us as we share results from an amazing new movement helping faculty scale innovation to increase student engagement and success. Listen as panelists describe how collaborative development of blended, interactive, personalized and social learning courses have been achieved utilizing a unique _Engaged Learning Bootcamp_ model - across California and beyond.  Learn how to leverage broad funding initiatives, best in class affordability programs and professional services to enact change, delight faculty, increase student performance and improve affordability. Panelists will describe actual successes in a variety of courses as well as share real time student data captured to track engagement.
column7: Understand how outcomes "blueprints" help faculty to easily convert courses to active, social and blended learning experiences.
column8: Discover how schools can rapidly scale innovation and change by wrapping great design around affordable solutions.
column9: Listen to CSU and Caf Learn explain how easy it is to fund and implement the Engaged Learning Bootcamp at your college or university.

column1: Watch, Chat and Learn the OVEE Way
column5: Katrina  Kehoe  (KLRN), Sharan Sklar (Independent Television Services: OVEE )
column6: What if you could plug free high quality media and live chats with world-class experts into your lesson plan?We all know real life experiences and moving images are powerful ways to bring classroom subjects to life. With OVEE you can create interactive learning events, pivoting around live-streaming, moderated chat and compelling PBS shows like NOVA and Frontline to spark discussion, build engagement and increase participation.Take your students on a virtual class trip to chat live with Astronaut Shannon Lucid or watch a nature series and dialog with scientists from around the country.Learn how educators are harnessing the power of public media to engage, educate and inspire students.
