column7: What is OVEE and why does it matter to me?
column8: Understand how educators are using this media driven social platform to power a new approach to teaching in the 21st century.
column9: Participate in a discussion on the future of media and interactivity in the classroom.

column1: Circuit Scribe - reinventing electronics education
column5: Brett Walker (Elecroninks Writeables, Inc.)
column6: STEAM education is typically taught via disparate techniques with a number of tools that cover a variety of individual topics within this growing, but vast field.  Circuit Scribe is a tool that allows electronics and many STEM principles to fluidly interact with art and creative classrooms to fully incorporated STEAM principles in the modern classroom by incorporating a rollerball metal glitter pen to manufacture electronics on notebook paper on the fly.
column7: Show that STEAM education can be fun and approachable using new tools at educators' disposal.
column8: Illustrate the effectiveness of hands on training for electronics.
column9: Show the removal of age restrictions typically required for electronics and STEAM education when the tool is distilled to a rollerball pen.

column1: Classroom Guitar: Building artistry and community
column5: Jeremy Osborne (Austin Classical Guitar)
column6: The guitar is arguably one of the most popular instruments in the world, yet it is not often utilized to it_s true potential in music education. Through an ensemble-based approach rooted in expressive music making, guitar class becomes a viable tool to engage diverse populations and create life long music learners. Austin Classical Guitar has developed over 50 classical guitar programs in Central Texas and will share their experience as a leader in classroom guitar education.
column7: Learn more about how classroom classical guitar programs can engage diverse populations of students in a rigorous and expressive musical community.
column8: Provide a description of a classical guitar program that is held to the same standard of quality as a traditional band, orchestra, or choir program.
column9: Discuss ACG's method of success in the classroom through their online teaching resource guitarcurriculum.com.

column1: Disrupting Creative Higher Education
column5: Ajay Kapur (Kadenze )
column6: Many students who dream of studying technology for creative technologies and arts face crippling financial barriers. So how should we ensure everyone has access to the highest quality education available?Ajay Kapur from Kadenze, a global learning platform, will discuss the broken profit-driven financial state of U.S. higher education, and how this industry deserves a more unique approach. By creating a new financial model, which benefits the students, instructors, and institutions, higher education institutions can make access to arts education a reality where people learn, question, create, think, discuss, are exposed to new ideas, and power over their own career paths.
column7: The current state of education is unsustainable and financial solutions need to be put into action, especially in less lucrative fields like the arts.
column8: What this new financial model means for the future of education and how it can be applied to other fields.
column9: How MOOCs can improve and become a better resource for students to learn from leading experts around the world in any industry.

column1: Education Through Arts Research
column5: Lon Parker (iStock by Getty Images)
column6: Creating art to experience art history to evolve an artistic career. Creating a fictional protagonist placed amid the seminal events of art history. Defined by styles of the era, creating new work as that character. The result; a refreshed personal artistic vision. The session is a detailed presentation of immersive, self-directed learning, based on the research and experience of producing my experimental film TRENCH and the Surrounded By Lions multi-media triptych project. From Dada to Abstract Expressionism. Art of the early 20th century. The artists, their society, the social/political climate that informed their work and critical analysis from fictional protagonist Alex Graf.
column7: Creating a deeper level of understanding to learning by introducing a personal attachment o the subject.
column8: Creation of a culturally opposite alter ego in order to challenge a personal artistic vision.
column9: Discovering a new inner voice by externalizing and presenting for critique personally held artistic beliefs and dogmas.

column1: Teaching Interactive Film
column5: Ross Johnstone (National Film Board of Canada)
column6: The new cinematic genre of Interactive film is exploding and is a tool for educators to try new things and go to new places with their students. In this session presented by the National Film Board of Canada, participants will explore Interactive productions and learn how to use them in the classroom to engage students on the environment, the economy, multiculturalism and community. Participants will gain a strong understanding of experiential nature that Interactives bring to learning. This session will provide direct curricular links and resources for all of the materials presented and it will show the power that Interactive films have in breathing new life into standard school subjects.
column7: Discovering Interactive film as a cross-curricular tool that creatively engages students in learning
column8: Using Interactive film to develop critical media literacy skills in your students
column9: Using Interactive film to develop digital literacy skills in your students and foster positive digital citizenship

column1: Educational Assessment Failing Our Children?
column5: Timothy  Vansickle (Questar Assessment Inc.)
column6: Assessments frustrate educators, drive parents to opt out, and push policymakers into untenable positions. Those dreaded end-of-year tests can sometimes seem to be more important than the student learning they are intended to assess. But it was never meant to be this way. Let_s delve into how we got here_and how we can make improvements to ensure educational testing lives up to its potential as a valuable tool for students, teachers, parents, administrators, and other stakeholders.
column7: Understand the purpose of a test or assessment, and how the differences between accountability, achievement, and growth can help define that purpose
column8: Discuss what the measurement community need to address to ensure that educational testing is useful, reliable, and valid for the purpose of the test
column9: Explore what a next-generation assessment system looks like and the impact it will have on educational assessment

column1: Freedom to Fail
column5: Andrew Miller (ASCD)
column6: Andrew K. Miller explains the many benefits of intentionally designing opportunities for students to "fail forward" in the classroom. He provides a raft of strategies for ensuring that students experience small, constructive failures as a means to greater achievement, and offers practical suggestions for ensuring that constructive failure doesn't detrimentally affect students' summative assessments. He also describes how teachers, too, can benefit from failure. Establishing a culture that embraces the freedom to fail helps students to adopt a growth mind-set, take risks in the service of greater learning, and develop realistic expectations of what it takes to succeed in the world at large.
column7: Learn how to build a classroom and school culture to allow for failure as a learning opportunity
column8: Plan assessment practices that work for failure instead of against it
column9: Gain Instructional Strategies that help support safe failure experiences.

column1: Measuring the Idea that All Children Can Learn
column5: Canda Mueller (Questar Assessment Inc.)
column6: All children can learn. But how do we know they are learning? And how do we know what they are learning? The answer is through assessment. Yes, the very thing that has become the bane of educators, students, and parents everywhere is_when done right_the very thing that can help you ensure that children fulfill their learning potential. This presentation will explore the value of measuring learning and how to make it less time consuming and more meaningful to educators, students, and parents.
column7: Examine methods for ensuring fairness in educational assessment
column8: Explore why standardized testing is necessary to measure student knowledge
column9: Bring educators and assessment providers together to work toward common goal of helping all children live up to their educational potential

column1: Flipped Kit- creative evidence of mastery
column5: Adam Coulter Johnson (Mountain Brook City Schools)
column6: Through the use of the "Flipped Kit," teachers can gain insight to how their students think and reason through their problem solving process. This revolutionary idea brings students' thinking to life. Students record their entire thinking process through the use of screen writing, screen casting and voice recording. Then, they quickly share their artifacts with their teacher and classmates allowing them to receive quality feedback on the entire learning process and not just the final answer. Learn to use the Flipped Kit in your classroom so you can give your students the freedom to show what they know!
column7: Flipped Learning
column8: Growth Mindset
column9: Assessment and Feedback

column1: Happiness Lies Within _ Perceptions of Happiness
column5: Deo  Mwano (Deo Mwano / College For America (SNHU))
column6: Happiness Lies Within _ Perceptions of HappinessWhat does happiness mean to you? Is it that brand new thing? Is it the comfort of knowing what_s next? Is it that weekly paycheck? Is it being in that perfect environment where everything is perceived to work in your favor? Does any of that lead to your true happiness?Learn a little about Deo Mwano's Story how he discovered internal happiness while going through adversity in the Democratic Republic of Congo.Deo will dissect external happiness factories that attempts to satisfy internal desires.Discover your own internal happiness desires and learn how to satisfied them in what you do everyday.Feed the beast!
column7: Differentiate between internal happiness and external happiness
column8: Discover what feeds your internal happiness.
column9: Learn how to consider your internal happiness as a factory to what you do.

column1: I learned how to read in law school
column5: Jason Webb (JP Webb)
column6: I devoured books through school, averaging about 1,000 pages a week in addition to what school required. Yet, I feel like I didn't really learn how to read until I went to law school. We will discuss different reading styles.  Then we will focus on how and why attorneys read differently and what that can do for non-attorneys.
column7: How do lawyers read.
column8: How to read like a lawyer.
column9: How to decide when to bring out your inner lawyer.

column1: Innovation in Listening
column5: Monica Brady-Myerov (Listen Current)
column6: _My students don_t listen!_ I have heard this countless times from educators at conferences, in workshops and in classrooms. We spend 65-90% of our time listening yet it_s a skill that is vastly overlooked in the K12 classroom. This session will explore the relationship between critical listening skills and literacy acquisition across childhood and beyond. It will also look at listening and English as a Second Language acquisition. As educators, we must intervene and innovate to build those skills. This presentation will explore specific methods and a variety of new online tools to foster better listening by students. It will also present current research on auditory processing.
column7: Teachers will develop a working understanding of the scholarship on critical listening and literacy acquisition for different populations of learners.
column8: Teachers will feel empowered to implement listening strategies to ensure that their students are college and career ready.
column9: Teachers will have access to innovative listening and literacy tools that help them support critical listening for their students.

column1: Neuroscience and Watson based learning experiences
column5: Satya Nitta (IBM Research)
column6: The recent emergence of highly interactive technologies such as touch and gesture recognition, natural language based interactions, etc, are historically important milestones in computing. Together, these technologies, along with related advances in the field of artificial intelligence (AI), are ushering in the era of cognitive computing, where the computers have attributes that allow them to interact more naturally with humans. At the same time, advances in cognitive neuroscience are beginning to shed light on learning processes and what impacts them. At the intersection of these fields lies the extraordinary opportunity to transform learning. These ideas will be explored in this session.
column7: A review of some of the principles extracted from recent publications in cognitive neuroscience with a focus on childhood learning
column8: A review of advances in cognitive computing and "adaptive interactivity" which includes augmented and virtual reality, and their impact on learning
column9: Structuring immersive, interactive and effective learning experiences through digital media at the intersection of cognitive neuroscience and AI

column1: STEM to STEAM: The _A_ is not enough
column5: Randy Swearer (Autodesk)
column6: Education is experiencing deep disruption_a necessary transformation to prepare the next generation for a new class of professional challenges. Many tech companies have a plethora of unfilled STEM jobs. Why aren_t students prepared? How can we ensure their success and continue to drive innovation in the U.S.? Along with a technical foundation, prospective STEM workers must have strong _soft_ skills, such as creativity, critical thinking and communication. Achieving this means going beyond adding an _A_ to STEM to create STEAM. The _A_ must represent more than art; it must reflect how artists and designers think and interact with the world. Soft skills are the key to tomorrow_s workplace.
column7: Challenge your idea of STEAM education
column8: Receive perspective on the value of soft skills
column9: Learn about curricula to teach both skillsets

column1: CINAGE, later life learning in cinema & filmmaking
column5: Jennifer Granville (Leeds Beckett University)
column6: The CINAGE Course package is a set of educational and supporting materials offering exciting learning opportunities to engage seniors with both critical analysis of selected films and practical film making experience, thus promoting active ageing. CINAGE was piloted by four European countries with a group of senior volunteers who attended screenwriting, directing and editing workshops, and who wrote and produced their own scripts based on autobiographical stories and strategies for coping with ageing.  The session will tell the story of the project, its strengths and weaknesses and how it can be used to encourage a healthy active ageing.  There will be a screening of some of the films made.
column7: To describe how senior volunteers engaged with learning practical filmmaking, what lessons were learned and how they can be applied in future.
column8: To illuminate  the benefits of inter-generational collaboration, its contribution to a successful project and how to integrate it into future projects
column9: To highlight the geragogical approach to teaching and learning and describe how it worked in the context of cinematic appreciation and film production

column1: Evolve or Die: Why Education has to Change
column5: Jim Deters (Galvanize)
column6: The landscape of higher education is quickly changing in the United States. The concept that a four-year degree guarantees a lifetime of success has been proven to be unrealistic in today_s job market.How do learners gain the skills and access necessary to be a part of the technology sector? What does education need to look like to keep up with market demands? What will happen to universities if they don_t evolve?In this presentation, Jim Deters, CEO and co-founder of Galvanize, will explain the tectonic demographic shifts causing these changes, how education providers need to step up to meet market demands, and what modern education will look like in the coming decades.
column7: Discover how and why the landscape of higher education is evolving.
column8: Learn how new programs are being developed to meet the needs of today_s workers.
column9: Receive actionable takeaways to support students with a modern education.

column1: The Incredible Edible Egg_s Farm-to-Table Journey
column5: Jerry  Wilkins (America Egg Board)
column6: One of America_s egg farmers will share where eggs come from and how egg farmers care for their hens, land and communities. This presentation aims to improve agricultural and eggricultural literacy _ awareness, knowledge and appreciation _ among PreK-12 teachers and their students.Since 2009, America_s egg farmers have talked to literally thousands of civic group across the country and at least one person at almost every presentation remarks: I had no idea what all is involved with egg farming, and I learned a lot today. Dozens of FAQs will be answered.
column7: Outline the egg production process via pictures and video from start to finish.
column8: Explain popular egg carton claims. America_s egg farmers believe in consumer choice, and work hard to provide you with the highest-quality eggs.
column9: Share highlights of how U.S. egg production has significantly decreased its environmental footprint in the past 50 years.

column1: A Proving Ground for Education
column5: Tom Kane (Center for Education Policy Research at Harvard University)
column6: The rate of progress in education will depend not only on our ability to create innovations, but will depend much more on our ability to learn what innovations work. Yet evaluations are costly, slow, and they don_t provide real-time data on implementation. For this reason, education leaders rarely test new ideas before rolling them out to teachers and students broadly. We need a _proving ground_ to easily learn what works and how. This session will describe a new infrastructure to make rigorous evaluation fast, cheap, and useful for schools systems and software providers.
column7: Understand the critical role rigorous efficacy trials could and should play in education _ and the barriers to carrying them out.
column8: Explore new models for evaluation better suited to the pace and complexity of a rapidly transforming field.
column9: Identify opportunities for sharing results rapidly _ to improve the speed at which the sector learns.

column1: Big Data and the Future of Education
column5: Matt Riley (Blueprint LSAT Prep)
column6: Education currently leverages a mostly summative approach to understanding students' progress and abilities. At best this method gives a collection of data points, but nothing like a predictive analysis of a student's trajectory or learning patterns.  By utilizing a digital platform that tracks multifaceted data, instruction and practice can be tailored to students' individual needs.  Data can be used to customize users' learning experience, allowing them to autonomously work through material. Having engineered such a learning platform that harnesses the power of big data for our own students, we_d like to explain how such systems can be architected to enhance education.
column7: We'll describe real world applications for Big Data in Higher Education and beyond.
column8: We'll explain the best data structure and catalog methods for aggregating the data needed to develop predictive models.
column9: We'll give a data driven analysis of the costs and benefits of digital education platforms that use Big Data, for both students and institutions.

column1: Building a Hybrid Education for a Hybrid Job Econo
column5: Matt Sigelman (Burning Glass Technologies)
column6: The labor market is transforming into a hybrid job economy as employers seek candidates who can weave together traditionally unrelated skill sets like statistics and marketing; or programming and art/design.  How do colleges, boot camps, and other nontraditional providers prepare students for a hybrid job market? By developing a hybrid educational system, combining the strengths of traditional higher education with non-traditional adult education. Mapping courses to specific competencies highlights what current programs can and can_t provide, allowing students to supplement their traditional degree with specific skills or certifications they_ll need for success in the workforce.
column7: Understanding the increase in hybrid job roles and their impact on the labor market
column8: Knowledge of the unexpected strengths of liberal arts programs for those seeking hybrid jobs
column9: Understanding alternatives for how higher education can help students mix and match different skill sets

column1: Connecting the Campus: Location-Based Messaging
column5: Todd Marks (Mindgrub)
column6: The next era of campus engagement is as simple as sending a message to a phone. Prospective students, current students, and alumni can be actively engaged with your university in new ways through location-based messaging; a concept that utilizes a school_s campus as a portal for discovery. Through the use of beacons, a prospective student can go on a self-guided campus tour, a current student can be sent today_s dining hall menu, and visiting alumni can be alerted to a football game_s start. This session will discuss the advantages of location-based messaging, the barriers that may arise, and the path for creating a personalized experience for your university's students and visitors.
column7: Identify specific features of mobile applications that can enhance the student experience.
column8: Provide examples of successful location-based university applications.
column9: Discuss current technologies and techniques for implementation.

column1: Data-Driven Administrative & Student Success
column5: Carlos Antequera (PeopleAdmin)
column6: Technology can_t offer students inspiration, motivation or encouragement; only teachers can. But today_s learning institutions can use technology to attract and retain top teachers and staff who can make a real difference in the lives of their students and to the sustainable growth of their schools. It all comes down to using the right data to hire the right people for the right jobs. As the leading provider of talent management solutions for K-12 and higher ed, PeopleAdmin is uniquely positioned to leverage years of data to extract trends and actionable analytics. This session will get into the types of data available and how to use that data to ultimately improve student success.
column7: Why driving administrative success is important to improving student success
column8: How data can provide strategic insights
column9: What data should institutions consider in order to strategically transform the institution and how this data can be obtained and analyzed

column1: Everything is an A/B Test, true or false?
column5: Krishna Gade (Pinterest)
column6: A/B Testing has become a powerful tool to test user experiences at scale in the past decade. In this talk Krishna will go through some of his experiences of building data-driven consumer products. He will walk over scenarios where you can use data to both build new product experiences, to measure how launched features are doing, to calculate early on what to invest your precious time on. In addition to real world examples, he gives a peek into how Pinterest has used data-driven approach for ever aspect of the product from user growth to building infrastructure.
column7: Often times people ask me, what can I do with all this data? In this talk, one can learn key ideas behind using data to build products.
column8: A/B testing has proved to be a powerful tool in testing user experiences for the past decade, in this talk we can learn how Pinterest is applying it.
column9: We're living in a data rich age, everyone wants to learn how to use data effectively, but don't know where to start. Attend this talk to learn!

column1: Harnessing the Power of Predictive Analytics
column5: Donald Fraynd (TeacherMatch)
column6: Imagine a new paradigm in teacher recruitment, where school systems can identify those candidates most likely to foster whole student development, deliver measurable academic growth and achievement, as well as advance district and school performance.Advances in modern test theory have made it possible to predict the impact a teacher candidate will have in the classroom. In this session, we will talk about one of the most robust teacher effectiveness research studies ever conducted and what the findings reveal, as well as how a predictive analytics tool is utilized for a more equitable and effective hiring process, and identifies teacher candidates who will influence student growth.
column7: Understand the four primary factors that decades of research show are directly correlated with teacher_s ability to impact student achievement.
column8: Understand how Hierarchical Linear Modeling, Structural Equation Modeling, and Value-Added Modeling adapt for greater predictive power.
column9: Understand how Computer Adaptive Technology ensures that a screening instrument continues to iterate over time.

column1: (I X C) X A = S
column5: Ken Rochon (The Umbrella Syndicate)
column6: This is an expanded explanation of how content and distribution of a message (brand, mission, purpose for living) rely on each other to be successful.The symbols stand for (Identify X Clarify) X Amplification = Impact Success on the WorldThe presentation will show how the numbers are derived and how to improve those numbers to have the highest impact possible in the world.
column7: Identify your message
column8: Clarify your message
column9: Amplify your message
column11: marketing, communications, public relations, publicity, tourism, travel, nonprofit

column1: Learning Analytics For Achievement and Engagement
column5: Shabbi Luthra (American School of Bombay)
column6: Nearly half of 5th-12th graders are disengaged in school. Engagement is a proxy for achievement (or not) in school and beyond. Similarly, being hopeful is a better predictor of success in college than either GPA or SAT scores. At the American School of Bombay we_re exploring how learning analytics and assessing achievement and engagement may reveal a bigger picture to help teachers support student intrinsic motivation, engagement, and hope to drive achievement and success in school and beyond.
column7: Learn how student data can be visualized to support their learning.
column8: Learn how visualizing engagement data is an important tool for personalizing learning
column9: Learn how data analytics and visualization could transform schools and education.

column1: One-to-one selling: a false frontier for data?
column5: David Lloyd (Wunderman UK)
column6: Businesses are becoming more adept at collecting and using data in real-time. A holy grail for some is individualized pricing, whereby an ecommerce platform can use what it knows about you; purchase history, demographics, and algorithmically offer a price it thinks you will pay. We have become accustomed to airlines dynamically varying pricing around demand, but what if price discrimination became about you as an individual? What if that online movie rental was a bit more expensive for you than for those across town, or even your neighbours? Netflix recently found they could improve profits by 1.4% through price discrimination. Could this become the norm or be a false frontier for data?
column7: How businesses use data to dynamically change pricing.
column8: How businessess might individualize pricing based on what they know about you.
column9: That one to one selling is or isn't going to become the norm.

column1: The Truth About Social Gaming & Adaptive Learning
column5: Trent Teti (Blueprint LSAT Preparation)
column6: The traditional classroom model in which an instructor teaches a group of students with a textbook is being quickly replaced by dynamically-generated online curricula, which promise more social engagement, gamification, and mobile access. But is this technology a fad or does it improve student learning? What real world advantages do social gaming and adaptive learning offer? What are their liabilities?How can educators, schools, and startups begin to build a modern educational experience?After years of developing a socially gamified, adaptive learning environment, we'll share our findings about the advantages and costs of digital learning platforms.
column7: We'll give data driven examples of how particular kinds of social gaming and adaptive learning benefit students.
column8: We'll explain the real world costs and pitfalls associated with constructing and implementing an online learning platform.
column9: We'll give practical suggestions for the most effective implementations of social gaming and adaptive learning and advice for what to avoid.

column1: Tweet Insights:  A study of 27 Twitter Communities
column5: Kimberly Chulis (Northwestern University)
column6: This session explores the community structures and characteristics of members of 24 Twitter brand communities across retail, insurance, automotive, beverage, luxury auto, luxury good, pharma and technology sectors.  We will see how these communities vary in ways that have an impact on brand outcomes.  Next we will dive into differences across demographic and regional groups from a luxury vs. normal brand perspective.  The study also studies 3 health topic communities (cancer, diabetes and asthma) and observes how subsegments of the community differ and how these community characteristics relate to health outcomes.
column7: Validate the existence and present a framework for Twitter communities and their members subsegments and motives.
column8: Identify microsegment-level Twitter community behaviors associated with positive and negative brand and health outcomes
column9: Understand how interaction motives differ for luxury vs. normal brands, how Tweeter motives vary by industry, and how they differ by health community

column1: What Tech Makes Possible in EDU Research
column5: Christopher Wolfram (Wolfram Research)
column6: Few educational studies quantitatively focus on smaller-scale interactions. The use of modern technologies can help fill that gap.  In education, potentially interesting data is everywhere (even inside something like a class chat function).  Sick and bored one day, I decided to study my class' communications. Once the decision to study this data was made, it was easy to see what interesting information could be extracted.In this talk, I will walk through how this study was conducted using features of an online classroom environment and modern data analysis technology.  I will discuss study design, data collection, results, and spend a good amount of time on the analysis performed.
column7: Nearly all data is good data-learn how to extract interesting things from data that you didn't even know you had (or even know was data).
column8: Learn how modern data analysis is making new things possible in educational research.
column9: Along the way, learn about some of the dynamics of an online class-some of which may carry over into non-online education.

column1: You want to show them WHAT? A Talk on Public Data
column5: Christopher Laubenthal (Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation)
column6: Data collection tools and systems are at the heart of data use in education, but they are insufficient if they do not facilitate access, analysis, and visualization. EdWise, developed and released publicly, is an innovative mechanism that organizes aggregate, publicly available data from two state education data systems to support analysis about schools and districts at no cost to the user. Hear about EdWise, why and how it came to be, and what it looks to accomplish.
column7: Recognize the current use of administrative education data, by many stakeholder groups, and how EdWise looks to change it.
column8: Outline categories of education data consumers with their different desires for and fears about education data.
column9: Identify uses of EdWise for education administrative needs

column1: Bringing preschool to the middle of nowhere
column5: Mikkel Storm (Waterford Institute)
column6: You wouldn_t put a four-year-old on a two-hour bus ride, would you? This is exactly what we_re asking many of our isolated communities to do for preschool. To accomplish the crucial goal of closing the early learning gap, we need to remember children in isolation without access to schools, libraries, museums, the Internet or even electricity. Many of these children enter school behind their peers, which can have a lasting negative impact throughout their academic career. By using Raspberry Pi technology, solar panels, and a satellite connection, adaptive learning curriculum can be delivered digitally to early learners, which will effectively prepare them to succeed in kindergarten.
column7: Know the research and understand the need for closing the early learning gap.
column8: Gain an understanding of technologies to deliver curriculum in isolated regions.
column9: Learn how to implement early learning initiatives for kids in rural communities.

column1: Fun way for young students get engaged with coding
column5: Hansol Hong (Robolink)
column6: Hansol Hong runs Robolink in San Diego. Robolink has taught thousands of students how to build and code robots. While many of students enjoy learning to code when they are at our educational center, but he noticed students don't continue working on it when they go back home. There were certain group who were coding very hard and engaged with it, and Hansol will be sharing the secret about that.
column7: Understand what type of students get engaged with coding
column8: Learn how to get students get motivated with coding
column9: Know current status of coding education

column1: Little Treasures: Teaching the value of money
column5: Ritika Mathur (Fiserv)
column6: Little Treasures explores the unique perspective young children have towards the value of money and aims to build their capacity as forerunners of a more prosperous and secure future. It provides a framework to empower teachers to build & integrate a variety of activities that can be incorporated within the existing educational curriculum to make children more aware about the intangible concepts of money & wealth, in a social & playful way. These hands on tools can be used and customised by teachers to best suit their subject, the age group of the children and the context of use.
column7: Redefining the concept of money & its value for young minds
column8: Explores behavioural game based learning approach to teach children the value of money in a social & playful way.
column9: Creates an opportunity to stir interesting conversations for teachers to discuss newer ways of approaching teaching methods.

column1: Tots and TVs: Children's Learning from Screens
column5: Sarah Lytle (Institute for Learning & Brain Sciences)
column6: Screens are everywhere! Young children are spending more and more time engaged with screen media. Learn what, when, and how infants and toddler are learning from screens as well as how we can support children_s media activities. We will also discuss important cognitive advances children make during the first years of life that impact their ability to learn from screens. Finally, we will explore the many practical applications and resources for parents and educators, and ways to make the most of ever-present media technology.
column7: Participants will consider the content, the context, and the individual child in selecting screen media for children.
column8: Participants will identify ways that caregivers and parents can jointly engage with children around screen media to increase learning.
column9: Participants will understand how cognitive development influences children_s ability to learn from screen media.

column1: A Cor da Cultura (The Colour of Culture)
column5: L£cia Ara£jo (Canal Futura)
column6: L£cia Ara£jo will present Canal Futura_s A Cor da Cultura. It is a social project that takes affirmative action to enhance and preserve African-Brazilian heritage, acknowledging the history and values of African culture as a fundamental element of our society. Since its beginning in 2004 the project has produced and distributed 29.000 educational kits, comprising TV programs, Books, Games, Maps of Africa and a music CD. The management of the project is done in partnership with NGOs and educational networks around the country. Educators and social leaders are trained on the methodology of these materials for classroom use, and Futura exhibits the programs on TV.
column7: Train educators in schools and NGOs to disseminate the methodology of the educational kits as a tool for reflection and local social development.
column8: Strengthen social-educational networks with the participation of Universities and NGOs that focus on contents relating to Afro-Brazilian culture.
column9: Contribute to the effectiveness of the law in the Brazilian constitution that establishes the inclusion and valorization of Afro-Brazilian culture.

column1: Adaptive Learning improving Brazilian Education
column5: La¡s Rocha (Geekie)
column6: This session aims to explore the process that Geekie, a four year-old Brazilian startup has gone through in order to give more than 3 million students access to its state-of-the-art adaptive learning platform in 2014, passing by its 2 million people mark achieved in 2013 and the 160 thousands in 2012, the companies first operational year. It aims to clarify how that scale was achieved in such a big country with as many challenges regarding infrastructure and access.
column7: Scalability: how important is to balance its growth taking in account the need to spread to new users and an economically viable model.
column8: how to best use partnership with other organizations in order to best deploy web based solutions.
column9: how to reach the government in a developing country, where public education lacks money and technological know how and has a bureaucratic surplus.

column1: Bringing the Real STEM World to Girls in Education
column5: Jodi Halligan (CurricuLead)
column6: After 15 years in advanced Health Occupations, using all 4 STEM letters daily...I transitioned to the world of education. Now leading online instructional design, curriculum development, and teacher trainings to help integrate REAL STEM into classroom practice, I've come to a conclusion. Educational leadership needs to improve their own understanding of what STEM means beyond school before trying to promote it to girls or other under-represented groups. Luckily, as part of the CA STEM Education Advisory, I'd like to suggest that STEM leadership integrate STEM industry-aptitudes into their own practice to better understand the term and its role in the classroom through a few easy steps.
column7: Identify the relationship between S-T-E-M in the world of industry and collaborative work.
column8: Recognize the ways in which education still separates STEM into its component pieces and undermines the cross-disciplinary skills it demands.
column9: Highlight a number of steps that STEM leadership can take to capture real STEM instruction and projects through their own work approach.

column1: Computer science: America's untapped opportunity
column5: Hadi Partovi (Code.org)
column6: Software and computers are everywhere, revolutionizing every field around us. But the majority of schools don't teach computer science. Code.org believes every student should have the opportunity to shape the 21st-century and wants to turn this problem around. Code.org has already helped over 100 million students try computer science for the first time with one Hour of Code, partnered with 70+ school districts to bring courses to schools, released a free online learning platform with 10% of students in K-8 US schools enrolled. We've helped change policy in 16 states to better support computer science.  This is just the beginning of our vision to bring this foundational field to all students.
column7: Explain why computer science is foundational for all young people to learn
column8: Identify strategies for bringing computer science to your school or district
column9: Identify the historical and cultural reasons for inequity in computer science

column1: Connecting To Compete: Toolkit and Best Practices
column5: Chike Aguh (EveryoneOn)
column6: In this session, EveryoneOn will present case studies from our work in digital inclusion from around the country that has helped to connect almost 300,000 low income students and their families to affordable high speed Internet services, low cost devices and relevant digital literacy.  We will also provide a breakdown of national efforts like ConnectED and ConnectHome so that audience members can plug into and bring back to their communities to help close the digital divide that we see in too many schools and neighborhoods.
column7: Learn best practices for building coalitions for and implementing strategies to increase access to Internet services for students and families
column8: Gain resources and connections to begin digital inclusion in their communities and be connected to national efforts already underway
column9: Learn about national efforts like ConnectED, ConnectHome and other regional/local efforts to increase digital access

column1: Education as a Side Hustle
column5: Aaron Saunders (Clearly Innovative Inc)
column6: Clearly Innovative CEO Aaron Saunders will offer a short presentation about his experiences transitioning his tech-ed program, Luma Lab, from a side hustle, to a sustainable organization.  Clearly Innovative, Inc., is a minority-owned digital solutions provider located in Washington, DC.  Luma Lab is the TechEd arm of the company, whose mission is to create a world where people from underrepresented backgrounds can have a seat at the digital table as creators, innovators and entrepreneurs.
column7: Discover how CEO Aaron Saunders transitioned his side hustle of tech education, into a full-fledged and successful organization.
column8: How Luma Lab aims to create a world where underexposed people can have a seat at the table as creators, innovators & entrepreneurs.
column9: Learn about the education practices used in Luma Lab programs across the DMV region, to facilitate early learning and love for technology.

column1: Feeding the Education Supply Chain
column5: Nathan Byrd (Opportunity International)
column6: Bricks & mortar of school buildings alone do not make an education, and neither do textbooks and teachers. What if we were to develop a new multi-axis vision of education to include school survival, educational quality, relevance of education, and the financial solvency/sustainability of educational institutions to foster long-term community growth and constant support structures for children and families. Nathan Byrd, Head of Education Finance from Opportunity Intl will discuss a revolutionary approach to education that supports the entire supply chain, tuning microfinance products and services into sustainable and scale-able and impactful vehicles of educational attainment,
column7: To hear how and why one of the largest microfinance organizations is adjusting its model to revolutionize education in the developing world
column8: How does financial sustainability of educational institutions foster long-term community growth and constant support structures for children/families
column9: Why education investment has the greatest ROI?

column1: Fulfilling the My Brother_s Keeper promise in BCPS
column5: Dr. S. Dallas Dance (Baltimore County Public Schools)
column6: Throughout Dr. Dance_s tenure at Baltimore County Schools, he has made it a priority to support all students; regardless of race, ethnicity, background or ZIP code. And while he works tirelessly to make sure every student gets a fair opportunity, data show that one of the most vulnerable subgroups in Baltimore County and in the US is that of young African American males. Hear Dr. Dance discuss how BCPS provides pathways to success for these young men and has implemented initiatives to ensure their academic success. Learn about his system-wide as well as personal approach to putting supports in place for young men of color to be successful.
column7: Discuss the challenges facing young men and women of color in today_s education system _ from the view of one of the country_s toughest districts.
column8: Discuss how to use technology to overcome these challenges and how to get buy-in from teachers, schoolboards and parents.
column9: Look at how to create parity within a district that has both very wealthy schools and incredibly poor schools.

column1: Getting to 12 years of universal education
column5: Philippa Lei (Malala Fund)
column6: 62 million girls around the world are out of school, unable access a quality secondary education.  Despite pledges by world leaders to invest in girls_ education, it could be another 100 years before all girls have the opportunity to complete 12 years of education. Now is the time to act. For just $39 billion a year _ 8 days of military spending _ we can make universal education a reality. We must redouble our efforts and close the education gap so no child has to end education early. Hear Philippa Lei of the Malala Fund, discuss the Fund's work alongside Malala to lessen the education gap and ensure all girls can achieve their potential and and inspire positive change in their communities.
column7: What are the most effective ways to advocate for policy change in education at global levels?
column8: What does the Malala Fund see as the most effective ways to provide quality education for girls globally?
column9: What do world leaders need to do in order to finance education for the next generation?

column1: Girls, STEM + Storytelling: A Love Story
column5: Robin Payes (Out of Time Media)
column6: Recent studies confirm girls_ ongoing aversion to all things STEM. In this talk, I show how story can inspire girls to explore, learn and experiment with STEM learning in ways they wouldn_t outside of a story framework and how teaching STEM through storytelling offers creative opportunities to encourage them to pursue their STEM-related passions. I'll introduce five innovative ways educators are teaching STEM through story, including an educator teaching his students math by first reading a short story about a utopian society. I_ll provide book ideas for teachers and parents interested in introducing girls to STEM through story, and integrating arts with STEM for innovative STEAM learning.
column7: Demonstrate how storytelling is one of the most powerful, organic ways to get girls excited about STEM-related topics and careers.
column8: Provide teachers with five creative examples of how other educators are teaching STEM through storytelling.
column9: Offer book recommendations as a great resource for getting girls (and boys!) interested in STEM through stories.

column1: Hacking the Racial Divide: Technology Education
column5: Albrey  Brown (Telegraph Academy )
column6: The technology industry has a huge problem -- diversity. In Silicon Valley, one of the most innovative and entrepreneurial environments in the world, there_s a severe underrepresentation of people of color. But it's not just a local problem. African Americans and Latinos only represent less than 10% of the technology industry. Yet, the sector is experiencing massive growth. There will be 1.4 million computing jobs by 2020.Telegraph Academy, an accelerated coding bootcamp -- in partnership with leading coding school Hack Reactor and born from the White House's TechHire initiative -- addresses this problem by fast-tracking software engineering careers for people of color.
column7: How far-reaching is the diversity problem within technology and what are the ramifications?
column8: What are the solutions to getting people of color into technology (i.e. software engineering roles)?
column9: What is a coding school and how is it different than online degrees, technical colleges and four year programs?

column1: How Text Messaging is Leveling the Playing Field
column5: Brian Kathman Kathman (Signal Vine, LLC)
column6: We have discovered that by combining text messaging and behavioral economics we can improve matriculation and persistence rates of first generation and low-income college students. This session will show how combining data, pinpoint timing, and interactive messaging can generate high engagement (70%+) and nudge behaviors to produce huge impacts.  Developed from Harvard Research, our translation of behavioral economics principles is improving access, retention, attendance, and financial literacy.  We will discuss successes of increasing matriculation by 11% and persistence by 20%, the technology behind intelligent messaging, and how to implement this intervention in a variety of capacities.
column7: Participants will learn how text-messaging can be utilized to promote educational outcomes such as college access and success.
column8: Participants will learn how to craft effective text-messaging programs to engage students and encourage them to act.
column9: Participants will gain insight from case studies involving implementing this technology in a variety of use cases.

column1: How to Find the Perfect Employees
column5: Frank  Donner (BLKBX Creative Group)
column6: The world of digital marketing is fast paced and forever evolving.  Finding the right staff to pave the correct paths is vital.  Who do you look for and what sets them apart from the rest of the candidates.  What will your perfect employees bring to your company to ensure that you aren't left behind?
column7: Finding the person with the key elements you need for success
column8: How to keep on top of current technology trends and who is the right person on your team to do that?
column9: We look for these skills -- how do you ensure that your employees have them?

column1: Reinventing Coding Education at AMNH
column5: Christina Wallace (American Museum of Natural History)
column6: The American Museum of Natural History launched BridgeUp: STEM in 2014 to address the gender & opportunity gap in computer science. Our pilot was an after-school program for cohorts of 9th and 10th grade girls using scientific data sets (like DNA strands and CT scans of dinosaur fossils) to instill a fluency in CS through the context of life sciences - disciplines that don't suffer as much of a gender gap as CS does. Through 120 hrs of Python and SQL, plus a 2nd yr of research and project work, we are crafting a new approach to inspire, captivate, and propel girls into CS in college and career. Learn more about the success of our pilot and how to adapt our theory of change for your work.
column7: Learn why the intersection of computer science and life/physical sciences is especially compelling for high school girls
column8: Understand the rationale behind single-sex education, the cohort model, and other program design elements that contributed to BridgeUp: STEM's success
column9: Learn how to adapt the BridgeUp: STEM model for your own educational setting

column1: Sakena Yacoobi, 2015 WISE Prize for Education
column5: Sakena  Yacoobi (Afghan Institute of Learning)
column6: Description to come soon
column7: TBC
column8: TBC
column9: TBC
column10: education in fragile and conflict zones

column1: Survival vs. Success: Why Poverty Impacts Learning
column5: Ruby Payne (aha! Process)
column6: How you spend your time determines what you know.  Knowledge bases vary significantly by economic class as do the _hidden rules_ necessary to negotiate those environments.   Educational institutions assume there is a level of stability in the external environment and a shared understanding of _hidden rules._    This session will explore the realities and hidden rules of survival, stability and abundance as they interface with educational institutions.  The impacts of language, instability, institutional demands, and environmental rules of negotiation will be examined.  The information will be from a social cognition perspective, not a systems, race, gender, or disability approach.
column7: Participants will be able to explain the intersection of instability, resources, and environmental demands.
column8: Participants will be able to discuss at least 4 ways in which poverty impacts academic learning.
column9: Participants will go away with at least three strategies to increase the achievement of students from under-resourced households.
column11: social brain, social skills, emotional management

column1: The Courage to Learn
column5: Ilna Colemere (University of Texas at San Antonio)
column6: Knowledge is the ultimate form of empowerment.  When motivation, the silent ego of learning, is coupled with empowerment, it becomes the language of confidence. One voice asking for knowledge is common but one voice speaking on behalf of many is powerful. The hunger to learn provided the foundation for a basic computer skills program for 125 housekeepers.  By choice or circumstance their formal education was interrupted, leaving many to languish in the squalor of their presumed intellectual limitation. In 3 years, they have learned to navigate the tools and features of computers. The uniqueness of this experience lies in the wish they had, no matter the obstacle, learning to learn again.
column7: Define the architecture of the program thru the constructs of accomplishment, mastery, and the elegant productive skills of the program pathfinders.
column8: Outline the transformational classroom landscape of collegiality, support and respect as central to the narrative of success.
column9: Describe the accountability of success as a benefit of the granting of a wish.

column1: The Future of Global Education
column5: David Long (Tuscany Associates)
column6: As we look at the past 50 years of education, we see a dramatic, worldwide increase in elementary to post secondary educational attainment. Looking broadly at international and national data sets over the past 50 years reveals both the dramatic growth in education and remaining challenges. These data demonstrate a shift away from traditionally structured classrooms towards interdisciplinary learning that emphasizes creativity, critical thinking, and communications. This shift, lead by high end public, private, and charter schools will fundamentally change the role of teachers, students, assessments, and learning outcomes. The countries that get it right will dominate the global economy.
column7: Understand how leading public, private, and charter schools are creating a new standard in education centered around student learning.
column8: Gain a perspective on how countries really stack up in international comparisons.
column9: Understand how bigotry, chauvinism, and caste systems retard economic growth.

column1: Why Disrupt Higher Ed Now?!
column5: Troy Williams (Macmillan New Ventures)
column6: US Higher Ed has a product that does not work, ridiculous costs, and an antiquated business model. For many years we accepted this because we see extraordinary value in education. However, with the cost of college increasing over 3x in real dollars (adjusted for general inflation) over the last 35 years, even middle and upper-middle class parents find they cannot give their children the education they enjoyed. Technology has recently put a spark to this fuel: on-line education works and dramatically improves costs and access. This is a big opportunity for entrepreneurs and a challenge for the Higher Education establishment - what does the future hold?.
column7: Identify the existential issues facing Higher Education establishments
column8: Examine the impact of past decisions and the need for dramatic change moving ahead
column9: Discuss the challenges and opportunities created by the current situation and what the future might hold

column1: 10 Ways 3D Printers Can Change Education Today
column5: Mac Cameron (Stratasys)
column6: 10 Ways 3D Printing Can Change Education Today:1.	Inventing2.	Promoting  3.	Training4.	Understanding concepts 5.	Competing6.	Collaborating 7.	Exploring passions 8.	Measuring outcomes 9.	Communicating globally10.	Creating JobsI will assist these ten components with case studies, unique sample parts, and inspiring media of how education has changed by using 3D printing/additive manufacturing. It is of great importance that administrators, teachers, students, educational experts, and government officials are involved with this rapidly advancing technology.
column7: Can locate and critically evaluate information about 3D printing.
column8: Understand the role 3D printing in creativity, innovation, discovery, and expression across disciplines.
column9: Can communicate effectively about the benefits of using 3D printing.

column1: A new class of schools: The R&D microschool
column5: Christine Ortiz ([ ]schools)
column6: This session is for individuals and organizations that currently or desire to catalyze, support and launch a new class of schools - the R&D microschool: intentionally small schools specifically designed to challenge assumptions about what "school" is. We view the next generation of new school models as a design challenge, rather than an execution challenge. Stemming from the process used to launch two R&D schools in Orlando, Florida, we will introduce participants to a lean and user-centered methodology specifically developed to support designers in creating and sustaining radically innovative school models.
column7: Introduce a new hybrid methodology of user-centered design, lean startup, School Model Canvas, etc., used to design innovative school models.
column8: Articulate a "theory of innovation" that outlines the conditions that must be true for innovative new school model development.
column9: Define a new class of schools -- R&D microschool -- which seeks to catalyze change in the sector by focusing on schools as the "unit of innovation".

column1: Apply Lean Startup To Your Education Idea
column5: Lloyd Nimetz (4.0 Schools)
column6: The Lean Startup process was designed primarily for tech companies and is tough to apply to programmatic models: e.g. after school programs or even a new school model. Program founders often first struggle to define their programs, component by component, and subsequently struggle to (1) identify key assumptions embedded in their program design, and (2) prioritize & track which ones to test & validate. We created a Lean Program Canvas to help the dozens of program edupreneurs that we work with, and we'd like to share it with the education community to help you apply it to your own programs: those that you_re currently involved with or those that are still just in the idea-stage.
column7: To become familiar with the Lean Startup philosophy and methodology
column8: To define your program clearly, identify assumptions and prioritize/track which ones to test
column9: To know how to apply the Lean Startup methodology to your program or idea

column1: Bring the excitement of Shark Tank to your school!
column5: Jason  Stambaugh (LaunchGen)
column6: What makes a student log out of Facebook and quit their iPhone games? What brings an engineering student into a textiles class? The answer isn_t just strict parents: It_s local student business competitions. Local student business competitions are the most cost-effective way to engage every student with a meaningful entrepreneurship education experience. Participating students enter into an exciting, real-world learning opportunity where they explore entrepreneurship and develop invaluable entrepreneurial thinking skills. This session is guaranteed to help you take your existing student business competition to the next level, or successfully launch a new one.
column7: Understand the critical role entrepreneurship education plays in creating dynamic communities and successful careers.
column8: Identify and assess opportunities to maximize the value of a student business competition in a school or school district.
column9: Use best-practice tips and student case studies to improve an existing business competition or successfully launch a new one.

column1: Detroit or (bank account) Bust
column5: Jerry Davis (University of Michigan Ross School of Business)
column6: Entrepreneurs continue to flock to Silicon Valley to build companies and increasingly succumb to tunnel vision, focused only on a successful exit. For companies unenchanted with following the beaten path, Detroit offers an atmosphere free from the chokehold of venture capitalists where companies can make an impact in the community and revitalize Detroit.  Detroit_s collaborative environment provides a support system, many paths to success and funding in an affordable location for growing a company.Jerry Davis, professor of management at the University of Michigan_s Ross School of Business, will discuss the benefits of skipping the Silicon Valley trend and setting up shop in Detroit.
column7: Why the next generation business leaders should put purpose ahead of profit and focus on making an positive impact
column8: How can educators help entrepreneurial students and alumni embrace creating their own path
column9: Why breaking free from the financial hold of Silicon Valley & considering Detroit and cities that offer affordability is a great business strategy

column1: Do Your Dream -- Or Die
column5: Erika Hayes (ResumeGypsy.com)
column6: My name is Erika Hayes and I am the owner of a start-up called ResumeGypsy.com. I have a unique story about quitting my job (lack of passion), having my husband leave me because of it (common sense financial guy) and raising my daughter with little to no money for the next four months. ResumeGypsy.com is now growing steadily but not without me paying a huge price. I want to talk to people about making mistakes, bouncing back, mental fortitude and that thing on the inside that keeps you going. It's the thing that say if I don't do this, I will "die." Something on the inside will die.
column7: Letting life lead you to your passion.
column8: Getting your mind right.
column9: Defining success.

column1: entrepreneurship: Innovation at its best
column5: Ivo Lukas (24Notion)
column6: When we think about innovation, we try really hard to see into the future. What could we invent? What could make a difference in the world? Sometimes, innovation is about new ideas and products. Other times, however, innovation is about reinvention (what could we be doing differently?). Some of the best innovation is a fusion -- taking new ideas or products and applying them to existing methods and processes.I'll be taking you through the journey of my bootstrapped company, 24Notion-The journey through adversity and finally raising through the challengescheck out most recently at TEDx: http://bit.ly/1cgH5Ll
column7: what it takes to be an entrepreneur
column8: Innovation still the center of the pillar
column9: The philanthropist
column10: entrepreneurs, start up, innovation, csr, philanthropy

column1: Everything You Need To Know:Independent Filmmaking
column5: David Pierce (Pierce Law Group LLP)
column6: This course will act as a legal primer for everything from developing to distributing your independent film.
column7: How to develop an independent film.
column8: Financing your film.
column9: Distributing your film.

column1: How To Create An Effective Brand
column5: B. Jeffrey Madoff (Madoff Productions)
column6: _Brand_ is one of the most used, least understood terms in business. When done right, a brand is the most valuable asset a company has; worth more than property, plant and equipment put together. This lecture will set the foundation for understanding what a brand is, citing historic and contemporary examples from television and print.Not only successful brands, but once successful brands whose businesses have fallen or have gone bankrupt will be examined to learn what failed. A very common mistake businesses make is not realizing the difference between a "brand" and "branding". We will explore that critical distinction.
column7: Participants will develop a deeper understanding of what a brand is, how to create one and why it is the most valuable asset any company has.
column8: The importance of story. Why storytelling and narrative is critical to a brand.The essential components of creating a great brand.
column9: The importance of having a brand compass and sticking to it. No brand can survive without that.

column1: Innovations in Medicine Through Education
column5: Matt Wayne (Medical Impact Ventures)
column6: The session will discuss the current and future convergence of education (patient and physician) and digital health that is leading to a new approach to delivering care, measuring health outcomes and improving the quality of care and enhancing patient safety.  The discussion will walk through real world examples of how
column7: The Future of Healthcare: The Convergence of Education and Digital Health
column8: Strategic Medical Education Approaches to Improving Physician Performance and Patient Quality of Care
column9: How Education and Big Data Will Change the Delivery, Quality, and Cost of Healthcare

column1: Insight into Asia's Edtech Ecosystems
column5: Mike  Michalec (EdTech Asia )
column6: Insight into the various edtech ecosystems within Asia with emphasis on the trends, challenges, and opportunities throughout the region. Differentiating factors across countries and regions will be discussed that will provide better insight as to the gaps and needs of various markets. Innovative use of technology for improved educational outcomes will be shared with the intention of idea cross-fertilization.
column7: Attendees will be able to recognize education market trends in several Asia countries and draw comparison with US and EU
column8: Attendees will be able to better understand Asian country demographics, challenges and opportunities in the education technology space
column9: Attendees will be able to understand current edtech entrepreneurship processes and consider how they can be improved

column1: Language Barrier - Can't code? No problem.
column5: Chino Lex (tapTrax)
column6: It's the best time in history to start a company. Specifically, a tech company. "But, I don't code?"No problem. Lots of notable founders were non-technical. From Jeff Bezos of Amazon to Tim Westergren at Pandora, it's been done before, and it's not as hard as you think.Learn how to cultivate your ideas, get a product out, and build a company. All for less than one year at a four-year university.
column7: How to start a tech company without programming experience
column8: How to develop your creative idea
column9: How to be alone as an entrepreneur (and not lonely)

column1: Learning can be EPIC. Real engagement in Edtech.
column5: Marco Fisbhen (Descomplica)
column6: As more educational content is presented in digital format, more the pedagogical content gets compared and contrasted to entertainment formats, from 5 min simple, user generated contend in Youtube to Hollywood blockbusters. "Hollywood meets Harvard" should not be just an empty slogan, and over the last few years Descomplica has helped more than 20M students in Brazil with a complete _epic_ video based approach.  From video on demand to live broadcasts with 250k students, from simple talking heads to upscale productions in the Amazon forest, teachers skydiving and flying hot air balloons to show physics concepts, we're now sure that learning can be epic, and this is a scalable mindset.
column7: Help teachers and decision makers (principals etc) prioritize what they should do / be doing to engage their students in online efforts.
column8: Redefine measurements of engagement, that are, in our point of view, as important as measurements of performance.
column9: Redefine the role of teachers and school staff in this new environment as the schools are being pushed towards building epic, highly engaging content.

column1: Not Just Rocket Science: Making Space for Everyone
column5: Thomas Markusic (Firefly Space Systems)
column6: The idea of our session is to inform SXSW audiences that the era of 'NewSpace' is upon us and that the access and use of space has and will continue to change.  It is no longer the purview of governments, large corporation and billionaires.  Individuals matter and make a difference.  Entrepreneurs will continue to build space-based companies, Investors will fund these companies, Educator and Artists with increased space-based connectivity will break geopolitical boundaries to reach millions while pioneers will venture into space in the hope of Making Space for Everyone. This session will provide participants the information they need to understand how this is being accomplished and by whom.
column7: Give participants an overview on the meaning of 'NewSpace', its intended goals and potential impacts on the economy as well as our lives.
column8: Impart understanding that increased access to space at reduced costs will open up a world of possibilities for innovations by many.
column9: Supply thoughts on where 'NewSpace' goes from here for Entrepreneurs, Investors, Educators, Artists, Pioneers and You.

column1: The NEW Resume: How to Jumpstart Your Career
column5: Antonio Neves (about.me )
column6: Now more than ever, employers are heading online to source candidates, relying on Google and social media to learn about YOU. The traditional paper resume is no longer the first stop in their search _ the NEW resume is your online brand. With this digital shift in the employment landscape, it is now crucial to build an online brand that showcases your unique identity and differentiates you from the competition. In this session, Antonio Neves, about.me_s Director of Higher Education and campus, will break down what students, millennials, and all job seekers need to know in order to build a compelling online brand, network towards employment, and jumpstart their careers.
column7: Learn best practices and mistakes to avoid when building your personal and professional online brand.
column8: Gain knowledge of new online networking tools and ways to form meaningful connections with others to further your career.
column9: Understand the employment landscape and job market in today_s digital world, and why having a strong online brand is crucial.

column1: The Rise of Edupreneurs-Facilitators & Innovators
column5: Wendy Perry (Workforce BluePrint)
column6: Edupreneurs are a mix of educators, entrepreneurs and innovators, facilitating initiatives and learning with community, economic, environmental & social outcomes.  Working with teens to adults, tapping into a spark of creativity & entrepreneurship, can result in positive transformation, improved productivity and higher engagement.  When applied in Vocational Education & Training or Higher Education contexts, Edupreneurs build strong employer & industry relationships, enabling collaborative project based, supply chain, regional & national workforce development plans.  Learn about the 'best of' entrepreneurial approaches to human capital development, skills & adult education.
column7: See how educators are fostering enterprise skills, entrepreneurship and social capital
column8: Hear about innovative examples from across the globe
column9: Experience new methodologies that Edupreneurs apply to achieve exponential outcomes

column1: Using Big Business Innovation to Change Education
column5: Taryn Waters (Corwin)
column6: Over the past decade, educators, entrepreneurs, government agencies, and associations have converged to answer one question- what works best in schools to improve learning? In this session we will examine the innovative processes that non-profit, business, and technology organizations across the country have used to affect meaningful change and discuss how these same processes can be leveraged to radically transform the education industry. You will learn how to build your team, school, or organization into an innovation engine poised to redesign the education landscape, reenvision what it means to create high achieving learners, and inspire hope through a vision of a better future.
column7: Learn the innovative processes that business sectors are using to accelerate positive change and radical breakthroughs.
column8: Work with other session attendees to brainstorm, define problem statements, and begin to ideate potential solutions.
column9: Understand how to become a facilitator of exponential change and create the paradigm shift necessary to make an impact in education.

column1: Building Social Landscapes in Educational Games
column5: John Krajewski (Strange Loop Games Inc)
column6: In the interest of safety, many educational games and technologies lock down social interactions, missing one of the most important and effective means of education.  This talk discusses how we can avoid throwing out the baby with the bathwater and use social interactions to create incredibly engaging learning experiences while maintaining student safety.
column7: An understanding of the current scope of social connections being used in educational games and technology.
column8: Case studies of Strange Loops experience creating educational social experiences with Codebreakers, Scribbly Wits, and the Dept. of Ed funded Eco
column9: A look at the future of social interaction in the field of technology, making innovative use of the classroom and the role of the teacher.

column1: How Gamification Can Reignite the Desire to Learn
column5: Yu-kai Chou (The Octalysis Group)
column6: There is great potential in the field of Educational Gamification. Humans have an innate desire to learn. However, too often the current systems _get in the way of our education._Asking children what is "work", they will often say, _school and homework!_ But when asked what is "play", many will say, _video and games!_ Clearly there should be a way to help kids learn from what they do best _ play. This is why many educators are looking into a variety of new tools and techniques in Educational Gamification.Yu-kai Chou will present how Gamification is far more than just "Points, Badges, Leaderboards", and introduce the Octalysis framework, as an effective design tool for education.
column7: Identify potential factors which create impediments to student engagement and motivation.
column8: To provide a lucid understanding of gameful design as a human-focused approach for creating motivation in young students.
column9: Introduce Octalysis as an effective tool for analyzing educational systems and to design key factors for promoting engagement and motivation.

column1: Using Games to Redefine the Learning Experience
column5: Shawn Young (Classcraft)
column6: Strengthening student engagement starts with creating a learning environment that_s fun, collaborative and completely immersive. Using the same mechanics that make video games so compelling, we can transform the classroom so that students have a great time, help each other thrive and keep coming back for more! Classcraft is an online platform that transforms any classroom into a giant RPG played through the school year and redefines the classroom experience. We_ll look at what makes a good video game, at how those concepts went into Classcraft_s design and why it_s gained incredible traction in the last year, transforming the lives of hundreds of thousands of students worldwide.
column7: Learn how gaming can transform the entire school experience
column8: Learn what makes a good video game and how we can use that in school
column9: Explore different testimonials and case studies to see the tangible impact gaming can have

column1: A study on populating an EDU ecosystem
column5: Bruno Panara (Google)
column6: Chrogramming is a browser-based coding environment. It is also a customisable learning environment, a platform for sharing exercises and code snippets, and an open source project. One of the guiding objectives is to foster a community that can learn, share and make teaching programming more fun and interesting. In this session, we discuss how these elements come together, how the community is shaping around this new project, and where it_s going next.
column7: Demonstrate the creation of a custom tutorial or code snippit, witness it in action and share it locally.
column8: Demonstrate the sharing of a custom tutorial to the community; downloading, modifying deploying it to a separate machine.
column9: Identify best typologies of community interaction, participation and feedback.

column1: Context is King: truly mobile learning
column5: Thomas Holl (Babbel)
column6: _Mobile_ doesn_t mean mobile. In fact, most smartphone usage happens in the home. For learning applications, that means context, not device, is what matters. Laptops are ubiquitous in coffeeshops, tablets on trains, smartphones literally everywhere. The context of physical location, independent of device, is just one aspect of context.Prior knowledge is another: a Frenchman doesn_t learn Spanish the same way as a German. Or consider the context of motivation: how does somebody_s end goal affect their learning needs?Ultimately, context is at the heart of both learning and memory. In this talk, we will explore what this means for the present and future of self-directed learning.
column7: Understand the different aspects of context and what they mean for online learning
column8: Gain knowledge of practical ways in which we can address these aspects within the technological limitations of current mobile devices
column9: Understand the facilitating role that contextually-aware technology plays in the shift from classroom-based to self-directed learning

column1: How millennials will change the face of healthcare
column5: Ellie Kenward (Deloitte Digital)
column6: Digitally savvy millennials will increasingly look to sensors and wearable tech to keep track of parents and grandparents. Baby boomers are reinventing old age. They want to be able to manage and prevent their own health conditions.We are only at the beginning of understanding how wearable technologies and sensors can improve health, including managing chronic disease for the elderly.
column7: Learn how to leverage sensors and wearables to create a connected solution
column8: Learn how to create a mobile health monitoring system
column9: Learn what solutions are available in the marketplace
column11: wearables, personal health data, health privacy

column1: How Tech Redefines Literacy & Learning
column5: Colum Elliott-Kelly (Blippar)
column6: At school we learn about different subject matters, sometimes struggling to understand the material due to the availability and nature of classroom resources. Textbooks in particular are designed to deliver content in two-dimensional, linear ways _ Technologies like image recognition and augmented reality (_AR_) connect the physical with the digital and bring dynamic learning experiences to the real world, which goes beyond any literacy level.
