AR facilitates unique interactive engagement _ through mobile apps people can see beyond images, listen to soundscapes or manipulate virtual models to learn about the world around them through their mobile.
column7: What is the effect of interactive ('AR-enabled') print in terms of engagement, learning outcome, efficacy etc.?
column8: How can we use student data to effectively support educators, students, parents and policy makers?
column9: What are the effects of integrating tablet computers in class? (i.e. innovation of teaching, BYOD, 1:1, promoting digital literacy etc.)

column1: Low stress coding for high impact teaching tools
column5: Rob Morris (Wolfram Research)
column6: Dispel the stereotype that you have to be a programmer to build powerful teaching tools. Anyone can create amazing interactive digital content for the classroom. Need an interactive map that explores sea levels rising? No problem. Want to digitally explore the effects of a changing slope on a linear equation? Easy. These are just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to using code to create teaching aids. Learn how to build and use simple tools that bring classroom concepts to life. In this session, we_ll address how to develop interactive illustrations that are easy to use in your classroom. Now is your chance to see how little you need to know in order to create amazing materials.
column7: Review successful strategies for using code to illustrate a variety of STEAM topics.
column8: Discuss approaches to introducing code into the classroom.
column9: Give ideas for simple programs to use in the classroom, right away.

column1: Stop the Insanity: Rethinking College Admissions
column5: Roger Dooley (Dooley Direct LLC)
column6: In recent years, there has been an explosion of college applications. The Common App alone sent 3.5 million applications to its 550 members. This places a huge burden on families and schools. Students apply to more colleges to improve their odds, and schools have to evaluate many more applications. The admissions process inevitably becomes more random, and the number of students who will enroll is more difficult to predict.This situation can be improved.In this session, Dooley will look at the factors affecting the admissions process and propose several market-based solutions to improve it. These will be based on the ideas of Nobel Prize winner Alvin Roth and other leading thinkers.
column7: Why the college admissions process is broken for many students and schools.
column8: How other sectors have used market-based approaches to create better matching between two groups, and produced more satisfying results for both.
column9: How proven solutions in other spaces can be applied to create better matches between students and schools while cutting effort and cost.

column1: The Ed/Tech Disconnect: combining UX and pedagogy
column5: Nick Robinson (ELTjam)
column6: In reviewing ELT (English Language Teaching) EdTech products on eltjam.com, a common flaw we've identified is what we_ve called the "Ed_Tech Disconnect": products tend to offer either a solid pedagogical underpinning or great UX but rarely, if ever, both. The best example of this is Duolingo, an app that's wildly popular despite its pedagogical shortcomings because of strong UX. In 2013, we began working on Newsmart, an app that uses daily content from The Wall Street Journal to teach English, and we tried to address the pedagogy/UX problem from the start. In this presentation, we look at how educators, developers, designers and product managers might work together to serve learners better.
column7: to recognise how and where pedagogy and UX intersect and why they often fail to connect
column8: to evaluate different EdTech product development approaches
column9: to formulate best practice guidelines for creating EdTech products that combine effective pedagogy with great UX

column1: What if you mix Makers, Entrepreneurs & Creativity
column5: Ben  Gallagher (Melton Primary School)
column6: What do you get if you mix Makers, Entrepreneurs, Creativity & Student-voice?Hear how I combined elements from the Maker Movement, Student Entrepreneurship, incredible amounts of Creativity and plenty of student voice to lead my students through the most ambitious project of my teaching career.Hear how my students led each other through an amazing project full of making, entrepreneurship and creativity. How one students idea to use LEGO, led to creating a movie and raising money to host a screening of the event at the local cinema.Did this fit within the curriculum? Yes. Was that the basis of the project design? No, because just like LEGO you can't always follow the instructions!
column7: Attendees will understand what can be achieved by combining elements from all the different education movements rather than just focus on one.
column8: Attendees will be inspired to give their students amazing, real learning experiences that they will remember for the rest of their lives.
column9: Attendees will understand the importance of digital story telling and how to use it in a meaningful way in their classroom.

column1: 10 Signs You're Doing It Wrong (Content Strategy)
column5: Carolyn Kent (Ologie)
column6: We hate to break it to you, but odds are, you're thinking about your content strategy all wrong. You can design a killer website, utilize all the shiniest tactics in the digital toolbox, and even measure the hell out of your KPIs. But unless you start with content that moves people- and is structured for the responsive interwebs- you're wasting time plotting out the channels in which you'll distribute your message. Let's rewind, identify top content mistakes, and learn how to make content structured, integrated, adaptable, and portable across touch points in your audiences' journeys.
column7: Learn the 10 most common content mistakes and how to avoid making them over and over again
column8: Identify best practices for creating unique content and publishing it in a way that facilitates consumption and sharing across touch points
column9: Take away template goodies to help you activate on what you've learned in this session

column1: 3 Act Math: A How-To
column5: Dane Ehlert (Wylie I.S.D.)
column6: 3 Act Math is an innovative, inquiry-based lesson format designed to tackle the challenge of modeling with mathematics. In this session, I will conduct a 3 Act Math task in order to provide tools for the audience to implement these lessons. The session will also describe why these tasks are important by detailing effects on student mindset.
column7: Learn what 3 Act Math is and how to implement it.
column8: Understand why it is used.
column9: Learn about the effects the lessons have on student mindset.

column1: A Teacher Like You: Sabrina Moore
column5: Sabrina Moore (Madison Park Business and Arts Academy (Tk-5 Elementary Site))
column6: A sixth grade teacher reflects on her inspirational teaching journey, the focus of a new mini-film by A Teacher Like You. She shares her path from unmotivated student in Oakland, CA back to a classroom in the same city, where she_s created a different learning experience for her students. From blended learning tools to critical reading skills to building trust, she shares strategies for equipping students to overcome personal and academic challenges and succeed in and beyond the classroom.
column7: Gain insight into implementing blended learning in a low-income, urban classroom.
column8: Explore strategies _ both human and technological _ for becoming a successful reader and writer in the Common Core era.
column9: Discuss how to extend critical thinking beyond the classroom and apply it for real-world success, especially in underserved neighborhoods.

column1: Astrobiologists eMentoring at risk youth in STEM
column5: Dr. Grasshopper Heshan Illangkoon PhD (Blue Marble Space Institute of Science)
column6: Astrobiology is a unique medium to encourage STEM interests in k-12 youth as the field encompasses nearly every scientific discipline, while also drawing from anthropology, theology and philosophy. Students inevitably find a niche which suits or peaks their interests. A group of early career scientists dedicated to public engagement combined with their passion for astrobiology to create an online social network for science communication with an eMentoring platform for k-12 STEM education especially targeting underserved youth.. The mentoring relationship can extend from an individual student, to educators, classrooms and even family based mentoring where parents participate from their home.
column7: Educate k-12 students, teachers, administrators and families to about the resources available by real scientists to be STEM eMentors for learners.
column8: Demonstrate and encourage higher ed admins and professors that E/PO (education and public outreach) is a healthy part of a graduate student career.
column9: Public engagement by scientists is a core component in educating the public and policy makers to foster support for future "moonshots" & discoveries.

column1: Become a Digital Sherlock: Inquiry with Google
column5: Jill Galloway (Engage Learning)
column6: Learning starts with a question, but deep learning happens as we investigate and craft the solutions. Sifting through a sea of information is challenging, unless you know where to look. According to Sherlock Holmes, "The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes." So are Google tools! Learn from a Google Certified Innovator how to digitally investigate curiosities with help from Google tools and some of their hidden gems.  Some of the richest features are deep under the surface of Google Books, Earth, Expeditions, Cardboard, Art Project, World Wonders, and more.  Learn how to find and use them to feed those inquisitive minds with a new perspective on research.
column7: Understanding the value in leveraging learners' curiosity for learning through inquiry
column8: Knowledge of the features of free Google tools that can stimulate inquiry and energize the research process for learners
column9: Ideas for how to incorporate these tools into learning experiences for kids and adults

column1: Beyond the Classroom: Reality of Digital Tech
column5: Candace Salmon-Hosey (Rowan-Salisbury School System)
column6: As technology becomes more ingrained in our everyday lives, classrooms that reflect this trend have become key to educating students and maximizing student learning both in and out of the classroom. But with limited budgets and tools to create and implement a truly rich, interactive and collaborative learning experience, rolling out programs that utilize new technologies can be difficult.In this session, learn first hand the successes and struggles districts and educators have faced when implementing and managing some of the most popular initiatives, such as an iPad 1:1 program, as well as other such programs that enable unique learning environments to prepare students for the world today.
column7: Participants will learn how state of the art classrooms are utilizing technology to create a different learning experience for students.
column8: Attendees will learn about successes and struggles of implementing programs, such as a iPad 1:1 program, from educators with first hand experience.
column9: Understand different factors for educators to consider when deciding what types of programs to implement and roll out in the classroom.

column1: Boosting Achievement with Whole Brain Education
column5: Bette Fetter (Young Rembrandts Franchise, LLC)
column6: Today's educational system is focused on teaching the left brain, largely ignoring the right brain, with rapidly declining effectiveness. Increased awareness and adjustments to current assessment and educational methods can break the cycle of underachievement and teach ways that allow all children to excel and use the unique strengths of their whole brain. The impact of these fully developed minds will be reflected in our schools, communities, businesses and the global marketplace.This presentation will discuss why it is critically important for our educational systems to re-focus on whole brain education and how that will ultimately prepare students for success in an ever evolving future.
column7: Identify failing current education and assessment strategies.
column8: Understand the nuances of left and right brain thinking and how each side learns differently.
column9: Discuss instructional tactics for educating the whole brain while advancing innovation and creative thinking.

column1: Build a Culture of Creators through Emerging Tech
column5: J.D. Pirtle (Catherine Cook School)
column6: In today_s consumer culture, how do we empower students to view themselves as producers of the technologies we_ve come to rely on? This program brings design thinking to life through replicable examples of student work, completed by kids ranging from 3-14 years of age, using design, systems and computational thinking to accomplish dynamic and complex works that demonstrate creative expression and inquiry. Learn how to develop a powerful curriculum that utilizes emerging technologies such as: digital fabrication tools, robotics, computer programming, 3D printing and textile arts. When effectively integrated into the classroom, schools can cultivate a culture of creators rather than consumers.
column7: Empower students and faculty to become producers and masters of technology, rather than solely consumers.
column8: Effectively integrate emerging technologies into existing curriculums, across all traditional subject areas.
column9: Create a culture of innovation school-wide in all types of learners, grade levels and faculty disciplines.

column1: Coding in the Classroom: A Template for All Ages
column5: Kristopher Velez (American School of Bombay)
column6: Programming is no longer a higher education skill. It is an important skill that can and should be taught at all grade levels. Attendees will learn a variety of effective strategies and effective tools that will support them to teach their students the core programming concepts they need. They will also learn how coding can be used to teach subjects ranging from math, to physics, art and writing. Finally, attendees will learn about a programming continuum that outlines the major programming concepts used to create paths for successful teaching and learning.
column7: Learn a variety of tools and strategies to identify learner needs and teach your students core programming concepts.
column8: Discover how to utilize coding to deepen understandings within subjects ranging from math, to physics, art and writing.
column9: Walk away with a programming continuum of major programming concepts to help assess and develop your learners' paths to becoming skilled coders

column1: Flirting with Flipping
column5: Aubrey Harrison (Charlotte Mecklenburg Schools)
column6: This session will help teachers understand how to effectively flip their classroom by relating flipping to flirting. We will look at how an effective flipped classroom can shift the role of the teacher and the student. We will also play with some great resources that you can implement into your flip that will change the way your students learn. There are also some important strategies to consider when flipping your classroom and I will give you some helpful hints on what to try and what roadblocks to avoid. I will show you some fun activities to use to extend the learning in the classroom and create more student choice and ownership. And of course, we will mix in a little flirting too.
column7: Expose teachers to why flipped classrooms are an effective instructional strategy and how to successfully implement this into their lessons
column8: Discuss some strategies for developing and delivering content to your students and demonstrate engaging activities for students to participate in.
column9: Examine and evaluate some effective tools and resources that allow students to view content at home and engage in authentic learning in the classroom

column1: Fostering the Next Bill Nye - How Hard Could It Be
column5: Elizabeth Choe (MIT+K12 Videos)
column6: What is the place of informal web series and shows in life-long learning and _formal_ educational experiences for users and creators? Can they be used to entertain in addition to educating, and if so, how can one measure those outcomes? This session will attempt an answer through an analysis of the inaugural years of MIT+K12 Videos_ original web series, including the student-hosted Science Out Loud. It_ll trace successes and failures, video analytics, the challenges associated with presenting science as a narrative (and teaching others to do so!), and lessons learned that could inform the way we think about equipping STEM-inclined students to become inspiring advocates for their fields.
column7: Understand possibilities and pitfalls of using video as a teaching cool from a creator_s standpoint
column8: Understand methods of context-specific informal video assessment; landscape of current best practices in informal-but-informative video
column9: Understand resources necessary to create video products with particular impacts and outcomes

column1: Getting Beyond Big Ideas Toward Implementations
column5: Brian Thomas (Lightspeed Systems)
column6: Technology is everywhere - except in our schools. Paper worksheets are still the norm. Why? Money, fear, time, community and parent concerns, and lack of PD. The reasons are many. But to make real progress, we need to get beyond the concerns and move toward the possibilities. In this presentation you'll hear real-world success stories to motivate your own teams - and the rest of the organization - to realize the potential of technology for improving learning outcomes.
column7: Realize the potential of technology for improving learning outcomes
column8: IT Progress in Schools
column9: Team Motivation

column1: How technology can solve our education problems
column5: Jonathan Blank (Mojo Learning Inc.)
column6: We have long assumed that technology would provide the answers to our educational challenges. Yet, despite significant investment, study after study has shown that technology has made no improvement to children_s learning. Why?Up to now, most of the effort in technology implementation has been focused on transferring existing analog curricula and approaches into a digital format and have failed to leverage the power that technology has to revolutionize the learning environment. However, new research on how children learn and digital curriculum development has opened the door to the creation of a new generation of educational technology that promises to positively transform the field.
column7: Learn about new educational technology.
column8: Learn about advances in neuro science that affect teaching.
column9: Learn about advances in curriculum development that leverage new technology.

column1: Inspiration to Action: A Transdisciplinary Course
column5: Aaron Bradley (University of Cincinnati)
column6: It started with an ambiguous text message: "Do you have a student who could design t-shirts for Muhammad Ali?". The resulting collaboration of a public university, a non-profit museum, and a cultural icon, became the platform for a new course model - a transdisciplinary class that brings together students from up to eight different majors into one classroom to practice problem solving, collaboration, and real-world applications of classroom topics.  This session will outline designing a scalable course model, "silo-busting" classroom activities, creative engagement of external partners and industry experts, and a variety of student success stories beyond the classroom.
column7: Learn strategies for creating transdisciplinary classroom experiences with students from multiple different majors, all in the same class
column8: Learn practical strategies for engaging an external partner as the "client" for problem solving exercises and idea generation in the classroom
column9: Explore opportunities for meaningful student engagement and employment opportunities with external partners after the class project ends

column1: Johannes Itten has left the building
column5: Jay Rutherford (Bauhaus-Universitt Weimar)
column6: Almost 100 years ago Johannes Itten conceived of a foundation course at the Bauhaus which, in one form or another, is still used at most art and design schools. With this method, aspects of formgiving are supposedly learned long before they are needed for assignments. At the Bauhaus-Universitt in Weimar we use something which one might call _just-in-time learning_. Basics are not taught in one go at the beginning of studies, they are rather integrated into project-based assignments throughout the entire study period. This is much more labour-intensive for teachers, but leads in the long run to graduates better prepared for independent professional practice or further study.
column7: How to improve teaching methods for art and design
column8: Examples of student works using improved methods
column9: A bit of design teaching history

column1: Making Math Contextual, Visual, and Interconnected
column5: Kyle Pearce (Greater Essex County District School Board)
column6: When you ask North Americans whether they understand math, the response more often than not is negative. Ask whether they find math enjoyable and that number is almost certain to decrease.ÿThis is a rather deflating fact for those of us entrusted to teach mathematics to students with very similar views at best. Although it might seem as though the deck is stacked against us, we now live in an age where technology makes it possible to teach math with context and visualization. Come experience how to leverage technology to engage and inspire students to not only enjoy mathematics, but understand the beauty of this universal language we share in our classrooms each and every day.
column7: Redefine mathematics education to promote student engagement, confidence and success in one of the most plagued subject areas in North America.
column8: Promote use of visuals through technology to make mathematics relevant and thought-provoking for students to gain a deeper understanding.
column9: Provide educators with actionable steps to assist in leveraging the natural curiosity that we all have through a task oriented mathematics lesson.

column1: Mobile Technology in the EFL Classroom
column5: Ross Miller (Otemon Gakuin University)
column6: This presentation will describe the development of a course aimed at teaching students how use mobile technology to help them with their study of English as a Foreign Language.  A survey illustrating how students tend to use their phones is followed by an argument that they need to be shown how to study with their phones.  This presentation includes specific strategies and tasks that get students using their phones for language study, while developing their critical thinking skills. It concludes with an explanation for why this training is necessary. *All of the apps mentioned in this presentation are free.
column7: Participants will learn how language students can use the built-in functionality of their smartphones for improving their pronunciation.
column8: Participants will learn a variety of activities that can be immediately adapted to their own teaching needs.
column9: Participants will be introduced to a variety of apps that can be used in the language classroom.

column1: Paradigm Shift: The Power of Simulation
column5: Dan  Barstow (The Virtual High School)
column6: Imagine, today_s assignment: Heading to a Launchpad, blasting off into orbit and docking at the International Space Station. But wait a moment!  This is an ONLINE course.  Of course students aren_t actually in space, they_re sitting at their computers!  They_re reading text, seeing pictures, watching videos, interacting with each other, asking questions, developing explanations for what they see _ but they_re not really in space. Or are they?  Here_s a radical proposition - the power of a simulation. Engaging students so deeply that they focus not on the technology of the simulation, but the reality of the experience. Learn about immersive imagination _ or today's online learning lesson.
column7: What are the first steps into cyberspace to ensure a school or district offers high quality, online simulation programs?
column8: How can I create interactivity and discussion when I can_t see who is squirming in their seat. What does a successful virtual teacher look like?
column9: Because a virtual class can represent a big culture change, how do you get better buy-in from parents (and those more traditional peers!)

column1: Pop Goes The Writing Workshop
column5: M Colleen  Cruz (Teachers College, Columbia University)
column6: In our drive to help students engage in learning and become lifelong literate people, we sometimes lose sight of just how much they already know and can do outside of the classroom. In this session, I will share field-tested ways to tap into kid culture as a powerful means of merging our students lives inside and outside of the classroom. I will show how teachers can exploit the rich and diverse skills and strategies kids use outside of school as a way to build a direct and engaging connection to oftentimes challenging writing skills, such as structure, craft and significance.
column7: Identify areas of children's pop culture consumption that might be used to help achieve writing goals
column8: Explore specific skills and strategies that students employ while consuming pop culture which can be transferred to academic learning
column9: Craft ready-to-use instructional practices and objectives to teach some of the most challenging aspects of writing, such as structure, theme and craft

column1: Preparation for Tech-Centric Classrooms
column5: Erin Clancy (UMD)
column6: To prepare students for a technologically driven world, teachers must create tech-centric lessons and classrooms. Faculty in higher education can prepare pre-service teachers for this advanced classroom structure by integrating technology into their courses and student-teaching placement requirements. This session will highlight ways technology is utilized in teacher prep: virtual classroom exercises to increase use of effective practices and improve classroom management; Twitter chats for networking and lesson exchange; student data collection; and skill-focused "podcast" creation tailored to student needs.
column7: Participants will understand unique ways technology is integrated into teacher preparation.
column8: Participants will gain knowledge on benchmark themes teacher-prep programs utilize to identify and integrate technology.
column9: Participants will recognize key characteristics of tech-centric curriculum and classrooms.

column1: Preparing Students for Jobs That Don_t Exist Yet
column5: Sandy  Bartle Finocchi (Carnegie Learning, Inc.)
column6: The world has changed, and as a result, how students learn is also changing. The top jobs in 2015 didn_t exist in 2004, and today_s students will be taking new positions and using new technologies that haven_t even been invented yet. With technology in every aspect of a student_s life, educators need to discover new, engaging ways to prepare them for a digital world where they can can think critically and generalize their learning to do anything and everything.
column7: Discuss making instructional shifts to focus on students becoming critical thinkers.
column8: Share tactics and strategies from K-12 settings where using technology in an innovative way has improved student outcomes.
column9: Form tangible actions to create learning environments that promote critical thinking strategies inside and outside classroom walls.

column1: Promoting Ownership with Student Led Conferences
column5: Mary Beth  Mullikin (Fulton County Schools)
column6: While it is crucial to communicate student progress with families, it can be ineffective when the teacher is doing all of the heavy lifting. Put the learning in the students' hands by giving them the opportunity to "take the wheel" during family conferences.  Turning traditional conferences into student-led conferences shifts the responsibility and focus to the student. This session will explain the benefits, formats and the roles of students, parents and teachers during conferences. We will investigate how to best prepare students for this new experience, as well as examine innovative, ready-to-use resources that will support them in the process, such as digital data folders.
column7: Participants will examine the benefits of student-led conferences and how they can positively impact student achievement and responsibility.
column8: Participants will observe how digital data folders can be used to take student-led conferences to the next level in their clasroom.
column9: Participants will understand the different formats of student-led conferences and how to execute each format effectively.

column1: Reading on Digital Devices: What's Hot, What's Not
column5: Colette Kastner (Hopkins School District)
column6: A reading revolution is underway in our classrooms as teachers leverage the power of iPads, Chromebooks, and digital devices for reading across curriculums. This session will highlight how using digital text, fiction and nonfiction, in your classroom will engage students and redefine how you deliver content and assess student learning. We will also address the challenges of accessing digital text. Discover what_s hot and what_s not when it comes to using digital devices for reading in the k-12 classroom.
column7: Highlight apps and online reading resources that increase student comprehension, engagement and student choice for grades k-12.
column8: Identify benefits and challenges students have reading and interacting with text on digital devices.
column9: Identify the challenges teachers face with publishing restrictions on purchasing fiction for digital devices.

column1: REVEL Helps Bring Course Content to Life
column5: Karl Clark (Coastal Bend College)
column6: To improve learning outcomes for students, Coastal Bend College is leveraging advances in digital learning technology to better engage students. In 2014, Professor Karl Clark began a pilot program with an immersive learning technology platform called REVEL. After utilizing the technology in his _U.S. History since 1865_ course for three chapters, students_ positive feedback led to Clark_s utilization of the technology for the remainder of the course. Hear how REVEL helps students connect with the course material, both inside and outside of the classroom, with the goal of increased learning and best practices for evaluating/exploring emerging technologies that enhance the learning experience.
column7: Learn about a technology that provides course content in bite-sized portions and is integrated with narrative, interactive activities and videos.
column8: Learn more about an immersive, online learning tool that brings study materials to life to keep students engaged.
column9: Hear the benefits of embracing a 21st century digital format that delivers content in a manner that facilitate true comprehension of course materials.

column1: Saving the World with Media Literacy
column5: Julie Smith (Webster University, Southern Illinois University - Edwardsville)
column6: American kids spend an average of 11 hours per day with electronic mass media. But nobody is talking about it!I think media literacy needs to be taught at every age, in every classroom. Get it out of the library!So in my session I will show teachers WHY they need to incorporate it, and HOW ...so they leave the session fired up to create critical media consumers.I am high energy with relevant, hilarious examples of how to engage students in this topic regardless of subject matter.
column7: WHY media literacy education is necessary
column8: HOW to incorporate media literacy regardless of subject matter/age
column9: WHERE to find media literacy education tips and tools

column1: STEM2STEAM: Using Digital Media 4 Science Learning
column5: Jayde Lovell and Bec Susan Gill (New York Hall of Science)
column6: Today_s teens send snapchats instead of email, upload YouTube vlogs instead of keeping diaries, and use emoji_s instead of words. They communicate visually and collectively - and yet science is still predominately taught through textbook. And we wonder, _where are all the young people in STEM?_ At the New York Hall of Science, we're combining young people's passion for digital media and with professional video production training _ to create the next generation of creative STEM advocates. This first-of-its-kind program demonstrates how adding arts to STEM (to create _STEAM_), can inspire student learning across many kinds of STEM education institutes _from schools to libraries & museums.
column7: How to successfully use video & social media production as education tools, particularly for educators with no background in video
column8: Ways to introduce formal video production programs to museums, libraries, and schools, within the existing curriculum and budget
column9: Case studies of successful digital content production programs in education organizations _ and lessons learned.

column1: Teaching Open Source in our Schools
column5: Nicole Engard (ByWater Solutions)
column6: There is a huge hole in computer science student education these days - open source software (OSS). The use and development of OSS is on the rise with _78 percent of companies running OSS and employers watching sites like GitHub to see if applicants have contributed to open source. Participation in the development of OSS teaches students not only how to code, but how to work in diverse teams, communicate effectively and how to problem solve on the job. This presentation will introduce instructors of all age groups to what OSS is, why students should be involved and how to educate/mentor students in the world of OSS.
column7: Attendees will learn what open source software is
column8: Attendees will leave with a toolbox of open source applications they can use/teach in their classes
column9: Attendees will know how to get started with an open source education program at their school

column1: The Complementary Method-Learning with Empowerment
column5: April Terrazas (Crazy Brainz Publishing)
column6: All of your students received above a 90 on their last exam. There is no bullying in your classroom. Your students work together as a team. How do you feel about that? The Complementary Method is a platform for empowerment, kindness and anti-bullying. In less than 10 minutes per class day, this method boosts self-esteem, creates an environment of camaraderie, and therefore reduces the occurrence of poor behaviors and bullying. The Complementary Method trial phase begins Fall 2015 with 30+ elementary classrooms across the United States. Results, feedback and improvements will be discussed at the conference. A mini-classroom demonstration of the method will be presented plus Q&A.
column7: Create a positive learning atmosphere in the classroom. Students treating adults and classmates with respect and admiration.
column8: Implement an empowering method that takes less than 10 minutes per day. The Complementary Method is used ideally 3x/day, 1 to 2 minutes each time.
column9: Increase grade point average. Empowerment, commendation and visualizations will increase self-worth in ALL students, leading to higher grades.

column1: The Dirty 30:  30 apps & extensions for classrooms
column5: Jay Eitner (Waterford Township Public School District)
column6: With over 700 apps being produced and published a week, who has time to sort and determine what works best in classrooms?  Join the 2015 national Superintendent of the year Jay Eitner for an overview of 30 apps and chrome extensions that will enhance instruction, make life easier for you as an educator, and most importantly, help your students succeed.
column7: The learner will be able to identify key applications & extensions that can be used in today's classrooms.
column8: The learner will be able to enhance current instructional practices by applying the apps and extensions to current practices.
column9: The learner will be able to collaborate with other peers and advance the current knowledge base in the classroom and the school.

column1: The Paper Diet: The true story of going paperless
column5: Jaimie Dubuque (Franklin Middle School)
column6: Thinking about going paperless in your classroom or district?  Step away from the Pinterest board, and leave the tweeting to the birds.  This is the story of what really happens when a teacher goes paperless in her classroom.  For six months (starting in September), I'm documenting the breakthroughs and downfalls of going on the Paper Diet, and what happens when I ditch paper in an effort to more efficiently use my time and resources to meet my students' needs.  In this session, I'll share my experience and give tips for those looking to leave paper behind.  Call me Shakespeare, because I'm writing the next great comedy, or tragedy, or love story; I'll let you know in March.
column7: Session attendees will analyze the risks and rewards of joining the paperless movement.
column8: Session attendees will experience the long-term effects on teachers, students, and parents in a paperless classroom.
column9: Session attendees will leave with a plan for mapping their own path to going paperless.

column1: Transforming Your Class with iBooks Author
column5: Justin Bell (Northeast Magnet High School)
column6: I will lead an interactive session using Presentain, which will allow the audience to post questions, respond to polls, and receive the slides along with my voice afterward. We will start with the why and the growing gap between students and older literature. Then we will delve into examples of different widgets that can be used in multi-touch books and how these various widgets will address various student learning styles, enable differentiation, and offer individualized instruction with instant feedback.This is a one-hour session; however, if the audience prefers, I can lead a workshop afterward in any available space.
column7: The audience will see why interactive books are a necessity.
column8: The audience will walk away with practical examples of the widgets used in a classroom.
column9: The audience will see the different steps in creating a multi-touch book.

column1: Transmedia Teaching Tools
column5: Christine McGlade (Analytical Engine Interactive Inc.)
column6: Transmedia storytelling is an immersive media form that engages audiences in story worlds where narratives unfold across multiple platforms, with audience participation.  Transmedia storytelling practices offer compelling tools to transform a flipped classroom into an immersive learning world.  In this session we_ll look at the _rules_ Transmedia producers use in their storytelling, and we will map them onto instructional design that can be used on both sides of the flip.  We_ll walk through three unique ways that we have created a Transmedia learning experience for students, and leave participants with ideas and tools they can try right away in their classroom or elearning business.
column7: Participants will understand what is meant by Transmedia storytelling and how it is used to create immersive experiences across platforms & screens
column8: Participants will learn new ways to combine educational media of various types with learner participation to enhance learning
column9: Participants will learn how to use Transmedia storytelling techniques to enhance learner engagement and participation inside and outside the class

column1: VR and Holographic imaging in the classroom
column5: George Warren (zSpace, Inc)
column6: With the rise of new interactive holographic and VR systems, classrooms stand to gain the most. How are schools utilizing these new tools to help introduce difficult to teach, hard to learn concepts or even dangerous experiments? How can we teach students to use their hands in lab situations without the liability inherent in labs? By using zSpace for Education, we will demonstrate how new schools and districts are taking advantage of this powerful tool for the classroom.
column7: VR for the Real World is available today and is a dynamic learning tool for the classroom.
column8: Early learning for Life Sciences is fun and interactive with this type of tool.
column9: Common limitations for CTE is overcome with multiple models for nursing, engineering and other career tech objectives.

column1: Walk the Earth from your Seat
column5: Nicholas Clayton (Victor Elementary School District)
column6: As a teacher there is always that age old question, "Where on Earth am I going to take my students on a field trip this year? The museum that has old exhibits and a four hour bus trip from hell?" How about space to talk to the ISS crew, Switzerland to discuss talk to the pilot of the first solar powered airplane that will round the globe? Well all is possible, and more, when you do some exploring of these sites, programs and tips I offer in this session!
column7: Educators will leave with knowledge of how to design lessons using Google Earth/Maps and virtual reality via Google Cardboard.
column8: Educators will gain useful educational resources for global communication in teaching.
column9: Educators will be able to plan lessons in all subjects using the information shared in this session.

column1: What Hip-Hop and Hackers can teach about Literacy
column5: Sage Salvo (Words Liive, LLC)
column6: With "What Hip-Hop and Hackers can teach about Literacy', we at Words Liive have designed a presentation that isolates the natural language structures replete in urban music and computer programming language to develop mastery over traditional classroom texts. Through our processes, students gain skill augmentation of traditionally-tested comprehension skills. We will highlight the work of specific urban artists and famous 'cult' hacker personnel to illuminate the similar treatment they give to grammar syntax. Specific attention will be given to the demarcation of surface structure grammar and deep structure grammar which will highlight the linguistics work of Noam Chomsky.
column7: We'd like our participants to export the knowledge of a process that prepares lesson plans for today using urban artists and computer programming code
column8: We'd like our participants to export the knowledge of how to integrate arts education into core curricula at multiple points.
column9: We'd like our participants to export the knowledge of what types of reading and writing skills will be requisite for the 21st century.

column1: Why we need to think more like programmers?
column5: Miriam Bogler (Project Pals, Inc.)
column6: Computer programming is hot again. The reasons mentioned most are practical in nature, such as students_ future career prospects or finding qualified workers for the technology industry, as well as big reasons, such as the country_s economic competitiveness. However, one of the most important reasons for learning programming relates to improving problem-solving skills and enhancing creativity--skills that are in great demand these days. As Steve Jobs once said _Everybody in this country should learn to program a computer...because it teaches you how to think._ In this talk I will explore how programming can improve our problem solving skills in other domains.
column7: Learn how programming can improve problem solving skills
column8: The skills that can be gained by learning programming
column9: How programming should be taught to maximize benefits for the learner

column1: 10 & Change: Urban Prep's Founding and Impact
column5: Tim King (Urban Prep Academies )
column6: In 2006, Tim King opened the first Urban Prep campus with a simple goal:  improve the educational outcomes for African-American males. Since then, Urban Prep has achieved a 100% college acceptance rate for its graduates, grown from one school to a network of schools, created an innovative program supporting college students, launched a workforce development program and served over 2,000 young African-American males. On the 10th anniversary of opening the first school, Tim reflects on his journey as an educator, what it took to build the country_s first network of public charter high schools for boys and the secret to Urban Prep's success. (Hint: there's no secret)!
column7: To tell a story of hope, growth, and success in and for the Black community that can inspire all communities to look inward and grow out.
column8: To demonstrate the change that can occur for our students and schools when we see a need and make the decision to fill it.
column9: To share lessons learned, challenges faced, and opportunities yet untapped with those excited to transform the education landscape.

column1: Building Higher Education Leadership Communities
column5: Evan Silberman (New York University (School of Social Work))
column6: This session will focus on successful efforts to build a cross-departmental, highly collaborative, and cross-functional IT community of practice within a large academic institution.  With over 1,000 IT professionals spread across multiple continents _ both on campus and overseas serving the global programs _ New York University is ideally positioned to serve as a learning lab on how to effectively manage and control organizational silo tendencies as well as explore opportunities to leverage specific technology toward building communities.
column7: Learn how to breakdown institutional silos
column8: Learn how to foster collaboration to reduce redundancy and save time and money
column9: Learn how to retain employees through people networks

column1: Future Ready: A Systemic Plan for Transformation
column5: Thomas Murray (Alliance for Excellent Education)
column6: When we analyze the US education system and classrooms across our nation, we see dramatic differences and gaps in innovation. Side-by-side images of classrooms from 1915 and one from 2015, yields eerie similarities in many schools today, even with the 100-year difference. What can be done? How can schools and classrooms transform into ones that are student centered, personalized, and leverage the power of technology? Districts and schools across the nation are transforming into ones that are Future Ready, revamping such aspects as teacher empowerment, personalized professional learning, innovative learning spaces, community partnerships, digital learning initiatives, among others.
column7: The Future Ready Framework will provide school leaders with eight key areas to guide their digital learning transformation.
column8: District leaders will gain access to the Future Ready Dashboard; a free systemic planning tool.
column9: Models, examples, and resources will be shared that leaders can use the next day to help their transformation!

column1: Future Work Skills
column5: Marina Gorbis (Institute for the Future)
column6: We're in the midst of a historic transformation in the nature of work and structure of jobs. A host of technologies_from workplace automation to platforms for task coordination such as Uber and TaskRabbit_are transforming not just what people do to earn their livelihoods but, at a much deeper level, how we organize to create value. Completely new archetypes of workers are emerging, like micro-taskers signed up on multiple platforms such as Lyft, Gigwalk, Upwork, etc., who don't work 8-5 jobs but rather stitch together tasks in flexible niches of time. This talk envisions the skills people will need and how learning will transform to navigate this future of global labor arbitrage.
column7: How learning is changing to meet the needs of the new economy
column8: What skills people will need to navigate the future of global labor arbitrage
column9: What dilemmas are we facing in this emerging future of work

column1: Managing EdTech
column5: Karl Rectanus (Lea(R)n)
column6: Modern teachers rely on various tools to engage with students and enhance learning. Technology supports education in many ways, but ed-tech is often difficult to manage within schools and across districts. Administrators constantly wonder if they are spending on the best products, but only teachers know what really works in their classrooms. That's why schools, districts and states need a complete ed-tech management system, such as Lea(R)n. The LearnTrials platform connects educators, so they can share feedback on any digital tool. This informs decision-makers thinking about how they spend on education technology products.
column7: Blended Learning - First, we will discuss how technology facilitates this modern approach, which personalizes each student's classroom experience.
column8: EdTech - Our research indicated the 8 most important factors to consider when making decisions about digital resources.
column9: LearnTrials - Finally, we will explain why thousands of educators already use our platform to manage technology in classrooms, schools and districts.

column1: Mapping Pathways for Student Success and Equity
column5: Susan Thomason (Austin Community College)
column6: The accountability movements of our time and flatline funding fueled by budget cuts have placed a variety of challenges on the doorstep of higher education institutions.  In addition to limited resources, some institutions now face declining enrollments, increasing operation costs and greater competition for external funding.  As we struggle to redefine priorities and establish new student-centered strategies to address completion, retention and success rates, it is clear that institutions have to do a better job of integrating planning and proposed solutions. Process mapping helps identify critical needs and priorities that address common goals for superior student pathways and success.
column7: Identify research-based elements of student pathways
column8: Review student pathway examples and select key features
column9: Examine process mapping techniques and strategies to integrate cross-institutional support and services in planning

column1: Micro-credentials for Teacher Leadership
column5: Mary Strain (Teaching Matters)
column6: This session will examine an innovative  partnership between Teaching Matters - a non profit organization and the NYC Department of Education focused on curating teacher leadership competencies, supporting teacher leaders to lead high impact collaborative learning teams and recognizing demonstrated competencies with micro-credentials. Micro-credentials provide recognition for teacher leader accomplishments, promote transparency and focus on outcomes linked to student achievement and improved teacher practice. Participants will examine a competency- based rubric that connects key initiatives to core instruction and examine the impact of micro-credentialing for educators.
column7: Understand a competency-based approach to assessing and recognizing teacher leaders
column8: Examine how competency based approach to professional development leads to an outcomes orientation
column9: Discuss the implications of micro-credentials for educators in the context of key district investment areas and teacher career pathways

column1: Set Sail with a Pirate Leader
column5: Hal Roberts (Hal Roberts Consulting)
column6: The presentation focuses on attributes of an effective leader. Hal uses the word _PIRATES_ as an acronym. Similar to the book _Teach like a PIRATE_ that Hal studied, hosted the author, Dave Burgess at his home & had him present to his district. He will share from his 38 years in education, life in the NFL, and 30 years of leadership. The session focuses on going against the status quo and  flies the black flag to show passion & perseverance; immersion & integrity; the importance of relationships; using authority to gain followers; trust as a huge asset; enthusiasm & service. Hal also uses video clips to enhance this presentation. Don_t miss out on this informative, fun & interactive session.
column7: learn attributes of an effective leader
column8: discover some excellent resources (books & videos)
column9: have fun & interact with the presenter

column1: Stop Teaching: Sharing Your Education Story
column5: Pete Janhunen (The Fratelli Group)
column6: Education experts struggle to win over their most important audiences and build support for their point of view among non-experts. We help them overcome these struggles and deliver winning messages on a routine basis. In our experience, successful communications takes three steps, outlined below. This session will explore _ and model _ these principles and show attendees how to win support and strengthen their advocacy efforts for the long haul.
column7: How to study your audience and their values.
column8: Importance of developing a succinct message.
column9: The art of sharing stories about real people and real challenges.

column1: Student Advisory: Empowering Student Voice & Ideas
column5: John Weiss (Neutral Zone)
column6: High School is a place where many students feel like their voices are not heard.  Due to the vast academic requirements placed on schools and teachers, many educators feel like they simply don't have the time to involve students in their own learning let alone across the broader issues of the school like climate, governance and policy.  This session will introduce Student Advisory, and the Youth Driven Space approach, as a successful model to provide student voice and ideas.  Implemented across 20 high schools in Michigan, Student Advisory incorporated student voice into school reform efforts through the development of authentic youth-adult partnerships.
column7: Examine the import of student voice through current research and practice
column8: Consider youth-adult partnerships as a driver for supporting authentic student voice in schools.
column9: Learn the stages of student advisory in order to consider possible steps for starting or increasing student voice.

column1: Superhero Movies Will Make You a Better Leader
column5: David Kahn (Rendina)
column6: I love superheroes. Always have. Being a solemn professional, my fascination is not based around their action-packed exploits or their salacious soap operatic stories; I am captivated by the ways Superman, Spider-Man and their costumed companions embody archetypal leadership skills that are applicable to us mere morals. Sourcing academic research and case studies (plus 75 years worth of comic books), this workshop will discuss how each of us can develop our leadership skills to more effectively influence others, provide strategic value, and enact meaningful change.
column7: Understand how superhero stories can be utilized to improve leadership practices
column8: Gain insight and practical skills to lead any team
column9: Learn the "Five Superpowers of Leaders" and how that can be immediately applied

column1: Teacher as Creative Professional
column5: Peter Nilsson (Deerfield Academy)
column6: Let_s shift the narrative. Teaching is extraordinarily creative work. This doesn_t mean crayons and coloring books_it means teachers are designers of experiences, technicians and artisans who construct and execute plans based on science and intuition. Teachers are creative professionals who generate new work. Every day.Conceived in this way, the teaching profession reveals its complexity. This talk dives deeply into this new way of thinking about what teachers do. It looks at what we know about creativity, intrinsic motivation, accountability, professional development, collaboration, and more. It includes research, art, experience, and, of course, the reflections of teachers themselves.
column7: To see the profession of teaching in a new way
column8: To better understand how we can support the work of teaching
column9: To nudge the narrative of how teachers are portrayed, elevating it and celebrating it

column1: Building the first adaptive MOOC
column5: Zachary Wissner-Gross (School Yourself)
column6: Although 2012 was declared the "Year of the MOOC," massive open online courses continue to struggle with student retention and engagement. In an effort to counteract these trends, our team designed and launched the first two adaptive MOOCs (covering high school-level algebra and geometry), in which each student receives personalized feedback and proceeds down unique learning paths through lessons and assessments. I will be sharing the lessons our team has learned in maintaining these nonlinear courses at scale, how we continue to leverage student data, and student reaction and behavior in this adaptive setting (spoiler alert: students are five times more engaged).
column7: What "adaptive" does mean, and what it doesn't mean.
column8: How to leverage student data in designing and implementing adaptive MOOCs.
column9: Understanding student behavior in adaptive vs. linear MOOCs.

column1: Changing lives through technology and CoderDojo
column5: Mary Moloney (The CoderDojo Foundation)
column6: Changing lives through technology; encouraging and empowering youth across the world through technology, coding on a self led learning basis at CoderDojo.A keynote delivered by Mary Moloney discussing self-led Learning, the global impact of CoderDojo on encouraging and empowering youth, technology changing lives, problem solving and project based learning. This session can be followed with a Q&A session.Mary will provide insights and share her wealth of knowledge and expertise on technology, coding, self-led Learning, encouraging and empowering youth, technology changing lives, problem solving and project based learning.
column7: How to engage and empower young people through technology and education.
column8: How to address the technology skill gap currently being experienced across the world.
column9: How to grow and sustain an open source, global movement fo free coding clubs for kids.

column1: Knowledge sharing and Collaboration Communities
column5: Lucian Tarnowski (BraveNew.com)
column6: 'Education is what others do to you, Learning is what you do for yourself'.  This session will explore peer-to-peer collaborative learning communities and their impact on education.  The session will explore case studies, trends as well as future predictions.  Learning communities help enable everyone to go from consumers of content to participants.  They help recognize and reward people for their informal learning.  We will explore how online community environments can democratize access to professional learning and in doing so create more of a meritocracy around opportunity.
column7: Online community building best practices and case studies.
column8: How to align incentives to recognize and reward learners in real time.
column9: Exploring the future of education and where it meets lifelong learning and employment.
column13: This is an video example of a closing keynote I did for 400 people at the Global Action Summit in Nashville.  The title of my talk was 'Creating Abundant Communities: The Second Human Potential Movement'.  You can see the video here: http://livestream.com/plussocialgood/globalactionsummitplussocialgood/videos/68675130 (watch from 33 mins in).
column16: Here are examples of slides I use: http://app.fileboard.com/p/3dbm7dwt

column1: Resilient Schools through Living Learnscapes
column5: Vanessa Carter (Occidental Arts & Ecology Center)
column6: Imagine our public schools as resilient community hubs demonstrating innovative models of sustainability while meeting Common Core Standards by connecting learning to PLACE.  Imagine the next generation of solutionaries designing regenerative systems through collaborative R&D with industry professionals. Imagine flocks of ecologically literate young people accustomed to whole systems thinking. How? Installing Living Learnscapes where campus is an opportunity for inquiry, observation & biophilia. This process takes deep community involvement, including educators, district leadership, local businesses, investors and designers to advance solutions that drive ecological justice for all. Join us!
column7: Attendees will explore an inspiring array of Living Learnscape designs linked to curricula that meets Common Core and STEM learning outcomes.
column8: Attendees will see models of community resilience using school campuses as their organizing hubs.
column9: Attendees will consider policy change opportunities that encourage thriving ecosystem health in the context of resilient school communities.

column1: Simplify: Carry-on Teacher in a Checked-Bag Class
column5: Kevin Croghan (Denver Public Schools)
column6: This session is designed to provide thoughts, resources and time for us to work together to help simplify our work lives.  Brass tacks: I like minimalism, I dig gadgets and tools that I can keep on my person, and I love the idea of going mobile.  In the session, we_ll cover tips and tricks, discuss great sites for ideas for everyday items to carry, and we will start to craft our own personal teaching toolkits for minimizing what what we need to manage our workflow.  This session works well for all, and it could be particularly valuable for educators who share teaching space.  In this session you will want a laptop.
column7: Discuss basics of minimalist thought to classroom environment
column8: Model a way to prioritize when selecting what is "essential" in your classroom
column9: Reflect on session content and begin to apply to personal practice

column1: Write Local
column5: Kristin Hoffmann (NC State University)
column6: Research suggests writing achievement can be increased by providing students with authentic, problem-based assignments with a real-world purpose & audience. WRITE LOCAL leverages crowdsourcing technology to create a scalable repository of authentic, problem-based writing prompts. Local businesses add to the repository by submitting letters of need (authentic problem solving tasks) along with supplemental informational documents. Students then research, plan, draft, & submit their solutions back to the local business in one central space. As a result, students not only acquire relevant content knowledge, but they also gain an understanding of the type of tasks professionals in their area perf
column7: Participants will understand the importance of informational reading and writing ability as it pertains to academic and workplace success.
column8: Participants will be able to describe the impact of authentic, problem-based writing prompts on expository writing achievement and engagement.
column9: Participants will learn ways to leverage existing technology to increase literacy achievement in K-12 classrooms.

column1: Behavior Systems: The Hidden Achievement Factor
column5: Stacy Morgan (Emergent Tree Education, Inc.)
column6: As campus and district strive to increase student achievement for increasingly diverse learners, the effects of behavior systems is often forgotten or not prioritized. But research has overwhelming indicated that behavioral needs have a dramatic and direct effect on student progress and campus success.  Additionally, many teachers enter the classroom with insufficient training and experience in behavioral science to allow for effective classroom management design, intervention development and data collection/analysis.  This presentation will outline the steps to deepen practitioner behavioral knowledge and develop effective and sustainable systems of behavior support for all students.
column7: The learner will identify core features of evidence-based behavior supports within a multi-tiered model.
column8: The learner will utilize the provided rubric to compare his/her current organization to national standards to determine areas of need.
column9: The learner will determine actions for improvement of current practices, needed resources and possible pitfalls and barriers.

column1: Creating Videos that Change Your School Climate
column5: Phil Echols (Wake County Public School System)
column6: Increase positive behaviors and boost school morale by incorporating videos into your school culture. We'll explore creative ways to address the social/emotional needs of all students through short yet powerful videos and innovative technology.  Presenter will share ways to incorporate videos into your school culture that are proven to impact bullying prevention and positive behavior support.  Videos, editing tips, and technology tools will be shared to help achieve these goals and to build further participants toolbox of delivery methods for enhancing their school environment.  Attendees will be able to brainstorm areas within their school, which could be improved through video production.
column7: Participants will learn how to engage students, teachers, and parents thought the use of videos and technology.
column8: Participants will learn basic video editing tips that can be used with a variety of editing tools.
column9: Participants will gain creative ways to improve their school climate through the use of videos and technology.

column1: The Social Brain: Children's Edition
column5: Craig Knippenberg (Knippenberg, Patterson & Associates)
column6: _Without friends, no one would choose to live._ _AristotleMaking friendships and forming deep bonds with others isn_t about effort, it_s about aptitude. Some children are born with it, and some are not. Those of us whose brains are pre-wired for social success have a distinct advantage. The good news for the rest of us is that we all, regardless of genetics, have the ability to understand, direct and ultimately own our brain based behaviors.  By acknowledging our limitations and educating ourselves about our neurological wiring and the behaviors to which we_re disposed, we can access the immense power of The Social Brain. Have fun with the President, Furnace and Mirror!
column7: The important roles the Prefrontal Cortex (The President), the amygdala (The Furnace) and Mirror System (The Mirror) play in pro-social behavior.
column8: How parents_ understanding of their own social functioning and brain-based behaviors influences and promotes their child_s growth.
column9: How our emotional brains, like muscles in the body, develop through rigorous exercise such as real-life, unstructured interactions with others.
column10: social brain, social skills, emotional management

column1: A Magical Watch to Level The Playing Field
column5: Betsy  Furler (BridgingApps )
column6: The Apple Watch is the most personal device that Apple has ever released.  What may appear as a novelty device for many people can be a game changer for people with disabilitie.  It is a single user device that can level the playing field for students with dyslexia and executive functioning difficulties in an unobtrusive manner.  The watch allows for personal and private cueing that keeps students on task without obvious, intrusive intervention.  This session will discuss apps and techniques for using the Apple Watch in inclusive settings as well as self contained settings. Best practices for app development for learning will also be discussed.
column7: Participants will receive a list of apps as well as instruction on how to choose apps for the Apple Watch for learning.
column8: Participants will learn best practices for app development and app needs for the Apple Watch for education.
column9: Participants will learn how to facilitate student use of the Apple Watch for support for reading, writing and executive functioning.

column1: Free Digital Tools for Diverse Learners
column5: Kim Martin (Can:Do 4Kids)
column6: An opportunity to learn tips & tricks for improving univerally designed and inclusive learning opportunities. Which will therefore improve the usability of mainstream tools such as iPads, Macs and Google Apps and Extensions for all learners. The majority of the tips will use free 'out of the box' accessibility enhancements that students can choose to use independently to complete tasks, demonstrate learning, access material and communicate or collaborate.
column7: Educators will be able to support diverse learners with tips and tools that can immediately impact choice and control over their learning access.
column8: Educators will be able to take away a list of tools and tips to try in their learning environment tomorrow.
column9: Educators will have a better understanding of the free out of the box accessibility options for all learners within the Apple and Google Ecosystems

column1: Robots, Robots, Everywhere! - The Musical
column5: Ammon Taylor (Paramount Academy of the Arts), Zoey Baylea (Paramount Academy for the Arts), Mitch Harris (Paramount Academy for the Arts), Antonio Delgado (Science In A Suitcase)
column6: Our goal is to give participants a hands on experience of the RoboArts Intesive - presented by The Paramount Academy Of The Arts and Science In A Suitcase. Together, we will go through the creative writing process, script new stories, program our robotic characters, find similarities in the engineering process, costume and stage design, song-write and share our performance for each other.
column7: To create a strong understanding + functionality of the theatre, stage-creative writing and songwriting while leveraging the open world of robotics.
column8: Foster a creative energy in our students to access these items from their personal and artistic toolbox.
column9: Pushing for students to understand and view the likeness of the engineering, creative writing and songwriting process.

column1: Let's Have a Clicker Con
column5: Herb Coleman (Austin Community College)
column6: I'd like to invite at least the top 5 or more Student Response System or "Clicker" vendors to set up a table to exhibit their products and allow for side by side comparisons.  Each company could be given 5 minutes to talk about their product and their unique features.  Then the audience would get a chance to walk around to each vendors' table and get some hands on experience.  Currently, each of the big three companies have their own users conference.  This would be a great chance to bring them all together in one space.
column7: Introduce those who have never used them to the possibilities of the various clicker systems.
column8: Provide those with some experience with clickers the opportunities to consider other features and applications of the technology.
column9: Provide attendees with the opportunity to see, touch and discuss the various uses of clickers and see how various systems differ.

column1: Economic Recovery Generates Promising Jobs
column5: Sandy Dawkins (Pearson)
column6: In this session, experts including UpSkill America_s Director Jaime Fall, will explore insights into why there has been a misconception that low-wage jobs have been driving economic growth, and examples of promising jobs that are popular among college graduates. In addition, this session will reveal how entry level workers in industries such as retail, hospitality and food service are gaining access to education, training and development that opens opportunities for advancement thanks to an upskilling movement being embraced by employers across the nation.
column7: Learn about examples of promising jobs that are popular among college graduates
column8: Learn how the upskilling movement is increasing access to education, training and development opportunities
column9: Learn about misconceptions that low-wage jobs have been driving economic growth

column1: Focus on Employability
column5: Sandy Dawkins (Pearson)
column6: According to a Gallup study, while 96 percent of Chief Academic Officers rate their institution as either very or somewhat effective at preparing students for the world of work, only 11 percent of business leaders strongly agree graduating students have the skills and competencies that their business needs. This panel presentation aims to help bridge the gap between education and the workplace to increase the employability of individuals. Numerous employability experts will cover the perspective of the learner, academic institution and employer, will include best-selling author, award-winning columnist Jeff Selingo, UpSkill America_s Jaime Fall, and LinkedIn.
column7: Learn how institutions can better prepare students for a successful transition from college to career
column8: Learn how employers can build stronger relationships with institutions to ensure students are prepared to meet job market demands
column9: Learn how students can increase their employability

column1: iGEM@SXSW: Getting started in synthetic biology
column5: Meagan Lizarazo (iGEM Foundation), Kim de Mora (iGEM Foundation), Randy Rettberg (iGEM Foundation)
column6: Synthetic biology will play a big role at SXSW in 2016 and iGEM has one of the strongest brands in synbio. We are driving the field by growing the largest community of synthetic biologists worldwide through our annual competition. How can you get into this fast moving and rapidly expanding field if you don't have a biology or biotech background? How can you become a member of our community 25,000+ alumni?This session will outline iGEM, highlight exemplar projects from previous years of the competition and describe how you can participate.
column7: Introduce iGEM to a broad audience
column8: Help people understand how to get into synthetic biology
column9: Illustrate great synthetic biology resources, such team created projects

column1: Improving College and Career Readiness
column5: Sandy Dawkins (Pearson)
column6: Employability experts, including best-selling author and award-winning columnist Jeff Selingo, will discuss how educators and institutions can better prepare K-20 learners for success in college and the workplace. Presenters will focus on best practices for building a pathway to postsecondary educational success, and securing and sustaining successful career opportunities.
column7: Learn how students can build a better pathway to college and career and technical education success
column8: Learn how students can build their own powerful personal brand to increase lifelong success
column9: Learn how students can secure and sustain successful career opportunities

column1: What Employers are Doing to Help Employees Succeed
column5: Sandy Dawkins (Pearson)
column6: In this session, leading employers will discuss innovative initiatives, such as increasing access to opportunities to earn GED credential and attend college through online learning, all designed to help their employees make measurable progress in their lives and increase their employability.
column7: Learn about innovative employer initiatives that are increasing access to continuing education opportunities
column8: Learn how use of online learning technology is helping individuals to accomplish their academic goals and ultimately increase their employability
column9: Learn how employers and institutions are collaborating to provide affordable higher education opportunities

column1: Black Lives Matter: from Protest to Pedagogy
column5: Roni Dean-Burren (University of Houston)
column6: The BLM Movement is rooted in the frequency at which Black people's lives are devalued in society. The first part of this session will focus on the history of the movement, its connection to current K-12 pedagogy, and how this toxic relationship perpetuates racism and oppression in society. The second part of this session will focus on the benefits of turning the BLM Movement into pedagogical practice in the K-12 classroom; time will be spent on what this pedagogical strand looks like in teacher education programs.  Furthermore, participants will learn how critical theory, the theoretical foundation for this summit, can create a socially just classroom -- and eventually a social just world.
column7: Learn the history of the Black Lives Matter Movement
column8: Learn the tenets of critical theory
column9: Learn how the Black Lives Matter Movement should look in a classroom and in teacher education programs

column1: Tomorrow's Problem Solvers are Today's Travelers
column5: Markus Badde (ICEF), Sid Krommenhoek (Peak Ventures), Katie Fang (https://www.schoolinks.com)
column6: Traditionally, attending college was an affair done in the borders of one_s home country. However in the past few decades the rise of globalization has been paralleled with an influx of students wanting to go abroad to receive their college education. However the demand by the myriad of students desiring to study abroad is never met, although many schools frequently fail to meet their admissions quota. In order for colleges to adapt and compete in a growing space, they must embrace the use of technology to improve their recruitment efforts and secure top talent from a mobilizing group of students.
column7: How the landscape of international higher education is changing
column8: Why schools need to adapt in an increasingly competitive market of education for more mobile international students
column9: How schools can use tech to adapt and improve their international recruiting

column1: K12 Social Innovation: Real World Problem Solving
column5: Nick Nowicki (Avenues: The World School), Sophie  Potter (Avenues: The World School), Ella Weinstein (Avenues: The World School ), Luca Leung (Avenues: The World School)
column6: This summit explores social innovation as a vehicle for real-world problem solving, design thinking, entrepreneurialism, service, and student-led work. Students and teachers from the Social Innovation Program at Avenues will present their projects, including design challenges, original curriculum, and a conference recently hosted at the school.  At the summit, teachers will briefly outline the goals and utility of SI curriculum and take Q&A. Students will run a mini-design challenge with attendees, create a spontaneous case study and class exercise, and examine the value and scope of student-led event planning and management as a particular variation of community-facing work.
column7: Understand why social innovation is a compelling theme for 21st century learning and global citizenship and corresponding skills and aptitudes
column8: Explore a theory-practice spectrum, including concrete examples used at Avenues and elsewhere, and hypothetical examples for your school
column9: Affirm the power of student-led learning by engaging and supporting student leaders as they present their work

column1: Legal Constraints on Creativity
column5: Jon Festinger (University of British Columbia, MDM Program), Patrick Pennefather (Simon Fraser University/MDM Program)
column6: Everyone is a content creator. What implications to the human creative process are engendered by law and legalities? When do we stop ourselves from contributing our _great_ ideas with others? How can we help learners manage their creative trajectories? This interactive summit_one part collaborative idea generator, one part legal examination of how ideas are negotiated and made public through various social channels, will propose some answers. We facilitate rapid prototyping tools to generate ideas quickly, travel on the potential journey your content traverses, and discuss the many ways creativity may be restrained, shaped and altered even while "freedom of speech" acknowledged.
column7: Participants will become more conscious of internal and external constraints on individual and group creativity.
column8: Participants will develop new strategies to cope with those constraints.
