column9: Participants will have added techniques to guide learners on creative trajectories while engendering a rights based dialogue.

column1: Beyond Devices: Bringing Blended Learning to Life
column5: John Branam (The Learning Accelerator), Sarojani Mohammed (The Learning Accelerator), Kira Keane (The Learning Accelerator), Beth Rabbitt (The Learning Accelerator)
column6: Interested in taking your blended learning implementation to the next level but not sure what resources exist to support you? Through a series of small-group sessions TLA will share expertise and resources focused on several key topics: competency-based education for students; competency-based professional development for educators; leadership competencies for blending learning; tools for tracking mastery; lessons learned from schools implementing blended learning; and measurement. Come experience a competency-based learning environment in which you will choose your own path based on your objectives and interests, and leave with a concrete resource or plan to improve your own implementation.
column7: Attendees will learn about TLA_s resources for implementing blended learning in K-12 settings
column8: Attendees will learn about the details of several of the implementation topics (each topic will include its own learning objectives)
column9: Attendees will be able to improve their current programs by creating a concrete resource or plan to progress to the next level of effectiveness

column1: Student Privacy - Ask the Experts
column5: Michael Tassey (U.S. Department of Education, Privacy Technical Assistance Center), Baron Rodriguez (U.S. Department of Education), Kathleen Styles (U.S. Department of Education), Michael Hawes (U.S. Department of Education)
column6: This summit will provide an opportunity for attendees to meet with privacy and security experts from the U.S. Department of Education.  The session will alternate between three different formats:  (1) short presentations and tutorials on hot-button topics in student privacy (e.g., privacy and cloud computing, FERPA 101); (2) table-top discussions on specific topics, facilitated by Department experts (e.g, data deidentification techniques, designing a district privacy program on a budget); and (3) "office hours with the feds" where attendees can meet one-on-one with Department experts on FERPA, IT security, data deidentification, data governance, etc. to get targeted advice and assistance.
column7: Attendees will learn the basics of federal laws and best practices for protecting student privacy.
column8: Participants will learn from federal experts, and from each other, about how to overcome common challenges to protecting student privacy.
column9: Participants will have the opportunity to meet one-on-one with federal officials and experts to ask specific questions and get individualized advice.

column1: Curiosity-based Learning: Exploring Innovation
column5: Meghan Cureton (Mount Vernon Presbyterian School), Bo Adams (Mount Vernon Presbyterian School & Institute for Innovation)
column6: We are born insatiably curious. It_s how we learn. In too many cases, though, curiosity can be shoved to the back seat, or even tossed out of the vehicle, in environments we call _school._ Yet, we talk of school innovation. What if we more purposefully developed mindsets that are essential to the _Innovator_s DNA?_ How might we grow our curiosity muscles and make school more about real-world pursuits? In this expeditionary session, participants will hear three stories of curiosity-based learning and curricular transformation. Then the group will engage in community exploration, observation journaling, and design thinking to spur ideation and action planning for immediate implementation.
column7: Understand observation, questioning, experimenting, and networking as practices of curiosity and methods for developing innovation capacity
column8: Explore community with collaborative observation and questioning, as well as see such practice as powerful instructional/curricular frame redesign
column9: Build capacity in design thinking; utilize flare and focus thinking routines to hypothesize, synthesize, and develop action plans for deep learning

column1: Designing a Student-Centric University
column5: Sultanna  Krispil (Minerva Schools @KGI), Carol J.  Carter  (LifeBound)
column6: The Future University: A Design SprintStudents will be broken into groups at the start of the session to brainstorm how they would design a student-centric university, with each group focusing on a unique aspect of the educational experience -- curriculum, assessments, co-curricular activities, mobility and exploration of diverse communities, and job preparation. Session leaders will provide valuable insights throughout the session, prompting attending students to consider different points of view. At the end of the session, groups will give presentations of how they would design a student-centric approach across the range of experiences that comprise the core of a modern university.
column7: Discuss how traditional approaches to higher education can be recreated and re-approached to best meet the needs of today_s modern students.
column8: Understand diverse points of view about what student success looks like, and consider how the richness of a student body can be better harnessed.
column9: Discuss how to practically go about enacting change at existing institutions.

column1: Innovative Learning Happy Hour
column5: Lindsey Own (The Evergreen School)
column6: Share your own and learn from others_ outcomes from the earlier workshops in the Ready GO! implementation summit on developing school-wide innovation culture, re-mixing processes for learning experience design, and rethinking assessment. Even if you didn_t attend the workshops, stop by for a snack and to learn from others.
column7: Participants will share, compare, and learn specific strategies for implementing innovative teaching practices.
column8: Participants will design ready-to-use new elements to bring back to their classrooms or development offices, utilizing those innovative practices.
column9: Participants will deepen skills in the innovative practices, prepared to return to their schools or companies and teach/lead their colleagues.

column1: Introduction to Gold Standard PBL: Getting Started
column5: Bob Lenz (Buck Institute for Education), Jennifer Cruz (Buck Institute for Education)
column6: The PBL Done Well summit focuses on the two most important factors in effective implementation of Project Based Learning: The teacher and the organizational context in which they operate. This first module _ Introduction to Gold Standard PBL: Getting Started with Project Design _ introduces educators to the instructional design model used by the Buck Institute for Education.
column7: Participants will develop an understanding of Gold Standard Project Based Learning.
column8: Participants will develop an understanding of the difference between dessert and main course projects.
column9: Participants will understand why Project Based Learning is a key strategy to meet the needs of today's learners.

column1: Practical Process to Schoolwide Innovation Culture
column5: Margaret Powers (Episcopal Academy), Kaleb  Rashad (Westwood Public Unified School District)
column6: Learn and share successes and pitfalls in developing innovation culture and mindset at different levels of school organization. Consider your school context and plan specific and positive actions that you and others at your school can take to shift individual and institutional mindsets. Leave with your own specific plan, continue into the next workshops of the Ready GO! implementation summit, and/or continue to share and learn from others at the summit_s culminating Happy Hour share-out.
column7: Participants will share, compare, and learn specific strategies for implementing innovative teaching practices - shifting culture toward innovation
column8: Participants will design ready-to-use new elements to bring back to their classrooms or development offices, utilizing those innovative practices.
column9: Participants will deepen skills in the innovative practices, prepared to return to their schools or companies and teach/lead their colleagues.

column1: Project Design: If You Build it They Will Learn
column5: Bob Lenz (Buck Institute for Education), Jennifer Cruz (Buck Institute for Education)
column6: The PBL Done Well summit focuses on the two most important factors in effective implementation of Project Based Learning: The teacher and the organizational context in which they operate. This second module - Project Design: If You Build It They Will Learn _ engages educators in a highly interactive project design workshop led by Buck Institute for Education staff.
column7: Participants will use design templates to create a draft project.
column8: Participants will develop an understanding of Gold standard PBL_s Essential Design Elements.
column9: Participants will engage in a peer feedback protocol.

column1: Re-Mix Your Learning Experience Design Process
column5: Lindsey Own (The Evergreen School), Martin Moran (Francis W Parker School)
column6: Does designing learning prompts, driving questions, project trajectories, and authentic audience interactions sometimes feel like magic? Experience other master teachers' strategies for how they approach re-mixing their students' learning experiences to incorporate deeper innovations in teaching and learning. Build and plan how to continue building your personal mental innovation library, and map out processes for yourself to rethink how you create learning experiences for your students. Leave with your own specific plan, continue into the next workshops of the Ready GO! implementation summit, and/or continue to share and learn from others at the summit_s culminating Happy Hour share-out.
column7: Participants will share, compare, and learn specific strategies for designing innovative learning experiences.
column8: Participants will design ready-to-use new elements to bring back to their classrooms or development offices, utilizing those innovative practices.
column9: Participants will deepen skills in the innovative practices, prepared to return to their schools or companies and teach/lead their colleagues.

column1: Reaching Gold Standard Project Based Learning
column5: Bob Lenz (Buck Institute for Education), Jennifer Cruz (Buck Institute for Education)
column6: Project Based Learning (PBL) is a hot trend in K-12 education, which is good news for 21st century students and teachers, but there's danger in popularity. If not done well, PBL could become yesterday's trend. Poorly designed and managed projects could backfire on teachers. School and district leaders might not see that PBL is not a simple pedagogy and sustaining PBL over time requires careful planning, commitment, and cultural change. In our Summit, four highly interactive, hands-on sessions will help teachers design projects that meet our model for "gold standard PBL" and guide leaders in planning its systemic implementation.
column7: Teachers & school leaders will understand the difference between "doing projects" & Gold Standard PBL, & reflect on Project Based Teaching Practices.
column8: Teachers will understand how to design authentic projects that engage students, guided by the Gold Standard Essential Project Design Elements.
column9: School and district leaders will understand how to lead a system-wide effort to adopt and institutionalize Gold Standard Project Based Teaching.

column1: Ready GO! Take Innovation from Concept to Practice
column5: Lindsey Own (The Evergreen School)
column6: Your pride yourself on staying on the forward edge of education innovation. You understand the value of constructivism AND constructionism, you promote student-driven learning, and you rock SAMR with your tech integration. You're ready to go deeper. Join expert teachers in a series of workshops to practice advanced implementations of innovations like design thinking, project-based learning, "making," geniushour, and other mindsets. Teachers: plan specific techniques to use in your classroom, and create usable projects to push your students to greater heights of learning and creating. Developers: understand these innovations to support these effective classroom practices in your products.
column7: Participants will share, compare, and learn specific strategies for implementing innovative teaching practices.
column8: Participants will design ready-to-use new elements to bring back to their classrooms or development offices, utilizing those innovative practices.
column9: Participants will deepen skills in the innovative practices, prepared to return to their schools or companies and teach/lead their colleagues.

column1: Rethink Assessment for Innovative Learning
column5: Cheryl Steighner (Tacoma Public Schools), Lindsey Own (The Evergreen School)
column6: Start from first principles for assessment to reconsider what it means to "grade" a student's learning. Play with other master teachers' tools for assessment, from project launch to tracking student progress on skill development to "final" assessments of learning. Design tools and classroom processes that support innovative learning and will actually work in your school context. Leave with your own specific plan, continue into the next workshops of the Ready GO! implementation summit, and/or continue to share and learn from others at the summit_s culminating Happy Hour share-out.
column7: Participants will share, compare, and learn specific strategies for implementing assessment in innovative learning experiences
column8: Participants will design ready-to-use new elements to bring back to their classrooms or development offices, utilizing those innovative practices.
column9: Participants will deepen skills in the innovative practices, prepared to return to their schools or companies and teach/lead their colleagues.

column1: Summit on Project-Based Citizen Science Curriculum
column5: Derek Runberg (SparkFun Electronics), Ben Leduc-Mills (SparkFun Electronics), Jeff  Branson (SparkFun Electronics)
column6: This summit session aims to introduce, discuss, explore, and present hands-on curriculum ideas for citizen science projects. The summit will be divided into three 2-hour sessions: air (hot air balloons), land (weather station), and sea (buoy). In each session, we will introduce each project as well as give participants hands-on instruction on how to build, program, and modify each instrument. We will then lead them in some 'free swim' time to play with their project, make it their own, and finally brainstorm as a group to develop activities that make use of their project in a way that fits into their own educational environment.
column7: An increased understanding of citizen science as a meaningful maker activity.
column8: Increased confidence in using and modifying some basic citizen science technologies and techniques, such as logging sensor data from an Arduino.
column9: An understanding of how to generate and incorporate hands-on citizen science activities into their own classroom.

column1: Visual Literacy Bootcamp
column5: John Woody (James Madison University), Julia Leong (Consultant), Brad Ovenell-Carter (Mulgrave School)
column6: Fire up the creative in your students--and yourself. This workshop introduces the _grammar_ of three core visual literacies--sketchnotes, photography, videography and teaches you how to build rich and engaging narrative with images. Our brains process visual and verbal information differently. By working both mental paths together, we can create powerful practices for all--students & teachers alike--to reflect on their thinking, grow their understanding and demonstrate their learning.
column7: Learn the basics of sketchnoting, photography & videography. Leave the workshop with skills you can apply immediately.
column8: Learn to capture and tell stories. Go beyond technical basics and add narrative to your drawings, photos and videos.
column9: Get more out of SXSWEdu. You will have new skills that will allow you to capture and share richer and more meaningful ideas from the event.

column1: Eduvate! Reimagining Education for 2025!
column5: Shawn Nason (Xavier Center For Innovation)
column6: The Xavier University Center for Innovation and IXL Center our partnering to shake-up the national educational space. We_ve partnered with a number of educational start-ups and we_re helping them to grow their business. We like to think of ourselves as the convener and connector of market makers. We simply connect talented people with other talented people. Our Eduvate! summits bring together educational leaders and innovators to talk about innovations, systems, trends, and most importantly, consumers. Led by Chief Innovation Officer, Shawn Nason, this half-day interactive program will premier at SXSWedu and will be delivered in cities nationwide in 2016.
column7: To identify innovations, technology, and systems needed in place by 2025 for consumers?
column8: To identify and ideate who will lead these changes--start-ups, companies, corporations, public or private schools, and universities?
column9: How will we go about preparing for this future and why do we need to work together to prepare for the fast-changing educational space

column1: How Students Can Help Reinvent Higher Ed
column5: Leticia Britos Cavagnaro (Stanford University), Ben Riddle (Furman University), Bre Przestrzelski (Clemson University), Humera Fasihuddin (VentureWell)
column6: We may think of students simply as customers of higher education, yet leading schools have discovered that students can play a far more strategic role as co-designers who can help reinvent the educational experience. In this hands-on session, hear from student leaders who are impacting how learning happens at their institutions. Discuss the advantages students have in navigating change in academia and identify strategies that university leaders, faculty and staff can leverage to accelerate the pace of institutional change. Work in small teams to apply these strategies and distill your own bold ideas into measurable experiments to make a difference at your organization.
column7: Explore case studies of student-led change in higher education to identify factors enabling collaboration between students, faculty and administrators
column8: Learn a framework for mapping and assessing the learning resources in your ecosystem
column9: Apply design thinking strategies to translate bold ideas for change into actions and learnings

column1: Leading a School Energized by Project Designers
column5: Bob Lenz (Buck Institute for Education), Jennifer Cruz (Buck Institute for Education)
column6: This third module - Leading a School Energized by Project Designers _ introduces school and district leaders to the skills, strategies and structures needed to create a context where GS PBL flourishes.
column7: Participants will develop an understanding of key leadership priorities in a PBL school and district.
column8: Participants will explore leadership tools that enhance inquiry and collaboration.
column9: Participants will develop an understanding of key structures needed to support the use of Gold Standard PBL.

column1: Moving From Privacy to Trust
column5: Aimee Guidera (Data Quality Campaign), Bob Moore (Dallas ISD), Deb Delisle (ASCD), Kathleen Styles (U.S. Department of Education)
column6: Concerns around the privacy of student data have been rising in recent years.  Educators are increasingly on the defensive as parents believe too much data is collected about their children, it is not secure and too often inappropriately used for commercial gain.	Trust is at the heart of the privacy debate.  Last year the Student Data Principles  were endorsed by 40 education associations.  Learn how we can build on the Principles through better educator training , improved review of education apps, clearer vendor agreements and building an ambitious _seal_ validating trusted learning environments. Then participate in an interactive forum on what else is needed.
column7: Identify ways that educators can reframe the debate over privacy of student data.
column8: Explore innovative ways that educators and nonprofits are building trust with parents and policymakers around privacy.
column9: Brainstorm on what else is needed to change the privacy conversation to one of trust.

column1: PBL? It_s All About the Plan
column5: Bob Lenz (Buck Institute for Education), Jennifer Cruz (Buck Institute for Education)
column6: This fourth module - PBL? It_s All About the Plan _ engages school and district leaders in a highly interactive Project Based Learning systemic action planning workshop led by Buck Institute for Education staff. We will review key considerations for schools and districts that want a sustainable and scalable implementation of gold standard Project Based Learning across their system.
column7: Participants will create a draft of the key components of a PBL implementation plan.
column8: Participants will develop an understanding of reasonable benchmarks over time.
column9: Participants will understand the key leadership moves and considerations prior to implementing PBL in their school or district at scale.

column1: Real Teachers, Real Talk
column5: Troy  Fischer (Newark Public Schools), Sabrina  Moore (Madison Park Business & Art Academy), Marcos  Saldivar (The Huffington Post), Rebecca Klein (The Huffington Post)
column6: The Huffington Post and A Teacher Like You, a project sharing inspirational teacher stories, will gather innovative educators from communities across the US to discuss their experiences, challenges and inspirations in an era of changing standards and new learning tools. The summit explores teaching on an emotional, personal level through interactive programming (a teacher video confessional and photobooth) and in-depth conversations led by the HuffPost team. All content will be shared on ATLY and HuffPost editorial channels.
column7: Equip educators with a communal voice and distribution platform in the broader conversation on education policy.
column8: Discuss challenges educators face today, from preparing students to meet Common Core standards to implementing best practices for blended learning.
column9: Explore ways in which teachers can harness support from fellow teachers and other stakeholders to better serve their students.

column1: Real Teachers, Real Talk
column5: Troy Fischer (Newark Public Schools), Sabrina Moore (Madison Park Business & Art Academy), Marcos Saldivar (Huffington Post), Rebecca Klein (Huffington Post)
column6: There_s been increasing public discussions on the state of education, from changing standards and assessments to new learning tools. But a key perspective is missing: voices of teachers, the ones on education_s front lines. Renaissance Learning launched A Teacher Like You at SXSW 2015 as a platform to share teachers_ experiences, challenges and inspirations. Now in partnership with the Huffington Post, this summit explores teaching on an emotional, personal level through interactive programming and conversations led by the HuffPost team. We celebrate the people changing lives in the classroom, asking what support they need to have a larger presence in the broader education dialogue.
column7: Equip educators with a communal voice and distribution platform in the broader conversation on education policy.
column8: Discuss challenges educators face today, from preparing students to meet Common Core standards to implementing best practices for blended learning.
column9: Explore ways in which teachers can harness support from fellow teachers and other stakeholders to better serve their students.

column1: Slow Pitch: An EdTech Design ThinkTank
column5: Joan Hughes (The University of Texas at Austin), Sean Duffy (EdTech Action)
column6: Join an interactive pitch session where startups, mentors and the audience will dialogue and hone startups_ products so that they will transform learning and penetrate school markets. Selected edtech startups (follow @techedges and @dearmrduffy to apply) will provide demos, evidence of real/potential impact, and marketing/monetization plans prior to SXSWedu. At the summit, we_ll cultivate a focused, generative dialogue between the startups, the 10+ educator, research, and business mentors, and the audience. Audience participation will be curated throughout with twitter, polls, and open-mic opps. This design thinktank will help emerging edtech advance and innovate. - See more at: http://panelpicker.sxsw.com/vote/54541#sthash.eW2Rt9O3.dpuf
column7: Experience a design process for edtech development that includes input from a wide array K-12 and business mentors to increase technology adoption
column8: Assist edtech startups in crafting their products/missions to transform young people_s learning and/or teachers_ instruction
column9: Work through edtech goals, design, development, funding, and business complexity with mentors from education, technology, and business

column1: Sparking Boston's Imagination: #HSReD
column5: Liz OBrien (Mayor's Office - City of Boston )
column6: Since the launch of Boston's High School Redesign initiative this past May, we've achieved at least two milestones.  First we have generated a robust data set of feedback + ideas through our public forums, community-led discussions + social media.  Secondly, incoming BPS Supt. Tommy Chang issued his 100-day plan which calls for the first wave of HSReD efforts to focus on Boston's Madison Park Vocational Tech High School. There's several options to explore for this session - e.g. how we have used design thinking to leverage the feedback we're getting to create changes in our high schools; how we have taught the City to use design techniques to be the foundation of our redesign efforts.
column7: Tutorial on Design Thinking and Building Capacity for Citywide Projects Like High School Redesign
column8: Leveraging Resources of Diverse Stakeholders Throughout City to Allow High-Impact Ideation + Prototyping
column9: Rise of Civic Innovation + Soliciting Meaningful Feedback From All Constituents

column1: Transforming Education with Learners at the Center
column5: Virgel Hammonds (KnowledgeWorks), Kelly Young (Convergence), Trace Pickering (IOWA Big), Michael Hinojosa (Dallas Independent School District)
column6: How do we realize a new future of learning in which every child fulfills their boundless potential?Join us to explore the learner-centered universe. Play with and expand your notions of where, how, when, and with whom learning happens. Engage with leading pioneers and hear about their transformational journeys to reimagine and create learning environments that work for all learners. Whether you are just beginning to explore or have been on the learner-centered path for decades, walk away inspired with new ideas to redesign learning in your own community.
column7: Explore the nascent learner-centered movement and hear practical examples of how it is taking shape in learning environments across the country.
column8: Learn about five elements of great learning that facilitate the shift from school-centric to learner-centric education.
column9: Identify strategies to redesign learning that are applicable to your environment.

column1: Enhancing learning with VR/AR
column5: Bob Wise (Alliance for Excellent Education ), Jeremy  Roschelle (Center for Technology in Learning at SRI International), Renee Hobbs (Media Education Lab, Rhode Island University), Cecilia Waismann (MindCET)
column6: The session will focus on theory and practise that showcase how VR experiences significantly enhance learning, presenting ongoing projects that expand the scope of students' learning experiences, providing new opportunities for the educator and the learner. The projects include curricular disciplines (such as physics) as well as pedagogical challenges (such as building empathy with the other), through collaborations between teachers, students, researchers and entrepreneurs from different countries (Israel, Brazil, Mexico, Spain, USA). The session we'll be a rhythmic and dynamic event in 3 parts: Panel of educational experts, Experiential showcase and participants' feedback activity.
column7: Virtual Reality potential for significantly enhance learning of science-related subjects
column8: VR & AR technological feasibility for education today and prediction for the near future
column9: Virtual reality potential to meet pedagogical challenges such as students' human values (e.g. empathy and understanding of significant other)

column1: Libraries 3.0- Libraries as Innovative Hubs
column5: Katie Delamarter (Lewisville ISD), Leah Mann (Lewisville ISD), Kathy Hoffman (Lewisville ISD)
column6: Have you heard a lot about STEM/STEAM, Makerspaces, 3D Printing and Coding recently? These buzzwords are more than just trends, and libraries are the perfect place for them to take shape and grow! Want to know how to implement them in your program? Or are you already doing these things and seeking ideas for year two (or beyond)? Join three Lewisville ISD school library media specialists at different places in their innovative journeys as they share the latest theories, ideas, apps, technology, materials, and resources to take your libraries to 3.0 status.
column7: Attendees will gain a deeper understanding of makerspaces and STEM/STEAM initiatives in K-12 education and their place in library media centers.
column8: Attendees will examine new and cutting-edge trends in EdTech and library programming and best practices for implementation.
column9: Attendees will transform ideas regarding the role of libraries in education and society in the 21st century.

column1: School Innovation - Design + Organizational Change
column5: Stephanie Sandifer (Houston Independent School District), Raechel Schneider (Stantec), Taryn Kinney (Stantec), Bryan Setser (2revolutions)
column6: This summit explores the intersection of physical design, innovative culture, and organizational change. A tremendous opportunity to affect generations of learners comes with each new or renovated school facility. However, even when spaces afford for progressive learning techniques, human behavior often gets in the way. Layering organizational change and an innovative culture to support a physical shift can have an immensely positive effect on learning. This summit brings together designers, researchers, administrators, strategists, and other stakeholders for action-oriented dialogue.
column7: Begin a dialogue between designers, researchers, administrators, strategists, and other stakeholders in the school change and innovation process.
column8: Highlight current success stories of and common barriers to the alignment of organizational and spatial transformation with the educational culture.
column9: Develop resources and action items to help districts integrate organizational change into the design process to create a culture of innovation.

column1: Creating Invincible Youth through Resilience
column5: Amy  McDonald (Southeast Island School District), Derek Peterson (International Institute for Student Support)
column6: Why do some children survive traumatic childhoods unscathed? The answers can help every child. Nearly 50 years ago, child psychologist Emmy Werner went looking for trouble in paradise. In 1955 she began studying the children of chronically poor, alcoholic, abusive, and even psychotic parents to try and understand (and document) how "failure" was passed down, from one generation to the next. She was amazed. She found that one out of every three youths she studied behaved nothing like the ones headed for disaster. Where she expected to find despair, she uncovered hope. She found that somehow these "resilient youth" could beat the odds and grow into emotionally healthy, competent adults.
column7: Receive a brief overview of the history of resiliency research and the psychological background of resiliency
column8: Learn about the competing resiliency frameworks_how they differ and how they complement each other
column9: Find out how to pass resiliency on to the children and youth within your circle of influence and how you can affect change in your community

column1: Whole Child Education - SEL, PE, and Creativity
column5: Yesenia Garcia - Herrington (Austin ISD), Paul Cruz (Austin ISD), Michele Rusnak (Austin ISD), Sherrie Raven (Austin ISD)
column6: Student engagement, physical health, and social and emotional skills are all areas that schools work to improve daily. Research shows that a 5 minute brain break can incorporate movement and SEL skills and increase attention and decrease time off task in the classroom. Creative activities using the arts also provide higher engagement and reinforce social and emotional skills. Learn the research background and learn and develop activities for all classrooms and all subject areas. This session will weave SEL, physical activity, and creative learning strategies into academic content lessons. Teachers will plan for the use of activities in their own lessons as well.
column7: Learn the scientific basis for using brain breaks, creative learning strategies and social and emotional learning in the classroom.
column8: Participate in brain breaks and creative learning strategies that reinforce social and emotional skills and relate to academic content.
column9: Plan for use of brain breaks, creative learning strategies, and social and emotional skills in your classroom or school.

column1: Learning and Attention Issues Summit
column5: Kevin Hager (Understood), Jim Wendorf (NCLD), Ashley Sandvi (Poses Family Foundation)
column6: Learning disabilities or learning differences. Reading disabilities or dyslexia. ADHD or executive functioning issues. We may use different terms and have different approaches. But we're all trying to do the same thing: help the 1 in 5 kids with learning and attention issues who struggle in school and in life. If you're part of an organization_large or small_dedicated to this mission, join a two-day summit where you'll meet others working toward the same goals you are. Share what you do, and network with nonprofits, funders and for-profit organizations. Find partnering opportunities around programming, development, marketing and problem solving. Get connected!
column7: Hear ideas about best practices and successes to spark ideas for your work
column8: Network with organizations committed to learning and attention issues
column9: Share the work you are doing in this space to inspire and engage others in your mission

column1: Mental Illness Stigma:  From Closet to Classroom
column5: Corrinne Pace (High Road Primary Schools)
column6: The discussion on mental health has been steadily evolving for decades, but only recently have we opened the door to discuss how our society's pervasive stigma weighs us down.  Students and parents are often hesitant to accept or disclose the Emotional Disability label because of real problems like prejudice, discrimination, and even bullying from children and adults alike!But what about the teachers?According to recent statistics, 1 in 4 adults, almost 900,000 K-12 teachers in the US, will face mental illness this year; and will struggle to hide their healing under the weight of a stigma that carries even more prejudice.  Break the cycle and share experience and new perspective.
column7: AWBAT discuss current mThe discussion on mental health has been steadily evolving for decades, but only recently have we opened the door to discuss how our society's pervasive stigma weighs us down.  Students and parents are often hesitant to accept or disclose the Emotional Disability label because of real problems like prejudice, discrimination, and even bullying from children and adults alike!But what about the teachers?According to recent statistics, 1 in 4 adults, almost 900,000 K-12 teachers in the US, will face mental illness this year; and will struggle to hide their healing under the weight of a stigma that carries even more prejudice.  Break the cycle and share experience and new perspective.ental health statistics as related to education, connecting the complex consequences that we all face as a result of stigma.
column8: AWBAT analyze the effects of society's views on mental health, extend this to the unspoken battles of adults in the field and hypothesize consquences.
column9: AWBAT tackle stigma in collaborative action plans, justify and assess the ideas, each finally devising and committing to one problem-solving solution.

column1: Special Needs Piano Camp
column5: Kara Blenden (Williams Community School), Suzanne Byrne (Williams Community School), Theron Pray (gravitycurrent.com), Richard Hurley (Hurley Piano)
column6: To demonstrate piano teaching to special needs kids. Will highlight the importance of sound, color and interactive technology. This is not music therapy. It is a structured approach to piano teaching within the special ed environment. We will have special needs kids demonstrating the interaction between piano and Synesthesia an app that generates images from music played on the piano. We are also demonstrating this at Google Fiber Space 201 Colorado Street here in Austin on November 2nd  in a special needs piano recital and art exhibition which will be streamed live. You are all invited. http://hurleypiano.com/special-event/
column7: How to introduce the piano to the special needs child at the first session. I will demo a piano lesson on stage with my special needs students.
column8: We will showcase a study where the Synesthesia app was used to aid speech development in a special needs student.
column9: The methodology will be analyzed by two BCBA's (board certified behavioral analysts).  who will debate the strengths and weaknesses of the program.

column1: World Numbers
column5: Rebecca Klemm (NumbersAlive!)
column6: Mankind developed math systems to describe and communicate the world around them.  The geometric meaning of math is often overlooked but is more natural to many learners and can be used to show the relevance and meaning of mathematical concepts.  Dr. Klemm will present portions of her presentation, "World Numbers" which she presents at family nights and numerous festivals. The presentation will show numeric world patterns in nature, architecture/art, sports and culture through numbers.  For example, what are the numeric symbols of the Statue of Liberty?  Which number should discuss recycling due to the recycle symbol?  Participants will never think of numbers/numeracy the same way again.
column7: Where do we find numbers in our environment?
column8: How do you and students discover the meaning of math as a human endeavor?
column9: How do  you use geometry to teach arithmetic?

column1: Create to Change: Artistic Practice as Pedagogy
column5: Bobby Biedrzycki (Goodman Theatre), Willa  Taylor (Goodman Theatre)
column6: This interactive hands-on workshop explores how artistic praxis (the what, how and why of what artists do) can be used by teachers to differentiate instruction and activate student engagement. Educators from the Goodman Theatre's Department of Education will lead activities from our PlayBuild Youth Intensive program, and examine the methodologies practiced in our award-winning teacher training programs. Participants will create implementation strategies for their own classrooms, and will also get hands-on experience with performance techniques that can be used to activate students, facilitate inquiry and discussion, and develop engaging learning projects.
column7: Learn philosophies and practices of differentiated instruction used in the award-winning education programs at the Goodman Theatre.
column8: Learn classroom instruction techniques rooted in the theatre arts that promote education as the practice of freedom, and build critical consciousness.
column9: Practice instructional methods that break down the traditional student/teacher dichotomy and create space for an in-depth understanding of the world.

column1: Improv(ing) the Writing Process
column5: Carrington Alvarez (n/a), Jennifer Oleniczak (The Engaging Educator)
column6: Writing is a process.  Every student, regardless of age, needs to learn it.  So why not improve and innovate the way you teach it? We'll go through each step of the creative writing process, from dreaming up ideas to revising, to composing a collaborative poem using improvisational theatre.  Participants will explore literary elements central to poetry, including figurative language, imagery, musicality, and rhythm, through improv.  This will allow teachers and students to journey through the writing process like never before. Participants will not only write and dramatize poems, but also learn a new, imaginative technique for literacy instruction that will inspire!
column7: Explore poetic elements using improvisational theatre
column8: Enhance students' understanding of the multi-step creative writing process with performing arts
column9: Collaborate meaningfully to compose and dramatize students_ own poems

column1: Leveraging Fine Arts in a Tech Rich Environment
column5: Joshua Essary (South Belton Middle School)
column6: Technology rich school, like 1:1, are popping up everywhere. Technology facilitators are being created. There are hundreds of websites and blogs that are filled with techniques to use technology in the classroom. However, the "classroom" usually leaves out some of the most power disciplines: The Fine Arts. These subjects enrich our students and our schools, and technology can work there as well. We will review ideas and techniques that incorporate technology into the Fine Arts. We will show ideas to create your own based on your situation (size, demographic, etc...). We will also review ways to use your fine arts across the curriculum while still achieving high technology implementation.
column7: Understand the challenge of technology use in the Fine Arts classroom
column8: Create and Determine Solutions to assist Fine Arts subjects concerning technology.
column9: Analyze techniques to get the most out of your Fine Arts department while making connections across the curriculum

column1: Literary Riot: Poetry with Get Lit - Words Ignite
column5: Marquesha Babers (Get Lit - Words Ignite), Diane Luby Lane (Get Lit - Words Ignite)
column6: POWER TO THE POET!This workshop will feature our Executive Director Diane Luby Lane & five of our most accomplished teen spoken word poets, giving performances of dynamic spoken word poetry combined with workshops on the Get Lit model which outlines how to read and understand classic poetry in a dynamic way, how to perform it, and how to write your own spoken word response. Our Players have been featured at the Library of Congress, Hollywood Bowl, Lincoln Center & more! Come see the artists that GOOD Magazine in Iceland called "The Teen Spoken Word Poets That Enchanted The Internet!" For more background, visit www.getlit.org. Join the #LiteraryRiot!
column7: Be afraid of classic poetry no more!
column8: Express yourself through poetry.
column9: Build performance technique & confidence.

column1: Master the Art of Pitching Your Project
column5: Lane Shefter Bishop (Vast Entertainment), Jennifer Wilkov (Your Book Is Your Hook LLC / School of Visual Arts)
column6: Can you sell your project in a sentence? Are you missing that one piece that could put over the top with agents, producers, publishers and Hollywood? Every day is like _American Idol_ or _America_s Got Talent_. But not all writers are prepared to talk concisely, confidently and competently about their projects. What is standing between writers like you and the bestselling writing career you_ve dreamed of is you shy away from the pivotal question: _What_s your project about?_ Learn to master the essential skillset to feel confident, comfortable and competent when you pitch your projects to literary, film, television and Broadway industry professionals and others.
column7: How to effectively answer the question, _So, what_s your project about?_
column8: How to talk authentically with anyone about your project, without notes or a script
column9: Why short and concise conversations about your project work best with agents, publishers and the press

column1: On Your Feet: Participatory Theatre for Learning
column5: Alison Lehner (YTeam Mental Health Program), Nikki  Zaleski (ICAH (Illinois Caucus for Adolescent Health))
column6: Participatory theatre (PT) refers to an interactive, dialogical mode of performance, in which facilitators and participants co-construct and manipulate narratives through inquiry and play. For more than five years, For Youth Inquiry (FYI) has been using this approach to activate the creative potential of health education. In this on-your-feet workshop, we will use the tools of game, story, and improvisation to: 1) amplify youth voice, 2) cultivate inquiry, and 3) spark critical dialogue. Through experiential learning and reflection, educators will uncover ways to apply participatory theatre in their own practice, and to empower youth as protagonists in their own learning.
column7: Participants will use the tools of game, story, and improvisation to open the door to safe, youth-centered conversations.
column8: Participants will analyze successful arts-based strategies for participatory design within a learning framework.
column9: Participants will discover how to use the 4 P_s of Participation (Pleasure, Perspective, Practice, and Power) to increase youth engagement.

column1: DIY GBL Assessments: Create Today. Use Tomorrow.
column5: David McCool (Muzzy Lane Software), Conall Ryan (Muzzy Lane Software)
column6: Bring your smart phone, tablet, or laptop to this workshop to create your own game-based mini-assessments that you can use in class the next day to measure higher order thinking.
column7: Muzzy Lane's game-based authoring tools enable you to create your own micro learning assessments to measure and improve higher order thinking skills.
column8: Customization by instructors for the individual student and class.
column9: Creating and using game-based learning apps where failure is temporary and success is always within reach.

column1: Open Maker Portfolios: Capture, Share and Assess
column5: Kylie Peppler (Indiana University Bloomington), Stephanie Chang (Maker Ed)
column6: Frustrated with test scores, grades, and traditional assessment? Thinking through ways of allowing youth to showcase their abilities and voices in real ways? Join Maker Ed's workshop session on open maker portfolios and engage in an opportunity to make a simple project while also capturing and documenting the process you go through. Inspired by Maker Ed_s current Open Portfolio Project, in conjunction with Indiana University_s Creativity Labs, the workshop will include discussion around portfolio principles, practices, and assessments, as well as facilitation techniques and documentation tools.
column7: Experience the process of creating a simple maker portfolio and consider what sort of prompting and facilitation is useful.
column8: Gain a deeper understanding of how portfolios can be used as means of assessment within formal and informal educational settings.
column9: Gain a deeper understanding of the current work and research on open maker portfolios.

column1: Podcasting as an Authentic Assessment
column5: Alexa Schlechter (Norwalk High School)
column6: Tired of the same, boring assessments that produce regurgitated responses from students, time and time again? Challenge your students to analyze, synthesize,  collaborate, write, and produce a podcast that truly showcases what they've learned instead of just briefly memorized.During this session, educators will learn how to implement this project-based assessment from start to finish, all while embedding their required curriculum standards. Using Google Apps for Education, various online sites, and podcasting programs, educators will receive a step-by-step foundation on how to integrate podcasting into their own classrooms and leave able to use these skills with their students.
column7: Identify the benefits of podcasting as an authentic assessment and its ability to evaluate a broad spectrum of skills
column8: Breakdown the step-by-step process of making a podcast, from brainstorming the idea through to editing the vocals.
column9: Determine the best use of podcasting in subject/grade specific areas and devise a plan of action for how to use a podcast assessment.

column1: The ILN Performance Assessment Resource Bank
column5: Linda Darling-Hammond (Stanford Center for Opportunity Policy in Education), Carisa Barnes (Kearny Digital Media and Design)
column6: Educators & students need authentic forms of assessments that drive meaningful & engaging learning experiences for students that better prepare them to excel after graduation. The use of performance assessments shows great promise and has risen to the forefront of education policy discussions. Nevertheless, education leaders often struggle on how to best support educators in the implementation of performance assessments. The Innovation Lab Network Performance Assessment Resource Bank (the ILN Resource Bank) is a tool aimed to advance the use of performance assessments in classrooms.
column7: Learn about the benefits in the use of authentic performance assessments to redesign teaching and learning.
column8: Identify common challenges related to performance assessments including concerns related to educator capacity, technical quality & policy conditions.
column9: Explore how to leverage the ILN Resource Bank as a tool to enable the design, development, review, use and scoring of performance assessments.

column1: A Compass for Creative and Critical Thinking/Doing
column5: Ela Ben-Ur (Olin College of Engineering & i2i Experience), Hassan Hassan (4.0 Schools)
column6: The _Creative Compass_ is an intuitive cognitive tool that visually and actionably frames four essential ways we stretch in creativity, critical thinking, and innovation. In this hands-on workshop, participants will see the Creative Compass in action in learning environments, orient it to their experiences, and build directly on it. Situations will span from curriculum design to classroom discussions and from 1-on-1 coaching to visualizing individual or organizational growth. Groups will reflect on their sense of this tool, and of the broader aspiration to help young people creatively and collaboratively navigate their way through any challenge/opportunity they meet in school, work or life.
column7: SEE ONE: Experience the many forms the Creative Compass has taken in the hands of students, educators, administrators, and other professionals.
column8: DO ONE: Engage with the Creative Compass. Orient it to problems and approaches you experience in your classroom, staffroom, boardroom_or living room.
column9: TEACH ONE: Experiment on fellow participants! Actively prototype the Compass visually and verbally in the ways you teach, coach or work with others.

column1: Brain Science and the Future of Teacher Training
column5: Glenn Whitman (CTTL), Dr. Ian Kelleher (The CTTL at St. Andrew's Episcopal School)
column6: Mind, Brain, and Education (MBE) Science is the most innovative thinking being applied to enhancing teacher quality and student achievement today. However, few teachers and school leaders understand how the brain learns and changes. Teachers and school leaders are clamoring for models of school-wide integration of the principles and strategies of this science. The Center for Transformative Teaching and Learning, in partnership with university researchers and faculty, has developed a multi-tiered professional growth framework that workshop participants can use to inform, validate, and transform how they teach and how each of their students learn.
column7: Workshop participants will investigate the foundational principles and strategies of Mind, Brain, and Education Science that all educators must know.
column8: Workshop participants will learn how to apply and measure three types of research--"ready made," original, and action-- to their work with students.
column9: Workshop participants will become part of a growing, transnational, Mind, Brain and Education Science professional learning community.

column1: Break Higher Ed Barriers with Behavioral Science
column5: Ethan  Fletcher (ideas42), Alissa Fishbane (ideas42)
column6: Applying behavioral science can help higher education experts approach old problems, like helping students navigate tricky systems or simply show up to class, in new ways. We begin with a crash-course in behavioral concepts through live demos of psychology experiments, followed by interactive case studies from our extensive work in higher education that demonstrate the successful use of behavioral science to solve difficult problems. We_ll discuss solutions to common problems, as well as explore the results of real, field-tested designs.
column7: Gain an introduction to frontline research in applying behavioral science to higher education practice and policy
column8: Look at old challenges- like why college students don_t re-apply for financial aid after their first year- in new ways, offering innovative solutions
column9: Provide a set of diagnostic tools participants can use to assess behavioral problems and design simple, effective solutions in their work

column1: Design Charrettes: Engaging with Stakeholders
column5: Mohammad Riza (Amplify Education), Quentin Suffren (Amplify Education)
column6: Amplify has years of experience developing engaging and innovative reports that communicate complex pictures of student assessment data through simple, actionable visualizations. With every new reporting project, we engage stakeholders in an intense design charrette around their reporting needs. The charette turns every user into a designer, giving them the opportunity to engage and explain what they are looking for in their own words.In this session, Amplify designers and consultants will take participants through a design charrette to demonstrate the methods we use to elicit meaningful input from non-designers.
column7: Learn how to solicit input and translate ideas into requirements
column8: Learn how to manage disparate groups of stakeholders and bring them together around key goals
column9: Learn how to use design principles to make requirements gathering more effective and fun for participants

column1: Future-casting: Why Speculative Design Matters
column5: Phil Balagtas (GE Software)
column6: Some call it alarmist and sensational, however, Speculative & Critical Design can be a powerful future-casting tool to address the social, cultural, political and ethical impact of design. Through a variety of exercises and examples, participants will learn how to identify a signal, project it into the future, and apply methods for synthesizing with different speculative & critical lenses. Participants will also learn how to apply this methodology in everyday practice as a method of lateral thinking towards responsible design.
column7: Understand the facets of Speculative & Critical Design (SCD)
column8: Learn 3 Methods for practicing SCD future-casting
column9: How to identify future challenges and use SCD practically

column1: Learning How to Learn with Concept Mapping!
column5: Laura Gatto (BrainPOP)
column6: This workshop defines the characteristics of good concept maps, how to create them and best practices for using them in your K-12 classroom.  Concept maps are powerful visual thinking tools for organizing, explaining and representing ones knowledge.  They are used to challenge students to explore focus questions, to solve problems in creative ways, and to look for patterns across subject domains.  In other words they encourage critical thinking skills. When we discover patterns or cross-links between ideas our learning deepens our understanding grows and we build our knowledge structures.  This is how we turn mere information into knowledge.
column7: Theory: Attendees will learn the theory and research that underpin the efficacy of concept mapping in the classroom.
column8: Use: Attendees will practice how to nurture divergent thinking for problem solving using concept maps to generate fluent, flexible, & original ideas.
column9: Assess:  Attendees will learn ways use rubrics and other creative approaches to give students formative feedback.
column12: brainstorming, problem solving, collaborative, multi-disciplined design teams, design theory, design studios

column1: So Many SXSWedu Ideas: See How They Connect
column5: Michael Ellsworth (Civilization), Amy Shaffer (The Wonderment)
column6: You just had an inspiring conversation. And saw a cool new app. And had an insight into a teaching approach you want to try.Now come explore how all these different ideas connect_and how they connect us to each other.Based on the findings of a three-year social experiment called the Idea Idea, this workshop is a place to actively explore, collide and combine ideas you_ve gathered during SXSWedu with other people/ideas. With insights into the social, neurological and cultural elements involved in such exchanges (and a bit of play), you_ll build new awareness and confidence to share and integrate your ideas across schools, skill-sets or industries_and make a few new friends to boot.
column7: Recognize and know how to overcome the barriers that keep us from sharing and integrating our ideas.
column8: Understand the cognitive and social processes involved in ideation and how to use them to make meaningful connections with others.
column9: Practice connecting your ideas from SXSWedu with others and develop fun, smart ways to bring your them home and integrate them in your daily life.

column1: Teaching How To Think, Not What To Think :FPSPI
column5: Marianne Solomon (Future Problem Solving Program International), Cori Coburn-Shiflett (Georgetown Independent School DIstrict)
column6: Grounded in teaching students "how to think" and not what to think, Future Problem Solving Program International (FPSPI) stimulates critical & creative thinking skills, encourages students to develop a vision for the future and prepares students for leadership roles. Founded in 1974 by creativity pioneer, Dr. E. Paul Torrance, FPSPI engages students in creative problem solving within the curriculum and provides competitive opportunities.  FPSPI involves thousands of students annually from Australia, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, Portugal, Singapore, Turkey, United Kingdom, & the United States. Join us as we explore the future through the FPSPI process. Get involved!
column7: To develop the ability of young people globally to design and promote positive futures through problem solving using critical and creative thinking.
column8: To inform interested parties how they can easily implement and/or support the FPSPI program in international 4-12 schools and beyond.
column9: To demonstrate hands-on how FPSPI supports critical thinking, problem solving and global collaboration for students from different backgrounds.

column1: Teaching Metacognitive Skills with Mobile Devices
column5: Tyler DeWitt (Self-Employed)
column6: What is more important than teaching students how to learn? Mobile devices can be extremely powerful tools to teach metacognition and to reveal the cognitive process in learning. As an educator, it frustrated me when students didn_t complete math homework because they _didn_t get it._ Then, I asked them to video record their hands and paper with smartphones as they did the work, talking me through why and where they were confused. Now I could _see_ the cognitive process. Here, we_ll talk about the pedagogical and technical aspects of using mobile devices to teach metacognition. We_ll examine different strategies and gain hands-on practice so teachers can immediately apply these new skills.
column7: Experiment hands-on with different methods of using mobile devices for teaching metacognition in a wide range of educational settings.
column8: Understand technical aspects, such as logistics of using device cameras, hosting content on websites, and managing online interactions.
column9: Brainstorm to come up with ways to use devices to address learning challenges in each participant_s unique classroom environment.

column1: Connected Learning: Transform Professional Growth
column5: Teresa Caraway (An educational endeavor of the Oberkotter Foundation (name announcement and website launch, Fall 2015)), Kendall Morris (Create Digital)
column6: Now more than ever, professionals are challenged with continuing to grow their professional knowledge while meeting the ever-expanding demands of their career. Learn how one organization is leveraging technology to advance the skills, knowledge, and practices of their industry. By empowering discipline specialists to share their learning & develop dialogues around best practices, they are creating connected learning experiences that will change professional practice & improve outcomes for professionals & the children they serve. Experience firsthand the fundamentals of communities of practice & dive into a discussion on designing experiences that foster meaningful professional learning.
column7: Technology can empower connected learning experiences.
column8: Social media allows for sustained, coherent and intense professional learning anytime anywhere and fosters vibrant online communities of practice.
column9: Non-profit organizations can use connected learning to dramatically alter their impact and effectiveness.

column1: Design Online Learning to Impact Teaching Practice
column5: Jenna  Hynes (Teachstone), Hilary Ritt (Teachstone)
column6: Can online learning improve teaching practice?  Our learners asked for the ease of online learning and the high quality of our face-to-face courses, so we set out to find the answer.  Join us as we share our story of how we transformed our online learning delivery and sparked behavior change by working at the intersection of fidelity, affordability, and usability.  We_ll use this model to support you in setting direction for quality online learning within your organization.
column7: Define quality online learning for your organization
column8: Plan to better meet learners_ needs online
column9: Prepare to communicate your vision

column1: Exploring solutions for better employability
column5: TBD TBD (TBD)
column6: The World Caf is a dynamic and structured conversational method to facilitate discussions and decisions around concrete topics. A number of discussions are concomitantly organized in the same room; a host leads and facilitates each discussion towards the emergence of concrete inputs for the initial question. Participants have about 20-30 minutes to engage in one discussion, moving then from one conversation to the other.This Generative World Caf will be a continuation of the Panel Discussion, and will aim to dig deeper into the question of education and employment and generate new ideas and insights from the collective understanding of this issue by participants.
column7: TBD
column8: TBD
column9: TBD

column1: Hip-Hop culture purpose education
column5: Byron Chambers (Global Records)
column6: My idea is to create a panel that educates all who participate in the Hip-Hop culture or all that are curious about the culture . I am an Austin Hip-Hop pioneer that was part of the 1st movements  of the culture being spread on 6th st and around town . I have participated in the 1st SXSW shows that implemented Hip-Hop with Keir Worthy and Andre Walker , Both of whom were in charge of setting the 1st Hip-Hop shows up .  I teach Hip-Hop history and culture purpose daily , From the knowledge that I research to the information that I relay from the NY pioneers that were actually there in the beginnings .
column7: To educate those who want to learn the culture's purpose that don't know where to start .
column8: To educate others about the 1st pioneers that started the culture and those that  changed the culture .
column9: Promote the elements , purposes , and the original intent of the culture .

column1: Improv(ing) Presentation Skills
column5: Jennifer Oleniczak (The Engaging Educator)
column6: Public speaking is feared more than death. Why? We spend so much time preparing WHAT we are going to say that we fail to focus on the HOW.While some people make wooing a crowd look easy, for a long time, public speaking was accepted to be hard, a skill possessed by and necessary for only a select few professions. Today, whatever your profession, the ability to stand in front of an audience and express your ideas and accomplishments, publicly and effectively, is not just admired but is expected.In this interactive workshop specially designed for SXSWedu speakers, we'll work specifically on the HOW you say what you say. You'll get the polish - and the practice!
column7: To polish and elevate personal speaking stylistic elements in pose, projection, enunciation, gesture, eye contact and improv
column8: To develop awareness and begin to eliminate speech disfluencies
column9: To better prepare to speak at SXSWedu

column1: Learn or burn: upping your team's digital fluency
column5: Merritt Robinson (Prophet), Dari Yerushalmi (Prophet)
column6: Digital is too important to be left to the digital people. Everyone in your company must get smart on technology and the radical shifts it is enabling. You need a plan to make digital learning appealing and accessible to all. We attacked all fronts to up our company_s digital IQ, developing a framework for content, engagement and application, and implementing it globally. We_ll share the vision and signature moves of our program along with video documentation of employees moving through their digital learning journey. Workshop participants will apply the DL&D framework to identify important criteria for their organizations and the building blocks of a custom digital learning program.
column7: How to frame and identify the right set of learning initiatives and which topics are cornerstones of a digital curriculum
column8: How digital learning feeds into and strengthens a broader learning agenda and how to develop partnerships that support nontraditional learning
column9: Which techniques, topics and courses resulted in high engagement and impact

column1: Nutrition Education Teacher Workshop
column5: Dan Marek (Whole Kids Foundation), Stephanie  Folkens  (Common Threads )
column6: Common Threads, a national nonprofit, committed to fighting childhood obesity by empowering underserved communities to cook for life has partnered with Whole Kids Foundation to give 5k+ teachers in Austin/NOLA nutrition education through the foundation_s Healthy Teachers program.Our program explores the state of food offerings, standard US diet, childhood obesity, healthy eating principles & tips, food as medicine, produce guides, nutrition labels, serving sizes, nutrient dense foods, cooking demos & techniques, recipes & connections between lessons & various state standards. Educators who go through the training receive a certificate of completion & proof of participation (cont ED credit)
column7: To have a strong understanding of the critical need for nutrition training as a preventative measure to fight the childhood obesity crisis.
column8: Recognize responsibility as role models practicing healthy habits for students, an understanding of what eating healthy looks like & how to implement.
column9: Tied to classroom state standards. Lessons will aid in creating a school-wide culture of health and empower students to make healthier choices.

column1: Personalizing PD: Digital Self Directed Learning
column5: Jonathan Maxwell (Katy ISD), Kelli Mallory (Edusmart)
column6: Teachers are not only prescribed what, when, and how long they teach their students, but also what, when, and how they will learn professionally. We believe that professional learning should be ongoing, cyclical, and focused on student achievement as well as personal growth. To achieve this, a model of self-directed and collaborative professional learning can be structured that leverages current digital technologies. This session will explore several strategies and digital tools for supporting teacher led personal learning through the use of a workshop model highlighting rotating workstations where discussions will center on how to effectively support teachers in learning with each tool.
column7: Better understand some of the tools and options that teachers could use to collaborate, research, and learn together in a digital community.
column8: Strategize with others to provide a broader range of continuing professional development opportunities for teachers to meet their learning needs.
column9: Experience models of professional learning and collaboration in small group workstations that can easily be translated to your district role.

column1: Resume and Career Development for Teachers
column5: Will Staton (Democracy Prep Public Schools)
column6: This session is designed for teachers who want to find new employment either within or outside the field of education; it is interactive with a focus on how to talk about one's career as an educator and highlight skills on a resume. It focuses on skills and storytelling that can aid candidates as they seek jobs in any field. However, the session is specifically designed to encourage people to remain cognizant of their time in the classroom, and apply the values of teaching regardless of the job.
column7: Attendees will be able to deliver a concise and powerful narrative about why they became teachers and what they are taking from the experience.
column8: Attendees will be able to verbalize transferable skills and highlight those skills on their resumes.
column9: Attendees will be able to explore instructional and non-instructional jobs within the field of education.

column1: Unconferencing SXSWedu!
column5: Stephanie Cerda (St. Gabriel's Catholic School), Adam Holman (Austin ISD)
column6: It's time to tap into the collective brainpower of educators in the room! Far too often professional development is a one-size-fits-all model that teachers feel is done to them rather than with them. An Edcamp is an innovative form of PD, often called an 'unconference', that brings educators together to talk about the things that matter most to them: their interests, passions, and questions. The agenda is created the day of the event and is based solely on the wants of the participants at SXSWedu. All this is done with the intent to share promising and innovative practices, which ultimately improves teaching and learning in schools.
column7: Participants will cultivate organic discussions on topics of interest.
column8: Participants will share their best practices as well as their questions with fellow educators.
column9: Participants will engage with a diverse set of educators.

column1: Classroom Data Analysis with Experiments in Space
column5: Ben Peters (Ardusat)
column6: Using real data from student experiments on satellites in Low Earth Orbit, we will walk you through the basics of analyzing data and teaching data analysis with Python. Learning topics will include importing data, dealing with missing/incomplete data, changing data frequency, averaging, visualizations, and basic statistical analysis using the tools of choice of scientists. Our goal is for every teacher to be able to leave the workshop ready to help their students analyze data from real world science experiments.
column7: Learn the basic tools required for Python data analysis and how to set them up
column8: Learn how to import, resample, and transform data.
column9: Learn how to create effective data visualizations and share completed data analyses

column1: How to Cope When Marketing Goes Digital
column5: Erika Ferrin (Smithsonian Institution)
column6: Digital marketing is the future of non-profit and higher education marketing. Yes, because digital marketing is extremely effective, but it can also be...FREE! Learn some tried and true formulas to help connect audiences to your content, programs, events, and majors through 13 general tips that you can use on your digital and social media properties. For free! Or at the least, for cheap. Small or no marketing budget? Then this session it for you. We'll workshop how to make your content or ideas more appealing to young audiences and how to piggy-back on big events online.
column7: Best practices in digital marketing to young audiences.
column8: How to market for free or for small budgets.
column9: How to "refresh" dry or informational content on the web for marketing to younger audiences.
column10: marketing, communications, public relations, publicity, tourism, travel, nonprofit

column1: Practical Measurement: Data for Improvement
column5: Heather Hough (Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching), Sola Takahashi (The Carnegie Foundation)
column6: This workshop introduces the principles and uses of _practical_ measures to support educational improvement. In contrast to accountability and research measures that dominate the field of education metrics, practical measures can be used easily and effectively by practitioners to provide powerful insights embedded in daily practice. We will address the characteristics of practical measurement and its uses in improvement efforts in school contexts. Participants will have hands-on experience with practical measures, analyzing data in groups and executing practical data visualizations.
column7: Participants will understand how measurement for improvement differs from measurement for accountability or research.
column8: Participants will learn about visualizations of data that are useful in improvement, such as Pareto charts and run charts.
column9: Participants will know protocols and practices to use when examining data with colleagues for the purpose of improvement.

column1: Understanding our digital identity
column5: Finola  Kerrigan (University of Birmingham), Pam Briggs (Northumbria University)
column6: Educators understand the increasing importance of social media as an educational resource as well as a way to have fun, relax and communicate. Through the use of films made entirely from the social media content of their subjects, participants can reflect on their own social media usage. This will be combined with reflection on participants own social media identities as presented through social media app MySocialBook. These actions will feed into the creation of a social media manifesto which will be useful for workshop participants and can be used with students to help them to think about how their digital identity can evolve as they evolve, start careers and encounter life changes.
column7: To investigate together how digital identities are formed and interpreted.
column8: Through examining the presentation of others' digital identities, attendees will be exposed to the challenge of managing our digital identities
column9: To develop a manifesto for social media to develop skills and practices for managing our evolving online selves in line with life changes

column1: Utilizing Arts to Teach STEM in Early Childhood
column5: Amanda  Whiteman (Wolf Trap Institute for Early Learning Through the Arts), Jennifer Cooper (Wolf Trap Institute for Early Learning Through the Arts)
column6: Experience how the performing arts enhance STEM knowledge for our youngest learners!  Using the performing arts to teach STEM concepts can build vital skills and inspire life-long interest in STEM. In this session participants will learn how to utilize the arts to engage young learners in the discovery processes integral to math, engineering, and the sciences.  Attendees will actively participate in dynamic arts experiences to understand the natural connections between the performing arts and STEM, and examine research that confirms the value of arts-integrated learning. Participants will also explore how performing arts strategies can be adapted to meet the STEM needs of their community.
column7: Explore a fresh perspective on STEM learning for young children and understand the connection between performing arts and early childhood STEM
column8: Come away with lessons learned on how teachers can successfully integrate the performing arts and STEM content to improve children_s STEM knowledge
column9: Review and discuss implications of research on the value of performing arts learning and the importance of STEM in early childhood

column1: Achievement or Opportunity Gap? Just Close It
column5: Elizabeth Gaines (Forum for Youth Investment), Shawn Griffin (Collaborative Communications)
column6: Today, higher income families outspend lower income families by 8 to 1 for enrichment activities outside school (Duncan and Murnane, 2011). Across the country, educators are working to close this opportunity gap. Solutions, though, require investment. In this session we will explore communities that have taken a strategic approach to raising and aligning resources to close the opportunity gap by mapping existing funds and securing sustainable new funds for children and youth to get an equal start.
column7: Learn the ABC_s of mapping the existing resources that can be tapped to support enrichment opportunities for all kids
column8: Hear how other communities have passed special taxing district legislation to raise new funds to close the opportunity gap
column9: Gain a deeper understanding of the opportunity gaps that compound the isolating effects of poverty on children

column1: Community Programming: Think Outside the Classroom
column5: Allison Keil (Community Roots Charter School), Sahba Rohani (Community Roots Charter School)
column6: One of the important elements of a truly innovative model is to be responsive to the needs of the community.  It seems imperative to not only have schools that meet the needs of our children, but also spaces where the school begins to feel like a vibrant community where all voices are heard and there are opportunities for involvement.  During this workshop, participants will be exposed to a number of practices adopted by Community Roots Charter School that engage students, staff, and families in developing school community.   Educators will leave prepared to go back to their school with an innovative new approach and practical plan to implement a program based on their own school site.
column7: Participants will be exposed to best practices in community development by learning about community programs in place at Community Roots.
column8: Participants will gain a deeper understanding of how to develop innovative and responsive community programming that consider diversity.
column9: Participants will be supported in planning one community program in their school based on a needs assessment of their school community.

column1: Cradle to Career Learning: Philanthropy Invests
column5: Ana Tilton (Grantmakers for Education), Karen Brennan (Harvard School of Education)
column6: As social and technological forces reshape the environment, the educational landscape is being similarly transfigured as parents, employers, policymakers and students grow impatient with incremental efforts to transform systems. Too often such efforts have proven both slow and inadequate to the evolving needs of all learners: innovations have been inequitably distributed, promising solutions have been difficult to implement at scale.
