Grantmakers across the nation are collaborating to address the inequities and assist in shaping a common vision for learners of all ages. Join our interactive session and assist in defining priorities for funding the future of teaching and learning.
column7: Explore present practices and future challenges and promise of developing learners prepared to succeed in a globally competitive world.
column8: Understand the implications of new technology for the delivery of more personalized learning.
column9: Inform education grantmakers' role in addressing inequity in education.

column1: Creating an Equitable STEM Classroom
column5: Kiki Prottsman (Code.org)
column6: An equitable learning environments means legitimate and equal social and intellectual access to class content. Unfortunately, not all learning spaces are inclusive or equitable. This inequity in education has led to a shocking trend in STEM industries: a well-documented dearth of women and people of color in the technological workplace.  In this hands-on, interactive workshop, participants will engage in learning activities and discussions to build their own capacity for creating equity in the classroom.
column7: Explain why equity matters in STEM and Computer Science education
column8: Self-assess your level of comfort with creating equity
column9: Identify easy to implement strategies for overcoming biases and making a more equitable classroom

column1: Ferguson and Beyond: Education & Social Justice
column5: Tracey Benson (Harvard Graduate School of Education)
column6: This case study presentation explores the circumstances that informed the organizational response of three school districts in St. Louis County to the civil unrest following the shooting of Michael Brown by a local police officer on August 6, 2014 in Ferguson, Missouri.  How should organizations, particularly education organizations, respond to incidents involving racial tensions?  This case brings to the forefront the racialized context in which educators operate, but often do not acknowledge.
column7: Participants will be able to recognize, identify, and analyze how structural racism impacts communities.
column8: Participants will be able to analyze political, social, and community context through a racial lens.
column9: Participants will be able to identify vestiges of structural racism and begin to think about how to combat them.

column1: From Butts in Seats to Minds on Fire
column5: Virgel Hammond (KnowledgeWorks), Matt  Williams (KnowledgeWorks)
column6: If jeans are not one-size-fits-all, why should learning be? Our education system advances students based on the amount of seat time, and not on their mastery of critical content knowledge and skills. From Butts in the Seat to Minds on Fire will explore what learners, educators, schools, districts and communities need to do to shift to a competency-based, personalized learning model. This is not a sit and git. Participants will collaborate to establish multiple learning communities that redefine how learning and proof of competency is determined. They will be given the tools to re-imagine systemic learning operations, while working within the confines of current finance and policy structures.
column7: Understand a personalized, student-centered approach to teaching and learning; how competency-based empowers an equitable system of education for all.
column8: Explore a re-imagined system that redefines how learning and proof of competency is determined & how districts can scale CBE within current structures
column9: Examine how policy structures support new innovative thinking and what state/federal government can do to catalyze and incentivize this shift.

column1: Is My Subconscious the Problem? Racial Bias in Ed
column5: Morgan Craven (Texas Appleseed), Yamanda Wright (Texas Appleseed), Madison Sloan (Texas Appleseed)
column6: Kids of color are punished more frequently in school and are less likely to live and attend school in high-opportunity communities than their white peers. To address these inequities, we must understand how racialized systems form and the part we play in perpetuating them. We all have unconscious biases that inform the way we view and assess students. Participants will explore these biases with an interactive group test and examine the role that community formations play in creating large-scale unequal education opportunities. Participants will also develop concrete de-biasing techniques and a nuanced understanding of the role our subconscious plays in creating race-based inequities.
column7: To explore the concept of subconscious (implicit) bias and identify our own biases through a group Implicit Association Test.
column8: To understand the real-world implications of our subconscious biases, with a focus on teacher-student interactions and unequal school discipline.
column9: To practice concrete techniques to address our subconscious biases in order to attack systemic inequities in our schools and communities.

column1: No computer, no problem: code in Swift on iOS
column5: Brian Foutty (Trumbull Career and Technical Center)
column6: Learn Swift with having access to only a single Mac or no Mac in your setting? A Swift Time to Code iTunes U course was developed for students in an iPad 1:1 high school so that they could learn to code in Swift on their iPads. Why Swift? Why now? Swift is quickly becoming one of the most popular programming languages and will be the language of the future as it will be used for app, web, and server-side development. A Swift Time to Code will give more students access to learn Swift since it is iOS based. More students can learn coding, problem solving, collaboration, logic, and communication. One language; multiple education and CS applications - period.
column7: Learn some of the basics of the Swift programming language through completing 2 Basic and 2 Intermediate Swift Time to Code iTunes U course lessons.
column8: Learn how to use the courses in the Swift Time to Code course on an iOS device or a Mac to teach coding to middle school, high school, & adults.
column9: Learn how to use Xcode and Playgrounds to enable students to learn coding and computer programming and get access to Swift TTC teacher course.

column1: Opening Up Educational Resources
column5: Matthew Dearmon (Elite Continuing Education University)
column6: In an era of innovation in educational technology that has spawned promisingly proliferative structures such as Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), Open Educational Resources (OER), and Open Scholarship, one question often goes unanswered: just how "open" are these innovations in practice? This session will overview some common ways of understanding openness as a possible tool for improving access and achieving greater educational equality. Attendees will then have an opportunity to work collaboratively to assess and improve the level of openness in their own work or field. Concrete methods will be shared to empower educators to harness the power of truly open education.
column7: Attendees will understand the utility and possible challenges posed by the "4 Rs" of Educational Openness (Hilton, et al., 2010).
column8: Attendees will assess the relative level of openness in their own work or that in their field.
column9: Attendees will workshop concrete methods to make their online educational resources and/or products more open, accessible, and proliferative.

column1: School _Brutality_ and Unconscious Bias
column5: Tracey  Benson (Houston Independent School District ), Sarah Fiarman (Harvard Graduate School of Education)
column6: Cases of police brutality surface the need to address unconscious bias in the police force.  Similarly, educators need to examine our own biases in order to recognize their damaging impact on children.  As authority figures, we respond quickly and instinctively to student behaviors, questions, and ideas. Too often we escalate problems instead of deescalating them, we reinforce inequitable outcomes instead of disrupting them.These responses are inextricably tied up in personal biases _ many of them unconscious, unexamined, and harmful to children.We begin by surfacing unconscious biases we all harbor. Through personal stories, we explore how to disrupt these biases in ourselves and schools.
column7: Learn one way that I am biased even though my intentions are otherwise.
column8: Recognize different forms of structural racism at my school and ways to disrupt these often long-term embedded and unquestioned systems.
column9: Commit to an action step to increase awareness of personal and structural racism at my school as a first step in dismantling the harmful outcomes.

column1: Science & Hip Hop - Creativity to Curiosity
column5: Tom McFadden (The Nueva School)
column6: Come for the live science raps, stay for the exploration of the Next Generation Science Standards. Tom makes a science YouTube show that brings diverse STEM role models into K-12 classrooms. In each episode, scientists model NGSS performance expectations & discuss their research. Episodes end with a music video prompting students to write their own verse on content, lab experiences, or science metaphor. The show helps science teachers to connect their classroom inquiries to the cutting edge research being done by young, diverse scientists and engineers and to use hip hop to engage the subset of kids for whom musical creation is a key hook into core content. Tom leads you in writing a verse!
column7: Connect science students to a diverse set of young charismatic scientists & engineer role models.
column8: Integrate NGSS science and engineering practices and performance expectations into cutting edge research questions being explored by scientists.
column9: Write your own "Verse Two" to a "Science With Tom" music video and experience how to utilize hip hop ed in your classroom.

column1: Swift Learners: Girls Coding By Design
column5: Mary Kiang (St. Andrews Priory), Douglas Kiang (Punahou School)
column6: Gain hands-on experience in coding using a new approach called Coding By Design that focuses on app design as the primary motivation for learning to code. We_ll use Swift, Apple_s new app development language, and explore middle school and high school resources to teach kids how to design and code their own apps that solve a problem or serve a purpose.This workshop is designed for anyone curious about what goes into creating an iOS app, as well as those looking for an innovative way to teach coding and programming that newly engages larger numbers of girls (and many boys as well) by providing relevance and context to what they are learning.
column7: Learn strategies for engaging girls in coding and programming activities centered around iOS app design and development.
column8: Experience coding in Swift using the Coding By Design approach and create workable prototypes using the Xcode development environment.
column9: Learn how to access and use a brand new high school coding curriculum that uses Swift to design and build apps.

column1: Teach about Race and Meet Common Core Standards
column5: Susan Santone (Creative Change Educational Solutions)
column6: Racial inequality is a challenging but necessary curriculum topic. To be effective, lessons must move beyond celebrations or anti-bias actions to include social analysis of institutional discrimination. This requires the advanced literacy skills at the heart of Common Core. This session will introduce a field-tested course on racial equity for grades 6-12. The course gradually builds understanding of racism and its solutions while also developing Common Core (CC) ELA skills. The session will highlight the course framework, introduce sample lessons, and review a 2014 pilot with 300 students (80% low-income, 80% African American) that resulted in 20%-95% gains on key Common Core ELA standards.
column7: Introduce a developmental framework for scaffolding instruction on race, racism, and its solutions while also building Common Core ELA skills.
column8: Analyze the design of a course developed with this framework and ways it develops academic and social-emotional learning.
column9: Assess instructional strategies that move students from viewing racism as an individual act to an understanding of institutional discrimination.

column1: 3 Steps To Start Selling into NYC Schools
column5: Kathy Walter (Nsoma), Deborah Chang (Nexus Works)
column6: New York City is an ideal testing ground for new education products & services but a notoriously hard market to enter. NYC is ideal as a testing ground because:- It has the greatest density & diversity of K-12 schools in the United States- Its school leaders are encouraged to innovate & have the decision making power to try new products & servicesIts barriers to innovation, however, include:- School leaders pressed for time & not interested in cold calls, emails, or meetings- Little insight into individual school contexts & needs- Difficult to discover informal sales channelsThis session lower these barriers by educating entrepreneurs on how to sell into NYC schools.
column7: What is the current state of New York City_s education procurement process? What roles do the district, school, & company personnel play?
column8: How do you establish productive relationships with early adopter educators & school leaders? Only they can add you to the NYC DOE purchasing portal.
column9: How do you scale up in NYC after you_ve successfully gained entry to the NYC DOE purchasing portal?

column1: A Hero's Journey: How to start a school.
column5: Isabel Gadala (Talent Unbound), Alejandro Rivera (Talent Unbound)
column6: Do you have the spark it takes to start your own school?Explore what works and what doesn't work when starting a school; from the day you choose a mission statement, to recruiting new students, building a curriculum, the first day of school, and the day-to-day.Leave this workshop with a clear idea and an action plan.Dive deeper into the journey of starting new schools, why would you do it, what are the biggest challenges, what's the most fun part? What will YOU do differently?
column7: Learn about the biggest challenges of starting a new school and how to overcome them. It's not easy, but it's definitely rewarding.
column8: Learn how to construct a clear mission statement and guiding principles, recruit parents, structure a curriculum, and best practices for hiring.
column9: Learn about why it is important that people start new schools. What micro-schools are and why they're making a comeback.

column1: An entrepreneurial mindset for student success
column5: Bree Langemo (The Entrepreneurial Learning Initiative), Gary Schoeniger (The Entrepreneurial Learning Initiative)
column6: An entrepreneurial mindset can empower ordinary people to accomplish extraordinary things; it is a mindset that exposes opportunity, ignites ambition, and fosters the intra- and interpersonal attitudes, behaviors, and skills that lead to success, both in college and in life. This session will offer an inside look at a promising new approach to student success designed to harness the power of entrepreneurial thinking as an essential life skill. Drawing from the results of an initial pilot, this session will lead participants in the fundamental practices of the entrepreneurial process for student success and will help participants devise new approaches to student success at their institutions.
column7: Redefine entrepreneurship in a way that anyone can embrace, and understand how the person, the process, and the situation foster student engagement.
column8: Shift from teacher-dependent to self-directed learning, by engaging learning models that foster autonomy, mastery, and relatedness.
column9: Bridge the classroom and the community, by making connections and building relationships that can support students throughout college and beyond.

column1: Cognitive in the Classroom: Educating the future
column5: Anoush Arakelian (IBM Watson)
column6: This session would be surrounding the recent expansion of Cognitive Computing courses in the classroom. Through a unique partnership with IBM Watson, professors around the World have had hands on access to some of the most innovative and new cognitive technologies. Students have the ability to build their own applications and ultimately create their own businesses surrounding their cognitive applications. We would have our lead IBMer or IBM Watson executive describing What is cognitive? How the course works? And show you an instance of Watson from the inside. Then we would have one student come speak to their application and future business ideas with cognitive.
column7: What is cognitive computing? Why is Watson a game changer?
column8: What does it mean to work with your own instance of Watson? How does Watson work?
column9: After you have trained and ingested data, what kinds of final projects can you expect to see? What makes these applications "cognitive"?

column1: Crowdfinance: Financing your Startup Organization
column5: AdaPia d'Errico (Patch of Land), Manolis Sfinarolakis (Reality Crowd TV Media Corporation)
column6: In this interactive workshop, learn practical strategies for using crowdfunding to finance your startup organization. We_ll review examples of organizations that have successfully implemented campaigns as well as brainstorm ways for participants to use crowdfunding as a financing resource. This workshop will benefit small businesses selling products and/or services, as well as non-profits, government agencies, and institutes of higher learning who run centers for entrepreneurship.Instructor: Manolis Sfinarolakis, Founder & CEO, Reality Crowd TV Media CorporationInstructor: AdaPia d'Errico, CMO of Patch of Land
column7: Overview of crowdfinance: Attendees should leave with a firm understanding of crowdfinance and its many applications in entrepreneurship & education.
column8: 9 stages of crowdfinance: A step by step process where attendees learn how to run funding projects or create course curriculums for their organization
column9: Case studies & audience participation: Audience will learn how to apply the step by step funding process through case studies & live Q&A segment.

column1: Dynamic Design, design for change
column5: Henk Haaima (Mirabeau)
column6: The web is still largely populated by static pages. These static web pages are somewhat like type cases _ old fashioned printer_s drawers used to store letters, with content stashed away in boxes and in which nothing really springs to life. This is the tragic downside of organisation-driven design. But this means that there is still a whole new world to discover when it comes to dynamic design.The workshop will be guided by the magazine 'Dynamic Design'. The articles in this magazine call for the creation of interfaces that respond to the user, not just in terms of content but also layout, look and feel. Dynamic design to create living, breathing interfaces.
column7: How to kill off the conception of the web as a collection of static pages that are linked by navigation?
column8: How to transform an organisation driven (static) design into an user and data driven (dynamic) design?
column9: What is the drawback of contextual design? What can we learn from the world famous architect Rem Koolhaas and his oneliner 'fuck the context'?

column1: Empowering Students with Critical Thinking Skills
column5: Chuck Clayton (NexLevel Thinking)
column6: This workshop is designed to teach people to organize their thinking using critical thinking, decision making and problem solving tools and techniques.   Practical critical thinking is lacking in today_s society.   It is not a core subject in most schools and yet it severally needed.  We are moving towards a more entrepreneur economy.  According to an article in Forbes, 50% of the labor force will be freelancers (entrepreneurs) by 2020. This information is cross cultural, essential for students, teachers, professionals, medical personnel, entrepreneurs and anyone else who needs to think on their feet.
column7: The basics of practical critical thinking, decision making and problem solving skills.
column8: Why organized thinking is crucial for students, teachers, professionals, entrepreneurs and anyone else who has to think on their feet..
column9: What you can do to be a more powerful critical thinker and to teach others to do the same.

column1: Making in swedish K-12 schools -a way to learn CT
column5: Katarina  Eriksson (Lulea Kommun), Karin  Hallberg (Lulea Kommun)
column6: During the workshop we will show and let you try some examples of thing that we do together with our pupils in our K-12 schools to make them go from digital consumers to digital producers. We will also show you how our special website for sharing ideas works and how you can use it.Our work starts in the Swedish curriculum. We use making as a theme to increase our pupils computational thinking (CT) and their entrepreneurial abilities. We try to get all subjects involved in this work and we share our ideas on a special website, Skapeididh.
column7: Examples of things you can do with your pupils to increase their computatinal thinking
column8: How to take part of and to share your ideas on our website "Skapeididh".
column9: How you can work to increase your pupils entrepreneurial abilities.

column1: Open Code: An Applied Workshop
column5: Claudia Reuter (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt)
column6: Coding is something we can all learn, a skill we can all share and a tool we can all use to solve the complex challenges facing the education space. It empowers us to translate ideas into reality. Open digital environments have created opportunities to make teaching and learning more accessible, flexible and equitable. Coding literacy, for both students and educators, is vital to the success of STEM curriculum and will prepare young people for achievement in career, college and beyond. Join experts from HMH Labs for a hands-on coding workshop and an introduction to using APIs to create apps, leverage creative problem solving and connect the education community.
column7: Provide an introduction to APIs led by experts from Houghton Mifflin Harcourt_s ideation center, HMH Labs. No previous experience necessary.
column8: Demonstrate why coding is an essential skill for teachers and students to understand and use in the classroom.
column9: Guide participants through the creation of a sample app using HMH APIs to build creative solutions for education challenges.

column1: Teachers as Designers: Design on a Global Platform
column5: Molly  McMahon (IDEO), Emma Scripps (IDEO)
column6: Join The Teachers Guild, an open innovation platform out of IDEO and The Riverdale Country School, for an interactive design sprint where we_ll create solutions for a key challenge facing education. In this workshop, you_ll sharpen your design thinking skills and become connected to a global network of teachers on our platform. You_ll walk away with new and better solutions, the mindset of a designer, and the ability to bring design thinking to your school.
column7: DESIGN THINKING: Teachers will learn the methods and mindsets that guide the design thinking process.
column8: COLLABORATE: Teachers will learn strategies to collaborate across a distributed network of teacher designers.
column9: INNOVATE. Teachers will create new solutions to a key challenge facing our education system.

column1: Game of Village: Learn Real Life on a Small Scale
column5: Dee Cardenas (AHB Community School)
column6: Game of Village (GoV) is a powerful, flexible, constructivist game that spans the disciplines in classrooms. It can be applied to any K-12th age group. Students solve real-life problems on a small scale, exploring roles and interests through a gaming avatar, a Peep.  GoV provides an integrated form of education, drawing from multiple disciplines~often simultaneously~that includes the four core subjects as well as the arts, and importantly, the often overlooked realm of social-emotional learning. Unlike digital games, GoV provides actual face-to-face interactions that are as instructive as they are unpredictable.  Mistakes can be learned from in a safe and supportive environment.
column7: How to create authentic learning opportunities and projects to nearly any content through the creativity of teachers and their students using GoV.
column8: How to expand social-emotional learning opportunities in a safe gamified context, including practicing resilience, failure, and interpersonal skills.
column9: How to emphasize cross-disciplinary and project-based learning while covering content and skills.

column1: Hackaball - A computer you can throw
column5: William Owen (made by Many), Veronika Janeckova (Made by Many)
column6: In this workshop you will learn how Hackaball works and how you can use it in your computer science lessons to teach children about Algorithms, Debugging, Decomposition, Instructing a computer, Bluetooth and wireless connection, Controlling physical devices, Input and output sensors and Computational thinking.Hackaball is a smart throwable computer for children aged 6-12 that helps them learn basics of programming while having fun! It's a connected digital device that's packed with a gyro, an accelerometer, a vibration motor, eight LEDs, a rechargeable battery, some memory and a speaker. That's all encased in a shock-absorbent housing, and can be programmed over Bluetooth using an iPad.
column7: Challenge the definition of a computer. Gain confidence in computing terminology through visual, auditory and kinesthetic demonstration.
column8: Teaching through generative play - learn how to facilitate children-driven learning process with Hackaball and its accompanying app.
column9: Learn how to teach programming basics in a fun way. Use "make, test, learn" approach to create your own game with Hackaball.

column1: Includification - How to Make Games Accessible
column5: Mark Barlet (AbleGamers)
column6: Includification is the award-winning document that teaches developers file to make popular AAA titles and indie games as accessible as they can be while still appealing to a mass audience. We'll discuss the top accessibility options that can be included to increase profit and include large segments of the disability community. We'll dive into the importance of being inclusive in an ever more diverse world. And we will get audience members to take away the knowledge of how to make popular ideas accessible and fun at the same time.
column7: The top obstacles for people with disabilities in videogames and how to overcome them.
column8: The business and ethical reasons behind including accessibility options for those with special needs.
column9: How to look out for people with special needs when you don't have a disability yourself.

column1: Pink or Blue? Examining Gender in Games
column5: Julie Evans (Project Tomorrow)
column6: Contrary to what we may want to believe, emerging research indicates that use of digital tools and content within learning is not gender-blind.  While girls and boys share a common interest in technology to support personalized learning, their uses of and aspirations for digital learning are often quite different.  This is especially true with game-based learning.  In this workshop, we will roll up our sleeves and interact with a variety of games that are popular in education.  Using a new evaluation tool, participants will gain an insider perspective on gender-bias or sensitivity within games by examining the characterization, imagery and language, storyline and results of the game play.
column7: Learn background and terminology associated with the emerging field of gender-sensitivity in digital learning, most notably in digital content & games
column8: Gain first-hand experience in determining the gender-sensitivity of specific types of games through the use of a new evaluation tool and game play
column9: Understand the importance and impact of gender-sensitivity when designing, implementing and evaluating games for K-12 education

column1: STEMlandia - An outdoor STEMcache gaming adventure
column5: Barbara MacEachern (Educational Gaming Environments at TERC), Jamie Larsen (Educational Gaming Environments at TERC)
column6: How can you open the door and let nature help guide STEM learning? Hear how our pilot, STEMLandia _ an outside gaming adventure at an arboretum, used geocaching to explore and engage people of all ages with the outside world. Learn how educators can design and create STEMcaches and use a free tool to connect them through adventures that guide players to discover and uncover STEM concepts and content. These location-based adventures are a great way for teachers to address nature deficit disorder and reconnect digital natives to the local environment. Don_t spend hours locked in a classroom, create an adventure to uncover STEM connections that leave no child inside!
column7: Understand how a real-world treasure hunting game can be used to create an outdoor adventure to connect STEM learning with nature exploration.
column8: Learn how to create a STEMcache, a special type of geocache, to facilitate learning and exhibiting 21st Century Skills with STEM concepts and content.
column9: Overview the free tools available to educators to work with learners to create an engaging STEMLandia type adventure.

column1: Built to Last: Sustainability & Revitalized Retail
column5: Heather Arnold (Streetsense)
column6: Laying groundwork for sustainable communities requires comprehensive investment today. Building on Streetsense and DC Office of Planning's Vibrant Streets Program, the session will highlight how neighborhoods can expand economic development & quality of life while reducing over-consumption.Most markets have an abundance of supply & VS encourages neighborhoods to redevelop existing retail space before adding new buildings. This creative use of inventory fosters inclusive, diverse communities that are attractive to all populations and form the basis of a sustainable shared economy. Take home tools to incorporate flexible design, revitalize vacant spaces & build physical & fiscal longevity.
column7: Attendees will be able to measure what kind of retail can be best supported their own commercial retail centers.
column8: Participants will learn how to focus community members around the common goal of retail street revitalization through flexible design.
column9: Participants will understand actions needed to reactivate struggling commercial areas & incorporate local communities in the revitalization process.

column1: Challenges & Solutions in Competency Based Ed
column5: Doug Naylor (Motivis Learning), Emily  Dustin (Motivis Learning)
column6: Competency based education (CBE) poses unique challenges that require dynamic and adaptive solutions in response to the limitless possibilities available in an anywhere, anytime, anyplace learning environment. Education without the usual constraints of walls, clock hours and a one-size-fits-all curriculum offers students in K-16 the most personalized education possible.  But how do we manage student information and the tracking of student progress towards mastery with so much diversity? Hear from industry leaders and expert educators committed to building customizable learning relationships with students through scalable blended learning.
column7: Learn what anywhere, anytime, anyplace learning looks like & how schools in K-12 and higher education are breaking the constraints of traditional ed.
column8: Learn how to build personalized learning experiences through learning relationship management through scalable blended learning.
column9: Learn how to connect students with affordable education, internships and resources that prepare students in a highly personalized way for success.

column1: Coding with Scratch: Connected Learning Workshops
column5: Paulina Haduong (Berkman Center for Internet & Society), Sarah Otts (Lifelong Kindergarten Group, MIT Media Lab)
column6: Today, creating and expressing oneself with technology are key fluencies for civic engagement. How can we increase the diversity of youth who become engaged in creating with new tech? We will explore ways to engage youth in their diverse interests, like fashion, hip-hop, or sports, through related activities using Scratch (a creative computing environment). Based on this design experience, we will discuss ways to develop and facilitate connected learning activities for youth. All levels welcome, from newcomers to experienced Scratchers. Bring a laptop (if available) to this hands-on workshop.
column7: To explore Scratch as a creative coding environment.
column8: To share ideas, resources, and best practices for implementing workshops for youth, as well as lessons learned.
column9: To develop and facilitate connected learning activities.

column1: CUE Air Corps and Sphero Speedway Jam Sessions
column5: jon corippo (CUE, Inc)
column6: CUE Air Corps and Sphero SpeedwayCUE Rock Star Jam Sessions at SXSW will be led by pair of top CUE Rock Stars co-teaching far out hands-on sessions featuring Coding, Spheros and quadcopters. The CUE Rock Stars will supply ample drones and use free apps. Only thirty people will be allowed into the sessions, providing a highly supportive and very intense learning opportunity. These are real life life skills that will bring math, science, writing and logic skills to K-8 classrooms
column7: Coding and robotics via Sphero and quadcopter drones
column8: Actively using STEAM in core subject areas
column9: Sharing free classroom resources to support coding and programming

column1: DEEP design thinking
column5: Mary Cantwell (Independent )
column6: What is Design Thinking?  When you ask this question, usually you either get blank stares or a bunch of big-worded malarky.  Design Thinking isn_t rocket science-- it is simply people-centered problem solving.  In this session, participants will go through a rapid 101 introduction of Design Thinking (DT), but, more importantly, they will learn that there is not just one way to screw in the proverbial DT light bulb. Participants will zero in on a K12 teacher designed and tested methodology called DEEPdt  (Discover Empathize Experiment Produce). They will also go through a Flash Lab (aka crash course) for DEEPdt where they will get their feet wet and curiosity unleashed into a methodology that
column7: What is design thinking, really?
column8: How can I adapt the standard design thinking process to meet my school_s needs?
column9: What ways can DEEPdt be utilized to revolutionize learning and instruction in the classroom and beyond?

column1: "Deliverology": The Lost Science of Implementation
column5: Courtney  Hawkins (Providence Talks ), Traci Wodlinger (Eagle County Schools)
column6: Implementation is often the missing skill-set for an education leader. If _culture eats strategy for breakfast,_ as we often say in reform circles, then implementation eats it for lunch! But it doesn_t have to be this way: implementation is a discipline that can be taught, practiced, and learned. That_s why we call it _deliverology_: the emerging science of getting things done.This workshop is for leaders who are tired of seeing good ideas fail to get the results they hoped for. Hear the stories of two leading practitioners who are using _deliverology_ to drive student results. Then, take the opportunity to work with them to apply the tools they've used to your own context.
column7: Understand what quality implementation looks like through two different case examples (Providence Talks and Eagle County Schools)
column8: Explore and practice with tools for goal setting, data and root cause analysis, and implementation planning
column9: Reflect on how you can apply these tools to the specific situations facing your organization

column1: Design Make Go: MakerEd & Tech Integration
column5: Patrick Benfield (St. Gabriel's Catholic School), Stephanie Cerda (St. Gabriel's Catholic School)
column6: This session is participatory, interactive, and hands-on by design. Meant for novices and experts alike, be prepared to engage your heart, mind, and hands to explore the fundamentals of constructivism.After an overview of the cultural and pedagogical contexts of making, participants will delve into concepts like tinkering, making thinking visible, human-centered design, and best practices for technology integration, followed by an opportunity for Q&A. No makerspace? No Problem! The concrete, culturally responsive examples taken away can be used in any setting and budget.
column7: Develop a greater understanding of the historical, cultural, and pedagogical contexts of making
column8: Explore specific ideas and activities for culturally responsive making in a variety of settings
column9: Discover ways to thoughtfully integrate technology to support making

column1: Disrupt and Co-construct - Lessons From NZ Ed
column5: Steve Mouldey (Hobsonville Point Secondary School), Claire Amos (Hobsonville Point Secondary School )
column6: This session will explore how one school is disrupting education in New Zealand. With their cross-curricular, project based learning approaches and their use of blended technology students at HPSS experience authentic, connected learning which they share with peers, teachers and families. In this workshop, participants will be introduced to a curriculum design process for co-constructing effective cross-curricular learning, workshopping ways to take lessons from this approach back to your own context.
column7: To explore cross-curricular project based approaches can support authentic, connected learning
column8: To learn how to co-construct a cross-curricular (interdisciplinary) High School courses
column9: To co-construct a cross-curricular (interdisciplinary) project based module

column1: High Schools & Colleges Collaborate; Students Win!
column5: Stacia Edwards (Columbus State Community College), M. Scott Reeves (Westerville City Schools)
column6: Can it be true? Yes! And you can help make it happen. Across the country, colleges are collaborating with high schools to create aligned and engaging educational experiences focused on college and career readiness. Students in these programs are much more likely to complete college and successfully enter a career. Participants will hear from a leading example_Columbus State Community College and Westerville City School District (Ohio) _and will participate in an interactive planning session facilitated by the speakers and experts from Jobs For the Future and Education First to identify concrete strategies they can pursue in their communities to advance this type of collaboration.
column7: What are the components of a strong high school/college collaboration and alignment agenda?
column8: What are the ingredients for successful collaboration? How does it happen?
column9: What can I do in my community to start and nurture strong and effective collaboration?

column1: Higher Education Hacks - Tech Tools for Completion
column5: Anthony Edwards (Tarleton State University), Jennifer Edwards (Tarleton State University)
column6: Higher education administrators, faculty, and staff encounter common problems that negatively impact student success at their early college high school, community college, or university.These common problems usually include: recruitment, developmental education, retention, on-time graduation rates (completion), increasing costs, changing demographics, workplace readiness (marketable skills), and budget constraints. Through this session, participants will identify higher education problems, explore low-cost and higher-cost solutions, and connect with others through social media-based, higher education learning communities (on Facebook and Twitter).
column7: To identify the MOST COMMON problems encountered by higher education administrators, faculty, staff, and students.
column8: To explore low-cost and higher-cost technological, programmatic, and service-based solutions for addressing the MOST common higher education problems.
column9: To connect with other participants to form two higher education learning communities: 1) teaching and learning and 2) higher education solutions.
column11: community college; student success; higher education leadership

column1: Improv(e) Your Ethics
column5: Karen Landolt (Engage Leadership Consulting), Amira Pollock (Center for Professional Education)
column6: Research shows that you are better equipped to behave ethically in the workplace when you have scripted in advance how to respond in the moment. We will use activating scenes, a technique used in theatre education, to role-play ethical dilemmas and help you enhance your in-the-moment responses to real life scenarios through strategic rehearsal. Join us for an interactive session that will apply improvisation techniques to expand your understanding of ethics and values, help you identify ethical red flags and equip you with decision-making frameworks to solve ethical dilemmas.
column7: Increase your likelihood of behaving ethically in difficult professional situations by role-playing how you would respond.
column8: Understand decision-making frameworks and how to use them to effectively assess and act on an ethical dilemma.
column9: Prophylactically spot ethical _red flags_ in the workplace and pre-script viable responses.

column1: Making Tech, Before Using Tech
column5: Alex Tosti (blink blink), Nicole Messier (blink blink)
column6: STEAM educational products introduce kids and adults to the basics of programming -- what_s missing from the conversation is a deeper understanding of electronic and engineering concepts behind the devices we use everyday. blink blink is the first educational kit that is providing a hands-on, under-the-hood introduction to the fundamentals of technology.  The session, Making Tech Before Using Tech will walk artists, educators, and hobbyists through the core principals of DIY physical computing using blink blink Creative Circuit Kits. You will get a hands on experience of designing, drawing and bringing to life creative circuits, switches and even sensors through simple DIY wearables.
column7: Understand the value in getting inside the _black box_ of electronic devices in order to learn the  fundamentals of circuitry & engineering concepts.
column8: Encouraging creative expression through wearables, arts, & crafts that integrate STEM concepts such as engineering and electronics.
column9: Teach educators how to setup a _sandbox_ style learning environment that meets a balance of enough space to explore with minimal boundaries to learn.

column1: No One Way: Creating Diversity in Education Styles
column5: David  Gilden (The University of Texas at Austin), Rozanna Yousef (Youth Innovations Cultivator)
column6: According to Swisher (1991) a learning style is generally thought of as the method by which one comes to know or understand the world. For some Native Americans, learning can be transmitted through storytelling from elders to children. In Bhutan, schools add some mindfulness exercises to their classes, and in the largely quoted Finnish system, we can read of importance in personal growth and outside the classroom learning. Why not embrace the idea that students can learn in a variety of ways, or that different educational structures can exist in one nation. Join us to learn about the importance of diverse learning, and to work with us to bring real change into our existing model.
column7: To Learn About Different Educational Models Around the World.
column8: To Understand Why Having a Variety of Learning Styles is Important in Schools
column9: To Work with the Audience on Different Solutions that Can Be Used To Start Actual Change In The Educational System.

column1: Promoting Diversity Through Project-Based Learning
column5: Michael Depew (University of Pittsburgh, School of Information Sciences), Dmitriy Babichenko (University of Pittsburgh, School of Information Sciences)
column6: High schools, colleges, and universities are working to introduce problem-based and project-based learning into curricula. We have successfully implemented a framework for identifying clients and projects from both industry and academia, mapping projects to learning objectives and students_ interests, and allowing faculty to streamline project management processes. This problem solver session will demonstrate how such a project management framework can be applied in virtually any domain, both in high school and in higher education, to promote collaboration between diverse populations. We will share our workflows,  templates, documents, and personal experience with the session participants.
column7: Learn how to create a manageable project-based learning framework
column8: Identify linkages between projects and course learning objectives
column9: Learn how to ensure quality of students_ work with iterations and frequent feedback

column1: Proven Process to Create Student Success Programs
column5: Jennifer Smith (The University of Texas at Austin), Susan  Harkins (The University of Texas at Austin - TIP Scholars Program)
column6: Want to learn how to create a new or transform an existing student success program? In this workshop, you will learn to: articulate the problem your organization seeks to address, identify your champions, examine available resources, and define your program population and goals. We will tackle big questions like - Who else is doing what you are doing?  What are their best practices?  Where do I start?  Facilitators with over 34 years of experience in higher education will use real examples from the Texas Interdisciplinary Plan (TIP) Scholars and University Leadership Network (ULN) programs to shed light on proven practical ideas and give you a heads up on pitfalls to avoid.
column7: Identify the problem your program addresses
column8: Network
column9: Problem-solve

column1: Running an Hour of Code Event
column5: Marcus Duvoisin (Digital Media Academy)
column6: The Hour of Code is a nationwide initiative during Computer Science Education Week to show students that anybody can learn computer programming.  This session will demystify code to teachers and prove that anybody can learn how to run an Hour of Code event.  No prior experience is necessary!  Get your hands dirty by learning the basics of a visually-based programming language called 'Processing' which has been highly successful in alleviating student's intimidation of code.  Spark an interest in your students and move one step closer to getting computer science in your school's core curriculum.
column7: Understand what the Hour of Code is and it's purpose.
column8: Prepare yourself to run an Hour of Code event with logistically varying setups.
column9: Learn how to continue the spark of interest in Computer Science in your students and your school after the event.

column1: Running Experiments in Outer Space
column5: Kevin Cocco (Ardusat Inc.)
column6: Learn how the emerging market of small satellites, CubeSats are democratizing access to student space exploration.  This workshop will include running hands-on experiments using CubeSat sensors in the classroom.  These same sensors are available on a constellation of CubeSats for student experiments.  Attendees will work with the tools used to design and upload experiments to satellite in low earth orbit.  Data analysis and visualization of previous space experiment data will be used to demonstrate the tools for creating a shareable experiment portfolios.
column7: Learn how to run hands-on classroom experiments with sensors and Arduino micro-controller
column8: Learn how to document the engineering / scientific method of an experiment into a shareable student portfolio
column9: Learn how to design experiments to be run on satellites in low earth orbit

column1: Solve Design Challenges in PD and Teacher Ed
column5: Ivan Cestero (Breaker), Eliza Spang (Woodrow Wilson Academy of Teaching and Learning), Shula Ehrlich (Institute of Play)
column6: Only 29% of teachers are satisfied with current professional development. What does it take to design engaging and effective teacher education and PD programs? Learn about design processes used by 3 new programs that aim to create more effective learning experiences for teachers, and explore design tools that you can apply in your own program. Then put these tools into practice immediately by testing a program component and helping to solve a design challenge the program is facing. Programs featured in this session will include the Woodrow Wilson Academy of Teaching and Learning, Institute of Play's TeacherQuest, and Breaker's Breakaway Workshops.
column7: Discuss real design challenges facing developers of PD programs for pre-service and in-service educators.
column8: Explore how teacher education and PD programs are prototyped through user-centered design processes.
column9: Test and provide feedback on program components, and reflect on how you can use the components and testing process in your own programs.

column1: A Disciplined Life: Activating Students for Peace
column5: Diana Shulla-Cose (Perspectives Charter Schools)
column6: The students at Perspectives Charter Schools in Chicago are standing up for peace in a movement that has gained national attention. In this interactive workshop, you will learn about the A Disciplined Life education model that empowers students to become ethical leaders for peace. After watching a short documentary about the students' peace movement (featuring U.S. Secretary of Education Arne Duncan and Grammy-winning artist Jennifer Hudson), you will work side-by-side with teacher and student peace ambassadors from Perspectives to brainstorm ways to cultivate a culture of peace in our schools, our communities, and throughout the globe.
column7: Understand the 26 principles of social-emotional learning curriculum of A Disciplined Life.
column8: Understand how students are enabled to create a culture of peace through the A Disciplined Life education model.
column9: Understand how to partner with students to foster peace in their schools, communities and throughout the globe.

column1: All Aboard the ELL Train: On-track Strategies
column5: Dr. Karon Henderson (Comal ISD), Linda Hicks-Green (Round Rock ISD)
column6: WHY should we, and HOW can we, develop linguistic accommodations for differentiated instruction? We'll review current research in the areas of language acquisition, brain research, and social learning communities, and share strategies to address the needs of the beginning-to-intermediate English speaker. Our goal is to support and design a framework to encourage PERSONAL REFLECTION of actual practices in the classroom for optimal ELL learning.
column7: Explore current brain research and its implications for the performance of English Language Learners.
column8: Learn about the latest social research and what community-building instructional practices keep students engaged.
column9: Understand the supports needed for differentiated classroom and to create opportunities for personal reflection on applying these strategies.

column1: ARG! Let's Create Games for Learning
column5: Jeff  Borden (St. Leo University), Cecila Bolich (Saint Leo University), Mitchell Weisburgh (Games4Ed.org)
column6: Role Playing Games (RPG) and Alternative Reality Games (ARG) excite students, enable them to take risks, and promote deep learning of both academic and higher order skills. After a brief intro into the what, how, and why, we will spend 2 hours creating an RPG or ARG that teaches a core academic subject including pre-game activities, the game itself, curriculum, assessment, reflections,and post-game activities. Participants will both be able to use this game and to lead teams to create other games in their content areas and grade levels. These are games that motivate, develop academic and 21st C skills, and assess learning.
column7: What are RPGs and ARGs, how do they work, and how do we use one?
column8: Specific curriculum and classroom instructions in using an RPG or ARG in a classroom to teach a topic
column9: The process and roles of creating an ARG or RPG that can be used in schools to teach and to assess learning

column1: Be a Highly Effective Manager and Instructor
column5: Kewanta Greer (Feed the Mind)
column6: This is not an _all talk, no action_ presentation.  Innovative techniques for classroom management and differentiated instruction will be modeled for and practiced by participants.  Session attendees will return to the field equipped with the tools they need to put philosophy into effective practice. Through clear, systematic instruction, this training proves how effective management brings the art and science of teaching into balance, which in turn, translates into academic success.Plan future lessons that will touch on many different modes of learning. Create instructional strategies to accommodate the full range of ability and intelligence in your classroom
column7: Handle challenging behaviors, decrease referrals, and manage with compassion.
column8: Increase academic achievement, promote high level thinking skills, engage all learning styles, promote active participation, and teach with passion.
column9: Reduce on-the-job stress, increase teacher job-satisfaction, and enjoy teaching again.

column1: BlocksCAD: STEM Learning thru 3D Design & Printing
column5: Henry Hough (Einstein's Workshop), Solomon Menashi (Einstein's Workshop)
column6: Learn how to use BlocksCAD-- an easy-to-learn, yet powerful CAD teaching tool that integrates creative design with 3D printer technology, while re-enforcing math and geometry concepts.Originally developed to teach elementary students how to create their own 3D printed projects, BlocksCAD has been successfully applied in a range of learning environments.An intuitive & familiar interface allows users of all ages to code & design within minutes and successfully printing their creations shortly thereafter.   BlocksCAD is an open source learning tool for students needing a visual, three-dimensional approach to understanding a variety of complex and often abstract math concepts.
column7: Participants will learn how to use the open-source BlocksCAD software and learn how to incorporate it in their specific teaching environment
column8: Participants will learn of specific examples where BlocksCAD was successfully used to drive math & programming learning in a class environment
column9: Participants will have the opportunity to design their own 3D printable object that they can have printed.

column1: Burn the Box: Pushing Past Your Comfort Zone
column5: Sherry Boyd (North Lake College), Ulanda Forbess (North Lake College)
column6: Examine technologies that play a strategic role in innovation and improvement of higher education course curriculum and student engagement. Join presenters, as they dive into the unique pedagogical applications of lecture/screen capture tools (such as_Snagit, Captivate, Kahoot, Zaption, iMovie, and NearPod ) for creating course curriculum and helping students create projects. Offering a re-purposed and innovative approach to using lecture/screen capture & gamification  as student engagement and presentation tools.  The presenters will answer the questions of _What is true feedback, and how can it improve learning?_  We will brainstorm on how these tools can be used in participants classroom.
column7: Demonstrate technology uses for assessment of learning in a wide range of curriculum areas
column8: Create one lesson with one of these technologies that can be use in a F2F classroom or an online classroom
column9: Model & facilitate effective use of current & emerging digital tools to analyze, synthesize, create a short lesson using one or more of the technology

column1: Close Reading 2.0: Web Annotation in the Classroom
column5: Jeremy Dean (hypothes.is), Casey Boyle (University of Texas at Austin)
column6: Our workshop explores web annotation as an essential pedagogical practice for the 21st century classroom. This emergent technology allows Internet users to privately comment on or publicly discuss any web page. It can be leveraged to teach students traditional literacy skills like close reading but also newer forms of digital and media literacy.Workshop participants will be introduced to the pedagogical value of web annotation and gain hands-on experience with an open-source, standards-based annotation client. Participants will leave with a solid orientation in the basic functionality of web annotation and specific collaborative annotation exercises that can be used in the classroom.
column7: Close reading--the ability to support analytic claims with textual evidence--applicable across both literary and informational texts.
column8: Collaboration--the ability to work effectively with others, especially in the context of contributing to a knowledge production project.
column9: Digital and media literacy--the ability not only to comprehend and analyze digital media technologies, but to utilize them for communication too.

column1: Coach the Coaches: Making Discussants of Lecturers
column5: Dustyn Williams (Tulane University)
column6: The flipped classroom is a novel learning approach in which the class leader (teacher) serves more as a discussant than a lecturer. The skillset that makes for an exceptional flipped classroom leader is vastly different than the skillset of a traditional lecturer. Whether looking to enhance their own repertoire, start fresh, or just brush up on some of these techniques, participants of all skill levels are welcomed. This session will explore what it takes to become a successful discussant and team-based learning leader. The reasoning and science behind the skills are developed, and specific skills are addressed with means to learn, improve, and practice once returning to their home class
column7: Understand why the flipped classroom is effective as an instruction model
column8: Learn the skillset necessary to be successful in the role as a leader of the flipped classroom
column9: Practice the skills with feedback and evaluation in real time

column1: Create to Learn
column5: David Ross (Lurner Group)
column6: Educators complain that students don_t demonstrate enough creativity in a standards-based classroom. But isn_t that the result of traditional instruction? Project Based Learning (PBL) is rightly described as an effective method to enhance student creativity, but PBL by itself doesn_t always generate student work. Creativity can be enhanced through structured activities, effective use of technology, and a design framework that encourages students to be creative for a purpose and audience. This workshop will introduce participants to a research-based creativity framework, engage participants in hands-on activities that spark creativity, and explore tech tools that deepen the process.
column7: Participants will examine a research-based framework for encouraging, teaching and assessing creativity.
column8: Participants will experience hands-on activities that generate a classroom culture of creativity.
column9: Participants will be introduced to and then play with tech tools that enhance and promote creativity.

column1: Creative Tech Out the Wazzoo!
column5: Ashley Bailey (Westwood High School ), Brittany Skillern (Westwood High School)
column6: Explore resources you can implement in your classroom TOMORROW. For beginner to intermediate levels of tech-savvyness. We'll explore topics such as: teacher websites, useful websites, useful apps, google slides as interactive agendas, QR codes, creative tech lessons, and more! We'll focus on streamlining your classroom using technology and challenging your students with fun websites and tech-integrated lessons.
column7: Understand how technology can make your classroom more efficient and more fun for students!
column8: Gain confidence with simple tech hacks you can use in your classroom immediately.
column9: Get creative with how students learn, compile, present and share information.

column1: Critical Creativity: Meaning Through Making
column5: Amy Burvall (Edgemakers, Inc), Dan Ryder (Wicked Decent Learning), Sean Ziebarth (Huntington Beach Union High School District)
column6: How might we choreograph an epiphany, remix an analysis, doodle a movement, costume a theme, hashtag a philosophy? We believe acts of making needn_t be limited in size or scope, method or medium, nor need they be mere exercises of imagination or engineering.  Creation reveals comprehension.  Our students_ increasingly diverse toolbox for expression, both analog and digital, emboldens the creative spirit into a force for authentic understanding, a vehicle for demonstrating proficiency.  Come with an open mind and nagging curiosity; leave with a concrete plan and bevy of strategies for integrating innovative imagination into your daily classroom practice.
column7: Participants will identify benefits of creative expression as a means of deeper understanding
column8: Participants will experiment with creative exercises and strategies applicable across the content areas
column9: Participants will design a plan for integrating creative expression into their impact areas

column1: Demystifying coding for elementary students
column5: Robin Ball (EducationCity Ltd), Holly Moffett (EducationCity Ltd)
column6: Attendees will be exposed to a wide range of ICT resources, including EducationCity_s 'Code Crunch Tool'. They will be encouraged to participate in a series of short, scaffolded lessons aimed at introducing computing, including coding, to K-5 students. These bite-size lessons will allow delegates to explore examples which model how to introduce computing to the elementary student. By the end of the workshop they will have a deeper understanding of computing and have a range of proven strategies to use in the elementary classroom.
column7: To be able to define and differentiate between the three core computing strands of digital literacy, information technology and computer science.
column8: Learn how to introduce complex concepts in simple to understand bite-size lessons for students age 5-11.
column9: Understand how to integrate computing into the elementary classroom and how to overcome the technical language barriers.

column1: DESIGN ACTION: Illuminating Climate Education
column5: Karen Magid (The Dumpster Project), Beth Ferguson (Sol Design Lab)
column6: How do we train and empower youth to become innovative thinkers in a broad network of climate actors? Participants in this workshop will get hands-on experience working collaboratively in teams to design a solar based product or service using a human-centered design process. We will examine how the design process enacts a community mindset _ a combination of problem solving and creative thinking that engages participants from different disciplines. Organizers will share lessons from their work using renewable energy education in underserved populations. Learn how you can incorporate solar design curriculum and skills to foster public awareness of renewable energy through hands on learning.
column7: Workshop participants will develop a hands-on solar product that can create transformative education experience for diverse audiences.
column8: Workshop participants will analyze the benefits of design thinking over traditional methods of teaching climate science.
column9: Workshop participants will determine how using design thinking, and tools such as HCD, for solar education can improve energy literacy.

column1: Designing and Sustaining Transformative PD
column5: Mia Morrison (Foxcroft Academy), Michael Mills (University of Central Arkansas)
column6: This workshop will focus on the design and cultivation of inspiring and practical differentiated PD resources, with an exploration of deployment strategies that promote anytime, anywhere engagement that can be sustained independently. Participants will explore techniques to design and deploy high quality PD, including high-impact interactive videos, collaborative agendas, and curated collections as well as engage with resources that allow educators to continue connecting and sharing beyond the traditional one or multi-day face-to-face meeting.
column7: Explore how to design differentiated training resources that are tailored to inspire faculty buy-in and motivation.
column8: Demonstrate effective use of curation tools that provide a "menu of opportunities" for teachers and administrators, both in the short and long term.
column9: Develop opportunities to keep teachers connected and engaged in their PD as they model lifelong learning.

column1: Designing the Next Gen Edu core competencies
column5: Ana  Berger (Brisa - Design LTDA), Ana Cecilia Bisso Nunes (PUCRS)
column6: What will one need to know in the future? This workshop addresses the reflection about core competencies for the next generation education through a collaborative design process. We invite you to think about scenarios of new ways of learning, considering technology and people_s own skills. Are the current educational models preparing one for challenges we even know exist? Innovation in education needs a win; let_s find possible ways together. Expect to empathize with colleagues, interact with a starter kit and to live a design thinking experience.
column7: Reflect about the next generation education core competencies needed as the world changes and technology advances.
column8: Experience a creative collaborative design process to build scenarios of new ways of learning.
column9: Be able to apply the knowledge discussed in the workshop in real life learning/teaching experiences.

column1: Developing a Design Thinking Culture in Schools
column5: Martin Moran (Francis W. Parker School), Tisha Johnson (Francis W. Parker School)
column6: Many schools have a few innovators who approach teaching with a designer's mindset. However, schools are having trouble scaling that mindset across their community. Phrases like "fail forward" and "prototype and iterate" are great, but what are the practical steps teachers and schools must take to develop a design culture? Specific materials and norms are needed to turn the design thinking ideals into reality across school cultures. In this session, we will design materials for schools, from course syllabi for teachers to faculty meeting norms for administrators. With these materials, faculty and administrators can take practical steps towards developing a design culture in their schools.
column7: Understand the practical needs for developing a design thinking mindset within a school culture.
column8: Develop cogent strategies for normalizing the tenets and mindsets of design thinking across schools, not just among early adopters.
column9: Develop specific, tangible artifacts that, when used in classrooms or faculty professional development, help promote design thinking mindsets.

column1: Differentiate with Digital Tools
column5: Amanda Haughs (Campbell Union School District)
column6: Differentiate and personalize learning for all students using digital tools. Come away with blended learning strategies and specific digital tools for differentiating instruction in the K-12 classroom. Tools for both iOS and Chromebook platforms will be covered. Bring a current lesson to modify-- time will be given to collaborate with colleagues to update the lesson to include digital differentiation strategies.
column7: Teachers will be able to use digital tools to create differentiated learning opportunities for students.
column8: Teachers will come away with a collection of digital resources to help them modify lessons in their classrooms.
column9: Teachers will understand ways of managing digital differentiation and of holding students accountable.

column1: Engaged Learning with Next Gen Science Standards
column5: Ben Neiswender (Ardusat)
column6: The Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) have provided a framework for science, technology, engineering and math education. In this workshop teachers, administrators and curriculum developers will get a primer on NGSS, and a hands on experience following the engineering design process to solve a virtual space mission. Attendees will see how fun and easy it can be to engage students in STEM by using the Next Generation Science Standards.
column7: Identify the components of an NGSS style lesson
column8: Follow the Engineering Design process to solve a problem
column9: Identify ways to engage students in STEM using the Next Generation Science Standards as a guideline.

column1: Engaging Tasks + Student Discussion = Math Success
column5: Diane Briars (National Council of Teachers of Mathematics)
column6: Research tells us that engaging students in challenging tasks coupled with discussion of solutions and approaches is essential for building conceptual understanding, problem solving, reasoning, and other habits of mind essential for learning and using mathematics effectively. But what tasks should you use? And how do you orchestrate a class discussion that is more than just _show and tell_? Participants in this interactive workshop will address these questions by analyzing artifacts of practice, including tasks, classroom video clips, and samples of student work.
column7: Identify characteristics of tasks that promote conceptual understanding and standards for mathematical practice (e.g. problem-solving, reasoning).
column8: Learn strategies to facilitate discussions that advance the math learning of entire class by analyzing and comparing student approaches and argument.
column9: Learn strategies for using engaging task development and resulting class discussions as the foundation for teacher development through collaboration.

column1: Exploring Interactive Learning Systems
column5: Katie Leining (Round Rock ISD), Jesse Sosa (Round Rock ISD)
column6: Keeping students engaged in today's classroom becomes more of a struggle as technology advances. Why not embrace these advances and use them to your advantage. Come learn about some of our favorite learning platforms that both capture student attention and increase teacher productivity. Join us as we provide brief overviews and demo learning platforms like Google Classroom, Atlas Learning's Apollo, Nearpod, and Blendspace. As an added bonus we will share a few of our favorite web tools that increase student engagement in the classroom like Kahoot, Padlet, and BrainPOP's newest features!
column7: A better understanding of interactive learning systems available to teachers and students.
column8: An idea of how to implement an interactive learning system that was presented.
column9: Setting up an interactive learning system to use in the classroom.

column1: FIRST Robotics for Informal Ed.: The How & The Why
column5: Gina Watts (FIRST in Texas), Megan Clark (New Braunfels Public Library)
column6: FIRST Robotics programs are a great opportunity for informal education organizations, such as libraries and museums, to provide access to STEM learning experiences for underrepresented youth. However, implementing teams can be a daunting task. In this workshop, we will guide attendees through the process of writing a proposal to start a FIRST Robotics team. We will address common concerns and obstacles, including how to secure continuing funding, how to recruit and train staff & volunteers, team management & retention tactics, and planning for sustainability. Attendees will get a hands-on crash course in robot building & programming, leading a research project, and the FIRST Core Values.
column7: How FIRST Robotics programs can support the mission of informal educational organizations and provide 21st century skills to youth.
column8: How to manage the administrative and logistical issues that may arise during implementation of FIRST programs and develop a sustainable program.
column9: How to build and program a basic robot, direct an engineering research project, and manage a team of youth ages 9-14.

column1: Flipping the Classroom: Building Impactful Prework
column5: Dustyn Williams (Tulane University)
column6: The Flipped Classroom (FC) is a popular teaching modality that requires skills separate from the traditional model. The Pre-Work is the cornerstone for success. Without it, the students come ill prepared for in-class tasks.The session begins before attendees arrive. They'll watch pre-work and learn the skill of building balloon animals, specifically a balloon animal sword. They'll then come to the workshop to build balloon swords.  The session will explore personal experience in the development of an FC by Dr. Williams, who uses an online educational platform he constructed for pre-work preparation for his students. Here, the focus is on pitfalls, costs, and errors learned along the way
column7: Experience the flipped classroom as a learner: pre-work to problem-based learning
column8: Learn what makes worth-while prework and why
column9: Identify the cost and pitfalls of creating and hosting pre-work

column1: Flipping the Script on Your Assignments: Using Dig
column5: Jennifer Peters (Seneca College), Ewan Gibson (Seneca College)
column6: Tired of essays? Looking to integrate digital media into assignments? Let_s explore how to design and support assignments that include videos, infographics, websites and more. Let_s also explore the power of storytelling and digital media. Stories are persuasive and encourage empathy, combine this with digital media and you_ll be amazed at what your students create!All tools used in this workshop are readily available or open educational resources so you can start using them right away!
column7: Create a toolkit of digital media resources
column8: Design a digital assignment using a template
column9: Create an instructional video, either animated or live action

column1: Globalizing Your School
column5: Kate Farmer (Asia Society)
column6: In increasingly diverse communities around the country, schools and educators are working to integrate the knowledge, skills and mindsets needed to support students as global 21st century learners.  Developing students_ global competence gives them the opportunity to apply learning, to engage in real-world thinking and problem-solving, and to make connections relevant to their lives and the broader community.  This workshop delivers strategies to globalize your school to deliver on deeper learning outcomes, while engaging students in meeting state and other standards such as the Common Core.
column7: Articulate the four domains of global competence and recognize how to connect them to classroom activities.
column8: Learn to incorporate a global focus in a lesson plan without being an expert.
column9: Use workshop activities to bring a global focus to a future lesson plan.

column1: HACK Your Classroom with Learning Platforms
column5: Jesse Buchholz (Northwest Nazarene University)
column6: In this session, participants will get hands-on experience with several different learning platforms (apps) and the H.A.C.K. Model of Instruction. They will also learn how to effectively scale technology into their classroom so that students will be engaged and be able to showcase their knowledge as well as increase their own knowledge of what learning platforms work in the classroom.
column7: The objective is to provide a hands-on apps experience that will build educators innovative capacity.
column8: The objective is to provide a hands-on experience that will transform the way educators teach.
column9: The objective is to provide teachers an approach that they can take back to their classrooms and implement the very next day.

column1: Hack Your Classroom: Build a Culture of Hackers
column5: Jason Messer (Manteca Unified School District), Kristen  Messer (Manteca Unified School District), Kathy Cambra (Manteca Unified School District)
column6: Come and explore how Manteca USD (23K students, 30 schools, 1200 teachers, 1:1 Windows 8.1 district) is promoting a maker/hacker culture. This  hands-on workshop will introduce participants to the pedagogy, tools and resources that support teachers successfully engaging students K-8 in hacking, making and coding activities. Come learn how we are using a cloud-based management system to manage and engage students, and try your hand at simple robotics, circuits/circuit boards, and other making/coding activities.
column7: Take away a basic understanding of the maker/coder/hacker culture and why it is important to engage students in collaborative, problem based learning.
column8: Leave with a basic understanding of the current tools and resources available to engage students in simple coding activities.
column9: Leave with a basic understanding of how to engage students with modern tool and resources for robotics and simple circuit boards.

column1: Hack Your Notebook & "Illuminate" Your Thinking!
column5: David  Cole (CV2), Molly  Adams (Waxahachie ISD)
column6: Looking for the right mix of "making," writing, STEM, and collaborative learning? "Hack" your notebook and rethink traditional notions of PBL by combining literacy, craft, science and art to bring 21st century competencies to a new level. Participants will design simple circuit systems, and learn how to integrate cross-disciplinary content with an emphasis on STEM, visual/textual storytelling, concept illumination, and maker-based PBL. We will also look at an open data prototype for notebooks, which integrates artistic and scientific journaling with a wifi dev board, and consider the opportunities for creating fully connected teaching and learning experiences with paper and electronics.
column7: Illuminate thinking in new ways using circuitry and a traditional notebook, turning the familiar sketchbook or journal into a tool for protoyping
column8: Work collaboratively in teams and explore connections between electronics, writing, reflection, fabrication, and production-centered learning
column9: Explore the tinkering mindset & develop your technical & expressive expertise with a creative learning experience that builds STEM and literacy skills

column1: How Education Can Stand Out on Pinterest
column5: Kim Vij (The Educators' Spin On It AND Vij Consulting)
column6: Pinterest is a valuable tool for education.  It can potentiall create a hub where educational resources from around the world can be hand selected and stored for others to discover. In this session we'll discuss a few of my favorite features on Pinterest too that helped us grow to over 1.6 Million followers pinning education based pins.  Including...  _Time saving tips for finding pins easily for your subject area_Pinterest Smart Feed and how to customize for your use_How to collaborate with peer teachers on Pinterest_Tools to use for Pinterest _Tips for Maximizing your Efforts on Pinterest _ How to Monetize your website using Pinterest
column7: To easily use Pinterest to search for content for lessons plan development with time effective strategies
column8: To use Pinterest to connect with educators around the world with common interests and become a voice for educational purposes
column9: To use Pinterest to monetize your online education based business

column1: Improv & Zombies: Waking Up the Virtual Classroom
column5: Kim McGaw (Rice University)
column6: Virtual classrooms are havens for zombies _ zoned out, multi-tasking students who don_t participate.  With no visual feedback online, instructors must find new ways to engage students and ensure they understand the material.
