This hands-on workshop is designed to inspire instructors to be more creative in their approach and to provide them with a toolkit of improv games and exercises to enliven online classes.  Takeaways include the ability to tie improv back to teaching strategies and to translate it to features available on learning management systems such as Canvas and Blackboard.
column7: Come away with a basic toolkit of improvisation exercises that can be adapted to enliven any subject.
column8: Discover ways to create an online learning environment that encourages active participation and builds camaraderie.
column9: Gain confidence practicing what you've learned through interactive challenges incorporating improv and virtual classroom tools.

column1: Improv + An Innovative Mindset
column5: Ellen Deutscher (), Dan Ryder (Mt Blue Campus)
column6: This workshop will be a high energy, hands-on class exploring the intersection of Improvisational Theater and Design Thinking. We will cover fundamental principles of improvisation including collaboration, active listening, resilience, inspiration, risk taking, and storytelling and their relation to a Design Thinking/Innovative mindset. Two veteran public school teachers from across the country will share activities, tips, and tricks that they use daily in their classrooms and in educator workshops they lead around the country.  Be ready to jump in, learn, and enjoy!!
column7: Participants will learn and understand the connection between improvisational theater and a Design Thinking/Innovative mindset.
column8: Participants will walk away with ready to use activities to build creative confidence in their students and school communities.
column9: Participants will learn to bring meaningful play into their classrooms and school environments.

column1: In Defense of Smarter Screen Time
column5: Sarah Morris (Nucleus Learning Network), Emily Weerts (Nucleus Learning Network)
column6: Do you bristle when you hear the phrase "Screen Time"? Often followed by dismissive statements about students staring blankly at devices, screen time needs defenders - and a revamp. Join us as we develop approaches to make screen time more constructive and engaging. Share resources and design activities that you can bring back to school as a Smarter Screen Time Advocate. Participate in debates, discussions, and collaborative exercises as we cultivate a culture that embraces Smarter Screen Time.
column7: Defining the problem: What is wrong with students using screens?
column8: Developing smart responses to screen time criticism and create Smarter Screen Time activities
column9: Share resources, curriculum, and talking points to advocate for Smarter Screen Time in schools, programs, and at home

column1: Kids Coding the Curriculum
column5: Liz Castillo (Punahou School), Jake Lee (Punahou School), Kris Schwengel (Punahou School)
column6: In this interactive workshop, we will look at examples of how students in elementary classrooms are coding out their learning. Coding is used to promote critical thinking, problem solving, and creativity. We will explore how students can code to learn while also building skills across various content areas. This is a hands-on workshop where participants will explore iPad and computer apps such as Kodable, Scratch, and Scratch Jr.  We will also take a look at how Wonder Workshop Dash & Dot robots, BeeBot, Lego WeDo, Makey Makey and other devices help to bring coding alive and extend the learning. Participants will be given time to collaborate and create a plan to integrate coding in K-5.
column7: Participants will learn and interact with blocky coding language using various iPad and computer apps.
column8: Participants will learn application strategies to incorporate coding into literacy, math, science, and social studies.
column9: Participants will collaborate and plan how to incorporate coding into K-5 curriculum and instruction.

column1: Learning Through Virtual Reality Experiences
column5: Maya Georgieva (New York University), Emory Craig (The College of New Rochelle)
column6: This workshop explores the impact of virtual reality on education. Participants experience VR devices to analyze how this immersive Wearable Technology reshapes the teaching-learning environment and institutional culture. New forms of experiential learning will draw upon visually rich virtual and augmented reality experiences. VR is raising fundamental questions about the shape of future media, narrative and storytelling. Technology is rapidly moving from information access to personal experience, where deeply compelling learning environments are immediately available before our eyes, requiring profound innovation in pedagogy, learning space design and institutional culture.
column7: Understand the rapid developments in Virtual Reality and Wearable Technology and the impact on Education
column8: How Virtual Reality devices will disrupt cultural and educational spaces and challenge our understanding of privacy and data analytics
column9: Explore how virtual, visual, and sensory experiences can transform learning and inspire new modes of creative expression and visual literacy

column1: Mind-mapping & Movie-making
column5: Cathleen  Ash (Manor ISD)
column6: Want your students to showcase their learning? See in a moment whether they "got" your lesson(s) or not? Here's how you can! Using Popplet Lite as a mind-map and storyboard, we will create a movie with Animoto. On our way to the final product, we will legally gather web movies, pix and sound, track our progress with a rubric, answer questions on the fly in a back-channel, and move around the room on various missions. Join me for an active, loud, student-centered (you!) and engaged workshop. Learn how to let your students' knowledge shine with these free apps and tools!)
column7: Animoto: create educator accounts, make movies, get fifty free accounts for students to create long movies for six months
column8: Poppet lite: create storyboards with text, drawing and images
column9: Rubistar4teachers and Creative Commons: create easy-to-grade rubrics and learn how to legally access web video, pix and sound

column1: Note This! Using Sketchnoting With Students
column5: Karin Perry (Sam Houston State University), Mary Ann Bell (Sam Houston State University)
column6: Sketchnoting is a great way to take notes, share information, and deliver instruction. Also known as visual note taking, it is an activity that K-12 students can fall into effortlessly. Unlike adults, they have fewer fears about trying to draw and then sharing their creations. Humans are born with a desire to create, need to use their hands to draw and write on paper as well as using technology to create. After a brief introduction this presentation will share successful projects and ideas for using it with PK-12 students and also with adult learners taking classes or for staff development. Technology comes into play with sharing completed notes and also with drawing apps. AND IT'S FUN!
column7: After attending the participant will be able to state the benefits of using sketchnoting in personal, professional, and educational settings.
column8: After attending the participant will be able to list multiple tools (analog and digital) to use when sketchnoting.
column9: After attending the participant will be able to list multiple tools (analog and digital) to use when sketchnoting.

column1: Preparing High Schoolers for the Future Workforce
column5: Oen Michael Hammonds (IBM Design), Erin Hauber (IBM Design)
column6: How do we prepare students for a changing job market? What skill sets are needed for high schoolers to be ready and prepared to succeed in the jobs of today and tomorrow? Using a design thinking framework, this workshop will allow educators/administrators and business owners to understand their audiences, to articulate the experience journeys of their users, and explore opportunities to create a more fulfilling experience for students.
column7: In this workshop, participants will gain a broader understanding of what students need to be successful when entering college and the workforce.
column8: Participants will gain a working knowledge of how to conduct collaborative activities and conversations with their peers to solve real problems.
column9: Participants will walk away with several low fidelity ideas that they can share and test with their peers, users and stakeholders.

column1: Protecting Student Data While Promoting Learning a
column5: David  Katz (Nelson Mullins Riley Scarborough, LLP)
column6: The adoption of cloud-based educational technologies in K-12 education means that student data now plays an increasingly important role in student outcomes.  As schools and districts increasingly turn to technology and data-driven strategies for improving schools and educational outcomes, legal protections regarding student privacy are essential foundations.  Federal law, including but not limited to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)and Protection of Pupil Rights Amendment (PPRA), provide baseline requirements nationwide and many states have added their own unique requirements through state statute.
column7: _Federal and State Regulatory Environment and a Congressional Overhaul of FERPA
column8: _	Recommendations for Technology Companies Navigating the Regulatory Maze
column9: _	Overview of State laws related to Student Privacy

column1: Rapid Prototyping the Classroom
column5: Patrick Pennefather (Simon Fraser University)
column6: Rapid prototyping (RP) is a well-known process in web, app and video game development. How can we apply its principles in educational contexts? This workshop will focus on how RP can support the design of instruction from big picture to specific exercise. Paper and physical prototyping, embodied play and digital prototyping exercises will form the core activities. These will be guided by imposing constraints of time and scope, leveraging improvisation tools and the principles of iterative design inside and outside of the classroom. Design classroom instruction, reflect in the moment, implement, repeat.
column7: Walk away with several rapid prototyping tools you can use in the iterative design of instruction from big picture to small exercises.
column8: Be able to facilitate exercises learned in the workshop to your learners.
column9: Develop a deeper awareness of your own creative limitations when it comes to designing learning.

column1: Rock and Roll: An American Story
column5: Adam Rubin (Rock and Roll Forever Foundation)
column6: Rock and Roll: An American Story is an online educational resource presented by Steven Van Zandt's Rock and Roll Forever Foundation and offered free-of-charge to educators and individuals everywhere. Interdisciplinary in nature, RRAS is geared toward middle and high school students but includes resources for learning at all levels.The workshop will feature RRFF staff discussing various methodologies for engaging students through the study of popular music. The conversation will emphasize ways that non-music teachers can use the curriculum to draw meaningful connections between music culture and a variety of subject areas, including Social Studies and English Language Arts.
column7: Participants will gain a familiarity with the educational resources available on teachrock.org.
column8: Participants will take away a variety of strategies to address popular music culture in the non-music secondary school classroom
column9: Participants will consider how successful pedagogy in music education can be leveraged more broadly to enhance how non-music teachers engage students.

column1: Science Super Powers for the Diverse Learner
column5: Joanne Billingsley  (Billingsley Education), Kathy Reeves (Scientific Minds, LLC), Rosemary Martin (Supporting Science Inc)
column6: Three innovative entrepreneurs, all former science teachers who founded education companies, will share tools and processes that support traditionally underserved students in the science classroom.   Attendees will experience a high-impact mix of technology, manipulatives, and brain-based learning strategies designed to accelerate acquisition of academic language, enhance scientific problem solving and provide scaffolded  support for English language learners, students of poverty and other diverse learners.
column7: To learn strategies to dramatically increase student comprehension and retention of science academic vocabulary and science concepts.
column8: To learn strategies to engage students, including ELLs, with frequent and safe opportunities to use and develop academic language.
column9: To learn strategies to foster enthusiasm for STEM careers and help students develop the academic skills required to pursue them.

column1: Speedometry: Teaching physics through play
column5: Fred Freking (USC Rossier School of Education), Tyron Young (USC Rossier School of Education)
column6: This hands-on workshop enables teachers and after-school staff to break the mold of traditional science instruction by using toy cars to teach physics. Speedometry is a free-to-use integrated STEM curriculum designed for 4th graders. It was developed by teachers and researchers in a first-of-its kind partnership between the University of Southern California and the Mattel Children_s Foundation. Using the 5E model of instruction Speedometry enables educators to guide students' inquiry into the physics of energy. Learn to engage both girls and boys in these exciting STEM lessons. The workshop includes a demonstration and the opportunity to teach through play alongside other participants.
column7: Participants will understand how to harness students' curiosity and creativity to  implement student-driven science inquiry lessons.
column8: Participants will learn how to implement two play-based inquiry science units using the 5-E model of instruction.
column9: Participants will improve their ability to facilitate students' learning through asking questions and guiding independent exploration.

column1: Swords+Plato= Learning: Role Playing in College
column5: Mark Carnes (Barnard College), Julie Casey (University of Texas at Austin), Charlie McCormick (Schreiner University)
column6: How can college students confront complexity and uncertainty? Plunge into the Athenian Assembly in 403 BCE in a microgame to debate the future of the city-state after war with Sparta and civil war.  Plot with your factions.  Debate concepts of justice and reconciliation.  Face exile, compromise, or victory .  Experience the intensity of a Reacting game that engages the intelligence and empathy of college students, leads to deeper learning, rejuvenates faculty, and prepares participants for the unscripted world they will enter. Learn by doing a method that has succeeded in first year seminar, honors, interdisciplinary, and disciplinary courses.
column7: Participants will experience the value of subversive play and role-immersion for learning in higher education
column8: Faculty will learn how to manage games to use student discomfort to get them to engage in critical texts and issues.
column9: Administrators and faculty will earn how Reacting to the Past games can revolutionize classrooms and curricula.

column1: Taming the Maker Beast: Getting Mobile & Modular
column5: Ana Josephson (The Ann Richards School for Young Women Leaders), Kat Sauter (Resources for Learning)
column6: Why isn't anyone talking about the elephant in the maker classroom? You know, the one where you have one teacher and 25 eager students, ready to get their hands on saws, power tools, sewing machines, and 3-D printers? Maker Education is hot, and rightfully so, but has anyone really addressed the issues of how to inspire creativity in this sometimes hectic environment? In this session, experienced maker teachers will offer practical solutions for managing a school maker space. This will lead to a productive, student-centered maker classroom where teachers can actively monitor and scaffold a variety of simultaneous projects, and go home at the end of the day without a throbbing headache!
column7: Participants will develop maker projects that challenge all levels of students to take risks, collaborate and create.
column8: Support projects with engaging, easy to make instructional videos that will allow students to direct their own learning and teachers to monitor.
column9: Organize and schedule a mobile maker space in the classroom to increase productivity, so students aren't waiting around for tools in limited supply.

column1: Teaching Sensitive Topics: Activities That Work
column5: Erin Crabill (Widener University)
column6: It can be difficult to teach sensitive topics. Many an educator has had a classroom freeze up during sex education, or erupt into a flame war over civil rights. In this workshop we will engage in several activities that sex educators have used to encourage critical thinking and create a safe environment where students can collaborate and test themselves. Play the slang game icebreaker, illustrate an issue with _forced choice,_ see where students cluster with the dots game, create bridges between polarized opinions with Reflections, and brainstorm ways to make any of these activities work with sensitive topics in your own educational environment.
column7: Implement several specific activities that allow learners to collaborate and grow from hearing each other_s diverse and even opposing viewpoints.
column8: Create a safe space where learners feel they can express themselves without fearing being _wrong_ or shamed for their personally held beliefs.
column9: Demonstrate the way that unbalancing through emotional discomfort can lead to lasting, more concrete understanding and personal growth.

column1: The Artist and the Engineer
column5: Mary Day (Houston Independent School District), Angelica  Halphen (Houston Independent School District)
column6: The Artist and the Engineer _ Turning STEM into STEAM (Grades K - 8)What are the connections between STEM and Art? This hands-on session will provide relevant experiences that demonstrate how art disciplines can be integrated into STEM to make it STEAM. By immersing yourself in a fun, creative world you will learn how to take Math, Science and STEM Design Challenges to the next level by adding an artist_s touch. The workshop has a workstation format where activities are based on 2D, 3D, and technology applications.
column7: The participants will engage in activities that immerse them in integrating the arts into STEM by partaking in hands-on workstations.
column8: The participants will build connections between the disciplines by collaborating with STEM colleagues and experts.
column9: The participants will compose next steps for integration in their classrooms and schools by collaborating with STEM colleagues and experts.

column1: The New Meeting
column5: Terrel LeCesne (AT&T)
column6: The _New Meeting_ is about acknowledging the strength of style being as important as substance, a breakaway from the old school meeting delivery of _just the facts_.  It_s an open acceptance of everyone_s time is valuable, that those opportunities to interact with your team, peers contain high value.With the emphasis placed upon social collaboration, engagement and innovation it is essential that the audience\participants of the meeting know and see the value of that interaction and how it benefits them while at the same time how they benefit everyone else in the meeting.We will look at techniques that are being used and can be used.  The interactive pot is warming, add your spice.
column7: Will be able to explain why it is essential to create and sustain engagement during meetings and the risk of non-engaged participants
column8: Will be able to explain how to uncover the WIIFM (what's in it for me) of your audience and highlight the value for them.
column9: Will be able to explain what trends and techniques are currently being used to create a value added meeting experience.

column1: This Above All: To Thine Own Lesson be True!
column5: Lord Jim Knight (TES Global)
column6: It_s no secret that teachers are some of the most talented artists. Their medium is the human mind, shaped by word and deed. The performance of an excellent teacher might as well be performed on stage, deserving even of the Globe Theatre!The art of teaching is channeled through the well-crafted lesson plan. This workshop is designed to equip teachers as they hone their planning process. Participants will also be given access to resources on the TES Connect platform_the largest teacher network in the world. An expert from the Royal Shakespeare Company will guide teachers as they create a world-class lesson on ol_ Bill, weaving process tips, resources and insight throughout.
column7: Practice effective strategies to improve the quality and efficiency of lesson planning.
column8: Access and utilize a global network of educational resources created by experts and educators on a wide range of topics.
column9: Learn about the life and work of William Shakespeare from a leading expert and incorporate these learnings into you lesson.

column1: Tools for Thought: Are You Teaching Effectively?
column5: Susan Lysecky (zyBooks), Alex Edgcomb (University of California, Riverside)
column6: Traditional classrooms are evolving in the digital age. From interactive educational content to flipped classrooms, innovative tools and approaches influence how and what we teach. But how do we know which tools and approaches are actually effective? How do factors like class size, student demographics, and subject material weigh in? This hands-on workshop will empower educators from all backgrounds to conduct their own education research studies, from single-classroom experiments to multi-university studies, to empirically determine the effectiveness of specific tools and approaches.
column7: Guide participants through the process of designing an effective education study
column8: Describe the details of statistical analysis for an education study
column9: Share solutions to challenges that an education researcher might face, including IRB review, participant acquisition, and multiple significance tests

column1: Transforming Learning in a Borderless World
column5: Madiha Murshed (Scholastica), Dana Mortenson (World Savvy)
column6: During this fast-paced session featuring student work videos and teacher interviews, and drawing on perspectives from around the world, attendees learn how innovative schools are giving their students a global perspective.  These schools are creating deeply engaging, more globally focused learning environments that strengthen teacher practice and student learning.  The session features a global competence matrix that educators can adopt and a series of practical tools that the presenters will demonstrate with attendees.  It also includes an honest look at the most significant challenges to building a global classroom.
column7: Reframe a lens on learning as demographics shift, and our world becomes more global
column8: Provide resources that attendees can take back to their district/school/classroom and use
column9: Inspire educators with ideas that support achieving the global education and competence goals in their strategic plans

column1: Ultimate Personalized Learning Boot Camp
column5: Dr. Ramona Trevino (Center for Collaborative Education), Dr. Christian  Weilbell (Agilix and Agilix University)
column6: Educators across the nation are rethinking traditional classroom practices to prepare all students for success in college, career and life in the 21st century. Personalized learning (P.L.), student-centered learning and competency based education are key concepts and reform models that are being explored and implemented in districts across various states. Effective technology systems to support and scale these models are few and far between. Through a process called the "Ultimate Personalized Boot Camp" educational leaders, teachers and stakeholders come together to design meaningful and costumized approaches to personalized and student- centered learning.
column7: Participants will be introduced to the "Design Thinking" process through a ultimate boot camp experience.
column8: Participants will apply the design thinking process around their IT problem of practice.
column9: Through the visioning exercise participants will outline a basic plan towards personalized learning in their schools.

column1: Unschool Your Creativity: A Maker Mentality
column5: Jacy Edelman (Lesley University), Sue Cusack (Lesley University), Kreg Hanning (Lesley University)
column6: Is there a way to immunize educators from the pressures of high stakes assessment and increased accountability? Yes! Makerspaces provide the perfect incubator for current and future educators to develop immunity to these pressures and nurture their confidence, increase their risk-taking, and help them foster new learning ecologies for their students that activate engagement and inspire learning. Join us and experience our simple theory of change. Come, be a maker and liberate your creativity.
column7: No more _deer in the headlights_ stress about facilitating maker activities for students; with this experience, these tensions give way to confidence.
column8: Through hands-on maker activities, educators will experience the relationship between divergent thinking, creativity, and increased learning outcomes.
column9: Educators will learn that constructivist maker experiences are not an add-on and can be aligned to their curriculum and support common core standards.

column1: Using Digital Resources to Change How You Learn
column5: Theresa Fox (Laurel School), David  Brubacher (BloomBoard)
column6: Join us for a hands-on experience where we will discuss what makes a learning resource valuable and ways that educators can improve their personal learning experiences. During the session, educators will create collections of resources they find valuable. By the end of the session, you_ll have a set of resources to share with peers, and you_ll have access to the resource collections made by other participants. If you_re looking to discuss and share new classroom inspiration, tools, and other learning resources, this is the session for you!
column7: Understand how to identify and package valuable learning resources.
column8: Design a meaningful collection of professional learning resources.
column9: Reflect on how digital learning resources can be used to empower growth.

column1: What is a makerspace and do I need one?
column5: Linda  Conway (Douglas County School District), Marci Milius (Douglas County School District)
column6: Have you heard the term MakerSpace and wondered what it meant? How do I develop a MakerSpace in my classroom, library, and school? What do I put in a MakerSpace? How does a MakerSpace support learning? How much does it cost to develop a MakerSpace? Spend a few hours and you will learn how a MakerSpace can engage your students for the _best day of school ever_! We will discuss: _ Supplies needed _ Types of MakerSpaces _ Space requirements _ Educational purposes of a MakerSpace _ How get materials for your MakerSpace for free _ Where can I get _stuff_ for my MakerSpace You will spend time as a student in this class prototyping in our MakerSpace. Bring your open mind and creativity.
column7: Participants will learn how to integrate literacy learning into the Makerspace environment through an experiential, hands - on activity.
column8: Participants will understand different types of learning that can occur in a Makerspace.
column9: Participants will be able to create a plan for how to develop a makerspace.

column1: 10 Easy & Inexpensive Ways to Market Your School
column5: Sheryl Simonitis (Noodle), Grace Daley (Noodle Education)
column6: How should you get the word out about your school? Search doesn_t seem to work. Social posts don_t get shared. Emails don_t get opened. So what does work? And why do other schools get more applicants? Join us as we show you the most effective ways to market your school and how to analyze the competition. This session will give you easy-to-implement best practices to take your marketing to the next level. (Bonus: Get a must-have checklist of the best marketing tools every school needs.)
column7: Understand the top marketing channels within the education space.
column8: Gain a firm grasp of the best tools to analyze and review competition and peers.
column9: Learn easy marketing wins to implement to see exponential growth.

column1: 6 Essential Elements to Impact Digital Learning
column5: Christine Fox (SETDA), Carla Wade (Oregon Department of Education)
column6: Participants will be challenged to carefully evaluate the steps needed to plan for & implement or update digital learning environments to personalize instruction & prepare students for college and careers. In-depth discussions will focus on 6 essential elements; planning, professional learning, broadband, tech support, digital content & devices. Highlights of both successes & lessons learned plus a variety of resources will be included. All will take a dive into The Guide to Implementing Digital Learning online resource, to help ensure investments spark positive results. An interactive backchannel will be incorporated with state level digital learning experts who will participate remotely.
column7: Participants will:Understand digital learning tools and resources as one overarching component of achieving school-wide goals.
column8: Understand the essential elements for effective planning for digital learning.
column9: Identify examples of effective practices for digital learning implementation.

column1: Avoiding Burnout While Changing the World
column5: Kasey Miller (National Association of Charter School Authorizers)
column6: In the world of education, we are all servant leaders constantly striving to improve the lives of our constituents. Most of us want to be doing this work for the long haul, but being an educator is tough work that can take its toll over time if you_re not putting the oxygen mask on yourself first. This highly interactive session will discuss why managing your energy _ not your time _ is key to developing resilience and will provide you with tools and techniques for upping your energy and avoiding burnout. You will walk away with a detailed plan for addressing your most pressing energy deficits!
column7: Explain why developing resilience is a critical factor being effective in your roles.
column8: Articulate the connection between energy management and resilience.
column9: Prioritize areas of attention and determine actions and/or behaviors to increase your resilience.

column1: Be the Agents of Transformation
column5: Kelly Young (Education Reimagined)
column6: We see a future in which the current school-centric education system has been transformed to a truly learner-centered one. It is a society of thriving learners, engaged parents, inspired educators, and empowered community members. Realizing this future will require the collaboration and design thinking of each education stakeholder. Join us to stretch your own design mindset, consider your commitment to learners, and explore the possibility of a transformed learner-centered education system.
column7: Grapple with your own underlying assumptions about education that impede what you can imagine and create.
column8: See new ways to approach systems-level change with a new, expanded mindset.
column9: Be empowered to explore how your own innovative work affects broader system redesign and to seek partners to transform the current education system.

column1: Because You Know It's All About Your Organization
column5: Johannes Flecker (Sound Leadership)
column6: Songwriting is a powerful tool for organizational and team development. It enables the expression of stories which are difficult to reveal otherwise. The participants create a song about a managerial challenge. The method is designed for business people, no music knowledge is required. The participants choose their individual song topic and create the title by using sense-bound writing. They fit their story into a verse-chorus form, they choose the fitting musical mood from a set of musical characteristics and write the chorus lyrics. Examples will be performed live by the moderator. Consequences for business team and organizational development will be discussed throughout.
column7: Express challenges: Participants have worked to describe and resolve specific management situations with the craft of songwriting and storytelling.
column8: Tell a story: Participants have learned to express challenging and complicated situations in a digestible, concise, memorable, meaningful way.
column9: Use creativity: Participants have experienced a method to use team creativity in a result-oriented, problem-solving and fun way.

column1: Becoming Maker Minded Leaders
column5: Eduardo Caballero (Edventure More), Sharon  Mor (Edventure More)
column6: We know that people who invest in personal growth are happier, more authentic, perform more effectively and stay in jobs longer. Our hands-on workshop will provide an opportunity for managers to develop techniques to increase their own work satisfaction while fostering employees' personal and professional growth. In this Maker Minded Leadership workshop, participants will see first hand how to create a space for staff to show up as their authentic selves, develop a can-do attitude, turn ideas into reality, iterate and improve, support co-workers, and build compassion, connection and community.  Managers will leave with experience and tools to take back to their workplace.
column7: Help managers to foster their staff's professional and personal growth, while simultaneously increasing their own job satisfaction.
column8: Discover how to get a more authentic "buy in" and investment from employees, resulting in a rewarding work environment and increased retention.
column9: Provide exercises and tools from the Maker Mindset that leaders can use to create a safe, supportive learning environment and foster self-expression.

column1: Belief Emebedded Professional Development
column5: Angela Tremble (University of San Diego), Diana Cornejo-Sanchez (University of San Diego)
column6: The _why I teach_ question is not just the social/emotional part of professional development, but it truly roots itself in pedagogy. Dr. Khader links beliefs to pedagogy as the driving force behind what happens in the classroom, _What teachers do in the classroom is said to be governed by what they believe, and these beliefs often serve to act as a filter through which instructional judgments and decisions are made_ (Pajares, 1992; Cantu, 2001). Therefore, as good practice, we must reflect on our beliefs, integrate them into professional learning, and find ways throughout the year to build upon them in order to create the best learning environments for our students and teachers.
column7: Reflect upon why we teach
column8: Connect beliefs and pedagogy
column9: Develop personalized professional development based off of teacher beliefs

column1: Design Thinking in K-12 Education
column5: Nick Resnick (California Education Partners)
column6: To empower students in the 21st century to participate, communicate and innovate, their teachers and administrators must engage in the same endeavor to transform their schools and districts. Through an overview of the design thinking process focusing primarily on the 3 stages of empathy (observation, immersion, engagement) and experiential learning, the participants will authentically engage with tools to incorporate design thinking into reconstructing mindset and implementation in their local context. The participants will experience the design thinking process through two hands-on activities that they will be able to replicate in their own contexts.
column7: Participants will utilize design thinking and the three stages of empathy to prototype solutions for a challenge.
column8: Participants will contextualize design thinking as a catalyst for systematic educational changes.
column9: Participants will be prepared to bring unique mindsets of design thinking to their own educational context with resources and a replicable workshop.

column1: Designing Personalized Professional Learning
column5: Rick Wilson (Folly Quarter Middle School, HCPSS), Julie Wray (Howard County Public Schools)
column6: Redesign your professional learning! Giving teachers personalized choices for professional learning increases buy-in, participation, and implementation of the learned strategies in their classrooms. Teachers who are genuinely engaged in their professional learning activities and see a direct connection to what they need to do to support student engagement and achievement are more likely to have highly effective and inspiring classrooms.  Providing professional learning choices represents an innovative world-class approach supporting each of our teacher_s professional growth and development.
column7: Session attendees will understand how our personalized professional learning model can enhance the professional learning culture of a school.
column8: Session attendees will understand how our personalized professional learning model can encourage continual personal growth and staff engagement.
column9: Session attendees will understand how our personalized professional learning model can improve student engagement to increase student learning.

column1: Embrace Uncertainty with Scenario Planning
column5: Jacquie  Furtado (Ashford University ), Heather Albin (Ashford University )
column6: Disruption and change are now a constant in the higher education landscape. Scenario based planning allows universities and partners to adapt quickly to external changes. In this workshop facilitators will provide an overview of the three phases of scenario based planning. Facilitators will then share the background and strategy of the University of the Future. Using this information each table will work through their assigned scenario to determine how the university's strategy should be adapted to react to the external change. The workshop will end with a discussion on when best to implement scenario planning and how to execute long term strategy.
column7: Develop an understanding of the benefits of scenario based planning.
column8: Sample tools used in a scenario based planning exercise and recognize how they can be applied.
column9: Learn how to design a scenario planning workshop.

column1: Empowering Girls to Design a Better Future
column5: Natalya Thakur (Girls Driving for a Difference), Rachel Chung (Girls Driving for a Difference), Katie Kirsch (Girls Driving for a Difference)
column6: Last summer, our team (Girls Driving for a Difference) spent 14 weeks crossing the U.S. in an RV, coaching leadership workshops for 1500+ middle school girls. Drawing inspiration from the Stanford d.school's design thinking methodology, we crafted our curriculum to empower girls to discover their abilities to create social change.Now we're ready to share our story and give educators the tools to spark this conversation with their own students. Our interactive session brings participants through our workshop, describes key insights behind it, and provides strategies for adapting our curriculum for other communities. Come join the journey and help our impact grow and live on!
column7: Create personal mission statements that incorporate participants' skills and leadership strengths to impact the future of education and beyond.
column8: Share our process and insights from designing and coaching summer workshops   for diverse communities of middle school girls nationwide.
column9: Guide participants to adapt our curriculum using design thinking principles in order to start this conversation in their own communities.

column1: Fighting to win: The power of advocacy
column5: Mattie  Weiss (Educators 4 Excellence), Konstantin Hatcher (Educators 4 Excellence)
column6: Everyday citizens such as principals, educators, and parents have more power than they realize. When you have an innovative idea, there are some simple steps that can lead to big change. At this interactive workshop, you will learn about a growing movement of teachers turned education advocates, and hear a case study about their work to improve and expand local educational programming to meet the social and emotional needs of their students. Participants will be invited to exercise the same basic steps into an advocacy plan of their own.
column7: Learn basic advocacy skills
column8: Build awareness for power structures in public education
column9: Better understand the dynamic role of teachers in public education today

column1: Ignite Your Passion - Be A Mentor, Get A Mentor
column5: Susan Bender Phelps (Odyssey Mentoring & Leadership)
column6: If you_ve ever had a boss or professor who was really good at what he or she did and they took you under their wing to help you grow and develop, you didn_t mind arriving early or working late. If you've been that mentor, then you've experienced, first hand, the rekindling of your passion for your work. In fact, you probably loved your job, advanced faster and earned more than your colleagues who didn't mentor. That_s the power of effective mentorship and leadership. Learn the dynamics of effective mentoring and mentoring programs that engage, empower and benefit both mentors and mentees.
column7: The Conversational Dance to Insight, Action & Accountability - Learn to produce actionable results in a 5 to 15-minute conversation.
column8: Mentoring, Coaching, Advising - What's the Difference & Why It Matters - Each is a powerful tool - Learn how to use them more effectively.
column9: Training & Support for Mentors & Mentees - They keys to successful programs - Learn the basic structures that ensure positive outcomes.

column1: Inspiring Action Through Storytelling
column5: Tyler Nakatsu (Getting Smart)
column6: Storytelling inspires action. From teachers looking for engagement strategies to EdTech startups sharing missions, storytelling is the connection of values. It_s the neuroscientific basis of community. Through our shared experiences, we connect across differences and build the courage and skills to take positive action. In the workshop, participants will build stories using the public narrative framework and practice telling their story in a podcast. The short podcasts will be uploaded and shared as we unpack our collective SXSWedu 2016 story and techniques to inspire action through our stories. The workshop will be recorded for a podcast for attendees and non-attendees.
column7: Participants will be able to craft a story using Marshall Ganz_s public narrative framework - Story of self, us, and now.
column8: Participants will learn the fundamentals of podcasting, including how to upload audio files to SoundCloud.
column9: Production a post-session resource -- a podcast that features the workshop's key takeaways and storytelling strategies.

column1: Leadership Essentials: Building Trust with Adults
column5: Kristin Anderson (Corwin)
column6: We know that healthy, respectful, and trusting teacher-student relationships nearly double the rate at which a student can learn. While not measured in the same fashion, building rapport and trust among adults has been proven to garner powerful results in businesses and schools/systems alike, and is an essential component in creating a culture of achievement. Using the latest research, this session will identify ways to propel your school, district, or organization towards success by improving your trust and communication skills with your colleagues, direct reports, and supervisors.
column7: Learn the most common breakdowns of the communication process and how to avoid them
column8: Understand the primary trust builders and trust barriers and discuss ways to improve our own practice in trust-building skills
column9: Identify ways to create a culture of achievement in your organization, rooted in open communication, feedback, and trust

column1: Partners in Code: Leading in a New Era of Learning
column5: Jason Swanson (KnowledgeWorks), Katherine Prince (KnowledgeWorks)
column6: Exponential advances in information and nano-technology are ushering in a new era of learning, living, and working. New partnerships with code that would have seemed like science fiction a few years ago are reshaping the social and economic realities that influence learning. This workshop will help leaders prepare for this emerging reality and consider how to foster vibrant, equitable learning ecosystems amid rapidly accelerating change. By examining drivers of change, questioning assumptions, and exploring possibilities for their own futures, participants will consider how to take advantage of the immense opportunities presented by the coming era of partners in code.
column7: Explore what education might look like in 2025
column8: Understand drivers of change shaping the economic and social contexts surrounding learning
column9: Examine possible strategies for leading learning amid accelerating change

column1: Professional Learning for Innovation and Change
column5: Rita S nchez (Teachers College, Columbia University), Ellen Meier (Teachers College, Columbia University)
column6: Our educational landscapes are changing. Learning is different, expectations are higher, and new technologies are emerging. Yet, schools need a bridge for systemic change. The Center for Technology and School Change, Teachers College, Columbia University has devised a catalytic model for transforming schools. This workshop will prepare educators to rethink professional learning for teachers, particularly as it relates to meaningful technology integration. Participants will design initiatives that build and sustain innovative approaches to instruction. Guiding questions: What does it mean to transform teaching and learning? What is educational innovation? How do we manage and support change?
column7: Participants will engage in substantive conversations about the changing educational landscape.
column8: Participants will experience hands-on, technology-infused approaches to professional learning as session facilitators model best practices.
column9: Participants will engage in designing a systemic initiative in response to a thoughtful case study using the design model developed by the Center.

column1: School Connectedness: Six Strategies for Impact
column5: Kevin Kerr (Austin ISD), Caroline  Chase (Austin ISD)
column6: When adults and / or students feel disconnected from their school, the feeling of safety is compromised and teaching and learning become very difficult. We_re going to learn about strategies to build school connectedness and how to involve staff in purposeful planning for connectedness that involves both adults and students. Teachers, administrators, other school staff and parents can all take part in implementing six strategies to increase school connectedness, which can enhance each of the four factors that influence school connectedness (adult support, belonging to a positive peer group, commitment to education, and a healthy school environment).
column7: Explore strategies to increase school connectedness with all stakeholders in their communities.
column8: Understand the importance of school connectedness and its relation to safety and learning.
column9: Create an action plan that will highlight what participants are doing to create school connectedness and new strategies that can be implemented.

column1: Student Leadership 2016: 7 High Impact Practices
column5: Jake Cohen (The Ohio State University), Matthew Van Jura (The Ohio State University)
column6: James MacGregor Burns describes "leadership" as the "most widely observed and least understood phenomenon on earth." Educators may agree that teaching students "leadership" is important - but can we define the properties of effective leadership, and structure learning experiences that develop all students into stronger leaders? This session will help attendees accomplish both these objectives.Presenters will share seven high impact practices from the Multi-Institutional Study of Leadership, and facilitate working groups that encourage attendees to consider how to apply these practices to programs or students they work with. Presenters will also share resources for assessing future work.
column7: Attendees will define "leadership" as a "values based, relational process of people coming together to attempt to accomplish positive social change."
column8: Attendees will relate high impact practices of student leadership (as outlined in the Multi-Institutional Study of Leadership) to their practice.
column9: Attendees will formulate strategies to apply high impact practices of student leadership development to their work, following the conclusion of SXSW.

column1: Ten FREE Tools for Principals
column5: David  Combs (Upper Canada District School Board), Steve McLean (Public Consulting Group)
column6: A humorous look at the Principalship and the associated trials and  tribulations that go along with the chair. In a collaborative working session,attendees will be introduced to ten tried and tested tools that can be adapted and implemented next day to make the work and efforts of the Principal more rewarding and effective. Attendees will take away all materials required for each of the ten tools along with exclusive access to a targeted Professional Learning Team that will provide support and mentoring in a safe and collegial atmosphere.
column7: Attendees will receive exposure to proven best practices on how to become a better, stronger Administrator on a daily basis.
column8: Attendees will get exclusive access to a targeted Professional Learning Team that can provide support and mentoring during the session and beyond.
column9: Attendees will walk away with 10 specific tools and the materials needed to implement these tools in their day to day work as an Administrator.

column1: The Educator's Role in Shaping Digital Culture
column5: Clara Alaniz (Plano ISD), Nancy Watson (Plano ISD)
column6: Who are today_s students? How can we as educators use our students_ connectedness to influence and shape how they handle positive and negative online experiences? The vast digital landscape includes helpful facts and false information, invigorating learning experiences and rancorous discourse, respectful relationships and cruel bullying. How do we help students positively impact this digital landscape? We will explore the ways that educators are uniquely positioned to influence and lead cultural change both in and out of the classroom. Learn new ideas, tips, and suggestions for shaping the digital culture.
column7: Discuss why and how educators can use their influence to be an agent for positive changes in the digital world.
column8: Analyze how literacy, citizenship, and cultural norms evolve, and articulate how those concepts contribute to our notion of culture.
column9: Design a personal digital leadership philosophy that includes goals for influencing digital culture.

column1: Use Storytelling to Inform & Empower Policymaking
column5: Jim Rickabaugh (Institute for Personalized Learning,  CESA#1), Gretchen Morgan (Colorado Department of Education)
column6: Across the country, communities and states are working to create next generation education systems that personalize learning experiences for students. States in the Innovation Lab Network take different policy pathways to personalized learning and competency-based education. This workshop explores the ways in which storytelling can inform and empower policymaking, and help others understand the impact of our policies on student learning.Leaders from Wisconsin and Colorado will facilitate an experiential workshop using video, interactive storytelling, and hands-on problem solving to guide participants through possible pathways to policy change.
column7: Participants will hear several stories of how states transformed systems to support personalized learning
column8: Participants will learn how to use storytelling to communicate the impact of policymaking on student learning
column9: Participants will learn how storytelling can empower others and inform policies that support personalized learning

column1: Building Blocks of Change: A Design Workshop
column5: Patricia Nobre (Gensler), David Stephen (New Vista ), David Schonthal (Northwestern University)
column6: Many innovations that shape our lives come from organizations that value experimentation and collaboration. This begins at the corporate ethos level and is reflected in and enhanced by workplace design. In education, we are beginning to see pedagogy approaches that foster these same values, but the design of learning environments has not kept pace. In this workshop we distill the essence of what makes these spaces successful and use this information to create a list of characteristics design strategies for the next generation of learning environments. But the real work happens afterwards: how can the lessons we uncover help us implement change when we return to our own organizations?
column7: Develop vocabulary for activity types that foster innovation within organizations; compare these values to traditional educational models.
column8: Using provided images of spaces & vocabulary from Part 1, participants will identify observed activities in the space that emulate innovative values.
column9: Group synthesis of Part 2 to develop meaningful next steps that participants can take back to organizations to catalyze and implement change.

column1: Facility Design Directly Impacts Academic Success
column5: Aaron Jobson (Quattrocchi Kwok Architects; Collaborative for High Performance Schools), Peter Barrett (University of Salford), Gina Silveira (Schaefer Charter School)
column6: The University of Salford in Manchester, UK, released results of a first-of-its-kind intensive study evaluating real-life K-6 classrooms, which revealed clear evidence that the physical characteristics of a classroom impacts learning progress by up to 16% variation. Hear from the lead researcher in his first U.S. talk on the conclusions of this study and specific recommendations to improve the classroom. Joined by a U.S.-based architect and an elementary school principal, the panel will discuss how to implement these improvements at various scales. Attendees will participate in an interactive Design Thinking exercise to explore the findings and apply solutions to improve any learning space.
column7: Understand how classroom design directly correlates the physical environment and academic performance through this comprehensive study.
column8: Learn about the classroom_s physical features proven to improve students_ academic performance.
column9: Take away practical ideas for educators and designers to apply these principles to their own spaces and building projects.

column1: Hacking Your PD
column5: Jill Galloway (Engage2Learn), Shannon Buerk (Engage2Learn)
column6: Opportunities for creativity deepen learning, and like kids, adults crave that, too.  Discover how to shift from the traditional _sit and get_ professional learning model into an interactive, collaborative and energizing experience using the best of hacker, maker and DIY spaces. While you explore each space, you will build a professional learning action plan proven to increase teacher engagement that will ultimately impact student learning.
column7: Understanding the difference of all three hacker, maker and DIY spaces and knowing how to apply each space effectively.
column8: Recognizing creativity and inquiry drives all learners, PD must model this learning experience we expect for our students.
column9: Having an action plan to shift the teacher learner experience from a lecture-style to an interactive, collaborative and energizing experience.

column1: Kids Learn to Code at a Pop-up CoderDojo Workshop
column5: Garima Singh (CoderDojo Round Rock)
column6: We propose running a live CoderDojo workshop at SXSWEdu. The session will be led by young people for young people! It will be a workshop for kids to learn their first lines of code.We will be inviting young people (7-17) from the schools in Austin to come to SXSWEdu where they experience a hands-on coding session in a fun, collaborative, high energy environment.The session will be led by Garima (17), the CoderDojo Round Rock champion, who runs her own CoderDojo every weekend! There will be support from the local CoderDojo community in Austin on the day.
column7: Coding is fun, easy and important for everyone to learn!
column8: Young people can be motivated to learn from their peers in a collaborative, fun and social environment.
column9: Hands-on, project based, peer to peer learning providing immediate gratification leads to greater confidence and eagerness to continue learning.

column1: STEAM Powered Parties: Host your own STEAM Nite
column5: Katie Byrd (The James Baldwin School for Expeditionary Learning), Jamie Munkatchy (The James Baldwin School)
column6: As steam builds for moving to a STEM framework in schools, so does the call for innovating student presentations of learning. Integrating the arts and switching up the spaces used for presentations of learning do double duty by popularizing the STEAM fields. Katie and Jamie will present the rationale for hosting STEAM Nites in schools, based on their experience of planning and hosting a community event in April 2015. Participants will engage in hands-on activities and create an action plan for their own STEAM powered parties. Takeaways will include a DYO bound notebook for notes and reflection and a digital storage space for archiving and continuing collaboration.
column7: I can describe how and why STEAM Nite reinvigorated The James Baldwin School.
column8: I can reflect on student presentations of learning.
column9: I can design an action plan for my school's own STEAM Nite.

column1: Supporting Learning in Youth Makerspaces
column5: Peter Wardrip (Children's Museum of Pittsburgh), Lisa Regalla (Maker Ed)
column6: What is it about spaces that enable making that also allows them to provide deep, rich experiences of learning? We will dive into an exploration of key considerations when creating or maintaining youth makerspaces (Purpose, People and Pieces & Parts) through a suite of tools and hands-on exploration. We_ll share powerful case studies of youth-based makerspaces around the country that illustrate empowering and energizing potentials and use them as a springboard to discuss specific tips, tools and strategies to get started, equip the space with both human and material capacity and sustain the space beyond initial funding.
column7: Gain a greater understanding of the purpose of a makerspace, including: goals, values, stakeholders, audience, and success metrics.
column8: Gain a greater understanding of the role of people in a makerspace, including: staffing structure, facilitation approaches, and staff capacity.
column9: Gain a greater understanding of the pieces and parts in a makerspace, including: tools, materials, physical architecture, and digital technology.

column1: The Small but Mighty School Starter Sit
column5: Ariel  Dochstader Miller (Skybridge Academy), Ali Ronder (Integrity Academy)
column6: Starting a school from scratch takes an entrepreneurial spirit, deep passion and infinite patience. This workshop will focus on sharing strategies in how to best approach starting a school and preparing yourself for the roller coaster ride that is the reality of running a school program. The workshop leaders are experienced school founders who have been in the realm of progressive education over 50 years cumulatively. They offer insights into for profit or non/profit for profit hybrids that are shifting the education start up realm from a poverty to abundance mentality. Attendees will leave with an understanding of the grit required to start a school and motivating strategies
column7: Let's get real: the life changing decision to start a school
column8: The parent, student, staff, administration feedback loop
column9: Money, money, money, non-profit, non-profit/for profit hybrid, or for profit model

column1: The Space: the Smartest Person in the Room
column5: Manuel  Herrera (Affton School District), Rebecca Hare (Pine Crest School, Ft. Lauderdale )
column6: Why? Today's classrooms are failing today_s students, and it will take all of the experts in the education community to create solutions. Create, make, and design with us as we build the learning spaces that kids deserve together, today using a unique design challenge format for this workshop.How? First, we must think beyond furniture and beyond walls. We have to break down the basic elements of a learning space and define how they support learning and student creation. Then we will work together to build our ideas and prototype new solutions for our students. Then, we will share and reflect on our ideas, insights and prototypes with our workshop and our global community.
column7: Participants will collaborate through a design challenge to craft even more meaningful learning spaces.
column8: Participants will create scale models, moodboards and video reflections to share with the global community.
column9: Participants will understand three key elements that affects human behavior and learning space design.

column1: Character Strengths and the Heart of Learning
column5: Lynn Ochs (Mayerson Academy), Jillian Darwish (Mayerson Academy)
column6: Teachers_ motivation and energy are amplified when they name and explore their unique constellation of character strengths and learn how they can best leverage those strengths in practice. In this Workshop participants will identify their unique Character Strengths using a free online tool. They will then learn how to spot strengths in others including colleagues, students and parents.  With this shifted perspective participants will maximize learning, collaboration and performance for all."The nature of relationships among the adults within a school has a greater influence on the character and quality of that school and on student accomplishment than anything else." Roland Barth
column7: Identify the unique set of character strengths that define each participant using the internationally acclaimed VIA Character survey, an online tool.
column8: Learn how to apply a character strengths approach in practice to improve learning, relating and performing.
column9: Learn how to identify character strengths in others and embed a common strengths-based language and approach with peers and students.

column1: Constructive Fidgeting for Self-Management
column5: Amber Adams (Sensory Nexus)
column6: The ability to both sense and manage one_s emotions is essential in order to focus, learn, and get along with others, but how do we learn to manage ourselves? And how can we teach these skills in a classroom?Research suggests that mind-body awareness is vital to learning self-management. This workshop explores the role of sensory/body awareness in learning self-regulation, and presents tools for teaching these skills in a classroom setting. Students learn to recognize and manage strong physical/emotional sensations, leaving more _bandwidth_ for challenging academic or social situations. Using small movements makes it accessible for children who struggle with stillness and attention.
column7: Understand how self-regulation of the nervous system works, and why sensation and movement are essential to the process.
column8: Gain an experiential understanding of how sensation & movement increases calm and focus, and prepares the nervous system for learning.
column9: Learn simple, short sensory tools to use in class to help yourself or your students improve calm, concentration and behavior.

column1: Leveraging data to promote students' mindsets
column5: Andrew Krumm (Center for Technology in Learning, SRI International), Rachel Beattie (The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching)
column6: A growth mindset, a strong sense of belonging, and a powerful purpose for learning all predict better educational outcomes _ yet, the important question is not WHAT is predictive, but HOW can we promote these mindsets to help our students succeed. Social-psychological interventions have been shown to lead to dramatic improvements in K-16 classrooms; however, context matters - failure to use the right intervention at the right time reduces its effectiveness. During this workshop, the presenters will give you the tools to contextualize these promising interventions and to use real-time data in order to determine when and how to act to effectively impact your students' mindsets.
column7: Participants will learn how to translate effective, brief, and inexpensive social-psychological interventions for their educational settings
column8: Participants will learn strategies and the process for collecting self-report and behavioral measures of noncognitive factors
column9: Participants will learn how to link social-psychological interventions with real time data on noncognitive factors

column1: Mindfulness: The Power of Pausing
column5: Erin Sharaf (Mindfulness + Magic)
column6: Mindfulness offers students and educators a way to increase creativity and resilience and reduce stress. It is an evidence-based practice which can enhance concentration and emotional regulation and promote positive emotions. With regular practice, this inner exploration can have dramatic results. Mindfulness is being embraced more widely as a crucial adjunct to traditional learning. This workshop will introduce basic mindfulness practices that enhance attention, concentration and communication and promote positive emotions.
column7: Attendees will develop an understanding of what mindfulness practice is and  explore how the practice can be useful both personally and professionally
column8: Participants will discover how the interplay of their thoughts, emotions and physical sensations impacts physiology and relationship to self & others.
column9: Attendees will directly examine how contemplative practice can enhance positive emotions, concentration and resiliency and reduce stress.

column1: Positive Prevention: A New Approach to Health Ed
column5: Amy Lauren Smith (Shanghai American School)
column6: The health concerns of our students have shifted dramatically over the last twenty years, and the past model of textbooks and scare tactics is obviously not working. It's time for a shift to a preventative, rather than reactionary, approach.In this workshop, participants will be guided through the process of creating a comprehensive skills-based health curriculum applicable for grades K-12 and aligned to the National Health Education Standards.Content areas covered will include: mindfulness, technology balance, puberty, current issues in sex ed, body image, nutrition for multicultural students, stress management, and social/emotional learning in the health class.
column7: What are the issues facing today's youth, and how can positive prevention reverse the growing trend of health concerns among them?
column8: Knowledge on current best practice in health education and tools to advocate for more comprehensive health education in schools and districts.
column9: Participants will leave with ready to use resources, projects and unit plans that are current, relevant, and adaptable to their student populations.

column1: Ready, S-E-T, Go: Building a Thriving SEL Culture
column5: Cheryl Hollis (WINGS for kids), Nicole Lovecchio (WINGS for kids)
column6: Research shows that social emotional learning (SEL) can help improve academics, attendance, and behavior in students.  Creating a culture where SEL can thrive requires teachers to have a deep understanding of SEL as well as being supportive, engaging, and thoughtful when interacting with students. Trainers from WINGS for Kids, the only education program focused solely on teaching SEL after school, will share SEL basics and help you become supportive, engaging, and thoughtful to get you started on developing an evidence-based SEL curriculum and supportive environment for your students.
column7: Have practitioners realize that strong SEL development in kids starts with strong SEL understanding by them
column8: Provide practitioners with concrete strategies to develop SEL skill development in their classroom and kids
column9: Provide practitioners with SEL resources to integrate into the classroom

column1: SEL: A Critical Partner to Rigorous Academics
column5: Hillary Johnson (Citizens of the World Charter Schools), Kriste Dragon (Citizens of the World Charter Schools)
column6: Social emotional learning is inextricably tied to academic skill and content mastery; you can't have one without the other. To ensure our students realize their full potential and become effective citizens, we need to teach students to be self-aware, to self-manage, to empathetically engage with and build meaningful connections with others who are different than them, and to value being part of a global community. Learn why Citizens of the World believes embedding social emotional learning within an academically rigorous, diverse classroom is necessary to ensuring our kids can be tomorrow_s leaders who can create a more compassionate and just world.
column7: Analyze the current definition of educational success and engage on why and how we expand that definition to ensure students reach their potential.
column8: Provide a window into how SEL can be embedded within an academic approach and implications for classroom and classroom and school practices.
column9: Provide a model of how a research-practice partnership plays a role in expanding our definitions.

column1: Transforming Education Through Creative Practices
column5: Sara LaHayne (Move This World)
column6: Through an experiential introduction to each module of the MTW Professional Development framework (self-exploration, community building, and curricular application), participants will gain an understanding of the theory and methodology behind Move This World's embodied approach to Social and Emotional Learning and walk away with tangible strategies to practice in their lives and work.
column7: Participants will learn Image Theatre techniques for exploring their own emotional intelligence.
column8: Participants will learn Move This World embodied exercises for establishing, building, and maintaining a safe space both physically and emotionally.
column9: Five MTW rituals for cultivating Social and Emotional Learning skills in youth that build sequentially from establishing a vocabulary of emotions.

column1: Autism:Social Inclusion through Robotic Workfellow
column5: Nikolaos Fachantidis (University of Macedonia)
column6: This workshop will discuss and design activities that exploit assistive robotics artifacts, regarding social inclusion for children with autism, in practice.  Assistive Robotics is a promising tool, contributing towards the establishment of socialization and the ability of children in the autism spectrum disorder to become autonomous inside and outside of the school context.   In order to get both theoretical and practical experience, attendees will organize activities aiming towards inclusion, based on the distinct steps of a method that has yield results at its pilot implementations.  A Europe wide awarded robot, in technology enhanced learning, will be used for those activities.
column7: Introduce robots used as work-fellows for educators / therapists in the area of autism, aiming towards social skills development
column8: Design and implement activities while exploiting robots for successful inclusion of the children in the autism spectrum disorder.
column9: Introduce a five step method for the gradual transition of children in the autism spectrum, from dyadic interaction to team work.
